个人知识

PERSONAL KNOWLEDGE

走向后批判哲学

Towards a Post-Critical Philosophy

经过

by

 

 

迈克尔·波兰尼

MICHAEL POLANYI

到

To

托马斯爵士和泰勒夫人

SIR THOMAS AND LADY TAYLOR

 

 

 

 

 

 

本文主要探讨的是科学知识的本质及其正当性。但我对科学知识的重新思考，却引出了科学之外的一系列广泛问题。我首先要摒弃科学超脱的理想。在精密科学领域，这种错误的理想或许无害，因为事实上，科学家们并不重视它。但我们将会看到，它在生物学、心理学和社会学中发挥着破坏性的影响，并歪曲了我们整个科学领域之外的视野。我想建立一种更为普遍的、另类的知识理想。

THIS is primarily an enquiry into the nature and justification of scientific knowledge. But my reconsideration of scientific knowledge leads on to a wide range of questions outside science. I start by rejecting the ideal of scientific detachment. In the exact sciences, this false ideal is perhaps harmless, for it is in fact disregarded there by scientists. But we shall see that it exercises a destructive influence in biology, psychology and sociology, and falsifies our whole outlook far beyond the domain of science. I want to establish an alternative ideal of knowledge, quite generally.

正因如此，本书的涵盖范围如此广泛，我才创造了一个新词——“个人知识”。这两个词看似矛盾：真正的知识被认为是非个人的、普遍确立的、客观的。但这种看似矛盾的矛盾可以通过修改“认知”的概念来解决。

Hence the wide scope of this book and hence also the coining of the new term I have used for my title: Personal Knowledge. The two words may seem to contradict each other: for true knowledge is deemed impersonal, universally established, objective. But the seeming contradiction is resolved by modifying the conception of knowing.

我以格式塔心理学的发现作为我进行这一概念改革的最初线索。科学家们已经回避了格式塔的哲学含义；而我则希望毫不妥协地支持它们。我认为认知是对已知事物的主动理解，这是一种需要技巧的行为。娴熟的认知和实践是通过将一系列细节（作为线索或工具）置于娴熟成就的塑造之下来实现的，无论是实践上的还是理论上的。然后，我们可以说，在我们对所实现的连贯实体的“焦点意识”中，对这些细节产生了“辅助性意识”。线索和工具是被使用的东西，而不是被观察到的。它们被设计成我们身体结构的延伸，这涉及到我们自身存在的某种改变。从这个意义上讲，理解行为是不可逆的，也是非批判性的。因为我们无法拥有任何固定的框架，以便在其中批判性地检验我们迄今为止固定框架的重塑。

I have used the findings of Gestalt psychology as my first clues to this conceptual reform. Scientists have run away from the philosophic implications of gestalt; I want to countenance them uncompromisingly. I regard knowing as an active comprehension of the things known, an action that requires skill. Skilful knowing and doing is performed by subordinating a set of particulars, as clues or tools, to the shaping of a skilful achievement, whether practical or theoretical. We may then be said to become Subsidiarily aware’ of these particulars within our ‘focal awareness’ of the coherent entity that we achieve. Clues and tools are things used as such and not observed in themselves. They are made to function as extensions of our bodily equipment and this involves a certain change of our own being. Acts of comprehension are to this extent irreversible, and also non-critical. For we cannot possess any fixed framework within which the re-shaping of our hitherto fixed framework could be critically tested.

这就是认知者在所有理解行为中的个人参与。但这并不意味着我们的理解是主观的。理解既不是任意的行为，也不是被动的体验，而是一种负责任的行为，具有普遍的有效性。这种认知在与隐藏的现实建立联系的意义上确实是客观的；这种联系被定义为预见一系列尚不清楚（或许是难以想象的）真实含义的条件。将这种个人与客观的融合描述为个人知识似乎是合理的。

Such is the personal participation of the knower in all acts of understanding. But this does not make our understanding subjective. Comprehension is neither an arbitrary act nor a passive experience, but a responsible act claiming universal validity. Such knowing is indeed objective in the sense of establishing contact with a hidden reality; a contact that is defined as the condition for anticipating an indeterminate range of yet unknown (and perhaps yet inconceivable) true implications. It seems reasonable to describe this fusion of the personal and the objective as Personal Knowledge.

个人知识是一种智力承诺，因此本身就具有风险。只有那些可能为假的断言，才可以说是传达了这种客观知识。本书中发表的所有断言均为我个人的承诺；它们仅以此为据，仅此而已。

Personal knowledge is an intellectual commitment, and as such inherently hazardous. Only affirmations that could be false can be said to convey objective knowledge of this kind. All affirmations published in this book are my own personal commitments; they claim this, and no more than this, for themselves.

我在本书中试图阐明这种情况。我指出，每一个认知行为都包含着认知者对认知内容的热情贡献，而这个系数并非仅仅是缺陷，而是他知识的重要组成部分。围绕这一核心事实，我试图构建一个相互关联的信念体系，我真诚地坚持它，并且我认为没有其他可接受的替代方案。但最终，正是我自己的忠诚支撑着这些信念，也正是基于这样的理由，它们才能吸引读者的注意。

Throughout this book I have tried to make this situation apparent. I have shown that into every act of knowing there enters a passionate contribution of the person knowing what is being known, and that this coefficient is no mere imperfection but a vital component of his knowledge. And around this central fact I have tried to construct a system of correlative beliefs which I can sincerely hold, and to which I can see no acceptable alternatives. But ultimately, it is my own allegiance that upholds these convictions, and it is on such warrant alone that they can lay claim to the reader’s attention.

曼彻斯特议员

Manchester M.P.

1957年8月

August 1957

 

 

致谢

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

 

 

本书基于我1951-1952年在阿伯丁大学发表的吉福德讲座。我感谢大学给予我这次发展思想的机会。由于后续工作并未从根本上改变我的观点，讲座的大部分内容得以保留；其他部分则经过重新考量，一些内容被删减，另一些内容则有所增补。

THIS book is based on my Gifford Lectures 1951–2, delivered in the University of Aberdeen. I wish to thank the University for this opportunity to develop my thoughts. Since subsequent work has not essentially changed my views, large parts of the lectures could be retained unchanged; other parts have been reconsidered, some cut out and others amplified.

曼彻斯特大学让我有机会接受阿伯丁大学的邀请，几乎用九年时间准备本书。学校参议院和理事会慷慨地允许我将物理化学系主任职位换成教授职位，而无需授课，这让我深感感激。我尤其要感谢时任校长约翰·S·斯托普福德爵士和时任理事会主席的威森肖勋爵西蒙。

Manchester University has made it possible for me to accept the invitation of Aberdeen and to spend nine years almost exclusively on the preparation of this book. The generosity of Senate and Council in allowing me to exchange my Chair of Physical Chemistry for a Professorial appointment without lecturing duties, has placed me deeply in their debt. I want to thank particularly Sir John S.B.Stopford, then Vice-Chancellor, and Lord Simon of Wythenshawe, then Chairman of the Council.

我在大学的许多同事都曾帮助我进行研究；我始终钦佩他们的耐心。在此，我要再次感谢他们。我怀着感激之情，回忆起曾两次在芝加哥社会思想委员会就这些主题发表演讲的几周时光。

Many of my colleagues at the University have helped me in my enquiries; I have never ceased to admire their patience. May I thank them here once more. I recall also with gratitude the weeks spent on two occasions with the Committee on Social Thought in Chicago, where I lectured on these subjects.

本书的完成很大程度上要归功于玛乔丽·格林博士。1950年我们在芝加哥第一次讨论这本书时，她似乎就猜到了我的全部意图，自此以后，她从未停止过对我的探索。多年来，她抛开自身哲学家的工作，全身心投入到本书的研究之中。我们的讨论催化了本书各个阶段的进展，几乎每一页都受益于她的批评。我在这里取得的任何成就都离不开她的贡献。J·霍尔德姆博士、欧文·克里斯托尔先生、伊丽莎白·塞维尔小姐和爱德华·希尔斯教授阅读了本书的全部手稿；W·哈斯先生、W·梅斯博士、MS·巴特利特教授和C·莱耶夫斯基博士阅读了部分内容。他们都提出了改进建议，对此我深表感谢。奥利弗·戴维斯小姐十年来一直负责本书的秘书工作。她的才华和辛勤付出给了我无价的帮助。此次调查的书籍、旅行和援助费用均由洛克菲勒基金会、沃尔克基金会和文化自由大会提供的资助支付。

This work owes much to Dr. Marjorie Grene. The moment we first talked about it in Chicago in 1950 she seemed to have guessed my whole purpose, and ever since she has never ceased to help its pursuit. Setting aside her own work as a philosopher, she has devoted herself for years to the service of the present enquiry. Our discussions have catalysed its progress at every stage and there is hardly a page that has not benefited from her criticism. She has a share in anything that I may have achieved here. Dr. J.H.Oldham, Mr. Irving Kristol, Miss Elizabeth Sewell and Professor Edward Shils have read the whole manuscript; Mr. W.Haas, Dr. W.Mays, Professor M.S.Bartlett and Dr. C.Lejewski have read parts of it. They have all suggested improvements, for which I thank them. Miss Olive Davies has carried the burden of secretarial work connected with this book for ten years. Her skill and hard work have given me invaluable assistance. Expenses of books, travel and assistance in the service of this enquiry were covered by grants received from the Rockefeller Foundation, the Volker Fund and the Congress for Cultural Freedom.

最后，我要表达对一个人的钦佩，她毫不犹豫地与我分享这项不寻常事业的风险，并年复一年地承受着我作为这项不寻常活动的中心所承受的压力；我指的是我的妻子。

Finally, I want to express my admiration for a person who unhesitatingly shared with me the risks of this unusual enterprise and sustained year after year the stresses radiating from me as the centre of this unaccustomed activity; I mean my wife.

我在1952年至1958年间发表了以下与本书主题相关的论文。括号中给出了本书的相应页码。

第一部分

PART ONE

认知的艺术

THE ART OF KNOWING

 

 

1

1

客观性

OBJECTIVITY

 

 

  1. 哥白尼革命的教训
  2. THE LESSON OF THE COPERNICAN REVOLUTION

在托勒密体系中，如同在《圣经》的宇宙起源论中一样，人类被赋予了宇宙的中心地位，但哥白尼却取代了人类。自此以后，渴望将这一教训深入人心的作家们便坚定地、反复地敦促我们摒弃一切感伤的利己主义，从真实的时空视角客观地看待自身。这究竟意味着什么？在一部忠实重现宇宙完整历史的“正片”电影中，人类从起源到二十世纪成就的崛起，不过是一瞬间的事。或者，如果我们决定客观地审视宇宙，对质量相等的部分给予同等的关注，那么我们终生都将专注于星际尘埃，只有在短暂的时间间隔里才会对炽热的氢物质进行观察——即便在数十亿年的生命中，人类也难以在转瞬之间注意到这一点。毋庸置疑，无论人们如何口头宣扬“客观性”，没有人——包括科学家——会以这种方式看待宇宙。这也不值得我们感到惊讶。因为，作为人类，我们必然会从自身内部的中心来看待宇宙，并用人类交流的迫切需求所塑造的人类语言来谈论它。任何试图将人类视角从我们的世界图景中严格剔除的尝试，都必然会导致荒谬。

IN the Ptolemaic system, as in the cosmogony of the Bible, man was assigned a central position in the universe, from which position he was ousted by Copernicus. Ever since, writers eager to drive the lesson home have urged us, resolutely and repeatedly, to abandon all sentimental egoism, and to see ourselves objectively in the true perspective of time and space. What precisely does this mean? In a full ‘main feature’ film, recapitulating faithfully the complete history of the universe, the rise of human beings from the first beginnings of man to the achievements of the twentieth century would flash by in a single second. Alternatively, if we decided to examine the universe objectively in the sense of paying equal attention to portions of equal mass, this would result in a lifelong preoccupation with interstellar dust, relieved only at brief intervals by a survey of incandescent masses of hydrogen—not in a thousand million lifetimes would the turn come to give man even a second’s notice. It goes without saying that no one—scientists included—looks at the universe this way, whatever lip-service is given to ‘objectivity’. Nor should this surprise us. For, as human beings, we must inevitably see the universe from a centre lying within ourselves and speak about it in terms of a human language shaped by the exigencies of human intercourse. Any attempt rigorously to eliminate our human perspective from our picture of the world must lead to absurdity.

哥白尼革命的真正教训是什么？哥白尼为何要用想象中的太阳视角取代他实际的地球观测站？唯一的解释是，他从太阳而非地球所见的星空全景中获得了更大的智识满足。哥白尼偏爱人类对抽象理论的乐趣，却以拒绝我们感官的证据为代价，这些证据向我们展现了太阳、月亮和星辰每天从东方升起，穿越天空，最终在西方落下这一不可抗拒的事实。因此，从字面意义上讲，新的哥白尼体系与托勒密的观点一样以人类为中心，区别仅在于它更倾向于满足人类不同的情感。

What is the true lesson of the Copernican revolution? Why did Copernicus exchange his actual terrestrial station for an imaginary solar standpoint? The only justification for this lay in the greater intellectual satisfaction he derived from the celestial panorama as seen from the sun instead of the earth. Copernicus gave preference to man’s delight in abstract theory, at the price of rejecting the evidence of our senses, which present us with the irresistible fact of the sun, the moon, and the stars rising daily in the east to travel across the sky towards their setting in the west. In a literal sense, therefore, the new Copernican system was as anthropocentric as the Ptolemaic view, the difference being merely that it preferred to satisfy a different human affection.

只有当我们接受这种知识满足感本质的转变作为更高客观性的标准时，才有理由认为哥白尼体系比托勒密体系更客观。这意味着，在两种知识形式中，我们应该认为那些更多地依赖于理论而非更直接的感官经验的知识更客观。这样，理论就像一道屏障，挡在我们的感官与那些我们原本可以通过感官获得更直接印象的事物之间，我们会越来越依赖理论指导来解释我们的经验，相应地，我们原始印象的地位也会降低到可疑的、甚至可能误导人的程度。

It becomes legitimate to regard the Copernican system as more objective than the Ptolemaic only if we accept this very shift in the nature of intellectual satisfaction as the criterion of greater objectivity. This would imply that, of two forms of knowledge, we should consider as more objective that which relies to a greater measure on theory rather than on more immediate sensory experience. So that, the theory being placed like a screen between our senses and the things of which our senses otherwise would have gained a more immediate impression, we would rely increasingly on theoretical guidance for the interpretation of our experience, and would correspondingly reduce the status of our raw impressions to that of dubious and possibly misleading appearances.

在我看来，我们有充分的理由认为理论知识比直接经验更客观。

It seems to me that we have sound reasons for thus considering theoretical knowledge as more objective than immediate experience.

（一个）理论是某种超越自我的东西。它可以作为一套规则体系写在纸上，它越能用规则体系完整地表达出来，就越能真正成为理论。数学理论在这方面达到了极致。但即使是一张地理地图，其本身也完全体现了一套严格的规则，用于在一片未知的经验领域中找到方向。事实上，所有理论都可以被视为一种延伸到时空的地图。地图显然可以正确也可以错误，因此，在我依赖地图的程度上，我会将由此犯下的任何错误归咎于地图。因此，我所依赖的理论是客观知识，因为当我运用这些知识时，被证明正确或错误的不是我，而是理论本身。

(a)A theory is something other than myself. It may be set out on paper as a system of rules, and it is the more truly a theory the more completely it can be put down in such terms. Mathematical theory reaches the highest perfection in this respect. But even a geographical map fully embodies in itself a set of strict rules for finding one’s way through a region of otherwise uncharted experience. Indeed, all theory may be regarded as a kind of map extended over space and time. It seems obvious that a map can be correct or mistaken, so that to the extent to which I have relied on my map I shall attribute to it any mistakes that I made by doing so. A theory on which I rely is therefore objective knowledge in so far as it is not I, but the theory, which is proved right or wrong when I use such knowledge.

（二）此外，理论不会被我个人的幻想所误导。为了通过地图找到方向，我必须有意识地阅读地图，而在这个过程中我可能会受到误导，但地图不会被误导，它本身就是对或错，不受个人影响。因此，我所依赖的理论作为我知识的一部分，不会受到我内心波动的影响。它拥有一个严谨的形式结构，无论我心情如何，愿望如何，我都可以依靠它的坚定性。

(b)A theory, moreover, cannot be led astray by my personal illusions. To find my way by a map I must perform the conscious act of map reading and I may be deluded in the process, but the map cannot be deluded and remains right or wrong in itself, impersonally. Consequently, a theory on which I rely as part of my knowledge remains unaffected by any fluctuations occurring within myself. It has a rigid formal structure, on whose steadfastness I can depend whatever mood or desire may possess me.

（三）由于理论的正式论断不受接受者状态的影响，因此理论的构建可以不受个人通常的经验方法的影响。这也是为什么哥白尼体系比托勒密体系更具理论性，也更客观的第三个原因。由于其对太阳系的描述忽略了我们地球的位置，因此它同样适用于地球、火星、金星或海王星上的居民，只要他们与我们拥有相同的知识价值观。

(c)Since the formal affirmations of a theory are unaffected by the state of the person accepting it, theories may be constructed without regard to one’s normal approach to experience. This is a third reason why the Copernican system, being more theoretical than the Ptolemaic, is also more objective. Since its picture of the solar system disregards our terrestrial location, it equally commends itself to the inhabitants of Earth, Mars, Venus, or Neptune, provided they share our intellectual values.

因此，当我们宣称哥白尼理论具有更高的客观性时，我们实际上暗示了它的卓越性并非我们个人品味的问题，而是一种值得理性生物普遍接受的内在品质。我们摒弃了感官层面较为粗暴的人类中心主义——但这只是为了支持理性层面更为雄心勃勃的人类中心主义。如此一来，我们便宣称有能力构建出一些理念，这些理念本身就因其合理性而备受尊重，并在此意义上拥有客观的地位。

Thus, when we claim greater objectivity for the Copernican theory, we do imply that its excellence is, not a matter of personal taste on our part, but an inherent quality deserving universal acceptance by rational creatures. We abandon the cruder anthropocentrism of our senses—but only in favour of a more ambitious anthropocentrism of our reason. In doing so, we claim the capacity to formulate ideas which command respect in their own right, by their very rationality, and which have in this sense an objective standing.

事实上，行星绕太阳运行的理论本身就足以说明问题，其意义远超其本身所宣称的合理性。它启发了开普勒（在哥白尼逝世六十六年后）发现行星的椭圆轨道及其恒定的表面角速度；十年后，又启发他发现行星运动第三定律，将轨道距离与轨道周期联系起来。又过了六十八年，牛顿向世人宣布，这些定律不过是普遍引力这一基本事实的一种表达。日心说体系最初为人们带来的知识满足，以及它为人们所接受，被证明是其创始人所未知的更深层意义的象征。未知但并非完全没有被怀疑；因为那些早期全心全意信奉哥白尼体系的人，因此对未来无限范围的可能证实该理论抱有期待，而这种期待对于他们相信该体系的优越合理性和客观有效性至关重要。

Actually, the theory that the planets move round the sun was to speak for itself in a fashion that went far beyond asserting its own inherent rationality. It was to speak to Kepler (sixty-six years after the death of Copernicus) and inspire his discovery of the elliptic path of planets and of their constant angular surface velocity; and to inspire again, ten years later, his discovery of the Third Law of planetary motion, relating orbital distances to orbital periods. And another sixty-eight years later, Newton was to announce to the-world that these laws were but an expression of the underlying fact of general gravitation. The intellectual satisfaction which the heliocentric system originally provided, and which gained acceptance for it, proved to be the token of a deeper significance unknown to its originator. Unknown but not entirely unsuspected; for those who whole-heartedly embraced the Copernican system at an early stage committed themselves thereby to the expectation of an indefinite range of possible future confirmations of the theory, and this expectation was essential to their belief in the superior rationality and objective validity of the system.

事实上，人们可以普遍地说，我们推崇的理论本身合理，也就意味着它具有预言的力量。我们接受它，是希望它与现实相联系；这样，我们的理论就有可能在未来的几个世纪中以其创立者未曾想象的方式展现其真理性。我们这个时代一些最伟大的科学发现，被恰当地描述为对公认科学理论的惊人证实。其真实含义的这种完全不确定的范围，蕴含着科学理论客观性的最深层意义。

One may say, indeed, quite generally, that a theory which we acclaim as rational in itself is thereby accredited with prophetic powers. We accept it in the hope of making contact with reality; so that, being really true, our theory may yet show forth its truth through future centuries in ways undreamed of by its authors. Some of the greatest scientific discoveries of our age have been rightly described as the amazing confirmations of accepted scientific theories. In this wholly indeterminate scope of its true implications lies the deepest sense in which objectivity is attributed to a scientific theory.

这就是哥白尼理论所体现的客观性的真正特征。客观性并不要求我们以人类微小的体型、短暂的过往或未来可能的职业来衡量人类在宇宙中的重要性。它也不要求我们将自己视为百万撒哈拉沙漠中的一粒沙。相反，它激励我们克服肉体存在的巨大缺陷，甚至构想出一个能够权威地解释宇宙的理性观念。它并非一种自我贬低的劝告，而是恰恰相反——是对人类心灵中皮格马利翁的呼唤。

Here, then, are the true characteristics of objectivity as exemplified by the Copernican theory. Objectivity does not demand that we estimate man’s significance in the universe by the minute size of his body, by the brevity of his past history or his probable future career. It does not require that we see ourselves as a mere grain of sand in a million Saharas. It inspires us, on the contrary, with the hope of overcoming the appalling disabilities of our bodily existence, even to the point of conceiving a rational idea of the universe which can authoritatively speak for itself. It is not a counsel of self-effacement, but the very reverse—a call to the Pygmalion in the mind of man.

然而，这并非我们今天所学。有人认为，科学中客观真理的发现在于理解一种值得我们尊重并引发我们沉思的钦佩的合理性；这种发现虽然以感官体验为线索，但通过拥抱超越感官印象的现实视野，超越了这种经验，这种视野不言而喻，引导我们对现实获得更深刻的理解——这种对科学程序的描述通常会被人们视为过时的柏拉图主义：一种与启蒙时代格格不入的神秘主义。然而，我正是想在本导言中坚持这种客观性的概念。我想回顾一下科学理论在现代人心目中是如何沦为一种方便的装置、一种记录事件和计算其未来进程的手段的，我想指出的是，二十世纪的物理学，特别是爱因斯坦的相对论的发现，通常被认为是这种实证主义科学观念的成果和例证，相反，它证明了科学通过认识自然界的合理性来与自然界的现实联系起来的力量。

This is not, however, what we are taught today. To say that the discovery of objective truth in science consists in the apprehension of a rationality which commands our respect and arouses our contemplative admiration; that such discovery, while using the experience of our senses as clues, transcends this experience by embracing the vision of a reality beyond the impressions of our senses, a vision which speaks for itself in guiding us to an ever deeper understanding of reality—such an account of scientific procedure would be generally shrugged aside as out-dated Platonism: a piece of mystery-mongering unworthy of an enlightened age. Yet it is precisely on this conception of objectivity that I wish to insist in this introductory chapter. I want to recall how scientific theory came to be reduced in the modern mind to the rank of a convenient contrivance, a device for recording events and computing their future course, and I wish to suggest then that twentieth-century physics, and Einstein’s discovery of relativity in particular, which are usually regarded as the fruits and illustrations of this positivistic conception of science, demonstrate on the contrary the power of science to make contact with reality in nature by recognizing what is rational in nature.

 

 

  1. 机制的成长
  2. THE GROWTH OF MECHANISM

故事分为三个部分，第一部分开始于哥白尼之前很久，尽管它直接引向哥白尼。故事从毕达哥拉斯说起，他比苏格拉底早一个世纪。即便如此，毕达哥拉斯在科学上还是个后来者，因为科学运动几乎是在泰勒斯的爱奥尼亚学派之前一代人以相当不同的方式开启的。毕达哥拉斯和他的追随者不像爱奥尼亚人那样试图用某些物质元素（火、空气、水等）来描述宇宙，而是只用数字来解释它。他们认为数字是事物和过程的最终实质和形式。当敲响一个八度音程时，他们相信他们可以在两根长度比为 1:2 的金属丝发出的和谐鸣响中听到 1:2 的简单数值比。声学使他们能够听到简单的数值关系的完美。他们把目光转向天空，看到了太阳和月亮的完美圆圈；他们观察苍穹的昼夜自转，研究行星，发现它们受复杂而稳定的圆周运动系统支配；他们以聆听纯粹音程的方式领悟天体的完美。他们以一种神秘的交流状态聆听着天体的音乐。

The story is in three parts, of which the first begins long before Copernicus, though it leads straight up to him. It starts with Pythagoras, who lived a century before Socrates. Even so, Pythagoras was a late- comer in science, for the scientific movement was started almost a generation earlier on rather different lines by the Ionian school of Thales. Pythagoras and his followers did not, like the Ionians, try to describe the universe in terms of certain material elements (fire, air, water, etc.) but interpreted it exclusively in terms of numbers. They took numbers to be the ultimate substance, as well as the form, of things and processes. When sounding an octave they believed they could hear the simple numerical ratio of 1:2 in the harmonious chiming of the sounds from two wires whose lengths had the ratio 1:2. Acoustics made the perfection of simple numerical relations audible to their ear. They turned their eyes towards the heavens and saw the perfect circle of the sun and moon; they watched the diurnal rotation of the firmament and, studying the planets, saw them governed by a complex system of steady circular motions; and they apprehended these celestial perfections in the way one listens to a pure musical interval. They listened to the music of the spheres in a state of mystic communion.

哥白尼在两千年后复兴天文学理论，是他有意识地回归毕达哥拉斯学派的传统。在博洛尼亚学习法律期间，他曾与天文学教授诺瓦拉共事。诺瓦拉是一位重要的柏拉图主义者，主张宇宙可以用简单的数学关系来理解。后来，他回到克拉科夫，心中怀揣着日心说的思想，进一步研究了哲学家，并将他的新宇宙观追溯到秉承毕达哥拉斯学派传统的古代作家。

The revival of astronomical theory by Copernicus after two millennia was a conscious return to the Pythagorean tradition. While studying law in Bologna, he worked with the professor of astronomy, Novara, a leading Platonist, who taught that the universe was to be conceived in terms of simple mathematical relationships. Then, on his return to Cracow, with the thought of a heliocentric system in his mind, he made a further study of the philosophers and traced his new conception of the universe back to writers of antiquity standing in the Pythagorean tradition.

继哥白尼之后，开普勒全心全意地延续了毕达哥拉斯对和谐数与几何之美的追求。在包含其第三定律第一条陈述的卷册中，我们可以看到他深入思考太阳——宇宙的中心，因此也因此某种程度上是理性（ nous ）本身——如何理解行星演奏的天体乐章：“太阳拥有什么样的视野，它的眼睛是什么，或者它拥有什么其他的动力……即使没有眼睛……来判断（天体）运动的和谐”，对于居住在地球上的人来说，这“难以推测” ——然而，人们至少可以梦想，“被行星带不断变化的和谐所催眠”，“在太阳中栖息着一种简单的智慧，智慧之火或心灵，无论它是什么，都是一切和谐的源泉”。 1他甚至用乐谱写下了每颗行星的曲调。

After Copernicus, Kepler continued wholeheartedly the Pythagorean quest for harmonious numbers and geometrical excellence. In the volume containing the first statement of his Third Law, we can see him speculating intensely on the way the sun, which is the centre of the cosmos and there-fore somehow nous (Reason) itself, apprehends the celestial music performed by the planets: ‘Of what sort vision is in the sun, what are its eyes, or what other impulse it has…even without eyes…for judging the harmonies of the (celestial) motions,’ it would be ‘for those inhabiting the earth; not easy to conjecture’—yet one may at least dream, ‘lulled by the changing harmony of the band of planets’, that ‘in the sun there dwells an intellect simple, intellectual fire or mind, whatever it may be, the fountain of all harmony’.1 He even went so far as to write down the tune of each planet in musical notation.

对于开普勒来说，天文发现是一种狂喜的交流，正如他在同一部作品的著名段落中所说的那样：等待六千年才有一个人来思考他的工作。2

To Kepler astronomic discovery was ecstatic communion, as he voiced it in a famous passage of the same work: waited six thousand years for a man to contemplate His work.2

开普勒在这里所宣称的关于柏拉图物体的说法是无稽之谈，他关于上帝等待他数千年的感叹只是一种文学幻想；然而，他的爆发传达了对科学方法和科学本质的真实想法；这个想法后来被人们持续不断地试图按照错误的客观性理想重塑的想法所扭曲。

What Kepler claimed here about the Platonic bodies was nonsense, and his exclamation about God’s having waited for him for thousands of years was a literary fancy; yet his outburst conveys a true idea of the scientific method and of the nature of science; an idea which has since been disfigured by the sustained attempt to remodel it in the likeness of a mistaken ideal of objectivity.

从开普勒到伽利略，我们见证了向动力学的转变，数字首次作为被测量的量进入数学公式。但伽利略的这种用法仅适用于地球上的事件，而对于天体运动，他仍然秉持毕达哥拉斯的观点，认为自然之书是用几何符号书写的。3在《两大世界体系》（1632 年）中，他根据毕达哥拉斯学派的传统，从世界各部分都井然有序的原理出发进行论证。4他仍然相信天体的运动。

Passing from Kepler to Galileo, we see the transition to a dynamics in which for the first time numbers enter as measured quantities into mathematical formulae. But with Galileo this usage applies only to terrestrial events, while in respect to heavenly motions he still holds the Pythagorean view that the book of nature is written in geometrical characters.3 In the Two Great Systems of the World (1632), he argues in the Pythagorean tradition from the principle that the parts of the world are perfectly ordered.4 He still believes that the motion of the heavenly bodies.

二十二年前，当我在天体轨道中发现五种立体时，我就预言了这一点；早在我读到托勒密的《和声学》之前，我就坚信这一点；在我确信我的发现之前，我就在这第五本书的书名中向我的朋友们承诺了这一点；十六年前，我极力主张去寻找这一点；为此，我把我一生中最好的部分奉献给了天文学思考，为此，我加入了第谷·布拉赫的行列……最后，我终于把它揭示出来，并认识到它的真实性，这超出了我的所有希望……所以现在，自从十八个月前的黎明，三个月前的白昼，以及几天前，最奇妙的沉思的纯净太阳本身已经照耀出来——没有什么能阻挡我；我将放纵我神圣的愤怒；我要坦白地向人类忏悔，我偷了埃及人的金瓶，为我的上帝建造圣殿，远离埃及的疆界。如果你们原谅我，我将欣喜；如果你们愤怒，我将承受；木已成舟，书已成书，我不在乎现在读还是留给后人；即使上帝亲自阅读，它也可能要等一百年才能读到——事实上，所有自然运动本身——都必须是圆周运动。直线运动意味着位置的变化，而这只能从无序到有序：也就是说，要么从原始混沌过渡到世界各部分正确排列的状态，要么在剧烈运动中，即一个被人为移动的物体试图回到其“自然”位置。一旦世界秩序建立，所有物体都会“自然地”处于静止状态或圆周运动中。伽利略观察到的沿地球平面的惯性运动，被他解读为绕地心的圆周运动。因此，哥白尼死后的第一个世纪受到了毕达哥拉斯学派的启发。这些学派最后的伟大体现或许是笛卡尔的普适数学：他希望通过理解清晰、明确且必然正确的观念来建立科学理论。

What I prophesied two-and-twenty years ago, as soon as I discovered the five solids among the heavenly orbits—what I firmly believed long before 1 had seen Ptolemy’s Harmonics—what I had promised my friends in the title of this fifth book, which I named before I was sure of my discovery— what sixteen years ago I urged to be sought—that for which I have devoted the best part of my life to astronomical contemplations, for which I joined Tycho Brahe…at last I have brought it to light, and recognized its truth beyond all my hopes…. So now since eighteen months ago the dawn, three months ago the proper light of day, and indeed a very few days ago the pure Sun itself of the most marvellous contemplation has shone forth—nothing holds me; I will indulge my sacred fury; I will taunt mankind with the candid confession that I have stolen the golden vases of the Egyptians, in order to build of them a tabernacle to my God, far indeed from the bounds of Egypt. If you forgive me, 1 shall rejoice; if you are angry, I shall bear it; the die is cast, the book is written, whether to be read now or by posterity I care not; it may wait a hundred years for its reader, if God himself has—in fact all natural motion as such—must be circular. Rectilinear motion implies change of place, and this can occur only from disorder to order: that is, either in the transition from primeval chaos to the right disposition of the parts of the world, or in violent motion, i.e. in the endeavour of a body artificially moved to return to its ‘natural’ place. Once world order is established, all bodies are ‘naturally’ at rest or in circular motion. Galileo’s observations of inertial motion along a plane terrestrial surface were interpreted by him as circular motions around the centre of the earth. Thus the first century after the death of Copernicus was inspired by Pythagorean intimations. Their last great manifestation was perhaps Descartes’s universal mathematics: his hope of establishing scientific theories by the apprehension of clear and distinct ideas, which as such were necessarily true.

但另一种不同的研究思路已逐渐兴起，它源于希腊思想的另一派，这种思想缺乏毕达哥拉斯的神秘主义，记录了对各种事物的观察，无论这些事物多么不完美。这一学派源自爱奥尼亚哲学家，最终发展到苏格拉底的同时代人德谟克利特，他首次教导人们以唯物主义的视角思考。他提出了这样的原则：“按照惯例，物质是有色的，按照惯例是甜的，按照惯例是苦的；而现实中，物质只有原子和虚空。”5伽利略本人也认同这一点；事物的机械属性才是主要的（借用洛克的术语），其他属性则是衍生的，或次要的。最终，事实证明，通过将牛顿力学应用于物质运动，这种宇宙的主要属性可以被理性控制，而其次要属性则可以从这种潜在的主要现实中推导出来。由此，机械论的世界观应运而生，并一直延续到上个世纪末。这也是一种理论化的客观观点，因为它用一种正式的时空图取代了我们感官的证据，这种时空图预测了物质粒子的运动，而物质粒子的运动被认为是所有外部经验的基础。从这个意义上讲，机械论的世界观是完全客观的。然而，从毕达哥拉斯学派到爱奥尼亚学派的理论知识观念，确实发生了变化。数字和几何形状不再被认为是自然固有的。理论不再揭示完美；它不再思考创造的和谐。在牛顿力学中，支配宇宙力学基础的公式是微分方程，不包含数值规则，也不表现出几何对称性。从此以后，“纯”数学，曾经是解开自然奥秘的钥匙，与数学在经验定律的表述中的应用严格分离。几何学成为研究虚空空间的科学；而分析，自此以后与之相关

But a different line of approach was already advancing gradually, stemming from the other line of Greek thought which lacked the mysticism of Pythagoras, and which recorded observations of all kinds of things, however imperfect. This school, derived from the Ionian philosophers, culminated in Democritus, a contemporary of Socrates, who first taught men to think in materialistic terms. He laid down the principle: ‘By convention coloured, by convention sweet, by convention bitter; in reality only atoms and the void.’5 With this Galileo himself agreed; the mechanical properties of things alone were primary (to borrow Locke’s terminology), their other properties were derivative, or secondary. Eventually it was to appear that the primary qualities of such a universe could be brought under intellectual control by applying Newtonian mechanics to the motions of matter, while its secondary qualities could be derived from this underlying primary reality. Thus emerged the mechanistic conception of the world which prevailed virtually unchanged till the end of the last century. This too was a theoretical and objective view, in the sense of replacing the evidence of our senses by a formal space-time map that predicted the motions of the material particles which were supposed to underlie all external experience. In this sense the mechanistic world-view was fully objective. Yet there is a definite change from the Pythagorean to the Ionian conception of theoretical knowledge. Numbers and geometrical forms are no longer assumed to be inherent as such in Nature. Theory no longer reveals perfection; it no longer contemplates the harmonies of Creation. In Newtonian mechanics the formulae governing the mechanical substratum of the universe were differential equations, containing no numerical rules and exhibiting no geometrical symmetry. Henceforth ‘pure’ mathematics, formerly the key to nature’s mysteries, became strictly separated from the application of mathematics to the formulation of empirical laws. Geometry became the science of empty space; and analysis, affiliated since

笛卡尔转向几何学，将其与几何学一起，融入了超越经验的领域。数学代表了所有看似必然正确的理性思维；而现实则被概括为被视为偶然事件的世界事件——也就是说，仅仅是碰巧发生的事情。

Descartes to geometry, seceded with it into the region beyond experience. Mathematics represented all rational thinking which appeared necessarily true; while reality was summed up in the events of the world which were seen as contingent—that is, merely such as happened to be the case.

非欧几何的发现进一步加剧了理性与经验的分离。此后，数学被否认有能力表述任何超出在传统符号框架内表述的重言式集之外的内容。相应地，物理理论的地位也进一步下降。十九世纪末，一种新的实证主义哲学兴起，它否认科学物理学理论具有任何内在合理性，并将这种合理性斥为形而上学和神秘主义。这一思想最早、最具活力和影响力的发展归功于恩斯特·马赫，他于1883年出版的《机械论》一书创立了维也纳实证主义学派。在马赫看来，科学理论仅仅是对经验的一种便捷总结。其目的是节省记录观察的时间和精力。它是思想对事实最经济的适应，并且就像地图、时间表或电话簿一样，外在于事实；事实上，这种科学理论的概念将包括科学理论的时间表或电话簿。

The separation of reason and experience was pressed further by the discovery of non-Euclidean geometry. Mathematics was thereafter denied the capacity of stating anything beyond sets of tautologies formulated within a conventional framework of notations. Physical theories were correspondingly also subjected to a further reduction of status. Towards the end of the nineteenth century a new positivist philosophy arose, denying to the scientific theories of physics any claim to inherent rationality, a claim which it condemned as metaphysical and mystical. The earliest, most energetic and influential development of this idea was due to Ernst Mach, who by his book, Die Mechanik, published in 1883, founded the Vienna school of positivism. Scientific theory, according to Mach, is merely a convenient summary of experience. Its purpose is to save time and trouble in recording observations. It is the most economical adaptation of thought to facts, and just as external to the facts as a map, a timetable, or a telephone directory; indeed, this conception of scientific theory would include a timetable or a telephone directory among scientific theories.

因此，科学理论被剥夺了其本身固有的说服力。它绝不能超越经验，断言任何无法通过经验检验的事物；最重要的是，科学家必须做好准备，一旦出现与其相冲突的观察结果，就立即放弃该理论。如果一个理论无法通过经验检验——或者看起来无法通过经验检验——就应该对其进行修正，使其预测仅限于可观测的量级。

Accordingly, scientific theory is denied all persuasive power that is intrinsic to itself, as theory. It must not go beyond experience by affirming anything that cannot be tested by experience; and above all, scientists must be prepared immediately to drop a theory the moment an observation turns up which conflicts with it. In so far as a theory cannot be tested by experience—or appears not capable of being so tested—it ought to be revised so that its predictions are restricted to observable magnitudes.

这种观点可以追溯到洛克和休谟，其巨大的现代荒谬性几乎完全主导了20世纪的科学思想，似乎是将数学知识与经验知识原则性分离的必然结果。现在我将讨论相对论的故事，它被认为出色地证实了这种科学观点，并将说明为什么在我看来，它反而提供了一些令人信服的证据来反驳它。

This view, which can be traced back to Locke and Hume, and which in its massive modern absurdity has almost entirely dominated twentieth- century thinking on science, seems to be the inevitable consequence of separating, in principle, mathematical knowledge from empirical knowledge. I shall now proceed to the story of relativity, which is supposed to have brilliantly confirmed this view of science, and shall show why in my opinion it has supplied on the contrary some striking evidence for its refutation.

 

 

 

 

  1. 相对论
  2. RELATIVITY

相对论的故事错综复杂，这归因于许多历史虚构的盛行。其中最主要的虚构在每一本物理教科书中都能找到。教科书告诉我们，相对论是由爱因斯坦于1905年提出的，目的是解释18年前，即1887年在克利夫兰进行的迈克尔逊-莫雷实验的否定结果。据称，迈克尔逊和莫雷发现，无论信号朝哪个方向发出，地面观测者测得的光速都是相同的。这令人惊讶，因为人们通常认为，观测者会在某种程度上追上沿地球运动方向发出的信号，因此在这个方向上速度会显得更慢；而观测者会远离沿相反方向发出的信号，因此速度会显得更快。如果我们想象一种极端情况，即我们正以光速沿着信号方向运动，这种情况就很容易理解了。光似乎停留在一个固定的位置，其速度为零，而与此同时，从相反方向发出的信号将以两倍光速远离我们。

The story of relativity is a complicated one, owing to the currency of a number of historical fictions. The chief of these can be found in every textbook of physics. It tells you that relativity was conceived by Einstein in 1905 in order to account for the negative result of the Michelson- Morley experiment, carried out in Cleveland eighteen years earlier, in 1887. Michelson and Morley are alleged to have found that the speed of light measured by a terrestrial observer was the same in whatever direction the signal was sent out. That was surprising, for one would have expected that the observer would catch up to some extent with signals sent out in the direction in which the earth was moving, so that the speed would appear slower in this direction, while the observer would move away from the signal sent out in the opposite direction, so that the speed would then appear faster. The situation is easily understood if we imagine the extreme case that we are moving in the direction of the signal exactly at the speed of light. Light would appear to remain in a fixed position, its speed being zero, while of course at the same time a signal sent out in the opposite direction would move away from us at twice the speed of light.

实验据推测并未显示出地球运动导致这种效应的任何迹象，因此——教科书上继续写道——爱因斯坦试图用一种新的时空概念来解释这一现象。根据这一概念，无论我们处于静止还是运动状态，我们都可以预期观察到的光速值始终相同。因此，牛顿空间（即“必然处于静止状态，不受任何外部物体影响”）以及相应的绝对运动物体和绝对静止物体之间的区别被抛弃，取而代之的是一个只能表达物体相对运动的框架。

The experiment is supposed to have shown no trace of such an effect due to terrestrial motion, and so—the textbook story goes on—Einstein undertook to account for this by a new conception of space and time, according to which we could expect invariably to observe the same value for the speed of light, whether we are at rest or in motion. So Newtonian space, which is ‘necessarily at rest without reference to any external object’, and the corresponding distinction between bodies in absolute motion and bodies at absolute rest, were abandoned and a framework set up in which only the relative motion of bodies could be expressed.

但历史事实并非如此。爱因斯坦在十六岁时还是个学生时就曾设想，如果一个观察者追赶并保持他发出的光信号，将会产生哪些奇妙的后果。他的自传表明，他经过十年的思考发现了相对论……而这个发现源于一个我十六岁时就遇到的悖论：如果我追赶一束速度为c （真空中的光速）的光，我应该会观察到这束光是一个静止的空间振荡电磁场。然而，无论是根据经验还是根据麦克斯韦方程组，似乎都不存在这样的事。从一开始，我就直观地明白，从这样一个观察者的角度来看，一切都必须按照与相对于地球静止的观察者相同的定律发生。6

But the historical facts are different. Einstein had speculated already as a schoolboy, at the age of sixteen, on the curious consequences that would occur if an observer pursued and kept pace with a light signal sent out by him. His autobiography reveals that he discovered relativity after ten years’ reflection…from a paradox upon which I had already hit at the age of sixteen: If 1 pursue a beam of light with the velocity c (velocity of light in a vacuum), 1 should observe such a beam of light as a spatially oscillatory electromagnetic field at rest. However, there seems to be no such thing, whether on the basis of experience or according to Maxwell’s equations. From the very beginning it appeared to me intuitively clear that, judged from the standpoint of such an observer, everything would have to happen according to the same laws as for an observer who, relative to the earth, was at rest.6

这里没有提到迈克尔逊-莫雷实验。该实验的发现完全是爱因斯坦基于纯粹的推测，在听说之前就凭直觉得出的。为了证实这一点，我咨询了已故的爱因斯坦教授，他证实了“迈克尔逊-莫雷实验对相对论的发现影响微乎其微”。 7

There is no mention here of the Michelson-Morley experiment. Its findings were, on the basis of pure speculation, rationally intuited by Einstein before he had ever heard about it. To make sure of this, I addressed an enquiry to the late Professor Einstein, who confirmed the fact that ‘the Michelson-Morley experiment had a negligible effect on the discovery of relativity’.7

事实上，爱因斯坦最初发表狭义相对论的论文（1905年）几乎没有为当时人们对其发现起源的误解提供任何依据。论文开篇用很长的一段话讨论了运动介质电动力学中的异常现象，尤其提到了其处理方式的不对称性：一方面，电流流过的导线相对于静止的磁铁运动；另一方面，磁铁相对于同一静止电流运动。论文接着写道：“类似的例子，以及观测地球相对于光介质相对运动的失败尝试，导致了这样的猜想：与力学一样，在电动力学中，绝对静止是不可观测的……” 1 8教科书通常将相对论解释为对迈克尔逊-莫雷实验的理论回应，这纯属虚构。它源于一种哲学偏见。当爱因斯坦在至少五十年前从未有过的观察的帮助下发现了自然界的合理性时，我们实证主义的教科书迅速用一种恰如其分的、美化了他发现的描述来掩盖这一丑闻。

Actually, Einstein’s original paper announcing the Special Theory of Relativity (1905) gave little grounds for the current misconception concerning the origins of his discovery. It opens with a long paragraph referring to the anomalies in the electrodynamics of moving media, mentioning in particular the lack of symmetry in its treatment, on the one hand, of a wire with current flowing through it moving relative to a magnet at rest, and on the other of a magnet moving relative to the same electric current at rest. It then goes on to say that ‘similar examples, as well as the unsuccessful attempts to observe the relative motion of the earth in respect to the medium of light lead to the conjecture that, as in mechanics, so also in electrodynamics, absolute rest is not observable….’18The usual textbook account of relativity as a theoretical response to the Michelson-Morley experiment is an invention. It is the product of a philosophical prejudice. When Einstein discovered rationality in nature, unaided by any observation that had not been available for at least fifty years before, our positivistic textbooks promptly covered up the scandal by an appropriately embellished account of his discovery.

这个故事还有一个更令人好奇的方面。爱因斯坦所推行的纲领，很大程度上是由他那套实证主义的科学观所预示的，而他自身的成就却公然驳斥了这种观点。它是由恩斯特·马赫明确阐述的，正如我们所见，他首先提出了将科学视为时间表或电话簿的概念。他曾广泛批评牛顿关于空间和绝对静止的定义，理由是该定义没有提出任何可以通过经验检验的东西。他谴责牛顿的定义是教条主义的，因为它超越了经验；也谴责牛顿的定义毫无意义，因为它没有指出任何可以通过经验检验的东西。9马赫主张重新表述牛顿动力学，以避免提及任何物体的运动，除了物体相对于彼此的相对运动，爱因斯坦承认马赫的书在他小时候对他产生了“深远的影响”，并随后对他发现相对论产生了“深远的影响”。 10

There is an aspect of this story that is even more curious. For the programme which Einstein carried out was largely prefigured by he very positivist conception of science which his own achievement so flagrantly refuted. It was formulated explicitly by Ernst Mach, who, as we have seen, had first advanced the conception of science as a timetable or telephone directory. He had extensively criticized Newton’s definition of space and absolute rest on the grounds that it said nothing that could be tested by experience. He condemned this as dogmatic, since it went beyond experience, and as meaningless, since it pointed to nothing that could conceivably be tested by experience.9 Mach urged that Newtonian dynamics should be reformulated so as to avoid referring to any movement of bodies except as the relative motion of bodies with respect to each other, and Einstein acknowledged the ‘profound influence’ which Mach’s book exercised on him as a boy and subsequently on his discovery of relativity.10

然而，如果马赫说得对，牛顿的空间绝对静止概念毫无意义——因为它没有说出任何可以证明真假的东西——那么爱因斯坦对牛顿空间的否定就不会对我们所坚持的真假产生任何影响。它也不可能导致任何新的事实的发现。事实上，马赫完全错了：他忘记了光的传播，没有意识到在这方面，牛顿的空间概念远非不可检验。意识到这一点的爱因斯坦表明，牛顿的空间概念并非毫无意义，而是错误的。

Yet if Mach had been right in saying that Newton’s conception of space as absolute rest was meaningless—because it said nothing that could be proven true or false—then Einstein’s rejection of Newtonian space could have made no difference to what we hold to be true or false. It could not have led to the discovery of any new facts. Actually, Mach was quite wrong: he forgot about the propagation of light and did not realize that in this connection Newton’s conception of space was far from untestable. Einstein, who realized this, showed that the Newtonian conception of space was not meaningless but false.

马赫的伟大功绩在于，他构建了一个机械宇宙，消除了牛顿关于单点绝对静止的假设。他的设想超越了哥白尼，与我们惯常的经验截然不同。因为我们感知到的每一个物体，都是本能地被我们置于一个被认为是静止的背景之上。牛顿在其“绝对空间”公理中体现了这种感官冲动，并称其“不可捉摸，不可移动”，而马赫则将这种冲动抛诸脑后，这是迈向理性理论的一大步，该理论根植于理性，超越了感官。其力量恰恰在于对理性的诉求，而马赫却试图将其从科学基础中剔除。因此，难怪他基于错误的理由提出这一理论，攻击牛顿的陈述是空洞的，却忽视了牛顿的陈述本身就是错误的——这远非空洞。因此，马赫预示了爱因斯坦伟大的理论愿景，感受到其内在的合理性，甚至在试图驱除他获得这种洞察力的人类思维能力时。

Mach’s great merit lay in possessing an intimation of a mechanical universe in which Newton’s assumption of a single point at absolute rest was eliminated. His was a super-Copernican vision, totally at variance with our habitual experience., For every object we perceive is set off by us instinctively against a background which is taken to be at rest. To set aside this urge of our senses, which Newton had embodied in his axiom of an ‘absolute space’ said to be ‘inscrutable and immovable’, was a tremendous step towards a theory grounded in reason and transcending the senses. Its power lay precisely in that appeal to rationality which Mach wished to eliminate from the foundations of science. No wonder therefore that he advanced it on false grounds, attacking Newton for making an empty statement and overlooking the fact that—far from being empty— the statement was false. Thus Mach prefigured the great theoretic vision of Einstein, sensing its inherent rationality, even while trying to exorcise the very capacity of the human mind by which he gained this insight.

但这个故事中仍有一段近乎荒唐可笑的部分需要讲述。1887年的迈克尔逊-莫雷实验，爱因斯坦曾引用该实验来支持他的理论，后来教科书错误地将其奉为迫使他提出该理论的关键证据，但实际上并没有给出相对论所要求的结果！诚然，它证实了实验作者的说法，即地球与“以太”的相对运动不超过地球轨道速度的四分之一。但实际观察到的效应并非可以忽略不计；或者说，至少，至今尚未被证明是可以忽略不计的。迈克尔逊和莫雷的观测中存在正效应，最早是由W·M·希克斯于1902年指出的。11后来，D·米勒（D.C. Miller）评估其相当于每秒八至九公里的“以太漂移”。此外，D·米勒及其同事在1902年至1926年间进行的一系列实验中，也再现了同样幅度的效应。他们使用新的、更精确的仪器，重复了迈克尔逊-莫雷实验数千次。

But there yet remains an almost ludicrous part of the story to be told. The Michelson-Morley experiment of 1887, which Einstein mentions in support of his theory and which the textbooks have since falsely enshrined as the crucial evidence which compelled him to formulate it, actually did not give the result required by relativity! It admittedly substantiated its authors’ claim that the relative motion of the earth and the ‘ether’ did not exceed a quarter of the earth’s orbital velocity. But the actually observed effect was not negligible; or has, at any rate, not been proved negligible up to this day. The presence of a positive effect in the observations of Michelson and Morley was pointed out first by W.M.Hicks in 190211 and was later evaluated by D.C.Miller as corresponding to an ‘ether-drift’ of eight to nine kilometres per second. Moreover, an effect of the same magnitude was reproduced by D.C.Miller and his collaborators in a long series of experiments extending from 1902 to 1926, in which they repeated the Michelson-Morley experiment with new, more accurate apparatus, many thousands of times.

外行人被教导要尊敬科学家，因为他们绝对尊重观察到的事实，并且秉持着明智客观、纯粹暂时的态度来看待科学理论（只要有任何矛盾的证据，他们就随时准备放弃理论）。他们或许会认为，当米勒在1925年12月29日美国物理学会主席演讲中宣布这一“积极效应”的压倒性证据时，他的听众会立即放弃相对论。或者，至少，科学家们——他们习惯于以自己智识上最谦逊的态度俯视其他教条主义的人们——可能会暂缓对此事做出判断，直到米勒的研究结果能够得到解释，而不会损害相对论。然而事实并非如此：到那时，他们已经完全拒绝接受任何威胁爱因斯坦世界观所取得的新合理性的建议，以至于他们几乎不可能再用不同的方式进行思考。很少有人关注这些实验，他们把证据放在一边，希望有一天这些实验会被证明是错误的。12

The layman, taught to revere scientists for their absolute respect for the observed facts, and for the judiciously detached and purely provisional manner in which they hold scientific theories (always ready to abandon a theory at the sight of any contradictory evidence), might well have thought that, at Miller’s announcement of this overwhelming evidence of a ‘positive effect’ in his presidential address to the American Physical Society on December 29th, 1925, his audience would have instantly abandoned the theory of relativity. Or, at the very least, that scientists— wont to look down from the pinnacle of their intellectual humility upon the rest of dogmatic mankind—might suspend judgment in this matter until Miller’s results could be accounted for without impairing the theory of relativity. But no: by that time they had so well closed their minds to any suggestion which threatened the new rationality achieved by Einstein’s world-picture, that it was almost impossible for them to think again in different terms. Little attention was paid to the experiments, the evidence being set aside in the hope that it would one day turn out to be wrong.12

DC·米勒的经历清楚地表明了“科学仅仅建立在任何人都可以随意重复的实验之上”这一断言的空洞性。它表明，任何对科学陈述的批判性验证都需要与科学发现过程相同的识别自然合理性的能力，即使它在较低的层次上运用这些能力。当哲学家分析科学定律的验证时，他们总是选择那些毫无疑问的定律作为样本，因此不可避免地忽视了这些能力的介入。他们描述的是科学定律的实际论证，而不是其批判性验证。结果，我们得到了一种关于科学方法的解释，它忽略了发现过程，理由是它没有遵循确定的方法。十三也忽视了验证过程，仅引用没有进行真正验证的例子。

The experience of D.C.Miller demonstrates quite plainly the hollowness of the assertion that science is simply based on experiments which anybody can repeat at will. It shows that any critical verification of a scientific statement requires the same powers for recognizing rationality in nature as does the process of scientific discovery, even though it exercises these at a lower level. When philosophers analyse the verification of scientific laws, they invariably choose as specimens such laws as are not in doubt, and thus inevitably overlook the intervention of these powers. They are describing the practical demonstration of scientific law, and not its critical verification. As a result we are given an account of the scientific method which, having left out the process of discovery on the grounds that it follows no definite method13 overlooks the process of verification as well, by referring only to examples where no real verification takes place.

米勒宣布其成果之时，相对论尚未做出几项能够被实验证实的预测。其经验支撑主要在于一些已知的观测结果。新理论对这些已知现象的解释被认为是合理的，因为它源于一个令人信服的合理原理。这与​​牛顿对开普勒三定律、月球周期和地球引力的全面阐述——以万有引力的广义理论——立即被赋予了至高无上的权威地位，甚至在由此推导出任何预测之前也是如此。正是相对论这种与生俱来的合理性优势，促使马克斯·玻恩，尽管他的科学论述强烈强调经验主义，早在1920年就赞扬相对论“思想的宏伟、大胆和直接”，这使得科学的世界图景“更加美丽和宏伟”。14

At the time that Miller announced his results, relativity had yet made few predictions that could be confirmed by experiment. Its empirical support lay mainly in a number of already known observations. The account which the new theory gave of these known phenomena was considered rational, since it derived them from one single convincingly rational principle. It was the same as when Newton’s comprehensive account of Kepler’s Three Laws, of the moon’s period and of terrestrial gravitation—in terms of a general theory of universal gravitation—was immediately given a position of surpassing authority, even before any predictions had been deduced from it. It was this inherent rational excellence of relativity which moved Max Born, despite the strong empirical emphasis of his accounts of science, to salute as early as 1920 ‘the grandeur, the boldness, and the directness of the thought’ of relativity, which made the world-picture of science ‘more beautiful and grander’.14

此后，岁月流逝，至少一个相对论公式得到了广泛而精确的证实；这或许是唯一一个登上《时代》杂志封面的公式。伴随核转变而来的能量(e)损失会导致质量(m)减少，这一事实已被反复证明，可以证实关系式e=mc² ，其中c是光速。但这些相对论验证只不过是对爱因斯坦及其追随者最初判断的证实，他们早在这些验证之前就致力于该理论的研究。它们更是对恩斯特·马赫早期为建立更合理的力学基础所作努力的证明，在尚无任何途径实现这一目标的时代，他为相对论制定了纲领。

Since then, the passing years have brought wide and precise confirmation of at least one formula of relativity; probably the only formula ever sent sprawling across the cover of Time magazine. The reduction of mass (m) by the loss of energy (e) accompanying nuclear transformation has been repeatedly shown to confirm the relation e=mc2, where c is the velocity of light. But such verifications of relativity are but confirmations of the original judgment of Einstein and his followers, who committed themselves to the theory long before these verifications. And they are an even more remarkable justification of the earlier strivings of Ernst Mach for a more rational foundation of mechanics, setting out a programme for relativity at a time when no avenues could yet be seen towards this objective.

正如我所说，当代物理学的合理性所蕴含的美与力量是一种全新的美。当古典物理学取代毕达哥拉斯传统时，数学理论被简化为一种纯粹的工具，用于计算机械运动，而这些运动被认为是所有自然现象的基础。几何学也置身于自然之外，声称能够提供对欧几里得空间的先验分析，而欧几里得空间被认为是所有自然现象的场景，但人们并不认为它与这些现象有关。相对论，以及随后的量子力学和现代物理学，都回归到了对实在的数学概念。黎曼在其非欧几何的发展中，将相对论的基本特征作为数学问题预见到了；而对相对论的进一步阐述则依赖于当时纯粹是推测性的张量微积分的力量，而爱因斯坦幸运地从苏黎世的一位数学家那里了解到了张量微积分。同样，马克斯·玻恩恰好发现了矩阵微积分，为海森堡量子力学的发展提供了便利，否则量子力学永远无法得出具体的结论。这样的例子不胜枚举。现代物理学通过这些例子，证明了人类思维在进入经验领域之前就发现并展现了支配自然的理性，而经验领域中先前发现的数学和谐将被揭示为经验事实。

The beauty and power inherent in the rationality of contemporary physics is, as I have said, of a novel kind. When classical physics superseded the Pythagorean tradition, mathematical theory was reduced to a mere instrument for computing the mechanical motions which were supposed to underlie all natural phenomena. Geometry also stood outside nature, claiming to offer an a priori analysis of Euclidean space, which was regarded as the scene of all natural phenomena but not thought to be involved in them. Relativity, and subsequently quantum mechanics and modern physics generally, have moved back towards a mathematical conception of reality. Essential features of the theory of relativity were anticipated as mathematical problems by Riemann in his development of non-Euclidean geometry; while its further elaboration relied on the powers of the hitherto purely speculative tensor calculus, which by a fortunate accident Einstein got to know from a mathematician in Zürich. Similarly, Max Born happened to find the matrix calculus ready to hand for the development of Heisenberg’s quantum mechanics, which could otherwise never have reached concrete conclusions. These examples could be multiplied. By them, modern physics has demonstrated the power of the human mind to discover and exhibit a rationality which governs nature, before ever approaching the field of experience in which previously discovered mathematical harmonies were to be revealed as empirical facts.

因此，相对论在一定程度上恢复了几何学与物理学的融合，而毕达哥拉斯的思想最初天真地认为这种融合是理所当然的。我们现在认识到，在广义相对论出现之前，欧几里得几何学被认为是正确地表达经验的，但它仅仅涉及物理现实中相对肤浅的方面。它对刚体的度量关系进行了理想化，并对其进行了详尽的阐述，同时完全忽略了物体的质量及其作用力。几何学被推广到多维非欧几里得空间，为扩展几何学以涵盖动力学定律提供了机会，而这在纯数学领域已经取得了进展，甚至在任何对这些结果进行实证研究之前都无法想象。1908年，闵可夫斯基迈出了第一步，提出了一种表达狭义相对论的几何学，并将经典动力学作为极限情况。物理动力学定律现在表现为四维非欧几里得空间的几何定理。爱因斯坦随后的研究，通过对这类几何的进一步推广，最终导致了广义相对论的诞生。广义相对论的公设经过精心挑选，使得它对所有假定物理等效的参考系都能够产生不变的表达式。由于这些公设，物体的运动轨迹遵循测地线，光也沿零线传播。当物理定律如此呈现为几何定理的具体例子时，我们可以推断，人们对物理理论的信任很大程度上源于它所拥有的卓越性，而纯几何和纯数学正是从这种卓越性中汲取兴趣，并因此而发展。

Thus relativity has restored, up to a point, the blend of geometry and physics which Pythagorean thought had first naïvely taken for granted. We now realize that Euclidean geometry, which until the advent of general relativity was taken to represent experience correctly, referred only to comparatively superficial aspects of physical reality. It gave an idealization of the metric relations of rigid bodies and elaborated these exhaustively, while ignoring entirely the masses of the bodies and the forces acting on them. The opportunity to expand geometry so as to include the laws of dynamics was offered by its generalization into many- dimensional and non-Euclidean space, and this was accomplished by work in pure mathematics, before any empirical investigation of these results could even be imagined. Minkowski took the first step in 1908 by presenting a geometry which expressed the special theory of relativity, and which included classical dynamics as a limiting case. The laws of physical dynamics now appeared as geometrical theorems of a four- dimensional non-Euclidean space. Subsequent investigation by Einstein led, by a further generalization of this type of geometry, to the general theory of relativity, its postulates being so chosen as to produce invariant expressions with regard to all frames of reference assumed to be physically equivalent. As a result of these postulates, the trajectories of masses follow geodetics, and light is propagated along zero lines. When the laws of physics thus appear as particular instances of geometrical theorems, we may infer that the confidence placed in physical theory owes much to its possessing the same kind of excellence from which pure geometry and pure mathematics in general derive their interest, and for the sake of which they are cultivated.

 

 

  1. 客观性与现代物理学
  2. OBJECTIVITY AND MODERN PHYSICS

如果我们不承认自己对令人振奋的美和令人着迷的深刻性的认可，就无法真正解释我们为何接受这些理论。然而，基于主观性与客观性分离的主流科学观，试图——而且必须不惜一切代价——从科学中消除这种对理论充满热情、个人化、人性化的评价，或者至少将其功能降到微不足道的地步。现代人将自然科学的概念确立为知识的理想，即它是一组陈述，其“客观”性在于其实质完全由观察决定，即使其表述方式可能受惯例影响。这种源于根植于我们文化深处的渴望的概念，如果必须承认对自然理性的直觉是科学理论的合理且不可或缺的组成部分，它就会破灭。正因如此，科学理论才被描述为对事实的简单描述；或者体现了一种进行经验推论的传统策略；或者是一种适合人类实际便利的工作假设——所有这些解释都故意忽视了科学的理性核心。

We cannot truly account for our acceptance of such theories without endorsing our acknowledgement of a beauty that exhilarates and a profundity that entrances us. Yet the prevailing conception of science, based on the disjunction of subjectivity and objectivity, seeks—and must seek at all costs—to eliminate from science such passionate, personal, human appraisals of theories, or at least to minimize their function to that of a negligible by-play. For modern man has set up as the ideal of knowledge the conception of natural science as a set of statements which is ‘objective’ in the sense that its substance is entirely determined by observation, even while its presentation may be shaped by convention. This conception, stemming from a craving rooted in the very depths of our culture, would be shattered if the intuition of rationality in nature had to be acknowledged as a justifiable and indeed essential part of scientific theory. That is why scientific theory is represented as a mere economical description of facts; or as embodying a conventional policy for drawing empirical inferences; or as a working hypothesis, suited to man’s practical convenience—interpretations that all deliberately overlook the rational core of science.

正因如此，即使这种理性核心的存在再次得到肯定，其冒犯性也会被一系列委婉语所掩盖，这是一种得体的轻描淡写，就像维多利亚时代将腿称为四肢时所用的那种——例如，我们可以观察到这种删节，试图用“简单性”取代“理性”。当然，将简单性视为理性的标志，并将任何理论视为简单性的胜利，这都是合理的。但伟大的理论很少是通常意义上的简单。量子力学和相对论都很难理解；只需几分钟就能记住相对论所解释的事实，但多年的学习可能不足以掌握该理论并在其语境中理解这些事实。赫尔曼·外尔（Hermann Weyl）说漏了嘴：“所需的简单性不一定是显而易见的，但我们必须让自然训练我们去识别真正的内在简单性。”15换句话说，只有当“简单性”以一种只有科学家才知道的特殊含义来使用时，科学中的简单性才能等同于合理性。我们只有通过回忆“合理的”、“合理的”或“我们应该同意的”的含义才能理解“简单性”的含义，而“简单性”一词本应取代这些含义。因此，“简单性”一词的作用仅仅是掩盖其自身含义之外的其他含义。它被用来将一种本质特质偷偷带入我们对科学理论的理解中，而错误的客观性观念不允许我们公开承认这种特质。

That is why, also, if the existence of this rational core yet reasserts itself, its offensiveness is covered up by a set of euphemisms, a kind of decent understatement like that used in Victorian times when legs were called limbs—a bowdlerization which we may observe, for example, in the attempts to replace ‘rationality’ by ‘simplicity’. It is legitimate, of course, to regard simplicity as a mark of rationality, and to pay tribute to any theory as a triumph of simplicity. But great theories are rarely simple in the ordinary sense of the term. Both quantum mechanics and relativity are very difficult to understand; it takes only a few minutes to memorize the facts accounted for by relativity, but years of study may not suffice to master the theory and see these facts in its context. Hermann Weyl lets the cat out of the bag by saying: ‘the required simplicity is not necessarily the obvious one but we must let nature train us to recognize the true inner simplicity.’15 In other words, simplicity in science can be made equivalent to rationality only if ‘simplicity’ is used in a special sense known solely by scientists. We understand the meaning of the term ‘simple’ only by recalling the meaning of the term ‘rational’ or ‘reasonable’ or ‘such that we ought to assent to it’, which the term ‘simple’ was supposed to replace. The term ‘simplicity’ functions then merely as a disguise for another meaning than its own. It is used for smuggling an essential quality into our appreciation of a scientific theory, which a mistaken conception of objectivity forbids us openly to acknowledge.

刚才关于“简洁性”的论述同样适用于“对称性”和“经济性”。它们是理论卓越之处的构成要素，但只有当这些术语的含义远远超出其通常的范畴，从而包含那些让科学家们为相对论之类的愿景而欣喜的更深层次的特质时，才能解释其价值。它们必须代表那些独特的智识和谐，这些和谐比任何感官经验都更深刻、更持久地揭示客观真理的存在。

What has just been said of ‘simplicity’ applies equally to ‘symmetry’ and ‘economy’. They are contributing elements in the excellence of a theory, but can account for its merit only if the meanings of these terms are stretched far beyond their usual scope, so as to include the much deeper qualities which make the scientists rejoice in a vision like that of relativity. They must stand for those peculiar intellectual harmonies which reveal, more profoundly and permanently than any sense-experience, the presence of objective truth.

我将这种做法称为“伪替代”。它被用来贬低人类真实且不可或缺的智力，以维护一个实际上无法解释这些智力的“客观主义”框架。其运作方式是，用科学相对琐碎的特征来定义其价值，然后使这些特征以与它们本应取代的真正术语相同的方式发挥作用。

I shall call this practice a pseudo-substitution. It is used to play down man’s real and indispensable intellectual powers for the sake of maintaining an ‘objectivist’ framework which in fact cannot account for them. It works by defining scientific merit in terms of its relatively trivial features, and making these function then in the same way as the true terms which they are supposed to replace.

其他科学领域将更有效地展现这些不可或缺的智力力量，以及它们在认知活动中的热情参与。本书标题“个人知识”所指的正是这些力量和这种参与。我们将发现个人知识体现在精密科学中对概率和秩序的理解中，并在描述性科学对技能和鉴赏力的依赖方式中更广泛地发挥作用。在所有这些方面，认知行为都包含着一种评价；这种塑造所有事实性知识的个人因素，在主观性与客观性之间的断裂中架起了桥梁。它暗示着这样一种主张：人可以通过热情地努力履行其对普遍标准的个人义务来超越自身的主观性。

Other areas of science will illustrate even more effectively these indispensable intellectual powers, and their passionate participation in the act of knowing. It is to these powers and to this participation that I am referring in the title of this book as ‘Personal Knowledge’. We shall find Personal Knowledge manifested in the appreciation of probability and of order in the exact sciences, and see it at work even more extensively in the way the descriptive sciences rely on skills and connoisseurship. At all these points the act of knowing includes an appraisal; and this personal coefficient, which shapes all factual knowledge, bridges in doing so the disjunction between subjectivity and objectivity. It implies the claim that man can transcend his own subjectivity by striving passionately to fulfill his personal obligations to universal standards.

 

 

2

2

可能性

PROBABILITY

 

 

  1. 程序
  2. PROGRAMME

本书旨在表明，通常被归因于精密科学的完全客观性，实则是一种妄想，实际上是一种虚假的理想。但我不会试图否定严格的客观性这一理想，而是会提出一种我认为更值得理性拥护的替代物；我称之为“个人知识”。在本书第一部分，题为“认知的艺术”，我希望能够充分预示“个人知识”这一概念将开启的视角，从而证明我坚持不懈（否则可能显得吹毛求疵）揭露当前科学观所有不为人知的秘密的合理性。这种道歉是必要的，因为每个思想体系当然都隐藏着一些未解决的问题，而我试图围绕“个人知识”这一概念构建的体系，也会让许多问题悬而未决。然而，事实是，人们一次又一次地对当前思想的漏洞百出感到恼火，转而转向另一个体系，而无视新体系中类似的缺陷。在哲学上，除了这个别无他法；这就是我现在继续重新评价科学的原因。

THE purpose of this book is to show that complete objectivity as usually attributed to the exact sciences is a delusion and is in fact a false ideal. But I shall not try to repudiate strict objectivity as an ideal without offering a substitute, which I believe to be more worthy of intelligent allegiance; this I have called ‘personal knowledge’, In this First Part, entitled The Art of Knowing’, I hope sufficiently to foreshadow the perspective which the conception of personal knowledge will open up, to justify my persistence—which otherwise may appear merely captious—in rattling all the skeletons in the cupboard of the current scientific outlook. This apology is necessary, for every system of thought has of course some loose ends tucked away out of sight, and the system that I am trying to build round the conception of personal knowledge will also leave many questions in abeyance. Yet it is a fact that time and again men have become exasperated with the loose ends of current thought and have changed over to another system, heedless of similar deficiencies within that new system. There is no other way in philosophy than this; and this is my reason for continuing now my re-valuation of science.

 

 

  1. 明确的陈述
  2. UNAMBIGUOUS STATEMENTS

精密科学的公开目标是建立对经验的完全理性控制，其依据是可以正式阐述并经经验检验的精确规则。如果这一理想能够完全实现，那么从此以后，所有真理和所有谬误都可以归因于一个精确的宇宙理论，而接受这一理论的我们则无需再运用个人判断：我们只需忠实地遵循规则即可。经典力学如此接近这一理想，以至于人们常常认为它已经实现了它。但这忽略了将力学公式应用于经验事实时所涉及的个人判断因素。以一颗绕太阳旋转的行星为例。牛顿力学为我们提供了一个精确的公式，借助该公式，我们只要获得一组描述该系统在某一时刻的数据，就可以计算出这个二体系统在最遥远的未来或最遥远的过去的结构。假设我们从地球上观察行星的运动，只要知道某一时刻( t 0) 的经度 (l 0 )和海拔( e 0 ) 就足以计算任何其他时刻(t)的任意一对经度(l)和海拔(e ) ……这样的操作将完全客观，甚至可以由机器自动完成，以至于看起来就像它根据其他先前的经验事实非常客观地预测了某些经验事实。但这忽略了一个事实：天体力学公式中表示经度、海拔和时间的数字并非经验事实。这些事实是特定天文台仪器的读数：我们从这些读数中得出数据，以此为基础进行计算，并以此检验计算结果。数据的推导和检验，用于弥合仪器读数与公式中数值之间的差距，永远不可能完全自动化。因为，引入精确理论的测量值与相应的仪器读数之间的任何相关性，都依赖于对观测误差的估计，而这种估计无法通过规则明确规定。这种不确定性首先归因于观测误差的统计波动，我将稍后再讨论这个问题。由于这些随机误差，我们只能从初始数据的可能值推导出预测震级的可能值，而且由于这两组数据之间不存在严格的关系，因此这个过程在某种程度上仍然是不确定的。除了这些波动之外，我们始终存在系统误差的可能性。即使是最严格的机械化程序，也难免会受到个人技能的影响，在运用过程中可能会引入个人偏见。

The avowed purpose of the exact sciences is to establish complete intellectual control over experience in terms of precise rules which can be formally set out and empirically tested. Could that ideal be fully achieved, all truth and all error could henceforth be ascribed to an exact theory of the universe, while we who accept this theory would be relieved of any occasion for exercising our personal judgment: we should only have to follow the rules faithfully. Classical mechanics approaches this ideal so closely that it is often thought to have achieved it. But this leaves out of account the element of personal judgment involved in applying the formulae of mechanics to the facts of experience. Take for example a single planet circling round the sun. Newtonian mechanics supplies us with an exact formula by the aid of which we can compute the configuration of this two-body system for the most distant future or for the remotest past, provided only that we are given one single set of data, describing the system at one single moment of time. Supposing we observed the motion of the planet from the earth, it would suffice to know its longitude (l0) and elevation (e0) at a time (t0), in order to compute any pair of longitudes (l) and elevation (e) for any other time (t). Such an operation would be quite impersonal and could indeed be done by a machine, automatically, so that it docs look as if it predicted certain facts of experience from other anterior facts of experience quite impersonally. But this would overlook the fact that the numbers giving longitudes, elevations, and times which enter into the formulae of celestial mechanics are not facts of experience. The facts are readings on the instruments of a particular observatory: readings from which we derive the data on which we base our computation and by which we check the results of such computations. The derivation of data and checking of data that bridge the gap between our instrument readings and the magnitudes figuring in our formulae can never be fully automatic. For any correlation between a measured number introduced into an exact theory and the corresponding instrument readings, rests on an estimate of observational errors which cannot be definitively prescribed by rule. This indeterminacy is due in the first place to the statistical fluctuations of observational errors, to which I shall yet return. In consequence of such random errors we can only proceed from the probable values of initial data to probable values of predicted magnitudes, and since no strict relationship exists between these two sets of figures, the process remains to this extent indeterminate. Apart from these fluctuations we have always the possibility of systematic errors. Even the most strictly mechanized procedure leaves something to personal skill in the exercise of which an individual bias may enter.

我们应该永远记住皇家天文学家尼古拉斯·马斯基林的著名案例，他解雇了他的助手金布鲁克，因为他持续记录星星的运行时间比他的上司晚半秒多。16马斯基林没有意识到，同样细心的观察者可能会通过他所采用的方法记录下系统不同的时间；只有贝塞尔意识到了这种可能性，

We should remember always the famous case of the Astronomer Royal, Nicholas Maskeleyne, who dismissed his assistant Kinnebrook for persistently recording the passage of stars more than half a second later than he, his superior.16 Maskelyne did not realize that an equally watchful observer may register systematically different times by the method employed by him; it was only Bessel’s realization of this possibility which

20 年后，这一分歧得以解决，并为 Kinnebrook 的合理性提供了迟来的证明。

20 years later resolved the discrepancy and belatedly justified Kinnebrook.

贝塞尔奠定了基础的实验心理学，自此便普遍教导我们，感知能力存在个体差异。因此，我们必须始终假设，某种隐藏的个人偏见可能会系统性地影响一系列读数的结果。17

Experimental psychology, of which Bessel thus laid the foundation, has since taught us universally to expect such individual variations in perceptive faculties. We must always assume, therefore, that some trace of a hidden personal bias may systematically affect the result of a series of readings.17

这些残留的不确定性，没有明确的规则约束，通常可以通过常规做法来处理。即便如此，这个过程总是会消除人们对任何一套明确规则的应用可能产生的怀疑，没有这些怀疑，任何科学工作都不可能完成，任何科学陈述都不可能被断言。即使在最精确的科学操作中，科学家也必须亲自参与。

Such residual indeterminacies, governed by no definite rules, can usually be disposed of according to routine practice. Yet even so, this process always sets aside conceivable doubts regarding the application of any definite set of rules, and without this no scientific work could ever be accomplished and no scientific statement could be asserted. We have here an essential personal participation of the scientist even in the most exact operations of science.

在每一次科学理论的验证中，个人判断的运用范围甚至更为广泛。与当前的观点相反，理论预测与观测数据之间已证实的差异本身并不足以推翻一个理论。此类差异通常可归类为异常现象。在发现海王星之前的60年间，观测到的行星运动扰动无法用行星间的相互作用来解释，大多数天文学家当时理所当然地将其视为异常现象，希望最终能找到某种解释，而不会损害（或至少不会从本质上损害）牛顿引力定律。更概括地说，我们可以说，在验证一个精确理论的过程中，科学家总是会习惯性地抛开一些可以想象的顾虑。这种个人判断行为构成了科学的重要组成部分。18

There is an even wider area of personal judgment in every verification of a scientific theory. Contrary to current opinion, it is not the case that a proven discrepancy between theoretical predictions and observed data suffices in itself to invalidate a theory. Such discrepancies may often be classed as anomalies. The perturbations of the planetary motions that were observed during 60 years preceding the discovery of Neptune, and which could not be explained by the mutual interaction of the planets, were rightly set aside at the time as anomalies by most astronomers, in the hope that something might eventually turn up to account for them without impairing—or at least not essentially impairing—Newtonian gravitation. Speaking more generally, we may say that there are always some conceivable scruples which scientists customarily set aside in the process of verifying an exact theory. Such acts of personal judgment form an essential part of science.18

 

 

  1. 概率陈述
  2. PROBABILITY STATEMENTS

然而，经典物理学的理论与科学领域其他所有篇章的不同之处在于，可以想象一些事件，这些事件会严格证伪经典物理学的理论。例如，可以想象一颗行星围绕着太阳旋转，它与其他天体的距离可能非常远，以至于这些天体引起的任何扰动都可以忽略不计，而我们应该知道情况确实如此。为了论证的目的，进一步假设我们能够在连续的时间点精确地观察到行星的位置，那么力学公式将获得做出完全客观预测的能力，而这些预测将被行星未能在预测的时间出现在任何预测的位置这一事实严格证伪。哪怕是有限的偏差，无论多么微小，都会导致理论的彻底驳斥。

Yet the theories of classical physics differ from all other chapters in the domain of science by the fact that events are conceivable which would strictly falsify them. It is conceivable, for example, that a sun with a planet circling around it might be so far removed from other celestial bodies as to render negligible any perturbations caused by these, and that we should know this to be the case. Assuming further, for the sake of argument, that we could observe the position of the planet exactly at successive moments of time, the formulae of mechanics would acquire the power of making quite impersonal predictions, which would be strictly falsified by the fact that the planet failed to turn up in any predicted position at a predicted time. A finite deviation, however slight, would entail a complete refutation of the theory.

通过上述假设，我们或许至少可以虚构地恢复经典力学中非个人知识的概念。但如果我们转向概率陈述，任何此类主张的虚伪之处就变得一目了然。即使我们假设所有外部扰动和所有观察误差都完全消除，概率陈述也永远不会与经验严格矛盾。证明这一事实的唯一困难在于它太明显了，因为没有人会愿意相信事情如此简单，因为围绕它已经写了这么多卷书，却没有明确说明这一点。

By such assumptions as the above we may succeed in restoring at least fictionally the conception of impersonal knowledge in classical mechanics. But the pretences of any such claim become altogether transparent if we pass on to statements of probability. Probability statements can never be strictly contradicted by experience, even if we assume that all external perturbations and all observational errors are entirely eliminated. The only difficulty in demonstrating this fact is that it is so obvious for nobody will be ready to believe that the matter is so simple, when so many volumes have been written around it without clearly saying so.

让我以量子力学描述的氢原子为例来说明这一点。它为我们呈现了一幅图，该图为无限空间中的每个点分配一个数值，该数值是该点与原子核距离r的函数f (r)。这个数值表示在该特定点以及与原子核距离r相同的任何其他点找到氢原子电子的概率。这一陈述之所以不会与任何可想象的事件相矛盾，原因很简单，因为它承认电子可能在特定场合在指定位置找到，也可能找不到。有一个故事，讲的是一位狗主人，他以自己对宠物的完美训练而自豪。每当他叫：“过来！你来不来！”时，狗总是要么来，要么不来。这正是电子在概率控制下的行为方式。

Let me illustrate the point by the example of a hydrogen atom as described by quantum mechanics. It presents us with a map which assigns to every point of infinite space a number which is a function f(r) of its distance r from the nucleus. This number denotes the probability of finding the electron of the hydrogen atom at this particular point and likewise at any other point having the same distance r from the nucleus. The simple reason why this statement cannot be contradicted by any conceivable event lies in the fact that it admits that the electron may be found or not be found at the designated place on the specified occasion. There is a story of a dog-owner who prided himself on the perfect training of his pet. Whenever he called: ‘Here! will you come or not!’ the dog invariably either came or not. That is exactly how electrons behave when controlled by probability.

这类陈述本质上是模棱两可的，因此似乎什么也没说。然而，如果（正如我所相信的）为我们在特定场合在特定位置找到电子的概率赋值具有某种意义，那么这种赋值必然意味着对这种模棱两可性有所限制；如果无法从这种概率赋值中得出任何严格客观的限制，我们或许可以期望从中找到一些指导，以指导我们亲自参与概率陈述所指的事件。

Statements of this kind are essentially ambiguous and may therefore seem to say nothing. However, if there is, as I believe that there is, some meaning in assigning a numerical value to the probability of our finding an electron at a certain place on a particular occasion, such an assignment must imply some restriction on this ambiguity; and if no strictly objective restriction can be derived from the assignment of this probability, we may expect to find in it instead some guidance to our personal participation in the event to which the probability statement refers.

如果我们暂时放下客观主义的复杂性，回归日常习惯，原则上很容易认识到我们参与了偶然事件。我们通常将某些事件描述为非凡的巧合；我们也有关于令人难忘的好运或厄运的故事。这些都是对受偶然性支配的事件的评估。我们在事件发生之前和之后都会做出这样的评估，如果它们的概率用数字来表示，这个数字会指导并在很大程度上表达我们的评估。如果我接受概率陈述，即连续掷出三个双六的概率是46656分之一，那么我相应地会抱有很小的期望；而如果它仍然发生，我会感到惊讶，其程度与这个数值概率的倒数相对应。这就是我参与概率陈述所指事件的程度，我认为这才是其概率的真正含义。

It is indeed easy to recognize in principle our participation in chance events if we relax for a moment our objectivist sophistication and revert to ordinary usage. We commonly describe certain events as remarkable coincidences; we have our stories of memorable pieces of luck or ill-luck. These are appraisals of events governed by chance. We make such appraisals both before and after such an event has taken place, and if their probability is expressed numerically, this number guides and largely expresses our appraisal. If I accept the probability statement that the chances of throwing three double sixes in immediate succession are one in 46656, I shall entertain a correspondingly small expectation of doing so; while if it should still happen, I shall be surprised, to a degree corresponding to the reciprocal of this numerical probability. Such is my participation in the event to which a probability statement refers, and this I regard as the proper meaning of its probability.

这并不是要赋予事件的概率以主观意义——无论是量子力学定律，还是掷出双六的概率为1/36这样的陈述。我赋予我的概率评估普遍有效性，尽管它们没有做出任何可能与任何可想象的事件相矛盾的预测。下一章我将提到精密科学领域中一系列普遍有效的评估，这些评估本质上都不可能与任何可想象的事件相矛盾。

This is not to ascribe a subjective meaning to the probability of an event—either in the laws of quantum mechanics or in the statement that the chances of throwing a double six are 1/36. I ascribe universal validity to my appraisals of probability, in spite of the fact that they make no predictions which could be contradicted by any conceivable events. I shall mention in the next chapter a wide range of universally valid appraisals within the exact sciences which are all essentially incapable of being contradicted by any conceivable event.

当然，在某种重要意义上，概率陈述可能会被事件推翻（尽管不会被反驳）。如果基于概率陈述的预期屡屡落空，而后续事件根据其先前的概率陈述似乎也相应地不太可能发生，我们就会开始怀疑该陈述的正确性。罗纳德·费舍尔爵士在其著名论文《实验设计》中系统地阐述了判定某个统计陈述是否站得住脚的流程。

There is, of course, an important sense in which a probability statement can be controverted (though not contradicted) by the events. If the expectations based on a statement of probability are repeatedly disappointed and the ensuing events appear to have been correspondingly improbable in the light of the anterior statement of their probability, we shall begin to suspect the correctness of this statement. The process of deciding that a certain statistical statement is untenable has indeed been systematically developed by Sir Ronald Fisher in his famous treatise, The Design of Experiments.

我将简要概述 Fisher 应用此程序的标准示例，并涉及查尔斯·达尔文关于异花授粉与自花授粉对植物高度的影响的实验。19每种植物测量15株，随机分成15对，得到15个高度差异（以八分之一英寸为单位）。这些差异记为X 1，

I shall give a brief outline of Fisher’s standard example for the application of this procedure, dealing with Charles Darwin’s experiments on the influence of cross-fertilization in contrast to self-fertilization on the height of plants.19 15 plants of each kind were measured and 15 pairs formed at random from which 15 differences in height (measured in eighths of an inch) were obtained. The differences being denoted by X1,

X 2、X 3 ……，它们的平均值为。的数值表明，异花受精植株平均比自花受精植株高20.93/8英寸。问题的核心在于，这种差异是显著的还是仅仅是偶然的。为了确定这一点，我们必须将这种差异的大小与样本中似乎发生的偶然变异的范围进行比较，并且 将要

X2, X3…, their mean is. The value of shows that on the average the cross-fertilized plants were 20·93 eighths of an inch taller than the self- fertilized plants. The heart of the question is then whether this difference is significant or due to mere chance. To decide this, we shall have to compare the magnitude of this difference with the range of ￼accidental variations which appear to occur in our sample, and will

只有当它充分超出这些变化的范围时，才被认为是显著的。从技术角度来说，我们用一个称为标准差a的量级来描述这个范围，其计算方法是：将与平均值的偏差平方和（假设有15个观测值）先除以14，再除以15，然后对结果取平方根，即

be acknowledged as significant only if it sufficiently exceeds the range of such variations. Technically, we describe this range by a magnitude called the standard deviation a which is computed by forming the sum of the square of the deviations from the mean, dividing this (in the case of 15 observations) first by 14 and then by 15, and taking the square root of the result, so that

 

 

在我们的例子中，σ等于 9·746 八分之一英寸。因此，显而易见的是 ￼大于个体身高的标准差。但问题依然存在：它是否足够大于σ ，以至于无法用身高的偶然变化来解释。

In our case σ comes out at 9·746 eighth inches. Thus it is immediately apparent that ￼is larger than the standard deviation of the individual heights. But the question still remains whether it is sufficiently larger than σ to be incapable of being accounted for by chance variations of heights.

回答这个问题，就是要用经验来检验一个概率陈述。让我们看看费舍尔是如何做到这一点的。他提出了比率 ￼,, 结果为 2·148；然后他查阅了一个表格，该表格基于 14 个独立差异计算出t具有任何特定值的概率，并发现在恰好 5% 的此类随机试验中，偶然达到或超过了t =2·148。

To answer this question is to bring a statement of probability to the test of experience. Let us watch how Fisher proceeds to do this. He forms the ratio ￼,, which comes out to 2·148; then he consults a table which tells what the probability is for t to have any particular value when based on 14 independent discrepancies, and finds that t=2·148 is reached or exceeded by chance in exactly 5 per cent of such random trials.

这告诉我们，假设（费舍尔称之为零假设），即自花受精和异花受精植物的高度差异纯属偶然，那么我们实际观察到的样本出现这种情况的概率不到5%。这样的表述使我们有理由对观察到的结果感到惊讶，就像我们从一个袋子里抽出一个黑球一样，这个袋子里本来应该装着100个其他方面无法区分的球，而实际上只有5个黑球。现在假设我们自己把这些球（95%是白球，5%是黑球）放进袋子里，然后摇晃袋子，抽出一个黑球。我们会非常惊讶，但仍然坚信袋子里装着我们放进去的球。然而，对于我们的零假设，情况并非如此。在这种情况下，罗纳德·费希尔爵士建议（我准备遵循他的观点），我们必须放弃这样的假设，即相对于自花授粉，异花授粉对植物的高度没有影响，因为达尔文的研究结果的可能性不到 5%，这使得该假设站不住脚。

This tells us that on the hypothesis (which Fisher calls the null- hypothesis) that the differences in the heights of self-fertilized and cross- fertilized plants are purely accidental, the probability for our actually observed sample having occurred was less than 5 per cent. Such a statement entitles us to be surprised by the observed result to the same extent as we would be if we drew a black ball from a sack supposed to contain only 5 black balls in a hundred otherwise undistinguishable balls. Now suppose that we had ourselves placed the balls, 95 per cent of them white and 5 per cent of them black, into the sack, and then having shaken them up, we drew out a black ball. We should be very surprised, yet remain unshaken in our belief that the bag contained the balls we had put into it. Not so, however, for our null-hypothesis. In this case Sir Ronald Fisher suggests (and I am prepared to follow him) that we must abandon the assumption that cross-fertilization as against self-fertilization has no effect on the height of plants, since the probability of Darwin's results, being less than 5 per cent, renders the assumption untenable.

事实上，我们或许可以接受费舍尔推荐的反驳零假设的标准程序，该程序基于排除低于5%的概率。但显而易见的是，该程序仅适用于我们认为其可能性与异花授粉相对于自花授粉无效性相当的假设性假设，而不适用于像我们放入一个袋子中黑白球持续存在那样可能性程度极高的假设。

Indeed, we may accept Fisher's recommendation of a standard procedure for disproving a null-hypothesis, based on the exclusion of probabilities that are less than 5 per cent. But it is already apparent that this procedure can apply only to hypothetical assumptions that we consider to be of a likelihood comparable to that of the ineffectiveness of cross-fertilization as against self-fertilization, and not to assumptions of such a high degree of likelihood as we would hold in respect of the continued presence in a bag of the black and white balls which we placed in it.

当然，一系列概率足够低的实际结果可能会动摇我们最初的假设，即使这些假设是极其坚定的。因此，美国莱因和英国索尔的猜牌实验，使得这些观察者及其追随者认为，在这些实验中，被猜的牌对猜牌过程没有影响的零假设站不住脚。但在这些情况下，根据零假设评估的观察结果的概率必须远低于5%，才能动摇人们对它的信念。当然，我们对零假设的合理信任度没有明确的下限，因此，我们根据某个零假设假设发生的事件的概率也没有明确的下限。因此，很明显，概率陈述不能与任何事件严格矛盾，无论该事件在它的视角下看起来多么不可能。这种矛盾必须通过个人的评估行为来确定，这种评估行为会拒绝某些可能性，因为这些可能性太小，无法被认为是真实的。

Of course, a series of actual results of sufficiently low probability might shake our initial assumptions even when they are most firmly held. Thus the card-guessing experiments of Rhine in the U.S. and of Soal in England have rendered untenable to these observers and their followers the null-hypothesis that in these experiments the card to be guessed had no effect on the guessing of it. But in these cases the probabilities of the observed results as evaluated on the basis of the null-hypothesis had to fall very far below 5 per cent in order to shake one's belief in it. There is of course no finite limit to the confidence we may reasonably place in a null-hypothesis, nor can there be therefore any definite lower limit either to the probability of events which we may assume to have occurred on the basis of some null-hypothesis.
