And like the works of imaginative art, the constructions of mathematics will tend therefore to disclose those hidden principles of the experienced world of which some scattered traces had first stimulated the imaginative process by which these constructions were conceived.

当经验的有序性被视为几何学的体现时，检验其与经验的对应性就成为可能。相对论现象的观察，曾被用来作为实验检验，以确定物质宇宙是否是黎曼几何的一个实例。黎曼几何是由爱因斯坦的规则在时空中表述的，并假设轨迹为大地测量学。再以32类对称性和230个空间群为例。32类对称性定义了多面体群，而230个空间群定义了空间中点的无限延伸模式。这些几何构造最初源于对晶体的思考及其原子结构的推测；因此，它们往往会与这些经验事物相关，而我们接受晶体学理论的任何经验依据都必须在对这种参考的后续观察中找到。

When experienced orderliness is taken to be an embodiment of geometry, it may become possible to test its correspondence to experience. The observation of relativistic phenomena has served as an experimental test for deciding whether the material universe was an instance of Riemann’s geometry formulated in space-time by Einstein’s rules, when combined with the assumption of trajectories being geodetics. Take again our 32 classes of symmetry and the 230 space groups. The 32 classes define groups of polyhedra and the 230 space groups define indefinitely extended patterns of points in space. These geometrical constructions were originally initiated by a contemplation of crystals and speculations about their atomic structure; hence they will tend to refer to these matters of experience, and it is in the following up of this reference by observation that any empirical grounds for our acceptance of crystallographic theory must be found.

为了简洁起见，我将主要讨论空间群理论。假设这230个群的推论在其自身前提上是正确的；那么经验只能告诉我们，世界上是否存在体现这些前提的原子结构实例。可能存在无数不体现这些前提的物体，其中甚至有一些（如无序固溶体）会形成外部形状良好的晶体；但这不会揭示任何内部的不一致性，因此不会给理论带来困扰。因此，任何可以想象的事件都无法证伪该理论。我已经暗示过，晶体学理论与经验的关系，在这方面类似于替代几何与实际经验宇宙之间的关系。但理论与经验的两种关系之间一个明显的区别在于：只有一个物质宇宙可以作为众多可能几何图形之一的实例，而存在着大量的晶体，每一个晶体都是230个可能空间群中的一个实例，共同构成一个单一的理论。在这方面，理论与经验的关系更类似于分类系统（例如动物学家或植物学家使用的分类系统）与它们所分类的标本之间的关系。但鉴于目前的分类是基于先前的几何秩序理论，理论与经验的关系或许更类似于一件艺术作品所建立的关系，它让我们从自身的角度看待经验。

For the sake of brevity I shall limit my discussion mainly to the theory of space groups. Supposing that the deduction of the 230 groups is, on its own premises, correct; then experience can only teach us whether or not there are in the world instances of atomic structure which embody these premises. There may exist an infinite range of bodies which do not embody them, among them even some (like disorderly solid solutions) which form externally well-shaped crystals; yet this would reveal no internal inconsistency and therefore cause no embarrassment to the theory. Therefore, no conceivable event could falsify this theory. I have already hinted that the relation of crystallographic theory to experience is similar in this respect to that between alternative geometries and the actually experienced universe. But an obvious difference between the two relations of theory and experience lies in the fact that there exists only one single material universe which can serve as an instance of one among many possible geometries, while there exist a great many crystals, each of which is an instance of one out of 230 possible space groups, comprising together one unitary theory. The relation of theory to experience is in this respect more akin to that between a classificatory system, such as that used by zoologists or botanists, and the specimens classified by them. But in view of the fact that the classification is based in the present case on an antecedent geometrical theory of order, the relation between theory and experience is perhaps even more akin to that established by a work of art which makes us see experience in its own light.

如果一个物体一旦被确定属于其某一类别，就能告诉我们很多关于它的信息，那么分类就具有重要意义。可以说，这样的系统是根据物体的独特性质对其进行分类的。230个空间群的独特性，就像32个晶体对称类的独特性一样，纯粹取决于我们对秩序的理解；它们以特定的对称性体现了我们必然赋予个人秩序概念的普遍性主张。然而，正如一般的晶体几何理论一样，该系统的分类功能充分证明了其正确性。它控制着大量晶体样本的收集、描述和结构分析，并得到了用于区分这些样本的物理和化学特性的充分证实。它已证明自己是一个自然的分类原则。

A classification is significant if it tells us a great deal about an object once this is identified as belonging to one of its classes. Such a system may be said to classify objects according to their distinctive nature. The distinctiveness of the 230 space groups, like that of the 32 classes of crystal symmetry, rests purely on our appreciation of order; they embody in terms of specific symmetries the claim to universality which we necessarily attach to our personal conceptions of order. Yet this system was supremely vindicated, as was the geometrical theory of crystals in general, by its classificatory functions. It has controlled the collection, description and structural analysis of an immense number of crystalline specimens and has been richly corroborated by the physical and chemical characteristics which are found to distinguish these specimens. It has proved itself a natural classificatory principle.

这里揭示了一个对理解经验具有巨大价值的知识体系，而可证伪性的概念似乎完全不适用于它。理论未描述的事实不会给理论带来任何困难，因为它认为这些事实与自身无关。这样的理论就像一种全面的语言，它巩固了与其相关的经验，而忽略了它未理解的一切。

Here stands revealed a system of knowledge of immense value for the understanding of experience, to which the conception of falsifiability seems altogether inapplicable. Facts which are not described by the theory create no difficulty for the theory, for it regards them as irrelevant to itself. Such a theory functions as a comprehensive idiom which consolidates that experience to which it is apposite and leaves unheeded whatever is not comprehended by it.

将晶体学理论应用于经验，就如同在行进队列前演奏的进行曲一样，面临经验反驳的风险。如果歌曲不贴切，就不会受到欢迎。从这个意义上说，晶体学理论可以说超越了它所适用的经验。但这种超越性使得经验理论无法被经验驳斥，当然存在于每一种理想化形式中。理想气体理论不能被观察到的偏差所推翻，只要这些偏差是我们应该忽略的那种。这种理想化实际上表达了同一种沉思式理解的元素，先验地构建和接受一个完整的对称系统就是一个完整的例子。只有当我们相信自己能够理解自然界中某种基本有序性，而这种有序性是自然界一些不那么有序的表象的基础时，我们才会被理想气体的概念所吸引。但在晶体对称性理论中，理想化超越了这一点。因为该体系所发展出的卓越标准，其内在意义远超公式pv=RT本身所能宣称的。它不仅仅是一种科学的理想化，更是美学理想的形式化，与艺术和艺术批评领域所遵循的那种更深层次、永不僵化的感性密切相关。正因如此，该理论教会我们欣赏某些事物，无论我们能否在自然界中找到它们；也允许我们在发现它们时，根据它们是否符合该理论为自然设定的标准进行批判。

The application of crystallographic theory to experience is open to the hazards of empirical refutation only in the same sense as a marching song played by the band at the head of a marching column. If it is not found apposite it will not be popular. Crystallographic theory may in this sense be said to transcend the experience to which it applies. But transcendence which renders an empirical theory irrefutable by experience is of course present in every form of idealization. The theory of ideal gases cannot be disproved by observed deviations from it, so long as they are of the kind which we are supposed to disregard. Such idealizations do in fact express an element of the same contemplative appreciation of which the a priori construction and acceptance of a complete system of symmetries is a fully constituted example. We can be legitimately attracted by the concept of ideal gases only in as much as we believe in our capacity for appreciating a kind of fundamental orderliness in nature which underlies some of its less orderly appearances. But in the theory of crystal symmetries idealization goes beyond this. For the standards of excellence which are developed by this system possess a much higher degree of intrinsic significance than the formula pv=RT may claim for itself. It is not merely a scientific idealization but the formalization of an aesthetic ideal, closely akin to that deeper and never rigidly definable sensibility by which the domains of art and art-criticism are governed. That is why this theory teaches us to appreciate certain things, regardless of whether we may find any of their kind in nature, and allows us also to criticize these things when we find them, to the extent to which they fall short of the standards which the theory sets for nature.

我们在此看到了一种实质性的替代，它既可以取代通常的客观陈述与主观陈述之间的分离，也可以取代分析陈述与综合陈述之间的分离。通过认可我们在精确自然科学领域内进行具有普遍意义的有效评估的能力，我们或许可以避免这些传统范畴所造成的贫瘠和混乱。

We see emerging here a substantial alternative to the usual disjunction of objective and subjective statements, as well as to the disjunction between analytic and synthetic statements. By accrediting our capacity to make valid appraisals of universal bearing within the exact natural sciences, we may yet avoid the sterility and confusion imposed by these traditional categories.

 

 

4

4

技能

SKILLS

 

 

  1. 技能的实践
  2. THE PRACTICE OF SKILLS

精密科学是一套与经验相关的公式。我们已经看到，在认可这种经验时，我们必须在不同程度上依赖个人认知能力。现在，我将尝试通过分析这些个人行为中蕴含的力量，进一步阐明其结构。科学的运作依赖于科学家的技能，而科学家正是通过运用技能来塑造其科学知识。因此，我们可以通过考察技能的结构来把握科学家个人参与的本质。

THE exact sciences are a set of formulae which have a bearing on experience. We have seen that in accrediting this bearing, we must rely to varying degrees on our powers of personal knowing. I shall now try to elucidate the structure of such personal acts further, by analysing the forces engaged in them. Science is operated by the skill of the scientist and it is through the exercise of his skill that he shapes his scientific knowledge. We may grasp, therefore, the nature of the scientist’s personal participation by examining the structure of skills.

我将以一个众所周知的事实作为本次调查的线索，即熟练表演的目的是通过遵守一套规则来达到的，而遵守这些规则的人并不知道这些规则。例如，游泳者保持漂浮的决定性因素是他调节呼吸的方式；他通过在呼气时避免排空肺部、在吸气时比平时更多地充气来保持较高的浮力：然而游泳者一般不知道这一点。一位著名的科学家，年轻时不得不靠教游泳来维持生计，他告诉我，当他试图发现是什么让他游泳时，他是多么困惑；无论他在水里做什么，他总是保持漂浮。

I shall take as my clue for this investigation the well-known fact that the aim of a skilful performance is achieved by the observance of a set of rules which are not known as such to the person following them. For example, the decisive factor by which the swimmer keeps himself afloat is the manner by which he regulates his respiration; he keeps his buoyancy at an increased level by refraining from emptying his lungs when breathing out and by inflating them more than usual when breathing in: yet this is not generally known to swimmers. A well-known scientist, who in his youth had to support himself by giving swimming lessons, told me how puzzled he was when he tried to discover what made him swim; whatever he tried to do in the water, he always kept afloat.

再次，通过询问物理学家、工程师和自行车制造商，我得出结论：骑车人保持平衡的原理并不为人所知。骑车人遵循的规则是：当他开始向右倾倒时，他会将车把向右转动，这样自行车的轨迹就会沿着一条向右的曲线偏转。这会导致离心力将骑车人推向左侧，并抵消将他向右拖拽的重力。这一动作会立即使骑车人失去平衡，他可以通过向左转动车把来抵消这一平衡；因此，他通过沿着一系列适当的曲线继续保持平衡。简单的分析表明，对于给定的不平衡角度，每次弯曲的曲率与骑车人行进速度的平方成反比。

Again, from my interrogations of physicists, engineers and bicycle manufacturers, I have come to the conclusion that the principle by which the cyclist keeps his balance is not generally known. The rule observed by the cyclist is this. When he starts falling to the right he turns the handle- bars to the right, so that the course of the bicycle is deflected along a curve towards the right. This results in a centrifugal force pushing the cyclist to the left and offsets the gravitational force dragging him down to the right. This manœuvre presently throws the cyclist out of balance to the left, which he counteracts by turning the handlebars to the left; and so he continues to keep himself in balance by winding along a series of appropriate curvatures. A simple analysis shows that for a given angle of unbalance the curvature of each winding is inversely proportional to the square of the speed at which the cyclist is proceeding.

但这真的能告诉我们如何骑自行车吗？不能。你显然无法根据你的不平衡量与速度平方的比值来调整自行车路径的曲率；如果你能做到，你就会从车上摔下来，因为在实践中还有很多其他因素需要考虑，而这条规则的制定却忽略了它们。艺术规则可能有用，但它们并不能决定艺术的实践；它们是格言，只有融入艺术的实践知识中，才能成为艺术的指南。它们无法取代实践知识。

But does this tell us exactly how to ride a bicycle? No. You obviously cannot adjust the curvature of your bicycle’s path in proportion to the ratio of your unbalance over the square of your speed; and if you could you would fall off the machine, for there are a number of other factors to be taken into account in practice which are left out in the formulation of this rule. Rules of art can be useful, but they do not determine the practice of an art; they are maxims, which can serve as a guide to an art only if they can be integrated into the practical knowledge of the art. They cannot replace this knowledge.

 

 

  1. 破坏性分析
  2. DESTRUCTIVE ANALYSIS

技能无法完全从细节上进行解释，这可能导致判断一场精湛的演奏是否真实存在面临严重困难。关于钢琴家“触感”的广泛争议可以作为一个例子。音乐家们认为，根据钢琴家的“触感”，钢琴上音符的发声方式可以多种多样，这是一个显而易见的事实。掌握正确的触感是每个学习者的努力方向，成熟的艺术家将掌握这种触感视为其主要成就之一。钢琴家的触感受到公众和学生的一致推崇：它具有极高的金钱价值。然而，当分析钢琴发声的过程时，似乎很难解释“触感”的存在。按下琴键时，琴槌会运动并敲击琴弦。按下的琴键只会推动琴槌一小段距离，从而使其自由运动，最终被弦音阻止。因此，有人认为，琴槌对弦的影响完全取决于琴槌在敲击弦时自由运动的速度。随着速度的变化，和弦的音调会或多或少地响亮。由于泛音成分的同时变化，音调的音色等也可能随之变化，但琴槌获得特定速度的方式应该不会产生任何影响。因此，初学者和演奏大师在特定钢琴上弹奏的音调之间应该没有任何区别；钢琴家演奏中最有价值的品质之一将完全丧失。这确实是你在标准教科书中找到的结论，例如Jeans的《科学与音乐》（1937年）和A.Wood的《音乐物理学》（1944年）。然而，这一结果错误地依赖于对钢琴家技能的不完整分析。 J.Baron 和 J.Hollo 已经证明了这一点（令我满意），他们提请注意当钢琴上的所有和弦都被移除时按下琴键所发出的噪音。40这种噪音可以在琴槌敲击速度不变的情况下发生变化。噪音与琴槌敲击弦弦发出的音符交织在一起，改变了音质。这似乎从原理上解释了钢琴家如何通过触键艺术来控制钢琴音调。

The fact that skills cannot be fully accounted for in terms of their particulars may lead to serious difficulties in judging whether or not a skilful performance is genuine. The extensive controversy on the ‘touch’ of pianists may serve as an example. Musicians regard it as a glaringly obvious fact that the sounding of a note on the piano can be done in different ways, depending on the ‘touch’ of the pianist. To acquire the right touch is the endeavour of every learner, and the mature artist counts its possession among his chief accomplishments. A pianist’s touch is prized alike by the public and by his pupils: it has a great value in money. Yet when the process of sounding a note on the piano is analysed, it appears difficult to account for the existence of ‘touch’. When a key is depressed, a hammer is set in motion which hits a string. The hammer is pushed by the depressed key only for a short distance and is thereby flung into free motion, which is eventually stopped by the chord. Therefore, it is argued, the effect of the hammer on the chord is fully determined by the speed of the hammer in free motion at the moment when it hits the chord. As this speed varies, the note of the chord will sound more or less loudly. This may be accompanied by changes in colour, etc., owing to concurrent changes in the composition of overtones, but it should make no difference in what manner the hammer acquired any particular speed. Accordingly, there could be no difference as between tyro and virtuoso in the tone of the notes which they strike on a given piano; one of the most valued qualities of the pianist’s performance would be utterly discredited. Such is indeed the conclusion you find in standard textbooks like Jeans’ Science and Music (1937) and A.Wood’s Physics of Music (1944). Yet this result relies erroneously on an incomplete analysis of the pianist’s skill. This has been demonstrated (to my satisfaction) by J.Baron and J.Hollo, who called attention to the noise that the depression of a key makes when all chords are removed from a piano.40 This noise can be varied while the speed imparted to the hammer remains unaltered. The noise mingles with the note sounded by the hammer on the chord and modifies its quality, and this seems to account in principle for the pianist’s capacity to control the tone of the piano by the art of his touch.

这个例子应该代表许多其他例子，它们都传递着同样的道理：仅仅因为我们无法用我们迄今为止接受的框架来理解某件事是如何完成或发生的，就否定它据称已经完成的可行性，或否定某个事件据称已经观察到的可能性，这往往会导致我们用解释的方式抹杀真正的实践或经验。然而，这种批判方法不可或缺，如果没有持续的运用，任何科学家或技术人员都无法在每天不得不抛开的众多未经解释的虚假观察中保持稳定。

This example should stand for many others which teach the same lesson; namely that to deny the feasibility of something that is alleged to have been done or the possibility of an event that is supposed to have been observed, merely because we cannot understand in terms of our hitherto accepted framework how it could have been done or could have happened, may often result in explaining away quite genuine practices or experiences. Yet this method of criticism is indispensable, and without its constant exercise no scientist or technician could keep a steady course among the many spurious observations which he has to set aside unexplained every day.

破坏性分析仍然是对抗迷信和似是而非做法的不可或缺的武器。以顺势疗法为例。在我看来，仅仅分析一下顺势疗法的宣传，就能彻底驳斥这种至今仍在广泛实践的所谓疗法的有效性。顺势疗法处方证据表明，用于顺势疗法的药物可以稀释到与普通食物和饮用水中相同的浓度，甚至更低；因此，再服用一勺同样稀释的药物，似乎不可能产生医学效果。

Destructive analysis remains also an indispensable weapon against superstition and specious practices. Take for example homeopathy. In this case the efficacity of an alleged art, still widely practised today, can be wholly refuted, in my opinion, by a mere analysis of its claims. Medicinal substances used homeopathically can be shown, on the evidence of homeopathic prescriptions, to be diluted to concentrations as low as, or below that, in which they are present in ordinary food and drinking water; it seems impossible that an additional spoonful of them administered in a similar dilution would be medically effective.

如果一项新技能的有效性存疑，而其发现者对其做出了错误的解读，就可能陷入绝境。从梅斯梅尔到布雷德，催眠术先驱们的惨痛失败就说明了这一点。梅斯梅尔的批评者，以及后来艾略特森的批评者，都很容易证明这些人声称自己正在实施的那些操作本身是无效的。艾略特森阐述了一整套关于所谓的动物磁力传递的定律。他声称，一杯水的磁力可以通过将一根手指、两根手指或整只手伸入水中来评估，而饮用这杯水会导致僵硬性恍惚。另一条“定律”宣称，受试者的黏膜表面，例如舌头或眼球表面，能够比皮肤接收更强烈的催眠刺激。后来，艾略特森宣布，金和镍比铅等贱金属对催眠的影响更敏感。所有这些都是胡说八道，而且很容易被证明是胡说八道。由于当时还没有人意识到催眠暗示是梅斯梅尔疗法的有效手段，因此得出的结论似乎不可避免：艾略特森的实验对象都是骗子，要么在欺骗他，要么在与他勾结。 41艾略特森苦苦哀求，但徒劳无功：“我已经以常识和人道的名义详细介绍了 76 例无痛手术，还想要什么呢？”四十二直到催眠的概念被确立为事实的框架，这些事实才最终被承认为真理。事实上，每当真理与谬误融合在一个连贯的概念体系中时，对该体系的破坏性分析只有在新的发现的补充下才能得出正确的结论。然而，并不存在任何规则来获得新的发现或发明更真实的概念，因此，也不存在任何规则来避免破坏性分析的不确定性。

A desperate situation may arise if a new skill, the efficacy of which is open to doubt, is given a false interpretation by its discoverers. This is illustrated by the tragic failures of the pioneers of hypnotism during the century from Mesmer to Braid. The critics of Mesmer and later of Elliotson found it easy to demonstrate that the manipulations which these men said they were performing were in themselves ineffectual. Elliotson had expounded a whole system of laws governing the alleged transmission of animal magnetism. He claimed that the magnetism of a glass of water, the drinking of which caused cataleptic trance, could be graded by dipping one finger into it, or two fingers, or the whole hand. Another ‘law’ declared that mucous surfaces of the subject, like those of the tongue or the eyeball, were capable of receiving a greater mesmeric stimulus than the skin. Later Elliotson announced that gold and nickel were more sensitive to mesmeric influences than base metals like lead. All this was nonsense and was easily proved to be nonsense. And since the assumption had not yet dawned upon anyone that hypnotic suggestion was the effective agent of Mesmerism, the conclusion seemed inevitable that Elliotson’s subjects were impostors, who were either deluding him or colluding with him.41 In vain did Elliotson bitterly appeal: ‘I have given details of 76 painless operations in the name of common sense and humanity, what more is wanted?’42 Not until the concept of hypnosis was established as a framework for the facts, could these facts be eventually admitted to be true. Indeed, whenever truth and error are amalgamated in a coherent system of conceptions, the destructive analysis of the system can lead to correct conclusions only when supplemented by new discoveries. But there exists no rule for making fresh discoveries or inventing truer conceptions, and hence there can be no rule, either, for avoiding the uncertainty of destructive analysis.

过去几十年来，技术研究实验室一直在不断推动一种类似于批判催眠术的进程，但没有明显的失败。大型工业，例如制革厂、陶器厂或钢铁厂，啤酒厂和各种纺织厂，以及农业及其众多分支，如今都意识到，它们在以艺术的方式开展活动，却对构成这些活动的具体操作一无所知。当现代科学研究应用于这些传统工业时，首先面临的任务是发现其中究竟发生了什么，以及这些产品是如何生产的。早在1920年，W·L·鲍尔斯（W.L. Balls）在棉纺科学研究中就深刻地认识到了这种情况。43迄今为止，纺球的实践被描述为“一件自成一体的事情，几乎与物理知识毫无关联”，因此“科学家最初十年的大部分工作将不得不仅仅花在定义纺纱工的知识上”。时任雪莉研究所（世界领先的棉花研究实验室）所长的FCToy博士向我证实了这一预测。四十四试图对既有的工业技术进行科学分析，到处都导致了类似的结果。事实上，即使在现代工业中，那些难以定义的知识仍然是技术的重要组成部分。我曾在匈牙利亲眼目睹过一台新进口的吹泡机，而这台机器与德国的机器一模一样，在德国运行良好，却整整一年都未能生产出一个完美的灯泡。

A process similar to that of the critique of Mesmerism, but without its obvious miscarriages, has been continuously fostered during the past decades by technical research laboratories. Great industries, like the tanneries, the potteries or steel mills, like the breweries and the whole range of textile manufactures, as well as agriculture in its numberless branches, have realized in these days that they were carrying on their activities in the manner of an art without any clear knowledge of the constituent detailed operations. When modern scientific research was applied to these traditional industries it was faced in the first place with the task of discovering what actually was going on there and how it was that it produced the goods. This situation was penetratingly recognized from the start as early as 1920 by W.L.Balls for the scientific study of cotton spinning.43 The hitherto accepted practice of spinning Balls described as ‘a thing in itself, scarcely related to physical knowledge at all’, so that ‘most of the initial decade’s work on the part of the scientist will have to be spent merely in defining what the spinner knows’. This prediction was confirmed to me by Dr. F.C.Toy, then Director of the Shirley Institute, the world’s leading cotton research laboratory.44 The attempt to analyse scientifically the established industrial arts has everywhere led to similar results. Indeed even in the modern industries the indefinable knowledge is still an essential part of technology. I have myself watched in Hungary a new, imported machine for blowing electric lamp bulbs, the exact counterpart of which was operating successfully in Germany, failing for a whole year to produce a single flawless bulb.

 

 

3. 传统

3. TRADITION

一门无法详细阐述的技艺无法通过规定传承，因为它本身并无规定。它只能通过师傅传给学徒，通过示范。这使得传播范围仅限于个人接触，因此我们发现，手工艺往往在严格限制的当地传统中得以传承。事实上，手工艺从一个国家传播到另一个国家，通常可以追溯到工匠群体的迁徙，例如路易十四时期因废除南特敕令而被驱逐出法国的胡格诺派教徒。此外，虽然清晰的科学内容在世界各地数百所新建大学中得到成功教授，但难以具体阐述的科学研究技艺尚未渗透到其中许多大学。400年前，科学方法首次起源于欧洲的地区，尽管如今仍然贫困，但在科学方面仍然比一些科研资金充裕的海外地区更加富有成果。如果没有为年轻科学家提供在欧洲接受学徒培训的机会，如果没有欧洲科学家移居到新的国家，海外研究中心几乎不可能取得太大的进展。

An art which cannot be specified in detail cannot be transmitted by prescription, since no prescription for it exists. It can be passed on only by example from master to apprentice. This restricts the range of diffusion to that of personal contacts, and we find accordingly that craftsmanship tends to survive in closely circumscribed local traditions. Indeed, the diffusion of crafts from one country to another can often be traced to the migration of groups of craftsmen, as that of the Huguenots driven from France by the repeal of the Edict of Nantes under Louis XIV. Again, while the articulate contents of science are successfully taught all over the world in hundreds of new universities, the unspecifiable art of scientific research has not yet penetrated to many of these. The regions of Europe in which the scientific method first originated 400 years ago are scientifically still more fruitful today, in spite of their impoverishment, than several overseas areas where much more money is available for scientific research. Without the opportunity offered to young scientists to serve an apprenticeship in Europe, and without the migration of European scientists to the new countries, research centres overseas could hardly ever have made much headway.

因此，一门艺术如果在一代人的时间里被废弃，就彻底失传了。这样的例子数以百计，而机械化进程又不断增添新的。这些损失通常是无法挽回的。看着人们用显微镜、化学、数学和电子技术，无休止地复制一把200多年前那位半文盲的斯特拉迪瓦里小提琴，这简直是家常便饭，真是令人唏嘘。

It follows that an art which has fallen into disuse for the period of a generation is altogether lost. There are hundreds of examples of this to which the process of mechanization is continuously adding new ones. These losses are usually irretrievable. It is pathetic to watch the endless efforts—equipped with microscopy and chemistry, with mathematics and electronics—to reproduce a single violin of the kind the half-literate Stradivarius turned out as a matter of routine more than 200 years ago.

以身作则就是服从权威。你追随师傅，是因为你信任他的做事方式，即使你无法详细分析和解释其有效性。通过观察师傅，并在师傅的示范下效仿他的努力，学徒无意识地掌握了技艺的规则，包括那些师傅本人并不明确知晓的规则。这些潜规则只有那些完全臣服于他人模仿的人才能吸收。一个想要保存个人知识储备的社会，必须遵循传统。

To learn by example is to submit to authority. You follow your master because you trust his manner of doing things even when you cannot analyse and account in detail for its effectiveness. By watching the master and emulating his efforts in the presence of his example, the apprentice unconsciously picks up the rules of the art, including those which are not explicitly known to the master himself. These hidden rules can be assimilated only by a person who surrenders himself to that extent uncritically to the imitation of another. A society which wants to preserve a fund of personal knowledge must submit to tradition.

实际上，如果我们的智力达不到精确形式化的理想水平，我们就会根据无法具体说明的知识来行动和观察，并且必须承认，我们接受我们个人评价的结论，无论是依靠我们自己的判断做出的第一手资料，还是通过服从作为传统载体的个人榜样的权威而做出的第二手资料。

In effect, to the extent to which our intelligence falls short of the ideal of precise formalization, we act and see by the light of unspecifiable knowledge and must acknowledge that we accept the verdict of our personal appraisal, be it at first hand by relying on our own judgment, or at second hand by submitting to the authority of a personal example as carrier of a tradition.

传统主义的主题在此无法详尽探讨；但传统程序的一些特点对于理解个人知识至关重要。这些特点可以在普通法的实践中找到，而普通法是最重要的严格推理的传统活动体系。普通法建立在先例之上。如今，法院在裁决案件时，会效仿过去裁决过类似案件的其他法院的做法，因为在这些行动中，法院看到了法律规则的体现。这一程序承认了所有传统主义的原则，即实践智慧更真实地体现在行动中，而不是在行动规则中表达。因此，普通法允许法官错误地解释其自身行为的可能性。有时被称为“格言主义”的司法准则规定，先例由法院的判决构成，无论作出判决的法官在其附带意见中对其的解释如何。法官的行为被认为比他所说的更为真实。 45

The subject of traditionalism cannot be pursued at length here; but some peculiarities of traditional procedure are of immediate interest for the understanding of personal knowledge. They are to be found in the practice of the Common Law, which is the most important system of strictly reasoned traditional activities. Common Law is founded on precedent. In deciding a case today the Courts will follow the example of other courts which have decided similar cases in the past, for in these actions they see embodied the rules of the law. This procedure recognizes the principle of all traditionalism that practical wisdom is more truly embodied in action than expressed in rules of action. Accordingly, the Common Law allows for the possibility that a judge may interpret his own action mistakenly. The judicial maxim which sometimes goes by the name of the ‘doctrine of the dictum’ lays it down that a precedent is constituted by the decision of a court, irrespective of its interpretation implied in any obiter dicta of the judge who made the decision. The judge’s action is considered more authentic than what he said he was doing.45

在十七、十八世纪，英国的公共生活发展出了一种政治艺术和一种政治学说。体现公共自由实践的艺术自然是不可具体化的，政治自由的学说是这门艺术的准则，只有精通该领域的人才能真正理解。然而，政治自由的学说在十八世纪从英国传到了法国，进而传遍了世界各地，而公共自由的不可具体化的实践艺术却只能通过传统传承，并未随之传播。当法国革命者践行这一学说时，如果缺乏实践应用的知识，这一学说就毫无意义。伯克以传统主义的自由社会观来反驳他们。

In the course of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries British public life developed a political art and a political doctrine. The art which embodied the exercise of public liberties was naturally unspecifiable, the doctrines of political liberty were maxims of this art which could be properly understood only by those skilled in the art. But the doctrines of political freedom spread from England in the eighteenth century to France and thence throughout the world, while the unspecifiable art of exercising public liberty, being communicable only by tradition, was not transmitted with it. When the French Revolutionaries acted on this doctrine, which was meaningless without a knowledge of its application in practice, Burke opposed them by a traditionalist conception of a free society.

 

 

  1. 鉴赏力
  2. CONNOISSEURSHIP

关于技能的论述同样适用于鉴赏家。医学诊断师的技能既是一门实践的艺术，也是一门认知的艺术。测试和品尝的技能与更活跃的肌肉技能（例如游泳或骑自行车）相衔接。

What has been said of skills applies equally to connoisseurship. The medical diagnostician’s skill is as much an art of doing as it is an art of knowing. The skill of testing and tasting is continuous with the more actively muscular skills, like swimming or riding a bicycle.

鉴赏力如同技能，只能通过言传身教，而非言传身教。要想成为专业的品酒师，掌握无数种不同茶的混合知识，或是成为一名医学诊断师，你必须在大师的指导下，经历漫长的实践过程。除非医生能够识别某些症状，

Connoisseurship, like skill, can be communicated only by example, not by precept. To become an expert wine-taster, to acquire a knowledge of innumerable different blends of tea or to be trained as a medical diagnostician, you must go through a long course of experience under the guidance of a master. Unless a doctor can recognize certain symptoms,

例如，肺动脉第二音增强，阅读包含该症状的综合征描述毫无意义。他必须亲自了解该症状，而要做到这一点，只有反复听诊已知存在该症状的病例，并对照已知不存在该症状的其他病例，直到他完全理解它们之间的区别，并能够以专家满意的方式实际展示他的知识。

e.g. the accentuation of the second sound of the pulmonary artery, there is no use in his reading the description of syndromes of which this symptom forms part. He must personally know that symptom and he can learn this only by repeatedly being given cases for auscultation in which the symptom is authoritatively known to be present, side by side with other cases in which it is authoritatively known to be absent, until he has fully realized the difference between them and can demonstrate his knowledge practically to the satisfaction of an expert.

在科学或技术领域，只要存在鉴赏力，我们就可以假设它之所以存在，只是因为无法用可衡量的等级来取代它。测量的优势在于它更加客观，这一点从世界各地不同观察者测量结果一致这一事实可以看出来，而相貌鉴定却很少能达到这种客观性。46化学、生物和医学专业的学生在实践课程上花费了大量时间，这表明这些学科在多大程度上依赖于师徒之间的技能和鉴赏力的传承。这令人印象深刻地证明了，在科学的核心中，认知的艺术在多大程度上仍然是难以定义的。

Wherever connoisseurship is found operating within science or technology we may assume that it persists only because it has not been possible to replace it by a measurable grading. For a measurement has the advantage of greater objectivity, as shown by the fact that measurements give consistent results in the hands of different observers all over the world, while such objectivity is rarely achieved in the case of physiognomic appreciations.46 The large amount of time spent by students of chemistry, biology and medicine in their practical courses shows how greatly these sciences rely on the transmission of skills and connoisseurship from master to apprentice. It offers an impressive demonstration of the extent to which the art of knowing has remained unspecifiable at the very heart of science.

 

 

  1. 两种意识
  2. TWO KINDS OF AWARENESS

我之前关于技能的不可指定性的观点与格式塔心理学的发现密切相关。然而，我对这些内容的评价与格式塔理论截然不同，因此我倾向于在此不提及该理论，尽管我将继续探讨其领域，并沿着与其教义密切相关的思路进行一些论证。在分析我们经常讨论的使用工具时的情况时，例如用锤子敲入钉子时，应该牢记这一点。

What I have said of the unspecifiability of skills is closely related to the findings of Gestalt psychology. Yet my evaluation of this material is so different from that of Gestalt theory, that I shall prefer not to refer here to this theory, even though I shall continue to draw on its domain and pursue some arguments on lines closely parallel to that of its teachings. This should be borne in mind for the following analysis of the often discussed situation in which we find ourselves when using a tool, for example when driving in a nail by the strokes of a hammer.

当我们用锤子敲钉子时，我们会同时关注钉子和锤子，但方式不同。我们会观察敲击钉子的效果，并尝试以最有效的方式挥动锤子。当我们放下锤子时，我们感觉不到锤柄击中了手掌，而是锤头击中了钉子。然而，从某种意义上说，我们确实对手掌和握着锤子的手指的感觉保持警觉。它们引导我们有效地使用锤子，我们对钉子的关注程度与对这些感觉的关注程度相同，只是方式不同。区别在于，这些感觉不像钉子，不是我们关注的对象，而是我们关注的工具。它们本身并非被观察；我们在观察其他事物的同时，也对它们保持着强烈的意识。我对手掌的感觉有一种辅助意识，这种意识融入了我对敲钉子的专注意识中。

When we use a hammer to drive in a nail, we attend to both nail and hammer, but in a different way. We watch the effect of our strokes on the nail and try to wield the hammer so as to hit the nail most effectively. When we bring down the hammer we do not feel that its handle has struck our palm but that its head has struck the nail. Yet in a sense we are certainly alert to the feelings in our palm and the fingers that hold the hammer. They guide us in handling it effectively, and the degree of attention that we give to the nail is given to the same extent but in a different way to these feelings. The difference may be stated by saying that the latter are not, like the nail, objects of our attention, but instruments of it. They are not watched in themselves; we watch something else while keeping intensely aware of them. I have a subsidiary awareness of the feeling in the palm of my hand which is merged into my focal awareness of my driving in the nail.

我们不妨设想用探针代替锤子，用来探索隐秘洞穴的内部。想想盲人如何用棍子摸索前进，这需要将传递到他手部和握棍肌肉的冲击转化为对棍尖所触及事物的意识。我们在此看到了从“知道如何”到“知道什么”的转变，并且可以看出两者的结构有多么相似。

We may think of the hammer replaced by a probe, used for exploring the interior of a hidden cavity. Think how a blind man feels his way by the use of a stick, which involves transposing the shocks transmitted to his hand and the muscles holding the stick into an awareness of the things touched by the point of the stick. We have here the transition from ‘knowing how’ to ‘knowing what’ and can see how closely similar is the structure of the two.

辅助意识和焦点意识是相互排斥的。如果一位钢琴家将注意力从正在演奏的乐曲转移到观察自己演奏时手指的动作，他就会感到困惑，甚至可能不得不停下来。四十七如果我们将注意力转移到我们之前只意识到其次要作用的细节上，通常会发生这种情况。

Subsidiary awareness and focal awareness are mutually exclusive. If a pianist shifts his attention from the piece he is playing to the observation of what he is doing with his fingers while playing it, he gets confused and may have to stop.47 This happens generally if we switch our focal attention to particulars of which we had previously been aware only in their subsidiary role.

那种由于注意力过于集中于动作的次要元素而导致的笨拙，通常被称为自我意识。其中一种严重且有时无法治愈的形式是“怯场”，它似乎表现为焦虑地将注意力集中在下一个必须找到或记住的单词、音符或手势上。这会破坏人们对语境的感知，而只有语境才能流畅地唤起单词、音符或手势的正确顺序。如果我们能够将思绪向前，并清晰地关注我们主要感兴趣的综合活动，就能消除怯场，恢复流畅的表达。

The kind of clumsiness which is due to the fact that focal attention is directed to the subsidiary elements of an action is commonly known as self-consciousness. A serious and sometimes incurable form of it is ‘stage-fright’, which seems to consist in the anxious riveting of one’s attention to the next word—or note or gesture—that one has to find or remember. This destroys one’s sense of the context which alone can smoothly evoke the proper sequence of words, notes, or gestures. Stage fright is eliminated and fluency recovered if we succeed in casting our mind forward and let it operate with a clear view to the comprehensive activity in which we are primarily interested.

在这里，技能的细节再次显得不可具体化，但这次并非指我们对其一无所知。因为在这种情况下，我们能够相当准确地确定我们执行的细节，而其不可具体化之处在于，如果我们将注意力集中在这些细节上，执行就会陷入瘫痪。我们可以将这种执行描述为逻辑上不可具体化，因为我们可以证明，在某种意义上，对细节的具体化在逻辑上与所讨论的执行或语境中隐含的内容相矛盾。

Here again the particulars of a skill appear to be unspecifiable, but this time not in the sense of our being ignorant of them. For in this case we can ascertain the details of our performance quite well, and its unspecifiability consists in the fact that the performance is paralysed if we focus our attention on these details. We may describe such a performance as logically unspecifiable, for we can show that in a sense the specification of the particulars would logically contradict what is implied in the performance or context in question.

以将某物认定为工具为例。这意味着可以通过将该物作为工具来实现有用的目的。如果我不知道该物的用途，我就无法将该物认定为工具——或者，如果我知道它的假定用途，但我认为它对此毫无用处。让我用p来表示将某物认定为工具时所隐含的断言。如果我知道或至少假设性地接受p，那么对我来说，该物就是工具；如果不是，它就是别的东西。它可能是一种动物，就像爱丽丝的槌球锤，因为它是一只火烈鸟而走开了。但在大多数情况下，如果我遇到一个我不知道其用途的工具，它只会给我一种形状奇特的物体的印象。仅仅将其视为这样就意味着我不相信甚至没有假设性地接受p；这当然否认了我相信或至少假设性地接受p 。而且由于p断言了一些非常不常见的事情，我不相信p实际上就等于我断言不p 。

Take for example the identification of a thing as a tool. It implies that a useful purpose can be achieved by handling the thing as an instrument for that purpose. I cannot identify the thing as a tool if I do not know what it is for—or if knowing its supposed purpose, I believe it to be useless for that purpose. Let me denote by p the affirmations which are implied in qualifying a thing as a tool. If I know or at least hypothetically entertain p, the thing is a tool to me; if not, it is something else. It may be an animal, like Alice’s croquet hammer which walked away because it was a flamingo. But in most cases, if I come across a tool of which I do not know the use, it will merely strike me as a peculiarly shaped object. To regard it merely as such is to imply that I do not believe and do not even hypothetically entertain p; which of course denies that I believe or at least hypothetically entertain p. And since p asserts something very uncommon, my not believing p virtually amounts to my asserting not-p.

这个方案的扩展可能允许我们将其应用于格式塔心理学的经典主题，即模式的细节

An extension of this scheme may allow us to apply it also to the classic theme of Gestalt psychology, which is that the particulars of a pattern

或者说，一个曲调必须被综合地理解，因为如果你单独观察细节，它们就不会形成任何模式或曲调。或许有人会说，我关注整个模式或曲调意味着它被理解为一个模式或曲调，而将我的注意力集中在曲调的单个音符或模式的片段上，会与此相矛盾。但或许更合适的做法是用更笼统的术语来表述这种情况下存在的矛盾，即我们的注意力一次只能集中在一个焦点上，因此，同时对同一个细节既有辅助性意识，又有焦点性意识，这本身就是自相矛盾的。

or a tune must be apprehended jointly, for if you observe the particulars separately they form no pattern or tune. It may be argued that my attending to the pattern or tune as a whole implies its being appreciated as a pattern or a tune, and this would be contradicted by switching my focal attention to the single notes of the tune or the fragments of the pattern. But it is perhaps more appropriate to formulate the contradiction in this case in more general terms, by saying that our attention can hold only one focus at a time and that it would hence be self-contradictory to be both subsidiarily and focally aware of the same particulars at the same time.

这个方案很容易在含义上重新表述和扩展。如果我们否定一个工具的实用性，它作为工具的意义就消失了。如果我们忽视它们共同构成的模式，所有细节都将变得毫无意义。

This scheme can be easily reformulated and expanded in terms of meaning. If we discredit the usefulness of a tool, its meaning as a tool is gone. All particulars become meaningless if we lose sight of the pattern which they jointly constitute.

最丰富的意义载体当然是语言中的词汇。回想一下，当我们在口语或写作中使用词汇时，我们只是以一种间接的方式意识到它们，这很有意思。这一事实通常被描述为语言的透明度，可以用我亲身经历的一件家常事来说明。我的早餐桌上收到了各种语言的信件，但我儿子只懂英语。刚读完一封信，我可能想把它转交给他，但必须先检查一下，再看看是用什么语言写的。我清楚地知道信中传达的意思，却对其中的文字一无所知。我仔细地观察它们，但只关注它们的含义，而不是它们作为对象的意义。如果我对文本的理解不够清晰，或者表达或拼写有误，那么文字就会引起我的注意。它们会变得略显晦涩，阻碍我的思维畅通无阻地理解它们所指的内容。

The most pregnant carriers of meaning are of course the words of a language, and it is interesting to recall that when we use words in speech or writing we are aware of them only in a subsidiary manner. This fact, which is usually described as the transparency of language, may be illustrated by a homely episode from my own experience. My correspondence arrives at my breakfast table in various languages, but my son understands only English. Having just finished reading a letter I may wish to pass it on to him, but must check myself and look again to see in what language it was written. I am vividly aware of the meaning conveyed by the letter, yet know nothing whatever of its words. I have attended to them closely but only for what they mean and not for what they are as objects. If my understanding of the text were halting, or its expressions or its spelling were faulty, its words would arrest my attention. They would become slightly opaque and prevent my thought from passing through them unhindered to the things they signify.

 

 

  1. 整体与意义
  2. WHOLES AND MEANINGS

格式塔心理学将物体转化为工具，以及随之而来的感觉转换（例如从手掌到探针的尖端）描述为将部分融入整体的例子。我略加修改地阐述了同样的内容，以便阐明一个人通过刻意将对某些细节的意识融入对整体的焦点意识中，从而致力于某些信念和欣赏，并接受某些意义的逻辑结构。这种逻辑结构在视觉和听觉整体的自动感知中并不明显，而格式塔心理学正是从这种自动感知中得出其普遍的概括的。

Gestalt psychology has described the transformation of an object into a tool and the accompanying transposition of feeling, as for example from the palm to the tip of a probe, as instances of the absorption of a part in a whole. I have covered the same ground in somewhat modified terms in order to bring out the logical structure in which a person commits himself to certain beliefs and appreciations, and accepts certain meanings by deliberately merging his awareness of certain particulars into a focal awareness of a whole. This logical structure is not apparent in the automatic perception of visual and auditory wholes from which Gestalt psychology has derived its prevailing generalizations.

但现在，从部分和整体的角度重新审视我们的分析，将会大有裨益。当我们关注整体时，我们会辅助性地意识到其部分，而这两种意识的强度并无差异。例如，我们越是仔细观察一个人的面相，就越能敏锐地注意到它的细节。同样，当某物被视为整体的附属物时，这意味着它参与了对整体的维系，我们现在可以将这种功能视为它在整体中的意义。

But it is illuminating to recast our analysis now in terms of parts and wholes. When focusing on a whole, we are subsidiarily aware of its parts, while there is no difference in the intensity of the two kinds of awareness. For example, the more sharply we scrutinize a physiognomy, the more keenly are we alert to its particulars. Also when something is seen as subsidiary to a whole, this implies that it participates in sustaining the whole, and we may now regard this function as its meaning, within the whole.

事实上，我们现在看到了两种整体和两种意义。更清晰的意义是指一个事物（例如一个词）意味着另一个事物（例如一个物体）。在这种情况下，相应的整体或许并不明显，但我们可以合理地遵循托尔曼的观点，将符号和物体融合成一个整体。四十八其他类型的事物，例如面相、曲调或图案，显然是整体，但这一次它们的意义却有些成问题，因为尽管它们显然并非毫无意义，但它们的意义只在于自身。两种意识之间的区别使我们能够轻易地认识到这两种整体和两种意义。回想一下棍子的各种用途，例如指点、探索或击打，我们很容易看出，任何在公认的语境中有效运作的事物在该语境中都具有意义，并且任何这样的语境本身都会被视为有意义的。我们可以将语境本身所拥有的意义描述为存在意义，以特别将其与外延意义或更普遍的代表性意义区分开来。从这个意义上讲，纯数学具有存在意义，而物理学中的数学理论具有外延意义。音乐的意义主要是存在意义，肖像的意义或多或少也具有代表性，等等。所有类型的秩序，无论是人为的还是自然的，都具有存在意义；但人为的秩序通常也传达着某种信息。

Indeed, we now see coming into view two kinds of wholes and two kinds of meaning. The more clear-cut cases of meaning are those in which one thing (e.g. a word) means another thing (e.g. an object). In this case the corresponding wholes are perhaps not obvious, but we may legitimately follow Tolman in amalgamating sign and object into one whole.48 Other kinds of things, like a physiognomy, a tune or a pattern, are manifestly wholes but this time their meaning is somewhat problematic, for though they are clearly not meaningless, they mean something only in themselves. The distinction between two kinds of awareness allows us readily to acknowledge these two kinds of wholes and two kinds of meaning. Remembering the various uses of a stick, for pointing, for exploring or for hitting, we can easily see that anything that functions effectively within an accredited context has a meaning in that context and that any such context will itself be appreciated as meaningful. We may describe the kind of meaning which a context possesses in itself as existential, to distinguish it especially from denotative or, more generally, representative meaning. In this sense pure mathematics has an existential meaning, while a mathematical theory in physics has a denotative meaning. The meaning of music is mainly existential, that of a portrait more or less representative, and so on. All kinds of order, whether contrived or natural, have existential meaning; but contrived order usually also conveys a message.

 

 

  1. 工具和框架
  2. TOOLS AND FRAMEWORKS

接下来，我将尝试强化和拓展辅助意识和焦点意识之间的区别，将其与另一个众所周知且普遍接受的区别联系起来，即我们在自身身体部位和外在事物之间的感觉。我们通常想当然地认为我们的手和脚是我们身体的组成部分，而不是外在的物体，以至于只有在它们受到疾病困扰时，我们才会意识到这一点。有些精神病患者感觉不到自己身体的某个部分属于自己。他们拥有从两侧肢体传递的所有正常感觉，但他们并没有将自己与传递这些信息的所有肢体认同；他们感觉其中一些肢体，例如右臂和右腿，是外在的物体。当他们从浴缸里出来时，可能会忘记擦干这些未被接纳的肢体。49

As a next step I shall try to strengthen and widen the distinction between subsidiary awareness and focal awareness by identifying it with another commonly known and universally accepted distinction, namely that which we feel between parts of our own body and things that are external to it. We usually take it so much for granted that our hands and feet are members of our body and not external objects, that this assumption is brought home to us only in case they happen to be disturbed by disease. There are certain psychotic patients who do not feel part of their body as belonging to them. They have all the normal sensations transmitted to them from their limbs on both sides, but they do not identify themselves with all the limbs from which these messages originate; they feel some of them, e.g. the right arm and right leg, as external objects. When stepping out of a bath it may happen that they forget to dry these unadopted limbs.49

相对于自身部位，我们对体外物体的外部性的感知依赖于我们对体内过程的辅助意识。只有当我们能够有意识地观察外部物体，并在外部空间中清晰地定位它时，外部性才能被清晰地定义。但是，当我注视某物时，我依靠视网膜上投射的两个图像之间的细微差别、眼睛的调节、眼轴的会聚以及控制眼球运动的肌肉收缩，以及从迷路接收到的脉冲（这些脉冲会随着我头部在空间中的位置而变化）来定位它在空间中的位置。我仅通过对所注视物体的定位来意识到所有这些；从这个意义上来说，我可以说我对它们具有辅助意识。

Our appreciation of the externality of objects lying outside our body, in contrast to parts of our own body, relies on our subsidiary awareness of processes within our body. Externality is clearly defined only if we can examine an external object deliberately, localizing it clearly in space outside. But when I look at something, I rely for my localization of it in space on a slight difference between the two images thrown on my retina, on the accommodation of the eyes, on the convergence of their axis and the effort of muscular contraction controlling the eye motion, supplemented by impulses received from the labyrinth, which vary according to the position of my head in space. Of all these I become aware only in terms of my localization of the object I am gazing at; and in this sense I may be said to be subsidiarily aware of them.

我们对工具和探针的辅助意识现在可以被视为使它们成为我们自身一部分的行为。我们使用锤子或盲人使用拐杖的方式，实际上表明在这两种情况下，我们都将与观察对象（这些观察对象被视为自身之外的客体）的接触点向外转移。当我们依赖工具或探针时，它们不会被当作外部客体来处理。我们可以测试工具的有效性或探针的适用性，例如在发现洞穴的隐藏细节时，但工具和探针永远不会处于这些操作的范围内；它们必然存在于我们这一侧，构成我们自身（操作者）的一部分。我们将自身倾注于它们，并将它们吸收为我们自身存在的一部分。我们通过栖居于它们之中而存在地接受它们。

Our subsidiary awareness of tools and probes can be regarded now as the act of making them form a part of our own body. The way we use a hammer or a blind man uses his stick, shows in fact that in both cases we shift outwards the points at which we make contact with the things that we observe as objects outside ourselves. While we rely on a tool or a probe, these are not handled as external objects. We may test the tool for its effectiveness or the probe for its suitability, e.g. in discovering the hidden details of a cavity, but the tool and the probe can never lie in the field of these operations; they remain necessarily on our side of it, forming part of ourselves, the operating persons. We pour ourselves out into them and assimilate them as parts of our own existence. We accept them existentially by dwelling in them.

 

 

  1. 承诺
  2. COMMITMENT

我们在此面对的是我们的信念赖以根植于自身的普遍原则。锤子和探针可以被智力工具取代；想想任何解释框架，尤其是精密科学的形式主义。我指的并非充斥在教科书中的具体断言，而是构成这些断言得出方法的基础的假设。我们通过学习用某种语言来表达事物，吸收了大部分这些预设。语言中有各种物体的名称，可以通过名称对物体进行分类，从而区分过去与现在、生与死、健康与病态，以及成千上万种其他事物。我们的语言包含数字和几何元素，并用这些术语来指代自然法则，由此我们可以在科学观察和实验中追寻这些法则的根源。

We are faced here with the general principle by which our beliefs are anchored in ourselves. Hammers and probes can be replaced by intellectual tools; think of any interpretative framework and particularly of the formalism of the exact sciences. I am not speaking of the specific assertions which fill the textbooks, but of the suppositions which underlie the method by which these assertions are arrived at. We assimilate most of these pre-suppositions by learning to speak of things in a certain language, in which there are names for various kinds of objects, names by which objects can be classified, making such distinctions as between past and present, living and dead, healthy and sick, and thousands of others. Our language includes the numerals and the elements of geometry, and it refers in these terms to laws of nature whence we can pass on to the roots of these laws in scientific observations and experiments.

奇怪的是，我们并不清楚我们的预设是什么，当我们试图表述它们时，它们似乎很难令人信服。我在关于概率的章节中已经阐述过，所有科学方法的陈述都是多么模棱两可和循环论证。我现在认为，所谓的科学预设之所以如此徒劳，是因为我们科学信念的实际基础根本无法被断言。当我们接受一套特定的预设并将其用作我们的解释框架时，可以说我们就像在自己的身体里一样栖居于其中。对它们的暂时不加批判的接受，构成了一个同化过程，通过这个过程，我们将自己与它们认同。它们没有被断言，也无法被断言，因为断言只能在我们暂时认同的框架内进行；由于它们本身就是我们的终极框架，它们本质上是无法言喻的。 50

The curious thing is that we have no clear knowledge of what our presuppositions are and when we try to formulate them they appear quite unconvincing. I have illustrated already in my chapter on probability how ambiguous and question-begging are all statements of the scientific method. I suggest now that the supposed pre-suppositions of science are so futile because the actual foundations of our scientific beliefs cannot be asserted at all. When we accept a certain set of pre-suppositions and use them as our interpretative framework, we may be said to dwell in them as we do in our own body. Their uncritical acceptance for the time being consists in a process of assimilation by which we identify ourselves with them. They are not asserted and cannot be asserted, for assertion can be made only within a framework with which we have identified ourselves for the time being; as they are themselves our ultimate framework, they are essentially inarticulable.50

科学家正是通过吸收科学框架来理解经验。这种理解经验的过程需要一定的技巧，它能将科学家的个人参与融入到最终的知识中。这包括正确地进行测量以验证科学预测或进行观察以应用科学分类的技能。此外，它还包括鉴赏力，科学家凭借这种鉴赏力抽象地欣赏数学理论——例如1912年之前的空间群理论——同样，也包括这种理论与对观测样本的评估的贴切性，自1912年发现晶体X射线衍射以来，空间群理论就一直为此服务。

It is by his assimilation of the framework of science that the scientist makes sense of experience. This making sense of experience is a skilful act which impresses the personal participation of the scientist on the resultant knowledge. It includes the skill of carrying out correctly the measurements which verify scientific predictions or the observations by which scientific classifications are applied. And it includes also connoisseurship, by which the scientist appreciates a mathematical theory in the abstract—such as the theory of space groups was until 1912—and equally, the appositeness of such a theory to the appraisal of observed specimens, for which the theory of space groups has served since the discovery of the diffraction of X-Rays by crystals in 1912.

追溯个人知识的根源，即我们身体的辅助意识与我们对外部对象的焦点意识的融合，不仅揭示了个人知识的逻辑结构，也揭示了其动态来源。我之前分析过将物体用作工具时所隐含的信念。在我刚刚勾勒出的新图景中，外部事物通过成为我们自身的延伸而获得意义，这些信念被转化为更积极的意图，这些意图会引导我们整个人。从这个意义上讲，我应该说，一个物体通过一种有目的的努力转化为一种工具，这种努力设想了一个操作领域，在这个领域中，受我们努力引导的物体将作为我们身体的延伸发挥作用。我对它的依赖是为了某种目的，即使它可能无法达到那个目的，它也使它变成了一种工具。为了迷惑一个人而烧毁他的指甲，是一种工具性的行为，它建立在将假定的手段与假定的目的错误地结合起来的基础上。同样，念诵咒语、发出诅咒或给予祝福，都是言语行为，说话者对其功效充满信心，并赋予其意义。相反，如果目的的实现方式并非旨在产生该结果，则这些方式不具有工具性。如果一只老鼠不小心按下了释放食物颗粒的杠杆，它并没有将其用作工具；只有当老鼠学会将其用于此目的后，杠杆才成为它的工具。布伊滕戴克（Buytendijk）描述过（在他之前，其他人也做过不那么详细的描述），老鼠学会走迷宫后行为发生了根本性的变化。51动物不再探索沿途墙壁和角落的细节，而仅仅将它们视为路标。它似乎失去了对它们的焦点意识，转而发展出一种辅助意识，这种辅助意识如今构成了其追求目标的一部分。

The tracing of personal knowledge to its roots in the subsidiary awareness of our body as merged in our focal awareness of external objects, reveals not only the logical structure of personal knowledge but also its dynamic sources. I have analysed previously the beliefs which are implied in using an object as a tool. In the new scheme which I have just drawn up of the process by which an external thing is given a meaning by being made to form an extension of ourselves, these beliefs are transposed into more active intentions which draw on our whole person. In this sense I should say that an object is transformed into a tool by a purposive effort envisaging an operational field in respect of which the object guided by our efforts shall function as an extension of our body. My reliance on it for some end makes an object into a tool, even though it may not achieve that end. The burning of a man’s nail pairings for the purpose of bewitching him is an instrumental action based on a mistaken integration of supposed means to supposed ends. Similarly, to pronounce a magic formula, to utter a curse or give a blessing, are verbal actions into which the speaker, confident in their efficacy, pours meaning. Conversely, where the ends are achieved by means which are not intended to produce that result, these means have no instrumental character. If a rat accidentally depresses a lever which releases a food pellet it has not used it as a tool; only after the rat has learned to use it for that purpose does the lever become its tool. Buytendijk has described (as others have done in less detail before him) the radical change in the behaviour of a rat when it has learned to run a maze.51 The animal ceases to explore the details of the walls and corners on its way and attends to these now merely as signposts. It seems to have lost its focal awareness of them and developed instead a subsidiary awareness of them which now forms part of the pursuit of its purpose.

我曾说过，工具只是事物融入整体（或格式塔）的一个例子，在这个整体中，它被赋予了辅助功能和意义，而这些功能和意义与我们所关注的事物相关。我将这种结构分析概括为将符号识别为后续事件的指示，以及为它们将要表示的事物建立符号的过程。我们也可以将这些关于工具的论述应用于这些情况。与工具一样，符号或象征只有在依靠它们来实现或表示某种事物的人眼中才能被理解为符号。这种依赖是一种个人承诺，它包含于我们所有的智力活动之中，通过这些活动，我们将某些事物辅助性地整合到我们关注的中心。每一次个人同化行为，通过我们对事物的辅助意识，使之成为我们自身的延伸，都是对我们自身的承诺；一种处置自身的方式。

I have said that a tool is only one example of the merging of a thing in a whole (or a gestalt) in which it is assigned a subsidiary function and a meaning in respect to something that has our focal attention. I generalized this structural analysis to include the recognition of signs as indications of subsequent events and the process of establishing symbols for things which they shall signify. We may apply to these cases also what has just been said about a tool. Like the tool, the sign or the symbol can be conceived as such only in the eyes of a person who relies on them to achieve or to signify something. This reliance is a personal commitment which is involved in all acts of intelligence by which we integrate some things subsidiarily to the centre of our focal attention. Every act of personal assimilation by which we make a thing form an extension of ourselves through our subsidiary awareness of it, is a commitment of ourselves; a manner of disposing of ourselves.

然而，认知者对其知识的个人贡献中蕴含着目的和承诺的脉络，却缺乏动态性。为了某种目的或在其他连贯的脉络中理解经验所提供的细节，将自身倾注于其中并非轻而易举。以我们习得使用工具或探针的方式为例。如果我们像视力正常的人一样被蒙住眼睛，就无法像长期使用棍棒的盲人那样熟练地使用棍棒。我们能感觉到棍棒不时地碰到某些东西，但无法将这些事件关联起来。我们只有通过努力构建对棍棒所碰到事物的连贯感知，才能学会做到这一点。然后，我们逐渐不再感觉到手指的一系列抽搐——就像我们在最初笨拙的尝试中仍然会感觉到的那样——而是将它们体验为一定硬度和形状的障碍物的存在，这些障碍物被放置在一定距离处，就在我们棍棒的尖端。更一般地说，通过努力将注意力集中在我所选择的操作层面上，我成功地吸收了所有我原本可能意识到的情形元素，因此我现在可以根据通过使用它们所取得的操作结果来意识到它们。

But the context of purpose and commitment, as found inherent in the personal contribution of the knower to his knowledge, yet lacks dynamic character. The pouring out of ourselves into the particulars given by experience so as to make sense of them for some purpose or in some other coherent context, is not achieved effortlessly. Take the way we acquire the use of a tool or a probe. If, as seeing men, we are blindfolded, we cannot find our way about with a stick as skilfully as a blind man does who has practised it for a long time. We can feel that the stick hits something from time to time but cannot correlate these events. We can learn to do this only by an intelligent effort at constructing a coherent perception of the things hit by the stick. We then gradually cease to feel a series of jerks in our fingers as such—as we still do in our first clumsy trials—but experience them as the presence of obstacles of certain hardness and shape, placed at a certain distance, at the point of our stick. We may say, more generally, that by the effort by which I concentrate on my chosen plane of operation I succeed in absorbing all the elements of the situation of which I might otherwise be aware in themselves, so that I become aware of them now in terms of the operational results achieved through their use.

当我们根据棍子触碰的物体对手指的冲击做出新的解释时，可以说我们在无意识地进行解释冲击的过程。同样，从实践角度来看，当我们学习根据我们努力掌握的情况来使用锤子、网球拍或汽车时，我们会对实现这一结果的行为失去意识。这种无意识的陷入伴随着在操作层面上对相关经验的新获得的意识。因此，将其描述为简单的重复结果是误导；它是通过重复的心理努力实现的结构性变化，旨在将某些事物和行为工具化以服务于某些目的。

When the new interpretation of the shocks in our fingers is achieved in terms of the objects touched by the stick, we may be said to carry out unconsciously the process of interpreting the shocks. And again, in practical terms, as we learn to handle a hammer, a tennis racket or a motor car in terms of the situation which we are striving to master, we become unconscious of the actions by which we achieve this result. This lapse into unconsciousness is accompanied by a newly acquired consciousness of the experiences in question, on the operational plane. It is misleading, therefore, to describe this as the mere result of repetition; it is a structural change achieved by a repeated mental effort aiming at the instrumentalization of certain things and actions in the service of some purpose.

 

 

  1. 不可指定性
  2. UNSPECIFIABILITY

现在，我们可以回答我在开始这项技能考察时提出的“不可具体化”问题了。如果一组细节已经沉入我们的辅助意识中，却完全从我们的意识中消失，我们最终可能会完全忘记它们，甚至可能对它们视而不见，无法回忆。从这个意义上讲，它们可能已经变得不可具体化了。然而，这似乎只是造成不可具体化的一个小原因，其本质是由一个略有不同但密切相关的过程来解释的。

We can now answer the problem of unspecifiability with which I started on this examination of skills. If a set of particulars which have subsided into our subsidiary awareness lapses altogether from our consciousness, we may end up by forgetting about them altogether and may lose sight of them beyond recall. In this sense they may have become unspecifiable. However, this seems only a minor reason for unspecifiability, which is accounted for essentially by a somewhat different, if closely related process.

心理努力具有启发式作用：它倾向于结合任何对其目的有帮助的可用情况元素。

A mental effort has a heuristic effect: it tends to incorporate any available elements of the situation which are helpful for its purpose.

科勒曾以猿类在面对可用作工具的物体时所做的实际努力为例描述过这一点。他说，动物的洞察力会重新组织其视野，使有用的物体作为工具出现在它的眼前。我们可以补充一点，这不仅适用于用作工具的物体，也适用于执行者自身可能有助于实现其目的的肌肉动作。如果这些动作只是辅助性地体验到的，就其促成的成就而言，其执行可能会从中选择那些执行者认为有用的动作，而他从未真正了解这些动作本身在执行者眼中是什么样子。这是一种常见的无意识试错过程，我们正是通过这个过程摸索着走向成功，并可能在不明确了解具体方法的情况下不断改进——因为我们从未将成功的原因视为可识别的事物，这些事物可以用它们所属的类别来描述。正因如此，你发明了一种游泳方法，却不知道它在于以特定的方式调节你的呼吸；你发现了骑自行车的原理，却不知道它在于调整你瞬间的方向和速度，以持续抵消你瞬间偶然的失衡。因此，在实践中，你发现了一系列未被人们意识到的技巧和鉴赏规则，它们构成了重要的技术过程，而这些过程很少能被完全阐明，即使能被完全阐明，也只有通过大量的科学研究才能最终确定。

Köhler has described this for the case of a practical effort, made by an ape in the presence of an object which may serve as a tool. The animal’s insight, he says, reorganizes its field of vision so that the useful object meets his eye as a tool. We may add that this will hold not only of objects which are made use of as tools, but also of the performer’s own muscular actions which may subserve his purpose. If these actions are experienced only subsidiarily, in terms of an achievement to which they contribute, its performance may select from them those which the performer finds helpful, without ever knowing these as they would appear to him when considered in themselves. This is the usual process of unconscious trial and error by which we feel our way to success and may continue to improve on our success without specifiably knowing how we do it—for we never meet the causes of our success as identifiable things which can be described in terms of classes of which such things are members. This is how you invent a method of swimming without knowing that it consists in regulating your breath in a particular manner, or discover the principle of cycling without realizing that it consists in the adjustment of your momentary direction and velocity, so as to counteract continuously your momentary accidental unbalance. Hence the practical discovery of a wide range of not consciously known rules of skill and connoisseurship which comprise important technical processes that can rarely be completely specified, and even then only as a result of extensive scientific research.

我们如此摸索前进的过程，其不可具体化性，解释了人类为何拥有如此广阔的精神领域，这不仅包括知识，还包括礼仪、法律以及形形色色的技艺，人类知道如何运用、遵守、享受或依附于它们，却并不明确地了解它们的内容。获得这一领域的每一步，都源于超越其创造者此前所掌握的能力的努力，以及其随后对成功的实现和维持。这依赖于一种探索行为，这种探索行为最初超越了其创造者的理解范围，而此后，创造者对此的意识仅仅停留在辅助层面，作为一项复杂成就的一部分。

The unspecifiability of the process by which we thus feel our way forward accounts for the possession by humanity of an immense mental domain, not only of knowledge but of manners, of laws and of the many different arts which man knows how to use, comply with, enjoy or live by, without specifiably knowing their contents. Each single step in acquiring this domain was due to an effort which went beyond the hitherto assured capacity of some person making it, and by his subsequent realization and maintenance of his success. It relied on an act of groping which originally passed the understanding of its agent and of which he has ever since remained only subsidiarily aware, as part of a complex achievement.

个人知识的所有这些奇特属性和含义，都源于我之前所描述的逻辑上的不可具体化性；也就是将注意力转向整体的各个部分所造成的混乱效应。现在，我们也可以从动态的角度来理解这种效应。

All these curious properties and implications of personal knowledge go back to what I have previously described as its logical unspecifiability; that is to the disorganizing effect caused by switching our attention to the parts of a whole. We can now appreciate this effect too in dynamic terms.

由于我们最初根据这些部分对合理结果的贡献来获得对这些部分的控制，因此它们从未被了解，更非意志所驱使。因此，将一个重要的整体转置到其构成要素的范畴中，就等于将其转置到被剥夺了任何目的或意义的范畴中。这种肢解只会给我们留下一些赤裸裸的、相对客观的事实，而这些事实曾构成了后续个人事实的线索。这实际上是根据潜在的相对客观知识对个人知识进行破坏性分析。

Since we originally gained control over the parts in question in terms of their contribution to a reasonable result, they have never been known and were still less willed in themselves, and therefore to transpose a significant whole into the terms of its constituent elements is to transpose it into terms deprived of any purpose or meaning. Such dismemberment leaves us with the bare, relatively objective facts, which had formed the clues for a supervening personal fact. It is a destructive analysis of personal knowledge in terms of the underlying relatively objective knowledge.

我把我们为获得认知的艺术而付出的努力描述为试图将某些细节同化为我们身体的延伸，以便通过融入我们的辅助意识，它们可以形成一个连贯的焦点实体。这是一种行动，但其中始终包含被动元素。如果我们相信一个物体确实对我们的目的有用，我们就可以把它同化为工具，这同样适用于意义与所指关系以及部分与整体关系。个人认知行为可以维持这些关系，只是因为行动者相信它们是恰当的：他不是创造了它们，而是发现了它们。因此，认知的努力受到对真理的责任感的引导：受到服从现实的努力的引导。

I have described the effort which we put into acquiring the art of knowing as the attempt to assimilate certain particulars as extensions of our body, so that by becoming imbued with our subsidiary awareness they may form a coherent focal entity. This is an action, but one that has always an element of passivity in it. We can assimilate an object as a tool if we believe it to be actually useful to our purposes and the same holds for the relation of meaning to what is meant and the relation of the parts to a whole. The act of personal knowing can sustain these relations only because the acting person believes that they are apposite: that he has not made them but discovered them. The effort of knowing is thus guided by a sense of obligation towards the truth: by an effort to submit to reality.

此外，由于每一种个人认知行为都重视某些细节的连贯性，它也意味着要遵循某些连贯性标准。运动员或舞蹈家展现出最佳水平，是对自己表演的评判，而鉴赏家则被公认为是对作品优劣的评判。所有个人认知都以自身设定的标准来评估其认知。

Moreover, since every act of personal knowing appreciates the coherence of certain particulars, it implies also submission to certain standards of coherence. While the athlete or the dancer putting forward their best, act as critics of their own performances, connoisseurs are acknowledged as critics of the goodness of specimens. All personal knowing appraises what it knows by a standard set to itself.

 

 

  1. 概括
  2. SUMMARY

让我总结一下我目前的论证。我从精密科学入手，将其定义为与经验相关的数学形式主义。科学家似乎在确立这种与经验的关系时参与其中。这在经典力学中最为明显，因此我认定物理学的这一章与完全独立的自然科学最为接近。它的陈述确实可以被表述得如此清晰，以至于可以通过经验进行严格的证伪。接下来，我列举了两组例子，以说明精密科学中个人参与的程度更为广泛，且不可忽视。第一组例子涉及科学中的概率知识；更具体地说，涉及假设一个看似重要的事件模式是偶然发生时所涉及的巧合程度。第二组例子论证了精密科学中对有序模式的评估，并表明有序性的标准虽然与经验相关，但却无法被经验证伪。相反，就像概率陈述的情况一样，它们本身可以评估任何相关的经验样本。

Let me sum up my argument so far. I started with the exact sciences, defining them as a mathematical formalism with a bearing on experience. There appeared to be present a personal participation on the part of the scientist in establishing this bearing on experience. This was least noticeable in classical mechanics and I accordingly accepted that chapter of physics as the closest approximation to a completely detached natural science. Its statements could indeed be so formulated as to admit of strict falsification by experience. There followed two sets of examples for a more massive and not conceivably negligible personal participation in the exact sciences. The first of these comprised the knowledge of probabilities in science; and more particularly of the degrees of coincidence involved in assuming that an apparently significant pattern of events had come about as the result of chance. The second set demonstrated the assessment of orderly patterns in the exact sciences and showed that standards of orderliness, though bearing on experience, cannot be conceivably falsified by it. On the contrary, as in the case of statements of probability, they themselves appraise any relevant samples of experience.

当然，经验可以提供线索，鼓励或否定关于概率或秩序标准的陈述，这种影响固然重要，但其重要性并不比小说事实主题对其可接受性的重要性高多少。然而，科学中的个人知识并非源于创造，而是源于发现，因此，它声称要与它所依赖的线索之外的现实建立联系。它让我们满怀热情地、远远超出我们的理解能力，致力于对现实的展望。我们不能通过设立可验证性、可证伪性、可测试性或任何其他名称的客观标准来推卸这一责任。因为我们生活在其中，就像生活在我们自身皮肤的衣服里一样。就像爱情——它与爱情相似——一样，这种承诺是一件“火焰衬衫”，充满激情，也像爱情一样，被对普遍需求的奉献所吞噬。这就是科学中客观性的真正含义，我在第一章中对此进行了阐述。我称之为对自然合理性的发现，这个名字的意思是，发现者声称在自然中看到的那种秩序远远超出了他的理解能力；因此，他的胜利恰恰在于他预知了大量尚未发现的含义，而他的发现将在日后向他人揭示这些含义。

Experience can of course offer clues to encourage or disappoint statements of probability or standards of order and this effect is important, but not much more important than the factual theme of a novel is for its acceptability. Yet personal knowledge in science is not made but discovered, and as such it claims to establish contact with reality beyond the clues on which it relies. It commits us, passionately and far beyond our comprehension, to a vision of reality. Of this responsibility we cannot divest ourselves by setting up objective criteria of verifiability—or falsifiability, or testability, or what you will. For we live in it as in the garment of our own skin. Like love, to which it is akin, this commitment is a ‘shirt of flame’, blazing with passion and, also like love, consumed by devotion to a universal demand. Such is the true sense of objectivity in science, which I illustrated in my first chapter. I called it the discovery of rationality in nature, a name which was meant to say that the kind of order which the discoverer claims to see in nature goes far beyond his understanding; so that his triumph lies precisely in his foreknowledge of a host of yet hidden implications which his discovery will reveal in later days to other eyes.

显然，我的论证在当时就已经延伸到了精密科学之外的领域。在本章中，我探寻了个人知识的根源，直至其最原始的形式，这些形式隐藏在科学形式主义的运作背后。我撕开图表、方程式和计算的纸质屏障，试图揭示我们以纯粹个人的方式认知事物的、难以言喻的智慧表现。我开始分析“善于做事”和“善于认知”的艺术，这些艺术的运用指导并认可了科学公式的运用，并且其影响范围远远超出了任何形式主义，它塑造了我们对构成我们世界的大多数事物的基本概念。

My argument was clearly overflowing already at that stage into domains far beyond the exact sciences. In this chapter I have pursued the roots of personal knowledge towards its most primitive forms which lie behind the operations of a scientific formalism. Tearing away the paper screen of graphs, equations and computations, I have tried to lay bare the inarticulate manifestations of intelligence by which we know things in a purely personal manner. I have entered on an analysis of the arts of skilful doing and skilful knowing, the exercise of which guides and accredits the use of scientific formulae, and which ranges far further afield, unassisted by any formalism, in shaping our fundamental notions of most things which make our world.

在此，在技能的运用和鉴赏的实践中，认知的艺术被视为一种有意识的改变：将我们自身倾注于对细节的附属意识中，这些细节在技能的运用中有助于取得精湛的成就，而在鉴赏的实践中，它们则作为所观察到的综合整体的要素发挥作用。技艺精湛的表演者被视为为自己设定标准并以此评判自己；鉴赏家被视为根据他设定的卓越标准来评价综合实体。这些要素，例如环境、锤子、探针、言语，都指向自身之外，并在这种环境里被赋予意义；另一方面，综合环境本身，如舞蹈、数学、音乐，拥有内在或存在的意义。

Here, in the exercise of skill and the practice of connoisseurship, the art of knowing is seen to involve an intentional change of being: the pouring of ourselves into the subsidiary awareness of particulars, which in the performance of skills are instrumental to a skilful achievement, and which in the exercise of connoisseurship function as the elements of the observed comprehensive whole. The skilful performer is seen to be setting standards to himself and judging himself by them; the connoisseur is seen valuing comprehensive entities in terms of a standard set by him for their excellence. The elements of such, a context, the hammer, the probe, the spoken word, all point beyond themselves and are endowed with meaning in this context; and on the other hand a comprehensive context itself, like dance, mathematics, music, possesses intrinsic or existential meaning.

因此，行动与认知的艺术，对意义的评价与理解，都被视为将我们自身延伸至构成整体的诸细节的次要意识之中的不同方面。这种个人认知的基本行为的内在结构，使得我们既必然参与其塑造，又以普遍的意图认可其结果。这便是智识投入的原型。

The arts of doing and knowing, the valuation and the understanding of meanings, are thus seen to be only different aspects of the act of extending our person into the subsidiary awareness of particulars which compose a whole. The inherent structure of this fundamental act of personal knowing makes us both necessarily participate in its shaping and acknowledge its results with universal intent. This is the prototype of intellectual commitment.

正是这种完整结构的投入行为，才使个人知识免于沦为主观臆断。知识投入是一种负责任的决定，它服从于我凭良心认为是真理的迫切要求。它是一种充满希望的行为，它努力在个人境况中履行义务，而这种境况并非我所能负责，因此也决定了我的使命。这种希望和义务体现在个人知识的普遍意图中。随着我进一步阐述，这种说法的含义将更加明确，并在第三部分的结尾进行总结。

It is the act of commitment in its full structure that saves personal knowledge from being merely subjective. Intellectual commitment is a responsible decision, in submission to the compelling claims of what in good conscience I conceive to be true. It is an act of hope, striving to fulfil an obligation within a personal situation for which I am not responsible and which therefore determines my calling. This hope and this obligation are expressed in the universal intent of personal knowledge. The sense in which this may be said to be the case will be made more definite as I proceed further and it will be summed up at the close of Part Three.

 

 

第二部分

PART TWO

隐性成分

THE TACIT COMPONENT

 

 

5

5

关节

ARTICULATION

 

 

  1. 介绍
  2. INTRODUCTION

黑猩猩GUA于1930年11月15日在古巴圈养出生。七个半月大时，她被印第安​​纳州布卢明顿的凯洛格夫妇收养，成为他们刚满五个月的宝宝唐纳德的陪伴。52在接下来的九个月里，两个婴儿以完全相同的方式成长，并用相同的测试记录他们的发育情况。一张图表比较了他们通过的智力测试的成功次数，显示出两者发展惊人的相似性。诚然，尽管年龄较小，孩子很快就超过了黑猩猩，并始终保持着这种优势，但与孩子即将显现的未来智力优势相比，这一优势微不足道。在15到18个月大的时候，黑猩猩的智力发育接近完成；而孩子的智力发育才刚刚开始。通过回应与它说话的人，孩子很快就开始理解语言并自己说话。通过这一个超越动物的技巧，孩子获得了持续思考的能力，并继承了其祖先的全部文化遗产。

GUA the chimpanzee was born in captivity on November 15th, 1930, in Cuba. When she reached the age of seven months and a half she was adopted by Mr. and Mrs. Kellogg of Bloomington, Indiana, to become a companion to their baby Donald, who had just completed the fifth month of his life.52 During the following nine months the two infants were brought up in exactly the same way and their development was recorded by identical tests. A graph comparing the number of successful intelligence tests passed by them shows a striking parallelism in the development of the two. It is true that the child, though the younger, soon took the lead over the chimpanzee and retained this throughout, but the advantage was slight compared with the child’s prospective intellectual superiority which was presently to become apparent. At the age of 15 to 18 months the mental development of the chimpanzee is nearing completion; that of the child is only about to start. By responding to people who talk to it, the child soon begins to understand speech and to speak itself. By this one single trick in which it surpasses the animal, the child acquires the capacity for sustained thought and enters on the whole cultural heritage of its ancestors.

动物和婴儿智力的微小成就与科学思维的成就之间存在着巨大的差距。然而，矛盾的是，人类相对于动物的巨大优势却源于其原始的、难以言喻的能力中几乎难以察觉的优势。53这种情况可以概括为三点。（1）人类的智力优势几乎完全归功于语言的使用。但是（2）人类的语言天赋本身并不能归功于语言的使用，而必须归功于前语言的优势。然而（3）如果排除语言方面的线索，人类在解决我们向动物提出的那种问题时，只会略胜一筹。由此可见，人类超越动物的那些非表达能力——那些潜力——以及通过语言来解释人类全部智力优势的那些能力——本身几乎是不可察觉的。因此，我们必须承认人类拥有我们在动物身上已经观察到的那种非表达能力，才能解释人类习得语言的原因。

The gap which separates the small feats of animal and infant intelligence from the achievements of scientific thought is enormous. Yet the towering superiority of man over the animals is due, paradoxically, to an almost imperceptible advantage in his original, inarticulate faculties.53 The situation can be summed up in three points. (1) Man’s intellectual superiority is almost entirely due to the use of language. But (2) man’s gift of speech cannot itself be due to the use of language and must therefore be due to pre-linguistic advantages. Yet (3) if linguistic clues are excluded, men are found to be only slightly better at solving the kind of problems we set to animals. From which it follows that the inarticulate faculties—the potentialities—by which man surpasses the animals and which, by producing speech, account for the entire intellectual superiority of man, are in themselves almost imperceptible. Accordingly, we shall have to account for man’s acquisition of language by acknowledging in him the same kind of inarticulate powers as we observe already in animals.

获得正式的思维工具所带来的心智能力的大幅提升，也与本书第一部分收集的事实形成了鲜明的对比。这些事实表明，认知者凭借一种本质上无法言说的技巧，广泛地参与认知活动。形式化智力的这两个相互冲突的方面，可以通过假设表达始终不完整来调和；我们清晰的表达永远无法完全取代，而必须继续依赖于我们与同时代的黑猩猩曾经共同拥有的那种无声的智力行为。诚然，我之前曾概述过的科学家的认知技巧比儿童或动物的认知技巧更高，而且只有结合科学作为一门正式学科的知识才能获得。其他高级智力技能也是在持续的正规教育过程中获得的；事实上，我们的无声能力正是在运用表达能力的过程中不断增长的。我们正式的成长经历在我们心中唤起一系列复杂的情感反应，这些反应在一个清晰的文化框架内运作。凭借这些情感的力量，我们吸收了这个框架，并将其作为我们的文化来维护；然而，将婴儿与黑猩猩进行比较，将有助于解释人类远超常人的智力。

The enormous increase of mental powers derived from the acquisition of formal instruments of thought stands also in a peculiar contrast with the facts collected in the first part of this book, which demonstrate the pervasive participation of the knowing person in the act of knowing by virtue of an art which is essentially inarticulate. The two conflicting aspects of formalized intelligence may be reconciled by assuming that articulation always remains incomplete; that our articulate utterances can never altogether supersede but must continue to rely on such mute acts of intelligence as we once had in common with chimpanzees of our own age. Admittedly the scientist’s art of knowing, which I have surveyed previously, is on a higher level than the child’s or the animal’s and can be acquired only in conjunction with a knowledge of science as a formal discipline. Other intellectual skills of a high order are acquired similarly in the course of a continued formal education; and indeed our mute abilities keep growing in the very exercise of our articulate powers. Our formal upbringing evokes in us an elaborate set of emotional responses, operating within an articulate cultural framework. By the strength of these affections we assimilate this framework and uphold it as our culture; yet the comparison of the baby and the chimpanzee will go a long way towards accounting for the vastly superior intelligence of man.

在转向我们的主要任务，即追踪表达智力和非表达智力之间的关系之前，我们可以利用当前的有利位置，确定我们此时所看到的本次调查的最终目标。54如果我们所有话语的含义在很大程度上取决于我们自身的一种娴熟的认知行为——认知行为——那么，接受我们自己的任何话语为真，都包含着我们对自身认知能力的认可。因此，肯定任何事物，在某种程度上都意味着对我们自身认知能力的评估，而真理的确立则最终取决于我们自身一套无法正式定义的个人标准。如果非言语的话语拥有最终决定权，虽未言明，却具有决定性，那么口头真理本身的地位必然会相应降低。非个人化的、超然的真理理想必须重新诠释，以考虑到宣告真理的行为本身所固有的个人特征。希望在这方面达到可接受的心理平衡，将指导本书第二部分和第三部分的后续探究。

Before turning to our principal task of tracing the relation between articulate and inarticulate intelligence, we may use the present vantage ground to set our course towards an ultimate aim of this enquiry which comes into view at this point.54 If, as it would seem, the meaning of all our utterances is determined to an important extent by a skilful act of our own—the act of knowing—then the acceptance of any of our own utterances as true involves our approval of our own skill. To affirm any thing implies, then, to this extent an appraisal of our own art of knowing, and the establishment of truth becomes decisively dependent on a set of personal criteria of our own which cannot be formally defined. If everywhere it is the inarticulate which has the last word, unspoken and yet decisive, then a corresponding abridgement of the status of spoken truth itself is inevitable. The ideal of an impersonally detached truth would have to be reinterpreted, to allow for the inherently personal character of the act by which truth is declared. The hope of achieving an acceptable balance of mind in this respect will guide the subsequent enquiry throughout Parts Two and Three of this book.

 

 

  1. 无法表达的智力
  2. INARTICULATE INTELLIGENCE

我将系统地开始这项任务，首先分析动物和儿童智力中那些难以言喻的表现。我暂时接受通常的区分，即有机体的自动功能（包括其本能行为）与动物原生行为库中未明确包含的高级行为形式。这类行为将被称为学习，我也将问题解决行为也纳入其中。学习将被视为智力的标志，与内脏器官的功能或本能行为相对照，后者则被归类为亚智力。55

I shall start on this task systematically by returning to the analysis of the inarticulate manifestations of intelligence in animals and children. I accept for the moment without discussion the usual distinction between the automatic functioning of the organism, including its instinctive performances, and the higher forms of behaviour not specifically included in the animal’s native repertoire. Such behaviour will be called learning in which term I shall include also acts of problem solving. Learning will be regarded as a sign of intelligence, in contrast to the functioning of internal organs or to instinctive performances which will be classed as sub- intelligent.55

各种学习模式可以很容易地分为三类。其中两类更为原始，分别植根于动物的运动能力和感知能力；而第三类则通过隐含的智力运作来处理动物生命的这两种功能。这种划分遵循了ERHilgard（《学习理论》（1948年；第二版，1956年））以及OHMowrer（《学习理论与人格动力学》 （1950年））的思想，某种程度上也遵循了OHMowrer的思想。他们又在很大程度上受到了ECTolman（《动物和人类的目的性行为》（1932年））的指导。然而，我的阐述与这些作者的阐述大相径庭，因此我只能在此以概括的方式向他们表示感谢。

The various modes of learning fall readily into three classes, two of which are more primitive and are rooted respectively in the motility and the sentience of the animal, while the third handles both these functions of animal life in an implicit operation of intelligence. This division follows E.R.Hilgard (Theories of Learning (1948; 2nd edition, 1956)), and to some extent also O.H.Mowrer (Learning Theory and Personality Dynamics (1950)), who in their turn were guided to a considerable extent by E.C.Tolman (Purposive Behavior in Animals and Men (1932)). My presentation differs, however, so much from that of these authors that I can only acknowledge my debt to them here in a summary fashion.

A类：技巧学习。运动学习的最佳范例是BFSkinner的理论。56他把一只饥饿的老鼠放在一个装有杠杆的盒子里，按下杠杆就会释放一颗食物颗粒。老鼠首先会在盒子里四处走动，嗅闻并用爪子抓挠任何显眼的物体。一旦意外按下杠杆，它就会吃掉释放的食物颗粒。过了一会儿，老鼠可能会再次按下杠杆，这时它就开始学习，学习频率会迅速增加。最终，老鼠会勤奋地按下杠杆并吃掉食物颗粒；学习过程就完成了。

Type A. Trick Learning. The best demonstration of motoric learning is B.F.Skinner’s.56 He places a hungry rat in a box equipped with a lever, the depression of which releases a food pellet. The rat will first roam about the box, sniffing and pawing at any prominent object. Having once accidentally depressed the lever, it eats the pellet so released. After a while the rat may happen to depress the lever again and learning will set in, showing itself by the fact that the action rapidly becomes more frequent. Finally the rat becomes engaged assiduously in lever-pressing and pellet-eating; and the process of learning is complete.

老鼠进食行为的这种放大，是通过提供一个可以用作工具的物体来引发的，它在于发现并练习如何正确使用这个工具。我们可以说，老鼠学会了设计一种对它有用的效果，或者说，它发现了一种有用的手段与目的关系。这里隐含的拟人化推论——以及在下文关于学习的概述中也同样如此——是经过深思熟虑的，并将在第四部分中针对行为主义的反对意见进行论证。

This amplification of the rat’s feeding behaviour is elicited here by providing an object which it can use as a tool, and it consists in discovering and practising the proper use of this tool. We may say that the rat has learned to contrive an effect that is useful to it, or else that it has discovered a useful means-end relationship. The anthropomorphic imputations implied here—and similarly in the following survey of learning—are deliberate and will be justified later in Part Four against behaviourist objections.

B类：手势学习。一只狗被训练成在屏幕上闪过红光后不久就会预期电击，它已经识别出预示事件的信号。巴甫洛夫的实验清晰地阐明了这种学习方式，但也在一定程度上扭曲了这种学习方式。在巴甫洛夫的实验中，他通过向狗发出明确的信号（例如摇铃）来诱导它们分泌唾液，表明食物即将到来。用巴甫洛夫的话来说，表示食物到来的铃声（条件刺激）在其效果上取代了食物的呈现（非条件刺激）。同样，根据巴甫洛夫的说法，表示即将电击的红光应该对受训动物产生与电击本身相同的作用。但这些都不完全正确：狗不会像对待食物一样跳起来咬铃铛，红光也不会引起电击引起的那种肌肉收缩。事实上，“条件反应”与最初的“非条件反应”有很大不同，就像对事件的预期与事件本身的效果有所不同一样。57与巴甫洛夫对这一过程的描述相反，这使我们有权说，在手势学习中，动物通过识别预示事件的手势来预期事件。

Type B. Sign-learning. A dog which is trained to expect an electric shock shortly after a red light is flashed on a screen, has recognized a sign foretelling an event. This type of learning has been sharply illuminated, but also somewhat distorted, by Pavlov’s experiments, in which he induced salivation in dogs by giving them definite signs (like ringing a bell) that food was forthcoming. In Pavlov’s terms the sound of a bell announcing food, the conditioned stimulus, replaces in its effect the presentation of food, the unconditioned stimulus. Similarly, according to Pavlov, a red light announcing the imminence of an electric shock would be supposed to act like the shock itself on the trained animal. But none of these is quite true: the dog does not jump and snap at the bell as if it were food, nor does a red light cause the kind of muscular contraction which results from an electric shock. In fact, the ‘conditioned response’ differs quite generally from the original ‘unconditioned response’, in the same way in which the anticipation of an event differs from the effect of the event itself.57 This entitles us to say, in contrast to Pavlov’s description of the process, that in sign-learning the animal is taught to expect an event by recognizing a sign foretelling the event.
