通过使用辨别箱（discrimination box）可以更深入地分析手势学习，辨别箱有多种类型。例如，动物面对两扇门，门通向两个隔间，隔间上有不同的标记，可以从一扇门切换到另一扇门。这种动物（通常是老鼠）被训练识别表示门后有食物的标记，与表示门后没有食物的标记区分开来。赋予动物更大的行动自由，使其行为能够揭示学习实现的一些初步阶段。

A closer analysis of sign-learning is provided by using a discrimination box, of which there are different types. For example, the animal is faced with two doors leading to two compartments with different markings that can be shifted from one door to the other. The animal, usually a rat, is trained to recognize the marking which signifies the presence of food behind the door as distinct from the other marking, behind which no food will be found. The greater freedom of action given here to the animal allows its behaviour to reveal some of the preliminary stages through which learning is achieved.

第一阶段是意识到问题的存在。为了诱导动物意识到这一点，研究人员向动物呈现一个简化的情景版本，以便动物一眼就能掌握。首先，在两个隔间中的一个隔间里公开提供食物；然后，隔间的入口关闭，动物被要求推开门，它会在门后找到食物或空着的地方。这些体验使动物意识到食物藏在两个隔间中的一个隔间里，推开正确的门就可以得到食物。对这个问题的理解会促使动物推开其中一个隔间去寻找食物。正是通过这种猜测正确隔间的尝试，动物最终会发现门上的某些标记表明门后有食物。

The first stage consists in realizing the presence of a problem. To induce this, the animal is presented with a version of the situation so simplified that it grasps it at a glance. Food is first offered openly in one or the other of the two compartments; then the entrances to the compartments are closed and the animal is made to push open the doors, behind which he will find either the food or an empty space. These experiences establish an awareness that food is hidden in one of the two compartments and that it can be got at by pushing open the right door. The understanding of this problem rouses the animal to search for food by pushing its way into one or the other compartment. It is by such attempts at guessing the right compartment that it will eventually hit on the fact that certain markings on the door signify the presence of food behind the door.

有证据表明，在这些尝试过程中，动物的选择并不是随机的，而是从一开始就遵循一些系统，例如“总是向右转”或“总是向左转”或“交替向右和向左转”，直到它最终意识到标记的相关性，然后相当迅速地识别出真正的标记。58整个过程清晰地展现了动物对情境的好奇心，它不断探寻隐藏的、能够控制自身的可能性，并在追求这一目标的过程中，发现隐藏在令人费解的表象背后的有序脉络。因此，即使在原始阶段，解决问题的本质特征也显而易见。

There is evidence that during these attempts the animal’s choices are not random, but follow from the start some such system as ‘turn always to the right’ or ‘always to the left’ or ‘alternately right and left’, until it eventually tumbles to the relevance of the markings and then fairly rapidly identifies the true one.58 The whole process clearly shows the animal’s capacity to be intrigued by a situation, to pursue consistently the intimation of a hidden possibility for bringing it under control, and to discover in the pursuit of this aim an orderly context concealed behind its puzzling appearances. The essential features of problem-solving are thus apparent even at this primitive level.

虽然手势学习和技巧学习一样，能带来新的运动习惯，但这些习惯相对来说微不足道，仅次于其他方面。只需稍微改动实验装置，就能轻易改变动物最终的行为，因此，手势事件关系的学习会导致截然不同的运动动作。因此， B 型学习的主要内容并非设计巧妙的动作，而是观察这些动作所依据的手势事件关系。这种学习主要不是基于运动能力，而是基于感知能力。像老鼠和狗这样的动物天生就具备连贯地掌握它们感知到的事物的能力，而手势学习似乎是这种感知能力通过智力力量的延伸。 59

While sign-learning results, like trick learning, in new motoric habits, these are comparatively trivial and only of secondary importance. What the animal will eventually do can be readily varied by slightly modifying the experimental apparatus, so that the learning of the sign event relationship results in quite different motoric actions. Type B learning consists therefore not primarily in the contriving of skilful actions, but in the observing of a sign-event relation on which these actions follow. Such learning is grafted primarily not on motility but on perception. Animals like rats and dogs are richly equipped by nature to grasp coherently the things they perceive, and sign learning appears to be an extension of this perceptive faculty by the power of intelligence.59

动物只有在欲望或恐惧的驱使下才会学习，从这个意义上讲，所有学习都是有目的的。然而，在设计一个有用的技巧时，目的会直接指导行动，而观察一个有用的符号则仅仅受感官的普遍警觉性所引导，这种警觉性受到任何特定目的的刺激，但并非由任何特定目的决定。因此，技巧学习，就像人类技能的运用一样，比符号学习更完全受目的控制，而符号学习，就像鉴赏力一样，主要依靠集中注意力。

Animals learn only when impelled by desire or fear, and in this sense all learning is purposive. But while in the contriving of a useful trick purpose guides action directly, the observing of a useful sign is guided only by a general alertness of the senses, which is stimulated but not determined by any specific purpose. Thus trick learning, like the performance of human skills, is more completely controlled by purpose than sign-learning, which, like connoisseurship, is primarily the achievement of strained attention.

C型。当动物发明新技巧时，它会利用特定的手段-目的关系来重组其行为以达到目的；同样，学习新手势的动物会通过在手势与其所指事件之间建立有效且有用的一致性来重组其感觉场。这两种学习形式都建立了时间序列，无论是学习者设计的还是观察到的。（A型或B型）C型学习发生在重组过程并非通过特定的设计或观察行为实现，而是通过对几乎从一开始就完全可以检验的情境获得真正的理解。C型被描述为潜在学习，表明在这种情况下，动物学到的东西可以比学习技巧或手势的经验教训以更多、更难以预测的方式巧妙地展现出来。例如，一只学会了走迷宫的老鼠，当其中一条路径被封闭时，它会在选择最短的替代路径方面表现出高度的独创性。60老鼠的这种行为可以解释为，它已经获得了迷宫的心理地图，当它面对迷宫内的不同情况时，它可以使用该地图进行引导。61

Type C. When an animal contrives a new trick it reorganizes its behaviour to serve a purpose by exploiting a particular means-end relationship; and similarly, the animal learning a new sign reorganizes its sensory field by establishing in it a valid and useful coherence between a sign and the event signified by it. Both forms of learning establish a time sequence, whether contrived or observed by the learner. (Type A or B.) Learning of Type C occurs when the process of reorganization is achieved not by a particular act of contriving or observing, but by achieving a true understanding of a situation which had been open to inspection almost entirely from the start. Type C has been described as latent learning, to suggest that in such cases the animal learns something which it can intelligently manifest in more numerous and less predictable ways than the lessons of trick or sign learning. Thus a rat which has learned to run a maze will show a high degree of ingenuity in choosing the shortest alternative path when one of the paths has been closed to it.60 This behaviour of the rat is such as would be accounted for by its having acquired a mental map of the maze, which it can use for its guidance when faced with different situations within the maze.61

从对情境的潜在知识中推导出各种适当途径或替代行为模式的能力，相当于一种基本的逻辑运算。它预示着一个清晰的解释框架的使用，我们依赖该框架来表征复杂的情境，并从中不断推导出关于该情境其他方面的新推论。当主体能够从一开始就一目了然地掌握所面临的情境时，潜在学习就转化为纯粹的问题解决。这将探索降至最低，并将任务完全转移到后续的推理过程。学习成为一种“洞察”行为，在此之前是一段静默的思考；正如我们在科勒的黑猩猩的表现中所看到的那样。

The capacity for deriving from a latent knowledge of a situation a variety of appropriate routes or alternative modes of behaviour amounts to a rudimentary logical operation. It prefigures the use of an articulate interpretative framework on which we rely as a representation of a complex situation, drawing from it ever new inferences regarding further aspects of that situation. Latent learning is transformed into pure problem- solving when the situation confronting the subject can be taken in by it from the start, at a glance. This reduces exploration to a minimum and shifts the task altogether to the subsequent process of inference. Learning becomes then an act of ‘insight’, preceded by a period of quiet deliberation; as we see demonstrated by the performances of Köhler’s chimpanzees.

相比之下，当理解力不足时，潜在理解力作为问题解决行为的指导作用最为明显。黑猩猩以一种极其不稳定的方式（例如，将它们竖直放置）堆放包装箱，表明它掌握了通过建造塔楼来攀爬以增加高度的原理，而不知道使这些塔楼稳定的条件。正如科勒所说，它的错误是一个“好错误”。62因为它证明了一种巧妙的推理过程，这种推理过程部分依赖于错误的假设，从而超出了自身的范围。因此，推理能力的崛起本身就带来了推理错误的能力。我们很快就会看到，在将实际问题转化为语言术语的过程中，这一点将得到进一步体现（第93页）。

The functioning of a latent understanding as a guide to the act of problem-solving comes out most clearly by contrast, when understanding is only partial. The chimpanzee who piles up packing-cases in a grossly unstable manner (for example by placing them edgewise), shows that he has grasped the principle of gaining height by constructing a tower on which to climb up, without knowing the conditions for making the constructions stable. Its error is a ‘good error’, as Köhler calls it,62 for it testifies to an ingenious process of inference which overreaches itself by relying partly on mistaken assumptions. Thus the very rise of inferential power brings with it the conjoint capacity for inferential error. We shall presently see this manifested further in the process of transposing practical problems into verbal terms (p. 93).

在儿童成长过程中，我们可以观察到儿童从不清晰的行为发展到接近并最终达到清晰行为的过程。皮亚杰对这类观察进行了广泛的研究，并根据儿童在其成长的各个连续阶段的行为中所体现的逻辑操作进行了分析。63在婴儿的早期阶段，甚至比通常用于动物智力测试的阶段更为原始，我们可以观察到婴儿正在构建空间框架。起初，婴儿无法识别物体的恒定性，但一旦物体被遮盖，他就会放弃寻找。例如，当一块手表被手帕遮住时，孩子不会拿起手帕，而是会缩回手。但随着婴儿逐渐成熟，他逐渐认识到，即使看不见或摸不到，物体仍然持续存在，并学会了即使距离不同、角度不同，也能将物体视为具有恒定大小和形状。64可以通过以下实验来测试空间定向能力的进一步提升：将三个不同颜色的娃娃串在一根金属丝上，并将它们移到屏幕后面，让儿童预测 (1) 娃娃在屏幕另一侧再次出现的正序，以及 (2) 娃娃返回时的逆序。逆序预测通常要到4-5岁左右，也就是皮亚杰所说的“前概念期”的末期。 65

The development of inarticulate behaviour up to the point where it approximates and finally achieves an articulate form, can be watched in the maturing child. Observations of this kind, carried out extensively by Piaget, have been analysed by him in terms of such logical operations as he finds embodied in the behaviour of the child at consecutive stages of its maturation.63 At the earliest stage, even more primitive than that usually studied in intelligence tests on animals, the infant can be observed building up a spatial framework. At first he does not recognize objects as permanent, but gives up any attempt to find them as soon as they are covered up. For example, when a watch is hidden by a handkerchief the child, instead of lifting the handkerchief, withdraws his hand. But with growing maturity, he learns that objects continue to exist even while not seen or felt, and learns to see them as having constant sizes and shapes though presented at different distances and from different angles.64 Further improvements in the capacity for spatial orientation may be tested, for example, by an experiment in which three dolls of different colours strung on a wire are moved behind a screen, and children are asked to predict (1) the direct order of reappearance at the opposite side of the screen, and (2) the reverse order of return. The reverse order is predicted only at about 4– 5 years, at the end of what Piaget calls the ‘preconceptual period’.65

皮亚杰曾将儿童以这种方式取得的进步描述为智力的发展，但更准确地说，应该称之为一种增强的心理训练，这种训练是通过建立一个日益复杂的固定解释框架来实现的。由固定框架引导的推理总是可以追溯到其前提，皮亚杰指出，这种“可逆性”可以被视为训练有素的思维的一个特征。 66

The progress achieved by the child in this manner has been described by Piaget as a development of its intelligence, but it might be more precise to call it an increased mental discipline, achieved by establishing a fixed interpretative framework of growing complexity. An inference guided by a fixed framework can always be traced back to its premisses, and such ‘reversibility’, Piaget points out, may be regarded as a characteristic feature of disciplined thought.66

可逆性可以与不可逆过程形成对比，后者在智能行为的重要部分中占主导地位。在（A）技巧学习、（B）符号学习和（C）潜在学习这三种类型中，我们都可以区分学习过程（不可逆）和学习所取得的成果（相对可逆）。在前两种情况下，区别相当明显。在案例A中，我们观察到设计技巧的不可逆行为，这与后续的成果截然不同，后续的成果不涉及任何变化，因此可以说它们是可逆的。在案例B中，我们观察到建立符号-事件关系的不可逆行为，这与后续对已被识别的符号做出反应的可逆成果截然不同。在案例C中，区别可能并不总是如此清晰。第一个不可逆阶段可能是系统探索的阶段，最终逐渐构建出一个解释框架，但也可能仅仅是对某种情境的困惑思考，最终在灵光一闪中得到解决方案。同样，在第二阶段的概念操作中，贡献不可逆系数的创造力的多少可能差异很大。尽管如此，在案例C中，我们也可以清楚地区分不可逆的洞察行为和相对可逆的由此产生的执行。

Reversibility can be contrasted with the irreversible processes which predominate throughout an important part of intelligent behaviour. In each case of the three types (A) Trick learning, (B) Sign learning, (C) Latent learning, we may distinguish between the process of learning, which is irreversible, and the performances achieved by learning, which are comparatively reversible. In the first two cases the distinction is clear enough. In case A we have the irreversible act of contriving a trick, as distinct from the subsequent performances, which involve no change in it and in this sense may be said to be reversible. In case B we have the irreversible act of establishing a sign-event relation, as distinct from the subsequent reversible performance of reacting to a sign already recognized as such. In case C the distinction is perhaps not always so clear. The first, irreversible phase may be one of systematic exploration, resulting in the gradual building up of an interpretative framework, but it may also be merely a puzzled contemplation of a situation, leading to a solution in a flash of insight. Again, the amount of ingenuity contributing an irreversible coefficient to the conceptual operations of the second phase, may vary considerably. Yet in spite of this we may distinguish also in case C, clearly enough, between an act of insight, which is irreversible, and the resultant performance, which is comparatively reversible.

在每种情况下，实际的学习过程都包含在第一阶段中，而第二阶段则在于展现通过学习获得的知识。我们可以将第一阶段称为启发式行为，而第二阶段则或多或少具有常规性。对于A型，启发式行为是设计；对于B型，启发式行为是观察；对于C型，启发式行为是理解。常规行为包括：对于A型，重复一个技巧；对于B型，持续对一个符号做出反应；对于C型，解决一个常规问题。从智力角度来看，首次设计、观察或理解某事物的能力不能低于基于由此获得的知识的表现。因此，我们在这个原始层面上已经承认存在两种类型的智力：一种是不可逆地实现创新，另一种是可逆地运用固定的知识框架。尽管在智力生活的非表达层面，这种区别可能显得不确定，但它在表达智力的相应领域中更充分确立的表现，在此已足够清晰地预示。

In each case the actual process of learning is covered by the first stage, while the second stage consists in displaying the knowledge acquired by learning. We may call the first a heuristic act by contrast to the second which is of a more or less routine character. For type A the heuristic act is a contriving; for B an observing; for C an understanding. The routine acts are: for A, the repeating of a trick, for B, the continued responding to a sign, and for C, the solving of a routine problem. The capacity for contriving, observing or understanding something for the first time cannot be rated intellectually below that of the performances based on the resultant knowledge. Therefore, we acknowledge already at this primitive level the existence of two kinds of intelligence: one achieving innovations, irreversibly, the other operating a fixed framework of knowledge, reversibly. Although at the inarticulate level of intellectual life this distinction may appear precarious, its more fully established manifestations in the corresponding domains of articulate intelligence are clearly enough prefigured here.

我们动物的三种学习类型，是人类三种更高级能力的原始形式。技巧学习可以被视为一种发明行为；符号学习被视为一种观察行为；潜在学习被视为一种解读行为。语言的运用将每一种能力发展成一门独特的科学，而其他两种能力则为其做出辅助性贡献。

Our three types of animal learning are primordial forms of three faculties more highly developed in man. Trick-learning may be regarded as an act of invention; sign-learning as an act of observation; latent learning as an act of interpretation. The use of language develops each of these faculties into a distinctive science to which the other two contribute subsidiarily.

因此，发明的最高境界将涵盖专利中描述的所有巧妙实用的操作，这些操作构成了工程和技术的主题。观察，即使仅限于动物在学习实验中所关注的事物，也可以被认为在最高的表达层面上涵盖了整个自然科学。从动物的角度来看，实验性条件反射相当于一个归纳推理的过程。因此，识别符号-事件关系的动物正在产生一种原始形式的观察科学。

Thus, invention will include at its highest reaches the whole array of ingenious and useful operations of the kind that are described in patents and form the subjects of engineering and technology. Observation, even when restricted to the kind of things animals are concerned within learning experiments, may be taken to include at the highest articulate level the whole of natural science. Experimental conditioning amounts from the animal’s point of view to a process of inductive inference. An animal recognizing a sign-event relationship is therefore producing a primordial form of observational science.

从C类不清晰学习到其清晰学习（我称之为“阐释”）的转变，在皮亚杰关于儿童训练思维起源的研究中已有追溯。最终，隐含地支配儿童成长至青春期智力行为的操作规则将包含一个逻辑系统，以及数学和经典力学的元素。这类智力的最高清晰形式是数学、逻辑和数学物理，或者更概括地说，是演绎科学。应用数学以对象为导向，而纯数学没有外部对象；由于它关注自身创造的对象，因此可以被描述为“对象创造”。

The transition from inarticulate learning of type C to its articulate counterpart (which I have called Interpretation), has been traced in Piaget’s work on the genesis of disciplined thought in children. Eventually, the operational rules implicitly governing the intelligent behaviour of the child growing up to adolescence will comprise a system of logic, together with the elements of mathematics and classical mechanics. The highest articulate forms of this type of intelligence are mathematics, logic and mathematical physics, or more generally, the deductive sciences. While applied mathematics is object-directed, pure mathematics has no outside object; being concerned with objects of its own creation, it may be described as ‘object creating’.

在智力的表达层面，启发式行为与对既有知识的单纯常规应用截然不同。它们是发明家和发现者的行为，需要独创性，并为天才的发挥提供空间，这一点既不同于工程师应用已知设备的行为，也不同于教师展示既有的科学成果的行为。启发式智力行为可以丰富知识，从这个意义上讲是不可逆的；而随后的常规操作则在现有的知识框架内进行，因此在一定程度上是可逆的。可逆和不可逆心理过程之间的区别，以及这种区别对可指定和不可指定知识形式之间区别的更广泛意义，将在下文中阐明。

At the articulate level of intelligence, heuristic acts fall distinctly apart from mere routine applications of established knowledge. They are the acts of the inventor and discoverer, which require originality and offer scope for genius, differing in this both from the performance of engineers who apply known devices and of teachers demonstrating established results of science. Intellectual acts of a heuristic kind make an addition to knowledge and are in this sense irreversible, while the ensuing routine performances operate within an existing framework of knowledge and are to this extent reversible. The wider significance of the difference between reversible and irreversible mental processes, and the bearing of this distinction on that between specifiable and unspecifiable forms of knowledge, will become apparent later.

 

 

  1. 语言的操作原理
  2. OPERATIONAL PRINCIPLES OF LANGUAGE

我现在将尝试定义语言成为实现巨大表达壮举的工具的主要原则。

I shall now try to define the main principles by which language becomes the instrument for the tremendous feats of articulation.

话语主要有三种类型：（1）情感表达；（2）诉诸他人；（3）事实陈述。每种类型都对应着不同的语言功能。我在此设想的从默示到清晰表达的过渡仅限于陈述事实的言语形式。67

There are three main kinds of utterances, namely: (1) expressions of feeling, (2) appeals to other persons, (3) statements of fact. To each of these there corresponds a different function of language. The transition from the tacit to the articulate which I am envisaging here is restricted to the indicative forms of speech, as used for statements of fact.67

诚然，语言首先且始终是人际的，并在某种程度上充满激情；这仅在情感表达（充满激情的交流）和祈使语气（言语行动）中体现，而即使在陈述事实的陈述中，也包含某种目的（沟通）和激情（表达信念）。事实上，我的论证试图展现的正是即使最不个人化的言语形式中也固有且不可或缺的个人激情成分。但如果我们暂时忽略这种可能性，主要关注语言纯粹的指示性运用，就能更清楚地认识到清晰表达所赋予的独特智性力量。 68即便如此，语言从一开始就应该包括文字、数学、图表和地图、图解和图片；简而言之，所有形式的符号表示，在随后对语言过程的描述所定义的意义上，都被用作语言。 69

Admittedly, language is primarily and always interpersonal and in some degree impassioned; exclusively so in emotional expression (passionate communication) and imperative speech (action by speech), while even in declaratory statements of fact there is some purpose (to communicate) and passion (to express belief). In fact, it is precisely the ingredient of personal passion inherent in and necessary to even the least personal forms of speech which my argument seeks to exhibit. But the peculiar intellectual powers conferred by articulation can be recognized more clearly if we disregard this possibility for the moment, and attend principally to the bare indicative solitary use of language.68 Even so, language should be taken from the start to include writing, mathematics, graphs and maps, diagrams and pictures; in short, all forms of symbolic representation which are used as language in the sense defined by the subsequent description of the linguistic process.69

语言的运作原则解释了人类在智力上远超动物的全部原因，这些原则似乎包含两个方面。第一，它控制着语言表征的过程；第二，它控制着符号的运作，以辅助思维过程。每一项原则都可以通过将其优势发挥到极致，甚至达到一种显然荒谬的极致完美境界来论证，从而揭示出一种此前被忽略的限制的必要性。

The operational principles of language which account for the entire intellectual superiority of men over animals seem to be twofold. The first controls the process of linguistic representation, the second the operation of symbols to assist the process of thought. Each principle can be demonstrated by taking its advantages to an extreme and obviously absurd limit of perfection, and thus exhibiting the necessity of a restraint which had thereby been left out of account.

（1）假设你想通过无限增加语言的丰富性来改进它。我们可以设想，通过不同的音素或字母组合，我们可以构建出 23 个字母的字母表，即大约一亿亿个八个字母的代码词，从而了解由不同音素或字母组合可以形成的印刷或书写单词的数量。这应该使我们能够用不同的印刷单词替换英语中曾经印刷过的每个不同的句子，这样这个代码词（可以充当动词）就可以涵盖该句子的含义。这种百万倍的丰富性会彻底摧毁英语；不仅因为没有人能记住这么多单词，更重要的是，这些单词将变得毫无意义。因为单词的意义是通过重复使用来形成和体现的，而我们绝大多数八个字母的代码词只会使用一次，或者至少很少使用，以至于无法获得和表达一个明确的含义。因此，一种语言必须足够贫乏，才能允许相同的单词被使用足够多次。我们可以称之为贫困法则。 70

(1)Suppose you wanted to improve a language by increasing its richness indefinitely. We can get an idea of the enormous number of printed or written words that could be formed by different combinations of phonemes or letters, by envisaging the fact that from an alphabet of 23 letters we could construct 238, i.e. about one hundred thousand million eight-letter code words. This should allow us to replace each different sentence ever printed in the English language by a different printed word, so that this code word (which would function as a verb) would cover what that sentence asserts. This millionfold enrichment of the English language would completely destroy it; not only because nobody could remember so many words, but for the more important reason that they would be meaningless. For the meaning of a word is formed and manifested by its repeated usage, and the vast majority of our eight-letter code words would be used only once or at any rate too rarely to acquire and express a definite meaning. It follows that a language must be poor enough to allow the same words to be used a sufficient number of times. We may call this the Law of Poverty.70

当然，如果要用一万个词语来表达一万亿个陈述，那么只有当我们能够组合词语，使它们共同表达一个既定的含义时，才能做到这一点。因此，一个足够贫乏的固定词汇必须在某些固定的组合模式中使用，这些模式始终具有相同的含义。只有符合语法规则的词组才能用有限的词汇表达与已知经验范围相关的、种类繁多的事物。71

Of course, if ten thousand words must do duty for making ten thousand million statements, this can be achieved only if we can form combinations of words so that they jointly express an intended meaning. A fixed vocabulary of sufficient poverty must therefore be used within some fixed modes of combination, which always have the same meaning. Only grammatically ordered word clusters can say with a limited vocabulary the immense variety of things that are apposite to the range of known experience.71

贫乏法则和语法法则并未穷尽语言的首要操作原则。它们指的是词语，但词语若非被可识别地重复并持续使用，就无法成为词语。因此，在贫乏法则和语法法则的基础上，我们还有另外两个要求：迭代法则和一致性法则。

The Laws of Poverty and Grammar do not exhaust the first operational principle of language. They refer to words, but words are not words unless they are both identifiably repeated and consistently used. Thus, underlying the Laws of Poverty and Grammar, we have two further requirements: the Laws of Iteration and Consistency.

为了使单词能够在不同的口语或书面语中被可识别地重复，音素和字母必须是可重复的。它们必须由某种特征来选择和定义，这种特征具有格式塔心理学所描述的“ prägnanz”的独特性，我在第一部分中已经通过将其与随机配置进行对比，以及其他类型的顺序来承认这种独特性。重复或识别单词的过程（无论是口语还是书面语）当然永远不会完全没有风险，从而产生可能歪曲历史的言语错误。72或导致语言用法的永久性变化。73发音错误和词语混淆是（至少直到最近）音乐厅里用来嘲讽低学历人群的惯用伎俩。音素、文字和词语如果能以其独特的格式塔减少这些危害，那就再好不过了。 74

In order that words may be identifiably repeated in different spoken or written sentences, phonemes and letters must be repeatable. They must be chosen for and defined by some feature possessing the kind of distinctiveness which Gestalt-psychology has described as prägnanz and which I have acknowledged before, in Part One, together with other types of order, by contrasting it with random configurations. The process of repeating or identifying words (whether in speech or writing) can of course never be quite free from hazards, whence arise verbal errors which may falsify history72 or lead to permanent changes in linguistic usage.73 Mispronunciations and the confusion of similar words are (or at least were until recently) the stock-in-trade of music halls for making fun of less educated people. Phonemes, scripts and words are good if they reduce these hazards by their distinctive gestalt.74

如果说词语可辨认的形状将之与无形的话语（例如呻吟或吱吱声）区分开来，那么，其一致的使用方式又将其与清晰可重复的话语（例如曲调）区分开来，后者缺乏用于表达某种表情、诉求或陈述的一致用途。只有当可重复的话语被一致使用时，它们才能具有明确的意义，而没有明确意义的话语则不是语言。语言的贫乏只有在话语既可重复又一致的情况下才能发挥其外延功能。

If their identifiable shape distinguishes words from shapeless utterances, like groans or squeaks, their consistent use distinguishes them from clearly repeatable utterances—like tunes—which have no consistent use for conveying an expression, an appeal or a statement. Only when repeatable utterances are used consistently can they have a definite meaning, and utterances without definite meaning are not language. The poverty of language can fulfil its denotative functions only if utterances are both repeatable and consistent.

“一致性”是一个刻意含糊的术语，指的是一种无法具体说明的性质。由于世界就像万花筒一样，永远不会精确地重复任何先前的情境（事实上，即使重复了，我们也无从知晓，因为我们无法判断其间是否发生了时间的流逝），我们只有通过识别某些特定特征明显不同的情境才能实现一致性，而这需要一系列个人判断。首先，我们必须确定哪些经验变化与识别这一反复出现的特征无关，因为它们不构成该特征的一部分，也就是说，我们必须区分其随机背景。其次，我们必须确定哪些变化应该被接受为这一可识别特征外观的正常变化，或者相反，应该被完全否定这一特征作为经验反复出现元素的可信度。因此，贫困和一致性定律意味着，每当我们使用一个词来表示某种事物时，我们都在执行并认可我们对概括行为的执行，并且相应地，使用这样一个词来指定我们赋予其实质性特征的类别。

‘Consistency’ is a deliberately imprecise term designating an unspecifiable quality. Since the world, like a kaleidoscope, never exactly repeats any previous situation (and indeed, if it did we would not know it, as we would have no means of telling that time had passed in between), we can achieve consistency only by identifying manifestly different situations in respect to some particular feature, and this requires a series of personal judgments. First, we must decide what variations of our experience are irrelevant to the identification of this recurrent feature, as forming no part of it, i.e. we must discriminate against its random background. Secondly, we must decide what variations should be accepted as normal changes in the appearance of this identifiable feature, or should be taken, on the contrary, to discredit this feature altogether as a recurrent element of experience. Thus the Laws of Poverty and Consistency imply that every time we use a word for denoting something, we perform and accredit our performance of an act of generalization and that, correspondingly, the use of such a word is taken to designate a class to which we attribute a substantial character.

此外，通过准备在未来的场合使用我们的语言，我们预期它适用于未来的经验，我们期望这些经验能够根据我们语言所认可的自然类别进行识别。这些预期形成了一种宇宙理论，我们在谈论事物的过程中不断地对其进行检验。只要我们觉得我们的语言能够很好地分类，我们就会一直认为它是正确的，并继续接受我们语言中隐含的宇宙理论为真。

Moreover, by being prepared to speak in our language on future occasions, we anticipate its applicability to future experiences, which we expect to be identifiable in terms of the natural classes accredited by our language. These expectations form a theory of the universe, which we keep testing continuously as we go on talking about things. So long as we feel that our language classifies things well, we remain satisfied that it is right and we continue to accept the theory of the universe implied in our language as true.

我们通过使用一种语言所接受的这种普遍理论的本质，可以通过以下方式更清晰地理解。在当今常用的2000到3000个英语词汇中，每个词汇在英国和美国各地人们的日常交流中平均出现一亿次。在一个拥有一百万册藏书、词汇量为3万个单词的图书馆中，相同的词汇平均会出现一百万次以上。因此，一个由名词、形容词、动词和副词组成的特定词汇表，似乎构成了一种涵盖所有可讨论主题的理论，其意义在于假定这些主题都是由相对较少的重复性特征构成的，而名词、形容词、动词和副词都指向这些特征。75这种理论与化合物理论有些相似。化学认为，数百万种不同的化合物是由少数（大约一百种）持久且相同的化学元素组成的。由于每种元素都有一个名称和特征符号，我们可以根据化合物所含的元素来记录其组成成分。这相当于用某种语言的词语写下一个句子。这种类比还可以进一步发展。我们可以将用于指定给定组成化合物内部结构的括号系统视为类似于语法结构，后者表明组成句子的词语所指事物之间的内部关系。

The nature of this universal theory which we accept by using a language can be more clearly understood as follows. Of the 2000–3000 English words in common usage today, each occurs on the average a hundred million times in the daily intercourse of people throughout Britain and the United States. In a library of a million volumes using a vocabulary of 30,000 words, the same words will recur on the average more than a million times. A particular vocabulary of nouns, adjectives, verbs and adverbs, thus appears to constitute a theory of all subjects that can be talked about, in the sense of postulating that these subjects are all constituted of comparatively few recurrent features, to which the nouns, adjectives, verbs and adverbs refer.75 Such a theory is somewhat similar to that of chemical compounds. Chemistry alleges that the millions of different compounds are composed of a small number—about a hundred—of persistent and identical chemical elements. Since each element has a name and characteristic symbol attached to it, we can write down the composition of any compound in terms of the elements which it contains. This corresponds to writing down a sentence in the words of a certain language. The parallel can be pushed still further. We may regard the system of brackets used for specifying the internal structure of a compound of given composition, as analogous to grammatical constructions which indicate the internal relations between the things denoted by the words composing a sentence.

我们已经看到，谈论事物就是将我们语言所隐含的宇宙理论应用于我们所说的具体事物。因此，这种谈论与第一部分所描述的过程相衔接，即精确科学的理论应用于经验的过程。但这种联系与第四部分稍后将要讨论的描述性科学更为密切。要像谈论事物一样，根据我们已有名称的特征对事物进行分类，需要具备博物学家识别动植物标本时所必备的那种鉴赏能力。因此，通过准确运用丰富的词汇进行精确表达的艺术，与专业分类学家所进行的精细辨别相似。

To talk about things, we have seen, is to apply the theory of the universe implied by our language to the particulars of which we speak. Such talk is therefore continuous with the process described in Part One, by which the theories of the exact sciences are brought to bear on experience. But the connection is still closer with the descriptive sciences to be treated later in Part Four. To classify things in terms of features for which we have names, as we do in talking about things, requires the same kind of connoisseurship as the naturalist must have for identifying specimens of plants or animals. Thus the art of speaking precisely, by applying a rich vocabulary exactly, resembles the delicate discrimination practised by the expert taxonomist.

第一部分从反思精确科学应用于经验中得出的教训现在可以扩展如下。我们已经看到，在将形式主义应用于经验的过程中，都存在着不确定性，观察者必须根据不可具体化的标准来解决它。现在我们可以进一步说，将语言应用于事物的过程也必然是非形式化的：它是无法言喻的。因此，外延是一门艺术，我们对事物的任何描述都假定我们认可自己掌握了这门艺术的技能。语言使用中固有的所有肯定的这种个人因素，我们将在不可言喻的知识和不可言喻的思想的更广阔背景下重新思考。

The lesson derived in Part One from reflecting on the application of the exact sciences to experience can be extended now as follows. We have seen that in all applications of a formalism to experience there is an indeterminacy involved, which must be resolved by the observer on the ground of unspecifiable criteria. Now we may say further that the process of applying language to things is also necessarily unformalized: that it is inarticulate. Denotation, then, is an art, and whatever we say about things assumes our endorsement of our own skill in practising this art. This personal coefficient of all affirmations inherent in the use of language will be presently reconsidered in the wider context of ineffable knowledge and ineffable thought.

（2）语言的第二个操作原则可以从将另一种完善语言的方式推向极致的荒谬性中发现。我可以用制图过程来最好地说明这一点。地图的比例尺越接近1，就越精确；但如果地图达到了1，并以自然大小来表示地貌特征，它就变得毫无用处，因为在地图上找到方向的难度与在地图所代表的区域内找到方向的难度差不多。我们可以得出结论，语言符号必须具有合理的大小，或者更概括地说，它们必须由易于处理的对象组成。印刷语言的易处理大小使得一个书架上的《大英百科全书》就能容纳涵盖所有现存最大和最微小物体的信息。语言能够帮助思考的程度，取决于其符号的可复制、存储、传输和重新排列程度，以及因此比它们所表示的事物更容易被思考的程度。教堂和金字塔是符号，但它们不是语言，因为它们不易复制或处理。我们可以把这个要求称为可管理性法则。

(2)The second operational principle of language can be discovered from the absurdity of taking to its limit another manner of perfecting language. I can best exemplify this by the process of mapping. A map is the more accurate the nearer its scale approaches unity, but if it were to reach unity and represent the features of a landscape in their natural size, it would become useless, since it would be about as difficult to find one’s way on the map as in the region represented by it. We may conclude that linguistic symbols must be of reasonable size, or more generally that they must consist of easily manageable objects. The manageable size of printed language enables a single shelf holding the Encyclopaedia Britannica to contain information ranging over all the largest and the most minute objects in existence. Language can assist thought only to the extent to which its symbols can be reproduced, stored up, transported, re-arranged, and thus more easily pondered, than the things which they denote. Churches and pyramids are symbols but they are not language because they cannot be easily reproduced or handled. We may call this requirement the Law of Manageability.

这一要求在某种程度上已被预见，前提是假设我们能够重复发出相同的指令，并能够按照某些规则将相同的词语组合成大量不同的句子。但可管理性的作用远不止于此，它还能拓展人类的智力。

This requirement has been anticipated already to some extent, by assuming that we can utter the same designation on repeated occasions and that we can compose a great number of different sentences by putting together the same words according to certain rules. But the services of manageability go far beyond this in enlarging the intellectual powers of man.

概括而言，可管理性原则在于设计一种经验表征，以揭示其新的面向。这一原则的运作方式很简单，只需写下或以其他方式说出对某种经验的描述，我们便可从中直接解读出其新颖的特征。符号的可管理性也可能包括其能够根据公认的符号操作规则进行操控的能力，或者仅仅是非正式地处理，例如我们翻阅书籍以重新思考其主题。

In the most general terms, the principle of manageability consists in devising a representation of experience which reveals new aspects of it. This principle can be put into operation simply by writing down or otherwise uttering a designation of an experience, from which we can directly read off novel features of it. Alternatively, the manageability of symbols may include their capacity to be manipulated according to rules acknowledged as symbolic operations, or else merely to be handled informally, as when we turn the pages of a book in order to reconsider its subject.

这些对思想的可管理性的服务可以描述为三个阶段：

These services of manageability to thought can all be described as taking place in three stages:

 

 

  1. 主要含义。
  2. Primary denotation.
  1. 其重组。
  2. Its reorganization.
  1. 结果的读取。
  2. The reading of the result.

 

 

当通过对主要含义进行新颖的解读而在心理上发生重组时，第 2 阶段和第 3 阶段会合并为一个。

Stages 2 and 3 are merged into one when reorganization occurs mentally by a novel reading of the primary denotation.

这三个阶段中的每一个阶段可能相对简单，也可能需要不同程度的创造力，直至达到天才的程度（我将在后面讨论）。此外，重组过程可能包括将原始符号转换为另一组符号，例如，当数值观察结果用图表表示或口头陈述用方程式表示时，这个过程也可能需要相当的创造力。

Each of the three stages may be relatively trivial or else may require various grades of ingenuity up to that of genius (of which I shall treat later). Furthermore, the process of reorganization may be taken to include the transposition of the primary denotation into another set of symbols, as when numerical observations are represented by graphs or verbal statements by equations, a process which may also require considerable ingenuity.

我们已经看到，在被称为C型的潜在学习过程中，动物会在心理上重组它们的经验记忆。现在看来，人类的智力优势主要在于这种能力的扩展，即通过将经验转化为易于理解的符号来表达，人类可以对其进行形式上或心理上的重组，从而获得新的信息。这种大幅增强的重新解释能力当然最终基于构成我们语言天赋的隐性能力相对略微的优势。语言就是设计符号，观察它们的适用性，并解释它们的替代关系；尽管动物拥有这三种能力，但它们无法将它们结合起来。 76

We have seen that in the process of latent learning, described as Type C, animals reorganize their memories of experience mentally. It appears now that the intellectual superiority of man is due predominantly to an extension of this power by the representation of experience in terms of manageable symbols which he can reorganize, either formally or mentally, for the purpose of yielding new information. This enormously increased power of reinterpretation is of course ultimately based on that relatively slight superiority of the tacit powers which constitute our gift of speech. To speak is to contrive signs, to observe their fitness, and to interpret their alternative relations; though the animal possesses each of these three faculties, he cannot combine them.76

 

 

  1. 清晰思考的力量
  2. THE POWERS OF ARTICULATE THOUGHT

下面的例子应该能说明通过简单的表示、重组和阅读机制所产生的巨大的精神力量，同时也表明，尽管我们的思维能力通过使用符号得到了极大的增强，但它们最终仍然在我们与动物共享的同一种非形式化智力媒介中运作。

The following examples should illustrate the immense range of mental powers generated by the simple machinery of denoting, reorganizing and reading, and should show at the same time that though our powers of thought be ever so much enhanced by the use of symbols, they still operate ultimately within the same medium of unformalized intelligence which we share with the animals.

对于这种极其简单的情况，使用地图寻路可以粗略地估算出从适当安排的经验表述中得出的推理能力。一幅英国粗略地图可以通过在一张纸上用点标记英国200个最大城镇的地理位置来绘制，每个点的笛卡尔坐标与该城镇的经度和纬度成恒定比例，每个点的下方都印有相应城镇的名称。从这样的地图上，我们一眼就能看出从任何城镇到任何其他城镇的路线，因此，我们最初输入的400个位置数据（200个经度和200个纬度）得出 ￼行程。实际上，从地图中获得的信息将比这更加丰富，每条行程平均包含约五十个地点，总计约一百万个项目，即输入量的2500倍。

The use of a geographical map for finding one’s way offers, for this exceptionally simple case, a rough numerical estimate of the inferential powers derived from a suitably arranged representation of experience. A rough map of England can be drawn by marking by dots on a sheet of paper the geographical positions of the 200 largest English towns, the Cartesian co-ordinates of each dot being chosen in a constant proportion to the longitude and latitude of one town, and each dot having the name of the corresponding town printed below it. From such a map we can read off at a glance the itineraries by which we can get about from any town to any other, so that our original input of 400 positional data (200 longitudes and 200 latitudes) thus yields ￼itineraries. Actually, the information derived from mapping will be much ampler even than this Each itinerary will comprise on the average some fifty places, amounting to about a million items, that is 2500 times the input.

原始目录列出了 200 个城镇的经度和纬度，但相对而言没什么用，因为它不能以一种肉眼容易理解的方式表示这些城镇的相互位置。我们可以把将目录转换成地图的形式看作对其数据进行的正式操作，然后再进行非正式操作，即从地图上读出各种路线。同样，1940 年英国空战期间收到的报告被连续地绘制在空军司令部的一张大桌子上，从而为最高指挥官提供了一种不断变化的形势的表示，他比报告本身更能理解这一点。我们知道，仅仅将一系列数值数据以图表的形式绘制在纸上，就可以揭示出我们从原始数字知识中完全无法预料的函数关系。其中一个例子是用于指示铁路交通方向的时刻表的图形表示，它立即显示了火车超越或相遇的地点和时间，而这些信息不容易从普通时刻表中推断出来。

The original catalogue of 200 towns, listing their longitudes and latitudes, would be comparatively useless, for it does not represent their mutual position in a way which the eye can readily take in. We may regard the transposition of the catalogue into the shape of a map as a formal operation carried out on its data, to be followed by the informal operation of reading off a variety of itineraries from the map. Similarly, the reports coming in during the air battles over England (1940) were continuously pictured at Air Force Command on a large table, offering thereby to the Supreme Commander a representation of the changing situation which he could grasp far better than the reports themselves. We know how the mere plotting of a series of numerical data on paper in the form of a graph, may reveal functional relationships quite unsuspected from our knowledge of the original figures. An example of this is the graphic representation of time-tables used for the direction of railroad traffic, which shows immediately the places and times at which trains overtake or meet each other, a piece of information which is not easily deduced from ordinary time-tables.

在所有这些通过适当的符号化来增强我们智力的例子中，显然，单纯的符号操作本身并不能提供任何新的信息，它之所以有效，仅仅是因为它通过读出结果来辅助我们运用那些难以言喻的思维能力。对于通过数学计算获取新信息的过程来说，这一点可能不那么明显；但在这里同样适用。假设我们知道保罗比彼得的两倍年龄小一岁，而他们之间的年龄差是四岁，我们想找出他们各自的年龄。我们必须首先用符号来表达这种情况；保罗的年龄是x，彼得的年龄是y，并且￼ 。

In all these instances of the enhancement of our intellectual powers by suitable symbolization, it is clear that the mere manipulation of symbols does not in itself supply any new information, but is effective only because it assists the inarticulate mental powers exercised by reading off their result. This may not be so obvious for the process of deriving new information by means of mathematical computations; but it is true all the same here too. Supposing we know that Paul is one year less than twice the age of Peter, while the difference between their ages is four, and we want to find the ages of each. We have first to set out the situation symbolically; age of Paul x, age of Peter y, and ￼.

然后我们对符号进行操作并得到 ￼；最终读出为：保罗9岁，彼得5岁。无论这个过程多么粗糙机械，其执行都需要一定程度的控制智慧。必须理解彼得和保罗的原始情况，并清楚地认识到其中涉及的问题；然后，必须正确地执行其符号表示，包括后续操作，并正确地解释结果。所有这些都需要智慧，正是在这些默契的智慧壮举过程中，过程中使用的正式操作得到认可，其结果也为执行者所接受。

Then we operate on the symbols and obtain ￼; which is finally read out as: Paul is aged 9 and Peter is aged 5. However crudely mechanical this procedure may be, its performance does require a measure of controlling intelligence. The original situation of Peter and Paul must be understood and the problem involved in it clearly recognized; then its symbolic representation, including the subsequent operations, has to be correctly performed and the result correctly interpreted. All of this requires intelligence, and it is in the course of these tacit feats of intelligence that the formal operations utilized in the process are accredited and their result accepted by the person carrying them out.

这里阐明的几个简单原理的运作实际上可以解释（根据第 70 页定义的第一个近似值）人类智力从动物中观察到的基本类型的非表达学习扩展到工程学、自然科学和纯数学的表达领域。

The operations of the few simple principles illustrated here can in fact account (in terms of the first approximation defined on page 70) for the expansion of human intelligence from the basic types of inarticulate learning observed in animals to the articulate domains of engineering, of the natural sciences and of pure mathematics.

首先以自然科学为例，包括精确和描述类的自然科学。经验的数值表示，以及随之而来产生新信息的计算，可以通过在计算中加入代表自然规律的公式，扩展为精确科学的逻辑机制。我在第一部分已经详细论述了作为形式主义体系的精确经验科学，下一章将再次讨论这个主题。

Take first the natural sciences, both of the exact and the descriptive kind. The numerical denotation of experience, followed by computations yielding new information, can be expanded into the logical machinery of the exact sciences by including in our computation the use of a formula representing a law of nature. I have already dealt at some length with the exact empirical sciences as a system of formalisms in Part One and shall return to the subject in the next chapter.

对于描述性科学，例如动物学和植物学，正如前文所述，我们可以从更原始的表达层面出发，仅依靠基本的，或至少是相当非正式的逻辑运算。这些科学是通过添加科学术​​语来扩展日常用语的，而它们主要依赖的符号运算是对记录知识的系统积累，以及从新的视角对这些记录进行重新整理和重新思考。

To the descriptive sciences, like zoology and botany, we can advance, as has been hinted already, from a more primitive level of articulation, relying only on rudimentary or at any rate quite informal logical operations. These sciences are an expansion of ordinary speech by the addition of a scientific nomenclature, while the symbolic operation on which they mainly rely is the systematic accumulation of recorded knowledge, and the rearranging and reconsidering of these records from new points of view.

然而，即便如此，表达过程也对我们与生俱来的记忆能力提供了极其有效的辅助。人类在迷宫中寻路的能力并不比老鼠强多少；而且，我们尚不清楚人类在其他方面是否拥有比动物更强大的、能够重组记忆经验的先天智慧。但动物的纯粹记忆只能零散地收集信息碎片，毫无系统可言；如果没有依赖于语言的系统化能力，人类也做不到更好。即便如此，直到印刷术的发明极大地加快了记录的复制速度，并使其更加简明扼要，描述性动物学和植物学才得以从亚里士多德和中世纪涵盖几百种类型的自然史发展成为涵盖数百万种物种的系统科学。

Yet even here the process of articulation has rendered immensely effective assistance to our native mnemonic powers. Man is not much superior to a rat in finding his way in a maze; and it is not clear that he possesses in other ways either much greater native intelligence than the animal for reorganizing remembered experiences. But the bare unaided memory of animals can only collect scraps of information, unsystematically; nor could man do much better, but for the power of systematization dependent on speech. And even so, not until the invention of printing enormously speeded up the reproduction of records and made them much more compendious, could descriptive zoology and botany expand from the Aristotelian and medieval natural history covering a few hundred types to a systematic science comprising millions of species.

在历史、文学和法律等人文学科领域，易于理解的记录的编纂也对记忆有着至关重要的帮助。我可能会顺便提及这些领域，尽管我的课程暂时将这些学科所属的人际表达类别排除在外。这些学科的进步完全取决于对原始资料的重新探索所带来的印刷记录的扩展，而这些原始资料本身大多是印刷记录或印刷文学作品。简明扼要地阐述此类信息的书籍以及使这些书籍易于获取的图书馆，对于扩大此类学术研究的机会至关重要。

Decisive assistance is rendered to memory by the compilation of manageable records also in the great domains of humanistic scholarship such as history, literature and law, to which I may refer in passing, though my programme has excluded for the time being the class of interpersonal articulation to which these branches of scholarship belong. Their progress depends altogether on the expansion of printed records derived from the renewed exploration of primary sources, which themselves are largely printed records or printed literary works. Books setting out such information concisely and libraries which make the books readily accessible are decisive in enlarging the opportunities of such scholarship.

与发音的记忆功能相结合的是，它们能够辅助发明家的思辨性想象力。发明家的速写本就是他的实验室。有一个测试创造力的标准实验：一个人面对着两根从天花板垂下来、几乎垂到地板的绳子，绳子两端相距甚远，以至于当你用一只手握住其中一端时，你无法够到垂直悬挂的另一根绳子。77任务是把绳子的两端系在一起。那些没能找到方法的人，很容易就找到了答案，因为他们在纸上画出了摆在面前的布置。衔接以缩小的规模描绘了情境的本质，这比笨拙的原始图景更容易被富有想象力地操纵；因此，它使工程科学成为可能。

Allied to the mnemonic services of articulation is their capacity for assisting the speculative imagination of the inventor. The inventor’s sketchbook is his laboratory. There is a standard experiment to test inventiveness, in which a person is confronted with two ropes hanging from the ceiling and almost reaching to the floor, the points of suspension being so far apart that while holding the end of either rope in one hand you cannot reach the other rope as it hangs straight down.77 The task is to tie the two ends of the ropes together. People who failed to discover how to do this, readily found the solution when they drew a picture on paper of the arrangement set up in front of them. Articulation pictures the essentials of a situation on a reduced scale, which lends itself more easily to imaginative manipulation than the ungainly original; it thereby makes possible a science of engineering.

因此，语言的两大操作原则的联合应用，可以被视为将言语扩展到科学技术文本中。但是，发明合适的符号并按照固定规则对其进行操作，可以完全超越处理经验问题的任务。通过符号运算进行的推理过程，可以在不参考实际计数或测量的实体的情况下进行，而这种推理可能很有趣。因此，纯数学是可能的。

Thus the joint application of the two operational principles of language can be seen to expand speech into the texts of science and technology. But the invention of suitable symbols and their manipulation according to fixed rules can transcend altogether the task of dealing with matters of experience. Processes of inference, conducted by symbolic operations, can be carried out without reference to actually counted or measured entities, and such inferences maybe interesting. Hence pure mathematics is possible.

如同棋子一样，纯数学符号并非（或必然）代表它们所指代的任何事物，而主要代表着根据已知规则可以运用它们的方式。数学符号体现了其可操作性的概念，正如国际象棋中的主教或骑士体现了其能够采取的走法概念一样。几个世纪以来，人们一直在发明新的数学符号，以便以更有趣或更实际的方式使用它们。数字的概念在动物中早已存在，但通过不断的符号发明，人类已将其发展到远远超出其最初六到八个整数的范围。位置符号、阿拉伯数字、零符号和小数点的出现，促进了算术运算的发明，这些运算极大地丰富了我们的数字概念，并使数字在计数和测量中的实际应用更加强大。

Like chessmen, the symbols of pure mathematics stand not, or not necessarily, for anything denoted by them, but primarily for the use that can be made of them according to known rules. The mathematical symbol embodies the conception of its operability, just as a bishop or a knight in chess embodies the conception of the moves of which it is capable. The invention of new mathematical symbols which can be used in a more interesting or practically more effective manner has been going on through the centuries. The conception of numbers is present already in animals, but, by successive symbolic inventions, man has developed it far beyond its original range of six to eight integers. The advent of positional notation, of arabic numerals, of the zero sign and the decimal point, have facilitated the invention of arithmetical operations which have both greatly enriched our notion of numbers, and made the practical application of numbers for counting and measuring more powerful.

一位数学家发明的符号可能会启发另一位数学家对相应概念进行一些有趣的变形。拉普拉斯评论说，笛卡尔幂指数的符号多么幸运，它激发了人们对除正整数幂之外的其他幂的可能性的思考。278数论中的一些问题长期以来由于计算量巨大而难以解决，直到电子计算机的出现，这些计算速度才得以提升数千倍。因此，数学的进步很大程度上依赖于发明富有表现力且易于操作的符号来表示数学概念。

A notation invented by one mathematician may suggest to another some interesting variation of the corresponding conception. Laplace remarks how fortunate was Descartes’ notation of the exponent of a power in stimulating speculations about the possibility of other than positive integer powers.278Some questions of number theory had long remained unapproachable on account of the forbidding labour of the computations required to explore them, until the construction of electronic computers speeded up these manipulations many thousand times. Thus the progress of mathematics depends greatly on the invention of expressive and easily manipulate symbols for the representation of mathematical conceptions.

形式逻辑的兴起，如同纯数学因符号创新而取得的进步。逻辑符号使我们能够清晰地表达日常语言难以理解的复杂句子。可理解的语法结构范围也因此大幅扩展，我们得以运用这些符号进行演绎论证，而这在其他情况下是难以想象的。这开辟了一个全新的推理领域，其精妙深奥值得我们认真钻研。

The rise of formal logic resembles the advances made in pure mathematics by the advent of happy symbolic innovations. Logical symbols allow us to state clearly such complex sentences as would be quite incomprehensible in ordinary language. The range of manageable grammatical structures being thus vastly increased, we can also perform in these terms feats of deductive argument which could not conceivably be attempted otherwise. This has opened up a new domain of inferences of such ingenuity and profundity as to be worth serious cultivation for its own sake.

代数或几何体系的解释术语种类繁多，令人惊讶，这体现了其指涉功能的脆弱性。它们并不指涉具体的事物，甚至可能完全是空范畴，定义明确，却不适用于任何事物。因此，无限集N包含所有数字，下一个更大的无限集N 1和N 2分别包含所有几何点和所有可想象的曲线，但集合N 3、N 4 ……等等比迄今为止所能想到的任何对象集都无限大，因此它们根本不适用于任何确定的事物——但这并不意味着它们就不具备数学实体的资格。这些自足的纯数学体系或许能告诉我们一些重要的东西，而无需首先提及自身之外的任何事物。因此，第二个衔接操作原理在此完全凌驾于第一个原理之上。事实上，数学运用了这一原理的最高威力，并证明了我们在运用这些威力时所获得的乐趣。关于这种对数学至关重要的求知热情，我将在下一章中进一步阐述。

The surprisingly varied terms in which systems of algebra or geometry can be interpreted, demonstrate the tenuousness of their denotative functions. They do not refer to particular things and may be altogether empty categories, well defined, but applying to nothing. Thus the infinite set N counts all numbers, the next larger infinite sets N1 and N2 count respectively all geometrical points and all conceivable curves, but the sets N3, N4…etc. are infinitely larger than any set of objects so far conceived, and so they apply to nothing definite at all—without being disqualified thereby as mathematical entities. These self-contained systems of pure mathematics may tell us something which is important, without primarily referring to anything outside themselves. Thus the second operational principle of articulation predominates here altogether over the first. Indeed, mathematics deploys the highest powers of this principle and testifies to our pleasure in exercising these powers. Of this intellectual passion, which is essential to mathematics, I shall say more in the next chapter.

现在，我们面前有以下一系列科学，它们对语言第一条操作原理的依赖程度逐渐降低，而对语言第二条操作原理的依赖程度逐渐增加：（1）描述科学，（2）精确科学，

We have now before us the following sequence of sciences relying decreasingly on the first and increasingly on the second operational principle of language: (1) the descriptive sciences, (2) the exact sciences,

（3）演绎科学。这是一个形式化和符号化操作不断增加，与经验联系不断减少的序列。更高程度的形式化使科学的陈述更加精确，其推论更加客观，相应地也更加“可逆”；但迈向这一理想的每一步都是以内容的逐渐牺牲为代价的。描述性科学所掌控的丰富多彩的鲜活形态，为了精确科学的目的，被缩小为纯粹的指针式解读，而当我们转向纯数学时，经验则完全从我们的直接视野中消失。

(3)the deductive sciences. It is a sequence of increasing formalization and symbolic manipulation, combined with decreasing contact with experience. Higher degrees of formalization make the statements of science more precise, its inferences more impersonal and correspondingly more ‘reversible’; but every step towards this ideal is achieved by a progressive sacrifice of content. The immense wealth of living shapes governed by the descriptive sciences is narrowed down to bare pointer- readings for the purpose of the exact sciences, and experience vanishes altogether from our direct sight as we pass on to pure mathematics.

言语的默会系数也存在相应的变化。为了更充分地描述经验，语言必须不那么精确。但更大的不精确性却能更有效地发挥那些需要解决随之而来的言语不确定性的、难以言喻的判断力。因此，正是我们个人的参与决定了我们言语所能指涉的具体经验的丰富性。只有借助这种默会系数，我们才能对经验进行任何描述——我已经通过证明外延过程本身是不可形式化的而得出了这个结论。

There is a corresponding variation in the tacit coefficient of speech. In order to describe experience more fully language must be less precise. But greater imprecision brings more effectively into play the powers of inarticulate judgment required to resolve the ensuing indeterminacy of speech. So it is our personal participation that governs the richness of concrete experience to which our speech can refer. Only by the aid of this tacit coefficient could we ever say anything at all about experience—a conclusion I have reached already by showing that the process of denotation is itself unformalizable.

 

 

  1. 思想与言语。一、文本与意义
  2. THOUGHT AND SPEECH. I. TEXT AND MEANING

这些关于默会参与表达过程的反复出现的观点，在我们明确默会与显会、个人与形式互动的过程之前，必然会一直模糊不清。但我们尚未准备好正面探讨这个问题。我们必须首先考察言语与思想之间关系的三个典型领域，在这些领域中，言语与思想的关系从一个极端类型过渡到另一个极端，中间存在一个平衡类型。这三个领域是：

These recurrent suggestions regarding the participation of the tacit in the process of articulation must remain obscure until we define the process by which the tacit co-operates with the explicit, the personal with the formal. But we are not yet ready for a frontal attack on this question. We must examine first three characteristic areas in which the relation between speech and thought varies from one extreme type to an opposite extreme, through the intermediary of a balanced type, lying midway between them. These three areas are:

（1）在这个领域中，默契占据主导地位，以至于表达几乎是不可能的；我们可以称之为不可言喻的领域。

(1)The area where the tacit predominates to the extent that articulation is virtually impossible; we may call this the ineffable domain.

（2）隐性成分是通过易于理解的语音传达的信息的领域，因此隐性成分与它所承载含义的文本具有同等广泛的范围。

(2)The area where the tacit component is the information conveyed by easily intelligible speech, so that the tacit is co-extensive with the text of which it carries the meaning.

（3）在这个领域中，默契与正式的表达方式分崩离析，因为说话者不知道，或者根本不知道自己在说什么。这种情况有两种截然不同的情况：(a)言语不通，导致表达阻碍了思维的默契运作；(b)符号操作超越了我们的理解能力，从而预示着新的思维模式。(a)和(b)都可以说构成了复杂性的范畴。

(3)The area in which the tacit and the formal fall apart, since the speaker does not know, or quite know, what he is talking about. There are two extremely different cases of this, namely (a) an ineptitude of speech, owing to which articulation encumbers the tacit work of thought; (b) symbolic operations that outrun our understanding and thus anticipate novel modes of thought. Both (a) and (b) may be said to form part of the domain of sophistication.

 

 

（1）当我谈到不可言喻的知识时，应该从字面理解，而不是将其视为神秘体验的代名词，我在此不便提及。即便如此，我试图谈论不可言喻之事，在逻辑上也可能被认为是毫无意义的。79或者说，冒犯笛卡尔的“清晰而独特的观念”学说，早期的维特根斯坦在他的格言中将其转化为语义学术语：“对于不能说的东西”——确切地说，就像自然科学中的一句话——“人们必须保持沉默”。80对这两个反对意见的回答都包含在第一部分和第二部分前面章节中提出的大量观察中，这些观察处处证明了形式化的局限性。这些观察表明，严格来说，我们所知道的任何事情都无法被精确地表述；81因此，我所说的“不可言喻”可能仅仅意味着我所了解的、甚至无法比平常更精确地描述，甚至只能非常模糊地描述的东西。回忆起这种不可言喻的经历并不难，而哲学家们对此的反对，则援引了不切实际的有效意义标准，如果严格执行，我们所有人都会陷入自愿的愚昧。当我们继续去做那些被这些反对者谴责为毫无意义或不可能的事情时，这一点将变得更加清晰。

(1)When I speak of ineffable knowledge, this should be taken literally and not as a designation of mystic experience, to which I do not wish to refer at this stage. Even so my attempt to speak of the ineffable may be thought to be logically meaningless,79 or alternatively, to offend against the Cartesian doctrine of ‘clear and distinct ideas’ which the early Wittgenstein transposed into terms of semantics in his aphorism: ‘Of what cannot be said’—i.e. said exactly, as a sentence in natural science— ‘thereof one must be silent’.80 The answer to both objections lies ready in the mass of observations presented in Part One and in the foregoing sections of Part Two, which have demonstrated everywhere the limits of formalization. These observations show that strictly speaking nothing that we know can be said precisely;81 and so what I call ‘ineffable’ may simply mean something that I know and can describe even less precisely than usual, or even only very vaguely. It is not difficult to recall such ineffable experiences, and philosophic objections to doing so invoke quixotic standards of valid meaning which, if rigorously practised, would reduce us all to voluntary imbecility. This will become clearer as we proceed to perform what such objections would condemn as meaningless or impossible.

我将要探讨的关于不可言喻性的内容，实际上与我之前论证个人知识的不可具体化性时所探讨的内容大致相同；不同之处在于，我现在将知识中不可具体化的部分视为由于表达不清晰而未言明的残余。这种缺陷很常见，而且往往很明显。我可能骑自行车却什么也不说，或者在二十件雨衣中挑出我的雨衣却什么也不说。虽然我无法清楚地说出我如何骑自行车，也无法清楚地认出我的雨衣（因为我并不清楚地了解它），但这并不妨碍我说我知道如何骑自行车以及如何认出我的雨衣。因为我知道我非常清楚如何做这些事情，尽管我只是以一种工具性的方式了解我所知道的细节，而实际上我对它们一无所知；因此，即使我无法清楚地，或者几乎完全无法说出我所知道的是什么，我也可以说我知道这些事情。

What I shall say of ineffability will in fact cover largely the same ground which I have previously traversed for the demonstration of the unspecifiability of personal knowledge; the difference being that I shall now regard the unspecifiable part of knowledge as the residue left unsaid by a defective articulation. Such defectiveness is common and often glaring. I may ride a bicycle and say nothing, or pick out my macintosh among twenty others and say nothing. Though I cannot say clearly how I ride a bicycle nor how I recognize my macintosh (for I don’t know it clearly), yet this will not prevent me from saying that I know how to ride a bicycle and how to recognize my macintosh. For I know that I know perfectly well how to do such things, though I know the particulars of what I know only in an instrumental manner and am focally quite ignorant of them; so that I may say that I know these matters even though I cannot tell clearly, or hardly at all, what it is that I know.

正如我所定义的，辅助知识或工具性知识本身并非已知，而是通过某种焦点性已知事物来获知，而它对焦点性已知事物的性质有所贡献；就此而言，它是不可具体化的。分析或许可以将辅助知识聚焦起来，并将其表述为准则或相貌特征，但这种具体化通常并非详尽无遗。尽管专业的诊断师、分类学家和棉花分类员能够指出线索并制定准则，但他们所知道的远比他们能够表述的要多，他们只是在实践中将它们作为工具性细节来了解，而不是明确地将它们作为对象来了解。因此，对这些细节的了解是无法言喻的，而根据这些细节进行判断的思考也是一个无法言喻的思维过程。这同样适用于鉴赏力，作为认知的艺术，也适用于技能，作为行动的艺术，因此，两者都只能通过实践案例来教授，而绝不能仅仅通过训诫。

Subsidiary or instrumental knowledge, as I have defined it, is not known in itself but is known in terms of something focally known, to the quality of which it contributes; and to this extent it is unspecifiable. Analysis may bring subsidiary knowledge into focus and formulate it as a maxim or as a feature in a physiognomy, but such specification is in general not exhaustive. Although the expert diagnostician, taxonomist and cotton-classer can indicate their clues and formulate their maxims, they know many more things than they can tell, knowing them only in practice, as instrumental particulars, and not explicitly, as objects. The knowledge of such particulars is therefore ineffable, and the pondering of a judgment in terms of such particulars is an ineffable process of thought. This applies equally to connoisseurship as the art of knowing and to skills as the art of doing, wherefore both can be taught only by aid of practical example and never solely by precept.

然而，即使所有细节都能被清晰地描述，构成整体的各个细节之间的关系也可能是无法言喻的。局部解剖学的研究对象就是一种无法言喻的关系，我们将以此为例来阐释这种无法言喻的原理。

But the relationship of the particulars jointly forming a whole may be ineffable, even though all the particulars are explicitly specifiable. The subject matter of topographic anatomy is such an ineffable relationship and will serve us as an example to illustrate the principle of this type of ineffability.

医学生首先要学习构成系统解剖学的骨骼、动脉、神经和内脏的列表。这在记忆方面可能比较困难，但在理解方面则基本没有困难，因为身体的特征部位通常可以通过图表清晰地识别。理解解剖学，以及解剖学教学中的主要困难，在于体内器官错综复杂、紧密排列的三维网络，任何图表都无法充分展现。即使是解剖，通过移除覆盖在某个区域上的部分，将区域及其器官暴露出来，也只能展现该区域的一个方面。想象力只能从这种经验中重建未开刀身体中暴露区域的三维图像，并在脑海中探索其与周围及下方相邻未暴露区域的联系。

The medical student first learns a list of bones, arteries, nerves, and viscera which constitutes systematic anatomy. This is hard on the memory, but mostly presents no difficulty to the understanding, for the characteristic parts of the body can usually be clearly identified by diagrams. The major difficulty in the understanding, and hence in the teaching of anatomy, arises in respect to the intricate three-dimensional network of organs closely packed inside the body, of which no diagram can give an adequate representation. Even dissection, which lays bare a region and its organs by removing the parts overlaying it, does not demonstrate more than one aspect of that region. It is left to the imagination to reconstruct from such experience the three-dimensional picture of the exposed area as it existed in the unopened body, and to explore mentally its connections with adjoining unexposed areas around it and below it.

因此，一位经验丰富的外科医生对其手术区域所掌握的那种地形学知识，是不可言喻的知识。我这样说，完全忽略了从大量细节各异的实际情况中形成正常解剖学概念所涉及的个人认知行为。假设所有人体都完全相同，并假设我们有无限的时间和耐心来绘制人体内部器官的图像。为此，假设将人体切成一千片薄片，并详细描绘每个横截面；甚至假设一位学生凭借超人的记忆力，能够准确地记住所有一千张横截面的图像。他会知道一组完全决定人体器官空间排列的数据；但他却不知道这种空间排列本身。事实上，除非他能根据这种迄今未知的排列方式来解释这些横截面，否则他所知道的横截面对他来说将是不可理解且毫无用处的；另一方面，如果他获得了这种地形理解，他就能从他的理解中获得无限量的新的、重要的信息，就像人们从地图上读出行程一样。这种推理过程可能需要持续的智力努力，是不可言喻的思想。

The kind of topographic knowledge which an experienced surgeon possesses of the regions on which he operates is therefore ineffable knowledge. In saying this, I disregard altogether the act of personal knowing involved in forming the conceptions of normal anatomy from a great number of actual instances which vary in detail. Let all human bodies be taken as absolutely identical, and let it be assumed that we have unlimited time and patience for mapping out the internal organs of the body. Let the body be cut for this purpose into a thousand thin slices and each cross section be depicted in detail; and let us even grant for full measure that, by a superhuman feat of cramming, a student could memorize precisely the picture of all the thousand cross sections. He would know a set of data which fully determine the spatial arrangement of the organs in the body; yet he would not know that spatial arrangement itself. Indeed, the cross-sections which he knows would be incomprehensible and useless to him, until he could interpret them in the light of this so far unknown arrangement; while on the other hand, had he achieved this topographic understanding, he could derive an indefinite amount of further new and significant information from his understanding, just as one reads off itineraries from a map. Such processes of inference, which may involve sustained efforts of intelligence, are ineffable thoughts.

绘图能力的缺陷，我们这里举的这个极端例子，在我们从绘制平面物体转向绘制曲面物体的那一刻就已经显现。我们只能以扭曲投影的形式在平面纸张上绘制整个地球表面，而用地球仪来表示地球表面则显得笨拙，一次只能显示一个半球。当我们面对由密集排列的不透明物体组成的复杂三维结构时，这种缺陷就变得更加难以实现。现在，对集合体有益方面的图表或演示只能为理解它提供线索，而理解本身必须通过艰难的个人洞察才能实现，而其结果必然难以言喻。82

The shortcomings of the powers of mapping, of which we have here an extreme case, set in already the moment we pass from the mapping of objects lying on a plane to objects on a curved surface. We can map the whole surface of the earth on a flat sheet of paper only in the form of a distorted projection, while its representation by a globe is clumsy and shows only one hemisphere at a time. This inadequacy is increased to the level of an impossibility when we come to an intricate three-dimensional arrangement of closely packed opaque objects. Diagrams or demonstrations of instructive aspects of the aggregate will now merely offer clues to its understanding, while understanding itself must be achieved by a difficult act of personal insight, the result of which must remain inarticulate.82

我们现在面临两种表达上的不足；它们既不同又密切相关。当我骑自行车或挑选我的雨衣时，我不知道我知识的细节，因此无法说出它们是什么；另一方面，当我了解一个复杂的三维集合体的拓扑结构时，我知道并能描述它的细节，但无法描述它们在空间上的相互关系。在这两种情况下，表达的局限性也相应不同。当用准则来解释认知技巧时，这些准则从未充分揭示该技巧的次要已知细节，因此表达能力在此阶段已经受到限制。对空间拓扑结构的表达则没有这样的限制，其细节是完全可理解的。这里的困难完全在于随后细节的整合，而表达的不足完全在于后者缺乏正式的指导。学生进行洞察行为所需的智力水平最终会向他传达地形知识，这为代表该地形的表达的局限性提供了衡量标准。

We have now two inadequacies of articulation before us; different and yet closely related. When I am riding a bicycle or picking out my macintosh, I do not know the particulars of my knowledge and therefore cannot tell what they are; when on the other hand I know the topography of a complex three-dimensional aggregate, I know and could describe its particulars, but cannot describe their spatial interrelations. The limitations of articulation are correspondingly different in the two cases. When arts of knowing are explained by maxims, these never disclose fully the subsidiarily known particulars of the art, so that the powers of articulation are already restricted at this stage. No such limitation is imposed on the articulation of a spatial topography, the particulars of which are fully accessible. The difficulty lies here entirely in the subsequent integration of the particulars, and the inadequacy of articulation consists altogether in the fact that the latter process is left without formal guidance. The degree of intelligence required from the student to perform the act of insight which ultimately conveys to him the knowledge of the topography, offers here a measure of the limitations of the articulation representing this topography.

这种难以言喻的熟练认知领域，其不可言喻性与动物和婴儿所拥有的知识在不可言喻性方面是连续的。正如我们所见，动物和婴儿也拥有重组其不可言喻的知识并将其用作解释框架的能力。解剖学家通过解剖探索复杂的结构，实际上就像老鼠在迷宫中穿梭一样运用其智力；由于他无法像老鼠一样，通过这种方式了解更多，因此他对结构解剖学的理解在这方面也与老鼠在迷宫中获得的理解相似。我们可以概括地说，通过获得一项技能，无论是肌肉技能还是智力技能，我们都获得了一种无法用语言表达的理解，这种理解与动物不可言喻的能力是连续的。

This ineffable domain of skilful knowing is continuous in its inarticulateness with the knowledge possessed by animals and infants, who, as we have seen, also possess the capacity for reorganizing their inarticulate knowledge and using it as an interpretative framework. The anatomist exploring by dissection a complex topography is in fact using his intelligence very much like a rat running a maze; and since he cannot tell any more than the rat what he gets to know in this way, his understanding of topographic anatomy remains similar in this respect as well to that which rats acquire of a maze. We may say in general that by acquiring a skill, whether muscular or intellectual, we achieve an understanding which we cannot put into words and which is continuous with the inarticulate faculties of animals.

我这样理解的东西对我来说是有意义的，它本身就具有这种意义，而不是像符号在指称对象时那样具有意义。我之前称之为存在意义。183由于动物没有能够指称任何事物的语言，我们可以将所有动物所理解的意义描述为存在意义。符号的学习，即迈向指称的第一步，因此仅仅是存在意义的一个特例。但当我们面对一个精心选择的、构成语言的符号系统时，我们必须承认，这些符号具有一种指称意义，这种意义并非固有于事物或行为的固定语境。 84

What I understand in this manner has a meaning for me, and it has this meaning in itself, and not as a sign has a meaning when denoting an object. I have called this earlier on an existential meaning.183Since animals have no language which could denote anything, we may describe all meaning of the kind that is understood by animals as existential. The learning of signs, which is the first step towards denotation, would then be only a special case of existential meaning, but when we come to a deliberately chosen system of signs, constituting a language, we must admit that these have a denotative meaning which is not inherent in a fixed context of things or actions.84

既然我已经就不可言说之事进行了一番详尽的论述，那么就更容易理解为什么这既非不可能也非自相矛盾。断言我拥有不可言说的知识，并非否认我能够谈论它，而只是否认我能够充分地谈论它，这一断言本身就是对这种不足的评估。我刚才在回忆我们无法充分阐述的知识具体内容时所做的反思，证实了我们对于所讨论情况的表达不足。当然，这样的反思最终必然诉诸于它们试图证明的那种不足感。它们并非试图消除，而只是通过坚持追求更精确的方向并反思这种尝试最终的失败，更生动地唤起我们对表述不足的感受。

Now that I have spoken at some length of the ineffable, it is easier to see why this is neither impossible nor self-contradictory. To assert that I have knowledge which is ineffable is not to deny that I can speak of it, but only that I can speak of it adequately, the assertion itself being an appraisal of this inadequacy. Reflections of the kind that I made a moment ago, when recalling the particular contents of our knowledge which we cannot adequately specify, have served to substantiate the inadequacy of our articulation for the cases in question. Such reflections must of course appeal ultimately to the very sense of inadequacy which they intend to justify. They do not try to eliminate, but only to evoke more vividly our sense of inadequate representation, by persevering in the direction of greater precision and reflecting on the ultimate failure of this attempt.

我认为我们应该承认自己拥有评估自身表达能力的能力。事实上，我们所有追求精准的追求都意味着我们对这种能力的依赖。否认甚至怀疑我们拥有这种能力，都会使任何努力正确表达自己的努力失去可信度；如果我们不承认这种能力，那么“词语作为常用话语”这一概念本身就会瓦解。这并不意味着这种能力是绝对可靠的，而仅仅意味着我们有能力运用它，并且最终必须依赖于我们对它的运用。如果我们要说话，就必须承认这一点，而我认为这也是我们义不容辞的责任。

I believe that we should accredit in ourselves the capacity for appraising our own articulation. Indeed, all our strivings towards precision imply our reliance on such a capacity. To deny or even doubt our possession of it would discredit any effort to express ourselves correctly, and the very conception of words as consistently used utterances would dissolve if we failed to accredit this capacity. This does not imply that this capacity is infallible, but merely that we are competent to exercise it and must ultimately rely on our exercise of it. This we must admit if we are to speak at all, which I believe to be incumbent on us to do.

（2）认识到我们有能力区分我们所知道的内容和我们可能说的内容之后，我们也可以自由地区分听到的信息和知道它向我们传达的内容。85就此我们或许可以再次回想一下，当我刚刚读完一封信时，我已经不知道它是用什么语言写的，尽管我清楚地知道它的内容。86我所获得的知识是这封信的意义。这种知识，或意义，在默契性方面，与我之前描述的那些不可言喻的知识类似，但其源于语言，又与它们有着深刻的区别。阅读这封信时，我既有意识地意识到了文本本身，也意识到了文本的意义，但我对文本的意识仅仅是对意义的辅助，因此文本的意义对于文本而言是透明的。放下信后，我失去了对文本的意识，但仍然凭借着对文本内容的无法言喻的认知，对文本保持着辅助性的意识。87因此，隐性知识不仅在超出表达能力时才明显存在，而且在与表达能力完全一致时也明显存在，就像我们刚才通过听或读文本获得它时一样。 88

(2)Having acknowledged our own capacity to distinguish what we know from what we may be saying about it, we are free to distinguish also between hearing a message and knowing what it conveys to us.85 We may recall in this connection once more how, having just read a letter, I no longer knew in what language it was written, though I knew its content precisely.86 The knowledge that I had acquired was the meaning of the message. This kind of knowledge, or meaning, resembles in its tacitness the kinds of knowledge that I have described as ineffable, but differs from them profoundly by its verbal origin. While I read the letter, I was consciously aware both of its text and of the meaning of the text, but my awareness of the text was merely instrumental to that of the meaning, so that the text was transparent in respect to its meaning. After putting the letter down, I lost my conscious awareness of the text, but remained subsidiarily aware of it in terms of my inarticulate knowledge of its content.87 Tacit knowledge is manifestly present, therefore, not only when it exceeds the powers of articulation, but even when it exactly coincides with them, as it does when we have acquired it a moment before by listening to or reading a text.88

即使在聆听演讲或阅读文本时，我们的注意力也集中在词语的含义上，而不是词语的声音或纸上的标记上。事实上，说我们阅读或聆听文本，而不仅仅是看到或听到它，恰恰意味着我们关注的是看到或听到的词语所暗示的内容，而不是这些词语本身。

Even while listening to speech or reading a text, our focal attention is directed towards the meaning of the words, and not towards the words as sounds or as marks on paper. Indeed, to say that we read or listen to a text, and do not merely see it or hear it, is precisely to imply that we are attending focally to what is indicated by the words seen or heard and not to these words themselves.

但词语除了通过先前获得的意义之外，什么也传达不了，这种意义可能会因当前的使用而有所改变，但通常不会在此时首次被发现。无论如何，我们对词语所指事物的认知很大程度上是通过经验获得的，就像动物认识事物一样，而词语的意义则通过先前指代这种经验而获得，无论是在我们面前被他人说出，还是我们自己使用时。因此，当我通过阅读一封信获取信息并思考信中的信息时，我不仅会辅助性地意识到它的文本，还会辅助性地意识到过去我理解文本的所有场合，而这种辅助性意识的全部范围都以信息的形式聚焦呈现。现在注意力所关注的信息或意义并非有形之物：它是文本所唤起的概念。这个概念是我们注意力的焦点，通过它，我们辅助性地关注文本以及文本所指代的对象。因此，文本的意义在于对所有相关的工具性已知细节的聚焦理解，正如行动的目的在于对其工具性使用细节的协调支配。这就是我们说我们阅读文本，而不是说我们观察文本的原因。

But words convey nothing except by a previously acquired meaning, which may be somewhat modified by their present use, but will not as a rule have been first discovered on this occasion. In any case, our knowledge of the things denoted by words will have been largely acquired by experience, in the same way as animals come to know things, while the words will have acquired their meaning by previously designating such experience, either when uttered by others in our presence or when used by ourselves. Therefore, when I receive information by reading a letter and when I ponder the message of the letter, I am subsidiarily aware not only of its text, but also of all the past occasions by which I have come to understand the words of the text, and the whole range of this subsidiary awareness is presented focally in terms of the message. This message or meaning, on which attention is now focussed, is not something tangible: it is the conception evoked by the text. The conception in question is the focus of our attention, in terms of which we attend subsidiarily both to the text and to the objects indicated by the text. Thus the meaning of a text resides in a focal comprehension of all the relevant instrumentally known particulars, just as the purpose of an action resides in the co-ordinated innervation of its instrumentally used particulars. This is what we mean by saying that we read a text, and why we do not say that we observe it.

虽然焦点意识必然是有意识的，但辅助意识可能在各种意识层面上有所不同。当我们阅读文本或聆听演讲时，我们对其拥有完全有意识的辅助意识，即使我们仍然有意识地意识到文本的信息，并持续关注其信息。因此，无论我们是否有意识地在脑海中思考这些词语，词语与思想之间的关系都是相同的。这让我们同意Révész的观点。89“无言”的思想可以（而且通常如此）建立在语言之上，但这并不意味着所有无法言喻的心理过程都缺乏思想的特征。关于这一点，我将在后文进一步评论。

While focal awareness is necessarily conscious, subsidiary awareness may vary over all degrees of consciousness. When reading a text or listening to speech we have a completely conscious subsidiary awareness of it, even while we remain consciously aware of the text also in terms of its message, to which we keep attending focally. The relation between words and thought is the same, therefore, whether we have the words consciously in mind or not. This will allow us to agree with Révész89 that ‘wordless’ thought can be, and often is, founded on language, without agreeing at the same time to disqualify all ineffable mental processes as lacking the character of thought. Further comments on this point will follow.

（3）我已经展示了一个领域，在这个领域中，知识和思想必然以隐性为主，然后展示了第二个领域，在这个领域中，我们关注的隐性是我们正在听或刚刚听过的言语的含义。90我们现在进入的复杂领域，是由尚未完全理解的符号操作构成的，这些符号操作可以

(3)I have shown a domain in which both knowledge and thought are of necessity predominantly tacit, and then a second domain in which the tacit, on which our attention is focussed, is the meaning of speech to which we are listening or have just listened.90 The domain of sophistication, on which we now enter, is formed by not fully understood symbolic operations which can be

（一个）一个失误，之后通过我们的默契来纠正

(a)a fumbling, to be corrected later by our tacit understanding

（二）这是一种开创性的尝试，之后将由我们的默契来跟进。更准确地说，我们应该说，在这两种情况下，我们指的是一种精神上的不安状态，因为我们感觉到我们的默契思维与我们的象征性运作不一致，因此我们必须决定应该依赖哪一种，又应该根据哪一种来修正。

(b)a pioneering, to be followed up later by our tacit understanding. More precisely speaking, we should say that we are referring in both these cases to a state of mental uneasiness due to the feeling that our tacit thoughts do not agree with our symbolic operations, so that we have to decide on which of the two we should rely and which we should correct in the light of the other.

这两种分歧中的第一种发生在儿童学习说话的时候。他们常常表现出，新的发音器官对他们来说并非是帮助，而是阻碍，因为他们尚未完全掌握这些器官的操作。皮亚杰观察到，尽管儿童知道如何（并且早已知道如何）解决与之相关的实际问题，但他们常常发现语言问题难以解决。他得出结论，所有逻辑操作都必须在语言思维层面重新学习。91

The first of these two types of disagreement occurs when children learn to speak. They often show themselves encumbered rather than assisted by their new articulate equipment, the operations of which they have not yet fully mastered. Piaget has observed how often children find verbal problems intractable, though they know, and have known for a long time, how to solve the practical problems corresponding to them. He concludes that all the operations of logic must be learned all over again on the verbal plane of thought.91

虽然将我们的思想转化为清晰的语言所带来的好处最终远远超过了最初的弊端，但总是存在犯错的可能性——甚至是严重的错误——这些错误源于我们采用清晰的解释框架。因此，这种风险在人类所有高级理性的运用中都与生俱来。动物也会犯错；兔子会落入陷阱，鱼儿会游向钓鱼者的鱼饵，而这些错误可能是致命的。但动物却不会犯错，因为它们拥有复杂的错误解释体系，而这些体系只能通过语言来建立。泛灵论、对巫术、神谕和禁忌的信仰在原始人中普遍盛行，在儿童时期也能发现类似的迷信倾向。当迷信被哲学和神学，或数学和自然科学所取代时，我们就会再次陷入新的谬误体系，我们的数学、科学、哲学或神学实践永远无法摆脱这些谬误。专注于符号运算的思维，获得了一种拥有无限力量的智力工具；但使用语言却会使人的心智面临危险，而这种危险的范围似乎也是无限的。默契与清晰表达之间的差距，往往会在健全的常识与可疑的复杂性之间造成分裂，而动物则完全不受这种分裂的影响。

Although the gains made by casting our thoughts into articulate terms eventually outweigh by far these initial disadvantages, there will always remain certain chances of error—and even of grave error—which arise from our very adoption of an articulate interpretative framework. This risk is therefore inherent in the exercise of all higher forms of human reason. Animals can make mistakes; rabbits fall into traps, fish rise to the angler’s fly, and such errors may be fatal. But animals are exempt from the errors due to elaborate systems of false interpretation, which can be established only in verbal terms. Animism, belief in witchcraft, oracles and taboos prevail universally among primitive people, and a tendency towards kindred superstitions can be found also in childhood. When superstition is superseded by philosophy and theology, or by mathematics and natural science, we become involved once more in new systems of fallacies from which our practice of mathematics, science, philosophy or theology can never be strictly free. The mind which entrusts itself to the operation of symbols acquires an intellectual tool of boundless power; but its use makes the mind liable to perils the range of which seems also unlimited. The gap between the tacit and the articulate tends to produce everywhere a cleavage between sound common sense and dubious sophistication, from which the animal is quite free.

语言学派哲学旨在通过更严格地控​​制词语的使用来消除这种不确定性。但是，除非你允许你所采用的形式主义按照其自身的运作原则运作，否则你无法从思维的形式化中获益，而你必须沉溺于这种运作方式，冒着被引入歧途的风险。回想一下，各种新的数字——无理数、负数、虚数、超限数——是如何通过将熟悉的数学运算扩展到未知领域而产生的，以及这些数字最初是如何被否定为毫无意义的，最终是如何被接受为重要的新数学概念的代表。这些通过将数学符号用于最初未曾考虑的目的而进行的思辨性运用所取得的惊人成果，提醒我们，形式主义的主要成果可能在其完全不受契约约束的功能中显现出来，而恰恰是在它最有可能陷入荒谬的点上。哥德尔已经证明，数学公式的范围是不确定的，也就是说，我们无法在算术这样的演绎系统中判断组成该系统的任何一组公理是否一致或相互矛盾。92如果我们想在这样的体系中发表任何言论，我们就必须承担完全胡言乱语的风险。

The linguistic school of philosophy aims at eliminating such uncertainties by bringing the use of words under stricter control. But you cannot benefit from the formalization of thought, unless you allow the formalism which you have adopted to function according to its own operational principles, and to this extent you must abandon yourself to this functioning and risk being led into error. Remember how various new kinds of numbers—irrational, negative, imaginary, transfinite—were produced as a result of extending familiar mathematical operations into unexplored regions, and how these numbers, after having first been repudiated as meaningless, were eventually accepted as denoting important new mathematical conceptions. Such spectacular gains, achieved by the speculative use of mathematical notations for purposes not originally entertained, remind us that the major fruitfulness of a formalism may be revealed in its entirely uncovenanted functions, precisely at points where the peril seems greatest of its drifting into absurdity. Gödel has shown that the scope of mathematical formulae is indeterminate, in the sense that we cannot decide within a deductive system like arithmetic whether any set of axioms comprising the system are consistent or mutually contradictory.92 We must commit ourselves to the risk of talking complete nonsense, if we are to say anything at all within any such system.

这也适用于应用于经验事物的日常语言。它包含描述性术语，每个术语都隐含着一种概括，肯定其所指代的某些特征的稳定性或周期性。正如我们所见（第80页），这些对一组周期性特征真实性的证明构成了一种宇宙理论，而这种理论又通过语法规则得到扩展，根据这些规则，术语可以组合成有意义的句子。只要这种普遍理论是正确的，它就会像其他真正的理论一样，预见到比其创始人所拥有甚至推测的更多的知识。我们可以粗略地回忆一下，即使是一张小小的地图，也能将原始的信息输入增加千倍；此外，实际上，人们可以通过这样一张地图研究的有意义且有趣的问题的数量要多得多，而且并非完全可以预见。我们更无法预先控制名词、

This is true also for ordinary language applying to matters of experience. It contains descriptive terms, each of which implies a generalization affirming the stable or otherwise recurrent nature of some feature to which it refers, and these testimonies to the reality of a set of recurrent features constitute, as we have seen (p. 80), a theory of the universe which is amplified by the grammatical rules according to which the terms can be combined to form meaningful sentences. So far as this universal theory is true, it will be found to anticipate, like other true theories, much more knowledge than was possessed or even surmised by its originators. We may recall as a crude model of this how even a small map multiplies a thousandfold the original input of information; and add to this that, actually, the number of meaningful and interesting questions one could study by means of such a map is much greater and not wholly foreseeable. Much less can we control in advance the myriads of arrangements in which nouns,

形容词、动词和副词可以有意义地组合，形成新的肯定句或疑问句，从而正如我们将看到的，词语本身的意义在这些新的语境中不断得到发展。因此，言语思辨既可以揭示取之不尽的真知，也可以引出新的实质性问题，同时也可能产生一些纯粹的诡辩。

adjectives, verbs and adverbs can be meaningfully combined to form new affirmations or questions, thus developing, as we shall see, the meaning of the words themselves ever further in these new contexts. Verbal speculation may therefore reveal an inexhaustible fund of true knowledge and new substantial problems, just as it may also produce pieces of mere sophistry.

我们该如何区分这两者？这个问题目前无法完全回答；但从上文所述，我们至少可以大致看出，需要用什么方法来做出决定。我们必须牢记三件事：文本、文本所暗示的概念，以及可能基于此的概念的经验。我们的判断是通过尝试将这三者相互协调来进行的。结果无法根据之前的语言用法来预测，因为它可能涉及纠正或以其他方式修改语言用法的决定。另一方面，我们也可以决定坚持之前的用法，并根据文本所暗示的一些新概念来重新解释经验，或者至少设想一些新的问题，从而导致对经验的重新解释。第三，我们可以决定将文本视为完全无意义的文本而予以驳斥。

How shall we distinguish between the two?
