The question cannot be fully answered at this stage; but from what has been already said, we can see, at least in outline, by what method the decision will have to be reached. Three things will have to be borne in mind: the text, the conception suggested by it, and the experience on which this may bear. Our judgment operates by trying to adjust these three to each other. The outcome cannot be predicted from the previous use of language, for it may involve a decision to correct, or otherwise to modify, the use of language. On the other hand, we may decide instead to persist in our previous usage and to reinterpret experience in terms of some novel conception suggested by our text, or at least to envisage new problems leading on to a reinterpretation of experience. And in the third place, we may decide to dismiss the text as altogether meaningless.

因此，说一种语言就意味着将自己置于双重不确定性之中，这源于我们既依赖其形式主义，又依赖我们自身对这种形式主义与其经验关系的持续反思。正如我们所有知识最终都具有默契性，我们永远无法说出我们所知道的一切一样，同样，鉴于意义的默契性，我们也永远无法确切地知道我们所说的话中究竟蕴含着什么。93

Thus to speak a language is to commit ourselves to the double indeterminacy due to our reliance both on its formalism and on our own continued reconsideration of this formalism in its bearing on experience. For just as, owing to the ultimately tacit character of all our knowledge, we remain ever unable to say all that we know, so also, in view of the tacit character of meaning, we can never quite know what is implied in what we say.93

 

 

  1. 默示同意的形式
  2. FORMS OF TACIT ASSENT

在继续论述之前，我必须先回顾一下我为第二部分和第三部分制定计划的初衷。当时我提出，要将真理的概念与以下三个从一开始就显而易见的事实相一致：

Before proceeding further, I must return for a moment to the point where I set out my programme for Parts Two and Three. I proposed there to bring the conception of truth into accordance with the following three facts which became broadly apparent from the start:

（1）人类超越动物的几乎所有知识都是通过使用语言获得的。

(1)Nearly all knowledge by which man surpasses the animals is acquired by the use of language.

（2）语言的运作最终依赖于我们与动物的智力相连续的隐性智力。

(2)The operations of language rely ultimately on our tacit intellectual powers which are continuous with those of the animals.

（3）这些无法言喻的智力行为力求满足自我设定的标准，并通过认可自己的成功来得出结论。

(3)These inarticulate acts of intelligence strive to satisfy self-set standards and reach their conclusions by accrediting their own success.

我已经追溯了这些决定性的默契系数

I have already traced back these decisive tacit coefficients of articulation

动物学习的三种基本类型；但这并不能解释我们深入的个人参与，去探索和征服知识。这种（有点自相矛盾地）既塑造了我们的理解，又使我们认同其真实性的求知欲，其根源必定在于一种积极的原则。事实上，它源于我们与生俱来的感知力和警觉性，这在最低等的动物身上已经体现在探索运动和食欲驱动力中，在稍高一些的感知力中也体现出来。在这里，我们发现了自我驱动和自我满足的目的和注意力冲动，它们先于动物的学习而存在，并且自身也驱动着学习。这些是高级求知欲的原始原型，它们既在对清晰知识的追求中寻求满足，又通过自身的认同来认可它。在接触这些原型时，我们必须从高级到低级的求知欲形式，因此，首先要讨论感知，然后再讨论驱动力。

to the three basic types of learning in animals; but this does not account for our intensive personal participation in the search for and conquest of our knowledge. The origin of this intellectual striving which (somewhat paradoxically) both shapes our understanding and assents to its being true, must lie in an active principle. It stems in fact from our innate sentience and alertness, as manifested already in the lowest animals in exploratory movements and appetitive drives, and at somewhat higher levels in the powers of perception. Here we find self-moving and self-satisfying impulses of both purpose and attention which antedate learning in animals and themselves actuate learning. These are the primordial prototypes of the higher intellectual cravings which both seek satisfaction in the quest for articulate knowledge and accredit it by their own assent. In reaching out to these prototypes we must proceed from the higher to the lower forms of intellectual strivings and, accordingly, shall come to perception first and deal with drives afterwards.

感知显然是一种寻求满足自身设定标准的活动。眼部肌肉会调节晶状体的厚度，以便在视网膜上形成观看者注意力所及物体的最清晰图像，而眼睛则会将由此看到的物体图像呈现给观看者，认为是准确的。这种努力预示了我们寻求理解并满足理解欲望的方式，即通过构建尽可能清晰的概念。

Perception is manifestly an activity which seeks to satisfy standards which it sets to itself. The muscles of the eye adjust the thickness of its lens, so as to produce the sharpest possible retinal image of the object on which the viewer’s attention is directed, and the eye presents to him as correct the picture of the object seen in this way. This effort anticipates the manner in which we strive for understanding and satisfy our desire for it, by seeking to frame conceptions of the greatest possible clarity.

但轮廓的锐利并不总是构成我们所见事物的主导因素。艾姆斯和他的学派已经证明，当一个球在一个毫无特征的背景下被充气时，它看起来似乎保持了原来的大小，并且正在靠近。94这种错觉似乎是由于在这种情况下，我们会将眼睛调整到更近的距离，即使这样物体会失焦。更糟糕的是，我们同时增加了眼睛的会聚度，以至于两个视网膜图像从相应的位置移开了，这通常会使我们看到重影。眼睛在这里接受了视网膜图像质量和位置的这些缺陷，以满足更紧迫的要求，即看到物体以合理的方式运动。由于网球不会自己膨胀到足球那么大，因此一个膨胀到足球大小的球必须被视为正在靠近我们，即使在形成这种感知的过程中，眼睛必须超越它原本会接受的正确性标准。

But sharpness of contour does not always predominate in the shaping of what we see. Ames and his school have shown that when a ball set against a featureless background is inflated, it is seen as if it retained its size and was coming nearer.94 This illusion seems to be due to the fact that in this case we accommodate our eyes to a closer range, even though in consequence the object gets out of focus. Worse still, we simultaneously increase the convergence of our eyes so that the two retinal images are displaced from corresponding positions, which would normally make us see the object double. These defects of the quality and position of our retinal images are accepted here by the eye, in the urge to satisfy the more pressing requirement of seeing the object behave in a reasonable way. Since tennis balls are not known to blow themselves up to the size of footballs, a ball which does so must be seen as approaching us, even though in shaping this perception the eye must override standards of correctness which it would otherwise accept as binding.

我们在塑造充气球的视觉时遵循的规则，是我们婴儿时期自学的，当时我们第一次尝试将拨浪鼓靠近眼睛，然后再移开。当时，我们必须在看到拨浪鼓交替膨胀和收缩，以及看到它改变距离但保持其大小之间做出选择，我们选择了后者。通过这种观察事物的方式，我们最终构建了一个普遍的解释框架，该框架假设物体普遍存在，在不同的距离和角度下观察时，它们的大小和形状保持不变，在不同的光照条件下观察时，它们的颜色和亮度也保持不变。（参见第80页前文。）

The rule that we follow in shaping the sight of the inflated ball is one that we taught ourselves as babies, when we first experimented with approaching a rattle to our eyes and moving it away again. We had to choose then between seeing the rattle swelling up and shrinking alternately, or seeing it change its distance while retaining its size, and we adopted the latter assumption. By this way of seeing things we eventually constructed a universal interpretative framework that assumes the ubiquitous existence of objects, retaining their sizes and shapes when seen at different distances and from different angles, and their colour and brightness when seen under varying illuminations. (See p. 80 ante.)

我们理解宇宙所基于的这一宏大概括，与高等动物有着共通之处。它们与生俱来的感觉器官，都为我们设定了相似的正确视觉标准，正是这种原始标准，在充气球的例子中，促使我们无视视网膜图像的反证。事实上，它促使我们主动干预，通过错误的视觉调节努力，制造出球正在接近我们眼睛的错误证据，而丝毫不顾这会破坏视网膜图像的清晰度和双眼对应性。这一过程清晰地展现了主动原则，即力求在所有视觉线索之间建立一种连贯性，以便我们对所见事物的辅助意识，足以让我们确信自己真正理解了所见之物。 95

This tremendous generalization, on which we base our understanding of the universe, we have in common with the higher animals. Their native sensory equipment and ours both set us similar standards of correct seeing, and it is this primordial standard which induces us to flout, in the case of the inflated ball, the contrary evidence of our retinal images, Indeed, it induces us to intervene actively in producing false evidence of the ball’s approach to our eyes, by a misplaced effort of visual accommodation, undeterred by the fact that this destroys the sharpness and the binocular correspondence of our retinal images. The process illustrates clearly the active principle which seeks to establish a coherence between all the clues of visual perception, so that our subsidiary awareness of them in terms of what we see shall satisfy us of having truly comprehended the things seen.95

从更广阔的视角来看，此刻看到充气球靠近我们的眼睛的体验，仅仅是我们一生中经历并塑造的一系列体验中的最后一个。我们对每一个体验都尽力去理解，而这些体验如今都辅助性地塑造和理解了我们当下的体验。因此，充气球提供的感官线索似乎与大量过去的线索一起被评估，这些线索已经无法被回忆——但并非没有有效的痕迹。

In a larger perspective, the present experience of seeing the inflated ball come nearer to our eyes appears merely as the last of a life-long chain of experiences encountered and shaped by us, to each of which we reacted to make sense of it as best we could, and which are now all subsidiarily effective in the shaping and comprehension of our present experience. The sensory clues offered by the inflated ball thus appear to be evaluated together with an immense array of past clues, gone beyond recall—but not without effective trace.

感官线索的意义通过我们的感知得以确立的过程，与我们终生将指称性词语应用于一系列可识别的实例，并最终塑造其意义的过程非常相似。这些语言识别实际上主要基于对不同距离、不同角度和不同光照条件下物体的感官识别，只是将我们感官解读中隐含的宇宙理论延伸到了我们用来谈论事物的词汇中所隐含的更广泛的理论。

This process, by which the meaning of sensory clues is established in terms of our perceptions, is closely analogous to that by which we shape the meaning of denotative words in the lifelong course of applying them to a long series of identifiable instances. These linguistic identifications are in fact based primarily on the sensory identification of objects at varying distances, under varying angles and varying illumination, and merely extend the theory of the universe implied in our sensory interpretations to the wider theory, implied in the vocabulary by which we talk about things.

格式塔心理学为我们提供了大量证据，表明感知是对线索的整体理解。但感知通常是自动运作的，格式塔心理学家倾向于优先收集这样一种类型的案例：感知的发生无需感知者任何刻意的努力，甚至无法通过事后重新考虑结果来纠正。视错觉因此被归类为真实感知，两者都被描述为同时刺激与一个综合整体的平衡。这种解释排除了任何刻意的努力，这种努力促使我们的感知在探求知识的过程中探索和评估感官所提供的线索。我认为这是错误的，我将在第四部分进一步阐述将感官视为理性判断中心的人的理由。在此阶段，只需回顾一下这种主动的个人参与的一些特征即可。96我们可以通过警觉的迹象来识别这一点，这些迹象可以区分警觉的动物和因疲惫或神经紊乱而无精打采的动物。只有当我们能够激发动物对其处境的兴趣，并使其意识到可以通过运用观察力来解决的问题时，符号学习实验才能成功。当然，这可以通过提供奖励来实现。

We owe to Gestalt psychology much of the available evidence showing that perception is a comprehension of clues in terms of a whole. But perception usually operates automatically, and gestalt psychologists have tended to collect preferentially examples of the type in which perception goes on without any deliberate effort on the part of the perceiver and is not even corrigible by his subsequent reconsideration of the result. Optical illusions are then classed with true perceptions, both being described as the equilibration of simultaneous stimuli to a comprehensive whole. Such an interpretation leaves no place for any intentional effort which prompts our perception to explore and assess in the quest of knowledge the clues offered to our senses. I believe this is a mistake, and shall say more in Part Four of the reasons for recognizing persons who use their senses as centres of intelligent judgment. At this stage it is enough to recall some features of this active personal participation.96 We recognize it in the signs of watchfulness which distinguish an alert animal from one rendered listless by exhaustion or neurotic disturbance. A sign-learning experiment can succeed only if we can arouse the animal’s interest in his situation and make him aware of a problem which can be solved by straining his powers of observation. This may of course be done by offering a reward.

但一旦学会了一项技巧，动物就会倾向于不求回报地重复练习，纯粹是为了好玩，这表明它解决问题的乐趣纯粹源于智力。事实证明，即使没有奖励，迷宫的学习也会持续进行。动物的智力会自发地对理解周围环境的问题保持敏锐。97

But once he has learned a trick, the animal’s inclination to repeat it without reward, for the mere fun of it, shows that his pleasure in solving a problem has a purely intellectual component. It has been proved also that the learning of a maze goes on even when no reward is offered. The animal’s intelligence is spontaneously alive to the problem of making sense of its surroundings.97

我稍后将回到动物身上这些原始的求知激情迹象。至于我们自己，我们应该深知观看事物的喜悦；新奇事物激发的好奇心；我们为了辨别所见之物而竭尽全力的感官，以及某些人在眼力和洞察力方面所拥有的巨大优势。我相信，我们应该承认这些感官活动是我们共同拥有并依赖的正当追求。这种对我们根据自身理性标准理解经验的天赋能力的认可，也应该使我们能够承认感知对清晰知识的隐性组成部分的普遍贡献。最终，它应该适当地决定我们以清晰的形式承认真理的方式。

I shall presently return to these primordial signs of intellectual passions in the animal. As to ourselves, we should know well the joy of seeing things; the curiosity aroused by novel objects; the straining of our senses to make out what it is that we see and the vast superiority of some people in quickness of eye and penetrating powers of observation. I believe that we should acknowledge these sensory actions as proper strivings which we both share and rely on. This endorsement of our native powers of making sense of our experience according to our own standards of rationality should also make it possible for us to acknowledge the ubiquitous contributions made by sense perception to the tacit components of articulate knowledge. And, eventually, it should duly condition our manner of acknowledging truth in its articulate forms.

这种对知觉的分析与一个传统问题相关：一个物体是否应该等同于它在我们感官上所产生印象的集合。赖尔的语言学分析认为这个问题毫无意义，理由是感官印象无法被观察到，而我们所观察到的一切都是物体。98这话没错，但问题依然存在。因为我们可以“看见”物体，却无需观察它们本身。婴儿很可能一直都是这样看待它们的。新生儿体验世界时，无法用智力控制它，因为他缺乏对负责检查和识别外部物体的器官的综合控制。由于眼部注视功能不足，他的眼睛茫然地盯着周围的事物。因此，他只能看到没有明确形状和大小的彩色斑块，这些斑块出现在没有特定距离的地方，并且颜色和色调不断变化。如果面对伪装得当或对他们来说完全陌生的物体，成年人也只能看到彩色斑块。天生失明、手术后恢复视力的患者必须费力地学习识别物体；同样，在黑暗中长大的黑猩猩也需要数周的练习才能看到像奶瓶这样有趣的物体。 99此外，刻意的沉思可以将物体溶解成色块。100因此，当我们从对某个物体的幻象式凝视过渡到对其的观察时，我们确实会确认某种超越我们先前所见的事物。这种行为包含着一种可能被误导的承诺。它建立了一种对现实的体验，这种体验是通过对先前在凝视过程中体验到的彩色斑块的辅助意识而形成的。

This analysis of perception bears on the traditional question whether an object is to be equated to the aggregate of the impressions made by it on our senses. Ryle’s linguistic analysis dismisses this question as nonsensical on the ground that sense impressions cannot be observed and that everything we observe is an object.98 That is true, but the problem remains. For we can ‘see’ objects without observing them as such. Babies probably always see them like that. The newborn child experiences the world without controlling it intellectually, for he lacks the integrative control of the organs which direct the examination and identification of external objects. His ocular fixation being deficient, his eyes stare uncomprehendingly at the things around him. In this way he can see only coloured patches of no definite shape or size, appearing at no particular distance and undergoing perpetual changes of shade and colour. If faced with objects that are effectively camouflaged or altogether novel to them, adults too see only patches of colour. Patients born blind and gaining sight after an operation must laboriously learn to recognize objects; and similarly, chimpanzees reared in the dark need several weeks of practice to see even so interesting an object as their nursing bottle.99 Besides, a deliberate act of contemplation can dissolve objects into patches of colour.100 In passing from the visionary contemplation of an object to its observation, we do make an affirmation, therefore, of something which lies beyond what we had seen before. This is an act involving a commitment which can prove misguided. It establishes a conception of reality experienced in terms of a subsidiary awareness of the coloured patches which had previously been experienced as such in an act of contemplation.

如果说感知预示着我们对事物的所有认知，那么驱动力的满足则预示着所有实践技能，两者始终交织在一起。我们为满足渴望和避免痛苦而做出的努力都受感知的引导；而只要这些努力能够满足我们的欲望，这反过来也是一种确定事实的方式，即某些事物能够满足我们的欲望。对驱动力的追求是一种无声的探索，如果成功，就会带来一种无声的肯定；而且——就像感官知觉一样——获取信息的过程本身会从自身的角度选择和关联它所指的事物，并根据它们与自身动机的关系来判断它们。尽管我们通过这种方式获得的信息——例如通过进食、吸烟或做爱——必然以我们自身为中心，但这些信息实际上确实强有力地融入了我们对世界的清晰描绘。对于一个完全无法感受到欲望、痛苦或安慰的无形智力来说，我们的大部分词汇都是无法理解的。因为大多数名词和动词要么指生物，其行为只有通过体验驱动它们的本能才能被理解，要么指人类为自己制造的东西，而这些东西只有通过理解它们所满足的人类需求才能被理解。

If perception prefigures all our knowing of things, drive satisfaction prefigures all practical skills, and the two are always interwoven. The efforts made to satisfy our cravings and to avoid pain are guided by perception; and insofar as they lead to the satisfaction of our appetites this is in its turn a manner of ascertaining a fact, namely, that certain things are satisfying to our appetites. The pursuit of drives is a mute exploration, which in the event of success leads to a mute affirmation; and—as in the case of sensory perception—the process by which information is gained itself selects and correlates from its own point of view the things to which it refers, and judges them in their relation to its own motivation. Though the information that we thus acquire—for example by eating, smoking, or making love—is necessarily centred on ourselves as agents, such information does in fact enter emphatically into our articulate picture of the world. To a disembodied intellect, entirely incapable of lust, pain or comfort, most of our vocabulary would be incomprehensible. For the majority of nouns and verbs refer either to living beings, whose behaviour can be appreciated only from an experience of the drives which actuate them, or to things made by man for his own use, which again can be appreciated only through an understanding of the human needs to which they minister.

驱动力满足和感知是两类智能行为的原始雏形，它们在更高层次（尽管尚不明确）的学习中体现为两种类型的学习：实践型学习和认知型学习。实践型学习（A类）通过掌握新的手段-目的关系来扩展先天的感觉运动能力；认知型学习（B类）则运用动物先天的感觉能力来学习新的符号事件关系。

Drive satisfaction and perception are the primordial rudiments of two classes of intelligent behaviour which manifest themselves—at a higher, though still inarticulate level—in learning of two types, the practical and the cognitive. The first (type A) enlarges on innate sensory-motor faculties by the grasping of new means-ends relationships, while the second (type B) deploys the animal’s innate sensory powers in the learning of new signevent relations.

C类学习是指动物理解和控制复杂情境的学习，它将运动和感觉能力作为原始概念操作的一部分。我们或许可以在动物的探索行为和不断调整平衡的过程中，识别出这种组合操作的早期雏形，例如，在倒立时，它们会想方设法恢复正常姿势。这些驱动力维持着动物自身以及与周围环境的理性连贯性，预示着在更高层次的智力发展中，它们将学习其他形式的“部分-整体”关系。

Learning of type C, by which an animal comes to understand and control a complex situation, uses both its motor and sensory faculties as part of a primitive conceptual operation. We may recognize the earliest rudiments of such combined operations in the animal’s exploratory behaviour and in the incessant adjustment of its balance, culminating, e.g., in its stratagems for restoring its normal position when turned upside- down. These drives, which preserve the animal’s rational coherence both within itself and in relation to its environment, foreshadow the learning of alternative part-whole relations at a more highly developed level of intelligence.

所有这些无法言喻的成就都源于自我满足。我们感官的适应性，我们欲望和恐惧的冲动，我们运动、平衡和扶正的能力，以及无法言喻的智力从这些努力中发展出来的学习过程，只有在我们认可它们对自己表现的默许，并根据它们为自己设定的标准进行塑造的程度上，才能说它们是它们本身，并实现它们所谓的目标。因此，在我们无数的表达根植于我们的亚智力努力，或任何我们无法言喻的智力壮举的点上，我们都依赖于我们自身的默契表现，并默许其正确性。

All these inarticulate achievements are guided by self-satisfaction. The adaptation of our sense organs, the urge of our appetites and fears, our capacity for locomotion, balancing and righting, as well as the processes of learning which an inarticulate intelligence develops from these strivings, can be said to be what they are and to achieve what they are said to achieve, only to the extent to which we accredit their implied assent to their own performance, shaped by them in accordance with standards set by themselves to themselves. Therefore, at each of the innumerable points at which our articulation is rooted in our sub-intellectual strivings, or in any inarticulate feats of our intelligence, we rely on tacit performances of our own, the rightness of which we implicitly confirm.

 

 

  1. 思想与言语。二、概念决策
  2. THOUGHT AND SPEECH. II. CONCEPTUAL DECISIONS

现在，我们或许可以开始认识到默会能力的本质，这种能力最终解释了通过表达所获得的知识的增长，以及运用这种能力的冲动的本质。我们已经看到，这种能力在思维与言语的三种典型关系中以略有不同的方式展现。在不可言喻的领域，它能够理解言语所传达的稀少线索；在聆听易懂的文本并记住其信息时，它所掌握的概念构成了我们关注的焦点；最后，它被视为重新调整思维中那些由于复杂化过程而瓦解的默会和形式成分的中心。在所有这些情况下，我们所依赖的能力，是我们理解文本及其所指事物的能力，而这种理解力源于文本本身所蕴含的概念，即文本的意义。

We may now begin to recognize the nature of the tacit faculty which accounts in the last resort for all the increase in knowledge achieved by articulation, and the nature of the urge to exercise it. We have seen this faculty revealed in somewhat different ways in all three characteristic relations between thought and speech. In the ineffable domain it made sense of the scanty clues conveyed by speech; in listening to a readily intelligible text and remembering its message, the conception grasped by it formed the focus of our attention; and lastly, it was seen to be the centre of operations for readjusting the tacit and the formal components of thought, which had fallen apart by a process of sophistication. The faculty on which we relied in all these situations was our power for comprehending a text and the things to which the text refers, within a conception which is the meaning of the text.

我们已经看到，寻找线索并理解这些线索的渴望始终存在于我们的眼睛和耳朵中，也存在于我们的恐惧和渴望之中。理解经验的渴望，以及指涉经验的语言，显然是这种原始的智性掌控力的延伸。我们概念的形成，受一种智性不适的驱使，从模糊走向清晰，从不连贯走向理解，这与我们的眼睛被迫使所见事物清晰连贯的感受类似。在这两种情况下，我们都会挑选出一些线索，这些线索似乎暗示着一个语境，在这个语境中，它们作为附属细节而有意义。

We have seen how the urge to look out for clues and to make sense of them is ever alert in our eyes and ears, and in our fears and desires. The urge to understand experience, together with the language referring to experience, is clearly an extension of this primordial striving for intellectual control. The shaping of our conceptions is impelled to move from obscurity to clarity and from incoherence to comprehension, by an intellectual discomfort similar to that by which our eyes are impelled to make clear and coherent the things we see. In both cases we pick out clues which seem to suggest a context in which they make sense as its subsidiary particulars.

这或许可以解决一个悖论：尽管所有表达的焦点都是概念性的，而语言在其中只扮演着次要的角色，但我们在智力上却如此感激表达。因为，当正确理解语言时，语言所传达的概念既能让我们意识到语言指涉某些事物的方式，也能让我们意识到这些事物本身的构成方式，因此，除非我们学会理解语言的含义，否则我们永远无法学会说话。因此，即使我们的思维是关于事物而非语言的，我们在所有思维中都能意识到语言的存在（就我们的思维超越动物而言），并且，如果没有语言，我们就无法拥有这些思维；如果不理解我们在这些思维中关注的事物，我们就无法理解语言。

This may resolve the paradox that we intellectually owe so much to articulation, even though the focus of all articulation is conceptual, with language playing only a subsidiary part in this focus. For since the conceptions conveyed by speech, when speech is properly understood, make us aware both of the way our speech refers to certain things and of the way these things are constituted in themselves, we can never learn to speak except by learning to know what is meant by speech. So that even while our thoughts are of things and not of language, we are aware of language in all thinking (so far as our thinking surpasses that of the animals) and can neither have these thoughts without language, nor understand language without understanding the things to which we attend in such thoughts.

举个例子——类似于我们用来阐释不可言喻之事的局部解剖学——或许可以展现学习语言过程中这种双重理解过程。想象一下，一位医学院的学生正在上肺部疾病X光诊断课程。他在一间昏暗的房间里，观察着贴在病人胸口的荧光屏上模糊的痕迹，并听着放射科医生用专业术语向他的助手们解释这些阴影的重要特征。起初，这位学生完全被搞糊涂了。因为他在胸部的X光片上只能看到心脏和肋骨的阴影，中间还有几处蛛网状的斑点。专家们似乎在夸夸其谈他们幻想出来的事物；他根本看不到他们正在谈论的任何东西。然后，随着他继续听了几个星期，仔细观察不同病例的新照片，他逐渐有了些许理解；他会逐渐忘记肋骨，开始看到肺部。最终，如果他能够坚持不懈，一幅包含重要细节的丰富全景图将展现在他面前：生理变异和病理变化、疤痕、慢性感染和急性疾病的症状。他进入了一个新世界。他仍然只能看到专家所能看到的一小部分，但现在这些图片肯定有意义了，对它们的大部分评论也是如此。他即将掌握所学的内容；他已经明白了。因此，在学习肺部放射学语言的那一刻，学生也将学会理解肺部 X 光片。两者只能同时发生。难以理解的文本向我们提出了两个问题，它们涉及一个难以理解的主题，共同指导我们努力解决问题，最终，通过发现一个包含对词语和事物的共同理解的概念，这些问题得到了解决。

An illustration—akin to that of topographic anatomy by which we exemplified the ineffable—may exhibit this dual movement of comprehension in learning a language. Think of a medical student attending a course in the X-ray diagnosis of pulmonary diseases. He watches in a darkened room shadowy traces on a fluorescent screen placed against a patient’s chest, and hears the radiologist commenting to his assistants, in technical language, on the significant features of these shadows. At first the student is completely puzzled. For he can see in the X-ray picture of a chest only the shadows of the heart and the ribs, with a few spidery blotches between them. The experts seem to be romancing about figments of their imagination; he can see nothing that they are talking about. Then as he goes on listening for a few weeks, looking carefully at ever new pictures of different cases, a tentative understanding will dawn on him; he will gradually forget about the ribs and begin to see the lungs. And eventually, if he perseveres intelligently, a rich panorama of significant details will be revealed to him: of physiological variations and pathological changes, of scars, of chronic infections and signs of acute disease. He has entered a new world. He still sees only a fraction of what the experts can see, but the pictures are definitely making sense now and so do most of the comments made on them. He is about to grasp what he is being taught; it has clicked. Thus, at the very moment when he has learned the language of pulmonary radiology, the student will also have learned to understand pulmonary radiograms. The two can only happen together. Both halves of the problem set to us by an unintelligible text, referring to an unintelligible subject, jointly guide our efforts to solve them, and they are solved eventually together by discovering a conception which comprises a joint understanding of both the words and the things.

但是，言语和知识的这种二元性是不对称的，从某种意义上说，这种不对称在非言语层面上是可以预见的，即知识与基于知识的表现之间的区别（这在动物的学习中已经很明显了）。我们已经看到，被称为潜在学习的那种知识的获得可以通过一系列不确定的表现来体现，这取决于动物在训练后所面临的情况。事实上，一旦动物学到了新的东西，它接下来的每一个反应都可能在某种程度上受到先前获得的知识的影响：这一事实被称为学习的迁移。而且，很容易看出，即使是通过口头获得的知识，也具有“潜在”的特征；用语言表达它是一种基于我们拥有这种潜在知识的表现。

But this duality of speech and knowledge is asymmetrical, in a sense anticipated on the inarticulate level, in the distinction (apparent already in the learning of animals) between knowledge and the performances based on knowledge. We have seen there that the acquisition of the type of knowledge called latent learning can be manifested by an indefinite range of performances, depending on the situation with which the animal is confronted after his training. Indeed, once it has learned something new, the animal’s every subsequent reaction may be affected to some extent by its previously acquired knowledge: a fact which is known as the transfer of learning. And it is easy to see that knowledge, even when acquired verbally, has a ‘latent’ character; to express it in words is a performance based on our possession of such latent knowledge.

以医学知识为例。虽然正确使用医学术语本身并非易事，但即使忘记了医学术语的用法，人们也能记住很多医学知识。我转行从匈牙利搬到了英国，忘记了在匈牙利学到的大部分医学术语，也没有学到其他术语来代替它们；然而，我再也不会像接受放射学培训之前那样，以完全不理解的方式看待——例如——肺部X光片。医学知识就像信件中的信息一样，即使传达这两种知识的文本已经无法回忆，人们仍然能够保留它。因此，谈论这种信息或医学问题是一种基于知识的实践，而且它实际上只是无数可以想象的、可以体现这种知识的实践之一。我们探索词语来表达我们所知道的，而我们的词语正是通过这些词根联系在一起的。沃斯勒写道：“真正的语言艺术家”101“始终意识到语言的隐喻性。他们不断地用一个隐喻来修正和补充另一个隐喻，允许他们的词语相互矛盾，只关注思想的统一性和确定性。”——汉弗莱102 正确地将以无限多种口头术语表达知识的能力与老鼠以无限多种不同动作表现其对迷宫的了解的能力结合起来。

Take the knowledge of medicine. While the correct use of medical terms cannot be achieved in itself, without the knowledge of medicine, a great deal of medicine can be remembered even after one has forgotten the use of medical terms. Having changed my profession and moved from Hungary to England, I have forgotten most of the medical terms I learned in Hungary and have acquired no others in place of them; yet I shall never again view—for example—a pulmonary radiogram in such a totally uncomprehending manner as I did before 1 was trained in radiology. The knowledge of medicine is retained, just as the message of a letter is remembered, even after the text which had conveyed either kind of knowledge has passed beyond recall. To speak of this message, or of medical matters, is therefore a performance based on knowledge, and it is indeed only one of an indefinite range of conceivable performances by which such knowledge can be manifested. We grope for words to tell what we know and our words hang together by these roots. ‘The true artists of speech’, writes Vossler,101 ‘remain always conscious of the metaphorical character of language. They go on correcting and supplementing one metaphor by another, allowing their words to contradict each other and attending only to the unity and certainty of their thought.’ Humphrey102 rightly aligns the capacity to express knowledge in an unlimited variety of spoken terms, with the capacity of a rat to manifest its knowledge of a maze in an unlimited number of different actions.

 

 

8.受过教育的心灵

8. THE EDUCATED MIND

当这些文字付印之时，唐纳德·凯洛格或许已经完成了大学学业。他或许即将成为一名出色的医生、律师或牧师，或许注定成为医学、法律或神学领域的权威，甚至成为一位先驱，其伟大之处只有后世才能知晓——而他的玩伴兼智力对手——黑猩猩瓜，在一岁半之前，永远无法超越他们共同达到的智力阶段。

By the time these pages appear in print, Donald Kellogg may have completed his studies at a university. He may be on his way to becoming a capable doctor, lawyer or clergyman, destined perhaps to become an authority on medicine, law or theology, or even a pioneer whose greatness will only dawn on generations yet to come—while Gua the chimpanzee, his playmate and intellectual rival until the age of a year and a half, will never have got beyond the stage of intelligence which they both reached

婴儿时期。唐纳德通过运用非言语能力获得了所有卓越的知识——主要在于他能够结合他们共同拥有的实践、观察和解释天赋——从而启动言语、印刷和其他语言符号的操作原则，甚至可能通过他自己的发现来扩展这一知识遗产。

as infants. Donald has acquired all his superior knowledge by the exercise of inarticulate powers—exceeding those of Gua mainly in the capacity for combining the practical, observational and interpretative endowments which they both shared—for setting in motion the operational principles of speech, of print and of other linguistic symbols, and perhaps even enlarging this heritage of knowledge by discoveries of his own.

通过教育获得的知识种类繁多，可能是医学知识、法律知识等等，也可能仅仅是受过教育的人的一般常识。我们清楚地意识到我们知识的广度和特殊性，即使我们几乎只对其中的无数知识点有所了解。我们之所以能意识到这些细节，仅仅是因为我们对它们所属学科的掌握程度。这种掌握感类似于对复杂地形的熟悉程度，但借助言语和其他语言指标，其广度会得到增强。这些指标独特的可管理性使我们能够追踪大量的经验，并确保在需要时能够获取其中无数细节中的许多。因此，我们对所受教育的意识最终存在于我们的概念能力中，无论是直接应用于经验，还是通过语言指涉系统进行中介。教育是潜在的知识，我们通过基于这些知识的智力感知来辅助地意识到这些知识。

Knowledge acquired by education may be of various kinds. It may be medical knowledge, legal knowledge, etc., or simply the general knowledge of an educated person. We are clearly aware of the extent and special character of our knowledge, even though focally aware of hardly any of its innumerable items. Of these particulars we are aware only in terms of our mastery of the subject of which they form part. This sense of mastery is similar in kind to the inarticulate knowledge of knowing one’s way about a complex topography, but its range is enhanced by the aid of verbal and other linguistic pointers, the peculiar manageability of which enables us to keep track of an immense amount of experience and to rest assured of having access, when required, to many of its countless particulars. Consciousness of our education resides ultimately, therefore, in our conceptual powers, whether applied directly to experience or mediated by a system of linguistic references. Education is latent knowledge, of which we are aware subsidiarily in our sense of intellectual power based on this knowledge.

我们概念的力量在于识别我们已知事物的新实例。我们概念框架的这一功能类似于我们的感知框架，它使我们能够看到所有新的事物本身；也类似于我们的欲望，它使我们能够识别所有新的事物，并满足它们的需求。它似乎也类似于实践技能的力量，它总是保持着应对新情况的积极性。我们可以将这整套能力——我们的概念和技能、我们的感知框架和我们的驱动力——整合成一种综合的预见能力。

The power of our conceptions lies in identifying new instances of certain things that we know. This function of our conceptual framework is akin to that of our perceptive framework, which enables us to see ever new objects as such, and to that of our appetites, which enables us to recognize ever new things as satisfying to them. It appears likewise akin to the power of practical skills, ever keyed up to meet new situations. We may comprise this whole set of faculties—our conceptions and skills, our perceptual framework and our drives—in one comprehensive power of anticipation.

由于世事瞬息万变，时时刻刻都在更新，我们的预期必然会遭遇某种程度上新颖且前所未有的事物。因此，我们发现自己既依赖于我们的预期，也依赖于我们不断调整这些预期以适应新颖且前所未有的情况的能力。这在技能的运用、感知的塑造，甚至在欲望的满足中都是如此；每当我们现有的框架应对其预期的事件时，它都必须相应地进行某种程度的自我调整。对于受过教育的心灵来说更是如此；能够通过吸收新的经验不断丰富和活跃自身的概念框架，是智慧人格的标志。因此，我们对一系列事物拥有智力控制权的感觉，总是将这样一种感觉结合在一起：一种预期，即预期会遇到某些在某些无法具体说明的方面新颖的事物；一种依赖，即我们自身能够通过适当调整预期框架来成功地诠释它们。

Owing to the unceasing changes which at every moment manifestly renew the state of things throughout the world, our anticipations must always meet things that are to some extent novel and unprecedented. Thus we find ourselves relying jointly on our anticipations and on our capacity ever to re-adapt these to novel and unprecedented situations. This is true in the exercise of skills, in the shaping of our perception and even in the satisfaction of appetites; every time our existing framework deals with an event anticipated by it, it has to modify itself to some extent accordingly. And this is even more true of the educated mind; the capacity continually to enrich and enliven its own conceptual framework by assimilating new experience is the mark of an intelligent personality. Thus our sense of possessing intellectual control over a range of things, always combines an anticipation of meeting certain things of this kind which will be novel in some unspecifiable respects, with a reliance on ourselves to interpret them successfully by appropriately modifying our framework of anticipations.

这并非老生常谈，而是我们主题的核心。我们的思维远比我们所知的深刻，并且能够出乎意料地向后人揭示其重要意义，这一点我在第一章中已经承认，是客观性的标志。哥白尼在一定程度上预见了开普勒和牛顿的发现，因为他体系的合理性暗示了一种在他眼中尚未完全揭示的现实。同样，约翰·道尔顿（以及在他之前很久，他的原子理论的众多先驱）看到并描述了一种现实的模糊轮廓，而现代原子物理学后来以精确可辨的细节揭示了这种现实。我们也知道，数学概念通常只有通过揭示尚未被察觉的蕴含或进行令人惊讶的概括，才能向后人揭示其更深层的意义。此外，数学形式主义可以以全新的、不受约束的方式运作，迫使我们犹豫不决的头脑表达出一种新的概念。这些重大的智力壮举在很大程度上证明了我所宣称的我们所有概念的力量，即在前所未有的情况下超越任何可指定的预期来理解。

This is no truism, but the very heart of our subject. The oddity of our thoughts in being much deeper than we know and in disclosing their major import unexpectedly to later minds, has been acknowledged in my first chapter as a token of objectivity. Copernicus anticipated in part the discoveries of Kepler and Newton, because the rationality of his system was an intimation of a reality incompletely revealed to his eyes. Similarly, John Dalton (and long before him the numerous precursors of his atomic theory) beheld and described the dim outline of a reality which modern atomic physics has since disclosed in precisely discernible particulars. We know also that mathematical conceptions often disclose their deeper significance only to later generations, by revealing yet unsuspected implications or undergoing a surprising generalization. Moreover, a mathematical formalism may be operated in ever new, uncovenanted ways, and force on our hesitant minds the expression of a novel conception. These major intellectual feats demonstrate on a large scale the powers which I have claimed for all our conceptions, namely of making sense beyond any specifiable expectations in respect to unprecedented situations.

我们为何要将思想的生命和指导托付给我们的概念？因为我们相信，它们明显的合理性源于它们与现实领域的接触，而它们已经掌握了现实的某一方面。正因如此，当我们构建一个概念时，我们内心深处的皮格马利翁总是准备从他自己的创造物中寻求指导；然而，凭借着他与现实的接触，即使在接受指导的同时，他也随时准备重塑他的创造物。我们赋予我们所接受的概念以权威，因为我们承认它们是一系列不确定的未来新事件的暗示——这些暗示源于我们通过它们与现实的接触——我们希望通过进一步发展这些概念，依靠我们自身在持续接触现实中的判断力，来掌控这些事件。自我设定标准的悖论在此被重新转化为我们主观上自信地宣称认识到客观现实的悖论。这使我更接近最终的真理概念，我将在其中寻求建立我的心灵平衡。但目前我先继续讨论一下手头的话题。

Why do we entrust the life and guidance of our thoughts to our conceptions? Because we believe that their manifest rationality is due to their being in contact with domains of reality, of which they have grasped one aspect. This is why the Pygmalion at work in us when we shape a conception is ever prepared to seek guidance from his own creation; and yet, in reliance on his contact with reality, is ready to re-shape his creation, even while he accepts its guidance. We grant authority over ourselves to the conceptions which we have accepted, because we acknowledge them as intimations—derived from the contact we make through them with reality—of an indefinite sequence of novel future occasions, which we may hope to master by developing these conceptions further, relying on our own judgment in its continued contact with reality. The paradox of self-set standards is re-cast here into that of our subjective self-confidence in claiming to recognize an objective reality. This brings nearer by a great step the final conception of truth within which I shall seek to establish my balance of mind. But let me proceed with the subject on hand a little further for the moment.

 

 

9.语言的重新诠释

9. THE RE-INTERPRETATION OF LANGUAGE

我已经指出，受过教育的人的大多数知识都依赖于语言线索。因此，其概念框架主要通过聆听或口语来发展，而其概念决策通常也包含着以新颖的方式理解或使用词语的决定。无论如何，每一次使用语言来描述不断变化的世界中的经验，都会将语言应用于其主题中某种前所未有的情况，从而在一定程度上改变语言的含义和我们概念框架的结构。103当我谈到外延作为一种艺术（第81页）时，我就已经暗示了这一点，并将词语意义的终生确立过程比作我们解读和重新解读感官线索的过程（第98-100页）。现在，这些暗示可以得到巩固和发展，通过更全面的分析，我们能够理解，在可识别的场合下，语言话语的重复如何带来其意义的变化，无论是我们聆听言语还是自己说话。

I have shown that the educated mind relies for most of its knowledge on verbal clues. It follows, then, that its conceptual framework will be developed mostly by listening or speaking, and that its conceptual decisions will usually entail also a decision to understand or use words in a novel fashion. In any case, every use of language to describe experience in a changing world applies language to a somewhat unprecedented instance of its subject matter, and thus somewhat modifies both the meaning of language and the structure of our conceptual framework.103 I implied this already, when I spoke of denotation as an art (p. 81), and likened the lifelong process by which the meaning of words is established to that by which we interpret and re-interpret our sensory clues (pp. 98– 100). These hints can now be consolidated and developed, within a fuller analysis of the way in which the reiteration of linguistic utterances with reference to identifiable occasions carries with it a change of their meaning, each time we either listen to speech or utter it ourselves.

语言的重新诠释可以发生在多个不同的层面。（1）学习说话的孩子会接受性地练习。（2）诗人、科学家或学者可以提出语言创新，并教导他人使用它们。（3）重新诠释也发生在日常语言使用的中间层面，这种语言在不知不觉中发生了改变，无需任何有意识的创新努力。

The re-interpretation of language can take place at a number of different levels. (1) The child learning to speak practises it receptively. (2) Poets, scientists or scholars can propose linguistic innovations, and teach others to use them. (3) Re-interpretation takes place also at an intermediate level in the everyday use of language which modifies it imperceptibly, without any conscious effort at innovation.

我将依次讨论这三种情况；但我必须首先提出另一条线索，以便在此提供指导。皮亚杰将新实例纳入先前接受的概念的过程描述为同化过程；而为了处理新经验而形成新的或经过修改的概念的过程，则被描述为适应过程。104我将使用这些术语来描述我们同时应用和重塑我们的概念的两个相关运动；因为我认为这种结合对于所有概念决策都至关重要，即使在任何特定情况下，两个特征之一可能占主导地位。

I shall deal with all three of these cases in turn; but I must first pick up yet another thread which may serve us as a guide here. Piaget has described the subsumption of a new instance under a previously accepted conception as a process of assimilation; while he describes as adaptation the formation of new or modified conceptions for the purpose of dealing with novel experience.104 I shall use these terms to describe the two associated movements by which we both apply and re-shape our conceptions at the same time; for I regard this combination as essential to all conceptual decisions, even though one of the two characters may predominate in any particular case.

用固定的解释框架吸收经验与调整该框架以包含新经验教训之间的区别，在所讨论的框架清晰明了时，获得了新的、更精确的含义。前者代表着按照严格的规则客观地使用语言的理想；后者依赖于说话者的个人干预，以改变语言规则以适应新的场合。前者是一种例行公事，后者是一种启发式行为。前者的范例是计数，它使其解释框架——计数中使用的数字——保持不变；后者的理想体现在诗歌措辞的独创性或涵盖新概念的新数学符号的独创性中。理想情况下，前者是严格可逆的，而后者本质上是不可逆的。因为修改我们的习语就是修改我们今后解释经验的参考框架；也就是修改我们自己。与我们可以随意重述并追溯其前提的正式程序不同，它需要转换到新的前提，而这些前提是任何严格的论证都无法从先前的前提出发的。它是一种源于我们个人判断的决定，即修改我们判断的前提，从而修改我们的智识存在，以使其更加令我们满意。

The distinction between assimilation of experience by a fixed interpretative framework and the adaptation of such a framework to comprise the lessons of a new experience, gains a new and more precise meaning when the framework in question is articulate. The first represents the ideal of using language impersonally, according to strict rules; the second relies on a personal intervention of the speaker, for changing the rules of language to fit new occasions. The first is a routine performance, the second a heuristic act. A paradigm of the first is counting, which leaves its interpretative framework—the numbers used in counting—quite unchanged; the ideal of the second is found in the originality of poetic phrasing or of new mathematical notations covering new conceptions. Ideally, the first is strictly reversible, while the second is essentially irreversible. For to modify our idiom is to modify the frame of reference within which we shall henceforth interpret our experience; it is to modify ourselves. In contrast to a formal procedure which we can recapitulate at will and trace back to its premises, it entails a conversion to new premises not accessible by any strict argument from those previously held. It is a decision, originating in our own personal judgment, to modify the premises of our judgment, and thus to modify our intellectual existence, so as to become more satisfying to ourselves.

但这种自我满足的渴望并非纯粹以自我为中心。我们渴望在言语和所讲述的经历中更加清晰连贯，这是为了寻求问题的答案，一个我们今后可以依赖的答案。它试图发现一些东西并将其牢固地确立下来。我们在此寻求的自我满足，仅仅是为了将其视为一种普遍令人满意的象征。我们进行知识认同的调整，是为了希望由此与现实更加紧密地联系。我们冒险一试，只是为了获得更稳固的立足点。这种未来联系的暗示是推测性的，可能会被证明是错误的，但它们并非因此而仅仅是像掷骰子那样的猜测。因为发现的能力并非赌徒的运气。它取决于天赋，通过训练培养，并由智力努力引导。它类似于艺术成就，同样不可具体化，但绝非偶然或随意。

But again, this urge to satisfy ourselves is not purely egocentric. Our craving for greater clarity and coherence, both in our speech and in the experience of which we speak, seeks a solution to a problem, a solution on which we may henceforth rely. It tries to discover something and to establish it firmly. We seek self-satisfaction here only as a token of what should be universally satisfying. The modification of our intellectual identity is entered upon in the hope of achieving thereby closer contact with reality. We take a plunge only in order to gain a firmer foothold. The intimations of this prospective contact are conjectural and may prove false, but they are not therefore mere guesses like betting on a throw of dice. For the capacity for making discoveries is not a kind of gambler’s luck. It depends on natural ability, fostered by training and guided by intellectual effort. It is akin to artistic achievement and like it is unspecifiable, but far from accidental or arbitrary.

正是出于这种意义，我才称外延为一门艺术。学习一门语言或修改其含义是一种心照不宣、不可逆转的启发式技艺；它是我们思想生活的一种转变，源于我们对更清晰、更连贯的渴望，同时也源于希望借此更贴近现实的希望。事实上，任何对预期框架的修改，无论是概念性的、感知性的还是欲望性的，都是一种不可逆转的启发式行为，它改变了我们的思维方式、观察方式和欣赏方式，希望使我们的理解力、感知力或感性更贴近真实和正确。尽管每一种非语言性的适应都会影响我们的语言，但在此我将只讨论概念框架和语言框架修改之间的相互作用，我在本节开头已经提到过这一点。

This is the sense in which I called denotation an art. To learn a language or to modify its meaning is a tacit, irreversible, heuristic feat; it is a transformation of our intellectual life, originating in our own desire for greater clarity and coherence, and yet sustained by the hope of coming by it into closer touch with reality. Indeed, any modification of an anticipatory framework, whether conceptual, perceptual or appetitive, is an irreversible heuristic act, which transforms our ways of thinking, seeing and appreciating in the hope of attuning our understanding, perception or sensuality more closely to what is true and right. Though each of these non-linguistic adaptations will affect our language, I shall continue to deal here only with the interaction between modifications of the conceptual and linguistic frameworks, to which I referred at the opening of this section.

（1）我提出的三个层面中，第一个层面是儿童学习说话的层面。儿童早期的猜测在成人看来或许显得笨拙而愚蠢，但它所揭示的语言用法的推测性，是所有言语中必然固有的，并且始终存在于我们的言语中。孩子会指着在风中飘动的衣物称之为“天气”，把挂着衣物的夹子称为“小天气”，把风车称为“大天气”。这种幼稚的、在猜测词义时做出的错误概括被称为“幼稚的言语行为”，1但成年人生活中仍然存在的错误却大同小异。例如，很少有人知道常用形容词“arch”的意思是“狡猾的”或“顽皮的”。即使是受过良好教育的人也可能会告诉你它的意思是“油嘴滑舌”、“奉承讨好”、“讽刺挖苦”或“装作贵族”。过去几年，《读者文摘》每周都会发布一份不同的词汇表，其中通常包含大多数人都熟悉的词汇，要求读者从列出的三个类别中找出每个词汇所指代的概念；很少有人能把整个列表都答对。我们对最常用的词汇有着相对可靠的了解，但这些可靠的词汇周围却充斥着一大堆我们几乎从未敢于使用的、一知半解的表达方式。这种犹豫反映出一种智力上的不安，促使我们探索更清晰、更连贯的表达方式。

(1)The first of the three levels on which I have proposed to illustrate the re-interpretation of language is that of the child learning to speak. Its early guesswork may appear floundering and foolish to adults, but the conjectural character of linguistic usage which it reveals is necessarily inherent in all speech and remains inherent in ours to the end. A child will point at the washing fluttering in the wind and call it ‘weather’, and call the pegs fastening the washing ‘small weather’, and the windmill ‘big weather’. Such infantile false generalizations in guessing the meaning of words are known as ‘childish verbalism’,1 but the mistakes persisting in adult life are quite similar. Few people seem to know, for example, that the common adjective ‘arch’ means ‘cunning’ or ‘playfully roguish’. Even exceptionally well educated persons may tell you that it means ‘oily’, ‘ingratiating’, ‘ironical’, or ‘pretending to be aristocratic’. For some years past the Readers Digest has published every week a different list often words known to most people, asking the reader to identify, out of three classes mentioned, that to which the notion designated by each word belongs; and rarely does anyone get the whole list right. We have a comparatively safe knowledge of the most frequently used words, but this assured vocabulary is surrounded by a swarm of half-understood expressions which we hardly ever venture to use at all. This hesitation reflects a sense of intellectual uneasiness, which induces us to grope for greater clarity and coherence.

我已经表达过我的信念，我们必须相信自己有能力评估自身表达的不足（第91页）。现在，我要亲自宣称自己拥有这种能力，因为我说过，言语错误与对我们感到困惑的主题的误解密不可分。一个孩子用同一个词“weather”（天气）来指代雨、衣夹和风车，他对天气的概念既不令人满意，也不稳定，因为所有这些截然不同的事物都混杂在一起了。我至今仍记得小时候一个令人费解的概念，我把面包和行李混在一起了，因为我无法区分德语单词“Gebäck”（包子）和“Gepäck”（行李），这两个词分别指代它们。迪伦·托马斯讲述了他童年时期如何将“front”（前面）的两个含义（分别指房屋入口和法国战场）融​​合在一起。105并对这种混合产生的奇特后果感到疑惑。像“epicene”或“cynosure”这样较为罕见的词语，在我们大多数人心中会引发困惑和不确定的概念，这些概念融合了支离破碎的线索，而这些线索大多借用自发音相似的词语。学者们仍在猜测，诸如“arete”和“sophrosyne”等希腊语术语究竟涵盖了哪些概念；他们的猜测遵循着与儿童在摸索理解语言时所依赖的适应性标准类似的标准。

I have already expressed my belief that we must credit ourselves with the capacity for appraising the inadequacy of our own articulation (p. 91). I shall now claim this capacity myself for saying that verbal mistakes go hand in hand with misunderstandings of the subject matter by which we feel puzzled. A child who uses the same word ‘weather’ for rain, clothespegs and windmills, has an unsatisfying and hence unstable conception of weather in which all these disparate things are amalgamated. I can still remember a puzzling conception I had as a child, in which buns and luggage were fused together, in view of the fact that I could not distinguish between the German words ‘Gebäck’ and ‘Gepäck’, which applied to the two respectively. Dylan Thomas tells how he fused in childhood the two meanings of ‘front’, designating the entrance to the house and the battlefields in France,105 and wondered at the curious consequences flowing from this hybridization. Rarer words like ‘epicene’ or ‘cynosure’ evoke in most of us confused and uncertain conceptions combining disjointed clues, borrowed mostly from the meaning of similarly sounding words. Scholars continue to conjecture on precisely what conceptions are covered by such Greek terms as ‘arete’ and ‘sophrosyne’; their guesses are guided by criteria of fitness similar to those on which the child relies in its fumblings to understand speech.

（2）在自然科学的某些分支学科中，混淆也可能长期存在，而最终只有通过澄清术语才能解决。化学的原子理论由约翰·道尔顿于 1808 年创立，并几乎立即得到普遍接受。然而，在该理论被普遍应用的约五十年中，其含义却一直模糊不清。1858 年，康尼扎罗精确区分了三个密切相关的原子量概念：分子量和当量（每价的重量），这给科学家们带来了启示，此前这三个概念一直被模糊地互换使用。康尼扎罗解释框架的恰当性给我们对化学的理解带来了新的清晰度和连贯性。这种澄清是不可逆的；如今，要重新构建化学家们在过去半个世纪中使用的那些混乱概念（例如，正是这些概念促使道尔顿否定了阿伏伽德罗定律，认为它与化学的原子理论相悖），就像在找到一个谜题的答案后再次被它难倒一样困难。还记得在麦斯麦尔首次出现后的近一个世纪里，科学家们一直认为，他们要么接受“动物磁性”的虚假主张，要么将所有支持该理论的证据都视为虚幻或欺诈，直到最后，布雷德提出了“催眠术”的新概念，解决了这个错误的困境。106催眠术的伟大先驱，如艾略特森，都曾因之前盛行的混乱而悲惨地成为牺牲品，因为缺乏一个概念框架，无法将他们的发现与似是而非、站不住脚的混合物区分开来。

(2)Confusion may prevail for a long time also in some branch of the natural sciences, and be finally resolved only in conjunction with a clarification of terms. The atomic theory of chemistry was established by John Dalton in 1808 and generally accepted almost at once. Yet for about fifty years, in which the theory was universally applied, its meaning remained obscure. It came as a revelation to scientists when in 1858 Cannizaro distinguished precisely the three closely related conceptions of atomic weight; molecular weight and equivalent weight (weight per valence), which had been used until then in an indeterminately interchangeable manner. The appositeness of Cannizaro’s interpretative framework brought new clarity and coherence into our understanding of chemistry. Such clarification is irreversible; it is as difficult to reconstruct today the confused conceptions which chemists used during the previous half century (and which for example induced Dalton to reject Avogadro’s Law as contrary to the atomic theory of chemistry), as it is to be baffled once more by a puzzle after having discovered its solution. Remember also how, during almost a century after the first appearance of Mesmer, men of science felt that they had either to accept the false claims of ‘animal magnetism’, or reject all the evidence in its favour as illusory or fraudulent, until at last Braid resolved the false dilemma by suggesting the new conception of ‘hypnotism’.106 Great pioneers of hypnotism, like Elliotson, had fallen tragic victims to the confusion previously prevailing, for lack of a conceptual framework in which their discoveries could be separated from specious and untenable admixtures.

坎尼扎罗和布雷德做出了概念上的发现，并通过语言的改进将其巩固；他们对研究对象的更深入理解使他们能够更恰当地表达研究对象。这种语言创新与新概念的形成息息相关，正如学习一门既定语言与习得对其研究对象的现有概念息息相关一样。正如幼稚的言语主义一样，我们在自然科学中看到的混乱源于智力控制的不足，这会导致不适，而这可以通过概念和语言的改革来弥补。

Cannizaro and Braid made conceptual discoveries, which they consolidated by an improvement of language; their better understanding of their subject matter enabled them to speak about it more appositely. Such linguistic innovation is linked to the shaping of new conceptions in the same way as the learning of an established language is linked to the acquiring of current conceptions of its subject matter. As in the case of childish verbalism, the confusions of which we have seen examples in the natural sciences consist in a deficiency of intellectual control, which causes uneasiness, and is remediable by conceptual and linguistic reform.

我必须在此略作离题，更深入地探讨在这些不同案例以及其他相关案例中消除困惑的过程。文本和意义的瓦解，无论是在儿童还是科学家身上，都是问题心理状态的标志。这种困惑的根源始终是概念性的。动物研究中有独立的证据表明，困惑可能出现在纯粹的表达障碍层面。107人类的困惑或许是言语上的，因为如果没有语言的使用，这种困惑就无法产生：一个人在思考如何预测自己的行为时，会感到黑猩猩无法体会到的困惑。然而，他的困惑与他思考如何用自己的鞋带站起来时所遇到的困惑类似；尽管这种困惑，即使是一个孩子或一只试图用这种方式站起来的黑猩猩，也可能难以言喻地感受到。

I must digress here briefly to consider more closely the process by which confusion is eliminated in these different cases and others related to them. The falling apart of text and meaning, whether in the child or in the scientist, is the sign of a problematic state of mind. The seat of such confusion is always conceptual. There is independent evidence from the study of animals that confusion can arise on the purely inarticulate level.107 Human confusion may be verbal, in the sense that it could not be produced without the use of language: a man speculating on the possibility of predicting his own actions is puzzled in a way no chimpanzee can be. Yet his perplexity is similar to that in which he would be involved by speculating on the possibility of lifting himself by his own shoe-laces; though this perplexity could be experienced inarticulately by a child or a chimpanzee trying to lift itself up in this manner.

当孩子混淆同音异义词或混淆发音相似的词语含义时，或者当他被一些用语言表述的问题所困扰，而他早已知道如何在实践中找到答案时，他的语言运用就会模糊原本默契理解中清晰可见的内容。这种幼稚的复杂化可以通过教导孩子根据他们先前对主题的不清晰理解来理解和使用语言来治愈。现代分析哲学已经证明，这在哲学中也适用。有时，我们可以根据我们对主题的简单理解来定义其术语的含义，从而化解哲学问题。

When a child confuses homonyms or fuses the meanings of similar- sounding words, or when it is perplexed by verbally formulated problems the answer to which it has long known how to find in practice, its use of language is obscuring what had previously been clear to its tacit understanding. Such childish sophistication can be cured by teaching children to understand and use speech in accordance with their anterior inarticulate understanding of the subject-matter. Modern analytic philosophy has demonstrated that this may hold also in philosophy. Philosophic problems may sometimes be dissolved by defining the meaning of their terms in accordance with our unsophisticated understanding of their subject matter.

但纯粹的思辨问题并非总是徒劳无功。例如，关于用鞋带提身的思辨，本质上与关于永动机的机械装置的思辨相吻合，而这些思辨只有在力学的发现之后才得以解决，它们也​​为力学的发现做出了实际贡献。爱因斯坦在学生时代提出的关于光在实验室中以光速运动的行为的悖论，只有在爱因斯坦对同时性概念的改革以及随之而来的狭义相对论的建立之后才得以解决。各种逻辑和语义悖论在促进逻辑学近期概念发展方面所起的根本性作用也同样众所周知。我相信，诸如我们能否预测自身行为这一问题所引发的哲学难题的解决，也可能带来重要的概念发现。1事实上，我这本书正是基于这些基础；我正试图通过概念改革来解决相信我可能怀疑的事情所带来的明显的自相矛盾。

But purely speculative problems are not always so fruitless. Speculations about lifting oneself by one’s own shoelaces, for example, coincide essentially with speculations on mechanical devices of perpetual motion, which were resolved only by the discovery of mechanics, to which they effectively contributed. The paradox raised by Einstein as a schoolboy about the behaviour of light in a laboratory moving with the speed of light, was resolved only by Einstein’s reform of the concept of simultaneity, and his conjoint establishment of special relativity. The fundamental part played by various logical and semantic paradoxes in stimulating the recent conceptual development in logic is equally notorious. I believe that the solution of philosophic puzzles, like that raised by the question whether we can predict our own actions, may also lead to important conceptual discoveries.1 In fact, my present book rests on precisely these grounds; I am attempting to resolve by conceptual reform the apparent self-contradiction entailed in believing what I might conceivably doubt.

我之前曾建议（第 95 页），当文本和意义分崩离析时，我们必须选择是否

I have suggested before (p. 95) that when text and meaning fall apart we must choose whether to

（1）（a）纠正文本的含义。

(1)(a) Correct the meaning of the text.

（b）重新解释文本。

(b) Re-interpret the text.

（2）重新诠释经验。

(2)Re-interpret experience.

（3）认为文本毫无意义，不予理会。

(3)Dismiss the text as meaningless.

 

 

现在看来，案例 (1a )既涵盖了我们提升语言知识的接受过程，也涵盖了现代哲学所实践的通过更严格的语言控制来消除语言难题的过程。(1b) 和 (2) 的结合，体现在科学中的概念发现；类似的发现，不依赖于经验，在数学中也是可能的，我稍后会再讨论这一点。将文本视为无意义的文本，并将其提出的问题视为伪问题（案例 (3)），可能是对其术语进行哲学澄清的结果（案例 (1a ) ）。

Case (1a) is now seen to cover both the receptive process by which we improve our knowledge of a language, and the elimination of verbal puzzles by a stricter control of language, as practised by modern philosophy. Combinations of (1b) and (2) are exemplified by conceptual discoveries in science; analogous discoveries, not referring to experience, are possible in mathematics, to which I shall yet return. The dismissal of a text as meaningless, and of the problem raised by it as a pseudoproblem (Case (3)), may result from the philosophic clarification of its terms (Case (1a)).

所有这些选择都涉及根据我们的清晰性和理性标准来塑造意义。这样的选择构成了一种启发式行为，它或许能够展现出最高程度的独创性。我刚才通过回顾坎尼扎罗和布雷德的例子来说明这一点。但我还想再次提及恩斯特·马赫的例子，他谴责牛顿的“绝对空间”毫无意义：相对论的发现后来证明，这个概念并非毫无意义，而是错误的。108因为这个错误让人想起了其他类似的错误。庞加莱说过，所有固体的线性维度的比例变化都是不可观测的，因此毫无意义。109他忽略了体积和尺寸关系相应变化所带来的一系列后果。一度​​人们认为洛伦兹-菲茨杰拉德收缩本质上是不可观测的。110这是错误的。长期以来，谎言悖论一直被认为是一种诡辩，在逻辑上毫无意义。111后来，这个问题被公认为一个根本问题。将一个问题视为伪问题而予以驳斥的解释行为，不可避免地充满了启发式决策的所有风险。

Every one of these choices involves the shaping of meaning in the light of our standards of clarity and reason. Such a choice constitutes a heuristic act which may display the highest degree of originality. This I have illustrated just now by recalling the examples of Cannizaro and Braid. But I want also to mention again the case of Ernst Mach, who denounced as meaningless Newton’s ‘absolute space’: a conception which the discovery of relativity later proved to be not meaningless but false.108 For this error recalls others of its kind. When Poincaré said that a proportionate change in the linear dimensions of all solid bodies would be unobservable, and therefore empty of meaning,109 he overlooked a host of consequences arising from the corresponding change in the relation of volumes and sizes. For a time it was thought that the Lorentz-Fitzgerald contraction was essentially unobservable,110 which is false. The paradox of the Liar was long regarded as a mere sophism, without importance in logic,111 in which it was later recognized as a fundamental problem. The interpretative act by which a question is dismissed as a pseudo-problem is inevitably fraught with all the risks of a heuristic decision.

(3) 语言在日常使用中不断被重新诠释，无需任何尖锐问题的尖锐刺激，一些类似的命名学问题在科学中通常也能以同样流畅的方式得到解决。支配这些情况的一般原则已经阐述；我现在将重申如下。在这个瞬息万变的世界中，我们的预见能力总是不得不应对某种程度上前所未有的情况，而通常情况下，只有经过一定程度的适应才能做到这一点。更具体地说：由于一个词的每个使用场合都在某种程度上与之前的每个场合不同，我们应该预料到，一个词的含义在每一次这样的场合都会有所改变。例如，由于没有一只猫头鹰与其他猫头鹰完全相同，因此说“这是一只猫头鹰”，这个表面上是关于我们面前这只鸟的陈述，也对“猫头鹰”一词，也就是关于猫头鹰总体而言，表达了一些新的含义。

(3) Language is continuously re-interpreted in its everyday use without the sharp spur of any acute problem, and some kindred questions of nomenclature are usually settled in a similarly smooth fashion in science. The general principle which governs these occasions has already been stated; I shall re-assert it now as follows. In this changing world, our anticipatory powers have always to deal with a somewhat unprecedented situation, and they can do so in general only by undergoing some measure of adaptation. More particularly: since every occasion on which a word is used is in some degree different from every previous occasion, we should expect that the meaning of a word will be modified in some degree on every such occasion. For example, since no owl is exactly like any other, to say ‘This is an owl’, a statement which ostensibly says something about the bird in front of us, also says something new about the term ‘owl’, that is, about owls in general.

这就引出了一个棘手的问题。我们能否安全地认可这种为了确保我们所说的内容真实而调整词义的做法？如果我们可以形容一种前所未有的猫头鹰，或许属于一个新物种：“这是一只猫头鹰”，并适当地修改这个名称的含义，那么为什么我们不能同样恰当地形容猫头鹰：“这是一只麻雀”，指的是一种迄今为止尚未被人们以这个名字命名的新麻雀？事实上，我们为什么要说一件事而不是另一件事，而不是随意选择描述性术语呢？或者，如果我们的术语要根据其目前的应用来定义，那么除了“这是这个”之外，还有什么陈述能表达更多含义呢？这显然毫无意义。

This raises an awkward question. Can we safely sanction the practice of adapting the meaning of words so that what we say shall be true? If we can say of an unprecedented owl, belonging perhaps to a new species: ‘This is an owl’, using this designation in an appropriately modified sense, why should we not equally well say of an owl: ‘This is a sparrow’, meaning a new kind of sparrow, not known so far by that name? Indeed, why should we ever say one thing rather than another, and not pick our descriptive terms at random? Or alternatively, if our terms are to be defined by conformity to their present applications, would any statement say more than ‘this is this’, which is clearly useless?

我将尝试用一个精确科学的例子来回答这个问题。1932年，尤里（Urey）发现重氢（氘）时，他将其描述为氢的一种新同位素。1934年，在皇家学会举行的一次讨论会上，同位素学的发现者弗雷德里克·索迪（Frederic Soddy）对此提出了异议，理由是他最初将元素的同位素定义为化学上不可分离的，而重氢在化学上可以与轻氢分离。112没有人理会这一抗议，而是默认接受了“同位素”一词的新含义。新的含义允许将重氢纳入氢的同位素之中，尽管它具有前所未有的特性，即可以通过化学方式与其他同位素分离。因此，“存在一种氘元素，它是氢的同位素”这一说法被接受，其意义重新定义了“同位素”一词，使得这一原本错误的说法变成了正确。新的概念摒弃了先前认为同位素学肤浅的标准，转而仅依赖于同位素中核电荷的同一性。

I shall try to answer this by an illustration from the exact sciences. When heavy hydrogen (deuterium) was discovered by Urey in 1932, it was described by him as a new isotope of hydrogen. At a discussion held by the Royal Society in 1934 the discoverer of isotopy, Frederic Soddy, objected to this on the grounds that he had originally defined the isotopes of an element as chemically inseparable from each other, and heavy hydrogen was chemically separable from light hydrogen.112 No attention was paid to this protest and a new meaning of the term ‘isotope’ was tacitly accepted instead. The new meaning allowed heavy hydrogen to be included among the isotopes of hydrogen, in spite of its unprecedented property of being chemically separable from its fellow isotopes. Thus the statement There exists an element deuterium which is an isotope of hydrogen’ was accepted in a sense which re-defined the term isotope, so that this statement, which otherwise would be false, became true. The new conception abandoned a previously accepted criterion of isotopy as superficial, and relied instead only on the identity of nuclear charges in isotopes.

因此，我们将氘鉴定为氢的同位素，证实了两点：(1) 氢和氘之间存在一种新的化学可分离性，这种可分离性适用于两种具有相同核电荷的元素；(2) 尽管这些元素可以分离，但仅仅基于它们相同的核变化，它们就应被视为同位素。(1) 中提到的新观察结果促使 (2) 中提出了概念和语言改革。这些改革使得“所有‘同位素’在化学上都是不可分离的”这一语言规则站不住脚，并迫使人们用一种新的用法来取代它，这种新的用法反映了从这些观察结果中得出的更真实的同位素概念。因为，如果保留原来的同位素概念，将轻氢和重氢之间的化学差异归类为两种元素在周期表中不同位置之间的化学差异，那将是极其荒谬的误导。这证明了我们在调整词义时必须遵循的原则，以便我们所说的内容是真实的：相应的概念决策必须是正确的——它们所隐含的指控是正确的。

Our identification of deuterium as an isotope of hydrogen thus affirms two things: (1) that there exists in the case of hydrogen and deuterium an instance of a new kind of chemical separability, pertaining to two elements of equal nuclear charge, (2) that these elements are to be regarded as isotopes in spite of their separability, merely on the grounds of their equal nuclear change. The new observations referred to in (1) necessitated the conceptual and linguistic reforms decreed in (2). They rendered the linguistic rule ‘all “isotopes” are chemically inseparable’ untenable, and compelled its replacement by a new usage reflecting the truer conception of isotopy derived from these observations. For to retain the original conception of isotopy, by which the chemical differences between light and heavy hydrogen would be classed with the chemical differences between two elements filling different places of the periodic system, would have been misleading to the point of absurdity. This demonstrates the principle which must guide us when adapting the meaning of words, so that what we say shall be true: the corresponding conceptual decisions must be right—their implied allegations true.

因此，我们将一种新的猫头鹰称为猫头鹰，而不是麻雀，因为修改猫头鹰的概念，将这种鸟纳入“猫头鹰”的一个实例，这样做是合理的；而修改麻雀的概念，将这种鸟纳入“麻雀”的一个实例，这样做是无稽之谈。前一种概念上的判断是正确的，其含义也正确，就像接受氘和氢作为同位素，但其含义有所改变一样，是正确的，其含义也正确。同样，在猫头鹰和同位素这两种情况下，其他判断都是错误的，其含义也不正确。这两种情况之间唯一的区别在于：对同位素概念进行调整以适应对氘和氢的观察，可以通过对同位素定义的修正来具体化；而对像“猫头鹰”这样的形态学概念进行调整以使其涵盖新的物种，通常无法如此具体化。我将在第四部分中在更广泛的背景下扩展这些观察。

Thus we call a new kind of owl an owl, rather than a sparrow, because the modification of the conception of owls by which we include the bird in question as an instance of ‘owls’ makes sense; while a modification of our conception of sparrows, by which we would include this bird as an instance of ‘sparrows’, makes nonsense. The former conceptual decision is right and its implications true, in the same sense in which the decision to accept deuterium and hydrogen as isotopes in a modified sense of this term, is right and its implications true. Similarly, in both cases—of owls and of isotopes—the alternative decisions are wrong and their implications untrue. There is only this difference between the two cases: that the adaptation of the isotope concept to accommodate the observations on deuterium and hydrogen can be specified in terms of an amendment to the definition of isotopy, while the adaptations of a morphological concept like that of ‘owl’, by which it is made to include novel specimens, can usually not be so specified. I shall expand these observations in Part Four within a wider context.

当我们的注意力集中在理解眼前情境时，我们概念的适应以及相应的语言运用对新事物（我们将其视为已知事物的新变体）的适应是逐渐实现的。因此，我们这样做的方式与我们通过追求清晰连贯的感知来不断辅助性地修改我们对感官线索的解读，或者通过在不断变化的情况下练习来提升我们的技能（尽管我们并不完全了解具体方法）的方式相同。因此，言语的意义在我们探索词语的过程中不断变化，而我们并没有完全意识到这种变化，而我们的探索以这种方式赋予了词语丰富的不可言喻的内涵。语言是人类在做出新的概念判断（并通过词语传达）的过程中探索词语的产物。 113

The adaptation of our conceptions and of the corresponding use of language to new things that we identify as new variants of known kinds of things is achieved subsidiarily, while our attention is focussed on making sense of a situation in front of us. Thus we do this in the same way in which we keep modifying, subsidiarily, our interpretation of sensory clues by striving for clear and coherent perceptions, or enlarging our skill without focally knowing how by practising them in ever new situations. The meaning of speech thus keeps changing in the act of groping for words without our being focally aware of the change, and our gropings invest words in this manner with a fund of unspecifiable connotations. Languages are the product of man’s groping for words in the process of making new conceptual decisions, to be conveyed by words.113

不同的语言是不同历史时期不同群体通过世俗探索得出的另类结论。它们维系着不同的概念框架，用略有不同的、据称反复出现的特征来解释所有可以讨论的事物。名词、动词、形容词和副词，这些词是由特定世代的探索者发明并赋予意义的，而他们对这些词的自信运用，表达了他们对事物本质的独特理论。114在学习说话的过程中，每个孩子都接受了一种以传统宇宙观为前提构建的文化，这种文化根植于其诞生群体的习语，受过教育的头脑的每一项智力努力都将在这个框架内进行。如果这种解释框架完全错误，人的整个智力生活都将付诸东流；人的理性程度取决于他所坚持的概念是否正确。上句中“真”一词的使用，是重新定义真理含义的一部分，旨在使其在其自身修正的意义上更加真实。

Different languages are alternative conclusions, arrived at by the secular gropings of different groups of people at different periods of history. They sustain alternative conceptual frameworks, interpreting all things that can be talked about in terms of somewhat different allegedly recurrent features. The confident use of the nouns, verbs, adjectives and adverbs, invented and endowed with meaning by a particular sequence of groping generations, expresses their particular theory of the nature of things.114 In learning to speak, every child accepts a culture constructed on the premises of the traditional interpretation of the universe, rooted in the idiom of the group to which it was born, and every intellectual effort of the educated mind will be made within this frame of reference. Man’s whole intellectual life would be thrown away should this interpretative framework be wholly false; he is rational only to the extent to which the conceptions to which he is committed are true. The use of the word ‘true’ in the preceding sentence is part of a process of re-defining the meaning of truth, so as to make it truer in its own modified sense.

不同的词汇用来解释事物，将人们划分成不同的群体，他们无法理解彼此看待事物和采取行动的方式。不同的习语决定了不同的情绪和行为模式。如果，且仅当我们相信女巫，我们才会把人当女巫烧死；如果，且仅当我们相信上帝，我们才会建造教堂；如果我们相信优等民族，我们才会灭绝犹太人和波兰人；如果陷入阶级战争，我们才会加入共产党；如果感到内疚，我们才会感到悔恨并惩罚罪犯；如果陷入内疚情结，我们才会寻求精神分析的帮助；等等。

Different vocabularies for the interpretation of things divide men into groups which cannot understand each other’s way of seeing things and of acting upon them. For different idioms determine different patterns of possible emotions and actions. If, and only if, we believe in witches may we burn people as witches; if, and only if, we believe in God will we build churches; if we believe in master races we may exterminate Jews and Poles; if in class war, we may join the Communist Party; if in guilt, we may feel remorse and punish offenders; if in guilt-complexes, we may apply psychoanalysis instead; and so on.

现代作家们反抗着文字对我们思想的影响力，他们贬低文字，认为文字不过是为了方便交流而建立的惯例。这种说法如同说人们选择相对论是为了方便一样具有误导性。我们完全可以把方便归因于追求某个主要目标时的小小优势。例如，把用巫术习语解释猝死的方便性与用医学术语解释猝死的方便性进行比较，或者把描述政治对手的方便性与称他们为间谍、怪物、人民公敌等等进行比较，都是荒谬的。我们对语言的选择关乎真理或谬误、对错——关乎生死。

Modern writers have rebelled against the power exercised by words over our thoughts, and have expressed this by deprecating words as mere conventions, established for the sake of convenient communication. This is just as misleading as to say that the theory of relativity is chosen for convenience. We may properly ascribe convenience only to a minor advantage in the pursuit of a major purpose. It is nonsense, for example, to compare the convenience of interpreting sudden death in the idiom of witchcraft with the convenience of using instead a medical terminology, or to compare the convenience of describing political opponents as such, with that of calling them spies, monsters, enemies of the people, etc. Our choice of language is a matter of truth or error, of right or wrong—of life or death.

语言是一套按照“语言游戏”的惯例规则使用的便捷符号，这种轻描淡写的说法源于名义主义的传统，该主义认为，通用术语仅仅是指称某些对象集合的名称——尽管这一学说确实存在一些难题，但如今大多数英美作家仍然接受它，因为他们对其形而上学的替代理论深恶痛绝。通过承认术语具有“开放结构”，我们回避了同一个术语如何适用于一系列不确定可变的个体的问题。1115然而，“开放”术语缺乏任何明确的意义；它们可能指任何意义，除非承认存在某种足以控制其意义范围的干预。我个人的观点承认了这一控制原则，即承认说话者有判断其言语表达其试图表达的现实的适当性。没有这一点，具有开放结构的词语就完全没有意义，任何用此类词语写成的文本也毫无意义。如果拒绝承认这一点，名义论者要么避免探究这些词语如何应用于经验（除非任意）；要么援引一套模糊的规范原则——而不去追问这些规则的权威性，以及鉴于其自身的模糊性，如何应用它们（除非任意）。116所有这些缺陷都被忽视了，因为人们主要想避免提及形而上学的概念，或者至少想用名义主义的体面来掩盖这些概念。

The understatement that language is a set of convenient symbols used according to the conventional rules of a ‘language game’ originates in the tradition of nominalism, which teaches that general terms are merely names designating certain collections of objects—a doctrine which, in spite of the difficulties admittedly attached to it, is accepted today by most writers in England and America, in abhorrence of its metaphysical alternatives. The question how the same term can apply to a series of indeterminately variable particulars is avoided by admitting that terms have an ‘open texture’.1115‘Open’ terms, however, lack any definite meaning; they may mean anything, unless some intervention is admitted which is competent to control the range of their meaning. My own view admits this controlling principle by accrediting the speaker’s sense of fitness for judging that his words express the reality he seeks to express. Without this, words having an open texture are totally meaningless, and any text written in such words is meaningless. Refusing to make this admission, the nominalist has either to refrain from enquiring how such words can be applied, except arbitrarily, to experience; or else to invoke a set of vague regulative principles—without asking on what authority these rules are to be accepted and how they can be applied, unless arbitrarily, in view of their own vagueness.116 All these deficiencies are overlooked in an overriding desire to avoid reference to metaphysical notions or at least to cover these up under a cloak of nominalist respectability.

或者说，语言规则的研究被当作对其术语所指事物的研究的伪替代品。例如，维特根斯坦说：“我不知道我是否感到痛苦”不是一个有意义的命题。 117但儿科医生的经验表明，孩子们常常怀疑自己是真的疼痛，还是因为其他原因感到不适。因此，这种替代的伪性在这里显而易见，因为隐含的陈述是错误的。如果维特根斯坦说“疼痛的本质在于，我总是能分辨出我是否感觉到它”，那他实际上就错了。通过使用这种伪替代：“无论我是否感觉到疼痛，都不能说它是疼痛，这违反了公认的惯例”，他所说的是与疼痛的本质无关的真理，而他实际上对疼痛的本质是错误的。

Alternatively, the study of linguistic rules is used as a pseudo- substitute for the study of the things referred to in its terms. For example, Wittgenstein says,‘“I don’t know whether I am in pain or not” is not a significant proposition.117 But the experience of pediatricians shows that children are often in doubt whether they are in pain or are uncomfortable for other reasons. Thus the pseudo-character of the substitution becomes apparent here because the implied statement is mistaken. Had Wittgenstein said. ‘It is in the nature of pain that I can always tell whether I feel it or not’ he would have been mistaken in fact. By using the pseudosubstitute: ‘It is contrary to accepted usage to speak of pain whether I feel it or not’, he said something true which was irrelevant to the nature of pain, about which he was actually mistaken.

相应地，关于事物本质的分歧不能表达为对现有词语用法的分歧。所谓的永动机是否是这样的机器，无法通过研究相关术语的用法来判断。法律究竟是“强者的意志”还是“主权者的命令”等等，无法通过与问题无关的语言学研究来判断。只有当我们使用现有的语言来引导我们的注意力到其主题上，而不是反过来，选择相关案例来引导我们的注意力到我们对语言的使用上，才能关注这些有争议的问题。“语法”正是语言规则的总和，这些规则可以通过使用语言而不关注所指代的事物来遵守。哲学假装只关注语法，其目的在于思考和分析现实，同时否定这样做的行为。 118

Correspondingly, disagreements on the nature of things cannot be expressed as disagreements about the existing use of words. Whether an alleged machine of perpetual motion is such a machine or not cannot be decided by studying the use of the terms in question. Whether the law is but ‘the will of the stronger’ or ‘the command of the sovereign’ or…etc., cannot be decided by linguistic investigations, which are irrelevant to the issue. These controversial questions can be attended to only if we use language as it exists to direct our attention to its subject matter and not the other way around, selecting instances of relevant cases to direct our attention to our use of language. ‘Grammar’ is precisely the total of linguistic rules which can be observed by using a language without attending to the things referred to. The purpose of the philosophic pretence of being merely concerned with grammar is to contemplate and analyse reality, while denying the act of doing so.118

当然存在“Scheinprobleme”（问题），而这些问题的出现都离不开语言。牛顿如果不谈论绝对静止，就不可能提出他的时间和空间公理。但绝对静止的概念并非源于语言的滥用，也无法通过参考日常经验和日常用法而被消除，因为它实际上根植于这些经验和用法之中。马赫的思辨也并非因为被牛顿的概念错误误导而毫无意义；因为它们提出了一个问题，并最终导致了一项伟大的发现。

There are of course ‘Scheinprobleme’, and none of these could have arisen without the use of language. Newton could not have formulated his axioms on time and space without talking about absolute rest. But the conception of absolute rest was not suggested by any abuse of language, nor could it be eliminated by reference to ordinary experience and everyday usage, for it was actually rooted in these. Nor were Mach’s speculations unavailing for being misguided by Newton’s conceptual error; for they raised a problem which led to a great discovery.

我建议我们更坦诚地面对自身处境，承认我们自身拥有识别真实实体的能力，这些实体的名称构成了合理的词汇。我相信，根据理性标准进行的分类应该形成一些事物群体，这些事物群体可能拥有无限数量的共同属性，因此，指定此类类别的术语将具有内涵，指的是该类别成员所共有的无限范围的、未约定的共同属性。关键特征的内涵越丰富，通常情况下，用其术语识别事物就应该越合理，这种分类也应该越真实地揭示被分类对象的本质；而根据没有内涵的术语进行的分类则应被视为纯粹人为的、不真实的、无意义的；除非它们纯粹是为了方便而设计的，例如，作为词语的字母记录。

I suggest that we should be more frank in facing our situation and acknowledge our own faculties for recognizing real entities, the designations of which form a rational vocabulary. I believe that a classification made according to rational criteria should form groups of things which we may expect to have an indefinite number of properties in common, and that accordingly the terms designating such classes will have an intension referring to an indefinite range of uncovenanted common properties shared by the members of a class. The ampler the intensions of a key feature, the more rational should be as a rule the identification of things in its terms and the more truly should such classification reveal the nature of the classified objects; while classifications made according to terms having no intension should be rejected as purely artificial, unreal, nonsensical; unless indeed they are designed purely for convenience as, e.g., an alphabetic register of words.

我相信我们有能力进行客观分类，因此在此可以肯定这一点，因为它与我先前在诸多方面对个人知识和个人清晰度系数的认可相一致——尽管它所蕴含的基于个人的客观性目前仍未得到阐明。因此，我将继续进一步阐述这一信念。

This belief in our capacity for conceiving objective classifications may be acknowledged here on the ground of its continuity with my previous endorsement of personal knowledge and of the personal coefficient of articulation in a great variety of aspects—even though the kind of personally grounded objectivity which it entails must still remain unelucidated at this stage. I shall go on therefore to elaborate this belief further.

内涵有三个层次，依次递增。第一层包含一类事物除了其共同的关键特征之外，还具有一些易于指定的属性；这种明显的内涵构成了该分类真实性的明确证据。第二层包含这些事物所共有的已知但不易指定的属性。一个术语所涵盖的这些属性的范围，决定了对该术语的分析能否加深对其所指事物的理解。几个世纪以来，具有重大人类意义的词汇积累了大量已知的次要内涵，我们可以通过反思这些词汇的使用来部分地聚焦这些内涵——就像我们可以通过分析性反思的过程来识别面相的特征要素或有助于技能的技巧一样。因此，对“正义”、“真理”或“勇气”等词汇的含义进行苏格拉底式的探究是卓有成效的。

There are three successively deeper strata of intensions, of which the first comprises the readily specifiable properties which a class of things are known to share apart from their common key-feature; such manifest intension forms the patent evidence for the reality of the classification. The second stratum comprises the known but not readily specifiable properties which these things share. The range of such properties subsumed under a term is the measure to which its analysis may lead to a deeper understanding of the things it designates. Words of great human significance accumulate through the centuries an unfathomable fund of subsidiarily known connotations, which we can bring partly into focus by reflecting on the use of such words—in the same way as we may recognize the characteristic elements of a physiognomy, or the tricks conducive to a skill—by a process of analytic reflection. Hence the fruitfulness of a Socratic enquiry into the meaning of words like ‘justice’ or ‘truth’ or ‘courage’, etc.

从这些角度理解，定义是对意义的形式化，它减少了意义的非形式化元素，并用形式化操作（对定义项的引用）部分取代它们。这种形式化也是不完整的，因为只有熟悉被定义项的人才能理解定义项。即便如此，定义仍然可以为被定义项带来新的启示，就像指导格言可以阐明一门艺术的实践一样，尽管它的应用必须依赖于该艺术的实践知识。这些定义（例如“因果关系是必然的延续”、“生命是持续的适应”），如果是真实的和新颖的，就是分析性的发现。这样的发现是哲学最重要的任务之一。

Understood in these terms, definition is a formalization of meaning which reduces its informal elements and partly replaces them by a formal operation (the reference to the definiens). This formalization will be incomplete also in the sense that the definiens can be understood only by those conversant with the definiendum. Even so, the definition may still throw new light on the definiendum, in the way a guiding maxim illuminates the practice of an art, though its application must rely on the practical knowledge of the art. Such definitions (like ‘causation is necessary succession’, ‘life is continuous adaptation’) are, if true and new, analytic discoveries. Such discoveries are among the most important tasks of philosophy.

聚焦于理解的次要要素是一种新的体验，通常也是一种冒险的行为。由此得出的结论本质上是一种解释。我们在此看到经验观察的特征与分析命题的特征相结合。这最终归因于这样一个事实：当我们能够以两种不同的方式认识同一事物时，必然的分析命题与偶然的综合陈述之间的二分法就不再成立，这两种方式无法通过逻辑运算相互转换，而只能通过苏格拉底式的探究来识别。

To take cognizance focally of a subsidiary element of a comprehension is a new experience, and an act which is usually hazardous. The conclusion thus reached is in the nature of an explanation. We see combined here the characteristics of an empirical observation with those of an analytic proposition. This is due ultimately to the fact that the dichotomy between analytic propositions that are necessary, and synthetic statements that are contingent, no longer holds when we can know the same thing in two different ways which cannot be transposed into each other by logical operations, but can be identified only by an enquiry of the Socratic type.

这样的探究必须以这样的事实为指导：谈论“正义”、“真理”、“勇气”等等，仅仅是基于我们对这些术语所指内容的理解而做出的一种行为。只有当我们确信能够辨别什么是正义、什么是真理或什么是勇气时，我们才能合理地分析我们自身运用“正义”、“真理”或“勇气”这些术语的实践，并希望这种分析能够更清楚地揭示什么是正义、什么是真理或什么是勇气。

Such an enquiry must be guided by the fact that to speak of ‘justice’, ‘truth’, ‘courage’, etc., is but a performance based on our understanding of the subject matter of these terms. Only if we are confident that we can identify what is just, true or courageous, can we reasonably undertake to analyse our own practice of applying the terms ‘justice’, ‘truth’ or ‘courage’, and hope that such an analysis will reveal to us more clearly what is just, true or courageous.

这就像我们为了提高锤击技巧而研究有效使用锤子的动作一样。为此，我们必须尽可能高效地挥动锤子，甚至在观察自己的动作以找到最佳的锤击方式的同时。同样，如果我们想分析“正义”一词的恰当应用条件，就必须尽可能正确、周到地使用，同时观察自己如何操作。我们必须专心而有辨别地透过“正义”一词来审视正义本身，这才是“正义”一词的恰当用法，也是我们想要定义的用法。如果只关注“正义”一词本身，只会破坏其意义。此外，将“正义”一词在适当情境中反复出现仅仅视为一种噪音来研究是不可能的，因为只有该词有意义的用法才能指示我们应该关注哪些情境。

It is the same as if we studied the motions involved in using a hammer effectively with a view to improving our hammering. For this we must wield a hammer as efficiently as we can, even while watching our motions to discover the best way of hammering. Similarly, we must use the word ‘justice’, and use it as correctly and thoughtfully as we can, while watching ourselves doing it, if we want to analyse the conditions under which the word properly applies. We must look, intently and discriminatingly, through the term ‘justice’ at justice itself, this being the proper use of the term ‘justice’, the use which we want to define. To look instead at the word ‘justice’ would only destroy its meaning. Besides, to study the recurrence of the word ‘justice’ as a mere noise in its repeated occurrence in appropriate situations is impossible, for only the meaningful use of the term can indicate to us what situations we are to look at.

更概括地说：为了分析一个描述性术语的用法，我们必须用它来思考其主题，而对这种思考的分析必然会延伸到被思考的对象。因此，这相当于分析我们共同认知该术语及其主题的概念，或者更准确地说，分析该概念所涵盖的细节：由此，我们既可以更理性地使用该术语，也可以更好地理解它所指称的事物。

Speaking more generally: in order to analyse the use of a descriptive term we must use it for the purpose of contemplating its subject matter, and an analysis of this contemplation will inevitably extend to the contemplated object. It will thus amount to an analysis of the conception by which we are jointly aware both of the term and the subject matter, or more precisely, to an analysis of the particulars covered by this conception: from which we may derive both a more rational use of the term and a better understanding of the things which it designates.

内涵的第三层，也是最深的一层，是由指称某物所表达的一系列不确定的预期所形成的。当我们相信自己确实指称了某个真实存在的东西时，我们预期它或许还会以一种不确定的、甚至完全出乎意料的方式展现其有效性。这一内涵包含一系列只有未来的发现才能揭示的属性——从而证实我们术语所传达的概念的正确性。 119

The third and deepest level of intensions is formed by the indeterminate range of anticipations expressed by designating something. When we believe that we have truly designated something real, we expect that it may yet manifest its effectiveness in an indefinite and perhaps wholly unexpected manner. This intension comprises a range of properties which only future discoveries may reveal—confirming thereby the rightness of the conception conveyed by our term.119
