我已经肯定，恰当词汇的这些不确定的预见能力源于其与现实的联系。我们可以扩展此处隐含的“现实性”概念，以解释形式思辨提出新问题并引领新发现的能力。如果一个新的数学概念的假设能够引出一系列新的、有趣的观点，那么我们就可以说它具有现实性。早在洛巴切夫斯基之前一个世纪，萨凯里就探索了基于欧几里得平行公设替代方案的几何学，但他未能意识到这些几何学可能是正确的。最终，只有洛巴切夫斯基和博雅伊从非欧几里得假设出发发展出的一系列有趣的观点，才说服了那些不情愿的公众。他们不得不承认，这些概念具有与迄今为止欧几里得体系同等程度的现实性。我们可以将这种现实性概念扩展到艺术领域，例如回顾EMForster对小说中“扁平”人物和“圆形”人物的区分。如果一个角色的行为几乎完全可以预测，我们就会称其为扁平角色；而如果一个角色能够“令人信服地”让读者感到惊讶，我们就会称其为圆形角色。一个新数学概念的丰硕成果预示着其更胜一筹的真实性；同样，在小说中，“圆形”人物的内在自发性也预示着其出人意料地展现出新的特征，而这些特征仍然源于其原始性格，因此令人信服。

I have already affirmed that these indeterminate anticipatory powers of an apposite vocabulary are due to its contacts with reality. We may extend the conception of reality implied here to account also for the capacity of formal speculations to raise new problems and lead on to new discoveries. A new mathematical conception may be said to have reality if its assumption leads to a wide range of new interesting ideas. Geometries based on alternatives to Euclid’s postulate of parallels were explored by Saccheri a century before Lobatschevski, but he failed to realize that they could be true. It was only the range of interesting ideas developed by Lobatschevski and Bolyai from non-Euclidean assumptions that eventually convinced a reluctant public. They had then to admit that such conceptions had the same degree of reality as had hitherto been ascribed to Euclid’s system. We may extend this conception of reality to the arts, by recalling for example E.M.Forster’s distinction between ‘flat’ and ‘round’ personages in a novel. A character is called flat if its actions are almost wholly predictable, while we say that a character is round if it can ‘convincingly surprise’ the reader. The fruitfulness of a new mathematical conception betokens its superior reality; and so, in a novel, does the internal spontaneity by which a ‘round’ personage may unexpectedly reveal new features which nevertheless flow from its original character, and are therefore convincing.

我们再次面临一个悖论：我们自力更生地寻求与现实的接触，而我们相信，现实终将以意想不到的方式显现。我们必须继续坚持这个悖论，直到我们在承诺的框架内找到平衡。

We come up here once more against the paradox of our self-reliance in seeking contact with a reality of which we believe that it will yet manifest itself in unexpected ways. This paradox we must carry forward unrelieved until we find a balance to it within the framework of commitment.

 

 

  1. 理解逻辑运算
  2. UNDERSTANDING LOGICAL OPERATIONS

当我们借助地图辨别方向时，我们便对地图所代表的区域有了了解，并由此推导出无数的路线。我们无需专注于地图或周围的地标，就能意识到自己对该区域的掌控；因为我们对这些细节的了解，会辅助性地融入一个由地图及其所代表的区域共同构成的概念中。我们通过重新组织这个概念，从而揭示出我们感兴趣的特定路线，从而找到在乡间行走的路。这种概念性的判断并非源于新的经验，而源于对我们已知事物的新兴趣，这是一种思辨行为，其原型在老鼠跑迷宫时就已预示。它是一种对替代性部分-整体关系的认知，类似于C类学习所实现的那种。

When we find our bearings by aid of a map we gain an understanding of the region represented by the map, and from this conception we can derive an indefinite number of itineraries. We are conscious of our mastery of the region without attending focally either to the map or to the landmarks around us; for our knowledge of these particulars enters subsidiarily into a conception comprising jointly both the map and the area that it represents. We find our way about the country by reorganizing this conception so as to reveal the particular itineraries in which we are interested. Such a conceptual decision, not induced by new experience, but by a new kind of interest in what we know already, is a speculative act of a kind prefigured primordially in rats running mazes. It is a recognition of alternative part- whole relations of the kind achieved by learning of type C.

尽管本文讨论的概念重组基于表述，但它本身是非正式的。然而，它可能需要付出脑力劳动，甚至可以说是为了解决问题。如果是这样，它就是一种演绎推理的过程，因为它会引出一个完全由我们原始概念所隐含，但又与之不同的新概念。这种演绎是非正式的，主要不可逆；但只要它遵循固定的程序规则（无论这些规则是否为人们所知），它就被认为是可逆的。

Though the conceptual reorganization in question is based on articulation, it is itself informal. Yet it may require a mental effort and might be said to solve a problem. If so, it is a process of deductive inference, as it leads to a new conception wholly implied by our original conception, yet different from it. Such deduction, being informal, is predominantly irreversible; but it can be acknowledged as reversible to the extent to which it follows fixed rules of procedure, be they focally known or not.

通过将某些操作表示事态的符号的规则作为推理操作，可以将重新组织概念以得出新推论的过程形式化。虽然这些操作是符号化的，但它们表示的并非事态本身，而是将一种事态概念转化为隐含在前一种概念中的另一种概念。它们唤起它们所象征的概念转换，就像“猫”这样的描述性术语唤起它所代表的概念一样。形式化推理过程的隐性成分与外延成分大致类似。它既表达了我们对形式操作的理解，也表达了我们对它们正确性的接受。

The process of reorganizing a conception for drawing new inferences from it can be formalized, by accepting as inferential operations certain rules for manipulating the symbols representing a state of affairs. Although such manipulations are symbolic, they denote not a state of affairs, but the transformation of one conception of a state of affairs into another conception of it that is implied in the first. They evoke the conceptual transformation which they symbolize in the same way as a descriptive term like ‘cat’ evokes the conception for which it stands. The tacit component of a formalized process of reasoning is broadly analogous to that of a denotation. It conveys both our understanding of the formal manipulations, and our acceptance of them as right.

人们或许会认为，理解形式化的推理链（例如数学证明）的困难在于其不为人熟知的符号系统。但动词性句子可能和任何数学公式一样难以理解。以芬德利教授构造的句子为例120用口头的方式解释一下哥德尔第一定理的结果。它的内容如下：

It may be thought that the difficulty of understanding a formalized chain of reasoning, as for example a mathematical proof, lies in its unfamiliar symbolism. But a verbal sentence may be as difficult to understand as any mathematical formula. Take the sentence constructed by Professor Findlay120 to paraphrase verbally the result of Gödel’s (first) theorem. It runs:

我们无法证明通过替换语句形式中的变量得出的语句‘我们无法证明通过替换语句形式中的变量得出的语句Y所讨论的语句形式的名称所讨论的语句形式的名称。

We cannot prove the statement which is arrived at by substituting for the variable in the statement form ‘We cannot prove the statement which is arrived at by substituting for the variable in the statement form Y the name of the statement form in question’ the name of the statement form in question.

当您用所讨论的语句形式的名称（即引号中的文本）代替变量Y时，您会发现 Findlay 的句子本身就表明它无法被证明，因此该句子为真，就像哥德尔句子如果无法被证明则为真一样。

When you substitute for the variable Y the name of the statement form in question which is the text in quotes, you see that Findlay’s sentence says of itself that it cannot be demonstrated, and that hence the sentence is true, just as a Gödelian sentence is true if it cannot be demonstrated.

即使有这样的解释，大多数人读芬德利的这句话二十遍也读不透；事实上，它可能永远无法传达任何意义，因为他们总是忘记理解这句话的思路。天赋和训练在这件事上至关重要。1949年夏天，我把芬德利的这段文字拿给罗素勋爵看，他一眼就明白了其中的意思。

Even with this explanation to aid them, most people may read Findlay’s sentence twenty times over without making head or tail of it; indeed, it may never convey any meaning to them, for they keep losing track of the process of comprehension by which it would make sense. Natural aptitude and training make all the difference in this matter. Lord Russell, to whom I showed Findlay’s text in the summer of 1949, took in its meaning at a glance.

没有人能够被他不理解的证明所说服，而学习一个我们无法信服的数学证明，对我们的数学知识没有任何帮助。事实上，没有哪个老师会满足于传授一系列由形式运算连接起来的公式，就像数学学生不应该满足于记住这些序列一样。庞加莱说，仅仅通过验证每个连续的步骤来看待数学证明，就像观看一场国际象棋比赛，只注意每一步是否遵循国际象棋规则。至少需要的是理解逻辑序列作为一种有目的的程序：庞加莱称之为“构成论证统一性的东西”。121正是这种“某种东西”——也许是以概括证明主要步骤的提纲的形式——让学生在被一连串毫无意义的操作弄得不知所措时去摸索，而当证明的细节被遗忘时，又会想起这种概括，它体现了数学证明的一般原理或一般结构。我仍然记得大约十年前我讲授的氢原子波动方程的求解一般程序，尽管我再也无法记下当时实际演示的任何部分；这种全面的回忆使我相信我仍然理解波动力学，并让我坚信它的说服力。另一方面，尽管我反复回顾了上述哥德尔定理形式证明的所有连续步骤，但它们对我来说毫无意义，因为我无法掌握它们的整个顺序。

No one can be convinced by a proof which he does not understand, and to learn up a mathematical proof which has not convinced us adds nothing to our knowledge of mathematics. Indeed, no teacher will be satisfied with imparting a chain of formulae connected by formal operations as constituting a mathematical proof, and no student of mathematics should be satisfied with memorizing such sequences. To look at a mathematical proof by merely verifying each consecutive step—says Poincaré—is like watching a game of chess, noting only that each step obeys the rules of chess. The least that is required is a grasp of the logical sequence as a purposeful procedure: what Poincaré describes as ‘the something which constitutes the unity of the demonstration’.121 It is this ‘something’—per- haps in the form of an outline embodying the main steps in the proof—for which the student will grope, if baffled by a sequence of operations which convey no sense to him, and it is again this outline, embodying the general principle or general structure of the mathematical proof, which will be remembered when the details of the proof are forgotten. I can still recall the general procedure followed in evaluating the wave equation of a hydrogen atom on which I lectured about ten years ago, though I could no longer write down any part of the actual demonstration; and this comprehensive recollection satisfies me that I still understand wave mechanics, and sustains in me the conviction of its cogency. On the other hand, though I have repeatedly gone over all the consecutive steps in the formal proof of Gödel’s aforementioned theorem, they have conveyed nothing to me, for I have not been able to grasp their sequence as a whole.

即使在数学家中，一个对一个人来说似乎完全令人信服的论点对另一个人来说可能甚至无法理解。122因此，人们试图通过对演绎科学进行严格的形式化，来消除任何运用个人判断的机会；现在看来，这种努力注定会适得其反。因为形式主义的意义在于，我们在以这种形式主义为支撑的概念焦点中对它产生的辅助意识，因此，在对那些完全非个人化的符号（即对象）进行的操作中，形式主义的意义必然缺失。当试图在数学中对一个证明进行完全形式化时，这种极端情况就有所体现：通过更严格地消除歧义，准确性有所提高，但清晰度和可理解性却有所下降。123

Even among mathematicians an argument which seems entirely convincing to one person may not even be comprehensible to another.122 Hence the striving to remove any occasion for the exercise of personal judgment by a strict formalization of the deductive sciences; a striving which can now be seen to aim at defeating itself. For the meaning of a formalism lies in our subsidiary awareness of it within a conceptual focus sustained in terms of this formalism, and is necessarily absent therefore in operations carried out on symbols seen quite impersonally, as objects. This limiting case is adumbrated when the complete formalization of a proof is attempted in mathematics: the gain in exactitude, resulting from a stricter elimination of ambiguities, is accompanied by a loss in clarity and intelligibility.123

我曾指出，符号的形式操作传达了逻辑蕴涵的概念，就像“猫”这个词传达了猫的概念一样。然而，尽管数学证明所指的主题不如猫那么具体，但证明的作用远不止指代其主题：它实现了主题。随着语言的第二个操作原则的启动，我们从符号的生成转向了形式过程的设计，这个过程首先构思出它接下来要传达的内容。这种构思以建立特定蕴涵并使其被接受的特定目的为指导。它认可这一目的值得付出巨大努力，并为实现这一目的的方式设定了经济性和美观性的标准。​​我们在这里看到的是一系列比命名经验中反复出现的特征更为复杂的目的性行为；严格来说，这是一种精妙的发明，是一种语言操作。

I have suggested that the formal operation of symbols conveys the conception of a logical entailment, even as the word ‘cat’ conveys the conception of a cat. But while the subject-matter denoted by a mathematical proof is less tangible than a cat, a proof does more than denote its subject matter: it brings it about. As the second operational principle of language is set in motion, we pass on from the making of signs to the devising of a formal process, which first contrives what it subsequently conveys. This contriving is guided by the specific purpose of establishing a particular implication and compelling its acceptance. It endorses this purpose as worthy of a great effort, and sets up standards of economy and beauty for the manner of its achievement. We have here a far more elaborate sequence of purposive actions than that involved in the naming of recurrent features of experience; it is a linguistic operation in the stricter sense of an ingenious contrivance.

 

 

  1. 问题解决简介
  2. INTRODUCTION TO PROBLEM-SOLVING

任何完全清醒的动物都无法摆脱一种目的性张力。这种张力在于随时准备感知和行动，或者更笼统地说，在于随时准备在理智和实践上理解自身处境。从这些为保持对自身和周围环境的控制而进行的日常努力中，我们可以看到一个解决问题的过程的出现，而这种努力往往会分为两个阶段：第一阶段是困惑，第二阶段是行动和感知，最终消除这种困惑。

There is a purposive tension from which no fully awake animal is free. It consists in a readiness to perceive and to act, or more generally speaking, to make sense of its own situation, both intellectually and practically. From these routine efforts to retain control of itself and of its surroundings, we can see emerging a process of problem solving, when the effort tends to fall into two stages, a first stage of perplexity, followed by a second stage of doing and perceiving which dispels this perplexity.

如果动物的困惑持续了一段时间，并且它显然在试图找到解决困扰它的情境的答案，我们就可以说它看到了问题。在这样做的过程中，动物是在寻找情境中隐藏的方面，它推测这些方面存在，而情境中明显的特征可以作为尝试性的线索或工具，帮助它找到或实现这些方面。

We may say that the animal has seen a problem, if its perplexity lasts for some time and it is clearly trying to find a solution to the situation which puzzles it. In doing so, the animal is searching for a hidden aspect of the situation, the existence of which it surmises, and for the finding or achieving of which the manifest features of the situation serve it as tentative clues or instruments.

发现问题无疑会丰富知识，就像发现一棵树，发现一个数学证明，或者一个笑话一样。它是一种推测，其真伪取决于它所假设的隐藏可能性是否真的存在。认识到一个可以解决且值得解决的问题，本身就是一种发现。著名的数学难题代代相传，留下了一系列由解决这些问题的尝试所激发的成就。即使在动物实验中，我们也可以看到心理学家向动物展示问题的存在，以便引导它去寻找解决方案。一只放在辨别箱里的老鼠被引导去意识到食物藏在两个隔间中的一个隔间里，这两个隔间都可以拿到。只有当它意识到这一点时，它才会开始寻找能够区分后面有食物的门或屏风和空隔间的东西。同样，动物们除非意识到迷宫中有一条路径，并且在出口处有奖励，否则不会主动开始探索。在科勒的洞察力实验中，他的黑猩猩从一开始就抓住了它们的问题，并通过安静地集中注意力来表达它们对任务的欣赏。

To see a problem is a definite addition to knowledge, as much as it is to see a tree, or to see a mathematical proof—or a joke. It is a surmise which can be true or false, depending on whether the hidden possibilities of which it assumes the existence do actually exist or not. To recognize a problem which can be solved and is worth solving is in fact a discovery in its own right. Famous mathematical problems have descended from generation to generation, leaving in their wake a long trail of achievements stimulated by the attempt at solving them. And even at the level of animal experiments, we can see the psychologist demonstrating to the animal the presence of a problem in order to start it off in search of a solution. A rat in a discrimination box is made to realize that there is food hidden in one of two compartments, both of which are accessible, and only if it has grasped this will it start searching for something which discriminates the door or screen with food behind it from that of the empty compartment. Similarly, animals will not start solving a maze unless they are made aware of the fact that there exists a path through it, with some reward at its outlet. In Köhler’s insight experiments his chimpanzees grasped their problem from the start, and marked their appreciation of the task by composing themselves quietly to concentrate on it.

意外事故通常在发现中扮演着一定的角色，甚至可能占据主导地位。学习实验可以这样安排：在缺乏清晰理解的问题的情况下，发现只能是偶然的。124设计此类实验的机械主义心理学家会将所有学习解释为随机行为的幸运结果。这种学习概念也构成了控制论模型的基础，该模型认为机器通过选择在一系列随机试验中被证明有效的“习惯”来“学习”。现在我将忽略这种启发式模型，继续探索源于智能努力的发现过程，而不论为此提出了何种神经模型。

Accident usually plays some part in discovery and its part may be predominant. Learning experiments can be so arranged that, in the absence of any clearly understood problem, discovery can only be accidental.124 Mechanistically minded psychologists who devise such experiments would explain all learning as the lucky outcome of random behaviour. This conception of learning underlies also the cyberneticist model of a machine which ‘learns’ by selecting the ‘habit’ which had proved successful in a series of random trials. I shall disregard now this model of heuristics, and continue to explore the process of discovery resulting from intelligent effort, irrespective of the neural model that may be proposed for it.

动物中，智慧解决问题的能力最有效地体现在科勒对黑猩猩的实验中。黑猩猩的行为已经展现出庞加莱认为数学发现的典型阶段。我已经提到了第一个阶段：对问题的理解。一只被关在笼子里的黑猩猩，它既能看到一串香蕉，又够不着，既不会徒劳地用武力去抓，也不会放弃获得香蕉的渴望。相反，它会异常平静地安顿下来，用眼睛环顾目标周围的情况；它已经意识到情况存在问题，并正在寻找解决方案。125 我们可以承认这一点（使用基于庞加莱的瓦拉斯的术语）作为准备阶段。126

Intelligent problem-solving is manifested among animals most effectively in Köhler’s experiments on chimpanzees, whose behaviour already presents the characteristic stages through which, according to Poincaré, discovery is achieved in mathematics. I have already mentioned the first: the appreciation of a problem. A chimpanzee in a cage within sight of a bunch of bananas out of its reach neither makes any futile effort to get hold of it by sheer force, nor abandons its desire of acquiring the prize. It settles down instead to an unusual calm, while its eyes survey the situation all round the target; it has recognized the situation as problematical and is searching for a solution.125 We may acknowledge this (using the terminology of Wallas based on Poincaré) as the stage of Preparation.126

在科勒观察到的最引人注目的洞察案例中，这一准备阶段之后会突然出现理智的行动。动物会突然打破平静，开始实施一项策略，以确保其目标，或至少表明它已掌握了实现目标的原则。它毫不犹豫的态度表明，它对整个拟议行动有着清晰的概念。这一概念就是它的发现，或者至少是它的初步发现——因为它并不总是可行的。我们可以将这一阶段视为启蒙阶段。由于洞察发现的原则的实际实现往往会带来甚至无法克服的困难，因此，动物将其洞察付诸实践的检验操作可以被视为验证阶段。

In the most striking cases of insight observed by Köhler, this preparatory stage is suddenly followed by intelligent action. Sharply breaking its calm, the animal proceeds to carry out a stratagem by which it secures its aim, or at least shows that it has grasped a principle by which this can be done. Its unhesitating manner suggests that it is guided by a clear conception of the whole proposed operation. This conception is its discovery, or at least—since it may not always prove practicable—its tentative discovery. We may recognize in its coming the stage of Illumination. Since the practical realization of the principle discovered by insight often presents difficulties which may even prove insurmountable, the manipulations by which the animal puts his insight to the test of practical realization may be regarded as the stage of Verification.

实际上，庞加莱观察到了发现的四个阶段：准备、孵化、启发、验证。127但第二种行为，即孵化，在黑猩猩身上仅能观察到其雏形。然而，科勒详细描述的观察结果显示，他的一只黑猩猩即使在忙于其他事情一段时间后，仍能持续努力解决问题。128在很大程度上预测了孵化过程：启发式张力在很长一段时间内奇怪地持续存在，在此期间问题并没有被有意识地考虑。

Actually, Poincaré observed four stages of discovery: Preparation, Incubation, Illumination, Verification.127 But the second of these, Incubation, can be observed only in a rudimentary form in chimpanzees. Yet the observation described in some detail by Köhler, in which one of his animals sustained its effort of solving a problem even while otherwise occupied for a time,128 anticipates to a remarkable extent the process of incubation: that curious persistence of heuristic tension through long periods of time, during which the problem is not consciously entertained.

全身心投入一个问题会造成情绪紧张，而从中解脱出来的发现则令人欣喜。阿基米德从浴室冲出，跑到锡拉丘兹的街道上高喊“尤里卡”（Eureka）的故事就是明证；我引用了科勒关于他研究的黑猩猩在解决问题前后行为的描述，表明它们也会体验到这种情绪。稍后我将更明确地阐述这一点。我现在提到这一点，只是为了明确一点：任何事情本身都不是问题或发现；只有当它使人困惑和担忧时，它才是一个问题；只有当它能将人从问题的负担中解脱出来时，它才是一个发现。一个国际象棋难题对黑猩猩或低能儿来说毫无意义，因此不会让他们感到困惑；另一方面，一位伟大的国际象棋大师可能不会被它困扰，因为他毫不费力就找到了解决方案；只有能力与问题相当的棋手，才会对它产生强烈的专注。只有这样的玩家才会将其解决方案视为一种发现。 129

An extensive preoccupation with a problem imposes an emotional strain, and a discovery which releases from it is a great joy. The story of Archimedes rushing out from his bath into the streets of Syracuse shouting ‘Eureka’ is a witness to this; and the account I have quoted from Köhler, of the way his chimpanzees behaved before and after solving a problem, suggests that they also experience such emotions. I shall show this more definitely later. I mention it now only to make it clear that nothing is a problem or discovery in itself; it can be a problem only if it puzzles and worries somebody, and a discovery only if it relieves somebody from the burden of a problem. A chess problem means nothing to a chimpanzee or to an imbecile, and hence does not puzzle them; a great chess master on the other hand may fail to be puzzled by it because he finds its solution without effort; only a player whose ability is about equal to the problem will find intense preoccupation in it. Only such a player will appreciate its solution as a discovery.129

评估一个问题的相对难度，并通过受试者解决一定难度问题的能力来测试他们的智力，似乎是可能的。科勒设计了一系列问题，成功地评估了黑猩猩的智力和某些问题的难度。他的一些猿猴经过一些努力就能解决这些问题，而其他一些则通常完全无法解决。耶基斯成功地向蚯蚓设置了问题（这些蚯蚓经过大约一百次尝试就能解决），这表明他甚至可以评估蚯蚓所需的极低的智力水平。130填字游戏专栏的编辑们也同样擅长为读者提供源源不断、难度始终相同的问题。我们可以得出这样的结论：虽然某个问题对于某些人来说总是会被看作是一个问题，但观察者能够准确地识别出，对于可识别的人来说，它就是一个问题。

It appears possible to appraise the comparative hardness of a problem, and to test the intelligence of subjects by their capacity for solving problems of a certain degree of hardness. The intelligence of chimpanzees and the hardness of certain problems were both successfully assessed by Köhler when he devised a series of problems, which some of his apes could solve with some effort while others among them usually failed altogether to do so. The success of Yerkes in setting problems to earthworms (which these could solve after about a hundred trials), shows that he could assess even such extremely low powers of intelligence as were required here from the earthworm.130 Editors of a crossword column undertake a similar feat in supplying their readers with a steady stream of always equally difficult problems. We may conclude that while a problem must always be regarded as being a problem to some kind of person, it is possible for an observer reliably to recognize it as such in respect to identifiable persons.

如果将一只已经解决问题的动物再次置于原始情境中，它会毫不犹豫地运用它最初花费大量精力甚至可能经过多次失败尝试才发现的解决方案。这表明，通过解决问题，动物获得了新的智力，这使得它不再被问题困扰。相反，它现在可以以常规的方式处理这种情况，无需任何启发式张力，也无需做出任何发现。对它来说，问题已不复存在。启发式进展是不可逆的。

If an animal who has solved a problem is placed once more in the original situation, it proceeds unhesitatingly to apply the solution which it had originally discovered at the cost of much effort and perhaps after many unsuccessful trials. This shows that by solving the problem the animal has acquired a new intellectual power, which prevents it from being ever again puzzled by the problem. Instead, it can now deal with the situation in a routine manner involving no heuristic tension and achieving no discovery. The problem has ceased to exist for it. Heuristic progress is irreversible.

发现的不可逆性意味着，如果一个问题的解决是通过遵循明确规则的程序实现的，那么它就不能被认定为发现。因为这样的程序是可逆的，因为它可以逐步追溯到起点，并像任何算术计算一样随意重复任意次数。因此，任何严格形式化的程序也将被排除在发现的途径之外。

The irreversible character of discovery suggests that no solution of a problem can be accredited as a discovery if it is achieved by a procedure following definite rules. For such a procedure would be reversible in the sense that it could be traced back stepwise to its beginning and repeated at will any number of times, like any arithmetical computation. Accordingly, any strictly formalized procedure would also be excluded as a means of achieving discovery.

由此可见，真正的发现并非严格意义上的逻辑实践，因此，我们可以将解决问题时需要克服的障碍描述为“逻辑鸿沟”，并将逻辑鸿沟的宽度视为解决问题所需智慧的衡量标准。“启迪”便是跨越逻辑鸿沟的飞跃。这是我们在现实彼岸站稳脚跟的一次冒险。科学家必须将自己的整个职业生涯一点一点地押注于这样的冒险之中。

It follows that true discovery is not a strictly logical performance, and accordingly, we may describe the obstacle to be overcome in solving a problem as a ‘logical gap’, and speak of the width of the logical gap as the measure of the ingenuity required for solving the problem. ‘Illumination’ is then the leap by which the logical gap is crossed. It is the plunge by which we gain a foothold at another shore of reality. On such plunges the scientist has to stake bit by bit his entire professional life.

发明人跨越的逻辑差距的宽度取决于法律评估。法院需要判断一项建议的技术改进所展现的独创性是否足以使其获得法律认可为一项发明，还是仅仅是通过应用现有技术规则实现的例行改进。必须承认该发明具有不可预测性，其性质的评估标准是它可能合理地引起的意外程度。这种意外性恰恰对应于发明人出发的先前知识与他随后获得的发现之间存在的逻辑差距。

The width of the logical gap crossed by an inventor is subject to legal assessment. Courts of law are called upon to decide whether the ingenuity displayed in a suggested technical improvement is high enough to warrant its legal recognition as an invention, or is merely a routine improvement, achieved by the application of known rules of the art. The invention must be acknowledged to be unpredictable, a quality which is assessed by the intensity of the surprise it might reasonably have aroused. This unexpectedness corresponds precisely to the presence of a logical gap between the antecedent knowledge from which the inventor started and the consequent discovery at which he arrived.

既定的推理规则为公众提供了从现有知识中得出明智结论的途径。那些通过跨越逻辑鸿沟得出独特结论的先驱者，偏离了普遍接受的推理过程，取得了令人意想不到的成果。这种行为之所以具有原创性，是因为它开辟了新的起点，而开创这种起点的能力正是原创性的天赋，而这种天赋只属于少数人。

Established rules of inference offer public paths for drawing intelligent conclusions from existing knowledge. The pioneer mind which reaches its own distinctive conclusions by crossing a logical gap deviates from the commonly accepted process of reasoning, to achieve surprising results. Such an act is original in the sense of making a new start, and the capacity for initiating it is the gift of originality, a gift possessed by a small minority.

自浪漫主义运动以来，独创性日益被视为一种与生俱来的天赋，唯有它才能使人开启一项重要的创新。如今，大学和工业研究实验室都建立在聘用具有独创性思维的人才的基础上。那些被​​誉为独创性的年轻科学家被授予永久职位，期望他们终其一生都能不断提出令人惊喜的想法。

Since the Romantic movement originality has become increasingly recognized as a native endowment which alone enables a person to initiate an essential innovation. Universities and industrial research laboratories are founded today on the employment of persons with original minds. Permanent appointments are given to young scientists who are credited with signs of originality, in the expectation that they will continue to produce surprising ideas for the rest of their lives.

无可否认，普通智力能力范围内存在一些细微的启发式行为，这些行为实际上与生命直至最低水平的适应能力相一致。我们已经看到，每当我们与现实接触（或认为我们已经接触）时，我们都会预期未来会有一系列意想不到的、能够证实我们由此获得的知识的事物。受过教育的头脑的解释框架总是准备好迎接一些新奇的体验，并以一些新奇的方式处理它们。从这个意义上说，所有生命都具有独创性，而更高层次的独创性只不过是普遍的生物适应性的放大形式。但天才与现实的接触范围异常广泛：他能够洞察问题，并探索解决问题的隐藏可能性，这远远超出了现有观念的预见能力。此外，通过以非凡的程度——远远超越我们这些旁观者——运用这种能力，天才的作品向我们展现了一种创造力的巨大力量，这种创造力既无法用其他术语来解释，也无法被毫无疑问地视为理所当然。通过尊重他人的判断，认为其优于我们自己的判断，我们强调承认了其独创性，这种独创性体现在我们无法具体说明其过程的表演中。因此，与天才的对抗迫使我们承认生命的原创力，而我们可能，而且常常，在其普遍存在的、低级的表现形式中，忽视了这种力量。

Admittedly, there are minor heuristic acts within the power of ordinary intelligence which are indeed continuous with the adaptive capacities of life down to its lowest levels. We have seen already that whenever we make (or believe we have made) contact with reality, we anticipate an indeterminate range of unexpected future confirmations of our knowledge derived from this contact. The interpretative framework of the educated mind is ever ready to meet somewhat novel experiences, and to deal with them in a somewhat novel manner. In this sense all life is endowed with originality and originality of a higher order is but a magnified form of a universal biological adaptivity. But genius makes contact with reality on an exceptionally wide range: seeing problems and reaching out to hidden possibilities for solving them, far beyond the anticipatory powers of current conceptions. Moreover, by deploying such powers in an exceptional measure—far surpassing ours who are looking on—the work of a genius offers us a massive demonstration of a creativity which can neither be explained in other terms, nor taken unquestioningly for granted. By paying respect to another person’s judgment as superior to our own, we emphatically acknowledge originality in the sense of a performance the procedure of which we cannot specify. Confrontation with genius thus forces us to acknowledge the originative power of life, which we may and commonly do neglect in its ubiquitous lesser manifestations.

在选择问题时，研究人员做出了充满风险的决定。任务可能难以解决，或者难度过高。在这种情况下，他的努力将被浪费，他的合作伙伴的努力以及整个项目所花费的资金也将付诸东流。但谨慎行事也可能同样浪费。平庸的结果不足以弥补高昂天赋的投入，甚至可能无法补偿为实现这些成果所花费的资金。因此，问题的选择不仅要预见到隐藏但并非不可触及的事物，还要根据任务的预期难度来评估研究人员自身（以及其合作伙伴）的能力，并合理地猜测所期望的解决方案是否值得其在人才、劳动和金钱方面的付出。对尚不清楚的、可能导致未知结果的预期程序的近似可行性进行此类评估，是任何从事独立科学或技术研究的人的日常职责。基于此，他甚至必须比较许多不同的可能方案，并从中选择最有希望攻克的问题。但我相信经验表明这种性能是可能的，并且可以依靠它以相当高的可靠性运行。

In choosing a problem the investigator takes a decision fraught with risks. The task may be insoluble or just too difficult. In that case his effort will be wasted and with it the effort of his collaborators, as well as the money spent on the whole project. But to play safe may be equally wasteful. Mediocre results are no adequate return for the employment of high gifts, and may not even repay the money spent on achieving them. So the choice of a problem must not only anticipate something that is hidden and yet not inaccessible, but also assess the investigator’s own ability (and those of his collaborators) against the anticipated hardness of the task, and make a reasonable guess as to whether the hoped for solution will be worth its price in terms of talent, labour and money. To form such estimates of the approximate feasibility of yet unknown prospective procedures, leading to unknown prospective results, is the day-to-day responsibility of anyone undertaking independent scientific or technical research. On such grounds as these he must even compare a number of different possible suggestions and select from them for attack the most promising problem. Yet I believe that experience shows such a performance to be possible and that it can be relied upon to function with a considerable degree of reliability.

 

 

12.数学启发法

12. MATHEMATICAL HEURISTICS

有三个主要的知识领域可以进行发现：自然科学、技术和数学。我引用了每个领域的例子来说明引导发现的预见性力量。这三个领域的预见性力量显然非常相似。然而，哲学家们的努力几乎全部集中在自然科学的基础——经验发现过程上——即试图定义和证明归纳过程。相比之下，似乎没有人尝试定义和证明技术创新的过程，例如新机器的发明过程。数学中的发现过程曾受到一些关注，最近也受到了来自逻辑和心理学角度的攻击，但这两种方法都没有提出任何与几个世纪以来在经验归纳方面所孜孜以求的问题类似的认识论问题。在我看来，任何认真分析发现过程的尝试都应该具有足够的普遍性，能够适用于所有三个系统知识领域。我希望通过识别和认可我们解决数学问题所依赖的力量，为这一纲领做出贡献。我暂时不讨论那些涉及数学基础修改的重大发现的历史，而只关注在教授数学时向学生提出的那种问题。由于这些问题的答案并不为学生所知，因此，即使它不涉及观念的根本性转变，寻找答案的过程也带有发现的痕迹。

There are three major fields of knowledge in which discoveries are possible: natural science, technology and mathematics. I have referred to examples from each of these fields to illustrate the anticipatory powers which guide discovery. These are clearly quite similar in all three cases. Yet the efforts of philosophers have been almost wholly concentrated on the process of empirical discovery which underlies the natural sciences—i.e. on an attempt to define and justify the process of induction, while by contrast, nobody seems to have tried to define and justify the process by which technical innovations are made, as for example when a new machine is invented. The process of discovery in mathematics had received some attention, and has recently been attacked both from the logical and psychological point of view, but neither approach has raised any epistemological questions parallel to those so sedulously pursued for centuries in connection with empirical induction. It seems to me that any serious attempt to analyse the process of discovery should be sufficiently general to apply to all three fields of systematic knowledge, and I should like to contribute to this programme here by identifying and acknowledging the powers on which we rely in solving mathematical problems. I shall exclude for the moment the history of major discoveries which involve modifications in the foundations of mathematics and shall attend only to the type of problems that are set to students in teaching them mathematics. Since the solution of these problems is not known to the student, the process of finding it bears the marks of a discovery, even though it involves no fundamental change of outlook.

数学教学很大程度上依赖于实践，这一事实表明，即使是这一高度形式化的知识分支，也只有通过培养一门艺术才能获得。这不仅适用于数学和形式逻辑，也同样适用于所有数学科学，例如力学、电动力学、热力学以及工程学的数学分支；如果不解决其中的具体问题，你就无法掌握任何一门学科。在所有这些情况下，你所追求的技能是将你迄今为止仅仅接受吸收的语言转化为处理新学科的有效工具——尤其是在数学领域，用于解决问题。

The fact that the teaching of mathematics relies to a large extent on practice shows that even this most highly formalized branch of knowledge can be acquired only by developing an art. This is true not only of mathematics and formal logic, but equally also of all mathematical sciences, like mechanics, electrodynamics, thermodynamics and the mathematical branches of engineering; you cannot master any of these subjects without working out concrete problems in them. The skill you strive for in all these cases is that of converting a language, which you so far had assimilated only receptively, into an effective tool for handling new subjects—and more particularly in mathematics, for solving problems.

由于数学问题的解决是一种跨越逻辑鸿沟的启发式行为，因此任何可以制定的指导规则都只能是模糊的格言，其解释必须依赖于它们所适用的艺术本身。我们将会看到，事实确实如此。 131

Since the solving of mathematical problems is a heuristic act which leaps across a logical gap, any rules that can be laid down for its guidance can be but vague maxims, the interpretation of which must rely on the very art to which they apply. We shall see that such is indeed the case.131

最简单的启发式尝试就是寻找你遗失的物品。当我寻找我的钢笔时，我知道我会找到什么；我可以说出它的名字并描述它。虽然我对钢笔的了解远超我的记忆，但我却不知道它究竟落在哪里；但我清楚地认识这支钢笔，而且我也知道它在某个地区的某个地方，尽管我不知道具体位置。当我在填字游戏中寻找一个合适的单词时，我对要找的东西的了解就少得多。这次，我只知道缺失的单词有一定数量的字母，并且代表着，例如，撒哈拉沙漠急需的东西，或者从中央烟囱里流出的东西。这些特征仅仅是我绝对不认识的单词的线索：我必须从这些线索中推断出这个未知单词可能是什么。同样，一个我很熟悉但一时想不起的名字，介于这两种情况之间。它比填字游戏的未知答案更贴近我的心境，但或许比失落的钢笔及其未知的下落更不贴近我的心境。数学问题属于填字游戏的范畴，因为要解决这类问题，我们必须找到（或构建）一些我们从未见过的东西，并以给定的数据作为线索。

The simplest heuristic effort is to search for an object you have mislaid. When I am looking for my fountain pen I know what I expect to find; I can name it and describe it. Though I know much more about my fountain pen than I can ever recall, I do not know exactly where I left it; but the pen is clearly known to me and I know also that it is somewhere within a certain region though I do not know where. I have much less knowledge of the thing I am looking for when I am searching for a word to fit into a crossword puzzle. This time I know only that the missing word has a certain number of letters and designates, for example, something that is badly needed in the Sahara or flows out of a central chimney. These characteristics are merely clues to a word that I definitely do not know: clues from which I must try to gain an intimation of what the unknown word may be. Again, a name which I know well but cannot recall at the moment, lies somewhere halfway between these two cases. It is more closely present to my mind than the unknown solution of a crossword puzzle, but less closely perhaps than the mislaid fountain pen and its unknown location. Mathematical problems are in the class of crossword puzzles, for to solve such a problem we must find (or construct) something that we have never seen before, with the given data serving us as clues to it.

一个问题或许可以系统地解决。通过一点一点地翻遍我的公寓，我最终或许能找到我的钢笔，我知道它就藏在里面的某个地方。我或许可以通过机械地尝试所有可能的走法和反走法的组合来解决一个国际象棋问题。系统方法也适用于许多数学问题，尽管它们通常过于费力，难以在实践中实施。132显然，任何此类系统操作都会在不跨越逻辑鸿沟的情况下得出解决方案，并且不会构成启发式行为。 133

A problem may admit of a systematic solution. By ransacking my flat inch by inch, I may make sure of eventually finding my fountain pen which I know to be somewhere in it. I might solve a chess problem by trying out mechanically all combinations of possible moves and countermoves. Systematic methods apply also to many mathematical problems, though usually they are far too laborious to be carried out in practice.132 It is clear that any such systematic operation would reach a solution without crossing a logical gap and would not constitute a heuristic act.133

系统化和启发式这两种问题解决方式的区别在于：系统化操作完全是经过深思熟虑的行为，而启发式过程则由主动和被动阶段组成。经过深思熟虑的启发式活动是在准备阶段进行的。如果之后是孵化期，那么在此期间，意识层面什么也不会发生，什么也不会发生。一个快乐想法的出现（无论是紧接着准备阶段还是在孵化期之后）是研究者前期努力的成果，但其本身并非研究者的行为；它只是偶然发生在他身上。同样，通过先前的验证过程来检验“快乐想法”也是研究者的另一项深思熟虑的行为。即便如此，决定性的发现行为必须在此之前发生，在快乐想法浮现的那一刻。

The difference between the two kinds of problem solving, the systematic and the heuristic, reappears in the fact that while a systematic operation is a wholly deliberate act, a heuristic process is a combination of active and passive stages. A deliberate heuristic activity is performed during the stage of Preparation. If this is followed by a period of Incubation, nothing is done and nothing happens on the level of consciousness during this time. The advent of a happy thought (whether following immediately from Preparation or only after an interval of Incubation) is the fruit of the investigator’s earlier efforts, but not in itself an action on his part; it just happens to him. And again, the testing of the ‘happy thought’ by a former process of Verification is another deliberate action of the investigator. Even so, the decisive act of discovery must have occurred before this, at the moment when the happy thought emerged.

尽管问题的答案是我们从未遇到过的，但在启发式过程中，它所扮演的角色，类似于我们熟知的遗失的钢笔或被遗忘的名字。我们寻找它，仿佛它就在那里，预先存在。当然，学生们所面对的问题都有答案；但相信存在一个我们或许能够找到的隐藏答案，在设想和解决一个从未解决的问题时，也同样至关重要。它也决定了“快乐的想法”最终如何呈现为某种内在满足感。它并非众多可供闲暇思考的想法之一，而是一个从一开始就令人信服的想法。稍后，通过对这一过程的更深入分析，我们将看到，这是启发式努力激发自身满足感的必然结果。问题是一种智识欲望（用K.Lewin的术语来说，是“准需求”），像所有欲望一样，它预设了某种能够满足它的东西的存在；对于一个问题来说，它的满足点就是它的解决方案。正如所有欲望都会激发想象力去思考如何满足它，而反过来，它又会被它所培育的想象力所激发。同样，对一个问题产生兴趣，我们也会开始思考它可能的解决方案，并因此更加专注于这个问题。

Though the solution of a problem is something we have never met before, yet in the heuristic process it plays a part similar to the mislaid fountain pen or the forgotten name which we know quite well. We are looking for it as if it were there, pre-existent. Problems set to students are of course known to have a solution; but the belief that there exists a hidden solution which we may be able to find is essential also in envisaging and working at a never yet solved problem. It determines also the manner in which the ‘happy thought’ eventually presents itself as something inherently satisfying. It is not one among a great many ideas to be pondered upon at leisure, but one which carries conviction from the start. We shall see in a moment, from a closer analysis of this process, that this is a necessary consequence of the way a heuristic striving evokes its own consummation. A problem is an intellectual desire (a ‘quasi-need’ in K.Lewin’s terminology) and like every desire it postulates the existence of something that can satisfy it; in the case of a problem its satisfier is its solution. As all desire stimulates the imagination to dwell on the means of satisfying it, and is stirred up in its turn by the play of the imagination it has fostered, so also by taking interest in a problem we start speculating about its possible solution and in doing so become further engrossed in the problem.

事实上，对自身问题的执着正是一切创造力的源泉。学生们曾开玩笑地问大师，如何才能成为“巴甫洛夫”，大师一本正经地回答道：“早上起床，问题摆在眼前。早餐，问题摆在眼前。去实验室，问题摆在眼前。晚餐，问题摆在眼前。睡觉，问题摆在脑海里。梦见它。”134正是这种对问题的不懈专注，赋予了天才们那众所周知的承受无限痛苦的能力。我们对问题的专注程度，也赋予了我们成功重组思绪的力量，无论是在探索的过程中，还是之后的休息时间。135

Obsession with one’s problem is in fact the mainspring of all inventive power. Asked by his pupils in jest what they should do to become ‘a Pavlov’, the master answered in all seriousness: ‘Get up in the morning with your problem before you. Breakfast with it. Go to the laboratory with it. Eat your lunch with it. Keep it before you after dinner. Go to bed with it in your mind. Dream about it.’134 It is this unremitting preoccupation with his problem that lends to genius its proverbial capacity for taking infinite pains. And the intensity of our preoccupation with a problem generates also our power for reorganizing our thoughts successfully, both during the hours of search and afterwards, during a period of rest.135

但这种全神贯注的目的究竟是什么？我们如何才能将注意力集中在我们未知的事物上？然而，这正是我们被教导要做的：“放眼未知！”——波利亚说道——“放眼终点。牢记你的目标。不要忘记你所需要的。牢记你为何而努力。放眼未知。放眼结论。”136没有比这更强烈的建议了。

But what is the object of this intensive preoccupation? How can we concentrate our attention on something we don’t know? Yet this is precisely what we are told to do: ‘Look at the unknown!’—says Polya— ‘Look at the end. Remember your aim. Do not lose sight of what is required. Keep in mind what you are working for. Look at the unknown. Look at the conclusion.’136 No advice could be more emphatic.

这个看似矛盾的论点，其实是这样的：即使我们从未遇到过解决方案，我们对它的概念，就像我们对一个被遗忘的名字的概念一样。通过将注意力集中在一个焦点上，我们辅助性地意识到所有让我们想起被遗忘的名字的细节，我们便形成了对它的概念；同样，通过将注意力集中在一个焦点上，我们辅助性地意识到决定问题解决方案的数据，我们便形成了对这个解决方案的概念。“审视未知”的劝诫，实际上意味着我们应该审视已知数据，但并非将其本身，而是将其视为通往未知的线索；将其视为指向未知及其组成部分的指针。我们应该坚持不懈地探索，以理解这些已知细节如何相互关联，以及它们与未知之间的联系。通过这样的暗示，我们确信未知确实存在，本质上由已知的信息决定，并且能够满足问题对它提出的所有要求。

The seeming paradox is resolved by the fact that even though we have never met the solution, we have a conception of it in the same sense as we have a conception of a forgotten name. By directing our attention on a focus in which we are subsidiarily aware of all the particulars that remind us of the forgotten name, we form a conception of it; and likewise, by fixing our attention on a focus in which we are subsidiarily aware of the data by which the solution of a problem is determined, we form a conception of this solution. The admonition to look at the unknown really means that we should look at the known data, but not in themselves, rather as clues to the unknown; as pointers to it and parts of it. We should strive persistently to feel our way towards an understanding of the manner in which these known particulars hang together, both mutually and with the unknown. By such intimations do we make sure that the unknown is really there, essentially determined by what is known about it, and able to satisfy all the demands made on it by the problem.

我们所有的概念都具有启发能力；它们总是随时准备通过自我修改来识别新的经验实例，从而将其纳入其中。技能的实践是创造性的；通过将目标集中在取得成功上，我们就能不断激发自身的新能力。问题兼具这两种努力。它是我们对某种正在努力实现的事物的概念。它是一种跨越逻辑鸿沟的理智渴望，在鸿沟的另一边存在着未知，它完全由我们对它的理解所标记，尽管我们从未见过它本身。寻找解决方案在于牢记这一目标。为此，我们通过执行两个必须始终同时尝试的操作来实现。我们必须 (1) 用合适的符号表达问题，并不断重新组织其表示形式，以期引出一些新的具有启发性的方面；同时 (2) 在我们的记忆中搜寻任何已知解决方案的类似问题。137这两种操作的范围通常会受到学生以不同方式转换给定数据的技术能力，以及他所熟悉的相关定理范围的限制。但他的成功最终取决于他能否感知到问题条件、已知定理以及他所寻求的未知解之间存在的尚未揭示的逻辑关系。除非他不断探索，并有一种可靠的感觉，即越来越接近解，否则他将无法取得进展。即使遵循最佳的启发式规则，随意做出的猜测也将是极其无效且毫无意义的。

All our conceptions have heuristic powers; they are ever ready to identify novel instances of experience by modifying themselves so as to comprise them. The practice of skills is inventive; by concentrating our purpose on the achievement of success we evoke ever new capacities in ourselves. A problem partakes of both these types of endeavour. It is a conception of something we are striving for. It is an intellectual desire for crossing a logical gap on the other side of which lies the unknown, fully marked out by our conception of it, though as yet never seen in itself. The search for a solution consists in casting about with this purpose in mind. This we do by performing two operations which must always be tried jointly. We must (1) set out the problem in suitable symbols and continuously reorganize its representation with a view to eliciting some new suggestive aspects of it, and concurrently (2) ransack our memory for any similar problem of which the solution is known.137 The scope of these two operations will usually be limited by the student’s technical facility for transforming the given data in different ways, and by the range of germane theorems with which he is acquainted. But his success will depend ultimately on his capacity for sensing the presence of yet unrevealed logical relations between the conditions of the problem, the theorems known to him, and the unknown solution he is looking for. Unless his casting about is guided by a reliable sense of growing proximity to the solution, he will make no progress towards it. Conjectures made at random, even though following the best rules of heuristics, would be hopelessly inept and totally fruitless.

因此，解决数学问题的过程在每个阶段都依赖于同样的能力，即预测隐藏的潜力，这种能力使学生能够首先发现问题，然后着手解决它。波利亚将一项由一系列连续步骤组成的数学发现比作一座拱门，拱门中每块石头的稳定性都依赖于其他石头的存在，并指出了一个悖论：石头实际上是一次放一块进去的。同样，这个悖论的解决方式是，不完整解决方案的每个后续步骤都受到最初引发其发明的启发式预期的支持：通过这种感觉，即它的出现进一步缩小了问题的逻辑鸿沟。

The process of solving a mathematical problem continues to depend, therefore, at every stage on the same ability to anticipate a hidden potentiality which will enable the student first to see a problem and then to set out to solve it. Polya has compared a mathematical discovery consisting of a whole chain of consecutive steps with an arch, where every stone depends for its stability on the presence of others, and he pointed out the paradox that the stones are in fact put in one at a time. Again, the paradox is resolved by the fact that each successive step of the incomplete solution is upheld by the heuristic anticipation which originally evoked its invention: by the feeling that its emergence has narrowed further the logical gap of the problem.

正如我上面所说，当我们苦苦思索一个遗忘的名字时，通常会感受到越来越接近问题的答案。我们都经历过那种离那个缺失的单词越来越近的兴奋感，这种感觉我们可能会自信地说：“我马上就会想起它”，或许过一会儿还会说：“它就在我的舌尖上”。这些话语所表达的期待，往往会被最终的事件所证实。我认为，我们同样应该承认，我们既有能力感知从给定前提中隐含推论的可及性，也能够发明前提的变换，从而增加隐含推论的可及性。我们应该认识到，这种预知会使我们的猜测偏向正确的方向，从而使它们命中目标的概率（否则为零）变得如此之高，以至于我们可以仅仅凭借学生的智力就完全信赖它；或者，如果成绩更高，则可以凭借专业数学家所拥有的特殊天赋。

The growing sense of approaching to the solution of a problem can be commonly experienced, as I said above, when we grope for a forgotten name. We all know the exciting sense of increasing proximity to the missing word, which we may confidently express by saying: ‘I shall remember it in a moment’ and perhaps later ‘It is on the tip of my tongue’. The expectation expressed by such words is often confirmed by the event. I believe that we should likewise acknowledge our capacity both to sense the accessibility of a hidden inference from given premises, and to invent transformations of the premises which increase the accessibility of the hidden inference. We should recognize that this foreknowledge biasses our guesses in the right direction, so that their probability of hitting the mark, which would otherwise be zero, becomes so high that we can definitely rely on it simply on the ground of a student’s intelligence; or for higher performances, on the ground of the special gifts possessed by the professional mathematician.

感觉我们与问题解决方案之间的逻辑鸿沟缩小了，意味着解决问题所需的工作量会减少。这也可能意味着解决方案的其余部分会相对容易，或者经过一段时间的休整后，它可能会自然而然地浮现出来，无需我们付出任何努力。我们的智力追求在潜伏期无需付出任何努力就能取得有效进展，这与所有知识的潜在特性相符。正如我们不断地了解很多事情，却并非总是去思考它们一样，我们自然也会不断地渴望或害怕各种各样的事情，却并非总是去思考它们。我们知道，一个既定的目标可能会自动导致之后的行动，就像我们上床睡觉时下定决心要在某个时间醒来一样。催眠后暗示可以启动潜在的过程，这些过程会在几个小时后强制地导致受试者按照要求完成任务。138蔡加尼克女士表示，未完成的任务同样会在我们无意识中继续占据我们的注意力；即使我们忘记了已完成的任务，这些任务的记忆仍然会存在。139未完成任务所引发的紧张感会持续推进，最终实现目标。运动员的著名经验表明，高强度训练后进行一段时间的休息可以提高技能。在一段时间的静默之后，寻找一个被遗忘的名字或找到一个问题的答案，自然而然地取得成功，也与此经验相符。

The feeling that the logical gap separating us from the solution of a problem has been reduced, means that less work should remain to be done for solving it. It may also mean that the rest of the solution will be comparatively easy, or that it may present itself without further effort on our part, after a period of repose. The fact that our intellectual strivings make effective progress during a period of Incubation without any effort on our part is in line with the latent character of all knowledge. As we continuously know a great many things without always thinking of them, so we naturally also keep on desiring or fearing all manner of things without always thinking of them. We know how a set purpose may automatically result in action later on, as when we go to bed resolved to wake up at a certain hour. Post-hypnotic suggestions can set going latent processes which compulsively result after a number of hours in the performance requested of the subject.138 Mrs. Zeigarnik has shown that unfinished tasks continue likewise to preoccupy us unconsciously; their memory persists after finished tasks are forgotten.139 The fact that the tension set up by the unfinished task continues to make progress towards its fulfilment, is shown by the well known experience of athletes that a period of rest following on a spell of intensive training produces an improvement of skill. The spontaneous success of the search for a forgotten name or for the solution of a problem, after a period of quiescence, falls in line with this experience.

这些先决条件也解释了问题解决的最终成功是如何突然降临的。因为每一步——无论是自发的还是刻意的——都让我们更接近解决方案，增强了我们对解决方案即将到来预感，并促使我们更加集中精力弥补逻辑上的差距。因此，解决问题的最后阶段往往可以以一种自我加速的方式实现，最终的发现可能就在一瞬间降临到我们身上。

These antecedents explain also the manner in which the final success of problem solving will suddenly set in. For each step—whether spontaneous or contrived—that brings us nearer to the solution, increases our premonition of the solution’s proximity and brings a more concentrated effort to bear on a reduced logical gap. The last stage of the solution may therefore be frequently achieved in a self-accelerating manner and the final discovery may be upon us in a flash.

我说过，我们的启发式渴望就像我们的身体欲望一样，意味着存在某种东西，它具有满足

I have said that our heuristic cravings imply, like our bodily appetites, the existence of something which has the properties required to satisfy

我们，引导我们奋斗的暗示也表达了这种信念。但在这种情况下，我们渴望的满足者并不实际存在；它不是一个隐藏的物体，而是一个从未被构想出来的想法。我们希望，在解决问题的过程中，这个想法会突然出现，无论是突然出现还是一点一点出现；只有我们相信这个解决方案存在，我们才能满怀热情地寻找它，并从自身激发出探索性的步骤来发现它。因此，当它出现在我们对某种我们认为存在的东西的探索中时，发现，或所谓的发现，总是会带着它是真实的信念来到我们身边。它提前得到了激发它的启发式渴望的认可。

us, and that the intimations which guide our striving express this belief. But the satisfier of our craving has in this case no bodily existence; it is not a hidden object, but an idea never yet conceived. We hope that as we work at the problem this idea will come to us, whether all at once or bit by bit; and only if we believe that this solution exists can we passionately search for it and evoke from ourselves heuristic steps towards its discovery. Therefore, as it emerges in response to our search for something we believe to be there, discovery, or supposed discovery, will always come to us with the conviction of its being true. It arrives accredited in advance by the heuristic craving which evoked it.

最大胆的原创壮举仍然受制于这一法则：它们必须建立在这样的假设之上：它们并非源于任何事物，而仅仅是揭示存在的事物。它们的成功证实了这一假设，因为已发现的事物蕴含着尚未预见的含义，因此带有现实的印记。数学启发法虽然旨在不参考新经验进行概念重组，但它再次以其自身的方式证明了，一种智识的追求蕴含着对现实的预见性信念。它也说明了这种信念如何被最终的解决方案所证实，而最终的解决方案之所以“解决”，正是因为它成功地宣称揭示了现实的某个方面。我们还能再次看到，整个发现和确认的过程最终如何依赖于我们对自身现实观的认可。

The most daring feats of originality are still subject to this law: they must be performed on the assumption that they origina nothing, but merely reveal what is there. And their triumph confirms this assumption, for what has been found bears the mark of reality in being pregnant with yet unforeseeable implications. Mathematical heuristics, though aiming at conceptual reorganization without reference to new experience, once more exemplifies in its own terms that an intellectual striving entails its conviction of anticipating reality. It illustrates also how this conviction finds itself confirmed by the eventual solution, which ‘solves’ precisely because it successfully claims to reveal an aspect of reality. And we can see once more also, how the whole process of discovery and confirmation ultimately relies on our own accrediting of our own vision of reality.

要开始解决数学问题，我们会拿起纸笔，在整个准备阶段，我们会不断地在纸上用符号运算来尝试各种想法。如果这样做不能立即成功，我们可能需要重新思考整个问题，或许会在很久以后的顿悟时刻意外地发现答案。然而，实际上，这种瞬间的胜利通常不会带来最终的解决方案，而只是对一个尚未被检验的解决方案的设想。因此，在验证或推导出解决方案的过程中，我们必须再次依赖明确的符号运算。因此，解决问题的最初主动步骤和最终解决方案的获得都有效地依赖于计算和其他符号运算，而跨越逻辑鸿沟的非正式行为则介于这两个正式程序之间。然而，研究者的直觉能力始终占据主导地位，具有决定性作用。优秀的数学家通常能够快速可靠地进行计算，因为除非他们掌握了这种技巧，否则他们可能无法发挥自己的创造力——而他们的创造力本身就在于产生想法。阿达玛说，他过去在计算中犯的错误比他自己的学生还多，但他能更快地发现这些错误，因为结果看起来不对；这几乎就像他通过计算仅仅画出他在概念上预先确定的结论的肖像一样。 140高斯曾说过一句被广泛引用的话：“我很久以前就找到了答案，但我仍然不知道如何才能得到它们。” 虽然这句话可能存在疑问，但它仍然说得很好。141每当我们发现自认为是问题解决方案的东西时，这种情况肯定都会出现。那一刻，我们心中浮现出一个看似正确的解决方案，因此我们有信心证明它是正确的。142

To start working on a mathematical problem, we reach for pencil and paper, and throughout the stage of Preparation we keep trying out ideas on paper in terms of symbolic operations. If this does not lead straight to success, we may have to think the whole matter over again, and may perhaps see the solution revealed unexpectedly much later in a moment of Illumination. Actually, however, such a flash of triumph usually offers no final solution, but only the envisagement of a solution which has yet to be tested. In the verification or working out of the solution we must again rely therefore on explicit symbolic operations. Thus both the first active steps undertaken to solve a problem and the final garnering of the solution rely effectively on computations and other symbolic operations, while the more informal act by which the logical gap is crossed lies between these two formal procedures. However, the intuitive powers of the investigator are always dominant and decisive. Good mathematicians are usually found capable of carrying out computations quickly and reliably, for unless they command this technique they may fail to make their ingenuity effective—but their ingenuity itself lies in producing ideas. Hadamard says that he used to make more mistakes in calculation than his own pupils, but that he more quickly discovered them because the result did not look right; it is almost as if by his computations he had been merely drawing a portrait of his conceptually prefigured conclusions.140 Gauss is widely quoted as having said: ‘I have had my solutions for a long time but I do not yet know how I am to arrive at them.’ Though the quotation may be doubtful it remains well said.141 A situation of this kind certainly prevails every time we discover what we believe to be the solution to a problem. At that moment we have the vision of a solution which looks right and which we are therefore confident to prove right.142

数学家在探索的过程中，将自己的信心从直觉转向计算，再从计算转向直觉，同时始终不放弃对两者的把握，这种做法体现了表达规范和扩展人类推理能力的全部操作范围。这种转换是不对称的，因为形式化步骤只有凭借我们默契的确认才能有效。此外，符号形式主义本身只是我们先前非形式化能力的体现——一种由我们无法表达的自我巧妙设计的工具，目的是将其作为我们的外部指南。因此，对原始术语和公理的解释主要是非表达的，而构成数学进步基础的对它们的扩展和重新解释的过程也是如此。直觉与形式之间的转换依赖于默契的肯定，无论是在每条形式推理链的开始还是结束。

The manner in which the mathematician works his way towards discovery, by shifting his confidence from intuition to computation and back again from computation to intuition, while never releasing his hold on either of the two, represents in miniature the whole range of operations by which articulation disciplines and expands the reasoning powers of man. This alternation is asymmetrical, for a formal step can be valid only by virtue of our tacit confirmation of it. Moreover, a symbolic formalism is itself but an embodiment of our antecedent unformalized powers—an instrument skilfully contrived by our inarticulate selves for the purpose of relying on it as our external guide. The interpretation of primitive terms and axioms is therefore predominantly inarticulate, and so is the process of their expansion and re-interpretation which underlies the progress of mathematics. The alternation between the intuitive and the formal depends on tacit affirmations, both at the beginning and at the end of each chain of formal reasoning.

 

 

6

6

求知激情

INTELLECTUAL PASSIONS

 

 

  1. 路标
  2. SIGN-POSTING

上一章是题外话。在第一部分中，我承认科学家在维护科学论断中无处不在，因此我想探究这种个人系数的起源，将其追溯到言语行为本身。为了找到这个关键点，探究必须超越它，深入到动物和婴儿的智力非言语层面，在这些层面上，口头知识的个人系数最初就形成了。进一步追寻这种隐性智力的根源，我们认识到一种控制和维持它的主动原则。在生命尺度上，直至蠕虫，甚至变形虫，我们都能看到动物普遍的警觉性，这种警觉性并非为了追求任何特定的满足，而仅仅是为了探索那里存在的东西；这是一种渴望在智力上掌控自身所面临的情境的冲动。最终，在这种探索——以及视觉感知——的逻辑结构中，我们发现了知识的主动塑造与将其作为现实象征的接受相结合的预兆，我们将其视为所有个人认知的显著特征。这一原则指导着所有技能和鉴赏力，并通过无处不在的默契系数，为所有清晰的认知提供指导，而口头表达必须依赖这一默契系数来引导和确认。

THE previous chapter was a digression. Having acknowledged in Part One the ubiquitous participation of the scientist in upholding the affirmations of science, I wanted to investigate the origins of this personal coefficient by tracing it back to the very act of uttering speech. In order to find this juncture the enquiry had to penetrate beyond it, to the inarticulate levels of intelligence of the animal and the infant, in which the personal coefficient of spoken knowledge is primordially preformed. Pursuing the roots of this tacit intelligence even further, we recognized an active principle which controls and sustains it. As far down the scale of life as the worms and even perhaps the amoeba, we meet a general alertness of animals, not directed towards any specific satisfaction, but merely exploring what is there; an urge to achieve intellectual control over the situations confronting it. Here at last, in the logical structure of such exploring—and of visual perception—we found prefigured that combination of the active shaping of knowledge with its acceptance as a token of reality, which we recognize as a distinctive feature of all personal knowing. This is the principle which guides all skills and connoisseurship, and informs all articulate knowing by way of the ubiquitous tacit coefficient on which spoken utterances must rely for their guidance and confirmation.

以此为线索追溯个人知识，通过所有口头表达，并进一步追溯到动物生命的活跃原则，表明我们与动物和婴儿共享的隐性智力，足以初步解释人类知识范围因语言习得而得到的巨大扩展。无论如何，这种近似方法的优势在于，它能够分别展现清晰思维中那些无需显著扩展动物所共有的隐性能力的方面。但是，思维的其他组成部分，以及科学本身，也受到远远超出动物智力范围的隐性能力的引导，现在我必须转向这些方面。

The tracing of personal knowledge on these lines, through all spoken utterances and further back to the active principles of animal life, has shown that the tacit intellectual powers which we share with animals and infants suffice to account in a first approximation for the immense expansion in the scope of human knowledge opened up by the acquisition of speech. This approximation has, at any rate, the advantage of representing separately those aspects of articulate thought which require no striking expansion of tacit powers beyond those common to animals. But there are other constituents of thought, and of science itself, which are guided by tacit powers far surpassing the range of animal intelligence, and to these I must now turn.

如果我迄今为止的研究不是局限于语言的肯定性运用（其中这种力量最不突出），那么在此之前，这些力量必然会吸引我们的注意。语言的表达性和互动性运用显然向我们展示了动物或婴儿所不具备的默契力量。艺术作品或社会准则具有明显的情感力量，这种力量在能言善辩的文化中被唤起，而没有语言的人能够接触到这种文化。但是，即使在语言本身的肯定性运用中，我们也曾遇到过这种力量。对一个伟大科学理论的肯定在某种程度上是一种喜悦的表达。该理论具有一种无声的成分来赞扬它的美，这对于相信该理论是正确的至关重要。没有动物能够欣赏科学的理智之美。

The powers in question would have inevitably forced themselves upon our attention before this, had I not limited my study so far to the affirmative use of language, in which such powers are least prominent. The expressive and interactive uses of language obviously present us with tacit powers beyond those of animals or infants. Works of art or social imperatives have a manifest emotional force, evoked within an articulate culture to which no speechless being has access. But we have met with such powers even in the affirmative use of language itself. The affirmation of a great scientific theory is in part an expression of delight. The theory has an inarticulate component acclaiming its beauty, and this is essential to the belief that the theory is true. No animal can appreciate the intellectual beauties of science.

诚然，动物生命的积极原则——我发现它预示了人类所有的智力追求——已经发出了充满激情的音符。科勒清楚地表明，黑猩猩从发现一种新的巧妙操作中获得的乐趣，与它们从中获得的实际利益截然不同；他描述了它们如何为了重复这种操作本身而重复这种操作，就像一种游戏。WN和LA凯洛格发现，一只幼年黑猩猩和同龄儿童一样，倾向于在游戏中重复使用它最初为某种实际目的而发明的工具的操作。这种动物也和孩子一样渴望爬到它通常需要解决问题的地方。动物的这些智力品味无疑预示了我们人类的表达能力所能获得的发现的乐趣，但在动物身上，它们在范围和高度上远远无法与这些乐趣相提并论。随着语言拓展了我们思维的范围，猿猴玩棍子的乐趣也扩展为一套复杂的情感反应系统，通过这套系统，自然科学、技术和数学领域中各种科学价值和创造力都得到了欣赏。这种情感正是本章标题所描述的“智识激情”。在进一步探讨之前，让我先来关注一下科学的这一方面，它所处的新语境。一种唤起人们对自身美的关注，并部分地依赖这种美来宣称自己代表了经验现实的科学理论，类似于一件唤起人们对自身美的关注，将其作为艺术现实的象征的艺术作品。它也类似于对自然的神秘沉思：这种亲缘关系在毕达哥拉斯理论科学起源的历史中得到了体现。更普遍地说，科学凭借其充满激情的基调，在那些试图唤起并强加正确情感模式的伟大话语体系中找到了自己的位置。在教授其自身独特的形式卓越性时，科学发挥着与艺术、宗教、道德、法律和其他文化组成部分相同的功能。

It is true that the active principle of animal life, in which I have found prefigured all intellectual strivings of man, already sounds a passionate note. Köhler clearly demonstrated that chimpanzees derive pleasure from the discovery of a new ingenious manipulation, quite apart from the practical benefit they derive from it; he described how they will repeat the performance for its own sake, as a kind of play. W.N. and L.A.Kellogg found that a young chimpanzee is just as much inclined as a child of the same age to repeat in play a manipulation involving the use of a tool which it had first invented for some practical purpose. The animal was also as keen as the child to climb into the place where it was usually confronted with the task of solving problems. These intellectual tastes of the animal prefigure, no doubt, the joys of discovery which our articulate powers can attain for man, but in the animal they do not remotely approach these joys in scope and elevation. As language enlarges the range of our thought, the ape’s pleasure in playing with a stick is expanded to a complex system of emotional responses by which scientific value and ingenuity of many kinds are appreciated throughout natural science, technology and mathematics. This is the kind of feeling described in the title of this chapter as intellectual Passions’. Before going into it further, let me notice the new context into which science is shifted by attending to this aspect of it. A scientific theory which calls attention to its own beauty, and partly relies on it for claiming to represent empirical reality, is akin to a work of art which calls attention to its own beauty as a token of artistic reality. It is akin also to the mystical contemplation of nature: a kinship shown historically in the Pythagorean origins of theoretical science. More generally, science, by virtue of its passionate note, finds its place among the great systems of utterances which try to evoke and impose correct modes of feeling. In teaching its own kinds of formal excellence science functions like art, religion, morality, law and other constituents of culture.

这种一致性极大地拓展了我们探究的视角。尽管我们此前已注意到，科学声称能够评估秩序和概率，并认可科学技能和鉴赏力，但与科学欣赏自身之美的智识激情相比，这些科学的评价要素显得毫无情感色彩。如果维护科学真理需要我们为这些充满激情的评价辩护，那么我们的任务也必然扩展到为那些同样充满激情的评价辩护，而这些评价正是文化各个领域得以确立的基础。如此一来，科学就无法再寄希望于一个由实证事实组成的孤岛，围绕着这个孤岛，人类其余的知识遗产便沦为主观情感主义。科学必须宣称某些情感是正确的；如果它能够兑现这一主张，它不仅能够自救，还能以其自身为榜样，维系其所属的整个文化生活体系。

This alignment greatly amplifies the perspective of our enquiry. Though we had noticed before that science claims to appraise order and probability and accredits scientific skill and connoisseurship, these evaluative components of science were emotionally colourless compared with the intellectual passions by which science appreciates its own beauty. If the upholding of scientific truth requires that we justify such passionate valuations, our task expands inevitably also to the justification of those equally passionate valuations on which the affirmation of the several domains of culture is predicated. Science can then no longer hope to survive on an island of positive facts, around which the rest of man’s intellectual heritage sinks to the status of subjective emotionalism. It must claim that certain emotions are right; and if it can make good such a claim, it will not only save itself but sustain by its example the whole system of cultural life of which it forms part.

然而，尽管我承认科学与其他文化领域之间不可避免地紧密相连，但我必须在本书中在这种联系的主张与篇幅限制之间做出妥协。虽然最终或许更容易在更广泛的基础上维护更全面的真理，但我无法在此完整地尝试这项任务。因此，我打算继续探究维护事实真理的条件，同时仅偶尔离题，以表明该项目的更广泛含义。

Yet while accepting the inescapable solidarity of science with other cultural provinces, I shall have to strike a compromise in this book between the claims of this connection and the limitations of my space. Though it may eventually prove easier to uphold a fuller truth on broader grounds, I cannot attempt this task here in its entirety. I propose, therefore, to continue my enquiry into the conditions for upholding factual truth, while digressing only from time to time to indicate the wider implications of this project.

 

 

  1. 科学价值
  2. SCIENTIFIC VALUE

从本书一开始，我就曾在各种场合提及科学家在发现新事物时所感受到的那种无比激动的心情，这种激动只有科学家才能体会，也只有科学才能在他们心中唤起。在第一章中，我就引用了开普勒宣布发现第三定律的那句著名话语：“……没有什么能阻挡我；我将放纵我神圣的愤怒……”143众所周知，在发现过程中会爆发此类情绪，但人们认为它们不会影响发现的结果。尽管科学源于激情，但人们仍将其视为客观确立的。现在，您应该已经清楚，我并不认同这种观点；现在，我想明确地探讨科学中的激情。我想表明，科学激情并非仅仅是心理的副产品，它还具有逻辑功能，为科学贡献了不可或缺的元素。它们回应了科学陈述中的一种基本特质，因此可以说它们是对的还是错的，取决于我们承认还是否认这种特质的存在。

From the start of this book I have had occasion, in various contexts, to refer to the overwhelming elation felt by scientists at the moment of discovery, an elation of a kind which only a scientist can feel and which science alone can evoke in him. In the very first chapter I quoted the famous passage in which Kepler announced the discovery of his Third Law: ‘…nothing holds me; I will indulge my sacred fury…’143 The outbreak of such emotions in the course of discovery is well known, but they are not thought to affect the outcome of discovery. Science is regarded as objectively established in spite of its passionate origins. It should be clear by this time that I dissent from that belief; and I have now come to the point at which I want to deal explicitly with passions in science. I want to show that scientific passions are no mere psychological by-product, but have a logical function which contributes an indispensable element to science. They respond to an essential quality in a scientific statement and may accordingly be said to be right or wrong, depending on whether we acknowledge or deny the presence of that quality in it.

这种品质是什么？激情赋予事物以情感，使其令人厌恶或吸引；积极的激情则肯定某物是珍贵的。科学家做出发现的兴奋是一种求知的激情，表明某物在智力上是珍贵的，更具体地说，对科学来说是珍贵的。这种肯定构成了科学的一部分。我引用的开普勒的话不是事实陈述，也不是开普勒个人感受的报道。它们将事实之外的东西断言为对科学的有效肯定：即某些事实的科学意义，即开普勒刚刚发现的事实。事实上，它们肯定这些事实具有巨大的科学意义，只要知识存在，就会一直受到重视。开普勒并没有被这种庄严的情感所欺骗。过去的几个世纪对他的远见卓识表示了越来越高的敬意，我相信，未来的几个世纪也将如此。

What is this quality? Passions charge objects with emotions, making them repulsive or attractive; positive passions affirm that something is precious. The excitement of the scientist making a discovery is an intellectual passion, telling that something is intellectually precious and, more particularly, that it is precious to science. And this affirmation forms part of science. The words of Kepler which I quoted were not a statement of fact, but neither were they merely a report of Kepler’s personal feelings. They asserted as a valid affirmation of science something else than a fact: namely the scientific interest of certain facts, the facts just discovered by Kepler. They affirmed, indeed, that these facts are of immense scientific interest and will be so regarded as long as knowledge lasts. Nor was Kepler deceived in this majestic sentiment. The passing centuries have paid their cumulative tribute to his vision, and so, I believe, will the centuries yet to come.

我在此赋予科学热情的功能在于，它能够区分哪些可论证的事实具有科学意义，哪些则不具科学意义。在所有可知事实中，只有极小一部分能引起科学家的兴趣，而科学热情也有助于评估哪些事物更有意义，哪些事物不那么有趣；哪些科学是伟大的，哪些相对微不足道。我想表明，这种欣赏最终取决于对理智美的感知；它是一种情感反应，永远无法客观地定义，正如我们无法客观地定义一件艺术作品的美或一项高尚行为的卓越一样。

The function which I attribute here to scientific passion is that of distinguishing between demonstrable facts which are of scientific interest, and those which are not. Only a tiny fraction of all knowable facts are of interest to scientists, and scientific passion serves also as a guide in the assessment of what is of higher and what of lesser interest; what is great in science, and what relatively slight. I want to show that this appreciation depends ultimately on a sense of intellectual beauty; that it is an emotional response which can never be dispassionately defined, any more than we can dispassionately define the beauty of a work of art or the excellence of a noble action.

科学发现揭示了新的知识，但随之而来的新视野并非知识。它不如知识，因为它是一种猜测；但它又比知识丰富，因为它是对尚不清楚、目前或许还无法想象的事物的预知。我们对事物普遍性质的认识是我们解释所有未来经验的指南。这种指导必不可少。试图用任何纯粹客观的形式程序来解释科学真理的确立的科学方法理论注定要失败。任何不受求知激情引导的探究过程都将不可避免地陷入琐碎的荒漠。我们对现实的认识，以及我们对科学美感所回应的认识，必然会向我们提出那些值得合理而又有趣的问题。它应该推荐哪些概念和经验关系本质上是合理的，因此即使某些证据似乎与之相矛盾也应该坚持；另一方面，它还应该告诉我们，哪些经验联系即使有证据支持，也应该被拒绝，因为它们似是而非——这些证据我们可能目前无法用任何其他假设来解释。事实上，如果没有基于对现实的视角来衡量趣味性和可信度的标准，就不可能发现任何对科学有价值的东西；而只有我们对科学之美的理解，并回应我们感官的证据，才能唤起这种视角。

Scientific discovery reveals new knowledge, but the new vision which accompanies it is not knowledge. It is less than knowledge, for it is a guess; but it is more than knowledge, for it is a foreknowledge of things yet unknown and at present perhaps inconceivable. Our vision of the general nature of things is our guide for the interpretation of all future experience. Such guidance is indispensable. Theories of the scientific method which try to explain the establishment of scientific truth by any purely objective formal procedure are doomed to failure. Any process of enquiry unguided by intellectual passions would inevitably spread out into a desert of trivialities. Our vision of reality, to which our sense of scientific beauty responds, must suggest to us the kind of questions that it should be reasonable and interesting to explore. It should recommend the kind of conceptions and empirical relations that are intrinsically plausible and which should therefore be upheld, even when some evidence seems to contradict them, and tell us also, on the other hand, what empirical connections to reject as specious, even though there is evidence for them—evidence that we may as yet be unable to account for on any other assumptions. In fact, without a scale of interest and plausibility based on a vision of reality, nothing can be discovered that is of value to science; and only our grasp of scientific beauty, responding to the evidence of our senses, can evoke this vision.

我们将科学价值的概念表述为三个因素的共同作用，以便更好地理解它。一个断言越能被接受为科学的一部分，它对科学的价值就越大，它所具备的条件也就越多：

We shall get a firmer hold on this concept of scientific value by representing it as the joint outcome of three contributing factors. An affirmation will be acceptable as part of science, and will be the more valuable to science, the more it possesses:

（1）确定性（准确性）

(1)certainty (accuracy)

（2）系统相关性（深度）

(2)systematic relevance (profundity)

（3）内在兴趣。

(3)intrinsic interest.

其中前两个标准本质上是科学的，第三个标准则是超科学的。

The first two of these criteria are inherently scientific, the third is extra- scientific.

这三个标准相互辉映，因此其中一个标准的不足之处，很大程度上可以通过其他标准的卓越性得到弥补。以物种进化为例。新达尔文主义虽然缺乏直接证据，但却得到了科学界的广泛认可和高度重视，因为它完美地契合了宇宙的机械体系，并且与人类起源这个具有极高内在意义的主题息息相关。在其他情况下，我们也看到事实的高度准确性弥补了系统相关性或内在意义的相对缺乏。曼内·西格班因在测量某些X射线光谱的波长方面取得了显著的精度而获得了诺贝尔物理学奖，尽管他的研究结果并没有揭示出其他什么有趣的东西。然而，对精确事实的欣赏是有限度的。T·W·理查兹教授于1914年因非常精确地测定原子量而获得诺贝尔奖，他的研究结果从未受到质疑。然而，1932 年，弗雷德里克·索迪 (Frederick Soddy) 写道，这种测量方法现在看来“毫无意义，就像确定一组瓶子的平均重量一样，其中一些是满的，而另一些则或多或少是空的”。144与此同时，人们意识到，原子量的数值源于自然界中元素组成同位素的偶然比例。一个看似表征宇宙深层特征的量级，最终却被证明与此无关。尽管事实上是正确的，但它却具有欺骗性，因为与预期相反，它与自然界中任何实质性的东西都不对应。当一种元素的精确原子量不再引起科学界的兴趣时，原本看似重要的东西就变得无关紧要了。

The three criteria apply jointly, so that deficiency in one is largely compensated for by excellence in the others. Take for example the evolution of species. Neo-Darwinism is firmly accredited and highly regarded by science, though there is little direct evidence for it, because it beautifully fits into a mechanistic system of the universe and bears on a subject—the origin of man—which is of the utmost intrinsic interest. In other cases we see great accuracy of facts compensating for comparative lack of systematic relevance or intrinsic interest. Manne Siegbahn was awarded the Nobel prize in physics for a greatly increased accuracy in measuring the wave length of certain X-ray spectra, though his results revealed little that is otherwise interesting. Yet there is a limit to the appreciation of accurate facts. Professor T.W.Richards was awarded the Nobel prize in 1914 for a very accurate determination of atomic weights, and his results have never been contested. Yet in 1932 Frederick Soddy could write of this kind of measurement that it appears now ‘of as little interest and significance as the determination of the average weight of a collection of bottles, some of them full and some of them more or less empty’.144 It had been realized meanwhile that the value of atomic weights results from the accidental proportion in which the constituent isotopes happen to be present in the elements as found in nature. A magnitude that had seemed to characterize a deep seated feature of the universe, had turned out to have no such bearing. Though factually correct it had proved deceptive, because—contrary to expectation—it did not correspond to anything substantial in nature. When the exact atomic weight of an element ceased to be of interest to science, what had seemed important turned out to be trivial.

虽然科学价值无法用精确的术语定义，但通常可以得到可靠的评估。在科学的推进和传播过程中，每天都需要对其进行评估，并且依赖这种评估。期刊咨询的审稿人必须判断一篇论文的科学价值是否值得花费出版费用。其他人则必须决定研究经费是否值得。科学家必须能够识别哪些是明显微不足道的，就像哪些是明显错误的一样。杰出的德国物理学家弗里德里希·科尔劳施（1840-1910）在一次关于自然科学目标的讨论中宣称，他很乐意精确测定水流过排水沟的速度，145他完全是在胡说八道。他完全误判了科学价值的本质；因为观察的准确性本身并不意味着它对科学有价值。

Though not definable in precise terms, scientific value can as a rule be reliably assessed. Its appraisal is required and depended upon every day in the process of advancing and disseminating science. Referees consulted by journals have to judge whether the scientific interest of a contribution would justify the expense of its publication. Others have to decide whether the award of a research grant is worth while. Scientists must be able to recognize what is manifestly trivial, just as what is manifestly false. When the distinguished German physicist Friedrich Kohlrausch (1840–1910) declared, in a discussion about the aims of natural science, that he would be pleased to determine accurately the speed of water running through the gutter,145 he was talking nonsense. He completely misjudged the nature of scientific value; for the accuracy of an observation does not in itself make it valuable to science.

科尔劳施的愚蠢承诺当然并非他的真意。他只不过是在比通常更一致地阐述一种错误的科学理论；毫无疑问，他以此为依据——正如休谟所说——哲学的错误只是荒谬的，其夸张之处不会影响我们的生活。146但在这样做的过程中，他不由自主地表明，只有完全放弃严格客观的科学理想，才能避免这种荒谬的结论——而且不会出现矛盾。

The foolish promise made by Kohlrausch was of course not his true intention. He was merely expounding a false theory of science more consistently than is usual; relying on it, no doubt, that—as Hume said— the errors of philosophy are only ridiculous and its extravagances do not influence our lives.146 But in doing so, he demonstrated involuntarily that such absurd conclusions can be avoided—without inconsistency—only by abandoning altogether the ideal of a strictly objective science.

人们常说，科学（不同于历史）只关注规律性，而不关注独特事件。这种说法仅在我前两个标准已经涵盖的范围内成立。如果一个事件可重复或可预测地重复出现，则该事件具有规律性。事实的可重复性使其观察结果格外可靠，而其重复性则表明它构成了自然系统的一部分。事实上，对系统性的兴趣甚至可能超过规律性的完全缺失。第谷·布拉赫于1572年观测到一颗异常明亮的新恒星，这引起了科学界极大的兴趣，因为它试图推翻亚里士多德的至高天不变体系。147同样，沃勒于1828年合成的尿素削弱了人们对生命物质独特性的传统信念。发现活体腔棘鱼的科学兴趣并非源于寻找此类动物的循环供应，而在于该物种作为所有陆地脊椎动物共同祖先所具有的重大系统学意义。此类发现的价值在于其广泛的意义，即使它们并未确立新的普遍规律。它们提供了一些更模糊也更深刻的东西；即对广阔经验领域的更真实的理解。普遍性实际上只是科学深度的一个方面，而深度本身，正如我们将会看到的那样，只是一种暗示，表明我们正在与现实建立一种新的、更广泛的联系。

It is often said that science (unlike history) is concerned only with regularities and not with unique events. This is true only up to the point covered already by my two first criteria. An event is regular if it is either reproducible or predictably recurrent. The reproducibility of a fact makes its observation exceptionally reliable, while its recurrence reveals that it forms part of a natural system. Indeed, systematic interest can outweigh even complete absence of regularity. Tycho Brahe’s observation in 1572 of a new fixed star of exceptional brightness was of the greatest interest to science, for it tended to invalidate the Aristotelian system of an unchangeable empyrean.147 Similarly, Wöhler’s synthesis of urea in 1828 weakened the traditional belief in the uniqueness of living matter. Nor did the scientific interest in the discovery of a living coelacanth depend on the prospect of finding a recurrent supply of such animals, but lay in the great systematic interest of that species as a common ancestor of all the land vertebrates. Discoveries like these are valued for the breadth of their implications, even though they establish no new general laws. They offer something more vague and also more profound; namely, a truer understanding of a large domain of experience. Generality is indeed but an aspect of profundity in science, and profundity itself, as we shall see, but an intimation that we are making a new, more extensive contact with reality.

此外，科学兴趣与历史兴趣之间的区别并非源于历史事件的独特性，而是源于它们在人际中的吸引力，这一点我将在后面详述。过去事件的历史兴趣，如同事实的科学兴趣一样，取决于它们与学术背景的关系：在这里，指的是历史背景。诚然，这种背景对历史学家的吸引力同样是人际的，因此不同于数学理论对科学家关注的诉求。148

The difference between scientific and historical interest, moreover, arises, not from the uniqueness of historical events but from their interpersonal appeal, of which I shall speak later. The historical interest of past events depends, like the scientific interest of facts, on their bearing on a scholarly context: in this case the context of history. Admittedly, the appeal which this context makes to the historian is again interpersonal and thus different from the claim made by a mathematical theory on the attention of the scientist.148

很多事实被科学家一致认为与科学无关，而对某些事实，他们的看法则有所不同。巴斯德在1860年提交给法国科学院的关于自然发生论的回忆录中，讲述了比奥和杜马如何劝阻他不要从事此类研究。149如今，只有极少数科学家认为验证超感知觉或念力存在的事实是值得的，因为他们中的大多数人会认为这是浪费时间，是对专业技能的不当利用。科学家们通常会忽略那些看似与公认科学知识体系不相容的证据，希望它们最终会被证明是错误的或无关紧要的。明智地忽略这些证据，可以避免科学实验室永远陷入为了验证虚假指控而进行的毫无逻辑且徒劳无功的努力之中。但不幸的是，没有任何规则可以避免偶尔忽略与现有科学理论相冲突（或看似冲突）的真实证据的风险。十八世纪，法国科学院固执地否认了陨石坠落的证据，尽管这在其他人看来显而易见。他们反对民间传统中与这种天体干预相关的迷信信仰，这让他们对相关事实视而不见。 150

A great many facts are unanimously regarded by scientists as irrelevant to science, while in respect to some they differ. Pasteur, in his memoir on spontaneous generation, presented to the French Academy in 1860, relates how Biot and Dumas discouraged him from undertaking work on such a subject.149 Today, only very few scientists consider it worth while to test the facts of extra-sensory perception or of psychokinesis, since most of them would regard this as a waste of time and an improper use of their professional facilities. It is the normal practice of scientists to ignore evidence which appears incompatible with the accepted system of scientific knowledge, in the hope that it will eventually prove false or irrelevant. The wise neglect of such evidence prevents scientific laboratories from being plunged forever into a turmoil of incoherent and futile efforts to verify false allegations. But there is, unfortunately, no rule by which to avoid the risk of occasionally disregarding thereby true evidence which conflicts (or seems to conflict) with the current teachings of science. During the eighteenth century the French Academy of Science stubbornly denied the evidence for the fall of meteorites, which seemed massively obvious to everybody else. Their opposition to the superstitious beliefs which a popular tradition attached to such heavenly intervention blinded them to the facts in question.150

正如正确感知的两个标准——轮廓的清晰度和图像的合理性——共同决定了眼睛所见的内容，科学价值的两个首要标准——我称之为“确定性”和“系统相关性”——也共同决定了事实的科学价值。正如眼睛如果看到与图像意义相符的细节，就会看到原本不存在的细节；如果看到毫无意义的细节，就会忽略它们一样，同样，只要一个所谓的事实符合一个宏大的科学概括，即使它本身具有极少的确定性，也不足以确保其具有最高的科学价值；而即使是最顽固的事实，如果在既定的科学框架中没有立足之地，也会被抛在一边。

As the two criteria of right perception—namely sharpness of contour and reasonableness of the image—combine in determining what the eye will see, so the claims of the two first criteria of scientific value, which I have called ‘certainty’ and ‘systematic relevance’, combine in determining the scientific value of a fact. Just as the eye sees details that are not there if they fit in with the sense of the picture, or overlooks them if they make no sense, so also very little inherent certainty will suffice to secure the highest scientific value to an alleged fact, if only it fits in with a great scientific generalization, while the most stubborn facts will be set aside if there is no place for them in the established framework of science.

一个主题的内在趣味（我已将其列为决定科学价值的第三个变量）与前两个变量（即准确性和系统相关性）之间也存在着竞争和互补。在科学中，如同在日常感知中一样，我们的注意力会被对我们有用或危险的事物所吸引，即使它们呈现得不那么清晰和连贯。这引发了实践兴趣和理论兴趣之间的竞争，我将在定义科学与技术的关系时更全面地探讨这个问题。但事物本身也各有其趣味，其内在趣味也千差万别。活着的动物比它们的尸体更有趣；狗比苍蝇更有趣；人比狗更有趣。就人本身而言，他的道德生活比他的消化系统更有趣；此外，在人类社会中，最有趣的主题是政治和历史，它们是重大道德决策的舞台——与此同时，与这些人类关切紧密交织在一起的是，那些影响人类对宇宙的思考以及他对自身、起源和命运的认知的主题，也具有巨大的内在趣味。

There is rivalry and compensation also between the intrinsic interest of a subject matter, which I have listed as the third variable in determining scientific value, and the first two, i.e. accuracy and systematic relevance. In science, as in ordinary perception, our attention is attracted by things that are useful or dangerous to us, even though they present themselves less distinctly and coherently. This sets up a competition between practical and theoretical interests, with which I shall deal more fully when defining the relation of science to technology. But things are also interesting in themselves, and their intrinsic interest varies greatly. Living animals are more interesting than their dead bodies; a dog more interesting than a fly; a man more interesting than a dog. In man himself his moral life is more interesting than his digestion; and, again, in human society the most interesting subjects are politics and history, which are the theatres of great moral decisions—while, at the same time, closely interwoven with these human concerns, there is great intrinsic interest also in the subjects which affect man’s contemplation of the universe and his conception of himself, his origin and destiny.

本身最有趣的学科并不适合进行精确观察和系统研究。但这两种等级划分在广泛的学科领域中可以相互弥补，它们以不同的比例结合，从而始终保持稳定的科学价值水平。物理学的极高精确性和科学连贯性弥补了其无生命研究对象的相对枯燥；而生物学的科学价值则因其所研究的生物具有更大的内在趣味而与物理学保持同一水平，尽管其处理方式远不如物理学精确和连贯。弗洛伊德体系或许尚未被科学界完全接受，但它基于科学主张的巨大影响力清楚地表明，即使是一个很大程度上基于推测且相当模糊的学说，如果能够探讨人类的道德和幸福，也可能引起科学界的极大兴趣。马克思主义，尽管只具备最薄弱的科学特征，却通过以自称科学的方式处理政治问题，成为了一股决定命运的力量。

The subjects which are most interesting in themselves do not lend themselves best to accurate observation and systematic study. But the two kinds of gradings can compensate for each other over a wide range of disciplines, in which they combine in variable proportions, and thus uphold throughout a steady level of scientific value.
