The supreme exactitude and scientific coherence of physics compensate for the comparative dullness of its inanimate subject matter, while the scientific value of biology is maintained at the same level as that of physics by the greater intrinsic interest of the living things studied, though the treatment is much less exact and coherent. The Freudian system is perhaps not wholly accepted by science, yet its enormous influence, based on its scientific claims, shows clearly that even a largely conjectural and rather vague doctrine may gain great scientific interest if it deals with man’s morality and happiness. Marxism, equipped with only the flimsiest scientific characteristics, has become a force of destiny, by dealing with politics in a manner claiming to be scientific.

科学在依靠其研究对象的先验兴趣来获取自身利益时，必须在很大程度上接受这些研究对象的前科学观念。动物的存在并非动物学家发现的，植物的存在亦非植物学家发现的，动物学和植物学的科学价值仅仅是人类对动植物前科学兴趣的延伸。心理学家必须从日常经验中了解人类智力的本质，才能设计出科学地测量智力的测试方法。如果他们测量的是日常经验中未识别为智力的东西，那么他们就构建了一个新的研究对象，而这个对象不再具有他们最初选择研究的对象的内在兴趣。诚然，生物学、医学、心理学和社会科学的研究或许可以修正我们对动植物，甚至对人类和社会的日常观念；但我们必须摒弃任何此类修改对其对最初研究对象兴趣的影响，因为正是这种兴趣促使并证明了对原始研究对象的合理性。如果在处理一个主题时，绝对优先考虑精确观察和严格关联数据的科学优点，而当用这些术语来表示时，该主题就会瓦解，那么结果将与主题无关，甚至可能没有任何意义。151

In relying for its own interest on the antecedent interest of its subject matter, science must accept to an important extent the pre-scientific conception of these subject matters. The existence of animals was not discovered by zoologists, nor that of plants by botanists, and the scientific value of zoology and botany is but an extension of man’s pre-scientific interest in animals and plants. Psychologists must know from ordinary experience what human intelligence is, before they can devise tests for measuring it scientifically, and should they measure instead something that ordinary experience does not recognize as intelligence, they would be constructing a new subject matter which could no longer claim the intrinsic interest attached to that which they originally chose to study. Admittedly, the pursuits of biology, medicine, psychology and the social sciences, may rectify our everyday conceptions of plants and animals, and even of man and society; but we must set against any such modification its effect on the interest by which the study of the original subject matter had been prompted and justified. If the scientific virtues of exact observation and strict correlation of data are given absolute preference for the treatment of a subject matter which disintegrates when represented in such terms, the result will be irrelevant to the subject matter and probably of no interest at all.151

拉普拉斯构建了一种科学概念的范式，即追求绝对超脱的理想，即用精确确定的细节来表征世界。拉普拉斯写道：“如果一个智慧体在某一时刻知晓所有驱动自然的力量，以及构成自然的实体各自的位置，…​​…它将用同一个公式来概括宇宙中最大的物体和最轻的原子的运动：对它来说，一切都是不确定的，未来如同过去一样，呈现在它眼前。”152这样的头脑将拥有关于宇宙的完整科学知识。 153

The paradigm of a conception of science pursuing the ideal of absolute detachment by representing the world in terms of its exactly determined particulars was formulated by Laplace. An intelligence which knew at one moment of time—wrote Laplace—‘all the forces by which nature is animated and the respective positions of the entities which compose it,… would embrace in the same formula the movements of the largest bodies in the universe and those of the lightest atom: nothing would be uncertain for it, and the future, like the past, would be present to its eyes.’152 Such a mind would possess a complete scientific knowledge of the universe.153

￼ ￼ ￼ ￼这种普遍知识的理想是错误的，因为它用一组数据代替了我们感兴趣的主题，而这些数据并没有告诉我们任何我们想知道的事情。用数学的方式表达，拉普拉斯普遍知识在于，根据给定的坐标p 0和 q 0 ( p (1) … p ( u ) … q (1) … q ( n) )，预测世界上所有n 个原子在时间t 的坐标p 和 脉冲 q， p ( 1) … p ( n ) ; q (1) … q ( n )

￼￼￼￼This ideal of universal knowledge is mistaken, since it substitutes for the subjects in which we are interested a set of data which tell us nothing that we want to know. Written down mathematically, Laplacean universal knowledge consists in the prediction of the co-ordinates p and the impulses q of all the n atoms of the world, p(1)…p(n); q(1)…q(n), at a time t, from the co-ordinates p0 and q0 (p (1)…p (u)…q (1)…q (n)) given at the

开始时间t =0。预测是通过一系列函数进行的

starting time t=0. The prediction is made by the aid of a series of functions

 

 

它决定了t时刻p和q的 2n个值的集合。现在假设我们能够在t时刻实际观测到这些原子量。虽然验证这一预测可能很有趣，但这仅仅回答了理论本身提出的一个问题。因此，除了那些假设在t时刻计算并随后观测到p和q的科学家之外，其他人对此并无兴趣。

which determines the whole set of 2n values of the p’s and the q’s at the time t. Suppose now that we could actually observe these atomic magnitudes at the time t. While it might be interesting to check up on this prediction, this would merely answer a question raised by the theory itself. It would be therefore without any interest except to the hypothetical scientists who had computed and would subsequently observe the p’s and q’s at the time t.

拉普拉斯竟然将这些几乎毫无意义的信息等同于对一切过去和未来的知识，而这种说法的荒谬性在他之后的世代中却鲜为人知。这只能用一个隐含的假设来解释，而这个假设默默地补充了这些信息。人们理所当然地认为，拉普拉斯的思维不会止步于时间t的p和q的列表，而是凭借其无限的计算能力，从这个列表中评估我们可能感兴趣的事件，乃至所有事件。

That such virtually meaningless information was identified by Laplace with a knowledge of all things past and all things to come, and that the stark absurdity of this claim has not been obvious to succeeding generations since his day, can be accounted for only by a hidden assumption by which this information was tacitly supplemented. It was taken for granted that the Laplacean mind would not stop short at the list of p’s and q’s at the time t, but proceed by virtue of its unlimited powers of computation to evaluate from this list the events, and indeed all the events, that we might be interested to know.

但这一假设实际上比拉普拉斯明确提出的假设更为宏大，性质也截然不同。它既不要求我们拥有无限的能力来执行有关机械系统的复杂计算，也不会以此满足，而是要求我们用原子数据来解释各种经验。这当然是机械论世界观的纲领，在现代，伽利略首先对其进行了推测；但这一纲领甚至从未在原则上得到实现，我们将在第四部分看到，它根本无法实现。拉普拉斯的想象力所构想出的巨大智力壮举，以一种魔术师惯用的方式，将人们的注意力从他用所有经验的知识取代所有原子数据的知识这一决定性花招上转移开来。一旦你拒绝这种欺骗性的替代，你就会立即发现，拉普拉斯的思维恰恰什么也不理解，它所知道的一切也恰恰毫无意义。

But this assumption is actually much larger and quite different in character from that explicitly made by Laplace. It neither demands, nor is it satisfied by our having an unlimited capacity for carrying out complex computations concerning a mechanical system, but requires instead that we should explain all kinds of experience in terms of atomic data. This is of course the programme of a mechanistic world view, which in modern times was first speculatively mooted by Galileo; but this programme has never been carried out even in principle and we shall see in Part Four that it cannot be carried out at all. The tremendous intellectual feat conjured up by Laplace’s imagination has diverted attention (in a manner commonly practised by conjurers) from the decisive sleight of hand by which he substitutes a knowledge of all experience for a knowledge of all atomic data. Once you refuse this deceptive substitution, you immediately see that the Laplacean mind understands precisely nothing and that whatever it knows means precisely nothing.

然而，拉普拉斯式妄想的魔咒至今仍未破除。拉普拉斯典型地阐述的严格客观知识的理想，至今仍维持着一种普遍的趋势，即提高科学的观察准确性和系统精确性，却以牺牲其对研究主题的影响力为代价。第四部分将通过反思我们对生物的认知来系统地探讨这个问题。我在此提及它，仅仅是作为一种更广泛的智力紊乱的中间阶段：即接受源自拉普拉斯式知识理想的人的概念，并以此为依据处理人类事务，将对所有文化价值观，包括科学价值观构成威胁。

Yet the spell of the Laplacean delusion remains unbroken to this day. The ideal of strictly objective knowledge, paradigmatically formulated by Laplace, continues to sustain a universal tendency to enhance the observational accuracy and systematic precision of science, at the expense of its bearing on its subject matter. This issue will be dealt with systematically in Part Four by reflecting on our knowledge of living beings. I mention it here only as an intermediate stage in a wider intellectual disorder: namely the menace to all cultural values, including those of science, by an acceptance of a conception of man derived from a Laplacean ideal of knowledge and by the conduct of human affairs in the light of such a conception.

怀特海写道，十八、十九世纪的思想冲突是由这样一个事实所决定的：“世界已经掌握了一个普遍的观念，这个世界既不能没有它也不能没有它。”154科学的严苛性，执意要扭曲我们生存的至关重要的事实，持续支撑着这场冲突，而这场冲突或许最终会引发一场针对科学的全面反击，认为科学是对真理的歪曲。这种情况早在公元四世纪就已发生，但其理由远不及圣奥古斯丁，他否定了自然科学的价值，认为它对救赎的追求毫无贡献。他的禁令摧毁了整个欧洲一千年来对科学的兴趣。

Whitehead wrote that the conflicts of thought in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries were governed by the fact ‘that the world had got hold of a general idea which the world could neither live with nor live without.’154 Scientific stringency, inflexibly resolved to denature the vital facts of our existence, continues to sustain this conflict, which may yet issue in a sweeping reaction against science as a perversion of truth. This happened before, with much less justification, in the fourth century, when St. Augustine denied the value of a natural science which contributed nothing to the pursuit of salvation. His ban destroyed interest in science all over Europe for a thousand years.

然而，就目前而言，对科学真正价值的威胁并非在于任何公开反对科学的行为，而在于接受一种基于拉普拉斯谬误的科学观，以此指导人类事务。这种简化的方案应用于政治，包含着这样一种观点：政治行动必然受制于武力，受贪婪和恐惧驱使，道德被用作蒙蔽受害者的屏障。这种唯物主义的政治观——就像与之相关的机械论人性观一样——可以追溯到拉普拉斯之前的远古时代，甚至远至古代。但自那时起，一场复杂的历史运动沿着一系列相互关联的线索，最终导致科学方法在我们这个时代确立为人类事务的最高解释者。这场运动在我们的文化中制造了一种普遍的张力，类似于早期理性反抗宗教所产生的张力，但其范围更为广泛。在这里，我将只讨论这场运动的一种形式，并只讨论它对科学价值理解的影响。

For the time being, however, the peril to the true values of science does not lie in any overt reaction against science. It lies in the very acceptance of a scientific outlook based on the Laplacean fallacy as a guide to human affairs. Its reductive programme, applied to politics, entails the idea that political action is necessarily shaped by force, motivated by greed and fear, with morality used as a screen to delude the victims. This materialistic view of politics can be traced—like the mechanistic conception of man to which it is allied—far back beyond Laplace and all the way to antiquity. But a complex historical movement has since then led, along a number of mutually related lines, to the establishment in our time of the scientific method as the supreme interpreter of human affairs. This movement has created a pervasive tension throughout our culture, similar to that generated at an earlier time by the rebellion of reason against religion, but even more comprehensive in its scope. Here I shall deal only with one form of this movement and only with its effects on the appreciation of scientific value.

拉普拉斯的普遍力学应用于人类事务，引出了这样的学说：物质福利以及建立一种无限的权力来强制实现物质福利的条件，才是至善。然而，我们这个时代却充斥着无节制的道德追求。权力和财富的目标吸收了这种狂热，获得了道德上的神圣性，这种神圣性加上它们所谓的科学必要性，使得它们被接受为人类至高无上、至高无上的命运。这场运动的全面主张不容置疑地维护公共自由，并要求所有文化活动都应服务于国家权力，使其能够改造社会，实现福祉。如此一来，一项发现的价值将不再取决于它能否满足科学家的求知欲，而是取决于它对加强公共权力和改善生活水平的可能效用。科学价值将受到质疑，其价值也将受到压制。

Applied to human affairs, the Laplacean universal mechanics induces the teaching that material welfare and the establishment of an unlimited power for imposing the conditions of material welfare are the supreme good. But our age overflows with inordinate moral aspirations. By absorbing this zeal the objectives of power and wealth acquire a moral sanctity which, added to their supposed scientific necessity, enforces their acceptance as man’s supreme and total destiny. The comprehensive claims of this movement leave no justification to public liberties, and demand that all cultural activities should subserve the power of the State in transforming society for the achievement of welfare. A discovery will then no longer be valued by the satisfaction which it gives to the intellectual passions of scientists, but will be assessed according to its probable utility for strengthening public power and improving the standard of living. Scientific value will be discredited and its appreciation suppressed.

正是如此，一场以严谨的科学态度为指导的哲学运动，最终威胁到了科学本身的地位。这种自相矛盾源于一种被误导的智识激情——一种追求绝对非个人化知识的激情，这种激情无法识别任何人，为我们呈现了一幅我们自身缺席的宇宙图景。在这样的宇宙中，没有人能够创造和维护科学价值观；因此，科学也就无从谈起。

This is how a philosophic movement guided by aspirations of scientific severity has come to threaten the position of science itself. This self- contradiction stems from a misguided intellectual passion—a passion for achieving absolutely impersonal knowledge which, being unable to recognize any persons, presents us with a picture of the universe in which we ourselves are absent. In such a universe there is no one capable of creating and upholding scientific values; hence there is no science.

拉普拉斯谬误的故事揭示了一种一致性的标准。​​它表明，我们对人与人类社会的理解必须能够解释人形成这些理解的能力，并授权在社会中培养这种能力。只有通过认可我们在观察人的过程中所运用的智识热情，我们才能形成既认可这种认可又维护社会文化自由的人与社会的理解。这种自我认可或自我证实的进步，将成为所有关于生物的知识的有效指南。

The story of the Laplacean fallacy suggests a criterion of consistency. It shows that our conceptions of man and human society must be such as to account for man’s faculty in forming these conceptions and to authorize the cultivation of this faculty within society. Only by accrediting the exercise of our intellectual passions in the act of observing man, can we form conceptions of man and society which both endorse this accrediting and uphold the freedom of culture in society. Such self-accrediting, or self-confirmatory, progression will prove an effective guide to all knowledge of living beings.

 

 

  1. 启发式热情
  2. HEURISTIC PASSION

到目前为止，我只是描述了理智激情的选择性功能。这一功能与开普勒同一篇文章中明确阐述的另一项功能相衔接。我们不妨在此再次回顾一下他的话：

So far I have been describing only the selective function of intellectual passions. This function is continuous with another which also comes out clearly in the same text of Kepler. We may recall here once more his words:

二十二年前，当我在天体轨道中发现五种立体时，我就预言了这一点；早在我看到托勒密的《和声学》之前，我就坚信这一点；在我确信我的发现之前，我就在这第五本书的书名中向我的朋友们承诺了这一点；十六年前，我极力主张去寻找这一点；为此，我把我一生中最好的部分奉献给了天文学沉思，为此，我加入了第谷·布拉赫的行列……最终，我把它带到了光明中，并认识到它的真实性，这超出了我的所有希望……所以现在，自从十八个月前的黎明，三个月前的白昼的光线，以及几天前最奇妙的沉思的纯净太阳本身照耀出来以来……没有什么能阻挡我…… 155

What I prophesied two-and-twenty years ago, as soon as I discovered the five solids among the heavenly orbits— what I firmly believed long before I had seen Ptolemy’s Harmonics—what I had promised my friends in the titleof this fifth book, which I named before I was sure of my discovery—what sixteen years ago I urged to be sought— that for which I have devoted the best part of my life to astronomical contemplation, for which I joined Tycho Brahe…at last I have brought it to light, and recognized its truth beyond all my hopes… So now since eighteen months ago the dawn, three months ago the proper light of day, and indeed a very few days ago the pure Sun itself of the most marvellous contemplation has shone forth…nothing holds me….155

 

 

求知的激情不仅肯定了和谐的存在，预示着未来无限的发现，还能唤起对具体发现的憧憬，并支撑着人们在多年的辛勤劳动中坚持不懈地追求这些发现。对科学价值的欣赏在此融入了发现它的能力；正如艺术家的感性融入了他的创造力。这就是科学激情的启发性功能。

Intellectual passions do not merely affirm the existence of harmonies which foreshadow an indeterminate range of future discoveries, but can also evoke intimations of specific discoveries and sustain their persistent pursuit through years of labour. The appreciation of scientific value merges here into the capacity for discovering it; even as the artist’s sensibility merges into his creative powers. Such is the heuristic function of scientific passion.

科学家——也就是富有创造力的科学家——毕生致力于猜测。他们受到启发式热情的支撑和引导。我们称他们的工作富有创造力，因为它通过深化我们对世界的理解，改变了我们所看到的世界。这种改变是不可逆转的。我曾经解决过的问题再也无法困扰我；我无法猜测我已经知道的东西。有了发现，我将永远无法再像以前那样看待世界。我的眼光变得不同了；我让自己变成了一个以不同的方式看待和思考的人。我跨越了一道鸿沟，即问题和发现之间的启发式鸿沟。

Scientists—that is, creative scientists—spend their lives in trying to guess right. They are sustained and guided therein by their heuristic passion. We call their work creative because it changes the world as we see it, by deepening our understanding of it. The change is irrevocable. A problem that I have once solved can no longer puzzle me; I cannot guess what I already know. Having made a discovery, I shall never see the world again as before. My eyes have become different; I have made myself into a person seeing and thinking differently. I have crossed a gap, the heuristic gap which lies between problem and discovery.

重大发现改变了我们的解释框架。因此，从逻辑上讲，我们不可能通过继续运用先前的解释框架来获得这些发现。因此，我们再次看到，发现具有创造性，因为它无法通过勤奋地执行任何先前已知且可指定的程序来实现。这强化了我们对原创性的理解。应用现有规则可以产生有价值的调查，但并不能推进科学原理。我们必须依靠我们启发式热情的不可言喻的冲动来跨越问题与其解决方案之间的逻辑鸿沟，并且在此过程中必须经历我们智力人格的改变。与所有我们全身心投入其中的冒险一样，这种有意的人格改变需要充满激情的动机来实现。原创性必须充满激情。

Major discoveries change our interpretative framework. Hence it is logically impossible to arrive at these by the continued application of our previous interpretative framework. So we see once more that discovery is creative, in the sense that it is not to be achieved by the diligent performance of any previously known and specifiable procedure. This strengthens our conception of originality. The application of existing rules can produce valuable surveys, but does not advance the principles of science. We have to cross the logical gap between a problem and its solution by relying on the unspecifiable impulse of our heuristic passion, and must undergo as we do so a change of our intellectual personality. Like all ventures in which we comprehensively dispose of ourselves, such an intentional change of our personality requires a passionate motive to accomplish it. Originality must be passionate.

但开普勒的话语也表明，这种追求真理的热情远非绝对正确。开普勒曾因在天体轨道中发现五种立体而欣喜若狂；他认为他所知的六大行星的太阳距离，与柏拉图式天体的大小相对应，而柏拉图式天体的大小是通过内切球和外切球的半径来衡量的。这纯属无稽之谈，无论它与事实多么吻合，我们今天都会认为它是无稽之谈；原因很简单，因为我们不再相信宇宙的基本和谐能够体现在这些简单的几何关系中。156尽管开普勒的现实观在这件事上误入歧途，但它却足够接近真理，引导他正确地发现了行星运动的三大定律。因此，尽管开普勒错误地引用了柏拉图的天体理论，但他在我们看来仍然是一位伟大的科学家。只有当他谈到诸如存在于太阳中的心灵聆听行星的声音，并用乐谱记录下行星的几种音调之类的事情时，我们才不再把他视为科学家，而是一位神秘主义者。我们在此区分两种错误：一种是最终被证明是错误的科学猜测，另一种是不仅错误而且不充分的非科学猜测。

But the words of Kepler show us also that this truth-bearing passion is far from infallible. Kepler rejoiced in his discovery of the five solids among the heavenly orbits; he thought that the solar distances of the six planets known to him corresponded to the sizes of the successive Platonic bodies, as measured by the radii of inscribed and circumscribed spheres. This is nonsense, and we would regard it as nonsense today, however accurately it corresponded to the facts; merely and simply because we no longer believe that the fundamental harmonies of the universe are disclosed in such simple geometrical relations.156 But though his view of reality led Kepler astray in this case, it was close enough to the truth to guide him aright to the discovery of his three laws of planetary motion. Therefore Kepler remains a great scientist to us, in spite of his erroneous reference to the Platonic bodies. It is only when he talks of such things as the mind residing in the sun which listens to the planets, and puts down in musical notation the several tunes of the planets, that we no longer regard him as a scientist, but as a mystic. We draw here a distinction between two kinds of error, namely, scientific guesses which have turned out to be mistaken, and unscientific guesses which are not only false, but incompetent.

因此，理智的激情可能完全被误导，就像拉普拉斯在阐述其客观主义理想时那样；即使是引导正确的激情，例如开普勒的例子，也可能与其他本质上错误的激情交织在一起。另一个例子将证实这一结论，它再次向我们展示了，即使是最伟大的科学家，其理智激情中也包含着多么紧密的真理成分和谬误成分，以及在何种意义上我们仍然可以区分这两者。

Intellectual passions, then, may be altogether misdirected, as were those of Laplace in formulating his objectivist ideal; and even those which lead aright, as in the case of Kepler, may be interwoven with others that are inherently erroneous. A further example will confirm this conclusion, by showing us once more how closely mingled are truth-bearing and fallacious components in the intellectual passions of even the greatest scientists, and in what sense we can yet distinguish between the two.

爱因斯坦在导致相对论发现的思辨中，受马赫的启发，怀揣着一个志向：摆脱当时流行的传统时空观念中固有的误导性假设，代之以一个纯粹人为的框架，用光速绝对恒定的假设取代绝对静止的假设。他不顾常识的反对，视其为习惯的抱怨，采纳了一种新视角，将运动物体的电动力学完美地从传统绝对时空框架强加于其上的所有异常中解放出来。爱因斯坦将这种理性之美视为现实的象征，并进一步推广他的视角，并从中得出一系列令人惊奇的新结论。这是一种科学中不为人知的美，因为它接受了一种新的现实观念。

In his speculations which led to the discovery of relativity, Einstein was guided by his aspiration—stimulated by Mach—to liberate himself from the misleading assumptions inherent in the hitherto current traditional conceptions of space and time, and to replace these by a frankly artificial framework in which the assumption of absolute rest was replaced by that of an absolutely constant velocity of light. Brushing aside the protest of common sense as the complaint of mere habit, he adopted a vision in which the electro-dynamics of moving bodies were set beautifully free from all the anomalies imposed on them by the traditional framework of absolute space and time. Accepting this intellectual beauty as a token of reality, Einstein went on to generalize his vision further and to derive from it a series of new and surprising consequences. This was an unfamiliar beauty in science, for it accepted a new conception of reality.

没有任何振动介质的电磁振动是对自伽利略和牛顿以来物理学界盛行的机械概念的挑战。这种新的美感开创了以数学定义现实的现代视角。

Electromagnetic vibrations without any vibrating medium were an affront to the mechanical conception of things which had prevailed in physics since Galileo and Newton. The new beauty inaugurated the modern view of a mathematically defined reality.

然而，爱因斯坦那敏锐的洞察力也让他能够发现其他线索，这使得他无法将这一观点作为唯一的指导。在他发表相对论著作的同一年（1905年），他通过采用分子运动的具体力学概念解决了布朗运动之谜。这一理论很快被佩兰通过实验证实，重新确立了原子作为物质粒子的现实性，而这一现实性曾被马赫的操作主义断然否定。但是，分子相互作用的力学性质（在这个案例中被如此成功地维护）却成为了绊脚石，因为爱因斯坦基于这些理由拒绝接受量子力学概率的最终现实性。他坚持认为单个分子事件必须由特定的原因决定，但这似乎是错误的。 157

Yet Einstein’s Argus-eyed sensitivity was open to other clues which did not allow him to accept this vision as his only guide. In the same year (1905) in which his work on relativity was published, he solved the riddle of Brownian motion by adopting a concrete mechanical conception of molecular agitation. This theory, soon to be confirmed experimentally by Perrin, re-established the reality of atoms as material particles, which had been peremptorily denied by Mach’s operationalism. But the mechanical character of molecular interactions, so triumphantly upheld in this case, became a stumbling block when Einstein refused on these grounds to accept the ultimate reality of quantum-mechanical probabilities. His insistence that individual molecular events must be determined by specific causes, seems to have been mistaken.157

由此可见，开普勒和爱因斯坦都怀着对自然的求知热情，以及这些热情所蕴含的信念，这既成就了他们的成就，也误导了他们的错误。这些热情和信念是他们个人的，尽管他们坚信它们具有普遍的有效性。我相信，即使他们冒着被这些冲动误导的风险，他们也能够遵循这些冲动。158再说了，今天我承认他们的工作是真实的，我个人也接受这一点，因为我受到与他们相似的激情和信念的引导，而我也坚信我的冲动是有效的、普遍的，尽管我必须承认他们可能是错误的。

So we see that both Kepler and Einstein approached nature with intellectual passions and with beliefs inherent in these passions, which led them to their triumphs and misguided them to their errors. These passions and beliefs were theirs, personally, even though they held them in the conviction that they were valid, universally. I believe that they were competent to follow these impulses, even though they risked being misled by them.158 And again, what I accept of their work as true today, I accept personally, guided by passions and beliefs similar to theirs, holding in my turn that my impulses are valid, universally, even though I must admit the possibility that they may be mistaken.

 

 

  1. 优雅与美丽
  2. ELEGANCE AND BEAUTY

但我尚未处理任何足以证明其为德摩斯梯尼式巨石的严肃反对意见，因为攻克它最终将释放我论证的主要力量。物理学的数学理论是形式系统，通过符号运算应用于经验。伟大的发现可以通过这种方式实现，例如亚当斯和勒威耶根据牛顿力学计算出海王星的位置，或者范特霍夫根据热力学第二定律推导出化学平衡定律。然而，将形式系统重塑为更易于理解的术语可以极大地简化此类操作。这增强了系统的美感和力量，而无需扩大其理论范围；它可以更流畅地讲述关于自然的内容，但其表达能力无法超越以往。因此，我们可以在解释框架中实现更经济、更简洁的表达，并尽情享受这种智慧优雅的展现，而无需提出任何实质性的新观点。

But I have yet to deal with a serious objection which will prove a Demosthenic pebble, as its conquest will finally release the major force of my argument. The mathematical theories of physics are formal systems which are applied to experience by symbolic operations. Great discoveries can be made in this manner, as when Adams and Leverrier computed the position of Neptune from Newtonian mechanics, or van’t Hoff derived the laws of chemical equilibrium from the Second Law of Thermodynamics. Such operations, however, can be greatly facilitated by re-casting a formal system into more manageable terms. This adds to the beauty and power of the system without enlarging its theoretical scope; it can tell more fluently what it says about nature, but cannot say more than it could say before. So we can achieve greater economy and simplicity in our interpretative framework, and keenly enjoy this as the display of intellectual elegance, without saying anything substantially new.

这种承认似乎危及了我们“理论的智性之美是其与现实联系的标志”这一主张。那么，正如马赫所教导的那样，任何理论的优势仅仅在于对观察到的事实进行简洁的描述，难道不是真的吗？

This admission seems to imperil our claim that the intellectual beauty of a theory is a token of its contact with reality. Could it not be true then after all—as Mach taught—that the advantage of any theory is merely to give an economical account of observed facts?

事实上，哥白尼的同时代人早已就哥白尼体系提出并激烈讨论过这个问题。本书开篇，我曾以此体系为例，阐述了作为现实象征的智识之美。早在哥白尼理论发表几年前，纽伦堡一位名叫安德烈亚斯·奥西安德的路德宗牧师就曾力劝哥白尼，认为他的体系只是托勒密理论的一种形式上的进步。奥西安德实际上成功地——我们并不清楚他究竟是如何做到的——在哥白尼著作开篇的“致读者”一文中表达了这一观点。由于哥白尼在1543年出版其著作时已奄奄一息，我们也无法得知他对这段文字有何感想。奥西安德的介入源于一种观点，这种观点在中世纪晚期被频繁捍卫，如今我们熟知的实证主义学说认为，“假设并非信条”，而仅仅是“计算的基础”，因此，只要它们准确地再现了运动现象，其真假都无关紧要。这些引文摘自奥西安德1541年的一封信，信中他恳求哥白尼接受对其理论的约定主义解读，以避免与当时亚里士多德学派和神学正统观念相冲突。 159

This question was actually raised and fiercely discussed already by the contemporaries of Copernicus, in respect to the Copernican system, which I have used at the opening of this book to exemplify intellectual beauty as a token of reality. Some years before the publication of his theory, a Lutheran Minister in Nüremberg, called Andreas Osiander, had urged on Copernicus that his system was merely a formal advance on Ptolemy, and Osiander actually succeeded—we do not know quite by what means—in getting this view stated in an Address to the Reader at the opening of Copernicus’s book. Nor, since Copernicus was dying when his work appeared in print (1543), do we know what he thought of this passage. Osiander was prompted to his intervention by the view, frequently defended in the later Middle Ages and now familiar to us as the teaching of positivism, that ‘hypotheses are not articles of faith’ but merely ‘foundations for calculation’, so that it does not matter whether they are true or false, provided that they reproduce exactly the phenomena of motions. These quotations are taken from a letter written by Osiander in 1541, entreating Copernicus to avoid a conflict with the current Aristotelian and theological orthodoxy, by accepting a conventionalist interpretation of his own theory.159

这一解释遭到了下一代哥白尼学派的强烈反对。焦尔丹诺·布鲁诺称其为一头无知而狂妄的蠢驴的杰作。伽利略对此表示赞同。开普勒宣称：“用虚假的原因来解释自然现象，实在是极其荒谬的虚构。”160这个问题激起了参赛者们的激烈争论，直至生死。乔尔丹诺·布鲁诺坚信哥白尼学说的正确性，并将其扩展为无限多太阳系的构想，这预示了现代恒星空间的概念。哥白尼逝世五十七年后，布鲁诺因其信念被活活烧死。伽利略多年来一直坚持哥白尼体系是真理而非仅仅是一个经济学假设的观点（他从未真正放弃过这一观点），因此遭受的迫害相对较轻。

This interpretation was violently rejected by the Copernicans of the next generation. Giordano Bruno called it the work of an ignorant and presumptuous ass. Galileo agreed. Kepler declared: ‘It is indeed a most absurd fiction to explain natural phenomena by false causes.’160 The issue engaged the contestants passionately to the death. Believing Copernicanism to be true, Giordano Bruno enlarged it to a vision of an indefinite multiplicity of solar systems, which anticipated the modern conception of stellar spaces. Fifty-seven years after the death of Copernicus, Bruno was burnt alive for his convictions. Galileo suffered lesser persecution over a number of years for adhering to the view (which he never sincerely abandoned) that the Copernican system was true and not merely an economical hypothesis.

引起如此深思熟虑并激起如此强烈情感的问题，仅仅是字面意义上的问题：关于“真”字的正确用法的问题吗？实际上，双方对“真”的含义都达成了共识；即真理在于与现实的接触——这种接触注定会通过一系列尚不可预见的后果进一步展现自身。因此，鉴于后来的天文学史，我认为哥白尼学派肯定新体系的真理是正确的，而亚里士多德学派和神学家仅仅承认它具有形式上的优势则是错误的。 161

Was the issue which engaged such minds and roused such fateful passions merely verbal: a question of the proper use of the word ‘true’? Actually, both sides agreed on what they meant by ‘true’; namely, that truth lies in the achievement of a contact with reality—a contact destined to reveal itself further by an indefinite range of yet unforeseen consequences. I believe accordingly—in view of the subsequent history of astronomy—that the Copernicans were right in affirming the truth of the new system, and the Aristotelians and theologians wrong in conceding to it merely a formal advantage.161

但两种观点之间的长期争论也表明，这种区分既困难又至关重要。162提出真正的发现以其成果丰硕为特征，而纯粹形式上的进步则缺乏成果丰硕，这恰恰掩盖了这一难题。除非“成果丰硕”本身就被定义为限定词，否则你无法用成果丰硕来定义真理的不确定的真实力量。托勒密体系一千年来一直是谬误的丰硕根源；占星术两千五百年来一直是占星家丰硕的收入来源；而马克思主义如今已成为三分之一人类统治者丰硕的权力源泉。当我们说哥白尼学说成果丰硕时，我们的意思是它是真理的丰硕源泉，除非通过这样的限定，否则我们无法将其成果丰硕与托勒密体系、占星术或马克思主义的成果丰硕区分开来。在不承认的情况下以这种意义使用“成果丰硕”一词，是一种欺骗性的替代，一种伪替代，一种拉普拉斯式的花招。

But the long controversy between the two views shows also that this distinction is as difficult as it is vital.162 The difficulty is merely covered up by suggesting that a true discovery is characterized by its fruitfulness, which a purely formal advance lacks. You cannot define the indeterminate veridical powers of truth in terms of fruitfulness, unless ‘fruitful’ is itself qualified in terms of the definiendum. The Ptolemaic system was a fruitful source of error for one thousand years; astrology has been a fruitful source of income to astrologers for two thousand five hundred years; Marxism is today a fruitful source of power for the rulers of one third of mankind. When we say that Copernicanism was fruitful, we mean that it was a fruitful source of truth, and we cannot distinguish its kind of fruitfulness from that of the Ptolemaic system, or of astrology, or Marxism, except by such a qualification. To use the word ‘fruitful’ in this sense, without acknowledging it, is a deceptive substitution, a pseudo- substitution, a Laplacean sleight of hand.

但即使“成果丰硕”被理解为引向新真理的能力，它也不足以概括真理。哥白尼主义很可能是真理的源泉——就像《以斯拉记》的伪经之于哥伦布一样——即使它是错误的。但哥白尼体系并非偶然地预见了开普勒和牛顿的发现：它之所以引领他们，是因为它是正确的。我们这样说，是用“真实”一词来承认哥白尼主义的不确定性的真实性：哥白尼主义者反对奥西安德对哥白尼体系的解读时所肯定的这种特性。他们认为，哥白尼体系正是在这个意义上才富有成果的。

But even when ‘fruitfulness’ is taken to mean the capacity for leading to new truths, it is an insufficient characterization of truth. Copernicanism could well have been a source of truth—as the apocryphal text of Esdras was for Columbus—even if it had been false. But the Copernican system did not anticipate the discoveries of Kepler and Newton accidentally: it led to them because it was true. In saying this we are using the term ‘true’ to acknowledge the indeterminate veridical quality of Copernicanism: the quality which the Copernicans affirmed against Osiander’s interpretation of the Copernican system. They believed that this system was fruitful in this and in no other sense.

因此，用“富有成效”取代“真实”似乎是似是而非的。但这同样荒谬，因为它暗示了一种明显荒谬的暗示：富有成效是一种更具体、更有限的品质，无需一路探寻真相就能确定。但当我们

Thus the substitution of ‘fruitful’ for ‘true’ is specious. But it is also nonsensical, for it implies the manifestly absurd suggestion that fruitfulness is a more concrete and limited quality which could be ascertained without going all the way to establish truth. But at the stage when we have

我们对一项发现的价值作出判断，其未来的影响仍然未知。当牛顿发表他的《自然哲学的数学原理》时，任何人都可以看出哥白尼是正确的；但哥白尼和哥白尼主义者，包括牛顿本人，早在这之前就确信了这一点。他们当时所确信的体系的真实性不可能是它后来观察到的成果。试图用对这种信念所预期的成果的观察来取代他们所相信的真理性，就像贝尔曼建议通过蛇鲨第二天的进食习惯来识别它一样。真正的发现的标志不在于它的成果，而在于对其成果的暗示。

to make up our minds about the merits of a discovery its future repercussions are still unknown. By the time Newton published his Principia anyone could see that Copernicus had been right; but Copernicus and the Copernicans, and among these Newton himself, were convinced of it long before this. The veridical quality of the system, of which they were then convinced, could not be its subsequently observed fruitfulness. The attempt to replace the quality of truth, in which they believed, by the observation of the fruitfulness which this belief anticipated, is like the Bellman’s advice for spotting a Snark by its habit of dining the following day. The mark of true discovery is not its fruitfulness but the intimation of its fruitfulness.

诚然，由于对理论进行便捷的重新表述可能会显著提高从中得出新结论的速度，形式上的优势也会带来成果，尽管其意义与接受新发现的人预期其成果的意义不同。但是，当形式上的优势如此巨大，以至于其发明本身就构成一项发现时，这种反对将预期成果作为真正发现标准的异议就完全消失了。达朗贝尔、莫佩尔蒂、拉格朗日和汉密尔顿对牛顿力学的重述体现了这类伟大的发现。这类发现通常伴随着或准备着数学的进步，而人们对它们的欣赏取决于它们与数学发现而非自然科学发现所共有的特质。因此，承认它们在某些物理学理论中的存在，尽管会在某种程度上使这种区别变得复杂，但并不会消除纯粹形式上的优雅与理论的智性之美（一种与外部现实建立新联系的美）之间的区别。

Admittedly—since the convenient reformulation of a theory may considerably enhance the rate at which new consequences are derived from it—a formal advantage also yields fruits, though not in the same sense in which a new discovery is expected to prove fruitful by those who accept it as true. But this objection to the anticipation of fruitfulness as a criterion of true discovery dissolves altogether when the formal advantage is of such magnitude that its contrivance does amount to a discovery. The restatements of Newtonian mechanics by d’Alembert, Maupertuis, Lagrange, and Hamilton embodied great discoveries of this kind. Such discoveries are usually accompanied or prepared by advances in mathematics, and their appreciation rests on qualities which they share with mathematical discoveries, rather than with discoveries in the natural sciences. So the recognition of their presence in some theories of physics does not obliterate, though it somewhat complicates, the distinction between a merely formal elegance and the intellectual beauty of a theory, a beauty which establishes a new contact with external reality.

然而，我的分析如今已过于泛化，偏离了其根源——哥白尼主义和相对论的历史。我必须先用其他例子来补充这些典型案例，以佐证物理学中理论发现的本质，以及这种发现与纯粹形式主义进步之间的区别，才能继续深入。

However, my analysis has by now proliferated too widely from its roots in the history of Copernicanism and Relativity. I must go no further without first supplementing these paradigmatic cases by other instances substantiating the nature of theoretical discovery in physics, and the difference between such discovery and an advance of a purely formal character.

路易·德布罗意（Louis de Broglie，1923年）纯粹出于理性之美，建议将波动性赋予可重粒子，便是一个恰当的例子。他向其提交了博士学位论文的教授们（包括保罗·朗之万）犹豫是否接受，并写信给爱因斯坦征求意见。爱因斯坦认可了该论文的科学价值，并正式授予了该论文的作者。1但当时没有人意识到，德布罗意的公式暗示电子束会产生类似于X射线的衍射图样，而这一结果最早是由W.Elsasser于1925年提出的。 163

The suggestion made by Louis de Broglie (1923), purely on grounds of intellectual beauty, to ascribe wave nature to ponderable particles, is a case in point. The professors (who included Paul Langevin) to whom he presented the work for the Doctorate were doubtful whether to accept it and wrote to Einstein for advice. The latter recognized its scientific merit and the degree was duly awarded to its author.1 But no one realised at the time that de Broglie’s formulae implied that electronic beams would give diffraction patterns similar to those of X-rays, a consequence which was first envisaged by W.Elsasser in 1925.163

再者，狄拉克（1928年）成功调和量子力学与相对论的数学框架，也展现出一些难以理解的特征，这些特征最终被证明是对正电子的描述，而这种粒子最终于1932年被安德森独立发现。这类早期例子包括威拉德·吉布斯（Willard Gibbs）的工作，他一直被认为纯粹是形式上的，直到巴克赫伊斯·鲁泽布姆（Bakhuis Roozeboom）发现了相律的广泛而富有启发性的适用性。更近的例子是德·唐德（de Donder）的巨著热力学推测，虽然在20世纪20年代发表时并未引起任何反响，但在新的不可逆系统热力学中，他们却获得了成功，人们发现这些推测在一定程度上预见了这一系统。然而，科学史只记录了美好的结局；更常见的是，形式上的推测最终毫无进展。范拉尔关于热力学势的无数论文，与德·唐德的论文发表时间大致相同，或许是众多此类不幸案例中的一个。这种功绩被大量的琐碎之事所稀释，使得真正的科学价值难以被认可。

Again, the mathematical framework by which Dirac succeeded (1928) in reconciling quantum mechanics with relativity, showed some incomprehensible features which were to turn out eventually to be a description of the positive electron, when this particle was discovered, independently, by Anderson in 1932. Among earlier examples of this kind is the work of Willard Gibbs which was regarded as purely formal, until Bakhuis Roozeboom discovered the wide and illuminating applicability of the Phase Rule. More recently, the voluminous thermodynamic speculations of de Donder, published without gaining any response in the 1920’s, came into their own within the new thermodynamics of irreversible systems which they were found to have partly anticipated. But the history of science records only happy endings; far more frequent are formal speculations which lead nowhere. The innumerable papers of van Laar on the thermodynamic potential, published about the same time as de Donder’s papers, may be remembered among a vast multitude of such unfortunate cases. This dilution of the meritorious by floods of triviality makes the recognition of true scientific value particularly difficult.

让我在此稍作停顿。我相信，现在有三件事已经毋庸置疑：理智之美揭示自然真理的力量；区分这种美与单纯的形式吸引力至关重要；以及两者之间检验的微妙之处，其难度之大，甚至可能让最敏锐的科学家都感到困惑。

Let me stop here for a moment. I believe that by now three things have been established beyond reasonable doubt: the power of intellectual beauty to reveal truth about nature; the vital importance of distinguishing this beauty from merely formal attractiveness; and the delicacy of the test between them, so difficult that it may baffle the most penetrating scientific minds.

我本可以用这些结论来结束本节，并留待以后再思考；但我担心，在许多读者心中，我的证据的说服力可能只会激起一种日益增长的不安感。我曾看到许多大学里的听众默默地、带着阴郁的厌恶听我讲述直觉的发现。然后，一个讽刺的声音会问，演讲者是否认为做实验真的有用；还有另一个声音会问，基于这样的理由，占星术的解释是否同样站不住脚。这些都是重要的问题。

I might have closed this section with these conclusions and carried them forward for later reflection; but I fear that in many readers’ minds the convincing power of my evidence may have evoked only a growing feeling of uneasiness. I have watched many a university audience listening to my account of intuitive discoveries silently, with sullen distaste. Then an ironical voice would ask whether the speaker thought that there was any use at all in making experiments; and yet another, whether on such grounds as these, explanations in terms of astrology would not be equally justified. These are important questions.

第一个问题的答案是，经验是理解自然不可或缺的线索，即便它并不决定对自然的理解。爱因斯坦曾谈到“直觉的理解”（ein intuitives Heranfühlen an die Tatsachen），我将其称之为对事实意义的探索。我们探索的这种经验指导，蕴含着形式上的进步与对事物本质的全新洞察之间的所有区别——难以捉摸却又至关重要。这种难以捉摸之处从何而来？它反映在最高科学成就的画布上，即我们永远无法确切地说出我们的意思是什么，甚至无法说清我们是否真的有某种意义。当我们最终决定接受一个理论作为关于自然界新事物的真实陈述时，意义的不确定性并没有被消除，而只是受到了限制。因为，尽管我们因此坚定地相信关于某些事物的信念，但除非其范围仍然不确定，否则这种信念就无法与现实产生任何关系。

The answer to the first is that experience is an indispensable clue to the understanding of nature, even though it does not determine its understanding. Einstein speaks of ‘ein intuitives Heranfühlen an die Tatsachen’, which 1 should call a groping for the meaning of the facts. In this empirical guidance of our groping lies all the difference—elusive and yet utterly decisive—between a merely formal advance and a new insight into the nature of things. Whence this elusiveness? It is a reflection on the canvas of the highest scientific achievement of the fact that we can never tell exactly what we mean, or even whether we mean anything at all. Indeterminacy of meaning is not eliminated, but only restricted, when we eventually decide to accept a theory as a true statement of something new about nature. For, while we heavily commit ourselves thereby to a belief concerning certain things, such a belief can have no bearing on reality unless its scope is still left indeterminate.

第二个问题，即我们为什么应该选择科学而非占星术，答案难以简略给出。在下一节中，我将逐步深入探讨这个问题，并在第三部分的结尾给出一个相当确定的答案；但本书的整个篇幅都是为了对这类问题寻求实质性的答案。最终，我应该能够用既不武断又不浮夸的语气说出：“我不接受任何基于占星术的解释，因为我不相信它们是真的。”

The answer to the second question, why we should prefer science to astrology, cannot be given briefly. In the next section I shall approach it by one step and a fairly conclusive reply will be reached at the end of Part Three; but the whole of this book is but a quest for a substantial reply to a question of this kind. In the end I should be able to say as a statement that will appear neither dogmatic nor trivial: ‘I do not entertain explanations in terms of astrology, for I do not believe them to be true.’

 

 

  1. 科学争议
  2. SCIENTIFIC CONTROVERSY

启发式热情不求个人拥有。它并非为了征服，而是为了丰富世界。然而，这样的举动也是一种攻击。它向他人提出了要求，并提出了巨大的要求；因为它要求所有人接受它赋予人类的礼物。为了得到满足，我们的智识热情必须得到回应。这种普遍的意图造成了一种紧张：当我们致力于的现实愿景被他人轻蔑地忽视时，我们就会感到痛苦。因为普遍的不信会在我们心中激起回响，危及我们自身的信念。我们的愿景必须征服，否则就会消亡。

Heuristic passion seeks no personal possession. It sets out not to conquer, but to enrich the world. Yet such a move is also an attack. It raises a claim and makes a tremendous demand on other men; for it asks that its gift to humanity be accepted by all. In order to be satisfied, our intellectual passions must find response. This universal intent creates a tension: we suffer when a vision of reality to which we have committed ourselves is contemptuously ignored by others. For a general unbelief imperils our own convictions by evoking an echo in us. Our vision must conquer or die.

正如其所源于的启发式热情一样，说服式热情也面临着逻辑上的缺口。发现者在多大程度上致力于新的现实视角，就将自己与那些仍然固守旧派思维的人区分开来。他的说服式热情如今激励他跨越这一缺口，通过让所有人接受他看待事物的方式，正如他的启发式热情曾经激励他跨越将他与发现隔离开来的启发式缺口一样。

Like the heuristic passion from which it flows, the persuasive passion too finds itself facing a logical gap. To the extent to which a discoverer has committed himself to a new vision of reality, he has separated himself from others who still think on the old lines. His persuasive passion spurs him now to cross this gap by converting everybody to his way of seeing things, even as his heuristic passion has spurred him to cross the heuristic gap which separated him from discovery.

因此，我们可以看出，为什么科学争议从来不完全局限于科学领域。因为，当一个涉及一整类所谓事实的新思想体系成为争论焦点时，问题在于它应该在原则上被接受还是被拒绝，而那些基于如此全面的理由而拒绝它的人必然会认为它完全不合格且不健全。以四个当代问题为例：弗洛伊德的精神分析、爱丁顿的先验物理学体系、莱因的“心智范围”或李森科的环境遗传学。这里提到的四位作者都有各自的概念框架，他们以此来识别事实，并在其中进行论证，并且每个人都用自己独特的术语来表达自己的概念。任何这样的框架都相对稳定，因为它可以解释大多数它认为已得到充分证实的证据，并且它本身足够连贯，足以让其追随者满意地暂时忽略那些它无法解释的事实或所谓的事实。相应地，它与任何根植于不同经验观念的知识或所谓的知识相隔离。这两种相互冲突的思想体系之间存在着逻辑鸿沟，就像问题与解决问题的发现之间存在着逻辑鸿沟一样。依赖于一种解释框架的形式运算无法向依赖于另一种框架的人阐明命题。这种框架的倡导者甚至可能无法获得这些人的倾听，因为他们必须首先教会他们一门新的语言，而任何人都无法学习一门新的语言，除非他首先相信它有意义。敌对的听众实际上可能会故意拒绝接受弗洛伊德、爱丁顿、莱因或李森科等人的新概念，正是因为他们担心，一旦接受了这个框架，他们就会得出他们——无论对错——都厌恶的结论。新体系的支持者只有首先赢得听众对他们尚未掌握的学说的理智同情，才能说服他们。那些充满同情地倾听的人会发现自己原本永远不会理解的东西。这种接受是一个启发式的过程，一种自我修正的行为，在某种程度上也是一种转变。它培养出形成学派的信徒，而学派内部的成员与学派外部的成员之间，暂时存在着逻辑鸿沟。他们思维方式不同，语言不同，生活在不同的世界，并且至少有一派（无论正确与否）暂时被排除在科学界之外。

We can see, therefore, why scientific controversies never lie altogether within science. For when a new system of thought concerning a whole class of alleged facts is at issue, the question will be whether it should be accepted or rejected in principle, and those who reject it on such comprehensive grounds will inevitably regard it as altogether incompetent and unsound. Take, for example, four contemporary issues: Freud’s psychoanalysis, Eddington’s a priori system of physics, Rhine’s ‘Reach of the Mind’, or Lysenko’s environmental genetics. Each of the four authors mentioned here has his own conceptual framework, by which he identifies his facts and within which he conducts his arguments, and each expresses his conceptions in his own distinctive terminology. Any such framework is relatively stable, for it can account for most of the evidence which it accepts as well established, and it is sufficiently coherent in itself to justify to the satisfaction of its followers the neglect for the time being of facts, or alleged facts, which it cannot interpret. It is correspondingly segregated from any knowledge or alleged knowledge rooted in different conceptions of experience. The two conflicting systems of thought are separated by a logical gap, in the same sense as a problem is separated from the discovery which solves the problem. Formal operations relying on one framework of interpretation cannot demonstrate a proposition to persons who rely on another framework. Its advocates may not even succeed in getting a hearing from these, since they must first teach them a new language, and no one can learn a new language unless he first trusts that it means something. A hostile audience may in fact deliberately refuse to entertain novel conceptions such as those of Freud, Eddington, Rhine or Lysenko, precisely because its members fear that once they have accepted this framework they will be led to conclusions which they—rightly or wrongly—abhor. Proponents of a new system can convince their audience only by first winning their intellectual sympathy for a doctrine they have not yet grasped. Those who listen sympathetically will discover for themselves what they would otherwise never have understood. Such an acceptance is a heuristic process, a self-modifying act, and to this extent a conversion. It produces disciples forming a school, the members of which are separated for the time being by a logical gap from those outside it. They think differently, speak a different language, live in a different world, and at least one of the two schools is excluded to this extent for the time being (whether rightly or wrongly) from the community of science.

现在，我们也能看到，试图说服他人接受科学新观点时可能遇到的巨大困难。我们已经看到，如果新观点代表了一种新的推理方式，我们就无法通过正式的论证说服他人，因为只要我们在他们的框架内进行论证，就永远无法诱导他们放弃它。因此，除了论证之外，还必须辅以能够促成转变的说服形式。拒绝接受对手的论证方式，必须通过使其显得完全不合理来证明其合理性。

We can now see, also, the great difficulty that may arise in the attempt to persuade others to accept a new idea in science. We have seen that to the extent to which it represents a new way of reasoning, we cannot convince others of it by formal argument, for so long as we argue within their framework, we can never induce them to abandon it. Demonstration must be supplemented, therefore, by forms of persuasion which can induce a conversion. The refusal to enter on the opponent’s way of arguing must be justified by making it appear altogether unreasonable.

这种全面的否定必然会使对手名誉扫地。他会显得完全被蒙蔽了双眼，在激烈的争论中，这很容易让人误以为他是个傻瓜、怪人或骗子。一旦我们着手建立这些指控，我们就会毫不犹豫地揭露对手是“形而上学家”、“耶稣会士”、“犹太人”或“布尔什维克”，视情况而定——或者，从铁幕的另一边来说，是“客观主义者”、“理想主义者”和“世界主义者”。在一场智识激情的碰撞中，双方必然会攻击对手本人。

Such comprehensive rejection cannot fail to discredit the opponent. He will be made to appear as thoroughly deluded, which in the heat of the battle will easily come to imply that he was a fool, a crank or a fraud. And once we are out to establish such charges we shall readily go on to expose our opponent as a ‘metaphysician’, a ‘Jesuit’, a ‘Jew’, or a ‘Bolshevik’, as the case may be—or, speaking from the other side of the Iron Curtain—as an ‘objectivist’, an ‘idealist’ and a ‘cosmopolitan’. In a clash of intellectual passions each side must inevitably attack the opponent’s person.

即使回过头来看，这类冲突也常常只能从这些角度来理解。它们并非以科学论证的形式出现，而是以对立的科学观点之间的冲突，或以科学价值观与外部利益之间的冲突的形式出现，这些利益非法干涉了科学探究的正当程序。为了说明这一点，我将在此回顾四场争论。第一场是哥白尼式的争论，我之前曾提到过。后三场争论发生在19世纪，其结果与前一场一样，对我们如今的科学价值观的形成发挥了重要作用。

Even in retrospect such conflicts can often be appreciated only in these terms. They do not appear as scientific arguments, but as conflicts between rival scientific visions, or else between scientific values and extraneous interests interfering illegitimately with the due process of scientific enquiry. I shall recall here four controversies to illustrate this. The first is the Copernican, to which I have already had occasion to refer. The other three occurred in the nineteenth century and their outcome, like that of the earlier one, had an effective part in developing our present sense of scientific value.

托勒密学说和哥白尼学说长期以来相互对立，它们实际上是两个几乎完整的体系，却被逻辑上的鸿沟所隔开。从哥白尼《天体运行论》出版到牛顿《自然哲学的数学原理》问世的148年间，任何时期已知的事实都可以用其中任何一个理论来解释。到1619年，开普勒第三定律的发现或许已经使天平向哥白尼学说倾斜。164但恒星观测角度没有任何季节性变化，这仍然给这个系统带来了严重的困难。运动中的落体不会垂直落向地球的错误论证已被伽利略驳斥；但他对潮汐的解释，尽管他认为这是地球自转的关键证据，却也犯了类似的错误。他发现木星的卫星或许具有启发性，但其重要性却不足以证明他对那些拒绝用望远镜观察这些卫星的人的轻蔑谩骂是合理的。165伽利略坚定信念的真正基础在于他对日心说更高科学价值的热情赞赏：这种情感因他对亚里士多德凌驾于科学之上的权威的愤怒反抗而更加强烈。他的对手们则持有常识性的观点，认为地球静止不动，而且最重要的是，他们深刻地意识到人类是宇宙中唯一对上帝负责的粒子，其独特性。他们渴望为人类保留与其在宇宙中的重要性相符的位置，这种情感力量与哥白尼学说的智识吸引力形成了鲜明对比。 166

The Ptolemaic and Copernican theories opposed each other for a long time as two virtually complete systems separated by a logical gap. The facts known at any time during the 148 years from the publication of Copernicus’ De Revolutionibus to the appearance of Newton’s Principia could be accounted for by either theory. By 1619 the discovery of Kepler’s third law may have tipped the balance in favour of Copernicanism,164 but the non-appearance of any seasonal variation in the angle at which the fixed stars are seen continued to present a serious difficulty to this system. The mistaken argument that falling bodies would not descend vertically to earth if it were in motion was disproved by Galileo; but his explanation of the tides, which he regarded as a crucial proof of terrestrial rotation, fell into a similar error. His discovery of Jupiter’s moons was perhaps suggestive, but its significance hardly justified his scornful invective against those who refused to look at these moons through his telescope.165 The real ground of Galileo’s conviction lay in his passionate appreciation of the greater scientific value of the heliocentric view: a feeling which was accentuated by his angry rebellion against Aristotle’s authority over science. His opponents had on their side the common-sense view which sees the earth at rest, and, above all, a vivid consciousness of man’s uniqueness as the only particle of the universe that feels responsible to God. Their craving to retain for man a location which corresponds to his importance in the universe was the emotional force opposed to the intellectual appeal of Copernicanism.166

哥白尼主义的胜利拒绝并压制了这一要求，认为它是对科学追求的非法干涉，并确立了科学真理不应考虑其宗教或道德影响的原则。但这一原则并非无可争议。如今，苏联的理论认为，所有科学都是阶级科学，必须以“党派主义”（partynost）为指导，这一理论也拒绝接受这一原则。天主教会也对此提出质疑，例如在1950年的《人类的起源》通谕中，以及世界各地的圣经原教旨主义者也对此提出质疑。我反对对事物进行普遍的机械解释，理由是它会损害人类的道德意识，这也在某种程度上意味着我对科学绝对道德中立性的异议。然而，尽管这个问题尚未完全解决，道德和宗教漠不关心的原则在整个现代科学中盛行，迄今为止尚未遇到任何有效的挑战，而哥白尼论战的结果仍然为这一原则提供了强有力的支持。 167

The victory of Copernicanism rejected and suppressed this demand as an illegitimate interference with the pursuit of science, and established the principle that scientific truth shall take no account of its religious or moral repercussions. But this principle is not incontestable. It is rejected today by the Soviet theory that all science is class science and must be guided by ‘partynost’, party-spirit. It is contested also by the Catholic Church, as for example in the Encyclical Humani Generis of 1950, and similarly by biblical fundamentalists everywhere. My opposition to a universal mechanical interpretation of things, on the ground that it impairs man’s moral consciousness, also implies some measure of dissent from the absolute moral neutrality of science. Yet though the issue is not altogether closed, the principle of moral and religious indifference prevails throughout modern science without facing so far any effective rival to its rule, and the outcome of the Copernican controversy continues to form an eminent support for this principle.167

现代科学的另一个信条，源于其早期与亚里士多德和经院哲学传统的冲突，即其经验主义理想。尽管我并不完全认同这种理想，因为我认为从科学中剔除个人知识将会摧毁科学，但我承认经验主义在开辟现代科学之路方面所取得的决定性成就。当然，我也不否认科学始终面临着空洞思辨的威胁，必须谨慎抵制并加以摒弃；但我认为，个人知识在科学中所扮演的角色使得我们无法制定任何精确的规则来区分此类思辨与正确进行的经验研究。经验主义只有作为一条准则才是有效的，而其应用本身也构成了认知艺术的一部分。一些科学争议的例子，在这些争议中，科学经验主义的准则获得了其当前的意义，这将表明经验主义的主张在一些重要情况下是多么具有争议性和误导性。

Another tenet of modern science which emerged at an early stage from its conflict with the Aristotelian and scholastic tradition is its ideal of empiricism. Though I dissent from this ideal in its absolute form, since I hold that the elimination of personal knowledge from science would destroy science, I acknowledge the decisive achievements of empiricism in opening the way to modern science. Nor do I deny, of course, that science is constantly in danger from the incursion of empty speculations, which must be watchfully resisted and cast out; but I hold that the part played by personal knowledge in science makes it impossible to formulate any precise rule by which such speculations can be distinguished from properly conducted empirical investigations. Empiricism is valid only as a maxim, the application of which itself forms a part of the art of knowing. Some examples of the scientific controversies in which maxims of scientific empiricism have acquired their current meaning will show how controversial and misleading the claims of empiricism have proved in some important instances.

年轻的黑格尔对科学的经验方法进行不切实际的攻击，并很快被科学家们击败，这是现代科学形成过程中最伟大的经历之一。1800 年，由波德领导的六位德国天文学家出发寻找一颗新行星，以填补火星和木星之间行星距离数列的空白。该数列由提丢斯发现，称为波德定律。该数列的方法是先写下数字 4，然后写下数列 3+4、2×3+4、2 2 × 3+4、2 3 × 3+4……等。这给出了前八位：4、7、10、16、28、52、100、196，只要去掉第五个数字，这些数字就可以很好地对应到 1800 年已知的七颗行星的相对距离。将地球距离任意设置为 10，您将得到以下表格：

The quixotic attack of the young Hegel on the empirical method of science and his swift defeat at the hands of the scientists was one of the great formative experiences of modern science. In the year 1800 a band of six German astronomers, led by Bode, set out to search for a new planet to fill a gap between Mars and Jupiter in the numerical series of planetary distances, discovered by Titius and known as Bode’s Law. The series is obtained by writing down the number 4, followed by the series 3+4, 2×3+4, 22×3+4, 23×3+4…etc. This gives for the first eight places: 4, 7, 10, 16, 28, 52, 100, 196, which can be shown to correspond pretty well to the relative distances of the seven planets known in 1800, provided you leave out the fifth number. Setting the distance of the Earth arbitrarily at 10 you have the table:

年轻的黑格尔对追寻一条毫无意义、只能是偶然的数字规则的探究嗤之以鼻。他认为，由内在理性塑造的自然界必然受制于合理的数字序列，并假设行星之间的相对间距必须符合毕达哥拉斯数列：1、2、3、4（2 2）、9（3 2 ）、 8（2 3）、27（3 3）——然而，他用16代替了8。这将行星的数量限制在7颗，并在第四颗行星和第五颗行星（即火星和木星）之间留下了巨大的空隙。因此，寻找第八颗行星来填补这一空隙的想法纯属空想。168

The young Hegel poured scorn on an enquiry following up a numerical rule which, being meaningless, could only be accidental. Arguing that nature, shaped by immanent reason, must be governed by a rational sequence of numbers, he postulated that the relative spacing of the planets must conform to the Pythagorean series 1, 2, 3, 4(22), 9(32), 8(23), 27(33)—in which, however, he substituted 16 for 8. This would limit the number of planets to 7 and allow a large gap between the fourth and fifth planet, i.e. Mars and Jupiter. The quest for an eighth planet to fill this gap was therefore chimerical.168

 

 

1800 年的波德定律

 

 

预测

Predicted

 

 

观察到

Observed

汞

 

 

43·9
金星

 

 

77·2
地球

 

 

（10）（10）
火星

木星

 

 

5252
土星

天王星

 

 

196192

 

 

然而，1801年1月1日，博德的天文学家团队在该区域发现了一颗名为谷神星的小行星。自那时起，人们在该区域发现了超过500颗小行星，其中2169这些可能是曾经占据这个地方的完整行星的碎片。

However, on January 1st, 1801, Bode’s party of astronomers discovered the small planet Ceres in the region in question. Since then over 500 small planets have been found in that neighbourhood,2169and it may be that these are fragments of a full sized planet that once occupied this place.

黑格尔大失所望，天文学家们却欢欣鼓舞。这一切都是好事，因为它证实了一种更为合理的科学价值观念。但我们应该意识到，它几乎没有其他支撑。波德定律是否有任何合理的基础，或者迄今为止的应验仅仅是巧合（正如黑格尔所想）至今仍有待商榷；过去20年来，人们对这个问题的看法已多次发生变化。170因此，黑格尔拒绝天文学家寻找新行星的理由可能是正确的。

Hegel was discomfited and the astronomers triumphed gleefully. This was all to the good, for it confirmed a juster sense of scientific value. But we should realise that it had little else to support it. Whether Bode’s Law has any rational foundation or has been fulfilled so far by mere coincidence (as Hegel had thought) is still open to question today; opinions have changed on the subject repeatedly during the last 20 years.170 Thus Hegel may have been right in rejecting the astronomers’ grounds for the search for a new planet.

体系，所以这是天文学家作为科学家有权做出的一种猜测。这是一种合理的猜测，而且——如果波德定律有任何真理的话——甚至是一种真正的猜测；而黑格尔的推论则完全不科学，是不合理的。幸运的是，黑格尔猜错了，而天文学家的猜测虽然可能没有道理，但却击中了目标。但即使黑格尔的猜测被证明是正确的，而天文学家的猜测是错误的，我们仍然会拒绝黑格尔对现实的看法，坚持天文学家的看法。

system, and so it was a kind of guess to which astronomers as scientists are entitled. It was a competent guess, and—if Bode’s Law has any truth in it—even a true guess; while Hegel’s inference was altogether unscientific, incompetent. Fortunately Hegel guessed wrong and the astronomers, though their guess was perhaps unjustified, did hit the mark. But even if Hegel’s guess had proved right and the astronomers’ wrong, we would still reject Hegel’s vision of reality and cleave to that of the astronomers.

科学家对自然哲学的反感是强烈而持久的。到本世纪中叶，经验主义已占据主导地位，无人能撼动。171但不幸的是，实证研究方法及其相关的科学价值概念和现实本质概念远非明确，因此对它的各种相互矛盾的解释不得不再次从逻辑鸿沟的角度相互争论。

The revulsion of scientists against Naturphilosophie was violent and lasting. By the middle of the century empiricism ruled unchallenged.171 But unfortunately the empirical method of enquiry—with its associated conceptions of scientific value and of the nature of reality—is far from unambiguous, and conflicting interpretations of it had therefore ever again to fight each other from either side of a logical gap.

J.Hvant Hoff 于 1875 年向乌得勒支大学提交了博士论文，提出了含有不对称碳原子的化合物具有光学活性的理论。1877 年，该论文的德文译本问世，并由杰出的德国化学家、光学活性领域的权威 Wislicenus 撰写了一篇推荐性导言。这篇论文的发表引起了另一位德国著名化学家 Kolbe 的猛烈抨击，Kolbe 当时刚刚发表了一篇名为《时代的标志》的文章。172他严厉批评了德国化学家们严谨科学训练的衰落；他说，这种衰落导致了

In his doctoral thesis, presented in 1875 to the University of Utrecht, J.H.van’t Hoff had put forward the theory that compounds containing an asymmetric carbon atom are optically active. In 1877 there appeared a German translation of this work with a commendatory introduction by Wislicenus, a distinguished German chemist and an authority on optical activity. This publication evoked a furious attack from Kolbe, another leading German chemist, who had recently published an article called ‘Signs of the Times’,172 in which he castigated the decline of rigorous scientific training among German chemists; a decline which, he said, had led to a renewed sprouting of

 

 

看似博学辉煌，但实际上琐碎空洞的自然哲学，在 50 年前被精确科学取代后，现在又一次被伪科学家从人类谬误的杂物室里挖出来，像一个妓女，穿上优雅的衣服，化上精致的妆，偷偷溜进她并不属于的体面的社交圈。

the weeds of a seemingly learned and brilliant but actually trivial and empty Philosophy of Nature, which, after having been replaced some 50 years ago by the exact sciences, is now once more dug up by pseudo-scientists from the lumber room of human fallacies, and like a trollop, newly attired in elegant dress and make-up, is smuggled into respectable company, to which she does not belong.

 

 

在第二篇论文中，173他又举了范特霍夫作品的例子来说明这种偏差，范特霍夫的作品“会像许多其他同类努力一样被忽视”，但“令人费解的是”，它竟然得到了像维斯利切努斯这样杰出的化学家的热情推荐。科尔贝写道：

In a second paper,173 he gave as a further example of this aberration an account of van’t Hoff’s work which ‘he would have ignored like many other efforts of its kind’ but for ‘the incomprehensible fact’ of its warm recommendation by so distinguished a chemist as Wislicenus. So Kolbe wrote:

 

 

乌得勒支兽医学院聘用的JHvan't Hoff博士似乎对精确的化学研究毫无兴趣。他觉得更方便的是骑上飞马座（无疑是从兽医学院借来的），在他的《太空化学》中宣称，在他勇敢地飞向化学帕纳索斯山的过程中，原子在他看来是如何在世界空间中排列的。

A certain Dr. J.H.van’t Hoff, employed by the Veterinary Academy at Utrecht, appears to have no taste for exact chemical research. He found it more convenient to mount Pegasus (borrowed no doubt from the Veterinary Academy) and to proclaim in his La Chimie dans l’espace how on his daring flight to the chemical Parnassus the atoms appeared to him disposed in world space.

 

 

科尔贝对维斯利切努斯为范特霍夫理论所作引言的评论，进一步揭示了他批评的原则。维斯利切努斯曾写道：“这是碳化合物理论发展过程中真正重要的一步，这一步是有机的、内在必然的。” 科尔贝问道：“什么是‘碳化合物理论’？‘这一步是有机的、必然的’是什么意思？” 他接着说道：“维斯利切努斯在此将自己从精确科学家的行列中驱逐出去，转而加入了那些不祥记忆中的自然哲学家的行列，他们与唯灵论者之间仅隔着一层薄薄的‘媒介’。”

Kolbe’s comment on the introduction given by Wislicenus to van’t Hoff’s theory reveals even further the principles of his criticism. Wislicenus had written of ‘this real and important step in the advancement of the theory of carbon compounds, a step which was organic and internally necessary’. Kolbe asks: What is ‘the theory of carbon compounds’? What is meant by saying that ‘this step was organic and necessary’? And he goes on: ‘Wislicenus has here expelled himself from the ranks of exact scientists and has joined instead the nature philosophers of ominous memory who are separated only by a slender “medium” from the spiritists.’

科学界最终驳斥了科尔贝对范特霍夫和维斯利切努斯的攻击，但他对推测化学（“纸上化学”）的怀疑仍然得到了大多数主流化学期刊的认同，这些期刊至今仍拒绝发表任何不包含新实验结果的投稿。尽管化学很大程度上基于道尔顿、凯库勒和范特霍夫的推测，而这些推测最初并没有任何实验观察的佐证，174化学家们仍然对这类工作心存疑虑。由于他们缺乏足够的自信来区分真正的理论发现和空洞的推测，他们不得不根据一种假设行事，这​​种假设或许有一天会导致一篇极其重要的理论论文被拒，而一些相对琐碎的实验研究却被接受。即使是领域内的专家，也很难根据经验主义的标准来区分科学价值和无用论调。

Scientific opinion eventually repudiated Kolbe’s attack on van’t Hoff and Wislicenus, but his suspicion of speculative chemistry (‘paper chemistry’) continues to be shared by most of the leading chemical journals, which refuse up to this day contributions containing no new experimental results. In spite of the fact that chemistry is largely based on the speculations by Dalton, Kekulé and van’t Hoff, which were initially unaccompanied by any experimental observations,174 chemists still remain suspicious of this kind of work. Since they do not sufficiently trust themselves to distinguish true theoretical discoveries from empty speculations, they feel compelled to act on a presumption which may one day cause the rejection of a theoretical paper of supreme importance in favour of comparatively trivial experimental studies. So difficult is it even for the expert in his own field to distinguish, by the criteria of empiricism, scientific merit from incompetent chatter.

这不仅适用于纯理论发现。关于酒精发酵本质的激烈争论始于1839年，持续了近四十年，表明验证实验观察结果也可能遭遇同样的困难。从1835年到1837年，至少有四位独立观察者（Caignard de la Tour、Schwann、Kützing和Turpin）报告称，发酵过程中产生的酵母并非化学沉淀物，而是由通过出芽繁殖的活细胞生物体组成，并得出结论：发酵是酵母细胞的一种生命功能。175但这违背了当代科学家主导的求知热情。1828年，沃勒用无机材料合成了尿素，并由此成功推翻了迄今为止被认为专属于生物体的力量的存在。李比希紧随其后，奠定了用化学方法研究所有生物体的基础；贝采利乌斯则认识到铂可以加速在其存在下发生的反应，就像酵母引发发酵一样。这三位大师都对这些说法嗤之以鼻，认为它们是他们永远禁止的那种“活力论”的异想天开的复活。沃勒和李比希发表了一篇精心编排的短剧，嘲讽这些荒谬的推测。176

Nor does this apply only to purely theoretical discoveries. The great controversy on the nature of alcoholic fermentation which, starting in 1839, went on for almost forty years, showed that the verification of an experimental observation may run into precisely the same difficulties. From 1835 to 1837 no less than four independent observers (Caignard de la Tour, Schwann, Kützing and Turpin) had reported that yeast produced during fermentation was not a chemical precipitate, but consisted of living cellular organisms which multiplied by budding, and had concluded that fermentation was a living function of yeast cells.175 But this went against the dominant intellectual passion of contemporary scientists. In 1828, Wöhler had synthetized urea from inorganic materials and had triumphantly disproved thereby the existence of powers hitherto ascribed exclusively to living beings. Liebig had followed suit by laying the foundations of a chemical approach to all living matter, and Berzelius recognized that platinum could speed up reactions occurring in its presence, in the same way in which fermentation was caused by yeast. All three great masters poured scorn on claims which they regarded as a fantastic resurgence of the kind of ‘vitalism’ they had banned for ever. Wöhler and Liebig published an elaborate skit making fun of these absurd speculations.176

1857年，巴斯德加入了“活力论者”的行列。他对酵母和腐败现象的研究，同时也使他卷入了另一场旷日持久的激烈争论——“自然发生”问题。在这个问题上，他当时也被认为是反动派（在撰写本文时，苏联仍然如此），他们否认可以通过实验从死物质中产生生物。 177

In 1857 Pasteur entered the lists on the side of the ‘vitalists’. His investigations on yeast and putrefaction involved him at the same time in another fierce controversy of longer standing, the question of ‘spontaneous generation’. In this, too, he was on the side considered at the time reactionary (and still so considered, at the time of writing this, in the Soviet Union), which denied that living beings could be produced experimentally from dead matter.177

巴斯德在谈到自己将发酵视为酵母活细胞功能的论点时，曾说过这样一句话，揭示了这两场争论为何会无限期地拖延下去：“如果有人说我的结论超出了既定事实（他写道），我会表示同意，因为我毫无保留地坚持我的立场，严格来说，这些立场是无法无可辩驳地得到证明的。”178因此，这种思想体系与李比希、沃勒以及他那个时代的许多其他伟人所持有的思想体系之间存在着逻辑鸿沟。这种分歧最终被一场概念改革所弥合，这场改革是由布赫纳于1897年发现酵母细胞榨出的液体中含有酵母酶而引发的。发酵剂被证明是一种李比希和贝采利乌斯所设想的死催化剂，但它也证明了酵母细胞是至关重要的器官，正如巴斯德及其自凯尼亚尔·德·拉·图尔以来的前辈们所肯定的那样；细胞内酶的新概念将这两个方面结合起来。4 179辩论以激动的语气进行，这在辩论双方之间是不可避免的，因为他们没有共同的框架来遵循更客观的程序。科尔贝无法反驳范特霍夫，他带着讽刺的兴致引用范特霍夫对原子螺旋排列的描述，对他来说，这足以证明新理论不过是一派胡言。从他自己的角度来看，他拒绝就这些方面进行任何详细的论证是正确的，因为他否认人们能够用这些疯狂的想法进行理性的辩论。沃勒和李比希对凯恩纳德·德·拉·图尔、施旺等人的论文的讽刺性回应，这些人声称发酵是活酵母细胞的功能，这种回应源于同样的观点，即一个被认为完全似是而非的论点不能被认真地逐点讨论。180当一位西方科学家被要求回答李森科的生物学理论时，他同样会拒绝以提出这些理论的马克思列宁主义为基础来讨论这些理论；而另一方面，李森科拒绝考虑孟德尔遗传学的统计证据，理由是“科学中没有偶然性”。181

The reason why both these controversies dragged on indefinitely is revealed by a remark of Pasteur concerning his own arguments for regarding fermentation as a function of the living cells of yeast: ‘If anyone should say that my conclusions go beyond the established facts (he wrote) I would agree, in the sense that I have taken my stand unreservedly in an order of ideas which, strictly speaking, cannot be irrefutably demonstrated.’178 This order of ideas was therefore separated by a logical gap from that entertained by Liebig, Wöhler and many other great men of his time. The schism was eventually bridged by a conceptual reform induced by Buchner’s discovery, in 1897, of zymase in the liquor squeezed out of yeast cells. The agent of fermentation was proved a dead catalyst of the kind imagined by Liebig and Berzelius, but it also proved a The great scientific controversies which I have just recalled were vital organ of yeast cells, as Pasteur and his precursors since Caignard de la Tour had affirmed; the new conception of intracellular enzymes combined these two aspects.4179conducted in passionate accents, as was inevitable between contestants who shared no common framework within which a more impersonal procedure could be followed. Kolbe could not argue against van’t Hoff, He quoted with ironical glee van’t Hoff’s description of the disposition of atoms in spirals, which to him was sufficient evidence that the new theory was a tissue of fancies. And from his own point of view he was right in refusing to enter into any detailed argument on these lines, since he denied that one could argue rationally in terms of such wild ideas. The ironical caricature by which Wöhler and Liebig replied to the papers of Caignard de la Tour, Schwann and others, who claimed that fermentation is a function of living yeast cells, sprang from the same view that an argument believed to be wholly specious cannot be seriously discussed point by point.180 A Western scientist challenged to answer Lysenko’s biological theories would similarly refuse to discuss them on the Marxist-Leninist grounds on which they were put forward; while, on the other hand, Lysenko refuses to consider the statistical evidence for Mendelism on the grounds that ‘in science there is no place for chance’.181

我们可以得出这样的结论：经验主义，如同科学的道德中立性，是一项原则，它是由过去关于特定思想体系的科学价值的争论结果所确立和诠释的。我们对科学价值的理解，在历史上是从此类争论的结果中发展而来的，正如我们的正义感是在过去几个世纪的司法判决结果中形成的一样。事实上，我们所有的文化价值观都是类似的历史性思想变革的沉淀。但最终，所有过去的思想冲突，只有根据我们自己认定的这段历史的真正结果和教训，才能在今天得到解释。而我们必须在当代争论的背景下做出这一决定，这些争论或许会重新挑战这些教训，并反过来提出一些全新的原则问题。历史的教训，就是我们自己所接受的。

We may conclude that empiricism, like the moral neutrality of science, is a principle laid down and interpreted for us by the outcome of past controversies about the scientific value of particular sets of ideas. Our appreciation of scientific value has developed historically from the outcome of such controversies, much as our sense of justice has taken shape from the outcome of judicial decisions through past centuries. Indeed, all our cultural values are the deposits of a similar historic succession of intellectual upheavals. But ultimately, all past mental strife can be interpreted today only in the light of what we ourselves decide to be the true outcome and lesson of this history. And we have to take this decision within the context of contemporary controversies which perhaps challenge these lessons afresh and raise in their turn quite novel questions of principle. The lesson of history is what we ourselves accept as such.

关于事物的本质，如今仍有一些严肃的问题悬而未决。至少我相信这些问题是悬而未决的，尽管绝大多数科学家坚信自己持有的观点是正确的，并蔑视任何挑战。一个臭名昭著的例子就是超感知觉。如今，科学家们忽视了它的证据，希望有一天它能找到一些微不足道的解释。在这一点上，他们或许是对的，但我也尊重那些认为自己可能错了的人；目前，双方之间不可能进行任何有益的讨论。

There are serious questions still open today concerning the nature of things. At least, I believe them to be open, though the great majority of scientists are convinced that the view they themselves hold is right and scorn any challenge to it. A notorious example is offered by extra-sensory perception. The evidence for it is ignored today by scientists in the hope that it will one day find some trivial explanation. In this they may be right, but I respect those too who think they may be wrong; and no profitable discussion is possible between the two sides at this stage.

再举一个例子。如今的神经学家几乎毫无例外地接受了这样一个假设：所有有意识的心理过程都可以被解释为神经系统中发生的一系列物质事件的附带现象。一些作家，比如梅斯博士，182我183以及 ROKapp 教授，184试图表明这在逻辑上是站不住脚的，但据我所知，只有一位神经学家，即 JCEccles 教授，通过引入意志干预的影响来修改大脑的神经模型，以决定在两个可能的选择决策之间的选择。185所有其他神经学家都轻蔑地忽视了这一建议，事实上，从他们的角度来看，很难对此进行有益的争论。

Another example. Neurologists today accept almost without exception the assumption that all conscious mental processes can be interpreted as epiphenomena of a chain of material events occurring in the nervous system. Some writers, like Dr. Mays,182 myself183 and Professor R.O.Kapp,184 have tried to show that this is logically untenable, but to my knowledge only one neurologist, namely Professor J.C.Eccles, has gone so far as to amend the neurological model of the brain, by introducing an influence by which the will intervenes to determine the choice between two possible alternative decisions.185 This suggestion is scornfully ignored by all other neurologists, and indeed, it is difficult to argue profitably about it from their point of view.

如今，主流遗传学派与主流遗传学派之间也存在着类似的分歧，主流遗传学派认为进化是随机突变序列的结果，而英国的格雷厄姆·坎农、比利时的达尔克、法国的范德尔等人则认为这种解释不充分，并支持一种假设，即存在一种和谐的适应力量，控制着高级生命形式起源中最重要的创新。

A similar schism is present today between the ruling school of genetics, which explains evolution as a result of a haphazard sequence of mutations, and writers like Graham Cannon in England, Dalcq in Belgium, Vandel and others in France, who consider this explanation inadequate and support the assumption of a harmonious adaptive power controlling the most important innovations in the origin of higher forms of life.

有些人可能会不耐烦地听着这些例子，因为他们认为科学提供了一种通过系统而客观的实证研究来解决任何此类问题的程序。然而，如果情况确实如此，那就没有理由对我生气了。我的论点毫无说服力，人们可以不经意地忽略它。

Some people may listen to these illustrations with impatience, for they believe that science provides a procedure for deciding any such issues by systematic and dispassionate empirical investigations. However, if that were clearly the case, there would be no reason to be annoyed with me. My argument would have no persuasive force, and could be ignored without anger.

 

 

我并不赞同这种激情的爆发。我不喜欢看到

I am not applauding the outbreak of such passions. I do not like to see

无论如何，让我在此明确阐述我所强调的。我曾说过，求知激情具有肯定的内容；在科学中，它们肯定某些事实的科学意义和价值，而反对其他事实缺乏这种意义和价值。这种选择性功能——如果没有它，科学就根本无法定义——与同一激情的另一个功能密切相关，在这种功能中，它们的认知内容被一种意动成分所补充。这就是它们的启发性功能。启发性冲动将我们对科学价值的理解与对现实的视角联系起来，而这种视角是探究的指南。启发性激情也是独创性的主要动力——这种力量促使我们放弃既定的解释框架，并通过跨越逻辑鸿沟，致力于使用新的框架。最后，启发性激情通常会转化为（并且必须转化为）说服性激情，这是所有根本性争议的主要动力。例如，一位科学家试图使对手在学术上受到蔑视，或为了让他闭嘴而为自己博取关注；但我承认，这种争议方式可能是悲剧性的，不可避免的。

At any rate, let me make quite clear what I have urged here. I have said that intellectual passions have an affirmative content; in science they affirm the scientific interest and value of certain facts, as against any lack of such interest and value in others. This selective function—in the absence of which science could not be defined at all—is closely linked to another function of the same passions in which their cognitive content is supplemented by a conative component. This is their heuristic function. The heuristic impulse links our appreciation of scientific value to a vision of reality, which serves as a guide to enquiry. Heuristic passion is also the mainspring of originality—the force which impels us to abandon an accepted framework of interpretation and commit ourselves, by the crossing of a logical gap, to the use of a new framework. Finally, heuristic passion will often turn (and have to turn) into persuasive passion, the mainspring of all fundamental controversy. a scientist trying to bring an opponent into intellectual contempt, or to silence him in order to gain attention for himself; but I acknowledge that such means of controversy may be tragically inevitable.

 

 

  1. 科学的前提
  2. THE PREMISSES OF SCIENCE

此时，我们可以探究，上述争议性原则在多大程度上可以被视为科学的前提。我们能否说科学建立在可具体化的预设之上，无论是建立在正确程序规则之上，还是建立在关于事物本质的实质性信念之上？我将首先根据我自己的观点，基于前述概述中所做的反思，来探讨这个问题。我们已经看到，研究对象的内在主张与对准确性和连贯性的追求之间的平衡是多么危险，例如在对有感知力的生物进行科学研究中；倾向于普遍的机械论事物观的倾向，可能会彻底改变我们对人的印象。我们还在开普勒和爱因斯坦的著作中看到了其他例子，表明最有力的科学真理观如何揭示出后来的根本性错误。我曾提及一系列伟大的思辨性发现，它们雄辩地证明了智性之美的真实力量，同时也表明，即使是最专业的评判者，也常常无法认可这些发现，甚至连它们的作者也无法一眼看出它们的含义。过去的重大科学争论进一步凸显了衡量科学价值的标准之微妙性。我们已经看到，这些争论的结果——以及其他科学巨变的结果——为我们今天奠定了这些标准，尽管最终我们仍需决定在多大程度上接受或修改这些解释。因为在科学史上，如同在所有其他人类活动史上一样，最终由讲述这些发现的人来认可或修改所有先前对其结果的评估——同时回应那些从未被思考过的当代问题。传统是从过去传承下来的，但它们是我们对过去的诠释，是我们根据自身当前问题的背景下得出的。

At this point we may enquire how far the controversial principles in question may be regarded as the premisses of science. Can science be said to rest on specifiable presuppositions, be it on rules of correct procedure or on substantial beliefs about the nature of things? I shall put the matter first in the light of my own views, based on reflections of the kind made in the course of the foregoing survey. We have seen how perilously poised is the balance between the intrinsic claims of a subject matter, and the passion for exactitude and coherence, e.g. in the scientific study of sentient beings; how the tendency towards a universal mechanistic conception of things may threaten completely to denature our image of man. We have seen other examples too, in the work of Kepler and Einstein, to show how the most powerful visions of scientific truth may reveal later elements of fundamental error. I have mentioned a series of great speculative discoveries which eloquently testified to the veridical powers of intellectual beauty, and have shown at the same time how frequently such discoveries may remain unrecognized by the most expert judges, and that no one—not even their authors—can even remotely discern at first what they imply. The delicate character of the criteria which characterize scientific value was brought home further by the great scientific controversies of the past. We have seen that the outcome of these controversies—together with the result of other upheavals in science—have laid down these criteria for us today, though in the last resort it still remains for us to decide how far we shall accept or modify these interpretations. For in the history of science, as in that of all other human activities, it falls finally to him who tells their story, to endorse or revise all previous assessments of their outcome—while simultaneously responding to contemporary issues unthought of before. Traditions are transmitted to us from the past, but they are our own interpretations of the past, at which we have arrived within the context of our own immediate problems.

从我所考虑的历史事例中得出的科学价值的一般标准，可以暂时被视为科学前提的公平样本。哥白尼及其反对者、开普勒和爱因斯坦、拉普拉斯和约翰·道尔顿、黑格尔和波德、德布罗意和狄拉克、范特霍夫和科尔贝、李比希和巴斯德、艾略特森和布雷德、弗洛伊德、爱丁顿、莱因和李先科；所有这些以及无数其他科学家，或自称是科学家的人，都对事物的本质以及科学研究的适当方法和目的持有某些所谓的“科学”信念。这些信念和价值观念向其追随者指出了哪些类型的问题看起来合理且值得探讨。他们推荐了哪些类型的概念和关系应该被认为是合理的，即使某些证据似乎与他们相矛盾；或者相反，即使有证据似乎支持这些假设，并且无法用其他理由轻易解释，也应该将其视为不可能假设而被拒绝。

The general criteria of scientific value to be derived from the historic instances I have considered, may be tentatively regarded as a fair sample of the premisses of science. Copernicus and his opponents; Kepler and Einstein; Laplace and John Dalton; Hegel and Bode; de Broglie and Dirac; van’t Hoff and Kolbe; Liebig and Pasteur; Elliotson and Braid; Freud, Eddington, Rhine and Lysenko; all these and countless other scientists, or persons claiming to be scientists, have held certain allegedly ‘Scientific’ beliefs about the nature of things and the proper method and purpose of scientific enquiry. These beliefs and valuations have indicated to their adherents the kind of questions which seem reasonable and interesting to explore. They have recommended the kind of conceptions and relations that should be upheld as plausible, even when some evidence seemed to contradict them; or which, on the contrary, should be rejected as unlikely, even though there was evidence which seemed to favour them and which could not be readily explained on other grounds.

我们采用的科学程序规则以及我们持有的科学信念和评价是相互决定的。因为我们根据预期的情况行事，并根据我们程序方法所取得的成功来塑造我们的预期。因此，信念和评价在科学探究中起着共同前提的作用。但在这种情况下，它们究竟应该如何定义呢？我们或许倾向于将与未来科学探究相关的普遍观点和目的视为前提。但“前提”是一个逻辑范畴：它指的是逻辑上先于其作为前提的断言。因此，一项科学发现的成就和确立中隐含的普遍观点和目的是其前提，即使这些观点和目的可能与首次认真思考该研究之前持有的观点和目的已不完全相同。这种矛盾的意义似乎是我们能够设想任何科学前提的唯一意义。但首先，让我简要阐述一下与日常知识相关的同一原则。

The rules of scientific procedure which we adopt, and the scientific beliefs and valuations which we hold, are mutually determined. For we proceed according to what we expect to be the case and we shape our anticipations in accordance with the success which our methods of procedure have met with. Beliefs and valuations have accordingly functioned as joint premisses in the pursuit of scientific enquiries. But how exactly should they be defined in this relation? We might be inclined to acknowledge as its premisses the general views and purposes bearing on a future scientific enquiry. But ‘premiss’ is a logical category: it refers to an affirmation which is logically anterior to that of which it is the premiss. Accordingly, the general views and purposes implicit in the achievement and establishment of a scientific discovery are its premisses, even though these views and purposes may no longer be quite the same as those held before the investigation was first seriously thought of. This paradoxical sense seems to be the only one in which we can envisage any premisses of science. But let me first elaborate the same principle briefly in respect to everyday knowledge.

自然科学处理的事实主要源于日常经验。因此，我们在日常生活中确立事实的方法在逻辑上先于科学的特殊前提，应该包含在这些前提的完整陈述中。那些促使和引导我们的眼睛去收集可见事物，并引导我们的思想去塑造我们对事物的理解的智力满足标准——那些通过我们日常描述性语言传达的关于事物本质的信念——所有这些都构成了科学前提的一部分，即使我们必须允许在科学内部对这些标准和信念进行修正。另一方面，假设自然界中存在持久性特征，这当然不是建立自然科学的充分前提。它为我们提供了参考事实并将宇宙视为事实集合的依据。但事实性并非科学。只有相对少数的特殊事实才是科学事实，而其余绝大多数事实则不具有科学意义。因此，像“自然的一致性”（J.S.米尔）或“有限多样性”（J.M.凯恩斯）这样的原则，或许能够解释事实性，但本身却无法解释自然科学。占星术和巫术与自然科学一样，同样依赖于自然的一致性或其有限多样性，尽管科学驳斥了占星家和巫医所宣称的事实。

Natural science deals with facts borrowed largely from common experience. The methods by which we establish facts in everyday life are therefore logically anterior to the special premisses of science, and should be included in a full statement of these premisses. The standards of intellectual satisfaction which urge and guide our eyes to gather what there is to see, and which guide our thoughts also to shape our conception of things—the beliefs about the nature of things transmitted by our everyday descriptive language—all these form part of the premisses of science, even though we must allow for the revision of these standards and beliefs within science. On the other hand, the assumption of persistent features in nature is certainly not a sufficient premiss for the establishment of natural science. It gives us grounds for referring to facts and for thinking of the universe as an aggregate of facts. But factuality is not science. Only a comparatively few peculiar facts are scientific facts, while the enormous rest are without scientific interest. Hence principles like that of the Uniformity of Nature (J.S.Mill), or that of Limited Variety (J.M.Keynes), which may account for factuality, cannot account by themselves for natural science. Astrology and magic rely as much on the Uniformity of Nature or on its Limited Variety as do the natural sciences, even though science repudiates the facts alleged by astrologers and medicine men.

我曾说过，科学的前提在科学实践和对其结果的接受中是被默默遵循的。自然界的一致性或有限的多样性也是如此。事实上，只有通过我们对事实的共同了解，这些事实要么在单一场合持续一段时间，要么在不同时间和地点不断重现，我们才能理解自然界的一致性或有限的多样性的含义。如果我们生活在一个气态宇宙中，在那里永远无法辨别出任何有限或重复出现的事实，这些概念对我们来说将是完全难以理解的。在我们开始确立事实之前，我们并不了解或相信事实性的逻辑前提，而是通过反思我们确立事实的方式而认识到的。我们必须首先预设，才能接受那些能够理解经验提供给我们的线索的事实，然后再由此推导出这一理解过程背后的前提。由于通过分析逻辑导数来发现逻辑前提的过程必然会引入一定程度的不确定性，因此，对这一前提的认识总是比对其后项的认识更不确定。我们不会因为先前且更牢固地相信任何明确的逻辑前提而相信事实的存在；相反，我们之所以相信某些明确的事实性前提，仅仅是因为我们发现它们隐含在我们对事实存在的信念之中。

I have said that the premisses of science are tacitly observed in the practice of scientific pursuits and in the acceptance of their results as true. This is true also of the Uniformity of Nature or of its Limited Variety. Indeed, it is only by our common acquaintance with facts, which either persist for a while on a single occasion, or keep recurring at different places and times, that we can appreciate what is meant by Uniformity or Limited Variety in Nature. These conceptions would be quite unintelligible to us if we lived in a gaseous universe, in which no circumscribed or recurrent facts could ever be discerned. The logical premisses of factuality are not known to us or believed by us before we start establishing facts, but are recognized on the contrary by reflecting on the way we establish facts. Our acceptance of facts which make sense of the clues offered by experience to our eyes and ears must be presupposed first, and the premisses underlying this process of making sense must be deduced from this afterwards.
