Since the process of discovering the logical antecedent from an analysis of its logical derivate cannot fail to introduce a measure of uncertainty, the knowledge of this antecedent will always be less certain than that of its consequent. We do not believe in the existence of facts because of our anterior and securer belief in any explicit logical presuppositions of such a belief; but on the contrary, we believe in certain explicit presuppositions of factuality only because we have discovered that they are implied in our belief in the existence of facts.

我们将会看到，同样独特的逻辑结构不仅适用于科学更具体的前提，甚至远不止这些，还适用于所有非正式心理过程的逻辑前提，其中一些因素甚至融入人类的每一个理性行为之中。这种结构最简单的例证是游泳、骑自行车或弹钢琴等技能的实践；回顾我对这些技能的分析，就能揭开前述表述的矛盾之处。游泳可以说预设了通过在肺部保留过多的残留空气来保持漂浮的原理；我们也可以列举骑自行车和弹钢琴的某些操作原理，这些原理同样可以被视为这些技能表演的基础前提。但我们已经看到，我们在掌握和练习这些技能时，并没有任何关于其前提的先验知识。事实上，一项技能的前提不可能在表演之前被先验地发现，即使他人明确地陈述了这些前提，在我们亲身体验其表演之前（无论是通过观看还是亲自参与），我们也无法理解这些前提。因此，在运用一项技能时，我们基于某些前提行事，这些前提我们主要不了解，但随着我们对该技能的掌握，我们会逐渐了解这些前提，并且可以通过分析我们在该技能上取得成功（或我们所认为的成功）的方式，逐渐了解这些前提。我们由此得出的成功规则可以帮助我们提升技能并将其传授给他人——但前提是这些原则首先要重新融入到以它们为准则的艺术中。因为，虽然任何一门艺术都无法按照其明确的规则来运用，但如果在一门艺术的娴熟运用中，将这些规则作为辅助手段来遵循，就能对其大有裨益。 186

The same peculiar logical structure will be seen to apply to the more specific premisses of science and indeed, far beyond these, to the logical antecedents of all informal mental processes, some of which enter into every rational act of man. The simplest illustration of this structure is given in the practice of skills like swimming, cycling or playing the piano; to recall my analysis of them will strip the foregoing formulation of its paradoxical features. Swimming may be said to presuppose the principle of keeping afloat by retaining an excessive residue of air in the lungs; and we can state certain operational principles of cycling and piano playing which can likewise be regarded as the premisses underlying these performances. But we have seen that we achieve and practise these skills without any antecedent focal knowledge of their premisses. Indeed, the premisses of a skill cannot be discovered focally prior to its performance, nor even understood if explicitly stated by others, before we ourselves have experienced its performance, whether by watching it or by engaging in it ourselves. In performing a skill we are therefore acting on certain premisses of which we are focally ignorant, but which we know subsidiarily as part of our mastery of that skill, and which we may get to know focally by analysing the way we achieve success (or what we believe to be success) in the skill in question. The rules of success which we thus derive can help us to improve our skill and to teach it to others— but only if these principles are first re-integrated into the art of which they are the maxims. For though no art can be exercised according to its explicit rules, such rules can be of great assistance to an art if observed subsidiarily within the context of its skilful performance.186

因此，我们可以将之前的表述修改如下。非正式心理过程的逻辑前提，例如事实认定，或者更具体地说，科学事实的认定，在其应用过程中逐渐被辅助性地认识；但它们只能在之后通过对其应用的分析才能被重点地认识，并且，一旦被重点地认识，就可以通过重新整合来应用它们，以辅助性地改进该过程的绩效。

We can accordingly amend our previous formulation as follows. The logical antecedents of an informal mental process like fact finding, or more particularly, the finding of a fact of science, come to be known subsidiarily in the very act of their application; but they can become known focally only later, from an analysis of their application, and, once focally known, they can be applied by reintegration to guide subsidiarily improved performances of the process.

因此，确立科学（或音乐、法律等）等精神成就前提的第一步，是承认其真实事例。我们并非接受所有关于事实的断言为真，也不能承认所有旨在对科学、音乐或法律做出的贡献都是真正的科学、音乐或法律的一部分。哪些“事实”是事实，什么“科学”是科学，什么“音乐”是音乐，什么“法律”是法律，这些问题可能确实极具争议。为了阐明事实，尤其是科学事实确立背后的假设，我们必须对这些存疑的问题表明立场。因为我们必须反思我们承认有效的科学事实和部分内容，或者至少反思我们认为即使未经有效确立，但也是充分断言的事实和部分内容。例如，我会接受这样的说法：根据开普勒所知的事实，行星的数量是六，尽管根据我们自身的知识，这并不是事实；我承认毕达哥拉斯的推测是开普勒科学工作的一部分，尽管我不相信它们是正确的；同时，我拒绝接受开普勒的星座运势和他的所有占星术，认为它们无论是作为事实陈述还是作为科学工作都是不合格的。

The first step towards establishing the premisses of a mental achievement like science—or music, or law, etc.—is, therefore, to acknowledge its authentic instances. We do not accept every allegation of a fact as true, nor can we acknowledge every intended contribution to science, or music, or law, as part of true science, or music, or law. The question, which ‘facts’ are facts, what ‘science’ is science, what ‘music’ is music, what ‘law’ is law, may indeed be highly controversial. In order to elucidate the assumptions underlying the establishment of facts, and particularly of the facts of science, we must take a stand on such doubtful issues. For we must reflect on facts and parts of science which we acknowledge as valid, or at least on facts and parts of science which we regard as competently alleged, even if not validly established. I would accept, for example, the statement that according to the facts as known to Kepler the number of planets was six, though this is not the fact according to our own knowledge; and I acknowledge Pythagorean speculations as part of Kepler’s scientific work, even though I do not believe them to be correct; while at the same time I reject Kepler’s horoscopes and all his astrology as incompetent, both as statements of fact and as scientific work.

任何试图更精确地定义科学体系的尝试都会面临这样一个事实：科学所包含的知识并非任何个人所能知晓。事实上，没有人能够充分了解科学的极小部分，从而能够直接判断其有效性和价值。对于其余部分，他必须依赖由被认可为科学家的群体权威间接接受的观点。但这种认可又依赖于一个复杂的组织。因为群体中的每个成员只能直接评判少数成员，但最终每个人都会得到所有人的认可。实际情况是，每个人都会承认其他一些成员是科学家，而这些成员也同样承认他是科学家，这些关系形成了一种链条，将这些相互认可间接地传递到整个群体。这就是每个成员直接或间接地获得所有人认可的方式。这个体系延续至今。它的成员承认同一组人是他们的主人，并从这种忠诚中获得了一种共同的传统，每个人都继承着其中特定的脉络。

Any attempt to define the body of science more closely comes up against the fact that the knowledge comprised by science is not known to any single person. Indeed, nobody knows more than a tiny fragment of science well enough to judge its validity and value at first hand. For the rest he has to rely on views accepted at second hand on the authority of a community of people accredited as scientists. But this accrediting depends in its turn on a complex organization. For each member of the community can judge at first hand only a small number of his fellow members, and yet eventually each is accredited by all. What happens is that each recognizes as scientists a number of others by whom he is recognized as such in return, and these relations form chains which transmit these mutual recognitions at second hand through the whole community. This is how each member becomes directly or indirectly accredited by all. The system extends into the past. Its members recognize the same set of persons as their masters and derive from this allegiance a common tradition, of which each carries on a particular strand.

对科学共识的分析将在下一章“欢乐”中进一步展开。这里只需指出，任何以当前意义谈论科学并通常表示认可的人，都接受这种有组织的共识来定义什么是“科学的”，什么是“非科学的”。因此，每一场重大的科学争论都倾向于演变成既定权威与觊觎者（艾略特森、库茨、莱因、弗洛伊德、范特霍夫、李森科等）之间的争论，而这些觊觎者至少在所讨论的工作方面尚未被认定为科学家。

This analysis of the scientific consensus will be carried further in the next chapter, on Conviviality. Suffice it here to say that anyone who speaks of science in the current sense and with the usual approval, accepts this organized consensus as determining what is ‘scientific’ and what ‘unscientific’. Every great scientific controversy tends therefore to turn into a dispute between the established authorities and a pretender (Elliotson, Kützing, Rhine, Freud, van’t Hoff, Lysenko, etc.) who is as yet denied the status of a scientist, at least with respect to the work under discussion.

这些伪装者并非否认科学观点的普遍权威，而只是在特定细节上对其权威性提出质疑，并试图修改其关于该细节的教诲。事实上，任何对权威的深思熟虑的服从都会受到某种（无论多么轻微的）反对的约束。这种立场与上文关于传统的论述类似，且紧密相关。当我谈论科学时，我既承认它的传统，也承认它有组织的权威，并且我否认任何完全拒绝这些的人都能被称为科学家，或对科学有任何正确的理解和欣赏。因此，我——一个接受科学传统和权威的人——关于科学的任何言论对这样的人都毫无意义，反之亦然。然而，我并非无条件地接受这种承诺，正如我拒绝遵循科学在心理学和社会学中追求客观主义理想的传统和权威这一事实所表明的那样。我接受现有的科学观点作为界定所谓“科学”主题的权威，但并非最高权威。

These pretenders do not deny the authority of scientific opinion in general, but merely appeal against its authority in a particular detail and seek to modify its teachings in respect of that detail. Indeed, every thoughtful submission to authority is qualified by some, however slight, opposition to it. The position is similar—and closely linked—to that already stated in respect to tradition. When I speak of science I acknowledge both its tradition and its organized authority, and I deny that anyone who wholly rejects these can be said to be a scientist, or have any proper understanding and appreciation of science. Consequently, nothing that I—who accept the traditions and authority of science—may say about science can mean anything to such a person, and this holds also in reverse. Yet I do not enter this commitment unconditionally, as shown by the fact that I refuse to follow both the tradition and authority of science in its pursuit of the objectivist ideal in psychology and sociology. I accept the existing scientific opinion as a competent authority, but not as a supreme authority, for identifying the subject matter called ‘science’.

这种区别隐含在我刚才关于开普勒的评论中。对于任何科学历史进程的考察而言，它都不可或缺。因为，将“科学”一词限制于我们认为有效的命题，将科学的前提限制于我们认为的真正前提，只会使我们的主题变得残缺。合理的科学观必须涵盖科学内部相互冲突的观点，并承认科学家基本信念和价值观的变化。承认一个人是科学家——甚至是一位非常伟大的科学家——仅仅意味着承认他在科学方面具有才能，这承认了他过去或现在在许多方面可能犯过错误。

This distinction is implicit in the remarks I have just made about Kepler. It is indispensable to any survey of the historic progress of science. For to limit the term science to propositions which we regard as valid, and the premisses of science to what we consider to be its true premisses, is to mutilate our subject matter. A reasonable conception of science must include conflicting views within science and admit of changes in the fundamental beliefs and values of scientists. To acknowledge a person as a scientist—and even as a very great scientist— is merely to acknowledge him as competent in science, which admits the possibility that he was, or is, in many ways mistaken.

我可以指出，正如我已经指出的那样，现代物理科学经历了三个阶段，每个阶段都有其自身的科学价值及其相应的终极实在观。第一个阶段的科学家相信数字和几何图形的系统，第二个阶段相信受机械约束的质量系统，最后一个阶段相信数学不变性系统。在致力于追寻这些关于事物本质的连续基本猜测的过程中，科学家的求知热情发生了深刻的变化——这种变化的程度与视觉艺术欣赏从拜占庭马赛克到印象派作品再到超现实主义所经历的变化相似，甚至可能并非毫无关联。但这两种情况都对持久的热情进行了类似的超越。诚然，哥白尼、伽利略和开普勒，甚至牛顿、拉瓦锡和道尔顿的许多论证在今天看来都是错误的，他们的预设导致了我们现在认为是错误的结论；即便这些昔日的巨擘，如果他们今天重回故土，或许不会轻易接受相对论和量子力学作为令人满意的科学体系；然而，早期科学的许多内容依然真实，甚至揭示了其更深层的含义，以至于科学先驱们在我们看来，几个世纪以来一直在不断成长。从这个意义上讲，科学包含着一种持续不断的追求，即逐渐改变，并且——我相信——总体而言，不断开明和提升的智识抱负。

I may observe then, as I have done already, that the modern physical sciences went through three stages, each of which had its own scientific values and its corresponding vision of ultimate reality. Scientists of the first period believed in a system of numbers and geometrical figures, the next in one of mechanically constrained masses, the last in systems of mathematical invariances. In attaching themselves to the pursuit of these successive fundamental guesses about the nature of things, the intellectual passions of scientists underwent profound changes—changes similar in extent, and perhaps even not unrelated, to those which the appreciation of visual arts underwent from the Byzantine mosaics to the works of the Impressionists and from these to Surrealism. But there was a similar transcendence of an enduring passion in both cases. Granted that many of the arguments of Copernicus, Galileo and Kepler, and even of Newton, Lavoisier and Dalton, seem misguided today, and that their presuppositions have led to conclusions which we now consider to be false; and granted also that these giants of the past, if they returned today, might not readily accept relativity and quantum mechanics as satisfying systems of science; yet so much of earlier science has remained true, and has even revealed as true ever more of its deeper implications, that the pioneers of science have kept growing through the centuries in our respect. In this sense then science embraces a consistent pursuit of gradually changing, and—I believe—on the whole, evermore enlightened and elevated intellectual aspirations.

这就是定义科学追求并确定其成就背后假设的总体框架。这一视角需要进一步拓展——正如我将在第四部分阐述的那样——以涵盖生物科学；而心理学和社会学的纳入将引发更多尖锐的争议性问题，我将仅作简要提及。

Such is the general framework within which the pursuit of science can be defined and the assumptions underlying its achievements identified. This perspective will have to be considerably widened—as I shall show in Part Four—to include the biological sciences; the inclusion of psychology and sociology would raise further, sharply controversial questions which I shall touch upon only in passing.

关于该领域的广度，就到此为止。我只能略微提及，任何对科学发现和验证的前提进行实质性研究都必须深入到何种程度。或许，它首先必须考察那些伟大的发现——尤其是在本世纪——科学家们在对自然的理性解释进行推测性的具体猜测时所取得的发现；它必须思考，其中一些猜测最初看起来是多么晦涩难懂、充满争议；有多少类似的猜测实际上是空洞的或错误的；然而，其中一些猜测又在几个著名的案例中被证明是多么惊人的真实和深刻的预见性。要发现这些非凡的猜测背后是哪些关于事物本质的普遍观念，需要非凡的洞察力。但即便如此，这样的描述也只能揭示过去科学成就的前提。在撰写本文时，科学的实际前提仅存在于那些尚未成形、正在专注于工作的科学研究人员的头脑中逐渐成熟的发现之中。一位大师的学术研究机构的访客——其直觉的理解力可以渗透到合作者的核心圈子，即使不完美——或许能从合作者谈论其工作的方式中，隐约辨别出未来发现的前提。我们无法更接近现有的科学前提。

So much for the breadth of the field. I can only hint at the kind of detail into which any substantial investigation of the premisses underlying scientific discovery and verification would have to go. Perhaps it would have to examine above all the great discoveries made—particularly in this century—by scientists speculatively pursuing some specific guesses at a rational interpretation of nature; it would have to consider how obscure and controversial some of these speculations appeared at first; how many similar speculations were in fact empty or mistaken; and yet how astoundingly true and deeply prophetic some of them proved in several famous instances. Exceptional sensibility would be needed in order to discover what general ideas about the nature of things have guided these remarkable guesses. But even so, such an account would only reveal the premisses of past scientific achievements. The actual premisses of science, at the moment of writing, are present only in the yet unformed discoveries maturing in the minds of scientific investigators intent on their work. The visitor to the research school of a great master—whose intuitive apprehensions can filter through, even though imperfectly, to an inner circle of collaborators—may dimly discern the premisses of prospective discoveries by the way the collaborators talk about their work. We can get no closer to the current premisses of science.

现在，我们眼前展现了科学从最初的模糊和猜测走向更高精确度和确定性过程的真实图景。正是在这个过程中，在发现和验证的过程中，科学的前提指导着科学家的判断。显然，任何曾经提出（或尚未提出）的关于这些前提的表述，都无法使一个缺乏科学家特殊天赋和训练的人胜任地解决我所提到的各种争议或疑点问题中出现的任何严重的不确定性。事实上，当我们试图运用这些表述中的任何一个来解决科学中的重大问题时，我们会发现它们恰恰模棱两可，以至于两种选择都同样值得商榷。

We have now before us a true image of science in the process of emerging from initial vagueness and conjecture to greater precision and certainty. It is here, in the course of discovery and verification, that the premisses of science exercise their guidance over the judgment of scientists. It is obvious that no formulation of these premisses ever proposed (or yet to be proposed) would have enabled a person lacking the special gifts and training of a scientist, competently to decide any of the serious uncertainties that have arisen in the various controversial or doubtful issues I have mentioned. Indeed, when we try to apply any of these formulations for deciding a great question in science, we find that they prove ambiguous precisely to the extent of allowing both alternatives to be equally arguable.

以马赫的“精神经济”原理为例，该原理认为科学是对事实最简单的描述或最便捷的概括。想象一下，德布罗意博士论文的审稿人困惑不解，竟然以此标准来评判该论文的科学价值。他们怎么能这样做呢？该理论最终被发现描述的大多数事实当时尚未被发现。他们不得不将自己局限于该理论已知的事实。他们是否应该组织一场比赛，以确定新理论是否更简单，即它是否更容易记住这些事实或在学校教授这些事实；或者，该理论是否可以在更小的篇幅或更熟悉的词汇中写下来？这个想法很可笑。他们首先要决定的是，这项工作是一项实质性的发现，还是仅仅是一个灵光闪现的玩笑。这也将决定它是否是科学上对事实最简单的描述。因为作为一种纯粹的自负，它是一种奇特而牵强的看待事物的方式；而事实上，这是一条通往广阔新视角的极其简单的捷径。

Take Mach’s principle of ‘mental economy’, according to which science is the simplest description or the most convenient summary of the facts. Imagine the puzzled examiners of de Broglie’s doctoral thesis having recourse to this criterion as to the scientific value of the work. How could they? Most of the facts which the theory eventually was found to describe were yet undiscovered. They would have had to limit themselves to the facts known to be described by the theory. Should they have arranged a competition to determine whether the new theory was simpler, in the sense that it would make it easier to memorize these facts or to teach them in schools; or that the theory could be written down in a smaller space or in a more familiar vocabulary? The idea is farcical. What they had to decide first and last was whether this work was a substantial discovery or a mere jeu-d’esprit. This would decide also whether it was the scientifically simplest description of the facts. For as a mere conceit it was a fancifully far-fetched way of looking at things; while as a true statement, it was an amazingly simple short-cut to vast new perspectives.

或者将“简单性”的概念应用于莱因猜牌实验的争议。如果你愿意相信超感知觉的存在，那么超感知觉当然是最简单的解释。然而，当今大多数科学家更倾向于其他解释，无论多么复杂，只要它属于迄今为止已知的物理相互作用的范畴。在他们看来，如果我们能够运用现有的原理，那么不引入新的原理似乎更“经济”；他们甚至准备忽略莱因的观察，直到这些观察能够被纳入现有的自然法则框架。同样，描述的简单性问题，就“简单”一词的通常含义而言，在这场争议中根本不起作用，而且也起不到任何作用。相反，无论最终如何解决，这将决定在科学意义上更简单的解释是什么。

Or apply the concept of ‘simplicity’ to the controversy about Rhine’s experiments on card guessing. Extra-sensory perception is of course the simplest explanation for them, if you are prepared to believe in extra- sensory perception. Yet most scientists today would prefer some other explanation, however complicated, if only it lay within the scope of hitherto known physical interactions. To them it appears more ‘economical’ not to introduce a new principle if we can possibly manage with those already accepted; and they are even prepared to disregard Rhine’s observations until such time as these can be fitted into the existing framework of natural laws. Again, the question of simplicity of description, in the ordinary sense of the word ‘simple’, plays, and can play, no part whatsoever in the controversy. On the contrary, in whatever way the issue is finally decided, this will determine what will be the simpler explanation in the scientific sense.

马赫公式中“简单”一词的模糊性源于我之前所陈述的事实，187也就是说，它在这里充当了“真”的伪替代品。结果，对于在特定情况下什么是简单的这个问题的答案，必然总是与对于在相同情况下什么是真的这个问题的答案一样令人怀疑。同样的模糊性也适用于其他真理的伪替代品，比如理论“有效”的实用主义标准。如果我们用实用性代替简单性作为诸如德布罗意论题或莱茵实验等有疑问或争议的问题的标准，这种模糊性就会以与“简单性”相同的方式显现出来。同样的检验对于成果性标准也会得出类似的结果，我已经表明了它是如何怪诞地模仿真理的功能。

This ambiguity of the term ‘simple’ within Mach’s formula follows from the fact which I stated before,187 namely that it functions here as a pseudo-substitute for ‘true’. In consequence, the answer to the question what is simple in a given case must always be exactly as doubtful as the answer to the question what is true in the same case. The same ambiguity will adhere to other pseudo-substitutes for truth, like the pragmatist criterion that a theory ‘works’. This ambiguity is revealed in the same way as that of ‘simplicity’, if we apply practicality in place of simplicity as a criterion of such doubtful or controversial issues as de Broglie’s thesis or Rhine’s experiments. The same test will yield similar results in respect to the criterion of fruitfulness, of which I have already shown how grotesquely it mimics the functions of truth.

我之前曾说过（第161页），科学的前提决定了其研究方法，反之亦然。然而，对科学程序的探究实际上是沿着独立且更加系统的路线进行的。其目标是发现一些严格表述的规则，通过这些规则可以从现有的经验观察中推导出有效的普遍命题。我在第二章中充分讨论并批判了这样一种方案，它基于收集证据的过程，该过程将提高经验命题的概率，使其达到实践确定性的程度。本章收集的补充材料应该能够让我重新表述这一批判，并将其应用于所有试图根据J.S.米尔的“一致与差异”原则来表述归纳过程的尝试。

I have said before (p. 161) that the premisses of science determine the methods of its pursuit and vice versa. Yet the enquiry into scientific procedure has in fact been conducted on separate and much more systematic lines. Its aim has been the discovery of some strictly formulated rule by which valid general propositions can be derived from available empirical observations. One such scheme, based on the process of collecting evidence which will increase the probability of an empirical proposition to the point of practical certainty, I have fully discussed and criticized in ch. 2. The additional material collected in the present chapter should enable me to re-formulate that criticism, and apply it also to all attempts made to formulate the process of induction on the lines of J.S.Mill’s principles of Agreement and Difference.

经验推理的具体规则主张（a）通过规定的操作从线索进行发现，或至少（b）展示如何根据某些此类规则验证或至少（c）证伪一个经验命题。鉴于可证明的事实，即发现与其依据之间存在逻辑空白，因此必须驳斥主张（a）。正如我之前所说，将科学方法设想为一个依赖于随机选择的假设的证据积累速度的自动过程，是对科学方法的嘲弄（第一部分，第二章，第30页）。重大科学争议的历史告诉我们，主张（b）和（c）同样毫无根据。

Specific rules of empirical inference claim (a) to proceed by a prescribed operation from clues to discovery or at least (b) to show how to verify, or at the very least (c) how to falsify, an empirical proposition according to some such rules. Claim (a) must be rejected in view of the demonstrable fact that discovery is separated by a logical gap from the grounds on which it is made. It is, as I said before, a travesty of the scientific method to conceive of it as an automatic process depending on the speed of piling up evidence for hypotheses chosen at random (Part One, ch. 2, p. 30). The history of the great scientific controversies teaches us now that claims (b) and (c) are equally unfounded.

其理由与我批评用“简单”等词代替“真实”的理由类似。所有科学程序的正式规则都必然存在歧义，因为根据科学家所遵循的关于事物本质的特定概念，它们将被截然不同地解读。而他能否得出真实而重要的结论，将决定性地取决于这些概念的正确性和洞察力。我们已经看到，有一种经验发现无需任何归纳过程即可实现。德布罗意的波动理论、哥白尼体系和相对论，都是通过纯粹的思辨，以内在理性的标准为指导而发现的。迈克尔逊-莫雷实验的胜利（尽管它给出了错误的结果），米勒为了追求对伟大理论愿景的纯粹经验检验而悲惨地牺牲了职业生涯，这些都是对所谓的实验至上论的讽刺。诚然，其他争议，例如关于发酵、催眠术和超感知觉的争议，似乎都集中在事实证据的问题上。但仔细审视这些争议，就会发现双方并不接受相同的“事实”作为事实，更不接受相同的“证据”作为证据。这些术语的模糊性，恰恰在于两种对立观点的差异程度。因为在两个不同的概念框架内，同一范围的经验会呈现出不同的事实和不同的证据。事实上，一方可能会完全忽视某些证据，并确信这些证据最终会被证明是错误的。我将在后面的章节（第三部分，第九章“怀疑论批判”）中进一步阐述科学理论对科学事实的这种影响力。

The reasons are similar to those I used for criticizing terms like ‘simple’ as a substitute for ‘true’. All formal rules of scientific procedure must prove ambiguous, for they will be interpreted quite differently, according to the particular conceptions about the nature of things by which the scientist is guided. And his chances for reaching true and important conclusions will depend decisively on the correctness and penetration of these conceptions. We have seen that there is a type of empirical discovery that is achieved without any process of induction. De Broglie’s wave theory, the Copernican system and the theory of Relativity, were all found by pure speculation guided by criteria of internal rationality. The triumph of the Michelson-Morley experiment, despite its giving the wrong result, the tragic sacrifice of D.C.Miller’s professional life to the pursuit of purely empirical tests of a great theoretical vision, are sardonic comments on the supposed supremacy of experiment over theory. Admittedly, other controversies, like those of fermentation, hypnotism and extra-sensory perception, seem to centre altogether on questions of factual evidence. But looking at these disputes more closely it appears that the two sides do not accept the same ‘facts’ as facts, and still less the same ‘evidence’ as evidence. These terms are ambiguous precisely to the extent to which the two opposing opinions differ. For within two different conceptual frameworks the same range of experience takes the shape of different facts and different evidence. Indeed, one side may disregard some of the evidence altogether in the confident expectation that it will somehow turn out to be false. I shall give further illustrations of this power of scientific theory over scientific facts in a later chapter (Part Three, ch. 9, ‘A Critique of Doubt’).

我们还应该记住，归纳法则自古以来就支持着与科学相悖的信念。占星术凭借着证实星座预测的经验证据，得以延续了3000年。这是历史上已知的最长的经验概括链。在史前的许多世纪里，魔法和巫术所蕴含的理论似乎得到了那些相信魔法和巫术的人眼中事件的惊人证实。莱基188正确地指出，十六、十七世纪人们对巫术的信仰之所以被摧毁，是因为有大量且仍在迅速增长的证据证明巫术的真实性。那些否认巫术存在的人根本没有试图解释这些证据，反而成功地促使人们忽视这些证据。格兰维尔是皇家学会的创始人之一，他以当代科学自诩的经验主义为由，毫无根据地谴责这种方法不科学。一些无法解释的巫术证据确实被永远埋没了，直到两个世纪后，当它们最终被确认为催眠力量的表现时，才经过艰苦的努力才被揭示出来。

We should also remember that the rules of induction have lent their support throughout the ages to beliefs that are contrary to those of science. Astrology has been sustained for 3000 years by empirical evidence confirming the predictions of horoscopes. This represents the longest chain of historically known empirical generalizations. For many prehistoric centuries the theories embodied in magic and witchcraft appeared to be strikingly confirmed by events in the eyes of those who believed in magic and witchcraft. Lecky188 rightly points out that the destruction of belief in witchcraft during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries was achieved in the face of an overwhelming, and still rapidly growing, body of evidence for its reality. Those who denied that witches existed did not attempt to explain this evidence at all, but successfully urged that it be disregarded. Glanvill, who was one of the founders of the Royal Society, not unreasonably denounced this method as unscientific, on the ground of the professed empiricism of contemporary science. Some of the unexplained evidence for witchcraft was indeed buried for good, and only struggled painfully to light two centuries later when it was eventually recognized as the manifestation of hypnotic powers.

 

 

此外，哲学家们试图通过赋予归纳法独特的可靠性来证明科学，但却忽视了更多我们更为熟悉的事实。189持续的结合会导致对大量过程做出荒谬的预测，而这些过程的进程是由衰老或食欲的满足决定的。我们对寿命的预期并不会随着我们存活的天数而增加。相反，在接下来的24小时内生存下来的经历，在连续发生30000次之后，重现的可能性远低于仅仅发生1000次之后。训练一匹马不进食的尝试，在连续成功了最长的一系列之后，也会失败；用自己最喜欢的笑话逗乐观众的确定性，也不会随着成功重复的次数而无限增加。的确，在条件反射实验中，动物倾向于预期一个事件，如果其前面反复出现一个信号，那么在再次出现该信号后，该事件会再次发生；但是，当孩子们被要求在两排平行出现的红绿灯随机序列中猜测接下来会出现哪一盏灯时，他们会预期是迄今为止出现次数较少的那盏。190我们可以很容易地想象一个宇宙，其中所有复发的次数都是有限的，因此新的复发的可能性会随着之前发生的次数而逐渐减少。

Moreover, a whole realm of more familiar facts has been overlooked by philosophers who strove to justify science by ascribing a unique reliability to the inductive method.189 Constant conjunction would lead to absurd predictions all over the enormous range of processes the course of which is determined by decay or the satiation of appetites. Our expectation of life does not increase with the number of days we have survived. On the contrary, the experience of living through the next 24 hours is much less likely to recur after it has happened 30,000 consecutive times than after only 1000 times. Attempts to train a horse to do without food will break down precisely after the longest series of successes; and the certainty of amusing an audience by one’s favourite joke does not increase indefinitely with the number of its successful repetitions. It is true that in conditioning experiments animals tend to expect that an event which is repeatedly preceded by a sign will recur after the sign is given again; but when children are asked to guess in a random sequence of red and green lights appearing in two parallel rows which of the two will come out next, they will expect that it will be the one which has so far occurred fewer times.190 We can easily imagine a universe in which all recurrences would be limited in number, so that new recurrences would invariably become steadily less likely with the number of their previous occurrences.

这些显然不充分的科学原理表述之所以会被杰出的智者们所接受，其决定性原因在于，他们极力渴望将科学知识描绘成非个人化的。我们已经看到，实现这一目标的方法有两种：

The decisive reason why such obviously inadequate formulations of the principles of science were accepted by men of great intellectual distinction lies in a desperate craving to represent scientific knowledge as impersonal. We have seen that this is achieved by two alternative recipes:

(1) 用某些次要特征（简单性、经济性、实用性、成果性等）来描述科学，以及 (2) 用概率或常数连接词建立某种形式模型。在这两种情况下，科学家都无需做出承诺；在第一种情况下，他只会说一本电话簿；在第二种情况下，他可以使用一台机器代替他说话，不带个人色彩。由于后一种解决方案仍然需要个人授权机器，因此可以按照方案 1 的思路，将这一行为描述为一项单纯的“政策”来淡化。但是，用科学程序作为一项政策的实际优势来证明其合理性，就是掩盖了这样一个事实：人们预期这种优势的产生仅仅是因为我们对事物的本质持有某些信念，而这些信念使得这种预期合理化。

(1) by describing science in terms of some secondary feature (simplicity, economy, practicality, fruitfulness, etc.), and (2) by setting up some formal model in terms of probabilities or constant conjunctions. In both cases the scientist would be left uncommitted; in the first because he would say nothing more than a telephone directory, in the second because he would have a machine to speak for him, impersonally. Since the latter solution still leaves over the personal act of accrediting the machine, this act may be played down on the lines of recipe 1 by describing it as a mere ‘policy’. But to justify a scientific procedure by its practical advantage as a policy, is to conceal the fact that this advantage is expected to accrue only because we hold certain beliefs about the nature of things which make this expectation reasonable.

我稍后（第191页）将进一步阐述任何科学（或数学）形式公理化都会陷入的荒谬逻辑困境。目前，我只想解释，对非个人知识的至高渴望，如何能够成功地使那些明显不充分的科学表述（如秘诀1或2所示）变得可信。我们之所以拥有这种强大的自欺欺人的能力，要归功于无处不在的默契系数，唯有通过这种系数，我们才能将任何清晰的术语应用于它们所描述的主题。这种能力使我们能够通过对其任何可具体特征的最粗略的描绘，唤起我们对一个我们熟悉的复杂而难以言喻的主题的概念。因此，科学家可以接受他自己科学原理中最不充分、最误导性的表述，而无需意识到其含义，因为他会根据自己对科学本质的默契知识自动进行补充，从而使该表述听起来真实可信。

I shall presently (p. 191) have more to say on the curious logical dilemma in which any formal axiomatization of science (or mathematics) leads itself ad absurdum. At the moment I only wish to explain how the paramount desire for impersonal knowledge could succeed in rendering plausible such flagrantly inadequate formulations of science as given either by recipe 1 or 2. We owe this immense power for self-deception to the operation of the ubiquitous tacit coefficient by which alone we can apply any articulate terms to a subject matter described by them. These powers enable us to evoke our conception of a complex ineffable subject matter with which we are familiar, by even the roughest sketch of any of its specifiable features. A scientist can accept, therefore, the most inadequate and misleading formulation of his own scientific principles without ever realizing what is being said, because he automatically supplements it by his tacit knowledge of what science really is, and thus makes the formulation ring true.

由于这一过程对于伪替代机制至关重要，而我认为伪替代机制作为一种误导性批判哲学的工具具有一定的重要性，因此我将稍微离题地讨论一下。一个最具戏剧性的自欺欺人的例子，是由观察者不善言辞的能力的介入造成的，发生在聪明汉斯的案例中：这匹马可以用蹄子敲出各种数学问题的答案，答案写在它面前的黑板上。来自各个相关知识领域的专家们对此表示怀疑，并对它进行了严格的测试，结果一次又一次地证实了它永不失败的智力。但最后，奥斯卡·普丰斯特先生想出了一个主意，问这匹马一个它自己也不知道答案的问题。这一次，这匹马继续无休止地敲打着，毫无规律或理由。事实证明，所有持严重怀疑态度的专家都在不自觉地向马发出信号，让马停止敲击，而他们知道正确答案，并希望马停止敲击。191他们正是通过这种方式，确保答案始终正确；哲学家们也正是通过这种方式，确保他们对科学的描述，或他们形式化的科学推理程序，始终正确无误。他们从不用这些方法来解决任何悬而未决的科学问题，无论是过去的还是现在的，而是将它们应用于他们认为毋庸置疑的科学概括。192这种信念消除了所有在恒定合取（或根据假设的概率递增而逐步证实假设）的形式程序中遗留的模糊性，从而使这两种程序都能得出正确的结果。此外，你还可以成功地向自己隐瞒一个难以解释的事实：你完全相信（比如说）万有引力定律，只需称其为一个纯粹的工作假设或对事实的简略描述等等。因为一个不容置疑的信念不会不受这些轻描淡写的影响。因此，这些公式可以安全地用来安抚一个严格的经验主义者的良心。只有当我们面对一个活生生的科学问题所带来的令人焦虑的困境时，形式程序和各种被弱化的科学真理标准的模糊性才会显现出来，并使我们失去有效的指导。 193

Since this process is essential to the mechanism of pseudo-substitution, to which I ascribe some importance as an instrument of a misguided critical philosophy, I shall digress on it a little further. A most dramatic instance of self-deception, caused by the intervention of the inarticulate powers of the observer, occurred in the case of Clever Hans: the horse which could tap out with his hoofs the answer to all kinds of mathematical problems, written out on a blackboard in front of him. Incredulous experts from all relevant branches of knowledge came and tested him severely, only to confirm again and again his unfailing intellectual powers. But at last Mr. Oskar Pfungst had the idea of asking the horse a question to which he, Pfungst, did not know the answer. This time the horse went on tapping and tapping indefinitely, without rhyme or reason. It turned out that all the severely sceptical experts had involuntarily and unknowingly signalled to the horse to stop tapping at the point where they—knowing the right answer—expected him to stop.191 This is how they made the answers invariably come out right; and this is exactly also how philosophers make their descriptions of science, or their formalized procedures of scientific inference, come out right. They never use them to decide any open scientific problem, whether past or present, but apply them to scientific generalizations which they regard as indubitably established.192 This belief eliminates all the ambiguities which the formal procedures of constant conjunction—or of the progressive confirmation of hypotheses according to their increasing probability— leave open, and thus makes either process give invariably the right result. And again, you can successfully conceal from yourself the unaccountable fact that you are absolutely convinced of (say) the law of gravitation, by calling it a mere working hypothesis, or a shorthand description of the facts, etc. For a belief which can be touched by no shadow of a doubt remains unaffected by such understatements. So these formulae can be safely uttered to appease a strictly empiricist conscience. It is only when we are confronted with the anxious dilemma of a live scientific issue, that the ambiguity of the formal processes and of the various attenuated criteria of scientific truth becomes apparent, and leaves us without effective guidance.193

这些正式的标准当然可以合法地作为科学价值和科学程序的准则。从开普勒到拉普拉斯，再从拉普拉斯到爱因斯坦，科学价值的每一次变革都对应着科学方法的变革，而这种变革可以通过改变程序准则来表述。我们过去曾目睹过此类立法的出现，它们是科学领域重大争议和剧变的产物。它们形成了科学传统，而我们最终需要在自身争议问题的背景下对其进行解读。

These formal criteria can of course function legitimately as maxims of scientific value and scientific procedure. To every change in scientific value, from Kepler to Laplace and from Laplace to Einstein, there has corresponded a change in scientific method, which can be formulated in changing maxims of procedure. We have seen such legislation occurring in the past as the outcome of great controversies and upheavals in science. They have formed the scientific tradition which it falls to us ultimately to interpret within the context of our own controversial issues.

这实际上正是探索科学逻辑前提的正当目的和意义。然而，任何试图将这些前提表述为经验推理的公理前提的尝试，都会掩盖这一意义。这些公设本身并不能令人信服，甚至难以清晰理解。它们的意义和说服力源于我们先前对一系列自然科学的信念，而这些信念似乎暗示了它们的有效性。只有当我们浸润于自然科学知识，并学会将其方法应用于新问题时，我们才能学会将这些公设视为我们赖以生存的指导原则。

Such is, in effect, the legitimate purpose and meaning of exploring the logical antecedents of science. But this meaning is obscured by any attempt at formulating these antecedents as the axiomatic presuppositions of empirical inference. What such postulates can say is not in itself convincing, nor indeed clearly comprehensible. They derive their meaning and convincing power from our anterior belief in a body of natural sciences which appears to imply their validity, and only as we become imbued with the knowledge of natural science and learn to apply its methods to new problems, can we learn to appreciate these postulates as guiding principles on which we rely.

如果我们未能认识到科学的逻辑前提是内在的，它们将不可避免地以先于科学研究而被接受的命题的形式出现。如果我们反思它们，发现它们并非逻辑上不可避免，那么我们将面临一个难以解决的问题，即为它们寻找论证。这个问题之所以无法解决，是因为它试图解释一种并不存在的状态。没有人能够独自证实科学的预设。科学的发现是由一代又一代伟人充满激情、持续不断的努力所取得的，他们以其坚定的信念的力量震撼了整个现代人类。我们的科学观就是这样形成的，而这些逻辑规则只是对这种科学观的一个高度概括。如果我们问为什么我们接受这种概括，答案就在于它们所概括的知识体系。我们必须通过回顾我们每个人接受这些知识的方式以及我们继续这样做的原因来回答。届时，科学将以庞大的信仰体系的形式出现，深深植根于我们的历史，并由我们社会中一个特殊组织的部分所培育。我们将看到，科学并非建立在对某个公式的接受之上，而是我们精神生活的一部分，由世界各地成千上万的专业科学家共同培育，并被数百万人以间接的方式接受和分享。我们将意识到，任何关于我们参与这种精神生活的理由的真诚阐述，都必须作为这种生活的一部分来阐述。

If we fail to realize that the logical antecedents of science are internal to science, they will inevitably appear as propositions accepted prior to the pursuit of science. If we then reflect on them and find that they are not logically inescapable, we are faced with the insoluble problem of finding a justification for them. The problem is insoluble, for it seeks an explanation for a non-existent state of affairs. Nobody has ever affirmed the presuppositions of science by themselves. The discoveries of science have been achieved by the passionately sustained efforts of succeeding generations of great men, who overwhelmed the whole of modern humanity by the power of their convictions. Thus has our scientific outlook been moulded, of which these logical rules give a highly attenuated summary. If we ask why we accept this summary, the answer lies in the body of knowledge of which they are the summary. We must reply by recalling the way each of us has come to accept that knowledge and the reasons for which we continue to do so. Science will appear then as a vast system of beliefs, deeply rooted in our history and cultivated today by a specially organized part of our society. We shall see that science is not established by the acceptance of a formula, but is part of our mental life, shared out for cultivation among many thousands of specialized scientists throughout the world, and shared receptively, at second hand, by many millions. And we shall realize that any sincere account of the reasons for which we too share in this mental life must necessarily be given as part of this life.

科学是我们所信奉的一套信念体系。这样的体系既无法从其他体系中的经验得到解释，也无法通过不带任何经验的理性来解释。然而，这并不意味着我们可以随意接受或拒绝它，而仅仅反映了这样一个事实：科学是我们所信奉的一套信念体系，因此无法用不置可否的术语来表述。在迈向这一立场的过程中，科学的逻辑分析明确地揭示了其自身的局限性，并超越自身，指向一种科学的受托人表述，我打算在本研究的后续阶段继续探讨这一问题。

Science is a system of beliefs to which we are committed. Such a system cannot be accounted for either from experience as seen within a different system, or by reason without any experience. Yet this does not signify that we are free to take it or leave it, but simply reflects the fact that it is a system of beliefs to which we are committed and which therefore cannot be represented in non-committal terms. In leading up to this position, the logical analysis of science decisively reveals its own limitations and points beyond itself in the direction of a fiduciary formulation of science, to which I propose to move on at a later stage of this enquiry.

 

 

  1. 私人和公共的激情
  2. PASSIONS, PRIVATE AND PUBLIC

我之前曾描述过，人们对一个唯有它才能引发发现的问题充满热情，并在其公布后，常常会面临对其意义和有效性的质疑，为此进行长期的斗争。在这种斗争中，发现的热情转化为一种令人信服的渴望，这显然是一个验证的过程，在这个过程中，一个人既要确保自己的主张得到认可，又要努力使他人接受这些主张。

I have described before the passionate preoccupation with a problem which alone can elicit discovery, and the protracted struggles against doubts of its significance and validity by which its announcement is often followed. Such a struggle, in which the ardour of discovery is transformed into a craving to convince, is clearly a process of verification in which the act of making sure of one’s own claims is coupled with the effort of getting them accepted by others.

然而，当我们追寻科学发现，观察它们如何陆续发表，如何进入教科书，最终确保它们被一代又一代的学生接受为既定知识的一部分，并由此被公众接受时，我们发现，它们所激发的求知热情似乎逐渐减弱，只剩下发现者在顿悟时刻初次激动的微弱回声。像相对论这样的理论，通过暗示其尚未被理解的美，不断吸引着新学生和门外汉的兴趣：每当有新的头脑领悟该理论时，这种美就会被重新发现。而且，正是由于这种遥远而难以接近的美，而不是因为它那几个有用的公式（可以在一分钟内记住），相对论仍然被视为一项思想的胜利并被接受为伟大的真理。公众对科学的所有真正欣赏仍然取决于对这种美的欣赏——即使只是间接感受到的；它间接地赞颂了大众所接受的价值观，即那些被灌输给一群接受其文化指导的人的价值观。尽管奔向大海的洪流不再开辟新的道路，但那些曾经激励着发现者的求知激情，依然在科学的普遍价值中跳动。

Yet as we pursue scientific discoveries through their consecutive publication on their way to the textbooks, which eventually assures their reception as part of established knowledge by successive generations of students, and through these by the general public, we observe that the intellectual passions aroused by them appear gradually toned down to a faint echo of their discoverer’s first excitement at the moment of Illumination. A theory like that of relativity continues to attract the interest of ever new students and laymen by intimations of its beauty yet hidden to their understanding: a beauty which is rediscovered every time a new mind apprehends the theory. And it is still for the sake of this remote and inaccessible beauty, and not for its few useful formulae (which could be memorized in a minute), that relativity continues to be valued as an intellectual triumph and accepted as a great truth. All true appreciation of science by the public continues to depend on the appreciation of such beauty—even though sensed only at second hand; it offers an indirect tribute to the values that the multitude have been taught to entrust to a group of men whose cultural guidance they have accepted. Though the torrent widening towards the ocean no longer breaks new paths, the intellectual passions which had urged on the discoverer still pulsate in the common valuation of science.

在此，从启发式行为到对其结果的常规教学和学习，最终转变为仅仅将这些结果视为已知和真实，在此过程中，认知者的个人参与发生了彻底的转变。最初的启发式行为中，冲动是研究者剧烈而不可逆转的自我转变，随后可能伴随着几乎同样剧烈的转变他人的过程，这种冲动首先在公众最终接受这一发现的过程中以更温和的形式重复出现，并最终呈现出一种所有动态特质都丧失的形式。个人参与从冲动地将自己倾注于未经检验的假设，转变为自信地将某些结论作为自身解释框架的一部分。原创性的驱动力被简化为静态的个人知识极化；导致发现并指导其验证的智力努力转化为一种坚信其为真的信念力量——这与习得技能的努力转化为对其精通的感受完全相同。这种情感的瀑布效应在许多不同的知识领域中都能找到类似的痕迹，这些领域最初由先驱者开创，后来又由他们的继承者掌握。但我先不谈学徒期的分析，而是先来比较一下我们身体情感和智力激情的积极作用。

A transition takes place here from a heuristic act to the routine teaching and learning of its results, and eventually to the mere holding of these as known and true, in the course of which the personal participation of the knower is altogether transformed. The impulse which in the original heuristic act was a violent irreversible self-conversion of the investigator and may have been followed by an almost equally tempestuous process of converting others, is first repeated as a milder version of itself in the eventual acceptance of the discovery by the public, and will thus assume finally a form in which all dynamic quality is lost. Personal participation changes from an impetuous pouring out of oneself into channels of untried assumptions, into a confident holding of certain conclusions as part of one’s interpretative framework. The driving power of originality is reduced to a static personal polarization of knowledge; the intellectual effort which led to discovery and guided its verification is transformed into the force of a conviction which holds it to be true—in exactly the same way as the effort of acquiring a skill is transformed into a sense of its mastery. This kind of emotional cascade could be detected on parallel lines over many different domains of knowledge which are originally shaped by pioneers and subsequently held by their successors. But I shall postpone this analysis of apprenticeship, and turn now to a comparison of the affirmative functions of our bodily emotions with those of our intellectual passions.

并非所有情绪都能对受其影响的人的外在事物产生足够尖锐的影响，从而暗示出一种肯定。倦怠、活泼或不安、焦虑（不同于恐惧）、醉酒后的狂喜，这些都是普遍存在的性格变化，并不意味着受其影响的人对自身以外的任何事物都抱有肯定的态度。但我们发现，驱动力、欲望的诱惑和恐惧的掌控，都具有与求知激情同样的尖锐特征。我们之前确实承认过，这些驱动力是我们掌握并保持知识的主动原则的最原始表现。

Not all emotions have a sufficiently pointed bearing on something outside the person moved by them to imply an affirmation. Languor, vivacity or restlessness, anxiety (as distinct from fear), drunken hilarity are all pervasive changes of personality that imply no affirmation on the part of the person affected by them about anything outside himself. But we find the same pointed character that intellectual passions invariably possess in the force of drives, the lure of lust, the grip of fear. We have indeed acknowledged such drives before as the most primitive manifestations of the active principle by which we grasp knowledge and hold it.

是的，饥饿、性和恐惧是人们以激情追求的动机，而这些追求试图通过进食、交媾或逃跑等满足性行为来发现满足其动机的手段；因此，食欲的满足也是一种验证方式——就像食物中的布丁一样。然而，我们必须考虑到布丁中可能有毒的可能性，并且不能认为动物吞下的所有东西都是合适的食物。虽然我们认为动物有能力选择食物，但我们不应认为它们的选择是绝对正确的。

Yes, hunger, sex and fear are the motives of quests pursued with passion, and these quests seek to discover the means to satisfy their motives by consummatory acts like eating, copulation or flight; and hence it follows also that the gratification of appetites is a manner of verification—the proof of the pudding which is in the eating. Yet we must allow for the possibility of the pudding’s being poisoned, and not consider that everything that an animal swallows is proper food for it. While we shall hold that animals are competent to choose their food, we shall not deem their choice infallible.

与求知激情的相似之处显而易见，与之形成鲜明对比的也同样如此。正如我们对本能的追求意味着假设存在着我们有理由渴望或恐惧的事物一样，所有激发和塑造发现的激情都意味着相信存在着一种知识，而这些激情正是这些知识的价值之所在；同样，在赋予这些激情以识别真理的力量时，我们并非假定它们绝对正确——因为没有任何科学程序规则能够确保找到真理并避免错误——而是承认它们的能力。然而，我们的求知激情与我们与动物共有的渴望和情感有着本质的不同。这些渴望和情感的满足终结了引发它们的情境。同样，发现终结了它所源于的问题，但它留下了知识，而知识满足了一种与维持探索渴望的激情类似的激情。因此，求知激情因其满足而永存。

The parallel with intellectual passions is clear, and so is the contrast to them. As the pursuit of our drives implies the supposition that there exist objects which we have reason to desire or to fear, so similarly, all passions animating and shaping discovery imply a belief in the possibility of a knowledge of which these passions declare the value; and again, in accrediting these passions with the power to recognize the truth, we do not assume their infallibility—since no rule of scientific procedure is certain of finding the truth and avoiding error—but we accept their competence. Our intellectual passions, however, differ essentially from the cravings and emotions which we share with the animals. The satisfaction of these terminates the situation which evoked them. Discovery likewise terminates the problem from which it started, but it leaves behind knowledge, which gratifies a passion similar to that which sustained the craving for discovery. Thus intellectual passions perpetuate themselves by their fulfilment.

求知激情的这种独特性，很大程度上源于它们依附于一个清晰的框架。科学家致力于发现一种令人满意的理论，一旦找到，便能永久地享受其卓越之处。激励学生攻克数学物理难题的求知激情，在他最终感到理解之后便会得到满足，但正是由此产生的精通感，才赋予了他永久的求知满足。动物在完成一项奇技淫巧后，纯粹的求知喜悦已经展现出同样持久的特质，而人类的表达能力可以将这种喜悦的范围拓展到整个文化满足体系。

This distinctive quality of intellectual passions is largely due to the fact that they are attached to an articulate framework. A scientist seeks to discover a satisfying theory, and when he has found it, he can enjoy its excellence permanently. The intellectual passion which animates the student to grapple with the difficulties of mathematical physics is gratified when he feels at last that he understands it, but it is the resulting sense of mastery that gives him permanent intellectual satisfaction. While the purely intellectual joy of the animal who has contrived a trick already shows the same enduring quality, the articulate powers of man can extend the range of such joys to whole systems of cultural gratification.

这种更广阔的视角让我们重新认识到，科学价值必须作为人类文化的一部分得到认可，而这种文化涵盖人类的艺术、法律和宗教，所有这些都同样是通过语言的运用而产生的。这座充满激情的思想大厦，其构建提供了创造的空间，其持久的结构也持续滋养和满足着这些激情。在这种文化中成长的年轻男女通过将自己的思想倾注于其结构中来接受它，并因此体验着它教导他们去感受的情感。他们又将这些情感传递给后代，而这座大厦的延续依赖于后代的热情回应。与满足欲望相比，文化的享受并不会导致满足之物的匮乏，而是确保并不断扩大这些满足之物的可及性。获得这些物品的人通过实践所学知识，增加了其普遍供应，并教导他人享受它们。学生则顺从于他所获得的知识，并以其标准提升自己。

This wider perspective brings us back to the fact that scientific value must be justified as part of a human culture extending over the arts, laws and religions of man, all contrived likewise by the use of language. For this great articulate edifice of passionate thought has been reared by the force of the passions to which its erection offered creative scope, and its lasting fabric continues to foster and gratify these same passions. Young men and women brought up in this culture accept it by pouring their minds into its fabric, and so live the emotions which it teaches them to feel. They transmit these emotions in their turn to succeeding generations, on whose responding fervour the edifice relies for its continued existence. By contrast to the satisfaction of appetites, the enjoyment of culture creates no scarcity in the objects of offering gratification, but secures and ever widens their availability to others. Those who obtain such goods increase their universal supply and teach others to enjoy them by practising what they were taught. The pupil submits to what he acquires and improves himself by its standards.

因此，满足我们智识激情的社会知识不仅仅是一种满足感的来源，更是被我们视为一种赢得尊重的声音。屈服于智识激情，我们渴望让自己更加满足，并承担起按照激情为自己设定的标准进行自我教育的义务。从这个意义上说，这些激情是公开的，而非私人的：它们乐于珍视外在的事物，纯粹是为了自身利益。这的确是欲望与精神兴趣的根本区别。我们必须承认，两者都是由激情所维系的，最终都必须依赖于我们为自己设定的标准。因为，尽管智识标准是通过教育习得的，而我们的欲望偏好主要源于天性，但两者都可能偏离当前的习俗；即使它们符合习俗，最终也必须由我们自己认可。然而，欲望受个人满足标准的引导，而追求精神卓越的激情则认为自己正在履行普遍的义务。

Accordingly, the social lore which satisfied our intellectual passions is not merely desired as a source of gratification; it is listened to as a voice which commands respect. Yielding to our intellectual passions, we desire to become more satisfying to ourselves, and accept an obligation to educate ourselves by the standards which our passions have set to ourselves. In this sense these passions are public, not private: they delight in cherishing something external to us, for its own sake. Here is indeed the fundamental difference between appetites and mental interests. We must admit that both are sustained by passions and must ultimately rely on standards which we set to ourselves. For even though intellectual standards are acquired by education, while our appetitive tastes are predominantly innate, both may deviate from current custom; and even when they conform to it, they must both ultimately be accredited by ourselves. But while appetites are guided by standards of private satisfaction, a passion for mental excellence believes itself to be fulfilling universal obligations.

这种区别对于文化的存在至关重要。如果否认这一点，所有文化生活原则上都会服从于我们欲望的要求以及负责促进物质福利的公共当局的要求。我将在定义纯科学与技术的关系时进一步探讨这种情况。

This distinction is vital to the existence of culture. If it is repudiated, all cultural life becomes subordinated in principle to the demand of our appetites and of the public authorities responsible for the advancement of material welfare. I shall deal with this situation further when defining the relation of pure science to technology.

 

 

  1. 科学与技术
  2. SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

在列举动物能够进行的三种学习方式时，我把技巧学习放在了手势学习之前，因为低等动物的运动能力在它们获得记录复杂感知的能力之前就已经充分发展。然而，执行有用行动的能力预设了对行动发生环境的某种纯粹的智力控制。技术总是涉及一些经验知识的应用，而这些知识可能属于自然科学的一部分。我们的发明总是利用一些先前的观察。

In the list of three kinds of learning of which animals are capable I have placed trick learning before sign learning, since motoricity is fully developed in the lower animals before they achieve the capacity for recording complex perceptions. Yet the capacity to perform a useful action presupposes some purely intellectual control over the circumstances in which the action is to take place. Technology always involves the application of some empirical knowledge and this knowledge may be part of natural science. Our contriving always makes use of some anterior observing.

这样说来，我们意识到技术操作中两件事的结合是不可通约的。假设你用锤子敲一颗钉子。开始之前，你会看着锤子、钉子和要钉钉子的木板；结果是你可以用语言表达的知识。然后你把钉子敲进去。结果是一个行为：现在某个东西被牢牢地钉上了。你可以拥有关于它的知识，但它本身并不是知识。它是一种物质变化，才算是一项成就。知识可以是真或假，而行动只能是成功或失败、正确或错误。

Putting it this way, we become aware of the incommensurability of the two things combined in a technical performance. Suppose you hammer in a nail. Before starting, you look at the hammer, the nail and the board into which you will drive it; the result is knowledge which you can put into words. Then you hammer in the nail. The result is a deed: something is now firmly nailed on. Of this you can have knowledge, but it is not itself knowledge. It is a material change which counts as an achievement. Knowledge can be true or false, while action can only be successful or unsuccessful, right or wrong.

因此，为设计做准备的观察，必须寻求不仅真实，而且能够指导实际操作的知识。它必须努力获得实用的知识。

It follows that an observing which prepares a contriving must seek knowledge that is not merely true, but also useful as a guide to a practical performance. It must strive for applicable knowledge.

应用知识的概念框架与纯粹知识的概念框架不同。它主要取决于与此类知识相关的成功操作。再次以敲击为例。这种操作隐含着锤子的概念，它定义了一类（实际或潜在的）锤子对象。除了常见的这类工具外，它还包括枪托、鞋跟和厚字典，并同时根据适用性对这些工具进行分级。一个物体作为锤子的适用性是一个可观察的属性，但它只能在其预期用途所定义的框架内观察到。

The conceptual framework of applicable knowledge is different from that of pure knowledge. It is determined primarily in terms of the successful performances to which such knowledge is relevant. Take hammering again. This performance implies the conception of a hammer, which defines a class of objects that are (actual or potential) hammers. It will include, apart from the usual tools of this kind, rifle butts, shoe heels and fat dictionaries, and establish at the same time a grading of these tools according to suitability. The suitability of an object to serve as a hammer is an observable property, but it can be observed only within the framework defined by the performance it is supposed to serve.

可观察的事物有三类，它们可以通过其在实践操作中的参与来定义：（1）材料；（2）工具，包括各种装置；（3）过程。木材、纺织品、燃料是技术材料；锤子、发动机、房屋、铁路是工具或装置；发酵、烹饪、冶炼是技术过程。许多技术概念包含各种原本互不相关的对象（例如，从棉花和羊毛到尼龙和玻璃纤维的不同种类的纺织品，以及从蜡烛到放电灯的不同照明方式），但所有这些对象都经过特殊准备、成型或其他设计，使其在技术上适用。就此而言，这些类别的物体或过程是已知的，而单个物体或过程本身只有在它们有效运作的框架内才可理解。缺乏这一框架的纯粹知识，尤其是纯粹科学，会忽略这些类别，也无法理解这些设计。我们不能从技术知识中消除工具性，就像我们不能用实际程序来代表自然科学一样。

There are three kinds of observable things which can be defined by their participation in practical performances: (1) materials, (2) tools, including all manner of installations, and (3) processes. Timber, textiles, fuels, are technical materials; hammers, engines, houses, railways, are tools or installations; fermentation, cooking, smelting, are technical processes. Many of these technical conceptions comprise a variety of otherwise disparate objects (for example, different kinds of textiles, from cotton and wool to nylon and glass fibres, and different means of lighting, from candles to discharge lamps), but all these objects are specially prepared, shaped or otherwise so contrived as to make them technically suitable. To this extent these classes of objects or processes are known, and the individual objects or processes themselves are intelligible only within the framework of a useful performance which they successfully serve. Pure knowledge, lacking this framework, and pure science in particular, ignore these classes and cannot understand these contrivances. We cannot eliminate instrumentality from technical knowledge, any more than we can represent natural science in terms of practical procedure.

两种知识之间出现了一道鸿沟，它们都与物质事物相关：一种源于公认的目的，另一种则与任何此类目的无关。我在此探讨的科学与技术的差异，稍后将与研究无生命事物（其中没有明显的目的）的科学与研究生物（只能从意识形态角度理解）的科学之间的关系相关。在进一步阐明技术特有的逻辑结构时，我们应该牢记这一前景。

A gap is opening up here between two kinds of knowledge, both of which refer to material things: one derived from an acknowledged purpose, the other unrelated to any such purpose. The disparity of science and technology which I am examining here will prove relevant later to the relation between the science of inanimate things, in which no purpose is apparent, and that of living beings which can be understood only in ideological terms. We should keep this prospect in mind while proceeding to elucidate further the characteristic logical structure of technology.

原始技术可能被视为仅仅是身体技能的延伸，用于满足身体欲望。即使在高度复杂且主要以表述为主的技术部门，例如纺织或钢铁生产，也包含一定程度的不可具体化的专有技术，而这些技术对于劳动效率和产品质量至关重要。制造经验对技术人员来说仍然是一项宝贵的资格，而一个国家所有技术人员的积累更是一笔巨大的国家财富。尽管技术科学的教学只有通过娴熟的实践才能发挥作用，但现代人掌握技术的基础在于教科书、期刊、专利等对技术的清晰阐述。

Primitive technology may be regarded as a mere extension of bodily skills employed for the satisfaction of bodily appetites. And even in highly complex and predominantly articulate branches of technology, like the manufacture of cloth or the production of steel, there is involved a measure of unspecifiable know-how which is essential to the efficiency of labour and the quality of its product. Manufacturing experience remains a valuable qualification to a technician, and its possession by the aggregate of a country’s technicians is a great national asset. But even though the teachings of technical science can become effective only by their skilful execution, the foundation of modern man’s technical mastery lies in the explicit exposition of technology by textbooks, journals, patents, etc.

技术教导行动。这一点在它以祈使语气表达时显而易见，就像烹饪书籍或机械使用说明书中经常出现的那样。处方开头的符号是一道祈使语气，它预示着配药的命令；像编织或焊接这样的手艺也是以祈使语气来教授的。所有技术都等同于一个条件命令，因为如果不至少间接地承认技术操作可能合理追求的优势，就不可能定义一项技术。当然，如果我们将实现这一行动结果的目的归咎于一个人，那么他所做的或可能做的任何事情都可以被描述为对优势的追求；但是，如果一门技术教授所有这些可归因的目的，那么它就如同一门科学列出所有可观察到的事实一样毫无意义。因此，一项技术必须宣称自己支持一组明确的优势，并告诉人们如何才能获得这些优势。

Technology teaches action. This is made plain when it speaks in imperatives, as it often does in cookery books or directions for the use of machinery. The symbol at the head of a prescription is an imperative pre- facing an order to make up a medicine; crafts like weaving or welding are taught in imperatives. All technology is equivalent to a conditional command, for it is not possible to define a technology without acknowledging, at least at second hand, the advantages which technical operations might reasonably pursue. It is true, of course, that anything a man docs or can conceivably do, could be described as the pursuit of an advantage if we imputed to him the purpose of achieving the consequences of this action; but a technology which would teach all such imputable purposes would be as meaningless as a science which would give a list of all observable facts. A technology must therefore declare itself in favour of a definite set of advantages, and tell people what to do in order to secure them.

技术仅仅教导人们按照（或多或少）可指定的规则，利用工具来采取旨在获取物质利益的行动。194这样的规则就是操作原则。正如工具是根据其所服务的操作来定义和理解的，它们也是根据操作原则来定义和理解的，操作原则告诉我们如何执行这样的操作。 195

Technology teaches only actions to be undertaken for material advantages by the use of implements according to (more or less) specifiable rules.194 Such a rule is an operational principle. As implements are defined and understood in terms of an action which they serve, they are defined and understood likewise in terms of the operational principle which tells how to perform such an action.195

我之前曾谈到我们在技能运用中辅助性地遵循的操作原则，也谈到了在获取科学知识时应用的操作原则（同样，这些原则大多是辅助性的）。我展示了根据某些明确规则执行的符号运算，并指出此类运算要求符号易于操作，就像工具必须易于使用一样。用于技术过程自动控制的现代电子设备表明，一些高度形式化的技术操作原则可以很容易地与数学运算联系起来。技术工具的含义与数学符号的含义相似，因为它们都旨在用于特定范围的操作，并且在这些操作中，它们可以被一整类同样可用、但在其他方面截然不同的实体所取代。这种亲缘关系可以通过对操作原则的后续分析来探究。

I have spoken before of the operational principles which we observe subsidiarily in the performance of a skill, and also of the operational principles applied—again for the most part subsidiarily—in achieving scientific knowledge. I have shown symbolic operations carried out according to certain explicit rules and have noted that such operations require that symbols should be manageable, just as tools have to be serviceable. Modern electronic devices used for the automatic control of technical processes show that some highly formalized operational principles of technology can be readily affiliated to mathematical operations. The meaning of technical implements resembles that of mathematical symbols, in so far as they are both intended for use in a certain range of operations, in the service of which they can be replaced by a whole class of equally serviceable, though otherwise disparate, entities. This kinship can be pursued through the whole subsequent analysis of operational principles.

专利法承认科学知识与技术运作原理之间的区别，并明确区分发现（它扩展了我们对自然的知识）与发明（它确立了新的运作原理，并带来某些公认的优势）。新发明通常依赖于已知的经验事实，但也有可能涉及一项新发现。然而，两者之间的区别仍然适用：只有发明才能获得专利保护，而发现本身则不予保护。

The difference between scientific knowledge and an operational principle of technology is recognized by patent law, which draws a sharp distinction between a discovery, which makes an addition to our knowledge of nature, and an invention, which establishes a new operational principle serving some acknowledged advantage. New inventions rely as a rule on known facts of experience, but it may happen that a new invention involves a new discovery. Yet the distinction between the two will still hold: only the invention will be granted protection by a patent, and not the discovery as such.

原因显而易见。专利具有两项功能：公开披露其主题，以及授予对其使用的垄断权。如果将其应用于新知识，其第一项功能将排除第二项功能：一旦此类知识公开披露，它就不再是任何人的垄断。但专利可以授予并执行任何新操作原则的垄断权；它可以限制未经授权的人使用其广为人知的新发明。196

The reason is obvious. A patent has two functions, namely, publicly to disclose its subject matter, and to grant a monopoly in respect to its use. If applied to new knowledge its first function would preclude the second: once such knowledge is publicly disclosed it can no longer be anyone’s monopoly. But the patent can grant and enforce a monopoly for the practice of any new operational principle; it can restrain unauthorized persons from using the new invention which it makes generally known.196

发明与发现的共同点在于，只有当它出人意料时，才能自称是发明本身。它必须与其先行成果之间存在相当大的逻辑差距。我之前提到过，如有疑问，法院会评估该逻辑差距是否足够大，足以支持一项发明的认定。这种差距衡量了发明的独创性。

Invention has it in common with discovery that it can claim to be what it is only if it is surprising. It must be separated from its antecedents by a considerable logical gap. I have mentioned already that in case of doubt the courts undertake to assess whether this logical gap is wide enough to warrant the acknowledgment of an invention. This width measures the ingenuity of the invention.

但是，一项新的操作原理可能被专利法承认，但在技术意义上却不构成一项发明。一种从香槟中提取自来水的巧妙新工艺可能在专利法意义上是一项发明，但在技术意义上却不被承认。因为除了公开新的操作原理之外，技术还要求一项发明必须具有经济性，从而实现物质优势。

But a new operational principle may be acknowledged by patent law, and yet not be an invention in the technological sense. A new ingenious process for extracting tap-water from champagne may be an invention in the sense of patent law, but it would not be acknowledged as such by technology. For in addition to the disclosure of a new operational principle, technology requires that an invention should be economic and thus achieve a material advantage.

因此，任何发明都可能因其所消耗的手段和所产生的结果的价值发生根本性变化而变得毫无价值，甚至荒谬可笑。如果所有燃料的价格上涨一百倍，所有蒸汽机、燃气轮机、汽车和飞机都将不得不被扔进垃圾堆。一项辉煌的发明常常会在一夜之间被一项更先进的发明变得毫无意义：如今的有轨电车和它们曾经取代的马车一样荒谬。与此相反，科学观察的有效性不会受到商品价值变化的影响。如果钻石变得像今天的盐一样便宜，而盐又像今天的钻石一样珍贵，这并不会使钻石或盐的任何物理和化学原理失效。如果这两种矿物中的任何一种变得稀有到几乎无法获取，这可能会影响人们对其研究的兴趣，但其结果的有效性不会受到影响。在科学上，也不存在真正与一项发明的消亡相对应的情况，因为出现了一种更有利可图的方式来实现同样的优势。

Hence any invention can be rendered worthless, and indeed farcical, by a radical change in the values of the means used up and the ends produced by it. If the price of all fuels went up one hundred-fold, all steam engines, gas turbines, motor-cars and aeroplanes, would have to be thrown on the junk heap. A brilliant invention is often rendered non-sensical overnight by a better invention: tram-cars are as absurd today as the horse-drawn buses which they once displaced. By contrast to this, the validity of a scientific observation cannot be affected by changes in the value of goods. If diamonds became as cheap as salt is today, and salt as precious as diamonds are now, this would not invalidate any part of the physics and chemistry of diamonds or of salt. If either of the two minerals became so rare as to be practically inaccessible, this might affect the interest attached to their study, but it would leave unimpaired the validity of its results. Nor is there any true parallel in science to the extinction of an invention by the emergence of a more profitable way of achieving the same advantage.

因此，发明之美与科学发现之美有所不同。两者皆赞赏原创性，但在科学领域，原创性在于比他人更深入地洞察事物本质的能力，而在技术领域，原创性在于工匠将已知事实转化为惊人优势的独创性。因此，技术人员的探索热情集中在其自身独特的关注点上。他追随的并非自然秩序的暗示，而是某种可能性，即以新的方式使事物运作，以实现可接受的目的，并且成本低廉，从而获得利润。在探索新问题、收集线索和思考未来前景的过程中，技术人员必须牢记科学家所忽略的一系列利弊。他必须敏锐地感知人们的需求，并能够评估人们为满足这些需求愿意付出的代价。对这种瞬息万变的景象的热情，对于专注于自然内在规律的科学家来说是陌生的。

The beauty of an invention differs accordingly from the beauty of a scientific discovery. Originality is appreciated in both, but in science originality lies in the power of seeing more deeply than others into the nature of things, while in technology it consists in the ingenuity of the artificer in turning known facts to a surprising advantage. The heuristic passion of the technician centres therefore on his own distinctive focus. He follows the intimations, not of a natural order, but of a possibility for making things work in a new way for an acceptable purpose, and cheaply enough to show a profit. In feeling his way towards new problems, in collecting clues and pondering perspectives, the technologist must keep in mind a whole panorama of advantages and disadvantages which the scientist ignores. He must be keenly susceptible to people’s wants and able to assess the price at which they would be prepared to satisfy them. A passionate interest in such momentary constellations is foreign to the scientist, whose eye is fixed on the inner law of nature.

因此，价值观的冲突就此产生，使得两种职业难以融合。JR奥本海默根据二战期间在洛斯阿拉莫斯研发原子武器的经历写道：“科学家对那些关注研发的人的实际执着感到恼火，而那些关注研发的人则认为科学家懒惰、无足轻重，而且根本没在做真正的工作。因此，实验室很快就会变成要么是科学家，要么是科学家。” 197

Hence there arises a conflict of values which makes it difficult to mix the two occupations. From his experience of developing atomic weapons in Los Alamos during the Second World War, J.R.Oppenheimer wrote: ‘The scientist is irritated by the practical preoccupations of the man concerned with development, and the man concerned with development thinks that the scientist is lazy and of no account and is not doing a real job anyway. Therefore the laboratory very soon gets to be all one thing or all the other.’197

科学与技术之间这种截然相反的界限，与某些领域在某一方面构成两者之间的过渡完全相容。构成现代工业主体的古老工艺，并非依靠科学的帮助，而是通过简单的反复试验而发明出来的。相比之下，电工技术和许多化学技术则源于纯科学在实际问题中的应用。因此，科学与技术之间存在着如下的相互关系：如果技术过程是科学知识的应用，那么它对科学没有任何贡献；而经验技术本身并不科学，正因为如此，它很可能为科学研究提供重要的素材。198

This sharp division between science and technology is entirely compatible with the existence of domains which in one respect or another form a transition between them. The older crafts which still form the majority of modern industries were invented by mere trial and error, without the aid of science. By contrast, electrotechnics and much of chemical technology are derived from the application of pure science to practical problems. Hence there is the following interrelation between science and technology. To the extent to which a technical process is an application of scientific knowledge it contributes nothing to science, while empirical technology, which is itself unscientific, may well offer—for this very reason—important material for scientific study.198

相应地，我们有两种介于科学和技术之间的研究形式。建立在科学应用基础上的技术可以形成自己的科学体系。电工技术与空气动力学理论就是系统技术的例子，它们可以像纯科学一样进行培养。然而，它们的技术特性显而易见，如果经济关系的彻底变化摧毁了它们的实际效用，它们可能会失去所有兴趣并被遗忘。另一方面，也可能出现这样的情况：纯科学的某些部分提供了异常丰富的技术上有用的信息来源，因此人们认为它们值得培养，尽管否则它们会缺乏足够的兴趣。对煤炭、金属、羊毛、棉花等的科学研究就是这种技术上合理的科学的分支。

We have, correspondingly, two forms of enquiry that lie between science and technology. Technologies founded on an application of science may form a scientific system of their own. Electrotechnics and the theory of aerodynamics are examples of systematic technology which can be cultivated in the same way as pure science. Yet their technological character is apparent in the fact that they might lose all interest and fall into oblivion, if a radical change of economic relationships were to destroy their practical usefulness. On the other hand, it may happen that some parts of pure science offer such exceptionally ample sources of technically useful information that they are thought worth cultivation for this reason, though they would otherwise lack sufficient interest. The scientific study of coal, metals, wool, cotton, etc., are branches of such technically justified science.

系统技术与技术论证科学是介于纯科学与纯技术之间的两个研究领域。但这两个领域可能完全重叠。发现胰岛素可以治愈糖尿病，这本身就对科学做出了重要贡献，因为它的主题本身就具有重要意义；它也发明了一种用于治疗糖尿病的操作原理。同样的特性也适用于药理学的大部分领域。事实上，当自然界中固有的过程因其结果的重要性而引起科学的兴趣，同时又可以随意操作以实现这一理想结果时，它就适用。科学与技术之间的这种巧合完全可以用将它们总体定义为完全不同领域的相同原理来解释。 199

Systematic technology and technically justified science are two fields of study lying between pure science and pure technology. But the two fields may overlap completely. The discovery of insulin as a cure for diabetes was an important contribution to science, owing to the intrinsic interest of its subject matter; it was also the invention of an operational principle serving to cure diabetes. The same quality applies over large parts of pharmacology. It holds, indeed, wherever a process inherent in nature is interesting to science owing to the importance of its outcome, while at the same time it can also be operated at will for achieving this desirable outcome. Such coincidences between science and technology are fully accounted for by the same principles which define them in general as completely disparate domains.199

直到最近，没有什么比纯科学与技术之间的区别更为明显。这种区别毫无疑问地体现在高等教育的总体框架中，例如大学和技术学院的划分；它体现在纯化学与应用化学、纯物理与应用物理、纯数学与应用数学等学科的现行区别中，也体现在大学教席、期刊和国际会议的描述中；它决定了大学和工业实验室科学家的就业条件；它构成了专利法运作的基础。

Nothing could have appeared more obvious until recently than this difference between pure science and technology. It is unquestioningly embodied in the general framework of higher education, as shown by its division into universities and colleges of technology; it is expressed in the current distinctions between pure and applied chemistry, pure and applied physics, pure and applied mathematics, etc., in the description of university chairs, journals and international congresses; it determines the conditions of employment of scientists in universities on the one hand and industrial laboratories on the other; it underlies the operation of the patent law.

这一框架在非马克思主义国家几乎未曾改变，在苏联也未完全被抛弃。但自1930年左右新马克思主义科学理论兴起以来，该理论在随后的十年内成为苏联的官方学说，并在苏联境外获得了广泛的影响。科学与技术之间的区别，即使在这些机构的持续运作下仍在实践中得到维护，在原则上也受到了强烈的挑战。

This framework survives practically unchanged in the countries not subject to Marxism and has not been altogether abandoned in the Soviet Union either. But since the rise around 1930 of the Neo-Marxian theory of science, which became within the subsequent decade the official doctrine of the U.S.S.R. and gained widespread influence outside it, the distinction between science and technology, even where still upheld in practice by the continued operation of these institutions, is violently challenged in principle.

这是前文所述将文化价值观置于极端功利主义的公共利益观念之下的驱动力的一部分：一种自相矛盾地被过度道德抱负所浸染的唯物主义观点。这种攻击当然是一把双刃剑。它否定了纯粹的智识激情在引导科学发现方面的有效性，因为它肯定科学进步中的每一步重要进步都源于特定的实际利益；同时，它也谴责为追求科学而追求科学是不负责任、自私和不道德的。从字面上看，这两种攻击是互不相容的，因为没有真正发生的事情不能被谴责为道德错误。但对文化的唯物主义解读是一种伪装的命令：它既宣称文化实际上是，又规定它应该是，福祉的仆人。这是拉普拉斯体系的一部分，在该体系中，道德必须通过用科学预测来体现自身，才能寻求科学的认可。 200我在此并不太关心这种对科学的威胁在实践中会有多严重。斯大林主义正统派官方对纯粹追求科学的否定，导致了俄国最杰出的生物学家尼·维维洛夫于1942年遭受迫害和死亡，并导致到1948年，生物学的各个分支学科遭到压制或严重扭曲。但除此之外，斯大林主义似乎并没有给自然科学家施加任何限制，除了让他们虚伪地宣称自己的工作以实际用途为指导。或许仅此而已。人们或许可以无限期地继续从事纯科学研究，同时宣称自己的科学理论揭露了这种职业的虚伪或将其斥为一种滥用。然而，在科学家没有被迫接受这一理论的国家中，这种理论在科学家中的传播确实提出了与我们相关的问题，即激发科学研究的独特激情是否有一天会被其他激情所取代，或者甚至可能由于缺乏回应而逐渐消失。

This is part of the drive, described earlier on, for subordinating cultural values to a radically utilitarian conception of the public good: a materialistic outlook paradoxically imbued by inordinate moral aspirations. Such an attack is of course double-edged. It denies the effectiveness of pure intellectual passions in guiding scientific discovery, by affirming that every important step in the progress of science occurs in response to a specific practical interest; while it also denounces the pursuit of science for its own sake as irresponsible, selfish, immoral. Taken literally, the two attacks are mutually incompatible, for something that does not really happen cannot be denounced as morally wrong. But the materialistic interpretation of culture is a disguised imperative: it both declares that culture really is, and decrees that it ought to be, the servant of welfare. This is part of the Laplacean system in which morality must seek the sanction of science by representing itself in terms of scientific predictions.200 I am not much concerned here with the question how serious this menace to science may prove in practice. While the official repudiation by Stalinist orthodoxy of science pursued for its own sake led to the persecution and death in 1942 of Russia’s most distinguished biologist, N.I.Vavilov, and had resulted by 1948 in the suppression or serious distortion of various branches of biology, it seems otherwise to have imposed on natural scientists little more restraint than the obligation falsely to declare their work to be guided by its practical usefulness. And this may be all. People may perhaps continue indefinitely to cultivate pure science, while professing a theory of science which exposes this occupation as a pretence or condemns it as an abuse. Yet the spread of this doctrine among scientists in countries where they are not compelled to subscribe to it, does raise the question which is relevant for us here, whether the distinctive passions which animate the cultivation of science may be superseded one day by other passions, or may even simply fade away for lack of response to them.

例如，ARC 支持达尔文关于豆芽弯曲的实验，或者温特夫妇早期关于燕麦胚芽鞘生长的实验——因为没有人能够预见到这些观察结果会对未来农业产生的影响……但研究理事会至少应该非常小心，不要阻碍纯科学的进步……知识是一株娇嫩的植物，……不断地拔起植物来观察根部生长情况是一种不可取的做法”（第42-3页）。

A.R.C. to have supported, for example, Darwin’s experiments on the curving of bean shoots or the early experiments of the Wents on the growth of the oat coleoptile— because no one could have foreseen the impact that these observations were going to have on the agriculture of the future…. But at least the Research Councils should take great care not to impede the advance of pure science…. Knowledge is a delicate plant, and…it is an undesirable practice to keep pulling plants up to see how the roots are getting on’ (pp. 42–3).

当我警告说，如果科学不能避免改变我们对人的观念，那么它可能会再次失去信誉，就像圣奥古斯丁所说的那样时，我已经从积极的意义上回答了最后一个问题。201对自然科学的欣赏起步较晚，其传统根植于有限的地域。自然科学只是众多同样古老而丰富的文明中的一个枝芽。希腊人从未发展出系统的自然科学，拜占庭和中国也一样，尽管他们在技术上取得了成就。202今天我们之所以能够自信地谈论十六、十七世纪的科学，只是因为凭借现代的后见之明，我们能够轻易地将真正的科学著作与不科学的杂糅区分开来。开普勒出版于1619年的《和声学》就充满了占星术的元素，这一点在之后两三代科学家的许多著作中也颇为典型。我之前提到过，1660年皇家学会的创始人之一格兰维尔坚持不懈地主张承认巫术的存在。另一位创始人约翰·奥布里除了一篇关于神秘现象的论文外，几乎没有发表过其他作品。203当时主导法国的笛卡尔精神是先验的，而非实验的。牛顿本人仍然偶尔在科学中运用宗教论证；例如，他认为上帝赋予世界原子结构最有利于实现他的目标。19世纪和20世纪的重大争议表明，反对外来观点侵入科学的斗争从未停止，并且在这些问题上，占主导地位的多数派和各种存疑的少数派科学家之间仍然存在着严重的分歧。然而，我们可以承认，到了牛顿的影响逐渐盛行之时，尤其是通过他的《光学》一书，观察科学的方法得到了有效的巩固。从那时起，尽管存在着我在“科学争议”一节中所描述的不确定性和变幻莫测，我们仍然可以辨认出一群团结一致的人，他们秉持着相同的科学传统，以适当的气质和对科学的真正理解为动力。阿拉戈称赞勒威耶 1846 年发现海王星是“他的国家最崇高的荣誉之一，值得后人感激和钦佩” 204用清晰的语调表达了这一点。没有任何知识贡献比发现这颗遥远的新行星更无用。

I have answered the last question in the positive sense, when warning that science may be once more discredited, as it was by St. Augustine, if it cannot avoid denaturing our conception of man.201 The appreciation of natural science is of recent origin and its tradition is rooted in a limited area. It is a single shoot of one civilization among many others of equal antiquity and richness. The Greeks never developed a systematic natural science, nor did Byzantium or China, despite their technological achievements.202 Today we can speak confidently of sixteenth- and seventeenth-century science only because, with modern hindsight, we can easily separate the genuine works of science from unscientific admixtures. Kepler’s Harmonics, published in 1619, was imbued with astrology, and it is typical in this respect of much subsequent writing among scientists for the following two or three generations. I have mentioned already that Glanvill, one of the founders of the Royal Society in 1660, argued persistently for the acknowledgment of witchcraft. Another founding fellow, John Aubrey, published little else than a treatise on occult phenomena.203 The Cartesian spirit dominating France at that time was a- prioristic rather than experimental. Newton himself still occasionally used religious arguments in science; for example when he suggested that God gave the world an atomic structure, as most conducive to his purpose. The great controversies of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries show that the struggle against intrusion of extraneous points of view into science have never ceased and that grave differences continue to persist in respect to these issues between a dominant majority and various dubiously established minorities of scientists. Yet we may acknowledge that by the time Newton’s influence became prevalent, and particularly through his Optics, the method of observational science became effectively consolidated. Since then, in spite of such uncertainties and vagaries as I have described in the section on Scientific Controversies, we may recognize a coherent body of men, standing in the same scientific tradition, moved by the proper temper and true Appreciation of science. Arago acclaiming Leverrier’s discovery of Neptune in 1846 as ‘one of the noblest titles of his country to the gratitude and admiration of posterity’204 expressed this in clear accents. No contribution to knowledge could be more useless than was the discovery of this remote new planet.

事实上，自然科学在此之前并未对技术做出任何重大贡献。工业革命的实现离不开科学的帮助。除了莫尔斯电报机之外，1851年的伦敦博览会上没有展出任何重要的工业设备或基于过去五十年科学进步的产品。人们对科学的欣赏几乎仍然不受功利主义动机的影响。

Actually, up to that time natural science had made no major contribution to technology. The industrial revolution had been achieved without scientific aid. Except for the Morse telegraph, the great London Exhibition of 1851 contained no important industrial devices or products based on the scientific progress of the previous fifty years. The appreciation of science was still almost free from utilitarian motives.

但这些情绪只在极小的范围内存在，当地居民中只有少数人持有这种观点。科学向海外以及亚洲和非洲国家的迁移是在后期缓慢进行的，那时科学的医学、工业和军事价值已经大大提升，足以促进工业欠发达国家接受科学。这些因素不利于人们真正欣赏科学。在世界各地，科学刚刚开始发展的地方，人们对其真正价值缺乏回应。因此，当局拨给研究的时间不足；政治因素扰乱了任命；商人们只资助实用项目，转移了人们对科学的兴趣。无论当地天才的资金多么丰富，这样的环境都无法使其开花结果。在本文所述的早期阶段，新西兰失去了卢瑟福，澳大利亚失去了亚历山大和布拉格，而这些损失进一步阻碍了新国家的科学发展。欧洲以外的科学很少（如果有的话）能够最终适应环境，除非一个国家的政府成功地吸引一些来自传统中心的科学家在其领土上定居，并在那里建立起一个以他们自己的传统标准为基础的科学生活的新家园。2

But these sentiments were held within a very small area and were shared at no time by more than a minority of the local population. The migration of science overseas and into Asian and African countries occurred slowly at a later period, when the medical, industrial and military value of science had greatly increased and could serve to recommend the reception of science to industrially less developed countries. These auspices did not favour a true appreciation of science. In all parts of the world where science is just beginning to be cultivated, it suffers from a lack of response to its true values. Consequently, the authorities grant insufficient time for research; politics play havoc with appointments; businessmen deflect interest from science by subsidizing only practical projects. However rich the fund of local genius may be, such an environment will fail to bring it to fruition. In the early phase in question, New Zealand loses its Rutherford, Australia its Alexander and its Bragg, and such losses retard further the growth of science in a new country. Rarely, if ever, was the final acclimatization of science outside Europe achieved, until the government of a country succeeded in inducing a few scientists from some traditional centre to settle down in their territory and to develop there a new home for scientific life, moulded on their own traditional standards.2

如今，在庸俗的粗俗功利主义和现代革命运动的意识形态功利主义的夹击下，对纯科学的热爱或许会逐渐消亡。而一旦丧失这种情感，科学的培育将失去唯一能够引导其实现真正科学价值的驱动力。普遍的观点认为，科学的培育将始终为了其实际效益而持续下去。例如，人们曾预期，如果李先科的理论是错误的，苏联政府很快就会放弃这些理论，因为它们无法产生任何有用的结果。这种预期忽略了一个事实，即这些问题在实践中无法得到解决。李先科的理论实际上是俄国的米丘林和美国的伯班克从他们作为植物育种家所取得的巨大成功中得出的理论结论。205几千年来，几乎所有困扰人类的重大系统性错误都源于实践经验。星座运势、咒语、神谕、魔法、巫术，以及现代医学出现之前的巫医和执业医师的治愈方法，都因其所谓的实践成功，在公众眼中经过数个世纪的巩固。科学方法的设计目的，正是在比实际问题所造成的情境更严谨的控制条件下，运用更严格的标准来阐明事物的本质。这些条件和标准只有通过对事物产生纯粹的科学兴趣才能发现，而这种兴趣又只能存在于受过科学价值鉴赏教育的头脑中。这种敏感性不能被随意地用于与其内在热情无关的目的。任何不相信科学本身重要——事实上是极其重要——的人，都不可能在科学领域做出任何重大发现。 206

Encircled today between the crude utilitarianism of the philistine and the ideological utilitarianism of the modern revolutionary movement, the love of pure science may falter and die. And if this sentiment were lost, the cultivation of science would lose the only driving force which can guide it towards the achievement of true scientific value. The opinion is widespread that the cultivation of science would always be continued for the sake of its practical advantages. It was expected, for example, that Lysenko’s theories, if false, would be soon abandoned by the Soviet Government because they could produce no useful results. This expectation overlooked the fact that such questions cannot be decided in practice. Lysenko’s theories are actually the theoretical conclusions which Michurin in Russia and Burbank in the U.S. derived from their substantial successes as plantbreeders.205 Almost every major systematic error which has deluded men for thousands of years relied on practical experience. Horoscopes, incantations, oracles, magic, witchcraft, the cures of witch doctors and of medical practitioners before the advent of modern medicine, were all firmly established through the centuries in the eyes of the public by their supposed practical successes. The scientific method was devised precisely for the purpose of elucidating the nature of things under more carefully controlled conditions and by more rigorous criteria than are present in the situations created by practical problems. These conditions and criteria can be discovered only by taking a purely scientific interest in the matter, which again can exist only in minds educated in the appreciation of scientific value. Such sensibility cannot be switched on at will for purposes alien to its inherent passion. No important discovery can be made in science by anyone who does not believe that science is important—indeed supremely important—in itself.206
