我这样说，其实是承认了，我认为超越的价值观可能只是人类中极少数人短暂地了解的。这并不矛盾：它正确地反映了普遍有效性并非一个可观察到的事实。当我们说一个陈述被普遍接受，或者任何理智的人都不会否认它等等时，我们是在谈论人们对该陈述的态度，只有当我们认可这些人对该陈述的判断时，我们才能认可该陈述。但并没有普遍的依据可以这样做：“永远普遍存在，万物皆有”（quod semper, ubique, ab omnibus）这句格言常常被证明是错误的。我们观察或评价的标准永远不可能来自统计调查。

In saying this, I have acknowledged that values which I deem to be transcendent may be known only transiently to a small minority of mankind. There is no contradiction in this: it correctly reflects the fact that universal validity is not an observed fact. When we say that a statement is generally accepted or that no sane person would deny it, etc., we are saying something about the attitude of people towards the statement, which accredits the statement only if we accredit those people’s judgment of it. But there is no general warrant to do this: the maxim ‘quod semper, ubique, ab omnibus’ has often proved erroneous. The standards by which we observe or appraise can never be derived from statistical surveys.

事实上，我们无法在使用标准的过程中审视它们，因为我们无法专注于那些为了塑造我们当前关注点而辅助使用的元素。我们赋予标准绝对性，因为通过将它们作为自身的一部分来使用，我们最终依赖于它们，即使我们认识到它们实际上既不是我们自身的一部分，也不是我们自身创造的，而是外在于我们自身的。然而，这种依赖只能在某个特定的时间和地点的瞬间发生，而我们的标准将在这个历史背景下被赋予绝对性。因此，我可以恰当地宣称，现代科学传统所秉持的科学价值观是永恒的，尽管我担心它们可能很快就会永远消失。这种二元性稍后将在承诺的概念中得到稳定。

Indeed, we cannot look at our standards in the process of using them, for we cannot attend focally to elements that are used subsidiarily for the purpose of shaping the present focus of our attention. We attribute absoluteness to our standards, because by using them as part of ourselves we rely on them in the ultimate resort, even while recognizing that they are actually neither part of ourselves nor made by ourselves, but external to ourselves. Yet this reliance can take place only in some momentary circumstance, at some particular place and time, and our standards will be granted absoluteness within this historical context. So I could properly profess that the scientific values upheld by the tradition of modern science are eternal, even though I feared that they might soon be lost for ever. This duality will be stabilized later within the concept of commitment.

 

 

  1. 数学
  2. MATHEMATICS

自然科学是观察的扩展；技术是设计的扩展；数学是理解的扩展。我曾用动物对复杂地形的认知方式来说明它们无法清晰表达的理解力。另一个例子，取自人类经验，是一位工程师掌握机器各部件如何组合并协同运作。理解过程清晰地通过将一组给定的公式转化为另一组公式（隐含在第一组公式中）的操作来实现，或者通过将一个几何图形转化为由第一组公式确定的另一个几何图形的构造来实现。其结果可以表达为定律，例如数论定律和几何定理，也可以表达为程序规则，例如我们解方程或从给定元素构造几何图形的规则。在第一种情况下，数学表现为一组类似于自然科学的陈述句；在第二种情况下，数学表现为一组类似于技术的处方。但这些陈述句并未记录对特定自然对象的观察，这些处方也未揭示实现任何特定物质优势的操作原理。数学公式的断言和数学证明中给出的秘诀都涉及可能与经验无特定关系的概念。有效的公式承认同一概念的两个替代方面是同一的，而证明则诱导对这两个替代方面的识别。第一个方面可以像自然科学的陈述一样被说成是真或假；第二个方面可以像技术的运作原理一样被说成是成功或失败（正确或错误）。但两者都仅仅是重组它们所论述的概念的清晰手段：一个陈述重组的结果，另一个规定实现重组的程序。

Natural science is an expansion of observing; technology, of contriving; mathematics, of understanding. I have illustrated inarticulate understanding in animals by the way they know their way about a complex topography. Another illustration of it, taken from human experience, was that of an engineer grasping how the parts of a machine fit together and function jointly. A process of understanding is carried out articulately by operations which transform a given set of formulae into another set of formulae, implied in the first, or by a construction which transforms a geometrical figure into another, determined by the first. The result can be expressed either as a law, such as the laws of number theory and the theorems of geometry, or as a rule of procedure, such as we have for solving equations or for constructing geometrical figures from given elements. In the first case mathematics appears as a set of declaratory sentences resembling natural science, in the second as a set of recipes resembling technology. But these declaratory sentences record no observations concerning specific objects of nature, and the recipes disclose no operational principles for achieving any specific material advantage. Both the affirmations of mathematical formulae and the recipes given in mathematical proofs deal with conceptions which may have no specific bearing on experience. Valid formulae acknowledge the identity of two alternative aspects of the same conception, while proofs induce the identification of two such alternatives. The first can be said to be true or false like the statements of natural science; the second to be successful or unsuccessful (right or wrong) like the operational principles of technology. But both are merely articulate means of reorganizing the conceptions of which they speak: one stating the result of the reorganization, the other prescribing the procedure for achieving it.

因此，数学既可以与自然科学联系在一起，也可以与技术紧密联系。当力学被转化为四维非欧几里得几何，或者当三维几何被视为包含刚性固体的度量关系时，物理学与数学便相通了。整数的概念是物理学的一部分，因为它肯定了永久离散对象的存在；另一方面，数学运算可以成为自动化技术过程的一部分，而严格形式化的技术也可以被视为数学的一部分。 207因此，数学符号和数学运算本身就适用于对事物和操作进行智力控制，但它们适用的情况千差万别，以至于控制它们的数学框架几乎无法体现任何特定的经验。即使是初等数学也包含着极其普遍的概念和运算，而这些概念又因数学创造力而进一步细化，数学创造力不断将数学的概念框架扩展到其与经验的最初联系之外。

Accordingly, mathematics can be equally well affiliated either to natural science or technology. Physics and mathematics coincide when mechanics is transposed into a four-dimensional non-Euclidean geometry, and when three-dimensional geometry is regarded as comprising the metric relations of rigid solids. The conception of integers is part of physics in so far as it affirms the existence of permanently discrete objects; while on the other hand, mathematical operations can form part of automatic technical processes and a strictly formalized technology may be regarded as part of mathematics.207 Mathematical symbolism and mathematical operations thus show themselves appropriate to the exercise of intellectual control both over things and manipulations, but the instances to which they apply are so varied as to leave extremely little of any particular experience attached to the mathematical framework controlling them. Even elementary mathematics denotes conceptions and operations of great generality, and these conceptions are further attenuated by mathematical inventiveness, which keeps extending the conceptual framework of mathematics ever further beyond its original contacts with experience.

这一过程主要由两种密切相关的渴望所引导。第一种渴望追求更高的普遍性。笛卡尔成功地发现解析几何定理不过是代数的一种例证，将人类思维提升到了一个将数字和图表融合在一起、形成共同和谐理解的境界。从那时起，数学在普遍性方面取得了无数的进步。此外，对更高普遍性的渴望往往意味着对更高严谨性的要求——这是引导数学发明的第二种渴望。欧几里得毫不犹豫地通过连接两个圆的交点和两个圆心来构造一个等边三角形。但是，一旦直线被定义为点集，两个相交的圆有交点似乎就不再显而易见了。与传统的常识相反，曲线现在可以被认为是在每一点都不连续的。因此，现代集合论在几何学中提出了新的批判性顾虑，并且通过满足这些顾虑，它建立了更严格的几何证明标准。 208

This process is principally guided by two closely related cravings. The first strives for ever greater generality. Descartes’ triumph in discovering that the theorems of analytical geometry were but an illustration of algebra elevated the human mind into a region where numbers and diagrams were merged in a common harmonious understanding. Since then mathematics has made innumerable further strides towards generalization. Moreover, aspirations for greater generality frequently entail demands for greater rigorousness—the second craving that guides mathematical invention. Euclid had not hesitated to construct an equilateral triangle by connecting the point at which two circles intersect with the centres of the two circles. But once lines were defined, by a generalization of arithmetic as point-sets, it seemed no longer obvious that two circles crossing each other had a point of intersection. Contrary to traditional common sense, curves could now be conceived as discontinuous at every point. Modern set theory has thus raised new critical scruples in geometry, and by satisfying these scruples it has established more exacting standards of geometrical proof.208

我们已经见证了概念改革在自然科学中的重要性，它们在技术领域也发挥着作用。但在数学中，它们展现出一种新的力量：它们创造了一个本身就引人入胜的论域。这（正如我之前所说）就像通过创造全新的概念来发明一款游戏，这些概念的符号仅仅表示它们是某些运算的适当对象。

We have seen the importance of conceptual reforms in the natural sciences, and they play their part also in technology. But in mathematics they take on a new power: they create a universe of discourse which is interesting in itself. This is (as I have said before) like inventing a game by the creation of entirely new concepts, the symbols of which denote nothing but that they are the proper subjects for certain operations.

数学创造其自身论述对象的想象行为只有在能够描述关于这些对象的一些有趣的东西（这些东西不能从其原始定义中立即显现出来）时才是可接受的。209我之前在将实在的概念扩展到数学时曾提到过这一点，并回顾了洛巴切夫斯基的假设，即可以通过一条直线外的一点画出多条与该直线平行的线。这一假设最终得到了数学家们的认可，因为它可以被证明包含一整套值得关注的蕴涵系统。在代数中，我们有一个关于这一过程的显著例子，即负数的虚根，它最早在16世纪被定义（卡丹、邦贝利），其合理性一直存在争议，直到19世纪高斯在复数（实数与虚数之和）的微积分中发现了它们具有深远意义的函数。稍后将提到一些其他的例子。

The imaginative acts by which mathematics creates the object of its own discourse are acceptable only if something interesting can be said about these objects that is not immediately apparent from their original definition.209 I have said this before in extending the concept of reality to mathematics and recalled there how Lobatschesvky’s assumption that a multiplicity of parallels to one straight line can be drawn through one point outside it, eventually carried conviction to mathematicians because it could be shown to involve a whole system of noteworthy implications. In algebra we have a striking instance of this process in the imaginary roots of negative numbers, first defined as such in the sixteenth century (Cardan, Bombelli), the justification of which remained questionable until the discovery of their far-reaching functions in the calculus of complex numbers (the sums of real and imaginary numbers) by Gauss in the nineteenth century. Some further examples will be mentioned later.

适用于外部对象的数学理论与仅就其本身而言有趣的数学发明之间，并没有明确的界限，因为数学定理总有可能在一段时间内被证明适用于经验。然而，这并非必然成立，而且对于绝大多数数学而言，这似乎不太可能，这正是这门科学的一个显著特征。210数学的主要关注点并非预测将会发生什么，也并非设计出任何人希望发生的事情，而仅仅是理解特定概念集合中不同方面之间如何进行逻辑关联。数学可以通过构想此类新问题无限扩展其研究主题，而无需任何经验的参考。随着新概念更广泛的含义和更广泛的可操作性逐渐显现，它们得以巩固。这种追求通过为进一步的概念创新提供新的机会而永存。

No sharp distinction can be drawn between mathematical theories which apply to external objects, and mathematical inventions which are interesting only in themselves, for there is always a possibility that a mathematical theorem may prove applicable to experience some time. Yet the fact that this is not necessarily true, and indeed appears very unlikely for the far greater part of mathematics, is a distinctive feature of this science.210 Not being primarily concerned with foretelling what is going to happen, or with contriving what anyone wished to happen, but merely with understanding exactly how alternative aspects of a certain set of conceptions are logically connected, mathematics can extend its subject matter indefinitely by conceiving new problems of this sort, without any reference to experience. New conceptions are thus consolidated, as their wider implications and more extensive operability come into view, and this pursuit perpetuates itself by throwing up ever new opportunities for further conceptual innovations.

现在看来，这个过程的逻辑结构并非完全是发明一款游戏，而是在玩游戏的过程中不断发明游戏。这种游戏的发明类似于写小说，两者在某种程度上确实相当相似。从来就不存在一个叫夏洛克·福尔摩斯的人，甚至也不存在像夏洛克·福尔摩斯这样的人。然而，通过描述他在一系列虚构情境中的一贯行为，这个角色得到了清晰的定义。柯南·道尔创作了几篇以夏洛克·福尔摩斯为主人公的优秀故事后，这位侦探的形象——无论其本身多么荒诞——就明确地为后续此类故事的创作奠定了基础。虚构的数学实体（例如复数）与像夏洛克·福尔摩斯这样的奇幻人物之间的主要区别在于，后者对我们的想象力有更大的掌控力。这是因为夏洛克·福尔摩斯的概念中融入了更丰富的感性元素。这就是为什么我们获得的是侦探的形象，而不仅仅是侦探的概念。

It now appears that the logical structure of this process is not quite that of inventing a game, but rather that of the continued invention of a game in the very course of playing the game. This kind of game-inventing is akin to the writing of a novel, and the parallel is indeed quite close up to a point. There never was a person called Sherlock Holmes, nor even a person like Sherlock Holmes. Yet this character was well defined by the description of his consistent behaviour in a series of fictitious situations. Once Conan Doyle had composed a few good stories with Sherlock Holmes as their hero, the image of the detective—however absurd in itself—was clearly fixed for the purposes of any further such stories. The main difference between a fictitious mathematical entity, like a complex number, and a fantastic character like Sherlock Holmes, lies in the greater hold which the latter has on our imagination. It is due to the far richer sensuous elements entering into the conception of Sherlock Holmes. That is why we acquire an image and not merely a conception of the detective.

 

 

  1. 数学的肯定
  2. THE AFFIRMATION OF MATHEMATICS

我们已经看到，如果一个陈述（1）符合事实，（2）与科学体系相关，并且（3）与一个并非没有内在意义的主题相关，那么它对自然科学而言具有价值；如果一个陈述（1）揭示了一种有效且巧妙的运算原理，并且（2）在现有情况下能够实现巨大的物质优势，那么它对技术而言也具有价值。数学比自然科学或技术自由得多。虽然它早期的​​原始概念和运算无疑最初是由经验启发而来的，并且用于控制对物质事物的操控，但这些经验和实践的联系并没有有效地融入到它目前的理解中。

We have seen that a statement is of value to natural science if it (1) corresponds to the facts, (2) is relevant to the system of science and (3) bears on a subject matter which is not without intrinsic interest; and that a statement is of value in technology (1) if it reveals an effective and ingenious operational principle which (2) achieves, in existing circumstances, a substantial material advantage. Mathematics is a much freer creation than either natural science or technology. While its early primitive conceptions and operations were no doubt originally suggested by experience and have served to control the manipulation of material things, these empirical and practical contacts do not enter effectively into its present appreciation.

那么，数学是什么？客观主义“冷酷无情、不可动摇的决心”对这个问题给出了奇怪的答案。虽然我们可以尝试将自然科学建立在所谓的经验事实的命令之上，从而实现其非个人化，技术也可以根植于实际生活的需要，但数学陈述唯一非个人化（或至少表面上非个人化）的正当性，就是它们不自相矛盾。因此，数学被描述为一组同义反复。

What, then, is mathematics? The ‘grim and inflexible resolve’ of objectivism has given strange answers to this question. For while we can attempt to achieve impersonality for natural science by basing it on the supposed commands of empirical fact, and technology can be grounded in the requirements of practical life, the only impersonal (or at least apparently impersonal) justification that is left to mathematical statements is their freedom from self-contradiction. Accordingly, mathematics has been described as a set of tautologies.

对此，首先必须反驳的是，它是错误的。重言式必然为真，但数学并非如此。我们无法判断算术公理是否一致；如果不一致，任何具体的算术定理都可能为假。因此，这些定理不是重言式。它们是并且必须始终保持尝试性，而重言式则是不容置疑的真理。

To this it must be objected in the first place that it is false. Tautologies are necessarily true, but mathematics is not. We cannot tell whether the axioms of arithmetic are consistent; and if they are not, any particular theorem of arithmetic may be false. Therefore these theorems are not tautologies. They are and must always remain tentative, while a tautology is an incontrovertible truism.

但即使假设数学完全一致，一致性标准——“重言式”理论试图支持的那个标准——仍然荒谬地不足以定义数学。人们不妨把一台随机打印字母和印刷符号的机器看作是生产所有未来科学发现、诗歌、法律、演讲、社论等等的文本。正如只有极小部分关于事实的真实陈述构成科学，只有极小部分可想象的操作原理构成技术一样，同样，只有极小部分被认为是一致的陈述构成数学。如果不诉诸将这极小部分与其他非自相矛盾陈述的压倒性优势集合体区分开来的原则，就无法正确地定义数学。

But even supposing mathematics were wholly consistent, the criterion of consistency, which the ‘tautology’ doctrine is intended to support, would still be ludicrously inadequate for defining mathematics. One might as well regard a machine which goes on printing letters and typographical signs at random as producing the text of all future scientific discoveries, poems, laws, speeches, editorials, etc. For just as only a tiny fraction of true statements about matters of fact constitute science and only a tiny fraction of conceivable operational principles constitute technology, so also only a tiny fraction of statements believed to be consistent constitute mathematics. Mathematics cannot be properly defined without appeal to the principle which distinguishes this tiny fraction from the overwhelmingly predominant aggregate of other non-self-contradictory statements.

我们可以尝试将数学定义为由一组特定的公理，按照某些运算推导出的定理的总和，这些运算将确保公理本身相互一致，从而满足自洽性。但这仍然不够充分。首先，它完全没有解释公理的选择，因此必然显得武断——但事实并非如此；其次，并非所有被认为是完善的数学都曾按照严格的程序完全形式化；第三，正如KR波普尔所指出的，在可以从一组公认的公理中推导出的命题中，对于每一个代表重要数学定理的命题来说，仍然有无数个平凡的命题。211

We may try to supply this criterion by defining mathematics as the totality of theorems derived from a certain set of axioms according to certain operations which will assure their self-consistency, provided the axioms themselves are mutually consistent. But this is still inadequate. First, because it leaves completely unaccounted for the choice of axioms, which hence must appear arbitrary—which it is not; second, because not all mathematics considered to be well established has ever been completely formalized according to strict procedure; and third, because— as K.R. Popper has pointed out—among the propositions that can be derived from some accepted set of axioms there are still, for every single one that represents a significant mathematical theorem, an infinite number that are trivial.211

所有这些困难都源于我们拒绝承认，数学若不承认其最显著的特征——即其趣味性——就无法定义。在数学中，人们能够如此深刻地感受到并如此细致地欣赏其各种层次和特质的智识之美，唯有对数学价值的非正式理解，才能将真正的数学与一堆形式上相似却又极其琐碎的陈述和运算区分开来。我们将会看到，数学的这种情感色彩也证明了它被接受为真理的合理性。正是通过满足数学家的智识激情，数学才使数学家着迷，并迫使他们在思考中追寻它并给予它认同。

All these difficulties are but consequences of our refusal to see that mathematics cannot be defined without acknowledging its most obvious feature: namely, that it is interesting. Nowhere is intellectual beauty so deeply felt and fastidiously appreciated in its various grades and qualities as in mathematics, and only the informal appreciation of mathematical value can distinguish what is mathematics from a welter of formally similar, yet altogether trivial statements and operations. And we shall see that this emotional colour of mathematics also justifies its acceptance as true. It is by satisfying his intellectual passions that mathematics fascinates the mathematician and compels him to pursue it in his thoughts and give it his assent.

我之前说过212我们只有通过对数学形式体系的默契贡献才能理解数学。我已经阐明，所有数学证明和定理最初是如何依靠直觉预见而发现的；这些发现的既定结果是如何以直觉掌握的提纲形式被正确地教授、理解和记忆的；这些结果是如何通过思考其直觉内容而有效地重新应用和进一步发展的；因此，它们只有在我们直觉认可的情况下才能获得我们的合法认可。我确实表明，所有表达都依赖于一种同类的默契成分来传达表达者认可的意义。而且，这种理解与肯定与动物生命的主动原则相一致，通过这种原则，我们塑造和接受所有层面的知识，直至驱动力、运动能力和感知能力，而作为动物，我们天生就具备这些能力。

I have said earlier on212 that we can understand mathematics only by our tacit contribution to its formalism. I have shown how all the proofs and theorems of mathematics have been originally discovered by relying on their intuitive anticipation; how the established results of such discoveries are properly taught, understood, remembered in the form of their intuitively grasped outline; how these results are effectively reapplied and developed further by pondering their intuitive content; and that they can therefore gain our legitimate assent only in terms of our intuitive approval. I have indeed shown that all articulation depends on a tacit component of the same kind for conveying a meaning accredited by the person uttering it. And also that this comprehension-cum-affirmation is continuous with the active principle of animal life by which we both shape and accept our knowledge at all its levels, down to that of drives, motoricity and perception, with which as animals we are equipped by nature.

我们用来理解和认同数学的那个难以言喻的系数，正是这种积极原则；它是一种对理智之美的热情。正是由于数学的理智之美——数学家们自己也宣称这种热情揭示了普遍真理——数学家们感到不得不接受数学为真，即使如今他已不再相信数学的逻辑必然性，并注定永远承认这样一种可以想象的可能性：数学的整个结构可能因揭示一个决定性的自相矛盾而突然崩溃。正是这种寻求意义和创造意义的渴望，支撑着他默默地弥合每一个形式证明中内在的逻辑鸿沟。

The inarticulate coefficient by which we understand and assent to mathematics is an active principle of this kind; it is a passion for intellectual beauty. It is on account of its intellectual beauty, which his own passion proclaims as revealing a universal truth, that the mathematician feels compelled to accept mathematics as true, even though he is today deprived of the belief in its logical necessity and doomed to admit forever the conceivable possibility that its whole fabric may suddenly collapse by revealing a decisive self-contradiction. And it is the same urge to see sense and make sense that supports his tacit bridging of the logical gaps internal to every formal proof.

事实上，有充分的证据表明，这种求知热情是数学得以确立的内在动力。现代数学诞生于一系列长期的概念改革，这些改革趋向于更普遍性和更严谨性，同时也源于更为激进的概念发明，这些发明开辟了全新的视角。接受这些概念创新是一种自我修正的思维行为，旨在寻求更真实的智识生活。权威人士曾指出：“科学最伟大的创造性进步往往与通过定义引入新概念相吻合。”213这之所以成立，是因为接受一个新概念，即使它由定义明确，最终也是一种非正式的行为：对我们在形式推理过程中所依赖的框架进行改造。它跨越一道逻辑鸿沟，到达彼岸，在那里我们将永远无法再以以往的方式看待事物。因此，就数学是过去概念创新的累积产物而言，我们对数学的肯定同样是一种不可逆转的、非正式的行为。

There is in fact ample evidence that such intellectual passions are intrinsic to the affirmation of mathematics. Modern mathematics has emerged from a long series of conceptual reforms tending towards greater generality and rigour, as well as from more radical conceptual inventions opening up altogether new perspectives. The acceptance of such conceptual innovations is a self-modifying mental act in search of a truer intellectual life. It has been authoritatively stated that ‘the moments of greatest creative advancement in science frequently coincide with the introduction of new notions by means of a definition’.213 This can be true only because the acceptance of a new conception, even when it is specified by a definition, is ultimately an informal act: a transformation of the framework on which we rely in the process of formal reasoning. It is the crossing of a logical gap to another shore, where we shall never again see things as we did before. To the extent, therefore, to which mathematics is the accumulated product of past conceptual innovations, our affirmation of mathematics is likewise an irreversible, informal act.

如果这样的行为符合我们追求卓越的标准，那么它就可以说是理性的。而数学家们充满热情的鉴赏家所推崇的数学的智性之美，正是这样的标准。因此，数学的根本性进步，包括概念的革新，都源于对美的追求。214这一立场与数学物理学中的情况基本相同；理智之美被视为隐藏现实的象征。然而，在自然科学中，与现实接触的感觉预示着未来尚未实现的、即将出现的发现将得到经验性的证实；而在数学中，它预示着数学本身内部未来一系列不确定的萌芽。

Such an act can be said to be rational if it satisfies our standards of excellence, and the intellectual beauty of mathematics, upheld by the passionate connoisseurship of mathematicians, is such a standard. Accordingly, fundamental progress in mathematics, involving conceptual reform, is found to be guided by a search for beauty.214 The position appears essentially the same as in mathematical physics; intellectual beauty is recognized as a token of a hidden reality. But while in the natural sciences the feeling of making contact with reality is an augury of as yet undreamed future empirical confirmations of an imminent discovery, in mathematics it betokens an indeterminate range of future germinations within mathematics itself.

由于数学证明的说服力源于我们对它的默契理解，因此对证明的接受也可能涉及彻底的概念创新。“集合论” （Mengenlehre）中有一些优美的定理，例如康托尔关于连续统“不可枚举性”的定理，G.H.哈迪写道：“一旦掌握了语言，其证明就很容易，但要使定理的含义清晰，则需要大量的解释。”215康托尔的证明跨越了一道逻辑鸿沟，只有那些愿意理解其含义并能够领悟的人才能理解。不愿或无力理解，导致数学家之间产生分歧，类似于范特霍夫和科尔贝在不对称碳原子问题上产生的分歧，或巴斯德和李比希在发酵作为酵母的重要功能问题上产生的分歧。阿达玛描述了他和伟大的勒贝格如何发现自己站在这场争论的对立面，不得不承认彼此无法理解。“我们无法回避这样的结论：显而易见的东西——所有思想领域确定性的起点——对他和我来说，意义并不相同。”216康托尔的工作所涉及的基本概念变化让 19 世纪 80 年代统治德国数学界的克罗内克非常反感，以至于他禁止康托尔在所有德国大学晋升，甚至禁止在任何德国数学期刊上发表他的论文。217阿达玛承认，在另一个伟大的现代发现领域——群论中，“尽管他最终能够将其用于简单的应用，但在掌握相当基础和肤浅的知识时，他遇到了难以克服的困难”。218诚然，一些重要的创新是通过无需如此深远的概念调整而建立的证明。即便如此，他们的卓越智识也有助于巩固其成功所基于的基本概念。

Since the convincing power of a mathematical proof operates through our tacit understanding of it, the acceptance of a proof may also involve radical conceptual innovations. There are beautiful theorems in the “theory of aggregates” (Mengenlehre) such as Cantor’s theorem of the “non enumerability” of the continuum’, writes G.H.Hardy, ‘the proof [of which] is easy enough once the language has been mastered, but considerable explanation is necessary before the meaning of the theorem becomes clear.’215 Cantor’s proofs traversed a logical gap across which only those willing to enter into their meaning and capable of grasping it could follow him. Reluctance or incapacity to do so caused divisions among mathematicians, similar to those which arose between van’t Hoff and Kolbe on the subject of the asymmetric carbon atom, or between Pasteur and Liebig on that of fermentation as a vital function of yeast. Hadamard describes how he and the great Lebesgue, finding themselves on opposite sides of this dispute, were compelled to recognize the impossibility of understanding each other. ‘We could not avoid the conclusion that what is evident—the very starting point of certitude in every domain of thought— had not the same meaning for him and for me.’216 The fundamental conceptual changes involved in Cantor’s work were so repulsive to Kroneker, who dominated German mathematics in the 1880’s, that he barred Cantor from promotion in all German universities and even from having his papers published in any German mathematical journal.217 Hadamard confesses that in another field of great modern discoveries, the theory of groups, ‘though being eventually able to use it for simple applications, he met with insuperable difficulty in mastering more than a rather elementary and superficial knowledge of it’.218 Some important innovations have, admittedly, been established by proofs requiring no such far-reaching conceptual adaptation. But even so, their intellectual excellence has contributed to the consolidation of the fundamental conceptions on which their success was based.

 

 

 

 

11

11

数学公理化

AXIOMATIZATION OF MATHEMATICS

 

 

我们再次置身于一门鲜活的科学的景象之中，它正摸索着寻求满足那些维护其价值的智识激情。我们看到它孕育了成千上万个大胆的猜测，这些猜测长期以来一直困扰着它们的作者，直到他们不辞辛劳地将它们付诸实践，并经常与旷日持久的反对意见抗争，最终在教科书中占据了一席之地。我们再次看到，这一景象与将这种启发式过程的结果——以及由此蕴含的任何进一步的延续——转化为严格形式化的公理和符号运算体系的理想之间存在着奇特的对比。事实上，对于数学而言，这一理想并非像自然科学那样留给哲学家去追求，而是包含在对数学本身所固有的、日益增强的普遍性和严谨性的追求之中。219

Once more we are brought up against the image of a living science, groping its way towards the satisfaction of the intellectual passions upholding its values. We see it originating thousands of venturesome guesses which had long obsessed their authors until they laboriously brought them to the test of completion, and often battled for them against protracted objections, until they finally gained their established places in the textbooks. And again we see the curious contrast between this image and the ideal of casting the result of this heuristic process—and by implication any further continuation of it—into a strictly formalized system of axioms and symbolic operations. Indeed, for mathematics this ideal was not left to be pursued by philosophers, as was the case in the natural sciences, but was included in the endeavour towards an ever greater generality and rigour inherent in the pursuit of mathematics itself.219

因此，这与我们无关。但我们必须问——就像我们在自然科学的案例中所做的那样——这套形式前提体系的逻辑地位是什么，特别是我们基于什么理由接受它为有效。这两个问题的答案与关于自然科学公理化的说法密切相关。当某些未定义的术语、公理和符号运算被确立为数学的逻辑前提时，这些都是基于数学为真的先前假设。我们对逻辑上在前内容的接受，是基于我们先前对逻辑上衍生内容的接受，这隐含在我们对后者的接受中。

As such it does not concern us here. But we must ask—as we did in the case of the natural sciences—what the logical position of this system of formal premisses is and, in particular, on what grounds we accept it as valid. The answer to both questions follows closely what has been said about the axiomatization of the natural sciences. When certain undefined terms, axioms and symbolic operations are established as the logical antecedents of mathematics, these are based on the prior assumption that mathematics is true. Our acceptance of what is logically anterior is based on our prior acceptance of what is logically derivative, as being implied in our acceptance of the latter.

公理化确实已被证明是所有演绎科学追求更高普遍性和严谨性的有力方法。但它并未为未来的发现过程提供形式化的工具。它也没有成为解决数学争议问题的最高裁决者。在这种情况下，我们无需像在自然科学中那样说明其原因，因为已经明确地证明了，除了在某种意义上微不足道的相当基本的问题外，不可能存在一种方法总是能够通过有限的步骤解决问题，也没有任何形式化的程序能够告诉我们哪些问题是可以这样判定的。2220这一结论可以部分地预料到，因为数学中的重大步骤通常涉及概念性决策，而这些决策本质上永远无法被严格证明是正确的。

Axiomatization has indeed proved a powerful method in the pursuit of greater generality and rigour in all deductive sciences. But it has not supplied a formalized organon for the process of future discovery. Nor has it become the supreme arbiter in deciding controversial issues in mathematics. It is not necessary to show in this case—as we did for natural science—why this is so, for it has been demonstrably established that apart from fairly elementary problems which in a sense are trivial, there cannot exist a method which would always lead in a finite number of steps to the solution of a problem, nor is there any formal procedure that can tell us what problem would be thus decidable.2220This conclusion could have been partly anticipated from the fact that major steps in mathematics often involve conceptual decisions which can by their very nature never be rigorously proved right.

现在我们可以探讨一下数学悖论，它建立在一套公理体系之上，而这些公理体系并非自明之理，事实上也无法相互一致。运用最大的创造力和最严谨的谨慎去证明逻辑或数学定理，而这些推论的前提却被欣然接受，毫无根据地被当作“未经证实的断言公式”，这似乎完全荒谬。这让人想起一个小丑，他庄严地在竞技场中央立起两根门柱，中间是一道锁紧的大门，然后掏出一大串钥匙，费力地选出一把能打开锁的，穿过大门，小心翼翼地锁上——与此同时，整个竞技场在门柱的两侧敞开，他可以毫无阻碍地绕过它们。一个完全公理化的演绎系统就像一扇锁紧的大门，位于一片无限空旷的区域之中。如果接受任何证明都需要在未经证明的情况下接受最终得出该证明的一些预设，那么拒绝数学中任何未经证明的陈述的原则也意味着拒绝所有已证明的陈述，从而拒绝所有数学。

We can now turn to the paradox of a mathematics based on a system of axioms which are not regarded as self-evident and indeed cannot be known to be mutually consistent. To apply the utmost ingenuity and the most rigorous care to prove the theorems of logic or mathematics, while the premisses of these inferences are cheerfully accepted, without any grounds being given for doing so, as ‘unproven asserted formulae’, might seem altogether absurd. It reminds one of the clown who solemnly sets up in the middle of the arena two gateposts with a securely locked gate between them, pulls out a large bunch of keys, and laboriously selects one which opens the lock, then passes through the gate and carefully locks it after himself—while all the while the whole arena lies open on either side of the gateposts where he could go round them unhindered. A fully axiomatized deductive system is like a carefully locked gate in the midst of an infinite empty area. If the acceptance of any proof requires the acceptance without proof of some presuppositions from which the proof is ultimately derived, it follows that the principle of rejecting any unproven statement in mathematics implies also the rejection of all proven statements and therefore of all mathematics.

解决方案在于摒弃拒绝接受未经证实陈述的规则，承认我们对数学程序逻辑上先行准则的信念，是基于我们先前对该程序有效性的接受。让我们再次记住，从先前接受其后件而得出的逻辑前提必然比其后件更不确定。因此，将这些前提视为我们接受其后件的依据显然是不合理的。

The solution lies in rejecting the rule which denies acceptance to unproven statements, by admitting that our belief in logically anterior maxims of mathematical procedure is based on our previous acceptance of this procedure as valid. And let us remember once more that logical antecedents derived from the prior acceptance of their consequents are necessarily less certain than the consequents. It is clearly unreasonable, therefore, to regard these antecedents as the grounds on which we accept their consequents.

相反，我们应该坦诚地宣称，我们沉浸于数学并肯定其陈述，是为了它的智性之美，这体现了其概念的现实性和其断言的真理性。因为如果这种热情消逝，我们将不再理解数学；它的概念将瓦解，其证明将失去说服力。数学将变得毫无意义，迷失在一堆无关紧要的同义反复和希思·罗宾逊运算的混乱之中，以至于它与这些运算再也无法区分。

We should declare instead candidly that we dwell on mathematics and affirm its statements for the sake of its intellectual beauty, which betokens the reality of its conceptions and the truth of its assertions. For if this passion were extinct, we would cease to understand mathematics; its conceptions would dissolve and its proofs carry no conviction. Mathematics would become pointless and would lose itself in a welter of insignificant tautologies and of Heath Robinson operations, from which it could no longer be distinguished.

数学曾经一度因难以理解而湮没于历史长河。公元前205年阿波罗尼乌斯去世后，口述传统一度中断，而正是这种传统才使得希腊数学文本得以被学生理解。221这可能部分是由于人们对数学的不信任感日益加深，因为数学与数字的概念相冲突，导致了像￼这样的量级 这无法用整数来表达。在我们这个时代，哥德尔的不确定性定理或许同样会削弱我们对自身数学的信心。其他影响也可能加深这种不信任。如今，意识形态功利主义谴责阿基米德轻视自己的实用发明，并认为他对智性之美的热爱——他希望以自己最杰出的几何定理作为自己墓碑的标记——是一种反常现象。这种运动会损害数学的核心，即其智性之美。如今，数学的传承比以往任何时候都更加岌岌可危，因为现在没有哪个数学家能够完全理解数学的极小部分。现代数学的活力只能来自众多数学家，他们共同培育同一价值体系的不同部分：只有通过大学、期刊和会议的热情关注，培育这些价值观，并让所有数学家都同样尊重这些价值观，才能保持这个共同体的凝聚力。222如此庞大的结构极其脆弱，一旦被破坏，便无法修复。它的废墟将使现代数学陷入比22个世纪前希腊数学被彻底遗忘更彻底、更持久的湮没。

Mathematics has once already fallen into oblivion by becoming incomprehensible. After the death of Apollonius in 205 B.C. there occurred a break in the oral tradition which alone made the mathematical texts of the Greeks intelligible to students.221 This was probably due in part to a growing distrust of mathematics, owing to its conflict with the conception of number at the point where it led to magnitudes like ￼ which could not be expressed in terms of integers. In our own time Gödel’s theorem of uncertainty might conceivably erode confidence, likewise, in our own mathematics. And other influences might deepen this distrust. Ideological utilitarianism censures Archimedes today for speaking lightly of his own practical inventions and his passion for intellectual beauty, which he expressed by desiring his grave to be marked by his most brilliant geometrical theorem, is dismissed as an aberration. This movement would discredit the core of mathematics, which is its intellectual beauty. The transmission of mathematics has today been rendered more precarious than ever by the fact that no single mathematician can fully understand any longer more than a tiny fraction of mathematics. Modern mathematics can be kept alive only by a large number of mathematicians cultivating different parts of the same system of values: a community which can be kept coherent only by the passionate vigilance of universities, journals and meetings, fostering these values and imposing the same respect for them on all mathematicians.222 Such a far- flung structure is highly vulnerable and, once broken, impossible to restore. Its ruins would bury modern mathematics in an oblivion more complete and lasting than that which enveloped Greek mathematics twenty-two centuries ago.

 

 

  1. 抽象艺术
  2. THE ABSTRACT ARTS

通过将我们的视角扩展到与之相关的其他情感，我们对科学中求知激情的认可将获得支持。这种亲缘关系体现在毕达哥拉斯最古老的科学理论成就中，该理论从产生音符的和弦长度之间的整数比中获得了连续音符的悦耳效果。基于这一惊人的事实，毕达哥拉斯学派传统在几个世纪以来一直保持着对控制天体秩序的数学定律的音乐欣赏。这些都是夸张的说法；但它们源于不同类型的秩序和美之间存在的亲缘关系，无论是在自然界中发现的，在数学中构思的，还是由艺术富有想象力地创造的。纯数学与抽象艺术（如音乐和抽象绘画）之间的关系最为密切。

Our acknowledgment of intellectual passions in science will gain support by extending our perspective to other emotions that are kindred to it. This kinship is manifest in the most ancient achievement of scientific theory due to Pythagoras, which derives the pleasing effect of a succession of musical notes from the integer ratio between the lengths of the chords struck in producing them. Sustained by this striking fact, the Pythagorean tradition maintained for centuries a musical appreciation of the mathematical laws controlling the celestial order. These were extravagances; but they stemmed from the existing kinship between different kinds of order and beauty, whether discovered in nature, conceived in mathematics, or imaginatively created by art. The relation is closest between pure mathematics and the abstract arts, such as music and abstract painting.

视觉和音乐作品都因其所蕴含的一系列复杂关系之美而被欣赏。与纯数学一样，在抽象艺术中，这些有趣的关系是在由不指代任何有形对象的话语构成的结构中发现或创造的。在抽象艺术中，音乐以其精确而复杂的表达而脱颖而出，并遵循其自身的语法。就深度和范围而言，它可以与纯数学相媲美。此外，这两者都证明了同一个悖论：即人类可以对虚无进行重要的论述。因为它们都在向我们说话。我们不只是听音乐，而是聆听它并通过理解它来享受它，就像我们享受数学一样。像数学一样，音乐表达了各种各样的理性关系，仅仅是为了理解它们而感到乐趣。

Both visual and musical compositions are appreciated for the beauty of a set of complex relations embodied in them. And as in pure mathematics, so also in the abstract arts, these interesting relationships are discovered, or created, within structures composed of utterances denoting no tangible object. Among the abstract arts music stands out by its precise and complex articulation, subject to a grammar of its own. In profundity and scope it may compare with pure mathematics. Moreover, both of these testify to the same paradox: namely that man can hold important discourse about nothing. For they both speak to us. We do not merely hear music but listen to it and enjoy it by understanding it, even as we enjoy mathematics. Like mathematics, music articulates a vast range of rational relationships for the mere pleasure of understanding them.

抽象绘画创造了令人愉悦的视觉关系。正因如此，我们不仅能欣赏画布，更能凝视它并试图理解它。抽象绘画的设计与几何学的关联，如同音乐与算术的关联。立体主义的理论，以及自维特鲁威以来，为欣赏和谐的绘画与建筑构图而构建的几何规则的尝试，都值得我们一探究竟。

Abstract painting creates pleasing visible relationships. That is why we not merely see a canvas, but look at it and try to understand it. Its design bears the same kinship to geometry as music does to arithmetic. Witness the theories of cubism, or the attempts made ever since Vitruvius, to formulate geometrical rules for the appreciation of harmonious pictorial and architectural composition.

诚然，数学与抽象艺术在符号运算实践方面有着根本区别；数学符号表明了它在这类运算中运作的方式。然而，抽象艺术的基本表达虽然不具备这样的意义，但它们可以依赖于其感性内容。一片色块、一个音符本身就如此充实，以至于它们能够表达与其他色块或其他音符的​​关系，而无需指向自身之外。它们并非指代某种事物——无论是外部物体还是自身的用途——而是着重呈现自身引人注目的感性存在。

It is true that mathematics differs radically from the abstract arts by its practice of symbolic operations; a mathematical symbol signifies the manner in which it functions within such operations. But while the elementary utterances of abstract art can have no such meaning, they can rely instead on their sensuous content. A patch of colour, a musical note are so substantial in themselves, that they can speak their part in articulating a relationship with other patches of colour, or other musical notes, without pointing beyond themselves. Instead of denoting something—whether an external object or their own use—they emphatically present their own striking sensuous presence.

智识热情在自然科学、工程学和数学等多个领域发挥着决定性作用，这体现了这种参与的普遍性。在每一个领域，相关的智识热情都确立了独特的智识价值，任何特定的成就都因此有资格进入该领域。艺术不再与科学对立，而是与科学紧密相连，只是在艺术中，思想者更深入地参与到其思考的对象中。

The decisive part which intellectual passions have been shown to play in the several domains of natural science, engineering, and mathematics, demonstrates the ubiquity of such participation. In each of these domains it is the relevant intellectual passion which affirms the distinctive intellectual values by which any particular performance may qualify for admittance to the domain. The arts appear then no longer as contrasted but as immediately continuous with science, only that in them the thinker participates more deeply in the object of his thought.

当然，由能言善辩的文化所孕育的情感生活，其根源在于无法言喻的生物的情感。我们已经看到，猿猴和婴儿在解决问题时所展现出的兴奋预示着科学带来的智力乐趣。国际象棋比赛本身就充满乐趣，但如果婴儿不会玩拨浪鼓，它就无法做到这一点；虽然笑话并非欢笑的表达，但它能够创造欢笑，因为人们会笑。对死者的哀悼和爱情歌曲同样是早期无形情感的表述，这些情感通过文字和音乐被重塑和放大，成为新的东西。最初体验到的情感并非被表达，而是被暗示，正如绘画中物体被暗示而非被表现一样。这种暗示可能与数论中对固体存在的暗示一样遥远，也可能与几何晶体学中对观察到的晶体的暗示一样接近；所有艺术都介于这两种界限之间。无论多么抽象，它都会呼应某种经验，对于缺乏此类经验的人来说，它毫无意义，就像算术对于生活在气态宇宙中的人来说毫无意义一样。同样，无论一件艺术作品的描述多么细致入微、表达多么直白，它在指涉经验方面都绝不会比晶体学与晶体更接近；任何事物都不可能比用其自身和谐的语言来表达一种可想象的经验更接近实际经验。艺术作品中包含的精确事实陈述或精准情感表达，往往会将其扁平化为一张地图、一份报告或一次私人通信。 223

The emotional life engendered by an articulate culture is, of course, primordially rooted in the emotions of inarticulate creatures. We have seen that the exhilaration shown by apes and babies when solving a problem prefigures the intellectual joys of science. A game of chess creates its own pleasures, but could not do so if babies could not play with rattles; though a joke is not an expression of hilarity, it can create hilarity because men can laugh. Laments for the dead and songs of love are likewise formulations of earlier shapeless emotions, which are refashioned and amplified into something new by words and music. The originally experienced sentiments are not expressed but alluded to, just as objects are alluded to rather than represented in a painting. Such allusions may be as remote as the allusions to the existence of solids in the theory of numbers, or as close as the allusion to observed crystals in geometrical crystallography; and all art lies between two limits of this kind. However abstract, it will echo some experience, and would be as meaningless to someone lacking any such experience, as arithmetic would be to a person living in a gaseous universe. And again, however meticulously descriptive and plainly expressive a work of art may be, it must never come any closer in referring to experience than crystallography does to crystals; no closer than a representation of a conceivable experience, framed in its own harmonious terms, can come to actual experience. Precise statements of fact or exact expressions of sentiment contained in a work of art tend to flatten it out to a map, a report or a personal communication.223

智慧完全栖居于自身创造的清晰结构之中，这反而加剧了所有智性激情运作中固有的悖论。视觉艺术和音乐艺术的实践释放、构建和训练了我们获得和谐体验的能力，它最大限度地发挥了艺术家的创造力和辨别力，仅仅是为了满足艺术家为自己设定的欣赏标准。交响乐显然是人类思维创造的新成果；但作曲家称之为交响乐，意味着要求人们承认它本身就具有卓越的品质。自然科学家和工程师则不能如此自由地满足自己；任何科学理论，如果是错误的，就不是美的；任何发明，如果不可行，就不是真正独创的。然而，这仅仅改变了自我满足过程的条件。科学价值和发明独创性的标准仍然必须得到满足，而这些标准是由科学家和工程师自身的智性激情所设定的。

An intelligence which dwells wholly within an articulate structure of its own creation accentuates by doing so a paradox that is inherent in the exercise of all intellectual passions. The practice of the visual and musical arts which releases, formulates and disciplines our faculties for harmonious experience, exerts to the utmost the artist’s powers of invention and discrimination merely for the purpose of satisfying the standards of appreciation which the artist has set for himself. A symphony is obviously something new achieved by the human mind; but in calling it a symphony its composer demands recognition for it as something inherently excellent. The natural scientist and the engineer are not so free to satisfy themselves; no scientific theory is beautiful if it is false and no invention is truly ingenious if it is impracticable. Yet this merely modifies the conditions of a process of self-satisfaction. The standards of scientific value and of inventive ingenuity must still be satisfied, and these standards are set by the scientist’s and the engineer’s own intellectual passions.

因此，就此而言，无论思想是栖居于其自身创造的宇宙之中，还是解读和控制着外部赋予它的自然，同样的矛盾结构都贯穿于迄今为止所考察的清晰系统之中。其中存在着一种个人的成分，它难以言喻，却又充满激情，它宣示着我们的价值标准，驱使我们去实现这些标准，并以此评判我们的表现。

To this extent, then, whether thought operates indwellingly within a universe of its own creation, or interprets and controls nature as given to it from outside, the same paradoxical structure prevails throughout the articulate systems so far surveyed. There is present a personal component, inarticulate and passionate, which declares our standards of values, drives us to fulfil them and judges our performance by these self-set standards.

 

 

  1. 栖居与突围
  2. DWELLING IN AND BREAKING OUT

一个有效清晰的框架可能是一种理论，也可能是一项数学发现，或是一首交响乐。无论是哪一种，人们都会通过沉浸其中来运用它，而这种沉浸感可以被有意识地体验。天文观测是通过沉浸于天文学理论而进行的，正是这种对天文学的内在享受使天文学家对星体产生了兴趣。这就是从内心思考科学价值的方式。但是，当天文学公式被例行公事地使用时，对这种乐趣的认识就会变得模糊。只有当天文学家反思其理论视野，或有意识地体验其智力力量时，才可以说他正在思考天文学。数学也是如此。在陈腐的练习和孤独发现者的启发式视野之间，存在着成熟数学的主要领域，数学家有意识地沉浸其中，沉浸在对其伟大之处的思考中。对科学和数学的真正理解包含着对它们进行沉思体验的能力，而这些科学的教学必须致力于将这种能力传授给学生。引导学生对音乐和戏剧艺术进行理性的沉思，同样是为了使学生能够沉浸于艺术作品之中。这并非观察或触碰它们，而是沉浸其中。因此，获得对外部世界的理性掌控的满足感，与获得对自我掌控的满足感息息相关。

A valid articulate framework may be a theory, or a mathematical discovery, or a symphony. Whichever it is, it will be used by dwelling in it, and this indwelling can be consciously experienced. Astronomic observations are made by dwelling in astronomic theory, and it is this internal enjoyment of astronomy which makes the astronomer interested in the stars. This is how scientific value is contemplated from within. But awareness of this joy is dimmed when the formulae of astronomy are used in a routine manner. It is only when he reflects on its theoretic vision, or consciously experiences its intellectual powers, that the astronomer may be said to contemplate astronomy. Similarly for mathematics. Between the practice of hackneyed exercises on the one hand and the heuristic visions of the lonely discoverer on the other, lies the major domain of established mathematics on which the mathematician consciously dwells by losing himself in the contemplation of its greatness. A true understanding of science and mathematics includes the capacity for a contemplative experience of them, and the teaching of these sciences must aim at imparting this capacity to the pupil. The task of inducing an intelligent contemplation of music and dramatic art aims likewise at enabling a person to surrender himself to works of art. This is neither to observe nor to handle them, but to live in them. Thus the satisfaction of gaining intellectual control over the external world is linked to a satisfaction of gaining control over ourselves.

对这种双重满足的渴望始终如一；然而，它却通过自我毁灭的阶段运作。构建一个能够帮助我们处理经验的框架始于婴儿，最终在科学家身上达到顶峰。这一努力有时必须通过推翻迄今为止被接受的结构或其部分来实现，以便建立一个更加严谨、更加全面的结构来取而代之。科学发现从一个这样的框架走向其后继框架，在短暂而强烈的启发式视野中突破了规范思维的界限。而当它如此突破时，心灵此刻正在直接体验其内容，而不是通过任何预设的解释模式来控制它：它被自身充满激情的活动所淹没。

The urge towards this dual satisfaction is persistent; yet it operates by phases of self-destruction. The construction of a framework which will handle experience on our behalf begins in the infant and culminates in the scientist. This endeavour must occasionally operate by demolishing a hitherto accepted structure, or parts of it, in order to establish an even more rigorous and comprehensive one in its place. Scientific discovery, which leads from one such framework to its successor, bursts the bounds of disciplined thought in an intense if transient moment of heuristic vision. And while it is thus breaking out, the mind is for the moment directly experiencing its content rather than controlling it by the use of any pre-established modes of interpretation: it is overwhelmed by its own passionate activity.

科学家渴望思考新问题，并在寻求解决方案的过程中开辟新途径，这体现了人类思维本质上的躁动，它不断地质疑人类先前可能获得的任何满足感。我们可以将这种现象追溯到动物的原始层面。诚然，当动物被棘手的情境激发行动时，它们往往会养成一种新的习惯，以适应当时的情况，并使进一步的智力努力变得不必要；但在高等动物中，这种普遍趋势有时会被嬉戏的欲望所抵消。嬉戏的动物寻求刺激，即使它们已经不再是嬉戏的阶段，也需要活动。人类以各种形式发展出这种对紧张的渴望。人类是少数几种成年后仍持续玩耍的动物之一。人类也一直在寻求冒险，并享受冒险故事。我们都欣赏狡猾的技艺或解开谜题的乐趣，并以无数种方式享受着自己所处的紧张状态的突然缓解，无论是通过实际参与还是仅仅在想象中。我们庞大的现代娱乐业预示了这种欲望的流行形式；但是，我们对精神不满的渴求也进入了人类自发独创性的最高形式。

The scientist’s urge to ponder new problems and break new paths in seeking to solve them, presents us with the essential restlessness of the human mind, which calls ever again in question any satisfaction that it may have previously achieved. We may trace this back primordially to the level of the animal. It is true that when provoked into action by a problematical situation the animal tends to establish a new habit which meets the situation and renders further intelligent effort unnecessary; but in higher animals this general trend is occasionally opposed and overcome by playfulness. Animals at play seek excitement, and even when they have outgrown the playful stage they need activity. Human beings develop this desire for tension in a variety of forms. Man is one of the few animals who continue to play throughout adult life. Men have also at all times gone out in search of adventure and enjoyed tales of adventure. We all appreciate feats of craftiness, or the solving of puzzles, and enjoy in innumerable ways the sudden relaxation of a tension in which we have become involved, whether by actual participation or merely in imagination. Our gigantic modern amusement industry betokens the popular forms of this desire; but our craving for mental dissatisfaction enters also into the highest forms of man’s spontaneous originality.

这种打破所有固定概念框架的冲动最根本的表现就是狂喜的想象。当我们沉浸于对星空的沉思时，我们会以一种非天文观测的方式关注它们。我们饶有兴致地看着它们，但不会去思考它们。因为如果我们这样做了，我们对星空的认识就会黯然失色，沦为仅仅是贴切概念的例证；我们兴趣的焦点会转移到星空之外，作为经验的观察者或操纵者，我们对经验的认识会受到经验的引导，并在经验中穿梭，而不会体验到经验本身。我们观察和操纵事物的概念框架就像一道屏障，阻隔了我们与这些事物之间的距离，它们的视觉、听觉、嗅觉和触觉都只能透过这道屏障微弱地传递，使我们与它们保持距离。沉思消解了这道屏障，停止了我们在经验中的活动，将我们直接投入到经验之中；我们不再处理事物，而是沉浸其中。沉思没有别的目的或别的意义；置身其中，我们不再与事物打交道，而是沉浸于自身体验的内在特质，纯粹为了体验本身。当我们沉浸于沉思时，我们便在沉思的对象中获得了一种非个人化的生命；而这些对象本身则弥漫着一种幻觉般的光芒，赋予它们一种全新而鲜活的、却又如梦似幻的现实感。它如梦似幻，因为它超越时间，没有明确的空间位置。 224 这不是一个目标，它们会成为这个焦点的附属品，并且它们对眼睛和心灵的生动影响将会消失。 225现实；因为它并非是理性感知的焦点，无法预期未来通过有形事物得到证实，而仅仅存在于事物呈现在眼前的各种形状的色块中。相应地，深度沉思的客观性在于人完全参与到他所沉思的事物中，而不是像在理想的客观观察中那样完全脱离它。由于沉思的客观性是一种自我放弃，它可以被描述为以自我为中心，也可以被描述为无私的，这取决于我们指的是沉思者的幻想行为还是他自身的沉浸。

The most radical manifestation of this urge to break through all fixed conceptual frameworks is the act of ecstatic vision. When we abandon ourselves to the contemplation of the stars we attend to them in a way which is not an astronomical observation. We look at them with great interest but without thinking about them. For if we did, our awareness of the stars would pale into that of mere instances of apposite conceptions; the focus of our interest being shifted beyond them, our awareness of as observers or manipulators of experience we are guided by experience and pass through experience without experiencing it in itself. The conceptual framework by which we observe and manipulate things being present as a screen between ourselves and these things, their sights and sounds, and the smell and touch of them transpire but tenuously through this screen, which keeps us aloof from them. Contemplation dissolves the screen, stops our movement through experience and pours us straight into experience; we cease to handle things and become immersed in them. Contemplation has no ulterior intention or ulterior meaning; in it we cease to deal with things and become absorbed in the inherent quality of our experience, for its own sake. And as we lose ourselves in contemplation, we take on an impersonal life in the objects of our contemplation; while these objects themselves are suffused by a visionary gleam which lends them a new vivid and yet dreamlike reality. It is dreamlike, for it is timeless and without definite spatial location.224 It is not an objective them would become subsidiary to this focus and their vivid impact on the eye and mind would be lost.225 reality; for it is not the focus of an intelligent perception anticipating future confirmation by tangible things, but resides merely in the coloured patches of various shapes which the things present to the eye. Correspondingly, the impersonality of intense contemplation consists in a complete participation of the person in that which he contemplates and not in his complete detachment from it, as would be the case in an ideally objective observation. Since the impersonality of contemplation is a self-abandonment, it can be described either as egocentric or as selfless, depending on whether one refers to the contemplator’s visionary act or to the submergence of his person.

宗教神秘主义者通过精心的思考，并辅以仪式，最终达到默观式的交流。通过专注于超越一切物质表象的上帝的临在，神秘主义者力求放松其感知力本能地对眼前景象施加的理智控制。他凝视不再逐一扫视每个物体，他的思维也不再识别它们的细节。他通常用来评估印象的整个理智理解框架，也随之沉寂，揭示了一个被无知地体验为神圣奇迹的世界。这一过程在基督教神秘主义中被称为“否定之路”（via negativa），而将其奉为通往上帝的唯一完美途径的传统，源于伪狄奥尼修斯的神秘神学。它邀请我们通过一系列的“超脱”，在绝对无知中寻求与超越一切存在和一切知识的上帝的结合。226我们不再从焦点角度看待事物，而是将其视为宇宙的一部分，视为上帝的特征。

The religious mystic achieves contemplative communion as a result of an elaborate effort of thought, supported by ritual. By concentrating on the presence of God, who is beyond all physical appearances, the mystic seeks to relax the intellectual control which his powers of perception instinctively exercise over the scene confronting them. His fixed gaze no longer scans each object in its turn and his mind ceases to identify their particulars. The whole framework of intelligent understanding, by which he normally appraises his impressions, sinks into abeyance and uncovers a world experienced uncomprehendingly as a divine miracle. The process is known in Christian mysticism as the via negativa and the tradition which prescribes it as the only perfect path to God stems from the Mystic Theology of the Pseudo-Dionysius. It invites us, through a succession of ‘detachments’, to seek in absolute ignorance union with Him who is beyond all being and all knowledge.226 We see things then not focally, but as part of a cosmos, as features of God.

基督教神秘主义者与世界的共融寻求一种和解，而和解是救赎技巧的一部分。它是人类臣服于上帝之爱，希望获得上帝的宽恕并进入祂的临在。“否定之路”的激进反智主义表达了试图突破我们常规概念框架并“变得像小孩子一样”的努力。这类似于对“上帝的愚昧”的依赖，这条通往理解基督教的捷径，圣奥古斯丁曾羡慕地说过，这条捷径对头脑简单的人是免费的，但对博学的人却无法逾越。日常行动中的基督教信仰正是这种持续不断的突破努力，由对上帝的爱和渴望支撑，上帝可以被爱，但不可被观察。接近上帝并非一种观察，因为它会淹没并渗透到崇拜者心中。观察者必须相对地超脱于他所观察的事物，而宗教体验会改变崇拜者。从这一点来看，它更接近于感官放纵，而非确切的观察。神秘主义者用情色的术语来谈论宗教狂喜，将与上帝或基督的交流描述为新娘与新郎的结合。在生育崇拜的狂欢仪式中，宗教与感官狂热公开地融合在一起。但宗教狂喜是一种清晰的激情，只有在其所达到的臣服程度上，它才与感官放纵相似。

The Christian mystic’s communion with the world seeks a reconciliation which is part of the technique of redemption. It is man’s surrender to the love of God, in the hope of gaining his forgiveness and admission to His presence. The radical anti-intellectualism of the via negativa expresses the effort to break out of our normal conceptual framework and ‘become like little children’. It is akin to the reliance on the ‘foolishness of God’, that short-cut to the understanding of Christianity, of which St. Augustine said enviously that it was free to the simple-minded but impassable to the learned. The Christian faith in everyday action is just such a sustained effort at breaking out, sustained by the love and desire for God, a God who can be loved but not observed. Proximity to God is not an observation, for it overwhelms and pervades the worshipper. An observer must be relatively detached from that which he observes, and religious experience transforms the worshipper. It stands in this respect closer to sensual abandon than to exact observation. Mystics speak of religious ecstasy in erotic terms, describing communion with God or with Christ as the union of bride and bridegroom. In the orgiastic rituals of fertility cults religion and sensual fervour are openly blended. But religious ecstasy is an articulate passion and resembles sensual abandon only in the surrender achieved by it.

这种臣服与礼拜者在宗教仪式中沉浸的程度相符，这可能是我们所能想象到的最高程度的内住。仪式包含一系列需要言说的话语和需要做出的手势，这些动作会调动我们的全身，唤醒我们整个存在。任何在礼拜场所真诚地言行这些行为的人，都必然会完全沉浸其中。他将会虔诚地参与宗教生活。

This surrender corresponds to the degree to which the worshipper dwells within the fabric of the religious ritual, which is potentially the highest degree of indwelling that is conceivable. For ritual comprises a sequence of things to be said and gestures to be made which involve the whole body and alert our whole existence. Anyone sincerely saying and doing these things in a place of worship could not fail to be completely absorbed in them. He would be partaking devoutly in religious life.

然而，基督教信徒在神圣礼拜仪式中的居所，与任何其他栖居于内在卓越框架中的居所不同，因为这种居所并非享受。忏悔罪过、臣服于上帝的仁慈、祈求恩典、赞美上帝，这些都会带来不断增长的张力。通过这些仪式行为，信徒承担起实现自身能力之外目标的义务，并努力实现它，希望得到上天的仁慈眷顾。崇拜仪式的设计初衷就是为了引发并维持这种痛苦、臣服和希望的状态。一旦有人声称自己已经到达彼岸，现在可以愉快地思考自身的完美，他就会再次陷入精神空虚。

But the dwelling of the Christian worshipper within the ritual of divine service differs from any other dwelling within a framework of inherent excellence, by the fact that this indwelling is not enjoyed. The confession of guilt, the surrender to God’s mercy, the prayer for grace, the praise of God, bring about mounting tension. By these ritual acts the worshipper accepts the obligation to achieve what he knows to be beyond his own unaided powers and strives towards it in the hope of a merciful visitation from above. The ritual of worship is expressly designed to induce and sustain this state of anguish, surrender and hope. The moment a man were to claim that he had arrived and could now happily contemplate his own perfection, he would be thrown back into spiritual emptiness.

因此，基督教信徒的内住，是一种持续的尝试，试图突破，试图摆脱人类的处境，即便谦卑地承认其不可避免。当这种内住将这种努力发挥到极致时，它便会得到最彻底的实现。它并非栖居于我们完全理解的伟大理论之中，亦非沉浸于一部音乐杰作的模式之中，而是在超越我们视野的发现的指引下，努力突破既定思维框架的启发式浪潮。基督教崇拜仿佛维系着一种永恒的、永不实现的预感：一种因其无法解决的张力而被接受的启发式愿景。它如同对一个已知无法解决的问题的执念，却又违背理性，坚定不移地遵循着启发式的命令：“看向未知！”基督教通过向人类提供被钉在十字架上的上帝的安慰，孜孜不倦地培养人类对精神不满的渴望，并在某种意义上永久地满足了人类对精神不满的渴望。

The indwelling of the Christian worshipper is therefore a continued attempt at breaking out, at casting off the condition of man, even while humbly acknowledging its inescapability. Such indwelling is fulfilled most completely when it increases this effort to the utmost. It resembles not the dwelling within a great theory of which we enjoy the complete understanding, nor an immersion in the pattern of a musical masterpiece, but the heuristic upsurge which strives to break through the accepted frameworks of thought, guided by the intimations of discoveries still beyond our horizon. Christian worship sustains, as it were, an eternal, never to be consummated hunch: a heuristic vision which is accepted for the sake of its unresolvable tension. It is like an obsession with a problem known to be insoluble, which yet follows, against reason, unswervingly, the heuristic command: ‘Look at the unknown!’ Christianity sedulously fosters, and in a sense permanently satisfies, man’s craving for mental dissatisfaction by offering him the comfort of a crucified God.

音乐、诗歌、绘画：艺术——无论是抽象的还是具象的——都是介于科学与崇拜之间的栖居与突破。数学曾被比作诗歌：“真正的喜悦之心、那种崇高的境界、那种超越凡人的存在感，是衡量最高境界的试金石，而这种精神在数学中和在诗歌中一样清晰可见。”伯特兰·罗素写道。227然而，这些愉悦的范围却存在着巨大的差异。由于其感性内容，一件艺术作品能够比一个数学定理对我们的影响更为广泛。此外，艺术创作和欣赏是一种沉思体验，比数学更类似于宗教交流。艺术如同神秘主义，突破了客观性的屏障，并利用了我们前概念的沉思视野。诗歌“从我们的内心视野中清除了那层模糊我们存在奇迹的熟悉的薄膜”，它打破了“一个熟悉的世界，对它而言，它就是一片混沌”（雪莱）。

Music, poetry, painting: the arts—whether abstract or representative— are a dwelling in and a breaking out which lie somewhere between science and worship. Mathematics has been compared with poetry: The true spirit of delight, the exaltation, the sense of being more than Man, which is the touchstone of the highest excellence, is to be found in mathematics as surely as in poetry’, writes Bertrand Russell.227 Yet there is a great difference in the range of these delights. Owing to its sensuous content a work of art can affect us far more comprehensively than a mathematical theorem. Moreover, artistic creation and enjoyment are contemplative experiences more akin than mathematics to religious communion. Art, like mysticism, breaks through the screen of objectivity and draws on our pre-conceptual capacities of contemplative vision. Poetry ‘purges from our inward sight the film of familiarity which obscures from us the wonder of our being’, it breaks into ‘a world to which the familiar world is chaos’ (Shelley).

否定神学开启通往上帝临在的机制，在此适用于艺术创作过程。但对熟悉意义的否定或许不止于此。它或许会将我们带入虚无的临在。萨特的《恶心》（Nausée）对这一过程进行了经典描述。它概括了一种通过重复一个词使其变得难以理解的技巧。你不停地说“桌子，桌子，桌子……”，直到这个词变成一个毫无意义的声音。你可以通过将所有事物简化为未经解读的细节，彻底摧毁意义。通过麻痹我们将一件事物置于另一件事之下的冲动，我们就能消除所有基于其他事物对事物的次要意识，并创造出一个原子化、完全非人格化的宇宙。在其中，你手中的鹅卵石、你口中的唾液以及你耳中的话语，都变成了外在的、荒谬的、充满敌意的事物。这个宇宙是宇宙观的对应物，绝望取代了希望。这是完全不信任我们自身信仰的必然结果。世界就是这样，任其自然发展。

The mechanism by which a negative theology opens access to the presence of God is applicable here to a process of artistic creation. But the negation of familiar meaning may go beyond this. It may usher us into the presence of nothingness. Sartre’s ‘Nausée’ contains the classic description of this process. It is a generalization of the technique for rendering a word incomprehensible by repeating it a number of times. You say ‘table, table, table…’ until the word becomes a mere meaningless sound. You can destroy meaning wholesale by reducing everything to its uninterpreted particulars. By paralysing our urge to subordinate one thing to another, we can eliminate all subsidiary awareness of things in terms of others and create an atomized, totally depersonalized universe. In it the pebble in your hand, the saliva in your mouth and the word in your ear all become external, absurd and hostile items. This universe is the counterpart of the cosmic vision, with despair taking the place of hope. It is the logical outcome of utterly distrusting our participation in holding our beliefs. Left strictly to itself, this is what the world is like.

现代艺术与存在主义哲学一同走向对日益激进的否定的探索。超现实主义不信任一切意义，现代诗歌亦是如此。它视轻松为庸俗，视可理解为不诚实。唯有碎片化才值得信赖；唯有碎片的集合才能承载一种完全不可言喻的意义，并由此抵御自我怀疑。

Modern art has moved along with existentialist philosophy towards the exploration of increasingly radical negations. Surrealism distrusts all meaning and so does modern poetry. It regards easiness as vulgar and intelligibility as dishonest. Fragmentation alone can then be trusted; only an aggregate of fragments can carry a meaning that is wholly ineffable and protected thereby against self doubt.

我曾说过，科学家引领他获得新发现的远见卓识，一旦取得发现，便会消退，转而进入对结果的平静沉思——而宗教实践则最终达到一种他们不断追求的境界。艺术则处于中间位置。如同科学一样，创作者探索的热情在强度上远远超过其成品所引发的情感。但艺术作品更类似于一种宗教虔诚的行为，因为即使在其完成的形式下，它仍然是更积极、更全面的沉思的工具。虽然艺术家无法让公众重温他的创作时光，但他确实让他们进入了一个他们从未见过、听过或感受过的广阔的视觉、听觉和情感世界。为了实现这一点，马塞尔·普鲁斯特写道：

I have said that the visionary powers of the scientist which lead him to new discoveries subside, once discovery is achieved, into a peaceful contemplation of the result—while religious practices culminate in an endeavour which they seek ever again to achieve. The arts are in an intermediate position. As in science, the heuristic passion of the originator far exceeds in intensity the sentiments induced by his finished product. But the work of art is more akin to an act of religious devotion in remaining, even in its finished form, an instrument of more active and comprehensive contemplation. Though the artist cannot make the public re-live his creative hours, he does make them enter a wide world of sights, sounds and emotions which they had never seen, heard or felt before. To achieve this,’ writes Marcel Proust,

富有创造力的画家、富有创造力的作家就像眼科医生一样行事。借助他们的画作和文字，这种治疗并不总是令人愉快的。治疗结束后，他们会告诉我们：你现在可以看了。就这样，这个世界并非只被创造过一次，而是每当一位新艺术家出现时都会被重新创造，它在我们看来是完全可以理解的——与旧世界截然不同。我们现在崇拜雷诺阿和吉罗杜笔下的女性，而在接受治疗之前，我们拒绝承认她们是女性。我们很想去那些以前似乎什么都不是树林的树林里散步，比如一幅由数千种色调编织而成的挂毯，只缺少了森林的色彩。这就是艺术家创造的转瞬即逝的新世界，它只存在到一位新艺术家出现。 228

the creative painter, the creative writer proceed like the eye specialist. The treatment—with the help of their paintings, their writings—is not always pleasant. When the treatment is concluded they tell us: you can look now. And thus the world which hasn’t been created only once, but is recreated every time a new artist emerges, appears to us perfectly comprehensible—so very different from the old. We now adore the women of Renoir and Giraudoux, whereas before the treatment we refused to recognize them as women. And we would love to go for a stroll in those woods which previously seemed to represent anything but woods, for example a tapestry woven of thousands of shades with just the colourings of a forest missing. Such is the passing and new universe created by the artist, which survives only until a new artist arises.228

普鲁斯特在这里过于温和地谈论了新艺术作品在我们眼中带来的不适。我们被一个自称有意义的陌生体系所震撼。当公众被迫进入新的框架以发现其意义时，他们的困惑变成了愤慨。他们对那些在他们看来应该蔑视的作品所获得的尊重感到愤慨，也对这种对他们自身卓越标准的隐含蔑视感到愤怒。早期印象派画家在巴黎的展览周围曾发生过暴力场面。1913年，斯特拉文斯基在巴黎的观众席中发生了打斗。 229瓦格纳的一些歌剧首演时，各国也曾发生过类似的骚乱。在这样的冲突中，双方实际上是在为自己的生命，或至少是生命的一部分而战。因为在各自的存在中，都有一个领域，只有通过否定对方存在中某个领域的现实性，才能维持这个领域。而这种否定，对对方的信念是一种冲击，也是一种对他存在的攻击，因为他生活在这种信念之中。

Proust speaks too gently here of the unpleasantness incurred in the treatment of our eyes by new works of art. We are shocked by the offer of an unfamiliar system purporting to be meaningful. When the public is pressed to enter the new framework so as to discover its meaning, their bewilderment turns into indignation. They are outraged by the respect paid to what seems to them deserving of contempt and angry at the implied contempt for their own standards of excellence. There were scenes of violence around the exhibitions of the early Impressionists in Paris. There was fighting in the Parisian audiences of Stravinsky in 1913229 and similar disturbances had occurred in various countries at the first performance of some of Wagner’s operas. In such conflicts the two sides are actually fighting for their lives, or at least part of their lives. For in the existence of each there is an area which can be kept in being only by denying reality to an area in the existence of the other. And such a denial is a shock to the conviction of the other and an attack against his being, to the extent to which he lives in this conviction.

我们已经看到，科学领域的重大革命——无论是数学还是自然科学——也都引发了类似的存在冲突。过去的宗教战争和当今的意识形态战争，稍后我将以类似的方式探讨。但在此我必须再次强调，在处理过去的科学争议时，我们不可避免地必须在当下亲自评判其结果。我们所有的文化价值观都是过去一系列动荡的积累，但最终由我们来判断这些动荡意味着什么：是胜利还是灾难。人们或许认为艺术创新并非包罗万象，以至于我们时代的新成就可以添加到我们对既有成就不变的欣赏中。但事实并非如此。新的艺术运动包含着对其祖先的重新评价，以及对过去所有其他艺术成就的评价的相应转变。这种必然性再次唤起了我在对比我们对科学美的永恒价值的信念与对其持续培育的担忧时已经出现的悖论。因为我们必须承认，真理与美可能不会盛行，或者可能不会盛行太久。我们知道后人的评判是多么的可怕。中世纪的罗马，在广场和战神广场的遗址上，人们使用特殊的窑炉将古代艺术品烧成石灰。230在我写这篇文章的时候，苏联的一些最伟大的艺术珍品——马蒂斯、塞尚、毕加索、雷诺阿等人的画作——被谴责为堕落作品并被收藏在莫斯科的一个阁楼里。231然而，一部新作品的接受必须以后世的认可为前提。艺术之美是艺术现实的象征，正如数学之美是数学现实的象征一样。它的欣赏具有普遍的意义，并超越了意义本身，证明了其中蕴藏着取之不尽、用之不竭的意义，未来数个世纪或许还会将其发掘出来。这就是我们对内在栖居的承诺。

We have seen that the major revolutions in science—both in mathematics and the natural sciences—have also evoked such existential conflicts. The religious wars of the past and the ideological wars of the present will be spoken of later on similar lines. But here I must yet recall that in dealing with scientific controversies of the past we must inevitably judge their outcome ourselves, in the present. All our cultural values are the deposit of a succession of past upheavals, but it is ultimately for us to say what these upheavals signify: whether a triumph or a disaster. It might be thought that artistic innovations are not so comprehensive, so that the new achievements of our time may be added on to the unchanged appreciation of our previous possession. But this is not so. New movements of art include a re-appreciation of their ancestry and a corresponding shift in the valuation of all other artistic achievements of the past. And this necessity re-evokes the paradox which had already presented itself when I contrasted our belief in the eternal value of scientific beauty with our fears for its continued cultivation. For we must admit that truth and beauty may not prevail, or may not prevail for long. We know how monstrous the judgment of posterity can be. Special kilns were used in Medieval Rome, on the site of the Forum and the Campus Martius, to reduce ancient works of art to lime,230 and at the moment of writing this some of the greatest art treasures of Soviet Russia—paintings by Matisse, Cézanne, Picasso, Renoir, etc.—are condemned as degenerate and stowed away in an attic in Moscow.231 Yet all the same, the acceptance of a novel work must presume the approval of posterity. Artistic beauty is a token of artistic reality, in the same sense in which mathematical beauty is a token of mathematical reality. Its appreciation has universal intent, and bears witness beyond that to the presence of an inexhaustible fund of meaning in it which future centuries may yet elicit. Such is our commitment to indwelling.

通过内住而接受的个人知识可能看起来仅仅是主观的。在此无法完全驳斥这种怀疑。但我们已经能够区分对清晰框架的认可，无论是理论、宗教仪式还是艺术作品，以及对体验的认可，无论是在这样的框架内还是作为幻象般的沉思。在似乎没有任何断言的地方，是否有任何可以认可的东西，这似乎值得怀疑。我们看到我们所看到的，闻到我们所闻到的，感受到我们所感受到的，似乎仅此而已。没有任何主张的体验才是真正不可纠正的。但首先我们必须承认，我们所看到或感受到的很大程度上取决于我们理解它的方式，而在这方面，它是可以纠正的。

A personal knowledge accepted by indwelling may appear merely subjective. It cannot be fully defended here against this suspicion. But we can already distinguish between the accrediting of an articulate framework, be it a theory, a religious ritual or a work of art, and the accrediting of an experience, whether within such a framework or as visionary contemplation. It might appear questionable whether there can be anything to accredit where nothing seems to be asserted. We see what we see, we smell what we smell and feel what we feel, and there seems no more to it. Experiences that make no claim whatever would be truly incorrigible. But we must allow in the first place for the fact that what we see or feel depends very much on the way we make sense of it, and in this respect it is corrigible.

当我们意识到一块白斑是沐浴在阳光下的黑布的一部分时，它可能会变黑。一个孩子可能感到饥饿，却不知道自己想吃东西，直到有人给他食物。但即使撇开这些不谈，任何刻意运用心智的行为，在获得理想体验方面都可以说是成功或失败的。信徒们全神贯注地祈祷，是为了表达对神的虔诚；他可能成功，也可能失败。饱受“酸症”折磨的僧尼因无法全心全意祈祷而备受折磨。经验可以进行深度比较，它们对我们的影响越深，就越可以说是真实的。此外，即使经验报告是正确的，也可能受到质疑。一个人可能正确地报告了大量物体的颜色，但却无法真正看出绿色和红色之间的区别；因此，当最终发现他是红绿色盲时，我们就会得出结论，他之前的报告虽然正确，但却是不真实的。

A white patch may turn black when we take in the fact that it is part of a black cloth bathed in sunshine. A child may feel hungry and not know that it wants to eat, until it is offered food. But even apart from this, any deliberate existential use of the mind may be said to succeed or fail in achieving a desired experience. The worshipper strenuously concentrates on his prayer for the sake of achieving devotion to God; he may succeed or fail. Monks and nuns afflicted by ‘acidia’ are tormented by failure to pray wholeheartedly. Experiences can be compared in depth, and the more deeply they affect us, the more genuine they may be said to be. Besides, reports of experience can be doubted even if they are correct. A person may correctly report the colours of a large number of objects, yet not really see any difference between green and red; so that when it is eventually found that he is red-green colour blind, we shall conclude that his previous reports, though correct, were not authentic.

不同类型的清晰系统作为精神居所的接受，是通过一个逐渐欣赏的过程而达成的，所有这些接受在某种程度上都取决于相关经验的内容；但自然科学与经验事实的关系比数学、宗教或各种艺术的关系更为具体。因此，我们完全有理由以不适用于其他清晰系统的意义来谈论科学的“经验验证”。相比之下，对科学以外的其他系统进行检验并最终被接受的过程，可以称为“验证”过程。

The acceptance of different kinds of articulate systems as mental dwelling places is arrived at by a process of gradual appreciation, and all these acceptances depend to some extent on the content of relevant experiences; but the bearing of natural science on facts of experience is much more specific than that of mathematics, religion or the various arts. It is justifiable, therefore, to speak of the verification of science by experience in a sense which would not apply to other articulate systems. The process by which other systems than science are tested and finally accepted may be called, by contrast, a process of validation.

一般来说，我们在确认中的个人参与度比在验证中的更高。当我们从科学转向邻近的思想领域时，断言的情感系数会增强。但验证和确认在任何地方都是一种承诺的承认：它们宣称存在某种真实且外在于说话者的东西。与这两者不同，主观体验只能被称为真实，而真实性并不像验证和确认那样包含承诺。

Our personal participation is in general greater in a validation than in a verification. The emotional coefficient of assertion is intensified as we pass from the sciences to the neighbouring domains of thought. But both verification and validation are everywhere an acknowledgment of a commitment: they claim the presence of something real and external to the speaker. As distinct from both of these, subjective experiences can only be said to be authentic, and authenticity does not involve a commitment in the sense in which both verification and validation do.

 

 

7

7

欢乐

CONVIVIALITY

 

 

  1. 介绍
  2. INTRODUCTION

那些能够培养和满足求知热情的、清晰的系统，只有在一个尊重这些热情所肯定的价值观的社会的支持下才能生存；而一个社会只有在承认并履行支持培养这些热情的义务的范围内，才能拥有文化生活。由于通过追求科学、技术和数学来促进和传播知识，构成了文化生活的一部分，因此，这些清晰的系统被理解和认可，并普遍支持我们对事实真理的塑造和肯定的那些默契系数，也是一个社会共享的文化生活的系数。

ARTICULATE systems which foster and satisfy an intellectual passion can survive only with the support of a society which respects the values affirmed by these passions, and a society has a cultural life only to the extent to which it acknowledges and fulfils the obligation to lend its support to the cultivation of these passions. Since the advancement and dissemination of knowledge by the pursuit of science, or technology and mathematics forms part of cultural life, the tacit coefficients by which these articulate systems are understood and accredited, and which uphold quite generally our shaping and affirmation of factual truth, are also coefficients of a cultural life shared by a community.

我现在首先要阐明的是，这种默契的知识共享是每一项清晰交流行为的基础。然后，我将探讨文化生活共享赖以存在的整个默契互动网络，并由此引出一个观点：我们对真理的坚守，可以被理解为意味着我们对一个尊重真理、并且我们信赖其尊重真理的社会的坚守。对真理以及对普遍知识价值的热爱，现在将重新体现为对培育这些价值观的社会的热爱；而对知识标准的服从，则被视为意味着参与一个承担文化义务以服务于这些标准的社会。

I propose now to show first that this tacit sharing of knowing underlies every single act of articulate communication. I shall then take in the whole network of tacit interactions on which the sharing of cultural life depends, and so lead on to a point at which our adherence to the truth-can be seen to imply our adherence to a society which respects the truth, and which we trust to respect it. Love of truth and of intellectual values in general will now reappear as the love of the kind of society which fosters these values, and submission to intellectual standards will be seen to imply participation in a society which accepts the cultural obligation to serve these standards.

一旦我们充分认识到我们智识热情的这些公民系数，我们就会再次面临更加危险的现实：我们怀着普遍的意图持有一套由我们特定的成长经历所习得的信念。因为，如果我们认为我们持有这些信念仅仅是因为被灌输了它们，它们可能会显得外在于我们；而如果我们承认自己主动决定接受它们，它们往往会显得武断。此外，这些令人不安的思考现在也会挑战社会框架。每当当权者被看作将一些反思后可能显得是外来的智识价值观强加于他人时，这种权威的正当性就会受到质疑。如果权威将实际上是狭隘的东西宣称为普遍的，那么这种权威的行使往往会显得偏执或虚伪。

Once we fully recognize these civic coefficients of our intellectual passions, we shall be confronted once again, and even more dangerously, with the realization that we hold with universal intent a set of convictions acquired by our particular upbringing. For if we believe that we hold these convictions merely because we were taught them, they may appear to be external to us; while to the extent to which we acknowledge that we have actively decided to accept them, they will tend to appear arbitrary. Moreover, these unsettling reflections will now challenge also the framework of society. At all points where men in authority are seen to impose on others intellectual values which on reflection may come to appear adventitious, the justification of this authority may be called in question. The exercise of authority will tend to appear as bigoted or as hypocritical, if it asserts as universal what is actually parochial.

因此，我们自身信念的紊乱，源于我们自身无处不在地参与塑造真理的景象，将扩展为一种公民困境，而在这一哲学境况中重拾精神平衡的斗争将获得新的意义。我们将意识到，这场斗争的成功取决于我们能否维护社会的思想和道德文化。

Thus the disturbance of our own convictions, caused by the sight of our own ubiquitous participation in the shaping of truth, will expand into a civic predicament, and the struggle to regain our mental balance in this philosophic situation will gain a new significance. We shall realize that on its success depends the possibility of upholding the intellectual and moral culture of our society.

不幸的是，虽然认识到我们哲学目标的公民效用会增强我们对此的兴趣，但这也会进一步使我们的任务复杂化，因为它会加深我们的怀疑：如果我们坚持自己的信念本身有效，我们就是在背信弃义。这种怀疑必须留到下一章，希望在下一章中，通过拟议的真理概念改革来消除它。

Unfortunately, while the realization of the civic usefulness of our philosophic aim will sharpen our interest in it, it will also further complicate our task, for it will extend to a deeper level our suspicion that in holding our convictions as valid in themselves we are acting in bad faith. This doubt will have to be carried over to the next chapter, in the hope of dispelling it there within the proposed reform of the conception of truth.

 

 

  1. 沟通
  2. COMMUNICATION

在关于表达的章节中，我仅探讨了个体运用语言所能获得的智力优势。现在，我将摒弃这一限制，并同时摒弃对语言陈述模式和描述性运用的限制。

In my chapter on Articulation I have restricted myself to the intellectual advantages which a solitary individual may conceivably derive from the use of language. This restriction will now be abandoned and with it also the restriction to the declaratory mode and descriptive use of language.

当然，我的论证已经反复地从语言的描述性运用延伸到互动性和表达性运用。对科学理论的肯定被视为传达对其美的欣赏，而所有数学陈述都被视为承载着一系列精妙的审美欣赏。此外，技术的操作原理和数学的形式化演示被视为成功行动的规则，这些规则可以最恰当地以祈使句的形式表达出来，尽管到目前为止，我们仅就其单独使用进行了探讨。

My argument has, of course, repeatedly overflowed already from the descriptive to the interactive and expressive uses of language. The affirmation of a scientific theory was seen to convey an appreciation of its beauty and all the statements of mathematics were seen to carry a whole gamut of delicate aesthetic appreciations. And again, the operational principles of technology and the formal demonstrations of mathematics were seen to be rules of a successful action which could be most appositely cast in the imperative form, even though they were being considered so far only in their solitary use.

当人际沟通中使用事实陈述时，描述性语言的表达性和祈使性成分会更加显著。沟通是一种称呼形式，它唤起某人对其信息和说话者的注意。然而，语言本身的描述能力已经预示了向他人传达信息的可能性。一组常用的符号，由于其独特的易理解性，使我们能够根据其符号表征更迅速地思考其主题。如果其他人能够像我们一样使用这种表征，那么它们就可以用来向他们传递信息。这只有当说话者和听众在类似情况下听到过这些术语，并从这些经验中得出符号与其所代表的反复出现的特征（或功能）之间的相同关系时才会发生。说话者和听众双方也必须发现这些符号易于理解，否则他们就不可能熟练地使用这些符号。

The expressive and imperative components of descriptive language become more marked when declarations of fact are used for purposes of interpersonal communication. Communication is a form of address, calling someone’s attention to its message and to its speaker. Yet the possibility of communicating information to others is already foreshadowed in the mere descriptive powers of language. A small set of consistently used symbols which, owing to their peculiar manageability, enable us to think about their subject matter more swiftly in terms of its symbolic representation, can be used to carry information to other people if they can use this representation as we do. This can happen only if speakers and listeners have heard the terms used in similar circumstances, and have derived from these experiences the same relation between the symbols and the recurrent features (or functions) which they represent. Both speakers and listeners must also have found the symbols in question manageable, as otherwise they could not have acquired any fluency in their use.

我相信，即使人们可能会误解对他们说的任何特定词语，他们通常仍然能够通过言语可靠地相互传递信息。因为我认为，在不同的人之间，符号传递过程中所涉及的默契判断往往会一致，而且不同的人也往往会发现同一组符号能够帮助他们巧妙地重组知识。 232现在让我在更广泛的背景下阐述这一信念。

I believe that even though people may conceivably misunderstand any particular words addressed to them, they can, as a rule, convey information to each other reliably enough by speech. For I think that the tacit judgments involved in the process of denotation do tend to coincide between different people and that different people also tend to find the same set of symbols manageable for the purpose of skilfully reorganizing their knowledge.232 Let me develop this belief now in a wider context.

人际间默契判断的巧合，与强烈情感的无声互动，从根本上延续至今。性爱的拥抱无言地传达着强烈的相互满足。养育幼崽的动物在亲子之间建立起一种相互满足，这种满足感带有支配与服从的色彩。婴儿会对微笑的成年人报以微笑，却会被皱眉的表情吓哭，而他们之间并没有任何实际的对应性经验。233根据皮亚杰的观察，孩子们在游戏中的陪伴过于亲密，以至于他们无法充分意识到自己与玩伴之间的区别。他们的反应方式颇具“自闭症”色彩，可能显得无私，也可能显得自我中心，这取决于人们是认为他们迷失了自我，还是认为他们占据了他人的位置。群居动物的欢乐习性（我稍后会谈到）似乎与此类似。

The interpersonal coincidence of tacit judgments is primordially continuous with the mute interaction of powerful emotions. The sexual embrace wordlessly communicates an intense mutual satisfaction. Animals which rear their young establish between parent and offspring a mutual satisfaction, coloured by dominance and submission. A baby smiles back at a smiling adult and is frightened into crying by a frowning countenance, without any practical experience of their corresponding dispositions.233 Judging by Piaget’s observation, the companionship of children in play is so close, that they insufficiently realize the distinction between themselves and their playmates. They react in an ‘autistic’ manner, which may appear selfless or egocentric, depending on whether one regards them as losing themselves or as appropriating the person of the others. The conviviality of gregarious animals, of which I shall speak later, seems akin to this.

弥漫的情感愉悦感不知不觉地融入到特定体验的传递中，形成了一种肉体同情，这种同情心会让旁观者在目睹他人剧痛时不禁产生共鸣。一个人必须经过特殊训练才能忍受外科手术的场面。即使是经验丰富的医生，看到病人眼部被深深的切口，也会晕倒或呕吐。施虐狂是将传递的痛苦转化为愉悦的兴奋；它是一种受虐狂式的分享他人痛苦的行为，并且已知与受虐狂的个体存在关联。即使是最坚定的罪犯也容易受到肉体同情的影响。据记载，当盖世太保头目希姆莱想要亲自测试灭绝技术时，他下令当着他的面杀死一百名犹太人，看到这一幕，他几乎晕倒了。尽管经过刻意训练，学会了残酷无情，并坚信其正确性，但对于负责大规模灭绝的人来说，他们行为的恐怖景象仍然是一个严重的难题，为了减少这种“残酷的对待”，最终采用了毒气室方法。 234

Diffuse emotional conviviality merges imperceptibly into the transmission of specific experiences in the kind of physical sympathy which overcomes the onlooker at the sight of another’s sharp suffering. One has specially to train oneself in order to stand the sight of a surgical operation. Even experienced doctors may faint or get sick at the sight of a deep incision in the eye of a patient. Sadism is the transmutation of transmitted pangs into pleasurable excitement; it is a masochistic sharing of another man’s torment and is known to be associated with masochism in the subject. Even the most determined criminals are liable to be effected by physical compassion. It is on record that when the head of the Gestapo, Himmler, desiring to test the technique of extermination at first hand, ordered the killing of a hundred Jews in his presence, he came near to fainting at the sight. In spite of deliberate training to merciless cruelty, upheld by a firm conviction of its rightness, the horrible sight of their deeds proved a serious difficulty to the persons charged with mass exterminations and it was in order to reduce this ‘seelische Belastung’, that the gas chamber method was eventually adopted.234

知识（不同于单一的经验）在原始层面上通过模仿过程从一代动物传递到下一代动物，动物行为学家称之为拟态。235但这一层面的交流与本能遗传所决定的行为并不容易区分。真正的知识传递源于欢乐，当一种动物分享另一种动物在其面前做出的智慧努力时，就会发生。W. Köhler 拍摄了一些生动的照片，照片中黑猩猩观察同伴尝试完成一项高难度动作，并通过它们的姿态表明自己参与了其他动物的努力。这种人际传递似乎在动物通过示例学习时发挥作用。当一只更聪明的黑猩猩发明了一个技巧，而另一只黑猩猩立即学会了，而这只黑猩猩自己永远也想不到的时候，它们显然就是这么做的。Köhler 列举了这一过程的例子，令人信服地断言，这并非鹦鹉学舌般的盲目模仿，而是动物之间智力表现的真正传递：一种在非言语层面上真正的知识交流。 236

Knowledge (as distinct from a single experience) is transmitted on a primordial level from one generation of animals to the next by an imitative process which students of animal behaviour call mimesis.235 But communication at this level is not readily distinguishable from the actions determined by the inheritance of instincts.
