A true transmission of knowledge stemming from conviviality takes place when an animal shares in the intelligent effort which another animal is making in its presence. There are telling photographs by W.Köhler of chimpanzees watching a fellow animal’s attempt to perform a difficult feat and revealing by their gestures that they participate in another’s efforts. Such interpersonal transmission seems at work whenever animals learn something by example, which they obviously do when a trick invented by a more intelligent chimpanzee is immediately taken up by another, who would never have been able to think of it on his own. Köhler, giving instances of this process, convincingly asserts that it is no blind parrot-like imitation, but a genuine transmission of an intellectual performance from one animal to another: a real communication of knowledge on the inarticulate level.236

所有艺术的学习都源于学习者对其信任之人的实践方式的巧妙模仿。掌握一门语言是一门艺术，它依赖于默契的判断和对非特定技能的实践。因此，儿童向成年监护人学习说话的方式，类似于幼年哺乳动物和幼鸟对其养育、保护和引导的长辈做出的模仿反应。言语的默契系数通过不清晰的交流传递，从权威者传递给信任的学生，而言语传达信息的能力取决于这种模仿传递的有效性。

All arts are learned by intelligently imitating the way they are practised by other persons in whom the learner places his confidence. To know a language is an art, carried on by tacit judgments and the practice of unspecifiable skills. The child’s way of learning to speak from his adult guardians is therefore akin to the young mammal’s and young bird’s mimetic responses to its nurturing, protecting and guiding seniors. The tacit coefficients of speech are transmitted by inarticulate communications, passing from an authoritative person to a trusting pupil, and the power of speech to convey communication depends on the effectiveness of this mimetic transmission.

口头交流是两个人成功地运用在学徒期获得的语言知识和技能，一方希望传递信息，另一方希望接收信息。凭借各自所学，说话者自信地表达，听者自信地解读，同时双方都依赖于对方对这些词语的正确运用和理解。真正的交流只有在对权威和信任的假设得到切实证实的情况下才能实现。

Spoken communication is the successful application by two persons of the linguistic knowledge and skill acquired by such apprenticeship, one person wishing to transmit, the other to receive, information. Relying on what each has learnt, the speaker confidently utters words and the listener confidently interprets them, while they mutually rely on each other’s correct use and understanding of these words. A true communication will take place if, and only if, these combined assumptions of authority and trust are in fact justified.

当这些条件严重无法实现时，我们就会意识到这些条件的不稳定性，就像皮亚杰所说的那样，孩子们的谈话“无法理解彼此……因为他们认为他们彼此理解”；237与此同时，“所说的话并不是从听话人的角度去思考的，当这些条件严重不成立时，我们就会意识到这些条件的不稳定性，就像在儿童的谈话中一样，正如皮亚杰所说，他们‘无法相互理解……因为他们认为他们后者……根据自己的兴趣选择它们，并扭曲它们以支持先前形成的概念’。238作为作者、演讲者和听众，我们深知此类反复无常的危险，并时刻保持警惕。说话和写作，就是一场不断更新的斗争，力求既贴切又通俗易懂，最终吐出的每一个字，都表明我们无法做得更好；但每当我们说完一句话，并让它保留下来时，我们也默认了这句话表达了我们的意思，因此也应该让听众或读者理解。尽管这些无处不在的默许，最终可能被证明是错误的，但如果我们还要说点什么，就必须接受这种风险。

We become aware of the precariousness of these conditions when they are grossly unfelfilled, as in the conversation of children, who, as Piaget says, ‘fail to understand on another… because they think that they do understand one another’;237 while at the same time ‘the words spoken are not thought of from the point of view of the person spoken to, and the We become aware of the precariousness of these conditions when they are grossly unfulfilled, as in the conversation of children, who, as Piaget says, ‘fail to understand one another…because they think that they do latter…selects them according to his own interest, and distorts them in favour of previously formed conceptions’.238 As writers, speakers and listeners, we know the perils of such vagaries and are constantly on the alert against them. Speaking and writing is an ever renewed struggle to be both apposite and intelligible, and every word that is finally uttered is a confession of our incapacity to do better; but each time we have finished saying something and let it stand, we tacitly imply also that this says what we mean and should mean it therefore also to the listener or reader. Though these ubiquitous tacit endorsements of our words may always turn out to be mistaken, we must accept this risk if we are ever to say anything.

 

 

 

 

  1. 社会知识的传播
  2. TRANSMISSION OF SOCIAL LORE

 

 

权威与信任的共同作用是语言学习和语言传递信息的基础，也是文化向后代传承的整个过程的一个简化例子。

The combined action of authority and trust which underlies both the learning of language and its use for carrying messages, is a simplified instance of a process which enters into the whole transmission of culture to succeeding generations.

我们现代的文化高度表述性。如果再次遭遇洪水，即使是最大的邮轮也不足以承载数百万卷书籍、数千幅绘画、数百种乐器、科学和技术仪器，以及众多具备独特资质、能够运用这些表述方式的专家，而我们正是通过这些专家，才得以将我们文明中最原始的遗迹传承给后洪水时代人类。目前，这些浩瀚的知识​​产物的代代传承，是通过成年人向年轻人传递的交流过程进行的。只有当一个人对另一个人、学徒对师傅、学生对老师、大众观众对杰出演说家或著名作家抱有高度信任时，才能进行这种交流。不同级别的新手能够吸收如此伟大的表述性知识体系，只有通过事先的融入才能实现，通过这种融入，新手接受一个培育这种知识、欣赏其价值并努力遵循其标准的社群的学徒身份。这种关联始于儿童在社群内接受教育，并随着成年后对同一社群的知识领袖持续抱有非凡信任而终生巩固。正如儿童学习说话时会假设在他们面前使用的词语具有某种意义一样，在整个文化学徒阶段，知识上的后辈渴望理解其知识上级的言行举止，也假设他们的言行举止蕴含着某种隐藏的含义，一旦发现，便会在某种程度上感到满足。我之前曾讨论过问题解决中的启发式暗示，并指出它们与学习者预期其试图理解的内容是否合理有着密切的联系。学习者与发现者一样，必须先相信才能知晓。然而，问题解决者的预知表达了对自己的信心，而学习者遵循的暗示则主要基于他对他人的信心；这是一种对权威的接受。

Our modern culture is highly articulate. If another Flood came over us, the largest liner afloat would not suffice to carry the millions of volumes, the many thousands of paintings and hundreds of different instruments, musical, scientific and technical, together with the host of specialists uniquely qualified to use these means of articulation, by which we might transmit to post-diluvian humanity even the crudest remains of our civilization. The current transmission of this immense aggregate of intellectual artefacts from one generation to another takes place by a process of communication which flows from adults to young people. This kind of communication can be received only when one person places an exceptional degree of confidence in another, the apprentice in the master, the student in the teacher, and popular audiences in distinguished speakers or famous writers. This assimilation of great systems of articulate lore by novices of various grades is made possible only by a previous act of affiliation, by which the novice accepts apprenticeship to a community which cultivates this lore, appreciates its values and strives to act by its standards. This affiliation begins with the fact that a child submits to education within a community, and it is confirmed throughout life to the extent to which the adult continues to place exceptional confidence in the intellectual leaders of the same community. Just as children learn to speak by assuming that the words used in their presence mean something, so throughout the whole range of cultural apprenticeship the intellectual junior’s craving to understand the doings and sayings of his intellectual superiors assumes that what they are doing and saying has a hidden meaning which, when discovered, will be found satisfying to some extent. I have spoken before of heuristic intimations in problem-solving and shown their kinship with the learner’s anticipation that what he tries to understand is in fact reasonable. The learner, like the discoverer, must believe before he can know. But while the problem-solver’s foreknowledge expresses confidence in himself, the intimations followed by the learner are based predominantly on his confidence in others; and this is an acceptance of authority.

这种个人效忠的授予——如同一种启发式推测——是一种将自身热情倾注于未曾尝试过的存在形式。清晰体系的持续传承，赋予我们知识满足以公开且持久的品质，始终依赖于这些臣服的行为。239

Such granting of one’s personal allegiance is—like an act of heuristic conjecture—a passionate pouring of oneself into untried forms of existence. The continued transmission of articulate systems, which lends public and enduring quality to our intellectual gratifications, depends throughout on these acts of submission.239

这些自我修正的过程本质上是非正式的、不可逆的，并且在某种程度上是非批判性的。诚然，一旦发现成果或学习者掌握了其学科知识，推测的张力就会降低：发现者可以证明其成果，学习者可以证明其所获得的知识的合理性。但我们能够从直接可用的证据中证明其合理性的知识量永远不会很大。因此，我们绝大多数的事实信念仍然通过信任他人而间接持有，并且在绝大多数情况下，我们的信任被置于相对少数、享有广泛认可地位的权威人士的手中。

These self-modifying processes are inherently informal, irreversible and to this extent a-critical. Admittedly, once discovery is achieved or the learner has mastered his subject, the conjectural tension is reduced: the discoverer can then demonstrate his result and the learner can justify the knowledge he has acquired. But the amount of knowledge which we can justify from evidence directly available to us can never be large. The overwhelming proportion of our factual beliefs continue therefore to be held at second hand through trusting others, and in the great majority of cases our trust is placed in the authority of comparatively few people of widely acknowledged standing.

此外，知识获取的真谛同样适用于所有其他的智力满足。当今社会思想的培养，始终依赖于一种个人自信，这种自信确保了社会知识的代代传承。我将在论述文化管理时详细阐述这一点。

Moreover, what is true of the acquisition of knowledge applies likewise to all other intellectual satisfactions. The current cultivation of thought in society depends throughout on the same kind of personal confidence which secures the transmission of social lore from one generation to the next. I shall go into this presently in detail when describing the administration of culture.

与此同时，我尚未对权威原则添加一项必要的限定条件。任何对权威的接受都受到某种程度的反抗，甚至反对权威的约束。对共识的服从总是在某种程度上伴随着将自己的观点强加于我们所服从的共识之上。每当我们在口语和写作中使用一个词时，我们既遵循惯例，又在某种程度上修改了现有的惯例；每当我选择广播节目时，我都会稍微调整当前文化价值的平衡；即使我以现行价格购买，我也会略微调整整个价格体系。事实上，每当我服从当前的共识时，我不可避免地会修改它的教义；因为我服从我自己认为它所教导的内容，并且通过在这些条款上加入共识，我影响了它的内容。另一方面，即使是最尖锐的异议，仍然需要部分服从现有的共识：因为革命者必须用人们能够理解的语言来表达。此外，每个异议者都是教师。安提戈涅和《申辩篇》中的苏格拉底的形象是异议者作为立法者的丰碑。旧约的先知们也是如此——路德和加尔文也是如此。自雅各宾派以来，所有现代革命者都同样表明，异议并非寻求废除公共权力，而是要将公共权力据为己有。

Meanwhile, I have yet to add an essential qualification to the principle of authority. Every acceptance of authority is qualified by some measure of reaction to it or even against it. Submission to a consensus is always accompanied to some extent by the imposition of one’s views on the consensus to which we submit. Every time we use a word in speaking and writing we both comply with usage and at the same time somewhat modify the existing usage; every time I select a programme on the radio I modify a little the balance of current cultural valuations; even when I make my purchase at current prices I slightly modify the whole price system. Indeed, whenever I submit to a current consensus, I inevitably modify its teaching; for I submit to what I myself think it teaches and by joining the consensus on these terms I affect its content. On the other hand, even the sharpest dissent still operates by partial submission to an existing consensus: for the revolutionary must speak in terms that people can under-stand. Moreover, every dissenter is a teacher. The figures of Antigone and of the Socrates of the Apology are monuments of the dissenter as lawgiver. So are also the prophets of the Old Testament—and so is a Luther, or a Calvin. All modern revolutionaries since the Jacobins demonstrate likewise that dissent does not seek to abolish public authority, but to claim it for itself.

诚然，服从权威通常不如异议行为那样刻意强硬。但并非总是如此。圣奥古斯丁为信仰启示而进行的抗争，远比当今宗教教育下的年轻人对启示的拒绝更具活力和独创性。无论如何，在我们成长并继续参与既定共识的过程中，我们每一步都会在不同程度的顺从和异议之间做出某种选择，而这两种选择都可能意味着一种更为被动或更为强硬的反应。

Admittedly, submission to authority is in general less deliberately assertive than is an act of dissent. But not always. St. Augustine’s struggle for belief in revelation was much more dynamic and original than is the rejection of revelation by a religiously brought up young man today. In any case, at every step of the process by which we are brought up and continue to participate in an established consensus, we exercise some measure of choice between different degrees of conformity and dissent, and either of these choices may mean a more passive or a more assertive reaction.

我们同时也应该意识到，这些认可性决定是多么不可避免，又是多么持续不断且包罗万象。每当我谈论一个科学事实、一个词语、一首诗或一位拳击冠军；谈论上周的谋杀案或英国女王；谈论金钱、音乐或帽子的时尚；谈论什么是正义或非正义、琐碎、有趣、无聊或丑闻，我都无法不提及一种共识，通过这种共识，这些事情被承认——或被否认——我所宣称的那样。我必须不断地支持现有的共识，或在某种程度上对其持有不同意见，无论哪种情况，我都会表达我认为就我所谈论的任何内容而言，共识应该是什么样的。本文以我自己的方式描述了每一种言论与公众共识之间的相互作用，它也不例外，与我在文中关于此类言论的论述一致。我在整本书中都坚定地肯定自己的信念，尤其是当我坚持（正如我在这里所做的那样）这种个人的肯定和选择是不可避免的，并且当我争辩（正如我将要做的那样）这就是我所能做的一切时。

We should realize at the same time how inevitable, and how unceasing and comprehensive are such accreditive decisions. I cannot speak of a scientific fact, of a word, of a poem or a boxing champion; of last week’s murder or the Queen of England; of money or music or the fashion in hats, of what is just or unjust, trivial, amusing, boring or scandalous, without implying a reference to a consensus by which these matters are acknowledged—or denied to be—what I declare them to be. I must continually endorse the existing consensus or dissent from it to some degree, and in either case I express what I believe the consensus ought to be in respect to whatever I speak of. The present text, in which I have described in my own way the interaction of every utterance with the public consensus, is no exception to what I have said in the text about utterances of this kind. Throughout this book I am affirming my own beliefs, and more particularly so when I insist, as I do here, that such personal affirmations and choices are inescapable, and, when I argue, as I shall do, that this is all that can be required of me.

 

 

  1. 纯粹的欢乐
  2. PURE CONVIVIALITY

信任的情感和令人信服的激情，使我们得以源源不断地传承我们能言善辩的遗产，这再次将我们带回到人类乃至动物群体中，在语言出现之前就存在的原始友爱情怀。动物和人类的经验，都证明了这种欢乐的原始性，以及这种欢乐互动所激发和满足的强烈情感。

The sentiments of trust and the persuasive passions by which the transmission of our articulate heritage is kept flowing, bring us back once more to the primitive sentiments of fellowship that exist previous to articulation among all groups of men and even among animals. Evidence of the primordial character of such conviviality and of the lively emotions engendered and gratified by its interplay is supplied by the experience both of animals and men.

刚孵出的小鸡很快就学会了加入母鸡周围的鸡群，并在母鸡的翅膀下寻求庇护。这个学习过程进展得如此迅速，通常难以察觉，但通过让一只小鸡在隔离环境中长大的实验，却清晰地揭示了这一点。两周后，这只在孤独环境中长大的小鸡被放归到野外，与已经聚集在母鸡周围的兄弟姐妹们团聚，这时它的行为变得狂躁起来。它会疯狂地啄食同伴，并惊恐地四处乱窜。240因此，我们可以说，鸡之间最早的人际互动会影响它们彼此的情感。它们通常能够发展出理性平衡的情感生活，而人为的隔离则会阻碍和扰乱这种情感生活。

A newly hatched chicken soon learns to join the flock around its mother and to seek protection under her wings. This educational process goes on so swiftly that it normally escapes notice, but it is clearly revealed by the experiment of letting a chicken grow up in isolation. When the chicken brought up in solitude is released after a fortnight, and brought together with its sisters and brothers, which have formed a flock around their mother, it behaves in a frantic manner. It pecks wildly at its fellow chicks and runs around terror-stricken.240 We may say therefore that the earliest inter-personal interaction between chickens affects their emotions towards each other. They usually succeed in developing a rationally balanced emotional life, which would be stunted and deranged by artificial isolation.

鸡在鸡群中长大时所享受的情感慰藉，与共享温暖和保护带来的身体满足感并非毫无关联，但它又不同于动物在寻找食物和住所时所享受的纯粹驱动力满足感。饥饿的狗会在食物即将到来时跳来跳去、吠叫，这种兴奋带有情感色彩；但狗与人之间的陪伴，以及由此带来的积极参与，则植根于更丰富、更无私的激情。事实上，狗会将它的感情寄托在与它玩耍、散步并始终对它感兴趣的主人身上，而不是喂它的人身上。241科勒曾用一句格言来概括欢乐关系的广泛性：孤独的黑猩猩并非真正的黑猩猩。它所有的生理需求都得到了满足，却因情感匮乏而萎靡不振。它缺乏动物同伴之间那种共享与互动的生活，而这种互动的多样性体现在各种情感之中。

The emotional comfort which chickens seem to enjoy when brought up in a flock is not unrelated to the bodily satisfaction of shared warmth and protection, but it is yet distinct from the pleasure cf mere drive- satisfaction which an animal enjoys in finding food and shelter. A hungry dog will jump about and bark when its meal is approaching and this excitement has emotional colouring, but the companionship afforded by a dog to a man, by which it may vitally participate in his existence, is rooted in richer and more disinterested passions. Indeed, a dog will attach its affection to a master who plays with it, goes for walks with it and generally shows interest in it, rather than to the person who feeds it.241 The comprehensive scope of convivial relations has been expressed by Köhler in the aphorism that a solitary chimpanzee is not a chimpanzee. All its physical needs are satisfied, yet it languishes through emotional starvation. It lacks that sharing and interplay of life between fellow animals, the manifold forms of which are reflected in a whole gamut of varied sentiments.

人与人之间的友谊往往在沉默中维持和享受。史蒂文森的《化身博士》中的厄特森先生，无论重要的事情都推后，与他的朋友理查德·恩菲尔德先生一起散步，两人都沉默不语。然而，欢乐的气氛通常通过更刻意地分享经验，最常见的是通过交谈来实现。问候和日常的闲聊是友谊的表达，一个人对另一个人每一次清晰的交谈都会为他们的欢乐增添一些色彩，因为他们彼此接触，分享彼此的生活。纯粹的欢乐，即培养良好的友谊，在许多交流行为中占主导地位；事实上，人们彼此交谈的主要原因是渴望陪伴。242单独监禁的折磨在于，它剥夺了人们获取信息的权力，但剥夺了人们交谈的权利，无论这种交谈多么无益。

Companionship among men is often sustained and enjoyed in silence. Mr. Utterson,in Stevenson’s Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, puts off any business, however important, to take his regular walk with his friend Mr. Richard Enfield, during which neither of them pronounces a single word. But conviviality is usually made effective by a more deliberate sharing of experience, and most commonly by conversation. The exchange of greetings and of conventional remarks is an articulation of companionship, and every articulate address of one person to another makes some contribution to their conviviality, in the sense of their reaching out to each other and sharing each other’s lives. Pure conviviality, that is, the cultivation of good fellowship, predominates in many acts of communication; indeed, the main reason for which people talk to each other is a desire for company.242 The torment of solitary confinement is that it deprives one not of information but of conversation, however uninformative.

在共同生活的小群体中培养良好的友谊，无论是家人、同学、船友、教会成员，还是工坊或办公室团队的成员，都直接有助于实现人类作为社会存在的目的和责任。而且，这个过程在提高群体联合活动的效率方面也具有实际用途。海军指挥官知道，一艘快乐的船的船员将拥有出色的作战能力。工业心理学家观察到，当工坊的工人在彼此的陪伴中找到乐趣时，其产出就会提高。243很多情况下，为了获得这种有利的结果，人们会刻意提高欢乐的气氛；这进一步证实了我们赋予陪伴情感的实质性特征。

The fostering of good fellowship within small groups of people living together, be it as families, as school-fellows, as shipmates, as fellow members of a congregation or of a workshop or office team, is a direct contribution to the fulfilment of man’s purpose and duty as a social being. But the process is also of practical use in making the joint activities of the group more effective. Naval commanders know that the crew of a happy ship will fight well. Industrial psychologists have observed that the output of a workshop increases when its operatives find pleasure in each other’s company.243 Many are the instances in which the improvement of conviviality is deliberately advanced for the sake of such advantageous results; and this offers, further confirmation of the substantial character that we have ascribed to the feelings of companionship.

它也构成了向第二种纯粹欢乐​​的过渡：从分享经验到参与共同活动。这种合作通常偶然地促成了共同的目标，但在共同执行仪式时，它变成了纯粹的欢乐。通过充分参与仪式，群体成员确认了他们存在的共同体，同时将他们群体的生活与传承了仪式的先辈群体的生活联系起来。群体的每一次仪式行为在某种程度上都是群体内部的和解，以及与其自身历史的连续性的重建。它肯定了群体超越个人的欢乐存在，无论是在现在还是在过去。这些情感重申的契机是周年纪念日或群体重建的周期性变化。它的一致性通过仪式与季节的年度节律一起更新，或者当死亡、出生、婚姻或其他地位变更的发生以传统方式庄严地神圣化时。244

It also forms a transition to a second kind of pure conviviality: from the sharing of experience to a participation in joint activities. Such cooperation is usually incidental to a purpose jointly aimed at, but it becomes purely convivial in the joint performance of a ritual. By fully participating in a ritual, the members of a group affirm the community of their existence, and at the same time identify the life of their group with that of antecedent groups, from whom the ritual has descended to them Every ritual act of a group is to this extent a reconciliation within the group and a re-establishment of continuity with its own history as a group. It affirms the convivial existence of the group as transcending the individual, both in the present and through times past. The occasions for these emotional reaffirmations are anniversary dates or the recurrent changes by which the group undergoes reconstitution. Its coherence is renewed ritually to the annual rhythm of the seasons, or else when the occurrence of death, birth, marriage, or other alterations of status, are solemnly consecrated in traditional terms.244

由于仪式是对欢乐生活的颂扬，它们招致了个人主义的敌意，个人主义否认群体生活作为一种存在形式的价值，认为孤立的个体无法获得这种存在。仪式也遭到功利主义者的贬低，理由是它没有实际用途；浪漫主义者（功利主义者的情感主义兄弟）则认为仪式压制了人们真正的自发情感，而推崇标准化的公共情感，迫使人们不真诚地假装分享这些情感。

Since rituals are a celebration of convivial existence they incur the hostility of individualism, which denies value to group life as a form of being, not accessible to the isolated individual. Ritual is deprecated also both by the utilitarian on the grounds of serving no tangible purpose, and by the romantic (the emotionalist brother of the utilitarian) for suppressing people’s genuine spontaneous feelings, in favour of the standardized public emotions which they are forced insincerely to pretend to share.

传统主义因反思我们在举行仪式时所遵循的庄严感是人为造成的这一事实而更加彻底地被否定。我们似乎既创造了它，又将其视为外在之物而屈从于它，这样做似乎欺骗了自己，也欺骗了我们的同伴。我们在此看到，自我设定的标准在其社会背景中更全面的范围内，其内在的不安全感再次出现。

Traditionalism is even more fundamentally discredited by reflecting on the fact that the solemnity to which we surrender in performing a ritual is of man’s own making. We seem both to generate it and submit to it as something external to us, and in doing so we seem to dupe ourselves and deceive our fellows. We see reappear here the internal insecurity of self- set standards, in the fuller range of their social setting.

 

 

  1. 社会组织
  2. THE ORGANIZATION OF SOCIETY

我迄今为止勾勒出的社会图景就像一艘刚刚下水的船——一个没有引擎的框架。我追溯了那些使信息流通、社会知识代代相传以及清晰共识的维持成为可能的默契人际互动。我也展示了同样的互动如何满足人们对陪伴的渴望，一种纯粹的欢乐，而参与共同的仪式正是这种欢乐的最有力体现。群体生活的这些特征足以形成一个团契，但不足以形成一个有组织的社会。只有当我们认识到群体的社会知识所赋予的人际义务框架时，我们才能理解后者。

The picture of society which I have so far outlined is like a newly launched ship—a frame without an engine. I have traced the tacit personal interactions which make possible the flow of communications, the transmission of social lore from one generation to the other and the maintenance of an articulate consensus I have shown also how the same interactions gratify a desire for companionship, a pure conviviality to which a participation in common rituals gives the firmest expression. These features of group life suffice for the formation of a fellowship, but not of an organized society. We can understand the latter only when we recognize the framework of interpersonal obligations imposed by the social lore of the group.

然而，仅仅分享不针对他人的智识激情，就已经建立了广泛的共同价值观，这些价值观与道德、习俗和法律所规定的人际欣赏相一致。此外，这种分享构成了一种维护某些智识和艺术标准的正统观念，并承诺致力于在这些标准指导下的追求，这实际上相当于对文化义务的承认。最后，由于仪式中表达的激情肯定了群体生活的价值，它们宣告了群体有权要求其成员保持一致，群体生活的利益可以合法地与个人利益相抗衡，有时甚至凌驾于个人利益之上。这承认了一种共同的利益，为了这种共同的利益，可以压制偏差，并要求个人做出牺牲，以捍卫群体免受外部的颠覆和破坏。

Yet the mere sharing of intellectual passions directed towards no other persons establishes already a wide range of common values, which are continuous with the interpersonal appreciations laid down by morality, custom and law. Moreover, such sharing constitutes an orthodoxy upholding certain intellectual and artistic standards, and an undertaking to engage in the pursuits guided by them, which amounts in effect to a recognition of cultural obligations. Finally, since the passions expressed in a ritual affirm the value of group life, they declare that the group has a claim to the conformity of its members, and that the interests of group life may legitimately rival and sometimes overrule those of the individual. This acknowledges a common good for the sake of which deviation may be suppressed and individuals be required to make sacrifices for defending the group against subversion and destruction from outside.

在这个阶段，文化与仪式团契的框架，从根本上揭示了社会组织的四个系数，它们共同构成了所有特定的固定社会关系系统。其中两个系数让人联想到在清晰层面上满足智识激情的两种方式，即通过肯定或内住：第一个系数是分享信念，第二个系数是分享团契。第三个系数是合作；第四个系数是行使权威或强制。

At this stage, the framework of cultural and ritual fellowship reveals primordially the four coefficients of societal organization which jointly compose all specific systems of fixed social relations. Two of these coefficients recall the two ways of satisfying intellectual passions on an articulate level, namely by affirmation or indwelling: the first is the sharing of convictions, the second the sharing of a fellowship. The third coefficient is co-operation; the fourth the exercise of authority or coercion.

这四个称谓指的是社会的四个方面，它们必须始终相互联系在一起看待，因为只有结合在一起，它们才能形成社会制度的稳定特征。然而，在现代社会中，基于精细清晰的系统和高度专业化，我们发现某些制度主要依次体现了这四个因素。（1）大学、教堂、剧院和画廊，服务于信仰的分享，我在这里应用的是广义的信仰分享。它们是文化机构。（2）社交、集体仪式、共同防御，主要是欢乐的机构。它们培养和要求集体忠诚。（3）为共同的物质利益而进行合作是社会作为一种经济制度的主要特征。（4）权威和强制力提供了公共权力，它庇护和控制社会的文化、欢乐和经济机构。

These four titles refer to four aspects of society which must always be seen in conjunction with each other, for only together can they form stable features in the shape of social institutions. Yet in modern society, based on elaborate articulate systems and on a high degree of specialization, we find certain institutions which predominantly embody each of these four coefficients in turn. (1) Universities, churches, theatres and picture galleries, serve the sharing of convictions, in the wide sense of the term which I am applying here. They are institutions of culture. (2) Social intercourse, group rituals, common defence, are predominantly convivial institutions. They foster and demand group loyalty. (3) Co-operation for a joint material advantage is the predominant feature of society as an economic system. (4) Authority and coercion supply the public power which shelters and controls the cultural, convivial and economic institutions of society.

原始的文盲民族无法运作如此独特的制度，因此无法将四种社会因素紧密地融合在一起。在此阶段，社会中的权力与思想之间不可能存在根本性的冲突。即使在权力与思想被分别体现在不同的制度中之后，只要社会接受其自身的结构为永久确立的，这种冲突也不会出现，就像在有记载的历史的大部分时间里一样。尽管在欧洲历史的最初2300年中，经历了许多伟大的改革——例如梭伦和克里斯提尼的改革，格里高利大帝或路德的改革，黎塞留或彼得大帝的改革——但等级森严的社会结构在很大程度上被认为是政治体存在的关键。直到美国革命和法国革命之后，人们才逐渐相信，通过行使人民的政治意愿，社会可以得到无限的改善，因此，人民应该在理论和事实上拥有主权。

Primitive illiterate peoples cannot operate such distinctive institutions and present therefore throughout an intimate amalgam of all four social coefficients. At this stage no fundamental tension can exist between power and thought in society. Nor did such a tension arise even after power and thought had been embodied in separate institutions, so long as society accepted its own structure as permanently established, as it did during the greater part of recorded history. For in spite of many great reforms—like those of Solon and Cleisthenes, of Gregory the Great or Luther, of Richelieu or Peter the Great—made during the first 2300 years of European history, a hierarchical social structure was for the most part regarded as essential to the very existence of the body politic. Only after the American and French revolutions did the conviction gradually spread over the world that society could be improved indefinitely by the exercise of political will of the people, and that the people should therefore be sovereign, both in theory and fact.

这一运动催生了现代动态社会，这种社会有两种类型。当一个社会决心突然彻底革新自身时，它的动态是革命性的；如果它的目标是循序渐进地走向完美，它的动态则是改良性的。在本章的其余部分，我将详细论述科学真理和其他知识价值在这两种社会中的地位，并由此阐述我之前暗示过的区别：极权主义试图通过将一切思想置于福利之下来实现拉普拉斯的纲领，而自由社会则原则上接受按照其固有标准培养思想的义务。但我必须首先阐明，无论多么粗略，这两种现代动态社会在与思想的关系方面与它们所起源的静态社会有何不同。

This movement gave rise to modern dynamic societies, of which there are two kinds. When a society is resolved on a sudden complete renewal of itself, its dynamism is revolutionary; if it aims at a more gradual approach to perfection, its dynamism is reformist. In the rest of this chapter I shall deal at length with the status of scientific truth and of other intellectual values in these two kinds of societies, elaborating thereby the distinction, at which I have hinted already, between a totalitarianism which tries to fulfil the Laplacean programme by subordinating all thought to welfare, and a free society which accepts in principle the obligation to cultivate thought according to its inherent standards. But I must make clear first, however sketchily, how both types of modern dynamic society differ, with respect to their relation to thought, from the static societies from which they have emerged.

为此，我们必须认识到思想自由与承认思想是一种真实力量之间的区别。任何静态社会都不会否认思想的内在力量和价值：宗教、道德、法律以及所有艺术都因其自身的权利而受到尊重。尽管他们的事业受到一套特定信仰的限制，禁止他们挑战这些信仰，但文化追求在这些限制之内蓬勃发展。此外，既定的正统观念是由统治者强加的，他们也将其作为自己的指导。尽管对某些教义的接受是不容置疑的真理，对真理的追求受到限制，但对这些教义权威的义务尊重，本身就意味着对真理的深深敬意。245

For this purpose we must acknowledge the difference between freedom of thought and the recognition of thought as a real force. No static society ever denied the intrinsic power and worth of thought: religion, morality, law and all the arts were respected in their own right. Though their enterprises were restricted by a set of specific beliefs which they were forbidden to challenge, cultural pursuits flourished within these limits. Moreover, the established orthodoxy was imposed by rulers who accepted it also for their own guidance. Though the quest for truth was restricted by the acceptance of certain teachings as indubitably true, the obligatory respect for the authority of these teachings implied a deep respect for truth.245

现代革命政府所实行的思想控制与此原则上有所不同。其统治者试图重塑社会，包括其思想，以服务于社会福祉。他们因此否定了思想的任何独立地位或自由活动，尽管他们实际上可能常常承认思想的权威，这是对常识的一种默认。

The intellectual control exercised by modern revolutionary governments differs from this in principle. Its rulers propose to re-shape society, including its thought, in the service of its welfare. They deny thereby any independent status or free activity to thought, even though they may in fact often admit its authority as a tacit concession to common sense.

这就是极权主义。与极权主义以及静态社会不同，自由社会赋予思想独立的地位和理论上不受限制的自由空间，但在实践中，它培育了一种特定的文化传统，并强制推行公共教育和维护现有政治经济制度的法律法规。

This is totalitarianism. By contrast both to it and to a static society, a free society accords both independent status and a theoretically unrestricted range to thought, though in practice it fosters a particular cultural tradition, and imposes a public education and a code of laws which uphold existing political and economic institutions.

原则上，自由社会与现代革命政权一样，都主张为了自我完善而享有自决权。事实上，这些渴望构成了创造自由社会的原始力量的一部分；它们源于推翻中世纪静态专制主义的不受约束的思想和慷慨的情感。然而，与此同时，它们也在其所构建的自由社会中制造了危险的矛盾。伟大的独立思想运动在现代人心中灌输了一种对所有非绝对客观的知识的强烈拒绝，而这反过来又意味着一种机械的人性观，这种观念必然会否定人的独立思考能力。这种客观主义必然代表着福利和权力方面的公共利益，并由此引发自由的自我毁灭。因为，当自由社会所公开宣称的伟大道德激情被贬低为似是而非或乌托邦式的时，它的活力就会转化为政治机器的隐藏驱动力，而这种政治机器随后被宣称为天生正确，并被赋予对思想的绝对统治权。

In principle, the free society claims the right of self-determination for the purpose of self-perfection as absolutely as the modern revolutionary regimes. Indeed, these aspirations form part of the original forces that created the free societies; they stem from the unfettered thoughts and generous feelings which overthrew the static authoritarianism of the Middle Ages. Yet at the same time they have set up a menacing contradiction in the free society that they produced. The great movement for independent thought instilled in the modern mind a desperate refusal of all knowledge that is not absolutely impersonal, and this implied in its turn a mechanical conception of man which was bound to deny man’s capacity for independent thought. Such objectivism must represent the public good in terms of welfare and power and set in motion thereby the self-destruction of freedom. For when open professions of the great moral passions animating a free society are discredited as specious or Utopian, its dynamism will tend to be transformed into the hidden driving force of a political machine, which is then proclaimed as inherently right and granted absolute dominion over thought.

这一公民困境的严重性——源于我们信念内在的不稳定性，最终不得不采取的手段——稍后将进行更详细的探讨。但我必须首先拓展我的视角，明确地介绍人类的道德渴望，它是人类更具体的智识激情的延伸。

The seriousness of this civic predicament—resulting in the last resort from the inherent instability of our convictions—will be presently explored in some detail. But I must expand my perspective first by introducing explicitly the moral aspirations of man as an extension of his more specifically intellectual passions.

 

 

  1. 两种文化
  2. TWO KINDS OF CULTURE

本书的主要目的是帮助我达到一种心境，使我能够坚定地坚持我所相信的真理，即使我知道它可能是错误的。本书仅探讨一般意义上的思想培养，作为维护真理的框架。然而，现在我必须明确地将道德、习俗和法律领域纳入文化体系。

The principal purpose of this book is to achieve a frame of mind in which I may hold firmly to what I believe to be true, even though I know that it might conceivably be false. The cultivation of thought in general is only examined as the context in which truth may be upheld. Yet I shall now have to include explicitly the domains of morality, custom and law within the system of culture.

道德判断是一种评价，因此类似于智识评价。对正义的渴望，如同智识激情所特有的，能够通过丰富世界来满足自身。如同艺术家和科学家一样，有道德的人也努力满足自己的标准，并赋予这些标准普遍有效性。

Moral judgments are appraisals and as such are akin to intellectual valuations. The thirst for righteousness has the same capacity for satisfying itself by enriching the world that is proper to intellectual passions. And like the artist and scientist, moral man strives to satisfy his own standards, to which he attributes universal validity.

但道德判断远比智力评价深刻得多。一个人可能被求知欲所吞噬；他可能是一位天才，但也可能谄媚、虚荣、嫉妒和心怀恶意。即使他是一位文坛巨擘，也可能是一个卑鄙的人。因为人的价值取决于他们的道德力量；我们道德奋斗的结果并非取决于我们任何外在行为的成败，而是取决于它对我们整个人的影响。因此，道德规则控制着我们的整个自我，而不是我们能力的运用；遵守道德、习俗和法律准则，就是在比遵守某些科学和艺术标准更为广泛的意义上遵守它。

But moral judgments cut much deeper than intellectual valuations. A man may be consumed by an intellectual passion; he may be a man of genius, yet be also sycophantic, vain, envious and spiteful. Though a prince of letters, he would be a despicable person. For men are valued as men according to their moral force; and the outcome of our moral striving is assessed, not as the success or failure of any external performance of ours, but by its effect on our whole person. Accordingly, moral rules control our whole selves rather than the exercise of our faculties, and to comply with a code of morality, custom and law, is to live by it in a far more comprehensive sense than is involved in observing certain scientific and artistic standards.

因此，道德规则是公民权力的工具，掌握在那些推行道德文化的人手中，而道德与习俗和法律息息相关。人们组成一个社会，取决于他们的生活是否受到相同的道德、习俗和法律的约束，这些共同构成了他们社会的风俗。

Moral rules are therefore an instrument of civic power in the hands of those who administer moral culture, and morality is allied to custom and law. Men form a society to the extent to which their lives are ordered by the same morality, custom and law, which jointly constitute the mores of their society.

我们在此认识到社会知识管理中的一个重要区别。因为我们看到，有些社会知识体系是为了我们个人的智力生活而培养的，而另一些则是通过按照这些体系来规范我们的社会生活而培养的。前者本质上是个人思想的社会培养，而后者本质上是公民思想的社会管理。

We recognize here an important division in the administration of social lore. For we see that while some systems of social lore are cultivated for the sake of our intellectual life as individuals, others are cultivated by the act of ordering our lives socially in accordance with them. The first is a social fostering of essentially individual thought, the second an administration of society in accordance with essentially civic thought.

一切思想都以其自身的标准为准绳，其进步也处处受到自身激情的推动。如果要社会性地培育思想，这些标准和激情必须为一群人所共有。为了确保这种共有，社会必须建立起构成其文化制度的适当的权利和义务体系。这将使社会中的思想生活间接地依赖于社会的公民制度，即依赖于群体的忠诚、财产和权力。但这种依赖性对社会中两种思想的影响不同，因为公民文化本身维系着社会的公民制度，而个人文化则相反，自身由这些制度所维系。

All thought is valid by its own standards and its progress is everywhere prompted by its own passions. If thought is to be cultivated socially, these standards and passions must be shared by a group of people. To secure this sharing, society must establish appropriate sets of rights and duties which constitute its cultural institutions. This will make the life of thought in society dependent at second hand on the civic institutions of society, that is on group loyalty, property and power. But this dependence will enter differently into the two types of thought in society, since civic culture itself sustains the civic institutions of society, while individual culture is, on the contrary, itself sustained by these institutions.

在此，我不会试图赋予这三种紧密交织的公民制度以逻辑或历史的优先性。例如，人们建立社会秩序的首要目的或许是为了谋生，因此，捍卫财产是群体忠诚的关键，也是在群体内部以及为捍卫群体而行使权力的关键。但无论这三种公民制度之间的联系如何，忠诚是狭隘的，财产是贪婪的，而公共权力则是暴力的。因此，公民的极点最终依赖于与知识或道德标准的普遍意图本质上相悖的系数。

I shall not try to assign here either logical or historical priority to any of the three closely interwoven civic institutions. It may be, for example, that men establish a social order in the first place for the sake of making a living, and that the defence of property is thus the key to group loyalty and to the exercise of power both within the group, and in defence of it. But whatever the connection between the three civic institutions, loyalty is parochial, property appetitive and public authority violent. Thus the civic pole relies ultimately on coefficients that are essentially at variance with the universal intent of intellectual or moral standards.

另一方面，任何社会秩序都不是缺乏思想的：它体现了那些信奉并以此为生的人们的公民意识和道德信念。对一个幸福的民族来说，公民文化就是公民的家园；而就此而言，支撑这种文化的智识激情实际上是深奥难懂的。然而，在一个批判的时代，公民需求与道德理想的这种交织仍将岌岌可危。当人们意识到道德标准是由武力维护、以财产为基础、并浸润着地方忠诚时，其真实性将受到质疑。事实上，此类冲突可能会彻底质疑公民思想的内在力量，如果在这场冲突中思想失败，那么思想的本质自主性将在此被否定——而且首先在此——。道德将被沦为一种纯粹的意识形态，这种对思想的贬低将蔓延开来，并最终导致所有思想都屈从于地方爱国主义、经济利益和国家权力。现在让我来阐述一下这种冲突趋势的模式。

On the other hand, no order of society is thoughtless: it embodies the civic sense and moral convictions of those who believe in it and live by it. To a happy people its civic culture is its civic home; and to this extent the intellectual passions sustaining this culture are in fact esoteric. But again, in a critical age, this intertwining of civic exigencies with the ideals of morality will remain precarious. The genuineness of moral standards will be rendered suspect when it is realized that they are upheld by force, based on property and imbued with local loyalty. Indeed, such conflicts may call in question altogether the intrinsic force of civic thought, and if in this conflict thought is the loser, thought will be denied here—and here in the first place—its essential autonomy. Morality will then be reduced to a mere ideology, and this depreciation of thought will tend to spread and to bring about eventually the subjection of all thought to local patriotism, economic interest and the power of the state. Let me now develop this pattern of conflicting tendencies.

 

 

  1. 个人文化管理
  2. ADMINISTRATION OF INDIVIDUAL CULTURE

我们将从自由社会的思想状况开始，以科学的进步作为培养个人思想的主要例子，社会赋予个人思想独立的地位。

We shall start with the condition of thought in a free society, and let the advancement of science serve as our principal example for the cultivation of individual thought to which independent status is accorded by society.

科学过程的组织首先取决于这样一个事实：现代科学浩瀚无垠，任何个人都只能理解其中的一小部分。皇家学会设有八个分委员会负责院士选举，每个分委员会都负责一个独立的研究领域。例如，其中一个领域就是数学；但个别数学家的专业性更强，只能胜任数学的一小部分。据说，在数学大会上提交的五十篇论文中，很少有数学家能够完全理解其中六篇以上。“其余四十四篇论文的大部分内容，对于只关注与自己专业最接近的六篇报告的人来说，简直是一头雾水。” 246结合我自己在化学和物理学方面的经验，我认为所有主要科学领域的情况可能都是类似的，因此任何一位科学家都只能直接判断当前科学总产出的百分之一。

The organization of the scientific process is determined, in the first place, by the fact that modern science is so vast that any single person can properly understand only a small section of it. The Royal Society has eight sub-committees for the election of Fellows, each of which has a separate field of research allotted to it. One of these fields, for example, is mathematics; but individual mathematicians are further specialized and are competent to deal only with a small part of mathematics. It is a rare mathematician—we are told—who fully understands more than half a dozen out of fifty papers presented to a mathematical congress. ‘The very language in which most of the other forty-four are presented goes clear over the head of the man who follows the six reports nearest his own speciality.’246 Adding to this evidence my own experience in chemistry and physics, it seems to me that the situation may be similar for all major scientific provinces, so that any single scientist may be competent to judge at first hand only about one hundredth of the total current output of science.

然而，这群人——科学家——共同管理着科学的进步和传播。他们通过控制大学校园、学术任命、研究经费、科学期刊以及授予学位来实现这一目标。这些学位使获得者有资格成为教师、技术或医疗从业者，并为他们提供学术任命的可能性。此外，通过控制科学的进步和传播，这群人——科学家——实际上确立了“科学”一词的当前含义，决定了什么应该被接受为科学，也确立了“科学家”一词的当前含义，并决定他们自己以及他们自己指定的继任者是否应被承认为科学家。社会对科学的培育依赖于公众对这些关于什么是科学以及谁是科学家的决定的接受。

Yet this group of persons—the scientists—administer jointly the advancement and dissemination of science. They do so though the control of university premisses, academic appointments, research grants, scientific journals and the awarding of academic degrees which qualify their recipients as teachers, technical or medical practitioners, and opens to them the possibility of academic appointment. Moreover, by controlling the advancement and dissemination of science, this same group of persons, the scientists, actually establish the current meaning of the term ‘science’, determine what should be accepted as science, and establish also the current meaning of the term ‘scientist’ and decide that they themselves and those designated by themselves as their successors should be recognized as such. The cultivation of science by society relies on the public acceptance of these decisions as to what science is and who are scientists.

当我们认同这种共识时，我们习惯于将其视为理所当然。这通常被认为是可以重复并证实任何科学记录的观察结果这一事实的必然结果。但对这一假定事实的肯定，实际上只是表达我们对该共识的坚持的另一种方式。因为我们从未重复过任何显著的科学观察结果。此外，我们非常清楚，如果我们尝试这样做却失败了（我们通常会失败），我们完全有理由将失败归咎于我们缺乏技能。我们还应该记住，即使我们能够可靠地重复科学记录的事实，这仍然不能证明我们接受科学基于这些事实得出的概括，更不能证明先前选择这些特定事实作为科学观察对象是合理的。我们还应该考虑到，即使概括的真实性也不能确立其作为科学的一部分，因为断言的可靠性只是构成陈述科学价值的三个系数之一。接受其宣称为科学的事物为科学的共识认可其科学价值，并根据可靠性、系统性兴趣和内在兴趣三重标准对其进行评级。

We are accustomed to take this consensus for granted when we are partners to it. It is commonly regarded as the obvious outcome of the fact that you could repeat and confirm any observation recorded by science. But the affirmation of this supposed fact is actually but another manner of expressing our adherence to the consensus in question. For we never do repeat any appreciable part of the observations of science. And besides, we know perfectly well that if we tried to do this and failed (as we mostly would), we would quite rightly ascribe our failure to our lack of skill. We should keep in mind also that even if we could reliably repeat the facts recorded by science, this would still not justify our acceptance of the generalizations which science bases on these facts, and would still less warrant the anterior selection of these particular facts as subjects of scientific observation. We should also take into account that even the truth of a generalization does not establish it as a part of science, since the reliability of an affirmation is only one of the three coefficients composing the scientific value of a statement. The consensus which accepts as science what it declares to be science endorses the scientific value of it as graded on the threefold scale of reliability, systematic interest, and intrinsic interest.

因此，我们看到，科学意见的共识远远超出了对共同经验的一致认同。它是对一个知识领域的共同评估，每个参与者都只能正确理解和判断其中很小的一部分。人们或许会疑惑，这样的共识如何才能合理地建立起来。我认为其基本原理是这样的：每个科学家都关注着一个由他自己的领域和一些相邻的领域组成的区域，而邻近的专家也可以对这些区域做出可靠的第一手判断。现在假设A和C能够可靠地判断关于B专业领域的工作；B和D能够可靠地判断关于C专业领域的工作；C和E能够可靠地判断关于D专业领域的工作；等等。如果这些邻近的专家群体都就其标准达成一致，那么A、B和C所认同的标准将与B、C和D所认同的标准相同，C、D和E也​​认同的标准相同，等等，在整个科学领域都是如此。这种标准的相互调整当然是沿着一整套体系进行的，这为沿着每条体系进行的调整提供了大量的交叉检验；科学家们也对专业上更久远、更杰出的成就直接做出的、但不那么确定的判断，对这一体系进行了充分的补充。然而，它的运作仍然本质上基于邻近评价的“传递性”——就像行军纵队通过每个人与旁边的人步调一致来保持步调一致一样。

We see, therefore, that the consensus of scientific opinion goes far beyond an agreement concerning a common experience. It is a joint appraisal of an intellectual domain, of which each consenting participant can properly understand and judge only a very small fraction. One may well wonder how such an agreement can ever be reasonably established. I think the underlying principle is this. Each scientist watches over an area comprising his own field and some adjoining strips of territory, over which neighbouring specialists can also form reliable first-hand judgments. Suppose now that work done on the speciality of B can be reliably judged by A and C; that of C by B and D; that of D by C and E; and so on. If then each of these groups of neighbours agrees in respect to their standards, then the standards on which A, B and C agree will be the same on which B, C and D agree, and on which also C, D and E agree, and so on, throughout the whole realm of science. This mutual adjustment of standards occurs of course along a whole network of lines which offers a multitude of cross-checks for the adjustments made along each separate line; and the system is amply supplemented also by somewhat less certain judgments made by scientists directly on professionally more distant achievements of exceptional merit. Yet its operation continues to be based essentially on the ‘transitiveness’ of neighbouring appraisals—much as a marching column is kept in step by each man’s keeping in step with those next to him.

凭借这一共识，科学家们形成了一条连续的批评线——或者更确切地说，是一个连续的网络——他们的审查确保所有经科学家认可的出版物都拥有相同的最低科学价值。不仅如此，通过彼此之间对近邻的同样信赖，他们甚至确保了高于这一最低水平乃至最高水平的科学著作的卓越性，在各个科学分支中都以同等的标准来衡量。这些比较性评价的正确性对科学至关重要，因为它们指导着不同研究领域之间人力和资助的分配，尤其决定着对科学领域的新突破给予认可和支持，或拒绝给予认可和支持的关键决策。尽管我们诚然很容易发现这种评价被证明是错误的，或者至少是令人遗憾的迟来的，但我们应该承认，只有在我们相信这些决策基本正确的情况下，我们才能将“科学”称为一套明确的、总体上具有权威性的系统知识体系。否则，科学机构将不再服务于科学的进步，反而会使其逐渐遭到破坏。“科学家”这个头衔（由被称为“科学家”的人们相互授予）将逐渐失去其真正意义，这些人用来描述自身研究的“科学”一词也将逐渐失去其真正意义。

By this consensus scientists form a continuous line—or rather a continuous network—of critics, whose scrutiny upholds the same minimum level of scientific value in all publications accredited by scientists. More than that: by a similar reliance of each on his immediate neighbour they even make sure that the distinction of scientific work above this minimum level, and right up to the highest degrees of excellence, is measured by equivalent standards throughout the various branches of science. The rightness of these comparative appreciations is vital to science, for they guide the distribution of men and subsidies between the different lines of study, and they determine, in particular, the crucial decisions by which recognition and assistance are granted to new departures in science or else withheld from them. Though it is admittedly easy to find instances in which this appreciation has proved mistaken, or at least sadly belated, we should acknowledge that we can speak of ‘science’ as a definite and on the whole authoritative body of systematic knowledge only to the extent to which we believe that these decisions are predominantly correct. Otherwise, scientific institutions would no longer serve the advancement of science but bring about its progressive mutilation. The title of ‘scientist’ (mutually granted to each other by persons thereby called ‘scientists’) would then gradually cease to carry its true meaning, and so would the word ‘science’ as used by these persons in description of their own pursuits.

让我进一步阐述一下。假设所有科学家都是江湖骗子（有些人确实如此）；或者，为了使这个假设更合理，假设他们都像李森科一样自欺欺人，或者要么不诚实，要么被迫屈从于那些本身就不诚实或自欺欺人的人的观点，就像李森科的追随者大多如此。或者假设科学可靠性和重要性的标准普遍被贬低，就像现在世界上某些地方的情况一样；或者更进一步，假设自然科学完全被基于神秘学方法的神秘科学所取代。各种专家之间可能仍然存在共识，彼此承认彼此是科学家，也相互承认各自伪科学领域的有效性和重要性，公众可能会被他们共同的保证所欺骗，接受他们所谓的“科学”就是科学。但显然，如果我知道这种共识背后的原因，我会认为这是流氓和傻瓜的共识，既欺骗彼此，也欺骗公众——是意外或阴谋的结果，无论哪种情况都没有任何真正的意义。

Let me expand this. Suppose for a moment that all scientists were charlatans, as some certainly are; or, to make the assumption more plausible, that they were all self-deluded like Lysenko, or else either dishonest or forced to conform to the views of people who are themselves either dishonest or self-deluded, as Lysenko’s followers mostly were. Or suppose that standards of scientific reliability and significance were generally so debased as they are even now in some parts of the world; or going a step beyond this, that the natural sciences were replaced altogether by the occult sciences based on cabalistic methods. There might still exist a consensus between the various specialists acknowledging each other as scientists, and mutually acknowledging also the validity and significance of their respective domains of pseudo-science, and the public might be deluded by their joint assurances to accept what they call ‘science’ as science. But clearly, if I knew what lay behind such a consensus, I should regard it as a consensus of rogues and fools, deceiving both each other and their public—the result of an accident or a conspiracy, and in either case devoid of any true significance.

当然，即使就单一共同经验达成共识也可能是虚幻的，如果我们认可它，我们是基于对这种共同经验的性质的某些假设。但是，相互认可的科学专家通过相互依赖达成的共识，以及公众通过这群专家的一致判断而达成的进一步共识，意味着更深远的假设。科学家必须假设，各个科学领域是如此的连贯，以至于众多不同领域的专家所做工作的科学价值实际上可以用本质上相似的标准来评估；并且他们（科学家）能够并且将会跨越各自专业的界限，相互监督彼此的评估，以至于他们可以继续安全地相互信任——即使经过几代人的传承——在任何地方都应用这些相似的标准。此外，公众必须认同这些假设，才能对整个科学体系抱有信心（事实上公众确实如此），尽管公众对整个科学体系几乎一无所知，并且能够接受（我们希望公众能够接受）未来未见的言论，不仅是在世的科学家，甚至是他们的继任者，有朝一日将被当今的科学界认可为科学家。

Of course, even a consensus on a single common experience might be illusory, and if we accredit it, we do so on certain assumptions about the nature of this shared experience. But the consensus which mutually recognized scientific specialists achieve by relying on each other, and the further consensus of the public with the agreed judgment of this body of specialists, imply assumptions of a more far-reaching kind. Scientists must assume that the various domains of science are so coherent that the scientific value of work done by the several specialists within a multitude of separate provinces is in fact assessable by essentially similar standards; and that they (the scientists) can and will actually so supervise each other’s assessments across the boundaries of their particular specialities, that they may continue safely to trust each other—even through the passage of succeeding generations—to apply these similar standards everywhere. Moreover, the public must share these assumptions if it is to grant confidence—as it does—to the whole body of science, of which it hardly knows anything at all, and to accept unseen—as we may hope it will—the future pronouncements not only of living scientists, but even of those of their successors to be accredited one day as scientists by the scientific opinion of the day.

我们在此提出了一种文化理想的假设：一种高度分化、集体追求的智识生活的理想；或者更确切地说，一种文化精英在一个对其智识热情做出积极回应的社会中积极开展这种智识生活的理想。接受这些假设，在科学家群体中确立了一种相互信任的契约，也确立了整个社会致力于支持他们的科学追求。这种奉献精神体现在科学机构的建立中，这些机构旨在促进科学进步，并在科学观点的权威下，将其传播到全社会。任何完全属于该社会的人，都将分享其文化奉献精神以及构成这种奉献精神的各项假设。

We have here the assumptions of a cultural ideal: the ideal of a highly differentiated intellectual life pursued collectively; or more precisely, of a cultural élite actively conducting such an intellectual life within a society responsive to the intellectual passions of this élite. The acceptance of these assumptions seals a pact of mutual confidence within the community of scientists and seals the dedication of society as a whole to the support of their scientific pursuits. This dedication takes effect in the establishment of scientific institutions, set up for the advancement of science and for its dissemination throughout society under the authority of scientific opinion. Anyone who integrally belongs to the society in question will share thereby its cultural dedication and the assumptions which underlie this dedication.

我将这一科学共识与一群骗子或傻瓜似是而非的论调进行了对比，表明我认同这一共识背后的假设。我在阐述这些假设时，毫无保留地使用了“科学标准”和“科学价值观”等认可性术语，这本身就暗示了我认同我所描述的内容。我相信，在提及人们共同的信念和价值观时，这种默许是不可避免的，我将在稍后再谈这一点。同时，我要补充一点，在认同一个社会在科学发展中所共有的假设和热情的同时，我也在某种程度上支持了这个社会。任何认可一个社会所基于的信念的社会学，都构成了对这个社会的辩护。如果作者是该社会的成员，那么他的社会学就是对它的忠诚宣言。事实上，一致性要求在肯定社会共同价值观时，我们的宣言应该与我们参与基于这些肯定的假定有效性的任何社会活动​​相一致。247然而，正是这种一致性使得此类宣言的普遍意图令人怀疑，因为它表明，这些宣言实际上是在支持既得权力，而这些权力正是由它们所维护的社会灌输给我们的。由于上一节中概述的原因，这种困境将在公民思想领域更加尖锐地再次出现。

The contrast in which I have set this scientific consensus with the specious coherence of a company of frauds or fools has shown that I share the assumptions underlying this consensus. My unqualified use of accreditive terms like ‘scientific standards’ and ‘scientific values’ in formulating these assumptions had already implied that I subscribed to what I was describing. I believe that tacit endorsements of this kind are unavoidable in referring to beliefs and valuations which one shares, and I shall return to this fact later on. Meanwhile, let me add that in subscribing to the assumptions and passions shared by a society in the cultivation of science I also lend—to this extent—my support to such a society. Any sociology which accredits the beliefs on which a society is founded forms a justification of this society. And if the writer is a member of the society in question, his sociology is a declaration of loyalty to it. Indeed, consistency requires that in the affirmation of socially shared values our declarations should agree with our participation in any social activities based on the assumed validity of these affirmations.247 Yet it is precisely this consistency which renders the universal intent of such declarations suspect, since it shows that they lend support to established powers, after having been instilled in us by the very society which they vindicate. This dilemma will reappear—for reasons adumbrated in the previous section— even more acutely in the realm of civic thought.

与此同时，让我将我所说的关于科学培养的内容推广到其他类型的个人思想的培养，尽管按照本书的计划，我只能再次粗略地看一下这些思想领域。

Let me generalize meanwhile what I have said of the cultivation of science to the cultivation of other kinds of individual thought, though, conforming to the plan of this book, I can again cast only a cursory glance at these provinces of thought.

人文学科、艺术或各种宗教实践的管理，如同科学一样，都委托给一系列权威专家。这些专家的地位和权力，可能由制度确立，例如教会；也可能完全取决于其崇拜者和追随者对他们的尊重，例如诗人或画家。在所有这些领域，观点分歧远大于科学家之间的分歧。大多数西方国家都拥有不同的宗教团体。此外，除了宗教（但不排除神学）之外，我们时代的文化主要是一种对创新的崇拜。艺术与科学一样，在自我更新的过程中最为活跃；艺术与科学一样，名声源于创造力。但艺术的原创性通常比科学的原创性更需要全面的视角变革，因此，在寻求确立权威的创新者与先前确立的艺术领域的领导者之间，往往会产生更为明显的意见分歧。因此，在科学领域中，相互竞争的思想流派并不常见且转瞬即逝，但对于现代艺术的蓬勃发展却至关重要。当然，即便撇开这些不谈，艺术本身也并非、也永远不可能像科学那样系统地融为一体。因此，不同类型的艺术家之间不可能存在像科学专家群体那样清晰的分工，也不可能形成如此坚定的意见共识。

The administration of the humanities, the arts, or of the practice of various religions are all entrusted, like that of science, to a chain of authoritative specialists. The position and power of these may be institutionally established, as it is in the churches, or it may depend entirely on the respect in which they are held by their admirers and followers, as is the case with poets or painters. In all these domains there is much greater divergence of views than there is between scientists. Most countries of the Western type include different religious bodies. Moreover, apart from religion (but not excluding theology), the culture of our time is predominantly a cult of innovation. The arts, like the sciences, are most alive in the process of renewing themselves; fame is earned in the arts, as in science, by creativity. But artistic originality involves as a rule more comprehensive changes of outlook than does originality in science, and tends to produce therefore more pronounced divisions of opinion between the innovator seeking to establish his authority, and the leaders of previously established art. Accordingly, rival schools of thought, which in science are infrequent and transitory, are essential to a vigorous cultivation of modern art. And of course, even apart from this, the arts are not, and never can become, systematically coherent after the fashion of sciences. There can, therefore, exist no such clear division of labour between different kinds of artists, nor such firm consensus of opinion among them, as we have within the community of scientific specialists.

文化精英可能接受公共资助，也可能依赖私人收入。直到十九世纪初，学术研究和文学创作主要由富人从事，他们依靠私人收入生活。然而，如今文化精英中很少有人属于这一阶层，知识生活也相应地在更大程度上依赖于缺乏创造力的广大公民给予少数富有创造力者的物质支持。这就引出了一个问题：社会在支付文化活动费用时，是否履行了以富有创造力的领袖为标准来扩大其知识财富的义务，还是仅仅为了自身的娱乐或某些公民利益（例如对人民进行道德和政治教化）而雇佣这些人。

A cultural élite may be publicly subsidized or dependent on private earnings. Until the beginning of the nineteenth century scholarship and literary pursuits were largely the occupation of wealthy people, living on their private incomes. Today, however, few members of the cultural élite belong to that class and intellectual life depends correspondingly to a greater extent on the material support given to a creative minority by the mass of non-creative citizens. This raises the question whether, in paying for cultural pursuits, society is fulfilling an obligation to enlarge its intellectual possessions by the standards of its creative leaders, or is merely hiring these persons for the purpose of serving either its own amusement or some civic interest, like the moral and political edification of the people.

我们可以回顾一下关于科学进步的类似问题的答案（第183页）。任何不相信科学本身重要性的人，都不可能在科学领域做出任何重大发现；同样，任何缺乏科学价值观的社会，都不可能成功地培育科学。这同样适用于所有文化生活：一个社会只有在尊重优秀文化的范围内，才可以说拥有文化生活。与科学一样，这种欣赏很少能体现出第一手的判断。人文学科、艺术、各种宗教，都是广泛而高度分化的集合体，没有人能够完全理解和评判其中的一小部分。然而，我们每个人都尊重这些文化领域中更广阔的领域。例如，我知道但丁的《神曲》是一首伟大的诗歌，尽管我读过的内容很少；我尊重贝多芬的天才，尽管我几乎听不到音乐。这些都是真正的二手欣赏，其形成方式与科学家欣赏整个科学以及公众效仿的方式相同。此类间接的欣赏，正是社会整体滋养文化生活的根源。通过追随他们所选择的思想领袖，非专业人士甚至可以在一定程度上参与到这些领袖的创作中，并进一步参与到他们所认可的整个文化领域中。 248

We can reply to this by recalling our answer to the equivalent question in respect to the advancement of science (p. 183). No important discovery can be made in science by anyone who does not believe that science is important in itself, and likewise no society which has no sense for scientific values can cultivate science successfully. The same applies to all cultural life: a society may be said to have a cultural life only to the extent to which it respects cultural excellence. As in science, this appreciation can rarely be the expression of a first-hand judgment. The humanities, the arts, the various religions, are all extensive and highly differentiated aggregates of which no one can fully understand and judge more than a tiny fraction. Yet each of us respects very much larger areas of these cultural domains. I know for example that Dante’s Divine Comedy is a great poem though I have read very little of it, and I respect Beethoven’s genius though I am almost deaf to music. These are genuine second-hand appreciations, formed in the same way in which scientists appreciate the whole of science and in which the public follows suit. Indirect appreciations of this kind are, again, the roots through which society as a whole nurtures cultural life. By following their chosen intellectual leaders, the non-experts can even participate up to a point in the works of these leaders and beyond this in the whole range of culture accredited by them.248

原始社会的民间传说数量不达数百万卷，也无需不断创新。因此，他们的文化生活无需大批专家来管理，其中许多内容人人都能直接分享。通俗艺术和宗教生活在现代社会中也广为流传，但这只是现代文化的一小部分。因此，一个不接受权威人士文化指导的现代社会，会切断其与境内任何文化的联系。其庸俗之风，对原创思想充耳不闻，使其知识分子在本土无家可归。

The folklore of primitive societies does not run into millions of volumes and is not subject to continuous innovations. Hence their cultural life does not require a legion of experts to administer it and much of it can be shared at first hand by everybody. Popular art and religious life is shared also in modern societies, but this is a small part of modern culture. Therefore, a modern society which does not accept cultural guidance from a set of authoritative individuals cuts itself off from any culture living within its borders. Its philistinism, deaf to original thought, renders its intellectuals homeless in their own country.

在西方现代社会中，科学的权威通过教育体系牢固确立，但所有其他文化权威都必须争取公众的响应，并与强大的竞争对手争夺其地位。公众成员可能会从一位领导者转向他的对手；他们可能会从一位学者的阵营转向某位创新者的阵营，皈依宗教或放弃信仰，退出某个特定的运动并加入另一个运动。理智不允许这种转变过于频繁，即便如此，这种转变的范围也仅限于在潜在领导者之间进行选择。他们仍然将思想的指导权留给少数人，这些人被普遍接受并被奖励为某些公认文化领域的领导者。我们的社会可以说拥有一种单一的文化，只要我们的文化领导者能够和谐地相互补充；并且，就这一点而言，这些领导者可以说维护了我们社会的共同知识标准：无论是在他们自己的工作中，还是通过引导公众对文化的欣赏，以及要求社会履行其文化义务。

In the Western type of modern society the authority of science is firmly established through the educational system, but all other cultural authorities have to fight for public response and also contest their position against strong rivals. Members of the public may shift their allegiance from one leader to his opponent; they may change from the camp of an academician to that of some innovator, be converted to religion or abandon their faith, drop out of any particular movement and join another. Sanity forbids such shifts to be very frequent, and even so their scope is limited to choices between potential leaders. They still leave the guidance of thought to a small number of individuals, popularly accepted and rewarded as leaders of certain recognized cultural domains. Our society may be said to possess a single culture to the extent to which our cultural leaders harmoniously supplement each other; and to this extent these leaders may be said to uphold the common intellectual standards of our society: both in their own work and by guiding the public appreciation of culture and enjoining society to fulfil its cultural obligations.

由于不同哲学、宗教或艺术运动之间的冲突，某一信仰的追随者可能拒绝承认另一信仰者的任何智力价值，称其为怪人、骗子或傻瓜。因此，人们在使用“作曲家”、“诗人”、“画家”、“牧师”等专业称谓时，以及在称呼自称作曲家、诗人等人士时，使用“专家”、“声誉卓著”或“杰出”等认可性术语时，也会有所不同。然而，在一个多元化社会中，大多数竞争对手的领导者享有相同的地位，这一事实表明，在赋予他们中的大多数人一定的智力价值方面，存在着某种共识。这也意味着承认所有这些相互竞争的主张背后都存在着一种思维过程：一种始终遵循着不同标准的思维过程，这些标准虽然明显不同，但却源于共同的价值观和信仰传承。这种对连贯思维的自主过程的信念（就像在科学中一样）是社会培养思想的基本条件，由其自身的标准引导并由其自身的激情推动。

Owing to the clash between different philosophies, religious or artistic movements, adherents of one persuasion may refuse to recognize any intellectual merit in those of a rival persuasion, calling them cranks, frauds or fools. People will differ accordingly also in their use of such professional descriptions as ‘composer’, ‘poet’, ‘painter’, ‘priest’ and in that of accreditive terms like ‘expert’, ‘reputable’ or ‘distinguished’, applied to persons claiming to be composers, poets, etc. Yet the fact that most rival leaders share the same status in a pluralistic society demonstrates a measure of consensus in according some intellectual merit to most of them. This implies also the acknowledgment of a process of thought underlying all these rival affirmations: of a process guided throughout by standards which, though manifestly disparate, are descended from a common inheritance of values and beliefs. This belief in an autonomous process of coherent thought is (as in science) the fundamental condition for the social cultivation of thought, guided by its own standards and prompted by its own passions.

 

 

  1. 公民文化管理
  2. ADMINISTRATION OF CIVIC CULTURE

这些文化机构在自由社会中维系着个人思想的自由。我们可以借由这些机构的原则，将其延伸至公民思想的培养，从而将民选政府的理想传承下去。

Such are the cultural institutions which sustain the freedom of individual thought in a free society. From these institutions we can pass on to the ideal of popular government by extending their principles to the cultivation of civic thought.

自治机制赋予公民舆论以强制力，以便在必要时强制推行其认为正确的任何现有道德规范的改革。因此，如果有关公民事务的舆论能够以有效维护个人思想自由的相同原则形成，那么公民思想也将自由发展，其所拥有的力量将是自由思想的力量。这正是理想自由社会的景象。道德信念的形成和传播应该在知识领袖的指导下进行，这些领袖遍布数千个特殊领域，并在每一个环节上与竞争对手竞争，以争取公众的认同。 249

The machinery of self-government equips civic opinion with coercive powers to enforce, if necessary, any reforms of the existing mores that it holds to be right. If, therefore, opinion concerning civic matters is allowed to take shape by the same principles which effectively sustain the freedom of individual thought, civic thought will also grow freely and the power wielded by it will be the power of free thought. This is what would happen in an ideal free society. The shaping and dissemination of moral convictions should take place in it under the guidance of intellectual leaders, spread out over thousands of special domains and competing at every point with their rivals for the assent of the public.249

描述自由社会中道德、法律和政治观点不断重塑的制度框架，未免有些牵强。只需列举这一过程的部分成果即可。自从大约130年前社会改革原则获得广泛接受以来，这一过程彻底改变了自由国家的生活。刑法和监狱制度发生了深远的人性化，陆军和海军的纪律也同样如此，学校、收容所、医院和家庭内部也发生了同样的变化；《工厂法》以多种方式强制实施了更人道的就业条件；建立了新的福利机构，为病人、老年人、残疾人、失业者和贫民窟居民提供服务；免费教育极大地拓宽了贫困人口子女的前景；妇女、天主教徒、犹太人和殖民地人民的法律障碍被消除或至少大大减少；选举权的扩大和工会的承认，使权力的平衡向迄今为止处于从属地位的阶级倾斜。所有这些都是社会道德的进步，例如，在英国历史上，这些进步可以追溯到一系列呼吁公众良知的具体运动；这些运动通常首先由致力于倡导某项特定改革的有说服力的个人所引发。这就是现代自由社会的活力。它在于公民思想的道德进步，这种进步通过自治机制将其结论转化为社会改革行动。它是受自身激情驱动并由自身标准引导的智识过程的实际成果。

To describe the institutional framework within which moral, legal and political opinions are thus continuously re-moulded in a free society would lead us too far. Suffice it to give some of the results of this process, which has radically changed life in the free countries since the principles of social reform gained wider acceptance some 130 years ago. There has taken place a far reaching humanization of the criminal law and of the prison system, and similarly of discipline in the army and the navy, while the same changes have gone on in the schools, asylums, hospitals and within the family itself; the Factory Laws have enforced more humane conditions of employment in an immense variety of ways; new welfare institutions have been set up to provide for the sick and the aged, for the disabled, the unemployed and the slum dwellers; free education has greatly widened the prospects of poorer people’s children; the legal disabilities of women, of Catholics, Jews and of the colonial peoples have been removed or at least greatly reduced; the extension of the franchise and the recognition of Trade Unions have shifted the balance of power in favour of hitherto subordinate classes. All these were moral improvements of society which in England’s history, for example, can be traced back to a series of specific movements appealing to the public conscience; movements which had usually been evoked in the first place by persuasive individuals devoted to the advocacy of one particular reform. Such is the dynamism of the modern free society. It consists in the moral progress of civic thought, which transmits its conclusions, through the machinery of self-government, into acts of social reform. It is the practical outcome of an intellectual process, moved by its own passions and guided by its own standards.

自由社会的宪法表达了对这些激情和标准的认可。其政府预先遵从公民自由达成的道德共识，并非因为他们如此决定，而是因为他们被视为有能力做出正确的决定，是社会良知的真正代言人。我知道这与当前的法律实证主义相悖，后者拒绝以任何方式限定特定法律结构“基本规范”的最终权威。250因此，我要补充一点，法律改革实际上仅仅是社会改革的组成部分。新的强制性规则的制定是在自愿的非正式变革中进行的：交往方式、家庭习俗和道德规则的改变。此外，法律本身也通过新的司法解释进行非正式的变革；重要的新机构在私人层面建立，整个现存的契约关系网络以千百种方式自愿更新。251立法改革植根于这些更广泛的自愿、私人、非正式的社会变革之中，而新法律则旨在巩固这些变革，并为不断创新提供新的框架。毫无疑问，这些构成立法改革主导矩阵的更广泛的公民文化变革，是由一种思维过程所决定的，这种思维过程由其自身的标准引导，并由其自身的激情驱动。 252

The constitution of a free society expresses its acknowledgment of these passions and standards. Its government bows in advance to the moral consensus freely arrived at by its citizens, not because they so decide, but because they are deemed competent to decide rightly, as the authentic spokesman of the social conscience. I know that this runs counter to current legal positivism, which refuses to qualify in any way the ultimate authority of the ‘basic norm’ of a given legal structure.250 Let me add, therefore, that reforms of law are in fact merely components of social reform. The laying down of new coercive rules proceeds within a medium of voluntary informal changes: changes in manners of intercourse, in family customs, in moral rules. Moreover, the law itself is being changed informally through new judicial interpretations; great new institutions are founded privately and the whole network of existing contractual relations renewed voluntarily, in a thousand ways.251 Legislative reforms are embedded in these broader voluntary, private, informal modifications of society, which the new laws serve to consolidate and to provide with a new framework for ever new departures. There can be no doubt that these broader changes of civic culture, which form the dominant matrix of legislative reform, are determined by a process of thought guided by its own standards and prompted by its own passions.252

有人或许会反驳说，新法律的通过很少能获得一致通过，而且在整个社会中，公民价值观并不像科学价值观甚至艺术价值观那样得到普遍认同。但这种差异只是表面上的：不同意见的冲突在公民事务中或许更为明显，但即便如此，这种冲突也仅限于当代事务。过去150年里，英国推行的无数社会改革，如今很少会遭到任何重要少数派的否定。如果一个国家不能就其过去的公民成就达成如此程度的共识，那么它将处于潜在的内战状态，无法被认为拥有自由立法的权利。它的自治将是多数人的强制性统治。统治阶级或许仍会遵循持续的道德冲动，就像绝对统治者和独裁者有时所做的那样，但一个社会为了追求在其内部自由培育的公民美德而不断重塑自身生活的形象将不再适用。因此，我们可以认为，在理想的自由社会中，公民生活仅通过培养道德原则就会不断得到改善。

It might be objected that the passing of new laws is rarely unanimous, and also that in society at large civic values are not universally shared in the way in which scientific values or even artistic values are. But the difference is only superficial: the clash of contending opinions is perhaps more marked in civic matters, but even so it is restricted to contemporary affairs. Few of the innumerable social reforms carried out in Britain during the past 150 years would be repudiated today by any important minority. If a nation could not agree to this extent on its past civic achievements it would be in a state of latent civil war and could not be held to legislate freely for itself. Its self-government would be the coercive rule of a majority. The ruling class might still follow the guidance of a persistent moral impulse, as absolute rulers and dictators have sometimes done too, but the image of a society continuously re- shaping its own life in the pursuit of civic virtues freely fostered in its midst would no longer apply. We may take it, then, that in an ideal free society civic life would be continuously improved solely by the cultivation of moral principles.

 

 

9. 赤裸裸的权力

9. NAKED POWER

但让我们牢记权力与物质目的的真相。尽管人们能够和谐地遵循他们共同认同的信念，但他们仍然必须组建政府来执行他们的目标。公民文化的繁荣只能归功于物质强制。它源于腐败。面对这一事实，我们现在必须揭露我们道德信仰的不稳定性。

But let us remember the facts of power and material ends. Though men be harmoniously guided by their agreed convictions, they must yet form a government to enforce their purpose. Civic culture can flourish only thanks to physical coercion. It is sown in corruption. We must expose now the instability of our moral beliefs in face of this fact.

严格来说，或许没有人能够被强迫做任何事。在过去的战争和革命中，许多囚犯忍受着极其残酷的酷刑，坚定地拒绝泄露托付给他们的秘密，也拒绝对无辜者提供虚假证据。当一些人屈服于酷刑和“洗脑”的结合时，这可能意味着人格的强制改变，例如通过药物、脑外科手术或诱发神经症或精神病的治疗来实现——这种改变并非人类意志的本性所抗拒。然而，我们仍然必须承认，大多数人在足够严重的威胁下，都会被诱导屈服，并被迫服从命令：这种屈服可以被恰当地说成是被武力强迫的。

It may be that strictly speaking nobody can be forced to do anything. During the past wars and revolutions many prisoners have endured tortures of utmost cruelty, steadfastly refusing to betray secrets entrusted to them or to give false evidence against innocent persons. When some yielded to torture combined with ‘brainwashing’, this may have meant an enforced change of personality, such as is achieved by drugs, by brain surgery or by treatments which induce a neurosis or psychosis—a change which it is not in the nature of man’s will to resist. Yet we have to admit all the same that most men can be induced to bend their will and reluctantly to obey commands given under sufficiently serious threats: a yielding which may properly be said to be compelled by force.

事实上，所有带有某种威胁性而发布的命令，在某种程度上都具有强制性，法律也必须具有有效的强制性，否则，它们就会以牺牲守法者为代价，奖励违法者，从而造成不公正。虽然仅仅因为道德上的反对而强制执行法律并非不可想象，但我们无需考虑这种微不足道的可能性，尤其是因为它几乎不会改变我们的结论：强制在人类社会中既是可能的，也是不可或缺的。

Indeed, all commands issued with some kind of threat behind them are to this extent coercive, and laws must be effectively coercive, since otherwise they create injustices by rewarding the law-breakers at the expense of the law-abiders. While it is not inconceivable that laws may be enforced by mere moral disapproval, we need not consider such a remote possibility, particularly since it would hardly alter our conclusion that coercion is both possible and indispensable in human society.

人们普遍认为，如果没有一些自愿的支持，比如忠诚的禁卫军的支持，权力就无法行使。253我认为事实并非如此，因为似乎有些独裁者人人畏惧；例如，在他统治末期，人人畏惧斯大林。事实上，不难看出，一个人完全可以掌控众多人，而无需任何一个人给予明显的自愿支持。如果在一个群体中，每个人都相信所有其他人都会服从一个自称是他们共同上级的人的命令，那么所有人都会将此人视为他们的上级。因为每个人都担心，如果他不服从他，其他人会按照上级的命令惩罚他的不服从行为，因此，仅仅因为假设其他人会继续服从，所有人就被迫服从，而无需群体中的任何成员给予上级任何自愿的支持。该团体的每个成员甚至会感到有必要报告其同伴之间任何不满的迹象，因为他担心在他面前提出的任何抱怨都可能被密探对他进行试探，如果他不报告这些颠覆性的言论，他将受到惩罚。因此，该团体的成员可能会彼此不信任，以至于他们即使在私下里也只会对一个他们都暗中憎恨的上级表示忠诚。这种赤裸裸的权力随着其控制下的团体规模的扩大而增强，因为一个心怀不满的核心，即使由少数私人伙伴之间幸运地建立起相互信任而形成，也会被周围他们认为仍然忠于独裁者的广大民众所震慑和麻痹。因此，用一个幅员辽阔的国家的武力来维持控制，比用大洋中一艘船的船员来维持控制更容易。因此，散布其他地方已经爆发起义的谣言也是起义者的标准策略。

It is commonly assumed that power cannot be exercised without some voluntary support, as for example by a faithful praetorian guard.253 I do not think this is true, for it seems that some dictators were feared by everybody; for example, towards the end of his rule everyone feared Stalin. It is, in fact, easy to see that a single individual might well exercise command over a multitude of men without appreciable voluntary support on the part of any of them. If in a group of men each believes that all the others will obey the commands of a person claiming to be their common superior, all will obey this person as their superior. For each will fear that if he disobeyed him, the others would punish his disobedience at the superior’s command, and so all are forced to obey by the mere supposition of the others’ continued obedience, without any voluntary support being given to the superior by any member of the group. Each member of the group would even feel compelled to report any signs of dissatisfaction among his comrades, for he would fear that any complaint made in his presence might be a test applied to him by an agent provocateur and that he would be punished if he failed to report such subversive utterances. Thus the members of the group might be kept so distrustful of each other, that they would express even in private only sentiments of loyalty towards a superior whom they all hated in secret. The stability of such naked power increases with the size of the group under its control, for a disaffected nucleus which might be formed locally by a lucky crystallization of mutual trust among a small number of personal associates, would be overawed and paralysed by the vast surrounding masses of people whom they would assume to be still loyal to the dictator. Hence it is easier to keep control by force of a vast country than of the crew of a single ship in mid-ocean. And hence also it is the standard tactics of an insurrection to spread the rumour that insurrections have broken out already in other places.

这种赤裸裸的权力原则似乎毋庸置疑地真实有效。很难想象任何权力的行使能够完全摆脱此类因素的影响，而恐怖政权很可能主要依赖这一原则。同时，任何最高权力的持续行使都不可能仅仅依靠强制手段。因为任何统治者（理智的一面）都不会在心中没有某种公共目的的情况下继续指挥其臣民，他的臣民也不会在某种程度上接受其目的的情况下继续按照其命令生活，而且任何独裁者（除非疯癫）都不会放弃这种倾向于理性行为的倾向为其政权赢得的声望。事实上，我们可以预期，任何独裁者都会运用其强制权力，向臣民灌输对他的忠诚。因为如果每个人都能在某种程度上确信服从是正确的，而抵抗他的权力是错误的，那么初生的不满情绪就会因一种错误感而被抑制；即使它不顾一切地表现出来，其声音也可能仅仅因为社会非议的重压而噤声。对合法性的诉求是权力最强大的工具。即使是像希特勒和斯大林这样将赤裸裸的权力机制发挥到极致的人，也从未停止通过公开的自我辩护来补充它。 254

This principle of naked power seems indubitably real and effective. It is difficult to imagine any exercise of power that is quite free from a coefficient of this kind, and a regime of terror may well rely preponderantly on this principle. At the same time, no continued exercise of supreme power is likely to consist merely in coercion. For no ruler (this side of sanity) could go on commanding his subjects without some public purpose in mind, nor his subjects go on living by his orders without accepting this purpose to some extent, and no dictator (unless mad) would forgo the measure of popularity which such inclination towards rational conduct would gain for his regime. We may expect, in fact, that no dictator will fail to use his coercive powers for inculcating loyalty to himself in his subjects. For if everybody can be convinced to some extent that it is right to obey and wrong to resist his power, incipient disaffection will be discouraged by a sense of being wrong; and if it is manifested in spite of this, its voice may be silenced by the mere weight of social disapprobation. A claim to legitimacy is a most formidable instrument of power. Even men like Hitler and Stalin, who had perfected to the utmost the machinery of naked power, have never ceased to supplement it by a flow of public self-justification.254

自我辩护的尝试必然意味着在权力的行使过程中，接受一定程度的一致性，并遵循被统治者认为合理的规则和政策。规则看起来越合理，制定规则的政府就越有把握，但其决策范围也因此越受限制。事实上，任何赤裸裸的权力用来支持自身的论点——无论多么虚伪荒谬——都必然会认可其所依据的一些被广泛接受的原则。斯大林和希特勒的对话表明，尽管他们玩世不恭，但他们坚信其专制统治的正确性，而且，除了某些特定的叛国行为外，他们对世界的解读与他们自己宣传的并无太大区别。255

Attempts at self-justification will involve the acceptance of a measure of consistency in the wielding of power, according to rules and policies which might be regarded as reasonable by the governed. The more reasonable the rules appear to be, the more assured will be the government which imposed them, but also the more restricted will become in consequence the range of its decisions. Indeed, any argument—however mendacious and absurd—that naked power might invoke in its own support, necessarily accredits some widely acceptable principles on which the argument rests. The conversations of Stalin and Hitler reveal that, in spite of their cynicism, they were convinced of the rightness of their despotic rule and that, except while engaged in some specific piece of treachery, they interpreted the world in terms not very different from those used in their own propaganda.255

极权独裁统治下的人民或许痛恨他们的统治者。但只要这些统治者有效地阻碍了独立知识分子领导层的形成，即使普遍否定官方正统观念，也不会产生任何替代性的思想运动。结果，即使官方意识形态本身并不支持，人们也会经常自动地用它来解读当前的事件。极权主义已经清楚地表明，任何现代文化——无论是个人文化还是公民文化——都无法生存，除非依靠权威机构的运作。

People under totalitarian dictatorship may bitterly dislike their rulers. But so long as these effectively prevent the formation of an independent intellectual leadership, even a universal repudiation of the official orthodoxy will produce no alternative movement of thought. In consequence, official ideologies will frequently be used automatically by people for the current interpretation of events, even though they do not support these ideologies. Totalitarianism has clearly demonstrated that no modern culture—whether individual or civic—can survive, except by the operation of authoritative institutions.

 

 

  1. 强权政治
  2. POWER POLITICS

我们已经看到，即使公共权力最初建立在恐怖之上，它也必然会以劝说来补充其强制力，而且，为控制民众而培育的思想必然会在某种程度上支配统治者自身的行为。因此，将道德诉求滥用于不道德的目的，其结果似乎证实了道德内在的解放力量。但权力为了将道德用于其强制目的而付出的代价，却只能证明道德是权力不可或缺的盟友，尽管它任性地如此。这并不能证明道德能够按照其自身的原则控制权力；公民文化仍然依赖于武力和物质目的，因此仍然值得怀疑。自由社会的历史也未能消除这种怀疑。相反，我们看到，每一个新的道德问题都引发了利益冲突；道德进步常常不得不在被压迫者的压力下强加于特权阶层；现有的特权分配如何始终赋予其受益者相当大的权力，以抵制那些削弱其优势的改革，以及他们如何用武力延续不公。或许有人会争辩说（我稍后会回到这一点） ，由于任何单一的细节改革都必须依赖于现有的社会结构，如同依赖于其母体一样，这种结构及其固有的不公永远无法通过任何一系列零碎的改革得到根本改善。因此，我们仍然可能怀疑，任何社会的统治者，无论其自治程度如何，是否会遵守道德要求，超越欺骗其臣民（及其海外盟友）相信其道德宣言所需的程度。

We have seen that even though a public power were originally based on terror, it could not fail to supplement its coercive force by persuasion, and that the thoughts cultivated for the purpose of controlling their people would inevitably gain ascendancy also to some degree over the rulers’ own behaviour. Thus the abuse of a moral appeal for immoral purposes seems to confirm by its outcome the intrinsic liberating power of morality. But the restraint which power incurs as the price of employing morality for its own coercive purposes proves only that morality is an indispensable, though self-willed, ally to power. It does not demonstrate that morality can ever control power according to its own principles; civic culture still remains dependent on force and material ends, and remains therefore suspect. Nor does the history of free societies dispel this suspicion. We see, on the contrary, how every new moral issue has evoked a clash of interests; how often moral progress had to be forced upon the privileged by the pressure of the oppressed; how the existing distribution of privilege has always granted its beneficiaries considerable powers to resist reforms that curtail their advantage, and how they have perpetuated injustice by force. It may indeed be argued (and I shall return to this point later) that since any single reform of detail must rely on the existing social structure as on its matrix, this structure and any iniquities inherent in it can never be fundamentally improved by any series of piecemeal reforms. We may still doubt, therefore, whether the rulers of any society, however freely self-governed, will ever observe the claims of morality beyond what is needed in order to delude their subjects (and their allies abroad) to trust their professions of morality.

这种怀疑可以追溯到古代；在现代，它首先被马基雅维利重新提起。弗里德里希·迈内克在第一次世界大战结束时写道，从马基雅维利开始——通过一系列伟大的思想家——欧洲大陆的政治理论逐渐接受了公共权力必然不道德的观点，无论在国内统治还是在外交事务中。

This doubt goes back to antiquity; in modern times it was first revived by Machiavelli. Friedrich Meinecke, writing at the close of the First World War, traced from Machiavelli—through a series of great thinkers— the steadily growing acceptance by Continental political theory of the necessary immorality of public power, both in ruling at home and in the conduct of foreign affairs.

迈内克以此解读德国与其对手之间的意识形态冲突。他认为，德国之所以被指责不道德，只是因为它坦率地宣称强权即公理，而同样肆无忌惮的盎格鲁-撒克逊列强则继续在口头上宣扬道德。他们通过指责德国诚实地宣扬他们自己暗中遵循的权力政治原则，为自己获得了不公平的道德优势。迈内克将这种情况的根源追溯到德国思想对权力不可避免的罪恶性的认识，以及德国哲学通过将道德视为内在优越性崛起的内在因素来克服这种矛盾的大胆尝试。他承认，德国人被这种哲学的残酷化误导了，但他认为，盎格鲁-撒克逊人只是通过对其理论与实践之间的矛盾视而不见才避免了类似的结局。 256

Meinecke interprets the ideological conflict between Germany and her opponents in these terms. He thinks that Germany was accused of immorality only because she frankly declared that Might was Right, while the Anglo-Saxon powers, who acted no less unscrupulously, continued to pay lip-service to morality.
