If, then, it is not words that have meaning, but the speaker or listener who means something by them, let me declare accordingly my true position as the author of what I have written so far, as well as of what is still to follow. I must admit now that I did not start the present reconsideration of my beliefs with a clean slate of unbelief. Far from it. I started as a person intellectually fashioned by a particular idiom, acquired through my affiliation to a civilization that prevailed in the places where I had grown up. at this particular period of history. This has been the matrix of all my intellectual efforts. Within it 1 was to find my problem and seek the terms for its solution. All my amendments to these original terms will remain embedded in the system of my previous beliefs. Worse still, I cannot precisely say what these beliefs are. I can say nothing precisely. The words I have spoken and am yet to speak mean nothing: it is only/who mean something by them. And, as a rule, I do not focally know what I mean, and though I could explore my meaning up to a point, I believe that my words (descriptive words) must mean more than 1 shall ever know, if they are to mean anything at all.

这种前景听起来或许令人惋惜，但接受这种前景的纲领至少可以声称自己是自洽的，而任何将意义的严格性作为理想的哲学都是自相矛盾的。因为，如果哲学家积极参与其言辞的意义理解，被哲学家视为一种缺陷，阻碍了其获得客观有效性，那么它就必须根据这些标准自我否定。客观主义哲学的一致性也无法通过承认词语具有开放的结构来恢复。因为，正如我们所见（第113页），除非我们认可说话者的合适性，否则这些词语没有任何意义。因此，如果哲学家没有明确承认并认可其个人判断是其哲学不可分割的一部分，那么以“开放结构”来表达的哲学也毫无意义。

This prospect may sound deplorable, but a programme that accepts it may at least claim to be self-consistent, while any philosophy that sets up strictness of meaning as its ideal is self-contradictory. For if the active participation of the philosopher in meaning what he says is regarded by it as a defect which precludes the achievement of objective validity, it must reject itself by these standards. Nor is the consistency of an objectivist philosophy restored by confessing that words have an open texture. For such words, as we have seen (p. 113), have no meaning except through our accrediting of the speaker’s sense of fitness. Therefore, without the explicit acknowledgment and endorsement of the philosopher’s personal judgment as an integral part of his philosophy, a philosophy expressed in terms of ‘open texture’ is also meaningless.

非个人意义自相矛盾，而个人意义的辩护却自证其有理，只要它承认其自身的个人特征。它允许某些表达条件，这些条件在我们反思这一允许过程时必然会显现，但不能因此而使其无效，因为这些条件本身就应该在这种允许的光照下被接受。如果我同意，我自信地说出的每一个有意义的词，都是作为我个人的承诺而说出的，那么我也可以同意，用于表达这一陈述本身的词语，同样也被用来表达我自己的意思。因此，如果我只能从语言内部说话，我至少可以用与这种情况相符的方式来谈论我的语言。

While impersonal meaning is self-contradictory, the justification of personal meaning is self-justifying, if only it admits its own personal character. It licenses certain conditions of articulation which are bound to become apparent when we reflect on this process of licensing, but which cannot be held to invalidate it, since they should be acceptable in the very light of this licensing. If I agree that every word I confidently utter as meaningful is so uttered as a personal commitment of my own, then I may agree also that the words used for making this statement itself are similarly employed to mean what I myself mean by them. Thus if I cannot speak except from inside a language, I may at least speak of my language in a manner consistent with this situation.

但一致性是不够的。我的纲领中还必须保留一些意义。如果我一开始说话就认可了某个特定词汇的无限延伸的含义，而之后对这些含义的任何论证仍然必然要用我试图论证的那些习语来表达，那么我还能证明我所说的一切吗？我们似乎拯救了意义的概念，使其免于被非人格化所摧毁，却又使其沦为教条的主观性。

But consistency is not enough. There must also be some significance left in my programme. Can I ever justify saying anything at all, if the moment I start speaking I am accrediting the indefinitely ramified implications of a particular vocabulary, and any subsequent justification of these implications would still be necessarily couched in the very idioms which I seek to justify? It might seem that we have saved the concept of meaning from destruction by depersonalization, only to expose it to being reduced to the status of dogmatic subjectivity.

我必须暂时搁置我的探究。因为本节所描述的个人意义模式的论证，只能在稍后结合受托人断言模式中出现的相关问题进行尝试。

Here I must leave my enquiry temporarily suspended. For the justification of the personal mode of meaning as described in this section can be attempted only later, in conjunction with the kindred problems arising from the fiduciary mode of assertion.

 

 

  1. 事实断言
  2. ASSERTIONS OF FACT

丹尼斯·德·鲁日蒙曾说过，在动物中，唯有人类会撒谎。或许更准确的说法是，人类之所以能最有效地欺骗他人，是因为唯有人类才能对他人撒谎。所有可以想象到的事实断言，都可以是善意的，也可以是谎言的。在两种情况下，陈述的内容相同，但其隐含的成分不同。真实的陈述使说话者坚信自己所断言的内容：他带着这份信念踏上了一片蕴含无限含义的汪洋大海。不真实的陈述则抑制了这种信念，如同将一艘漏水的船推向大海，任由他人登上沉没。

Denis de Rougemont has remarked that man alone among animals can lie. It may be more accurate to say that man can deceive others most effectively, because he alone can tell them a falsehood. Every conceivable assertion of fact can be made in good faith or as a lie. The statement remains the same in both cases, but its tacit components are different. A truthful statement commits the speaker to a belief in what he has asserted: he embarks in it on an open sea of limitless implications. An untruthful statement withholds this belief, launching a leaking vessel for others to board and sink in it.

除非事实断言伴随着某种启发式或令人信服的感觉，否则它只是一种空洞的语言形式。任何试图通过制定或检验事实断言的精确规则来消除这种个人因素的尝试，从一开始就注定是徒劳的。因为我们只能从我们在掌握这些规则之前就已接受为真实的事实陈述的例子中推导出观察和验证的规则；最终，我们规则的应用必然会再次依赖于事实观察，而接受事实观察是一种个人判断的行为，不受任何明确规则的指导。此外，这些规则的应用必须始终依赖于我们自身个人判断的指导。这一论证正式确认了说话者在任何真诚的事实陈述中的参与。

Unless an assertion of fact is accompanied by some heuristic or persuasive feeling, it is a mere form of words saying nothing. Any attempt to eliminate this personal coefficient, by laying down precise rules for making or testing assertions of fact, is condemned to futility from the start. For we can derive rules of observation and verification only from examples of factual statements that we have accepted as true before we knew these rules; and in the end the application of our rules will necessarily fall back once more on factual observations, the acceptance of which is an act of personal judgment, unguided by any explicit rules. And besides, the application of such rules must rely all the time on the guidance of our own personal judgment. This argument formally confirms the participation of the speaker in any sincere statement of fact.

我们如何将这个系数纳入我们对真理的理解中？我们说一个事实陈述为真，究竟意味着什么？

How can we take this coefficient into account in our conception of the truth? What can we mean by saying that a factual statement is true?

清晰的断言由两部分组成：传达断言内容的句子和断言该句子的默认行为。278清晰断言可以通过分离其两部分并暂时取消断言行为来检验，同时将未断言的句子与经验进行对比。如果测试结果显示我们决定重新进行断言行为，则两部分将重新合并，句子将被重新断言。这种重新断言可以通过声明最初断言的句子为真来明确表达。

An articulate assertion is composed of two parts: a sentence conveying the content of what is asserted and a tacit act by which this sentence is asserted.278 The articulate assertion can be tested by separating its two parts and tentatively cancelling the act of assertion, while the unasserted sentence is being confronted with experience. If as a result of this test we decide to renew the act of assertion, the two parts are reunited and the sentence is reasserted. This reassertion may be made explicit by saying that the originally asserted sentence is true.

当然，断言行为本身并非由两部分组成——一部分是默示的，另一部分是表述的——其中，第一部分可以被取消，而第二部分（现在未被断言）可以通过与事实的对比来检验。它是一种默契理解的行为，完全依赖于执行者的自我满足。它可以被重复、改进或取消，但不能像事实陈述那样被检验或被说成是真的。

The act of assertion itself does not, of course, consist of two parts—one tacit, the other articulate—of which the first can be cancelled while the second, now unasserted, can be tested by confrontation with the facts. It is an act of tacit comprehension, which relies altogether on the self- satisfaction of the person who performs it. It can be repeated, improved or cancelled, but not tested or said to be true, in the sense in which a factual statement can be tested and said to be true.

因此，如果“ p为真”表达了我对句子p 的断言或重申，那么“ p为真”就不能像事实句子那样被说成是真或假。“ p为真”声明我将自己与事实句子p的内容等同起来，并且这种等同是我正在做的事情，而不是我正在观察到的事实。因此，表达式“ p为真”本身不是一个句子，而仅仅是（一个未断言的）句子，即句子p的断言。说“ p为真”就是承保承诺或签署接受书，其意义类似于此类行为的商业含义。因此，我们不能断言表达式“ p为真”，就像我们不能在自己的签名上签名一样；只能断言句子，而不能断言行为。

Therefore, if ‘p is true’ expresses my assertion or reassertion of the sentence p, then ‘p is true’ cannot be said to be true or false in the sense in which a factual sentence can. ‘p is true’ declares that I identify myself with the content of the factual sentence p, and this identification is something I am doing, and not a fact that I am observing. The expression ‘p is true’ is therefore not itself a sentence but merely the assertion of (an otherwise unasserted) sentence, the sentence p. To say that ‘p is true’ is to underwrite a commitment or to sign an acceptance, in a sense akin to the commercial meaning of such acts. Hence we cannot assert the expression ‘p is true’, any more than we can endorse our own signature; only a sentence can be asserted, not an action.

“ p为真”这一表达式的误导性形式，将一种承诺行为伪装成陈述事实的句子，从而导致逻辑悖论。如果句子p的断言必须紧接着说“ p为真”，而“ p为真”本身又是一个句子，那么这个句子就会引出它的后续结论“‘ p为真’为真”，如此循环往复，永无止境。如果我们意识到“ p为真”并非一个句子，这种永不满足的倒退就不会发生。

The misleading form of the expression ‘p is true’ which disguises an act of commitment in the form of a sentence stating a fact leads to logical paradoxes. If the assertion of the sentence p has to be followed up by saying ‘p is true’ and ‘p is true’ is itself a sentence, then this sentence brings in its sequel ‘“p is true” is true’ and so on, indefinitely. This insatiable regress does not arise, if we realize that ‘p is true’ is not a sentence.

说谎者悖论基于类似理由被排除。我们可以将这个悖论写成如下形式：“这本书第10页顶部的句子是假的”，其中“句子”一词表示（正如我们通过查找第10页顶部发现的那样）“这本书第10页顶部的句子是假的”。设p引用了刚才的句子；那么当且仅当这本书第10页顶部的句子为假时，p才为真，即当且仅当p为假时，p才为真。但如果“ p为假”仅仅表明说话者否认接受p ，那么“ p为假”就不是一个句子，悖论也不会出现，因为这样一来，在所讨论的这本书第10页顶部就找不到任何句子了。

The Paradox of the Liar is eliminated on similar grounds. We may write this paradox in the form: ‘the sentence on top of page 10 of this book is false’, in which the word ‘sentence’ designates (as we discover by looking up the top of page 10) ‘the sentence on top of page 10 of this book is false’. Denote the sentence just quoted by p; then p is true if and only if the sentence on top of page 10 of this book is false, i.e. p is true if and only if p is false. But if ‘p is false’ merely declares that the speaker denies acceptance to p, then ‘p is false’ is not a sentence and the paradox does not arise, for there is then no sentence to be found on top of page 10 of the book in question.

通过将“ p为真”和“ p为假”这两个表达式重新解释为一种断言或怀疑的行为，我们能够消除无限倒退和臭名昭著的自相矛盾，这一事实极大地强化了这种解释。通过概括我们对两种表达方式的区别：一种是出于主要目的而自信地使用语言，另一种是仅仅为了支持我们对所说内容的信心而使用的表达方式，一系列长期存在的哲学问题都可以被消除。 279

The fact that we can eliminate an infinite regress and a notorious self- contradiction, by reinterpreting the expressions ‘p is true’ and ‘p is false’ as expressing an act of assertion or doubt, substantially strengthens this interpretation. By generalizing our distinction between the confident use of language for primary purposes, and the class of expressions which merely endorse our confidence in what we have said, a whole range of persistent philosophic problems can be eliminated.279

 

 

  1. 迈向个人知识的认识论
  2. TOWARDS AN EPISTEMOLOGY OF PERSONAL KNOWLEDGE

我们已经将“真”一词重新定义为表达其所指句子的断言。这与塔斯基对“真”的定义非常相似，例如，塔斯基的定义意味着：“‘雪是白色的’为真当且仅当雪是白色的”。但塔斯基的定义现在似乎将句子等同于动作。可以通过将定义修改如下来消除这种异常：“当且仅当我相信雪是白色的，我才会说‘雪是白色的’为真”。或者可能更合理：“如果我相信雪是白色的，我就会说‘雪是白色的’为真”。诚然，这种表达方式表明在断言一个句子和说它是真的之间存在强调的区别：前者强调我们知识的个人特征，后者强调其普遍意图。但它们仍然是对该陈述的个人认可。

We have re-defined the word ‘true’ as expressing the asseveration of the sentence to which it refers. This is closely akin to Tarski’s definition of ‘true’ which implies, for example:’ ‘“snow is white” is true if and only if snow is white’. But Tarski’s definition now appears to equate a sentence with an action. This anomaly may be eliminated by revising the definition as follows: ‘I shall say that “snow is white” is true if and only if I believe that snow is white’. Or perhaps more reasonably: ‘lf I believe snow is white I shall say that “snow is white” is true’. This expression, admittedly, suggests a difference in emphasis between asserting a sentence and saying that it is true: the first stressing the personal character of our knowledge, the second its universal intent. But they both remain personal endorsements of the statement.

早些时候——在概率章节中280——我否定了用陈述事实的可能性来表达对事实陈述的信任行为的可能性。我建议，对句子的认可行为应该用弗雷格用作断言符号的前缀“”来书面表示，该前缀应该读作“我相信”，或读作某种等效的认可表达。这样的前缀不应充当动词，而应充当确定句子情态的符号。将事实断言转换为“受托人模式”将正确地反映这样一个事实，即这种断言必然归属于特定地点和时间的特定人：例如，在将断言写在纸上时归属于断言的作者，或者在读者阅读并接受所写内容时归属于读者。

Earlier on—in the chapter on Probability280—I have denied the ￼possibility of expressing the act of placing my confidence in a statement of fact by a statement of the probability of this fact. I suggested that the act of endorsing a sentence should be indicated in writing by the prefix ‘’ used by Frege as an assertion sign, which should be read as ‘I believe’, or as some equivalent expression of endorsement. Such a prefix should not function as a verb, but as a symbol determining the modality of the sentence. The transposition of an assertion of fact into the ‘fiduciary mode’ would correctly reflect the fact that such an assertion is necessarily attributable to a definite person at a particular place and time: for example, to the writer of the assertion at the moment of putting it to paper, or to the reader when he reads and accepts what is written.

这种转换极大地改变了我们解释事实断言的情境。只要我们赋予陈述句真或假的属性，我们就必须以解释绿叶为何呈绿色的方式解释这些属性。这种自言自语的句子似乎具有非个人的真或假性质，而这必须再次用非个人的标准来解释：这当然是不可能的。如果我们反过来问自己，为什么我们相信某些事实陈述，或者为什么我们相信某些类型的陈述，例如科学陈述，我们或许更有可能实现认识论反思的目的。因为既然认识到“非个人的指控”本身就是自相矛盾的——就像“匿名支票”一样——我们将不再试图为我们的指控找到任何不包含我们个人指控的论证。为我的科学信念辩护应该不太难，尤其是用我自己的一些逻辑上先行的信念来辩护，这种辩护本身再次被承认包含着我自己的信托行为。问题在于，这看起来很容易，以至于毫无意义。因为有人会反驳说“你可以相信你喜欢的”；这又一次把我们带回到自我设定标准的悖论；如果我所遵循的合理性标准最终是由我对这些标准的信心所支持的，那么辩护这些信念的整个过程可能看起来只是对我自身权威的徒劳授权。

This transposition considerably modifies the situation within which we have to account for making assertions of fact. So long as we ascribed to declaratory sentences the properties of being true or false, we had to account for these properties in the same sense as we would explain what makes green leaves green. Such self-speaking sentences appeared to possess the quality of being true or false impersonally, and this would have to be accounted for again in terms of impersonal criteria: which is of course impossible. We might have a better chance of achieving the purpose of epistemological reflection if we asked ourselves instead why we do believe certain statements of fact, or why we believe certain classes of statements, such as those of science. For having recognized that an ‘impersonal allegation’ is a contradiction in terms—just as an ‘anonymous cheque’ would be—we shall no longer try to arrive at any justification of our allegations which would not in its turn be composed of personal allegations of our own. It should not be too difficult to justify my scientific beliefs, in particular, in terms of some logically antecedent beliefs of my own, this justification itself being acknowledged once more to involve a fiduciary act of my own. The trouble is in fact that this may appear so easy as to be quite pointless. For it will be objected that ‘You can believe what you like’; which brings us back once more to the paradox of self-set standards; if the criteria of reasonableness, to which I subject my own beliefs, are ultimately upheld by my confidence in them, the whole process of justifying such beliefs may appear but a futile authorization of my own authority.

就这样吧。只有这种采用受托模式的方式本身才是一致的：必须承认这样做的决定本身就是一种受托行为。事实上，同样的道理也适用于整个研究以及由此得出的所有可能的结论。尽管我将继续论证一系列观点并为我提出的结论提供证据，但我始终希望大家理解，我的陈述最终肯定了我的个人信念，这些信念是通过文本中给出的考量，结合我自己其他无法具体说明的动机而得出的。我所说的任何内容都不应声称具有某种客观性，在我看来，任何推理都不应追求这种客观性；也就是说，它遵循一个严格的过程，阐释者对此过程的接受，以及他推荐他人接受此过程，都不含有任何个人的热情冲动。

Yet so be it. Only this manner of adopting the fiduciary mode is consonant with itself: the decision to do so must be admitted to be itself in the nature of a fiduciary act. Indeed, the same must apply to the whole of this enquiry and to all conceivable conclusions to be derived from it. While I shall continue to argue a series of points and adduce evidence for my proposed conclusions, I shall always wish it to be understood that in the last resort my statements affirm my personal beliefs, arrived at by the considerations given in the text in conjunction with other not specifiable motives of my own. Nothing that I shall say should claim the kind of objectivity to which in my belief no reasoning should ever aspire; namely that it proceeds by a strict process, the acceptance of which by the expositor, and his recommendation of which for acceptance by others, include no passionate impulse of his own.

我希望以后能巩固这个决定。与此同时，我还没有面临客观主义者试图将我们的智能思维过程非人格化所带来的其他困境。

I hope to consolidate this decision later. Meanwhile, I have yet to face some further dilemmas arising from the objectivist urge to depersonalize our intelligent mental processes.

 

 

  1. 推理
  2. INFERENCE

我们智力上优于动物几乎完全归功于我们符号运算的能力；唯有依靠这些能力，我们才能进行任何连续推理。难怪致力于非人格化思维理想的运动始终致力于将人类智慧的这一核心机构简化为受严格规则约束的运作。近年来，用于各种复杂用途的高效自动化装置的出现，进一步增强了这种希望。高射炮配备了由炮手初始读数自动控制的预测器。一旦瞄准器对准目标，机器就会计算快速移动目标的轨迹以及准备发射的炮弹的轨迹，并进行瞄准以确保命中。随之而来的是自动驾驶仪和制导导弹的出现，以及办公室和工厂工作的全面自动化。这些仪器无需任何人工干预就能完成复杂的智能任务。这显然为实现完全超脱思维的理想提供了新的前景。

Our intellectual superiority over the animals is almost entirely due to our powers of symbolic operations; it is only by relying on these that we are able to carry out any process of consecutive reasoning. No wonder then that the movement bent on the ideal of impersonal thought has consistently aimed at reducing this central agency of human intelligence to operations governed by strict rules. This hope was recently heightened by the construction of highly effective automatic devices for various complex purposes. Anti-aircraft guns were equipped with predictors automatically governed by the gunner’s initial readings. Once the sights were set on a plane, the machines computed the course of the swiftly moving target, as well as that of the projectile ready to be sent out, and aimed the gun so as to assure a hit. There followed the construction of automatic pilots and of guided missiles, and the comprehensive automation of work in office and factory. Here were instruments carrying out complex feats of intelligence without any intervention of man. This clearly offered new prospects for attaining the ideal of completely detached thought.

由于我已经谈到（并且稍后还会谈到）形式化经验推理过程的不可能性，因此我在这里只讨论将演绎推理过程非个人化的尝试。

Since I have spoken already (and shall yet say more later) of the impossibility of formalizing the process of empirical inference, I shall deal here only with the attempt to depersonalize the process of deductive inference.

我们之前已经看到，演绎推理可能完全无法言喻，即使是最完全形式化的逻辑运算也必然包含一个非形式化的隐性系数。我们已经看到，这种系数的热情力量如何激发发现，激起争论，并支持学生努力理解所学内容；我们也看到，不同领域的数学家们也拥有同样的热情，以至于他们始终遵循共同的标准，并通过专业共识将这些标准相互推行。下文中，我将仅以简短的形式术语来提及这些隐性系数在演绎科学中广泛分布的运算。通过简明扼要地描述这整个个人承诺的集合，我将使我的论证具有足够的严谨性，以承载我即将赋予它的重担。

We have seen before that deductive reasoning may be altogether ineffable and that even the most completely formalized logical operations must include an unformalized tacit coefficient. We have seen how the passionate force of this coefficient actuates discovery, inflames controversy, and sustains the student’s efforts to understand what he is being taught; we have seen how these passions are shared between mathematicians working in different fields, so that they will always be guided by common standards which they enforce on each other by their professional consensus. I shall refer in the following to the widely ramified operations of these tacit coefficients in the deductive sciences only in brief formal terms. By compendiously designating this whole aggregate of personal commitments, I shall lend to my argument sufficient rigidity for carrying the burden I shall presently place upon it.

数字计算机作为逻辑推理机器的操作与符号逻辑的操作相一致。因此，我们可以将以这种特殊方式运作的机器的构造和使用中所涉及的形式化，与构建演绎系统的程序联系起来。该程序包含三个方面：（1）它指定未定义的术语；（2）它指定未经证实的断言公式（公理）；（3）它规定了这些公式的处理方式，以便写下新的断言公式（证明）。这一结果是通过持续努力消除所谓的“心理”因素——我称之为“隐性”的因素——而实现的。未定义的术语旨在不带任何意义，本身就像纸上的标记一样完整；未经证实的断言公式旨在取代被认为是不证自明的陈述；构成“形式证明”的操作同样旨在取代“纯粹的心理”证明。

The operations of digital computers as machines of logical inference coincide with the operations of symbolic logic. We may therefore identify the formalization involved in the construction and the use of machines, operating in this particular way, with the procedure governing the construction of a deductive system. This procedure is threefold. (1) It designates undefined terms; (2) it specifies unproven asserted formulae (axioms); and (3) it prescribes the handling of such formulae for the purpose of writing down new asserted formulae (proofs). This result is achieved by a sustained effort to eliminate what are called ‘psychological’ elements—the factors which I call ‘tacit’. The undefined terms are intended to stand without signifying anything, complete in themselves as marks on paper; unproven asserted formulae are to replace statements believed to be self-evident; operations constituting ‘formal proof’ are similarly intended to replace ‘merely psychological’ proof.

然而，这种试图消除逻辑学家个人参与的尝试必然会在每一点上留下不可简化的心理操作残余，形式化系统本身的运作将继续依赖于这些残余。（1）接受纸上的标记作为符号意味着：（a）我们相信我们能够在各种情况下识别该标记；（b）我们知道其正确的符号用法。在这两种信念中，我们都可能是错误的，因此它们构成了我们自己的承诺。（2）在同意将符号集合视为公式时，我们接受它作为可以断言的东西。这意味着我们相信这样的集合能够说明某些事情。我们期望识别出满足公式的事物，以区别于不满足公式的其他事物。由于满足我们公理的过程必然是非形式化的，因此我们对这一过程的认可就构成了我们的一种承诺行为。 （3）按照机械规则处理符号不能被称为证明，除非它包含这样的信念：任何满足运算起始公理的事物也必然满足所得出的定理。任何我们拒绝承认其成功证明蕴涵的符号处理都不能被称为证明。而且，这种证明是一个非形式化的过程，它构成了一种承诺。

However, this attempt to eliminate the personal participation of the logician must leave at each of these points an irreducible residue of mental operations, on which the operations of the formalized system itself will continue to rely. (1) The acceptance of a mark on paper as a symbol implies that (a) we believe that we can identify the mark in various instances of it and (b) that we know its proper symbolic use. In both these beliefs we may be mistaken, and they constitute therefore commitments of our own. (2) In agreeing to regard an aggregate of symbols as a formula, we accept it as something that can be asserted. This implies that we believe that such an aggregate says something about something. We expect to recognize things which satisfy a formula, as distinct from other things which fail to do so. Since the process by which our axioms will be satisfied is necessarily left unformalized, our countenancing of this process constitutes an act of commitment on our part. (3) The handling of symbols according to mechanical rules cannot be said to be a proof, unless it carries the conviction that whatever satisfies the axioms from which the operation starts will also satisfy the theorems arrived at. No handling of symbols to which we refuse to award the success of having convinced us that an implication has been demonstrated can be said to be a proof. And again, this award is an unformalized process which constitutes a commitment.

因此，在许多情况下，一个由符号和运算组成的形式系统，可以说只有凭借系统操作者所认可的非形式化补充，才能发挥演绎系统的功能：符号必须可识别且其含义为人所知，公理必须被理解才能断言某事，证明必须被承认才能论证某事，而这种识别、认识、理解和承认，都是形式系统运作所依赖的非形式化操作。我们可以将它们称为形式系统的语义功能。当人们依赖于形式系统的使用时，这些功能由人们借助形式系统来实现。281

Thus, at a number of points, a formal system of symbols and operations can be said to function as a deductive system only by virtue of unformalized supplements, to which the operator of the system accedes: symbols must be identifiable and their meaning known, axioms must be understood to assert something, proofs must be acknowledged to demonstrate something, and this identifying, knowing, understanding, acknowledging, are unformalized operations on which the working of a formal system depends. We may call them the semantic functions of the formal system. These are performed by a person with the aid of the formal system, when the person relies on its use.281

确实，说逻辑推理机能够自行推理，这在逻辑上是荒谬的。推理机本身仅仅是一台“推理机”，只能进行“推理”。省略引号表明我们认可该机器，并因此接受其运算得出的结论是我们自己的推理。形式化的合理目的在于将隐性系数降低到更有限、更明显的非正式操作；但旨在完全消除我们的个人参与则是荒谬的。

It is, indeed, logically absurd to say of a logical inference machine that it draws inferences of its own. By itself an inference machine is merely an ‘inference machine’ and can only draw ‘inferences’. The omission of the quotation marks expresses our accrediting of the machine, and hence our acceptance of the conclusions arrived at by its operations, as our own inferences. The legitimate purpose of formalization lies in the reduction of the tacit coefficient to more limited and obvious informal operations; but it is nonsensical to aim at the total elimination of our personal participation.

这一结论以这种一般形式适用于所有类型的自动机制。目前，它只能针对逻辑推理过程和执行逻辑推理的机器进行精确阐述；但这也将对用于智能目的的任何类型自动机制的逻辑分析具有指导意义。限制逻辑思维形式化的最重要定理归功于哥德尔。这些定理基于这样一个事实：在任何包含算术的演绎系统（例如《数学原理》系统）中，都有可能构造公式（即句子），这些公式在该系统内可证明为不可判定的，并且这样的句子（著名的哥德尔句子）可以说它在该系统中是不可判定的。然后，我们可以进一步将句子与其所处的情境（即其自身不可判定性的证明）非正式地匹配。现在我们将发现句子所说的内容为真，并据此决定在这种意义上断言它。因此，断言的句子代表一个附加公理，它独立于未断言的句子所衍生的公理。 282

This conclusion will be found applicable in this general form to all kinds of automatic mechanisms. It can be precisely elaborated for the time being only for the process of logical inferences and for machines carrying out logical inferences; but this will prove instructive also for the logical analysis of any kind of automatic machinery used for intelligent purposes. The most important theorems limiting the formalization of logical thought are due to Gödel. They are based on the fact that within any deductive system which includes arithmetic (such as for example the system of Principia Mathematica) it is possible to construct formulae—i.e. sentences—which are demonstrably undecidable within that system, and that such a sentence—the famous Gödelian sentence—may say of itself that it is undecidable within the system. We can then go further by informally matching the sentence with the situation on which it bears, that is, with the demonstration of its own undecidability. We shall now find that what the sentence says is true and decide accordingly to assert it in that sense. Thus asserted, the sentence represents an additional axiom, which is independent of the axioms from which the unasserted sentence was derived.282

这一过程揭示了任何（足够丰富的）形式系统必然是不完备的，而我们的个人判断可以可靠地为其添加新的公理。它为演绎科学提供了一个概念创新的模型，从原则上说明了数学启发法的无穷无尽性，以及持续利用这些可能性的行为所具有的个人性和不可逆性。

This process reveals both that any formal system (of sufficient richness) is necessarily incomplete and that our personal judgment can reliably add new axioms to it. It offers a model of conceptual innovation in the deductive sciences, which illustrates in principle the inexhaustibility of mathematical heuristics and also the personal and irreversible character of the acts which continue to draw upon these possibilities.

哥德尔还证明，可证明不可判定的句子可能会说，该系统的公理无法被证明是一致的。这表明（正如我之前提到的），我们永远无法完全了解我们的公理的含义，因为如果我们知道，我们就可以避免在一个公理中断言另一个公理所否定的东西的可能性。对于任何特定的演绎系统，这种不确定性可以通过将其转移到更广泛的公理系统中来消除，在这个系统中，我们或许能够证明原始系统的一致性。但任何这样的证明仍然是不确定的，因为更广泛的系统的一致性始终是不可判定的。

Gödel has also shown that the sentence which is demonstrably undecidable may say that the axioms of the system cannot be proved to be consistent. This shows (as I have mentioned before) that we never know altogether what our axioms mean, since if we knew, we could avoid the possibility of asserting in one axiom what another axiom denies. This uncertainty can be eliminated for any particular deductive system by shifting it unto a wider system of axioms, within which we may be able to prove the consistency of the original system. But any such proof will still remain uncertain, in the sense that the consistency of the wider system will always remain undecidable.

塔斯基通过一个与哥德尔定理证明极其相似的逻辑论证，证明了：任何形式系统，如果我们可以在其中断言一个句子，同时又能反思其断言的真实性，那么它必然是自相矛盾的。因此，具体而言，断言“给定形式语言的任何定理为真”，只能由一个在该语言中无意义的句子来做出。这样的断言构成了一种比它所断言的句子所构成的语言更丰富的语言。 283

In a logical demonstration closely akin to the proof of Gödel’s theorems, Tarski has shown that any formal system in which we could assert a sentence and also reflect on the truth of its assertion must be self- contradictory. Thus, in particular, the assertion that any theorem of a given formal language is true, can be made only by a sentence that is meaningless within that language. Such an assertion forms part of a richer language than that which comprises the sentences whose truth it asserts.283

哥德尔句子的构造表明，演绎推理过程可以产生一种情境，这种情境不可抗拒地暗示出一个在其前提中并未正式隐含的断言。塔斯基定理认为，真值断言属于一种逻辑上比被断言为真的句子的（形式）语言更丰富的（形式）语言，这表明，先前断言的句子是否为真的问题引发了类似的扩展。在这两种情况下，这种扩展都源于对已述内容的反思。在哥德尔过程中，我们在一个形式上未决的陈述中添加了我们自己默认的解释。创新行为在于认识到我们刚刚所说的话在这个新的意义上是正确的。塔斯基过程基于断言句子的“二元性”；形式创新源于我们能够质疑迄今为止默认的同意，并以明确的措辞重申我们的同意。在这两个过程中，我们都通过自己不可避免的行为建立了一些新的东西，这种行为是由正式操作引发的（但不是由正式操作执行的）。

The construction of the Gödelian sentence shows that a process of deductive inference can produce a situation which irresistibly suggests an assertion not formally implied in its premisses. Tarski’s theorem that the assertion of truth belongs to a logically richer (formal) language than the (formal) language of the sentences asserted to be true, shows that the question whether a previously asserted sentence is true evokes a similar expansion. It arises in both cases from a reflection on what has been said. In the Gödelian process we add to a formally undecided statement of ours a tacit interpretation of our own. The act of innovation consists here in realizing that what we had just said was true in this new sense. The Tarski process is based on the ‘duality’ of asserted sentences; the formal innovation being due here to our capacity for calling in question a hitherto tacit assent of ours and renewing our assent in explicit terms. In both processes we establish something new by an inescapable act of our own, induced—but not performed—by formal operations.

我之前（第二部分，第五章，第131页）描述过数学家如何通过将其信心从直觉转向计算，再从计算转向直觉，从而逐步实现发现，同时始终保持对两者的掌控。这些转变通常是渐进的。哥德尔语句与其所指事实的匹配，以及随后对哥德尔语句的重申，共同决定了隐性思维接管控制权并跨越逻辑鸿沟的精确点。284

I have described before (Part Two, ch. 5, p. 131) how the mathematician works his way towards discovery, by shifting his confidence from intuition to computation, and back again from computation to intuition, while never releasing his hold on either of the two. These shifts are usually gradual. The matching of the Gödelian sentence with the facts to which it refers and the subsequent reassertion of the Gödelian sentence, determine jointly a precise point at which tacit thought takes over control for the crossing of a logical gap.284

我们发现，在庞加莱视为所有数学创新原型的“数学归纳法”中也存在类似的交替。285它首先证明一系列适用于连续整数的定理，每个连续定理都由前一个定理推导而来，并由此得出结论：该定理对所有数普遍成立。为了得出这样的推论，思维必须回顾一系列证明，并概括自身过去运算的原理。在第二部分第六章（第185页）中，我引用了达瓦尔和吉尔博的论述，阐述了连续性概念是如何通过这种反思过程发现的。

We find a similar alternation involved in the method of ‘mathematical induction’ which Poincaré regarded as the prototype of all mathematical innovations.285 It starts by proving a series of theorems which apply to successive whole numbers, each consecutive theorem being derived from the previous one, and proceeds to conclude hence that the theorem is true generally for all numbers. To draw such inferences the mind must look back upon a series of demonstrations and generalize the principle of its own past operations. In Part Two, ch. 6 (p. 185) I have quoted an account by Daval and Guilbaud, showing how the conception of continuity was discovered by such a process of reflection.

哥德尔式的创新过程与庞加莱所概述的发现语法之间的相似性，佐证了非正式的断言行为与同样非正式的发现行为之间的连续性。两者的区别在于所跨越的逻辑鸿沟的宽度。重申哥德尔式的语句时，需要跨越的鸿沟极其狭窄——几乎难以察觉——而在真正的发现行为中，它可能是任何人类思维都无法企及的。再次证明，同意行为与发现行为在逻辑上相似：它们本质上都是非形式化的、直觉性的心理决策。

The analogy between the Gödelian process of innovation and the grammar of discovery outlined by Poincaré lends support to the continuity between the informal act of assertion and the equally informal act of discovery. The difference between the two lies in the width of the logical gap that is being crossed. The gap to be crossed for the reassertion of the Gödelian sentence is extremely narrow—almost imperceptible—while in true acts of discovery it may be as large as any human mind can hope to overcome. The act of assent proves once more to be logically akin to the act of discovery: they are both essentially unformalizable, intuitive mental decisions.

 

 

  1. 自动化概述
  2. AUTOMATION IN GENERAL

哥德尔发现的大量公理提供了明显的证据，证明操作逻辑推理机的人可以非正式地获得一系列知识，而这些知识是任何逻辑推理机都无法展现的，即使逻辑推理机的操作表明人们很容易获得这些知识。这证明了思维能力超越了逻辑推理机。但我们尚未面对由瞄准器预测器、自动驾驶仪等引发的更广泛的问题，也就是说，这些机器的性能远远超出了逻辑推理的范围。A.M. 图灵已经证明286设计一台机器，既能构造出一系列不确定的哥德尔语句，又能将其断言为新的公理，这是可能的。任何常规的启发式过程——在演绎科学中，哥德尔过程就是一个例子——都可以自动执行。机器可以自动进行常规的国际象棋比赛，事实上，所有艺术都可以在规则可指定的范围内自动进行。虽然这种规则可能包含随机元素，例如通过旋转硬币做出的选择，但任何不可指定的技能或鉴赏力都不能被输入到机器中。

The proliferation of axioms discovered by Gödel offers manifest proof that a person operating a logical inference machine can achieve informally a range of knowledge which no operations of such a machine can demonstrate, even though its operations suggest an easy access to it. It proves that the powers of the mind exceed those of a logical inference machine. But we have yet to face the wider problem raised by gunsight predictors, automatic pilots, etc., that is, by machines whose performances range far beyond logical inferences. A.M. Turing has shown286 that it is possible to devise a machine which will both construct and assert as new axioms an indefinite sequence of Gödelian sentences. Any heuristic process of a routine character—for which in the deductive sciences the Gödelian process is an example—could likewise be carried out automatically. A routine game of chess can be played automatically by a machine, and indeed, all arts can be performed automatically to the extent to which the rules of the art can be specified. While such a specification may include random elements, like choices made by spinning a coin, no unspecifiable skill or connoisseurship can be fed into a machine.

我们无法用适用于逻辑推理机的那些形式标准来界定一般自动操作的范围。然而，机器与人之间必然的关联性，确实从根本上限制了机器的独立性，并使一般自动机的地位低于会思考的人。因为只有当一个人（实际上或假设地）依赖机器来实现某种目的时，机器才是机器，而这个人相信，通过他认为机器的正常运作，这种目的就可以实现：机器是依赖它的人的工具。这就是机器与心智的区别。人的心智可以借助机器完成智力任务，也可以在没有机器帮助的情况下完成，而机器只能作为人身体的延伸，在心智的控制下运作。因此，机器只能在三部分系统中作为机器存在。

We shall not be able to circumscribe the scope of automatic operations in general by such formal criteria as apply to logical inference machines. Yet the necessary relatedness of machines to persons does essentially restrict the independence of a machine and reduce the status of automata in general below that of thinking persons. For a machine is a machine only for someone who relies on it (actually or hypothetically) for some purpose, that he believes to be attainable by what he considers to be the proper functioning of the machine: it is the instrument of a person who relies on it. This is the difference between machine and mind. A man’s mind can carry out feats of intelligence by aid of a machine and also without such aid, while a machine can function only as the extension of a person’s body under the control of his mind. Accordingly, the machine can exist as a machine only within a tripartite system

我 二 三

I II III

头脑 机器 心灵所怀有的功能、目的等。

mind machine functions, purposes etc. entertained by the mind.

由于用户的思维对机器的控制——就像对一套严格规则的所有解释一样——必然是无法指定的，因此可以说机器只有在用户的思维提供的无法指定的个人系数的帮助下才能智能地运行。

Since the control exercised over the machine by the user’s mind is—like all interpretations of a system of strict rules—necessarily unspecifiable, the machine can be said to function intelligently only by aid of unspecifiable personal coefficients supplied by the user’s mind.

 

 

  1. 神经病学和心理学
  2. NEUROLOGY AND PSYCHOLOGY

神经病学基于这样的假设：神经系统——根据已知的物理和化学定律自动运作——决定了我们通常认为的个体思维的所有运作方式。心理学研究也表现出类似的趋势，即将其研究对象简化为可测量变量之间的明确关系；而这些关系总是可以通过机械制品的性能来表征。

Neurology is based on the assumption that the nervous system— functioning automatically according to the known laws of physics and chemistry—determines all the workings which we normally attribute to the mind of an individual. The study of psychology shows a parallel tendency towards reducing its subject matter to explicit relationships between measurable variables; relationships which could always be represented by the performances of a mechanical artefact.

这就引出了一个问题：鉴于对“正在使用的机器”的逻辑分析，我们是否可以接受一个神经模型（或类似的心理模型）作为个体心智的表征。在回答这个问题时，我们必须考虑到自动神经模型与为智能目的而操作的机器之间的一个明显区别；即，神经模型不应为神经学家的目的而运行，而应为神经学家代表其所代表的主体心智而赋予其操作的目的。因此，三部分系统如下：

This raises the question whether in view of the logical analysis of ‘a machine in use’ we can accept a neurological model (or an analogous psychological model) as the representation of an individual’s mind. In answering this question we must take into account an obvious difference between an automatic neurological model and a machine operated for intelligent purposes; namely, that the neurological model is not supposed to operate for purposes of the neurologist, but for purposes attributed to its operations by the neurologist on behalf of the subject whose mind it represents. The tripartite system accordingly becomes:

我 二 三

I II III

 

 

心灵（的

Mind (of

神经科医生

neurologist)

 

 

受试者的神经模型

Neurological model of subject

 

 

神经病学家赋予该主题的智力目的。

Intellectual purposes attributed to the subject by the neurologist.

 

 

但第三部分简要提到的非正式心理功能指的是神经学家的心理功能，因为主体心理的非正式（因而是个人的）功能实际上在三部分系统中根本没有体现。因为神经学模型就像一台机器，完全是非个人化的，无法解释主体任何无法具体说明的倾向。

But the informal mental functions briefly indicated under III are those of the neurologist’s mind, since the informal, and hence personal, functions of the subject’s mind are in fact not represented at all in the tripartite system. For the neurological model is—like a machine—strictly impersonal and can account for none of the unspecifiable propensities of the subject.

这些个人能力包括理解意义的能力、相信事实陈述的能力、根据目的解释机制的能力，以及更高层次上反思问题并运用独创性解决问题的能力。事实上，它们包括通过个人判断得出结论的各种方式。神经学家在构建人类神经模型时，最大限度地运用了这些能力——而他本人也正是在构建模型的过程中，否认了人类拥有任何类似的能力。心理学家也是如此，他将人类的精神表现简化为可测量的量的关系，因为这些量的关系总是可以通过机器人的行为来体现。

These personal powers include the capacity for understanding a meaning, for believing a factual statement, for interpreting a mechanism in relation to its purpose, and on a higher level, for reflecting on problems and exercising originality in solving them. They include, indeed, every manner of reaching convictions by an act of personal judgment. The neurologist exercises these powers to the highest degree in constructing the neurological model of a man—to whom he denies in this very act any similar powers. The same is true of a psychologist who reduces the mental manifestations of man to specifiable relations of measured quantities, for as such these can always be represented by the performances of a robot.

只要观察者只关注对象的自动反应，那么解读心智自信地运用其能力，却拒绝被解读对象拥有这些能力，这种差异就合情合理。当生理学家记录一个人的反应时，他理所当然地宣称自己拥有判断力，而他所考察的另一个人的能力却缺乏这些判断力。正如精神疾病剥夺了患者对自身思维的控制力一样，精神科医生也会从他对对象的优越视角来观察相关的病理机制。

This disparity between the powers which the interpreting mind is confidently exercising in the very act of denying them to the subject interpreted by it, is justified, so long as the observer is concerned only with the automatic responses of his subject. When a physiologist records the reflexes of a person, he is rightly claiming for himself powers of judgment which are absent in the faculties he is examining in another person. To the extent to which mental illness deprives those suffering from it of control over their thoughts, a psychiatrist will also observe the pathological mechanism in question from the superior position assumed by him towards his subject.

相反，承认某人是神志健全的人就是与他建立一种互惠关系。凭借我们自身的理解能力，我们将他人的类似能力体验为该人心智的存在。我们聚焦或辅助性地认识事物的能力在此起着决定性作用。心智并非其聚焦性已知表现的总和，而是我们在辅助性地意识到其表现的同时将注意力集中于其上的东西。这是我们承认一个人的判断并分享其其他意识形式的方式（将在第四部分进一步分析）。这种认识一个人的方式使他完全具备心智控制的三部分系统中位置 I 的功能；而他聚焦性已知表现的总和并不能使他具备这些功能。

By contrast, to acknowledge someone as a sane person is to establish a reciprocal relation to him. By virtue of our own art of comprehension we experience another person’s similar faculties as the presence of that person’s mind. Our capacity for knowing things either focally or subsidiarily is decisive here. Mind is not the aggregate of its focally known manifestations, but is that on which we focus our attention while being subsidiarily aware of its manifestations. This is the way (to be analysed further in Part Four) by which we acknowledge a person’s judgment and share also other forms of his consciousness. This manner of knowing a person qualifies him fully for the functions of a mind in position I of a tripartite system controlled by a mind; while the aggregate of his focally known manifestations do not qualify him for these functions.

根据这些关于“心智”和“人”的定义，无论是机器、神经模型，还是类似的机器人，都不能说它们能够思考、感受、想象、渴望、理解、相信或判断。它们或许会模拟这些倾向，甚至达到完全欺骗我们的程度。但欺骗，无论多么引人注目，都不能因此而成为真理：无论后续经验如何丰富，我们也无法理直气壮地将两件从一开始就已知本质不同的事物视为同一事物。287

According to these definitions of ‘mind’ and ‘person’, neither a machine, nor a neurological model, nor an equivalent robot, can be said to think, feel, imagine, desire, mean, believe or judge something. They may conceivably simulate these propensities to such an extent as to deceive us altogether. But a deception, however compelling, does not qualify thereby as truth: no amount of subsequent experience can justify us in accepting as identical two things known from the start to be different in their nature.287

我们的知识理论如今被视为蕴含着一种心灵本体论。客观主义要求一个特定运作、无意识的认知者。相反，接受知识的不确定性则要求我们认可一个人有权根据其自身判断，以非特定的方式塑造其认知。这一概念——应用于人——反过来又意味着一种社会学，在这种社会中，思想的发展被视为一种独立的力量。而这种社会学是对一个尊重真理、为自身而培养人类思想的社会的忠诚宣言。288这个本体论——源自我的知识理论——将在第四部分进一步概述。

Our theory of knowledge is now seen to imply an ontology of the mind. Objectivism requires a specifiably functioning mindless knower. To accept the indeterminacy of knowledge requires, on the contrary, that we accredit a person entitled to shape his knowing according to his own judgment, unspecifiably. This notion—applied to man—implies in its turn a sociology in which the growth of thought is acknowledged as an independent force. And such a sociology is a declaration of loyalty to a society in which truth is respected and human thought is cultivated for its own sake.288 This ontology—which flows from my theory of knowledge— will be outlined further in Part Four.

 

 

  1. 关于批判
  2. ON BEING CRITICAL

各种清晰的肯定都可以或多或少地经过批判性思考——甚至是完全不加批判地进行。只要有批判，被批判的每次都是对清晰形式的断言。我们个人对清晰形式的接受被判断为批判性或非批判性，而这种判断表达了我们对在接受该清晰形式或清晰操作之前对其进行检验的评价。给予这种接受的思想被认为是批判性地或非批判性地行事。逻辑推理过程是人类思维最严格的形式，通过多次逐步复习，可以对其进行严厉的批判。事实断言和外延也可以进行批判性审查，尽管它们的检验不能形式化到同样的程度。

All kinds of articulate affirmations can be made more or less critically— and indeed quite uncritically. Where there is criticism, what is being criticized is, every time, the assertion of an articulate form. It is our personal acceptance of an articulate form that is judged to have been critical or uncritical, and this judgment expresses our appraisal of the tests to which we have subjected the articulate form or articulate operation before accepting it. It is the mind granting this acceptance which is said to have been acting critically or uncritically. The process of logical inference is the strictest form of human thought, and it can be subjected to severe criticism by going over it stepwise any number of times. Factual assertions and denotations can also be examined critically, although their testing cannot be formalized to the same extent.

按照刚才所述的意义，默会知识不可能是批判性的。动物和人类一样，会对妄想保持警惕。小狗比老狐狸更鲁莽。黑猩猩在解决问题时的犹豫可能会给它带来压力。但系统的批判形式只能应用于清晰的形式，你可以一次又一次地重新尝试这些形式。因此，我们不应该将“批判的”或“非批判的”这两个术语应用于任何单独的默会思维过程本身；就像我们不会谈论跳高或舞蹈的批判性或非批判性表演一样。默会行为需要用其他标准来判断，因此应被视为非批判性的。这种区别的意义在接下来的两章中应该会变得更加清晰。289

In the sense just specified, tacit knowing cannot be critical. Animals, like men, may be alert against delusions. A young dog is more rash than an old fox. The hesitations of a chimpanzee in solving a problem may impose a strain upon him. But systematic forms of criticism can be applied only to articulate forms, which you can try out afresh again and again. We should not apply, therefore, the terms ‘critical’ or ‘uncritical’ to any process of acit thought by itself; any more than we would speak of the critical or uncritical performance of a high-jump or a dance. Tacit acts are judged by other standards and are to be regarded accordingly as a-critical. The significance of this distinction should become clearer in the next two chapters.289

 

 

  1. 受托人计划
  2. THE FIDUCIARY PROGRAMME

 

 

我们默契的力量决定了我们对特定文化的依附，并支撑着我们在其框架内进行智力、艺术、公民和宗教方面的活动。人类思维的清晰表达是人类对宇宙的独特贡献；通过符号形式的发明，人类赋予了思想以生命力和持久性。然而，尽管我们的思维创造了这些技巧，但它们却拥有控制我们自身思想的力量。它们向我们诉说，让我们信服。正是由于它们对我们自身思维的控制力，我们才认识到它们的合理性以及它们被普遍接受的必要性。

Our tacit powers decide our adherence to a particular culture and sustain our intellectual, artistic, civic and religious deployment within its framework. The articulate life of man’s mind is his specific contribution to the universe; by the invention of symbolic forms man has given birth and lasting existence to thought. But though our thinking has contrived these artifices, yet they have power to control our own thought They speak to us and convince us, and it is precisely in their power over our own minds that we recognize their justification and their claim to universal acceptance.

然而，这里究竟是谁在说服谁？如果人类死了，他那未解的文字将毫无意义。从整体来看，人类既是其自身思想的始，又是其终，既是其思想的创造者，又是其思想的产物。他是否在用一种只有他自己才能理解的语言自言自语？

Yet who convinces whom here? If man died, his undeciphered script would convey nothing. Seen in the round, man stands at the beginning and at the end, as begetter and child of his own thought. Is he speaking to himself in a language he alone can understand?

起初，许多话语被视为神圣。律法被尊崇为神圣，宗教经文被尊崇为上帝启示的文字。基督徒敬拜道成肉身。教会的教义无需人为验证。当人接受其教义时，并非自言自语，在祈祷中，他可以诉说教义的根源。

In the beginning many words were held to be sacred. The law was respected as divine, and religious texts were revered as revealed by God. Christians worshipped the word made flesh. What the Church taught required no verification by man. When accepting its doctrine man was not speaking to himself, and in his prayers he could address the very source of the doctrine.

后来，当法律、教会和圣经的超自然权威衰落或崩溃时，人类试图通过在自身之上建立经验和理性的权威来避免单纯的自我主张所带来的空虚。但如今事实证明，现代科学主义对思想的束缚丝毫不亚于教会。它不为我们最重要的信仰提供任何空间，并迫使我们用荒谬而不恰当的术语来掩盖它们。以此为框架的意识形态将人类的最高愿望转化为毁灭灵魂的暴政。

Later, when the supernatural authority of laws, churches and sacred texts had waned or collapsed, man tried to avoid the emptiness of mere self-assertion by establishing over himself the authority of experience and reason. But it has now turned out that modern scientism fetters thought as cruelly as ever the churches had done. It offers no scope for our most vital beliefs and it forces us to disguise them in farcically inadequate terms. Ideologies framed in these terms have enlisted man’s highest aspirations in the service of soul-destroying tyrannies.

那么我们能做什么呢？我相信，提出这个挑战就是回答这个问题。因为它表达了我们拒绝中世纪教条主义和现代实证主义的自立精神，它要求我们自身的智力，在缺乏任何固定的外部标准的情况下，判断在缺乏这些标准的情况下，基于什么理由可以断言真理。对于“这里谁说服谁？”这个问题，它简单地回答：“我正在努力说服我自己。”

What then can we do? I believe that to make this challenge is to answer it. For it voices our self-reliance in rejecting the credentials both of medieval dogmatism and modern positivism, and it asks our own intellectual powers, lacking any fixed external criteria, to say on what grounds truth can be asserted in the absence of such criteria. To the question, ‘Who convinces whom here?’ it answers simply, ‘I am trying to convince myself.’

我曾在不同场合强调过这一点：反复指出，我们必须将自身的判断力视为我们所有智力成果的最高裁决者，并宣称我们有能力追求智力上的卓越，将其视为一种隐秘现实的象征。我将尝试阐述这种终极自立的结构，本书将以此为证。现在我只想指出，这种自我认可本身就是我自己的一种信托行为，它反过来又使我所有终极假设转化为我自己信念的宣言合法化。

I have insisted on this before on diverse occasions: pointing out repeatedly that we must accredit our own judgment as the paramount arbiter of all our intellectual performances, and claiming that we are competent to pursue intellectual excellence as a token of a hidden reality. I shall yet try to elaborate the structure of this ultimate self-reliance, to which this entire book shall bear witness. Let me observe now only that this self-accrediting is itself a fiduciary act of my own, which legitimates in its turn the transposition of all my ultimate assumptions into declarations of my own beliefs.

当我将本书命名为“迈向后批判哲学”时，我心中正浮现着这一转折点。批判运动如今似乎已接近尾声，但它或许是人类思想史上最卓有成效的努力。过去的四五个世纪，逐渐摧毁或掩盖了整个中世纪的世界，却在精神和道德上丰富了我们，其程度之深远是任何类似时期都无法比拟的。然而，它的炽热源于基督教遗产在希腊理性主义的氧气中燃烧，而当这种燃料耗尽时，批判框架本身也随之燃烧殆尽。

When I gave this book the sub-title ‘Towards a Post-Critical Philosophy’ I had this turning point in mind. The critical movement, which seems to be nearing the end of its course today, was perhaps the most fruitful effort ever sustained by the human mind. The past four or five centuries, which have gradually destroyed or overshadowed the whole medieval cosmos, have enriched us mentally and morally to an extent unrivalled by any period of similar duration. But its incandescence had fed on the combustion of the Christian heritage in the oxygen of Greek rationalism, and when this fuel was exhausted the critical framework itself burnt away.

现代人是前所未有的；然而，我们现在必须回到圣奥古斯丁，恢复我们认知能力的平衡。公元四世纪，圣奥古斯丁首次开创了后批判哲学，从而终结了希腊哲学史。他教导说，一切知识都是恩典的礼物，我们必须在先验信仰的指导下努力争取：nisi credideritis, non intelligitis。290他的学说统治了基督教学者的思想达一千年之久。后来，信仰衰落，可论证的知识占据了上风。到十七世纪末，洛克对知识与信仰作出了如下区分：

Modern man is unprecedented; yet we must now go back to St. Augustine to restore the balance of our cognitive powers. In the fourth century A.D., St. Augustine brought the history of Greek philosophy to a close by inaugurating for the first time a post-critical philosophy. He taught that all knowledge was a gift of grace, for which we must strive under the guidance of antecedent belief: nisi credideritis, non intelligitis.290 His doctrine ruled the minds of Christian scholars for a thousand years. Then faith declined and demonstrable knowledge gained superiority over it. By the end of the seventeenth century Locke distinguished as follows between knowledge and faith:

 

 

无论信仰的确信如何根基牢固、多么伟大，它始终是信仰而非知识；是说服而非确定性。在启示宗教（因此被称为信仰）领域，事物的本质允许我们达到的最高境界，便是如此；我们内心的说服力，而非知识，才是决定我们能否获得这些真理的​​结果。 291

How well-grounded and great soever the assurance of faith may be wherewith it is received; but faith it is still and not knowledge; persuasion and not certainty. This is the highest the nature of things will permit us to go in matters of revealed religion, which are therefore called matters of faith; a persuasion of our own minds, short of knowledge, is the result that determines us in such truths.291

 

 

在此，信仰不再是一种更高的力量，它向我们揭示超越观察和理性范围的知识，而是一种纯粹的个人接受，缺乏经验和理性的可论证性。奥古斯丁的两个层面之间的相互地位被颠倒了。如果神启继续受到尊崇，它的功能——就像英国国王和上议院的功能一样——就会逐渐沦为在礼仪场合受到尊崇。所有真正的权力都落入了名义上拥有客观可论证主张的下议院手中。

Belief is here no longer a higher power that reveals to us knowledge lying beyond the range of observation and reason, but a mere personal acceptance which falls short of empirical and rational demonstrability. The mutual position of the two Augustinian levels is inverted. If divine revelation continues to be venerated, its functions—like those of the Kings and Lords in England—are gradually reduced to that of being honoured on ceremonial occasions. All real power goes to the nominally Lower House of objectively demonstrable assertions.

批判性思维的断裂就在于此，它否定了其两种认知能力中的一种，并试图完全依赖剩余的认知能力。信仰被彻底抹黑，以至于除了一些特殊的机会（例如仍然赋予持有和宣扬宗教信仰的机会）之外，现代人失去了将任何明确的表述接受为自身信仰的能力。所有信仰都被降格为主观性：一种不完善性，知识正因如此才缺乏普遍性。

Here lies the break by which the critical mind repudiated one of its two cognitive faculties and tried completely to rely on the remainder. Belief was so thoroughly discredited that, apart from specially privileged opportunities, such as may be still granted to the holding and profession of religious beliefs, modern man lost his capacity to accept any explicit statement as his own belief. All belief was reduced to the status of subjectivity: to that of an imperfection by which knowledge fell short of universality.

我们现在必须再次认识到信仰是一切知识的源泉。默契的认同和求知的热情，对某种习语和文化遗产的分享，以及对志同道合社群的归属感：这些驱动力塑造了我们对事物本质的理解，而我们正是依靠这些理解来掌控事物。任何智慧，无论多么批判或独创，都无法脱离这样的信任框架而运作。

We must now recognize belief once more as the source of all knowledge. Tacit assent and intellectual passions, the sharing of an idiom and of a cultural heritage, affiliation to a like-minded community: such are the impulses which shape our vision of the nature of things on which we rely for our mastery of things. No intelligence, however critical or original, can operate outside such a fiduciary framework.

虽然我们接受这个框架是获得任何知识的条件，但这个框架本身并非自证。虽然我们的基本倾向是与生俱来的，但它们会因我们的成长经历而发生巨大的改变和扩展；此外，我们对经验的先天解读可能会产生误导，而我们一些最真实的后天习得的信念，虽然可以清晰地论证，却可能极难坚持。我们的心智存在于行动中，任何试图明确其预设的尝试都会产生一套公理，而这些公理无法告诉我们为什么应该接受它们。科学的存在取决于人们对其美的热爱，这种美被认为是普遍而永恒的。然而，我们也知道，我们对这种美的感受并不确定，对它的充分欣赏仅限于少数行家，而它能否传承给后代也存在不确定性。少数人持有且如此不稳定的信念，在任何经验意义上都并非不容置疑。我们的基本信念只有在我们相信它们如此的意义上才是不容置疑的。否则它们甚至不是信仰，而仅仅是某人的心理状态。

While our acceptance of this framework is the condition for having any knowledge, this matrix can claim no self-evidence. Although our fundamental propensities are innate, they are vastly modified and enlarged by our upbringing; moreover, our innate interpretations of experience may be misleading, while some of our truest acquired beliefs, though clearly demonstrable, may be most difficult to hold. Our mind lives in action, and any attempt to specify its presuppositions produces a set of axioms which cannot tell us why we should accept them. Science exists only to the extent to which there lives a passion for its beauty, a beauty believed to be universal and eternal. Yet we know also that our own sense of this beauty is uncertain, its full appreciation being limited to a handful of adepts, and its transmission to posterity insecure. Beliefs held by so few and so precariously are not indubitable in any empirical sense. Our basic beliefs are indubitable only in the sense that we believe them to be so. Otherwise they are not even beliefs, but merely somebody’s states of mind.

这就是我们从客观主义中解放出来：认识到我们只能从我们的信念内部——从逻辑上先于我们自己的任何特定主张、先于任何特定知识的掌握——来表达我们的终极信念。如果要达到并明确一个终极逻辑层面，这必须是我个人信念的宣言。我相信，哲学反思的功能在于揭示并确认我那些隐含在我认为有效的思想和实践中的信念；我必须致力于发现我真正相信的东西，并阐明我所持有的信念；我必须克服自我怀疑，以便牢牢把握这一自我认同的框架。

This then is our liberation from objectivism: to realize that we can voice our ultimate convictions only from within our convictions—from within the whole system of acceptances that are logically prior to any particular assertion of our own, prior to the holding of any particular piece of knowledge. If an ultimate logical level is to be attained and made explicit, this must be a declaration of my personal beliefs. I believe that the function of philosophic reflection consists in bringing to light, and affirming as my own, the beliefs implied in such of my thoughts and practices as I believe to be valid; that I must aim at discovering what I truly believe in and at formulating the convictions which I find myself holding; that I must conquer my self-doubt, so as to retain a firm hold on this programme of self-identification.

圣奥古斯丁的《忏悔录》就是对基本信仰进行逻辑一致阐述的一个例子。它的前十卷记述了他皈依前的时期以及他为尚未拥有的信仰而奋斗的情况。然而，他却是从皈依后的观点来解释这整个过程的。他似乎承认，你不能通过从导致错误的前提来解释错误来揭露错误，而只能从被认为是正确的前提来解释错误。他的格言“非理性信仰不可”表达了这一逻辑要求。据我理解，这句话的意思是，考察任何主题的过程既是对该主题的探索，也是对我们依据其研究该主题的基本信仰的诠释；是探索与诠释的辩证结合。在这样的过程中，我们的基本信仰不断地被重新审视，但仅限于其自身基本前提的范围内。

An example of a logically consistent exposition of fundamental beliefs is St. Augustine’s Confessions. Its first ten books contain an account of the period before his conversion and of his struggle for the faith he was yet lacking. Yet the whole of this process is interpreted by him from the point of view which he reached after his conversion. He seems to acknowledge that you cannot expose an error by interpreting it from the premisses which lead to it, but only from premisses which are believed to be true. His maxim nisi credideritis non intelligitis expresses this logical requirement. It says, as I understand it, that the process of examining any topic is both an exploration of the topic, and an exegesis of our fundamental beliefs in the light of which we approach it; a dialectical combination of exploration and exegesis. Our fundamental beliefs are continuously reconsidered in the course of such a process, but only within the scope of their own basic premisses.

同样，我刚才所说的决定，即刻意表达我真正持有的信念，在本书的前几部分中也早已有所体现。当我考察默契系数在认知艺术中的运作时，我指出了心灵在任何地方都遵循着它自己设定的标准，并且我默契地或明确地认可了这种确立真理的方式。这种认可与它所认可的行为属于同一类型，因此可以归类为一种有意识的非批判性陈述。

Similarly, the decision which I have now stated, to give deliberate expression to the beliefs I find myself truly holding, was duly anticipated all during the previous parts of this book. As I surveyed the operations of the tacit coefficient in the art of knowing, I pointed out how everywhere the mind follows its own self-set standards, and I gave my tacit or explicit endorsement to this manner of establishing the truth. Such an endorsement is an action of the same kind as that which it accredits and is to be classed therefore as a consciously a-critical statement.

这种教条主义的引诱或许令人震惊；然而，这不过是人类批判能力大幅提升的必然结果。批判能力赋予我们的心灵一种自我超越的能力，我们再也无法将其剥夺。我们从树上摘下了第二个苹果，它永远地危及了我们对善恶的认知，从今以后，我们必须学会在我们崭新的分析能力的耀眼光芒下认识这些特质。人类再次被剥夺了纯真，被赶出了另一个花园，无论如何，那是一个愚人的天堂。我们曾天真地相信，凭借客观的有效性标准，我们能够摆脱对自己信仰的所有个人责任——而我们自身的批判能力粉碎了这一希望。突然赤身裸体的打击，让我们或许会试图厚颜无耻地炫耀虚无主义的职业。但现代人的不道德性并不稳定。不久，他的道德激情以客观主义的伪装重新显现，科学主义的牛头怪诞生了。

This invitation to dogmatism may appear shocking; yet it is but the corollary to the greatly increased critical powers of man. These have endowed our mind with a capacity for self-transcendence of which we can never again divest ourselves. We have plucked from the Tree a second apple which has for ever imperilled our knowledge of Good and Evil, and we must learn to know these qualities henceforth in the blinding light of our new analytical powers. Humanity has been deprived a second time of its innocence, and driven out of another garden which was, at any rate, a Fool’s Paradise. Innocently, we had trusted that we could be relieved of all personal responsibility for our beliefs by objective criteria of validity—and our own critical powers have shattered this hope. Struck by our sudden nakedness, we may try to brazen it out by flaunting it in a profession of nihilism. But modern man’s immorality is unstable. Presently his moral passions reassert themselves in objectivist disguise and the scientistic Minotaur is born.

我试图在此阐明的另一种选择是，再次赋予我们深思熟虑地持有改良信仰的权力。我们现在应该能够有意识地、公开地信奉那些在现代哲学批判达到其如今的深刻程度之前可能被默认为理所当然的信仰。这种权力或许看似危险。但教条主义的正统观念可以从内到外受到制约，而颠倒为科学的信条则既盲目又具有欺骗性。

The alternative to this, which I am seeking to establish here, is to restore to us once more the power for the deliberate holding of improved beliefs. We should be able to profess now knowingly and openly those beliefs which could be tacitly taken for granted in the days before modern philosophic criticism reached its present incisiveness. Such powers may appear dangerous. But a dogmatic orthodoxy can be kept in check both internally and externally, while a creed inverted into a science is both blind and deceptive.

 

 

9

9

怀疑论批判

THE CRITIQUE OF DOUBT

 

 

  1. 怀疑论
  2. THE DOCTRINE OF DOUBT

我决心将哲学作为我终极信仰的宣言，这尚未得到系统阐述。但我们必须首先摒弃一种偏见，否则它将损害我们整个事业的士气。

MY resolve to make philosophy the declaration of my ultimate beliefs will have yet to be stated systemically. But we must first get rid of a prejudice which otherwise will undermine the morale of our whole enterprise.

在整个哲学批判时期，人们理所当然地认为，接受未经证实的信念是通往黑暗的康庄大道，而通往真理的途径则是笔直狭窄的怀疑之路。我们被警告，从孩提时代起，我们就被灌输了大量未经证实的信念。宗教教条、古人的权威、学校的教诲、幼儿园的格言，所有这些都被整合成一套传统，我们之所以倾向于接受它，仅仅是因为这些信念此前曾被他人持有，而他们也希望我们接受它们。我们被敦促用哲学怀疑原则来抵制这种传统灌输的压力。笛卡尔曾宣称，普遍怀疑应该清除他头脑中所有仅仅基于信任的观点，并向牢固建立在理性基础上的知识敞开大门。在其更严格的表述中，怀疑原则禁止我们完全沉溺于任何相信的欲望，并要求我们保持头脑清空，而不是让任何不可辩驳的信念占据我们的头脑。康德说，数学中不存在单纯的观点，只有真正的知识，如果没有知识，我们就不能做出任何判断。 292

It has been taken for granted throughout the critical period of philosophy that the acceptance of unproven beliefs was the broad road to darkness, while truth was approached by the straight and narrow path of doubt. We were warned that a host of unproven beliefs were instilled in us from earliest childhood. That religious dogma, the authority of the ancients, the teaching of the schools, the maxims of the nursery, all were united to a body of tradition which we tended to accept merely because these beliefs had been previously held by others, who wanted us to embrace them in our turn. We were urged to resist the pressure of this traditional indoctrination by pitting against it the principle of philosophic doubt. Descartes had declared that universal doubt should purge his mind of all opinions held merely on trust and open it to knowledge firmly grounded in reason. In its stricter formulations the principle of doubt forbids us altogether to indulge in any desire to believe and demands that we should keep our minds empty, rather than allow any but irrefutable beliefs to take possession of them. Kant said that in mathematics there was no room for mere opinion, but only for real knowledge, and that short of possessing knowledge we must refrain here from all judgment.292

怀疑方法是客观主义的逻辑推论。它相信，即使根除信仰中所有自愿成分，最终留下的仍然是完全由客观证据决定的知识。批判性思维无条件地相信这种方法能够避免错误并确立真理。

The method of doubt is a logical corollary of objectivism. It trusts that the uprooting of all voluntary components of belief will leave behind unassailed a residue of knowledge that is completely determined by the objective evidence. Critical thought trusted this method unconditionally for avoiding error and establishing truth.

我并非说在批判性思维时期，这种方法一直被严格地实践，或者说从未被严格地实践过——我认为这是不可能的——而只是说，这种方法的实践一直被公开宣扬和强调，而它的放松则只是边缘性的，只是被顺便承认。诚然，休谟在这方面相当坦率；他公开地选择在那些他认为自己无法诚实遵循的点上，抛开他自己的怀疑论结论。即便如此，他也没有承认这样做是在表达他自己的个人信念；他也没有主张自己有权利或义务去声明这些信念，因为这相当于压制怀疑并放弃严格的客观性。他对怀疑论的异议完全是非正式的，并未构成他哲学的明确组成部分。然而，康德却认真对待这一矛盾。他竭尽全力去应对休谟知识批判所揭示的局面，却丝毫不承认怀疑有任何放松。他在谈到这些困难时写道：“这些动乱的根源在于，

I do not say that during the period of critical thought this method has been always, or indeed ever, rigorously practised—which I believe to be impossible—but merely that its practice has been avowed and emphatic, while its relaxation was marginal and acknowledged only in passing. Admittedly, Hume was fairly frank in this respect; he openly chose to brush aside the conclusions of his own scepticism at those points where he did not think he could honestly follow them. Even so he failed to acknowledge that by so doing he was expressing his own personal beliefs; nor did he claim his right and accept his duty to declare such beliefs, when this amounted to the silencing of doubt and the abandonment of strict objectivity. His dissent from scepticism was strictly unofficial, forming no explicit part of his philosophy. Kant, however, took this contradiction seriously. He rallied to a superhuman effort to meet the situation exposed by Hume’s critique of knowledge, without admitting any relaxation of doubt. ‘The root of these disturbances’, he wrote in respect of such difficulties,

 

 

深藏于人类理性本质的邪恶必须被清除。但我们若不赋予它自由，甚至滋养，使其萌发嫩芽，使其展现在我们眼前，然后彻底毁灭，又怎能做到这一点呢？因此，我们必须思考那些对手从未想到过的反对意见，并借给他我们的武器，给予他他可能渴望的最有利的地位。我们无所畏惧，却充满希望；也就是说，我们或许能为自己赢得一份永无止境的财富。 293

which lies deep in the nature of human reason, must be removed. But how can we do so, unless we give it freedom, nay, nourishment, to send out shoots so that it may discover itself to our eyes, and that it may then be entirely destroyed? We must, therefore, bethink ourselves of objections which have never yet occurred to any opponent, and indeed lend him our weapons, and grant him the most favourable position which he could possibly desire. We have nothing to fear, but much to hope for; namely, that we may gain for ourselves a possession which can never again be contested.293

 

 

康德对理性不可争辩地位的期盼早已被证明是过高的；但怀疑的狂热却一直延续至今。十九世纪的大众思想被那些着眼于自然科学的作家所主导，他们满怀信心地宣称，他们不会接受任何未经无限制怀疑检验的信念。J.S .密尔对怀疑原则的这一雄辩论述，可以作为一千个次等论者的杰出范例：

Kant’s hopes of an incontestable estate of reason has long since proved too high; but the fervour of doubting was transmitted up to our day. Popular thought in the nineteenth century was dominated by writers who, with an eye on the natural sciences, declared with complete assurance that they accepted no belief whatever that had not passed the test of unrestricted doubt. As a distinguished example for a thousand lesser ones, take this eloquent declaration of the principle of doubt by J.S.Mill:

 

 

我们最有把握的信念，没有可靠的保障，只有向全世界发出邀请，要求它们证明自己毫无根据。如果挑战不被接受，或者接受了挑战但尝试失败，我们距离确定性仍然很远；但我们已经尽了人类理性所能及的最大努力；我们没有忽略任何可能让我们有机会获得真理的事物；如果机会是开放的，我们可以希望，如果存在更好的真理，当人类心智能够接受它时，它就会被发现；与此同时，我们可以依靠自己，已经达到了我们这个时代可能达到的接近真理的程度。这就是一个容易犯错的人所能达到的确定性程度，也是获得它的唯一途径。 294

The beliefs which we have most warrant for have no safeguard to rest on, but a standing invitation to the whole world to prove them unfounded. If the challenge is not accepted, or is accepted and the attempt fails, we are far enough from certainty still; but we have done the best that the existing state of human reason admits of; we have neglected nothing that could give the truth a chance of reaching us; if the lists are open, we may hope that if there be a better truth, it will be found when the human mind is capable of receiving it; and in the meantime we may rely on having attained such approach to truth as is possible in our own day. This is the amount of certainty attainable by a fallible being, and this the sole way of attaining it.294

任何关于思想正直的宣言都再真诚不过了；然而，其措辞却缺乏明确的含义，其含糊不清之处恰恰掩盖了他们所大声批判的个人信念。我们知道，J.S.米尔和其他秉持自由主义哲学怀疑传统的作家，在科学、伦理、政治等领域持有——并且至今仍持有——各种各样的信念，这些信念绝非毫无争议。如果他们认为这些信念尚未被“证明毫无根据”，这仅仅反映了他们拒绝接受那些曾经或现在针对他们的论点的决定。自由主义的信念在任何其他意义上都不能被视为无可辩驳的。但从这个意义上讲，所有基本信念都是无可辩驳的，同时也是无法证明的。事实上，证明或反证的检验与接受或拒绝基本信念无关，而声称你严格避免相信任何可以被反证的事物，只不过是在自我批评的严肃性伪装背后，掩盖你相信自己信念的意愿。

No proclamation of intellectual integrity could be more sincere; yet its words are devoid of any definite meaning, and their ambiguity conceals precisely the kind of personal convictions which they so loudly repudiate. For we know that J.S.Mill and other writers standing in the Liberal tradition of philosophic doubt held—and hold today—a wide range of beliefs in science, ethics, politics, etc., which are by no means unquestioned. If they regard these as not having been ‘proved unfounded’, this merely reflects their decision to reject the arguments which are or were advanced against them. At no time could the beliefs of Liberalism be regarded as irrefutable in any other sense. But in this sense all fundamental beliefs are irrefutable as well as unprovable. The test of proof or disproof is in fact irrelevant for the acceptance or rejection of fundamental beliefs, and to claim that you strictly refrain from believing anything that could be disproved is merely to cloak your own will to believe your beliefs behind a false pretence of self-critical severity.

这种自满情绪非但不会减弱，反而会因谦卑地承认自身结论的不确定性而进一步增强。因为，当我们承认我们信念所依据的证据可能不完整时，我们实际上掩盖了一个残酷的事实：我们根本无法获得任何证据来佐证这些信念。事实上，强调自身易错性，只会再次肯定我们虚伪的智识诚信标准，并凸显我们开放思想的闪光品质，这与那些公开宣称信仰是最终个人承诺之人的墨守成规形成了鲜明对比。

This complacency is not lessened, but further enhanced by humbly acknowledging the uncertainty of our own conclusions. For when we admit that the proofs on which our beliefs are supposed to be founded may conceivably be incomplete, we effectively cover up the brute fact that we can have no proof at all to warrant them. Indeed, the emphatic admission of our fallibility only serves to reaffirm our claim to a fictitious standard of intellectual integrity and to bring out the shining qualities of our open mind, in contrast to the hidebound attitude of those who openly profess their beliefs as their final personal commitment.

怀疑不仅被誉为真理的试金石，也被视为宽容的保障。认为哲学怀疑能够平息宗教狂热并带来普遍宽容的信念可以追溯到洛克，而这种信念至今仍充满活力。其最具影响力的代表人物罗素勋爵曾多次雄辩地阐述这一信念，例如在以下这段话中：

Doubt has been acclaimed not only as the touchstone of truth, but also as the safeguard of tolerance. The belief that philosophic doubt would appease religious fanaticism and bring about universal tolerance goes back to Locke, and this belief is still vigorously alive in our own day. Its most influential representative, Lord Russell, expressed it eloquently many times, as for example in this passage:

 

 

阿里乌斯派和天主教徒、十字军和穆斯林、新教徒和教皇追随者、共产党员和法西斯分子，在过去1600年的大部分时间里，充斥着无谓的争斗。稍加思考，就能让所有这些争论的双方明白，双方都没有充分的理由相信自己是正确的。教条主义……无论在当今时代还是过去，都是人类幸福的最大精神障碍。1

Arians and Catholics, Crusaders and Muslims, Protestants and adherents of the Pope, Communists and Fascists, have filled large parts of the last 1600 years with futile strife, when a little philosophy would have shown both sides in all these disputes that neither had any good reason to believe itself in the right. Dogmatism…in the present age as in former times, is the greatest of the mental obstacles to human happiness.1

 

 

有一点在现代人的思想中根深蒂固——我甚至在自己的思想中也发现如此——那就是，尽管怀疑可能变得虚无主义，并因此危及一切思想自由，但与坚持一个我们一旦决定就可以放弃的信仰相比，克制信仰始终是一种智识上的正直。顺从一种自愿的冲动而接受一种信仰，无论是我自己的，还是处于某种境地的其他人的

It remains deeply ingrained in the modern mind—as I find even in my own mind—that though doubt may become nihilistic and imperil thereby all freedom of thought, to refrain from belief is always an act of intellectual probity as compared with the resolve to hold a belief which we could abandon if we decided to do so. To accept a belief by yielding to a voluntary impulse, be it my own or that of others placed in a position of

 

 

权威，被认为是对理性的放弃。你无法教导这样做的必要性，否则——甚至在你内心深处——就会招致蒙昧主义的怀疑。在探索后批判哲学的每一步中，批判时代的警示都会在我们心中回荡。用康德的话来说：

authority, is felt to be a surrender of reason. You cannot teach the necessity for doing this without incurring—even in your own heart—the suspicion of obscurantism. At every step in quest of a post-critical philosophy the warning of the critical age will echo in our minds. In the words of Kant:

 

 

理性在其一切活动中都必须接受批判；如果它用任何禁令来限制批判的自由，它就必然会损害自身，

Reason must in all its undertakings subject itself to criticism; should it limit freedom of criticism by any prohibitions, it must harm itself, drawing

1伯特兰·罗素，《大学季刊》1 （1946 年），第 38 页。

1 Bertrand Russell, Universities Quarterly, 1 (1946), p. 38.

本身就是一种有害的怀疑。没有什么东西因其实用性而如此重要，没有什么东西因其神圣而可以免于这种毫无人情味的审视。理性的存在本身就依赖于这种自由。295

upon itself a damaging suspicion. Nothing is so important through its usefulness, nothing so sacred, that it may be exempted from this searching examination, which knows no respect for persons. Reason depends on this freedom for its very existence.295

 

 

除非我首先通过对怀疑原则的批判性审查来充分满足这一警告，否则我不会放心地提倡不批判的信仰态度。

I shall not feel reassured in advocating an attitude of a-critical belief, unless I have first fully met this warning by a critical examination of the principle of doubt.

 

 

  1. 信念与怀疑的等价性
  2. EQUIVALENCE OF BELIEF AND DOUBT

我们可以用非常广泛的意义来谈论怀疑。任何略带智慧的动物在行为中都会表现出片刻的犹豫，这种犹豫可以被描述为怀疑。一个正在瞄准的神枪手在扣动扳机之前可能会一直犹豫不决。一个诗人为了写好一行诗而不断尝试，也充满了这样的犹豫。296这种默契的怀疑存在于所有清晰的智力形式中，体现在断言行为中，无论其形式如何。这种怀疑是唯一一种适用于接受清晰框架作为居所的怀疑，因此它从源头上控制着我们精神存在的范围和方式。但在探讨这种更深层次的怀疑之前，我将简要讨论明确的怀疑形式：即对他人断言或我们先前断言的明确事实陈述的质疑。

We may speak of doubt in a very wide sense. A moment of hesitancy such as may be observed in the behaviour of any animal possessing a glimmer of intelligence, could be described as doubt. A marksman taking aim may be in doubt until he pulls the trigger. The renewed attempts of a poet to get a line right are filled with such hesitations.296 A measure of such tacit doubt is present in all articulate forms of intelligence within the act of assertion, throughout its many variants. It is the only kind of doubt that applies to the acceptance of an articulate framework as a dwelling place, and it controls therefore at their source the range and manner of our mental existence. But before examining this deeper doubt 1 shall deal briefly with explicit forms of doubt: that is, the questioning of explicit statements of fact either asserted by others or previously asserted by ourselves.

我对怀疑的批判的第一点是表明，对任何明确陈述的怀疑仅仅意味着试图否定该陈述所表达的信念，而支持暂时不受怀疑的其他信念。

The first point in my critique of doubt will be to show that the doubting of any explicit statement merely implies an attempt to deny the belief expressed by the statement, in favour of other beliefs which are not doubted for the time being.

假设某人说“我相信p ”，其中p代表“行星沿椭圆轨道运行”，或者“人人都会死”。而我回答“我怀疑p ”。这可以理解为我与p 相矛盾，可以用“我不相信p ”来表达。或者，我可能仅仅反对p为真的断言，否认有足够的理由在p或非p之间进行选择。这可以用“我相信p未经证明”来表达。我们可以将第一种怀疑称为“矛盾的”，将第二种怀疑称为“不可知论的”。

Suppose somebody says ‘I believe p’ where p stands for ‘planets move along elliptic orbits’, or else for ‘all men are mortal’. And I reply ‘I doubt p’. This may be taken to mean that I contradict p, which could be expressed by ‘I believe not-p’. Alternatively, I may be merely objecting to the assertion of p as true, by denying that there are sufficient grounds to choose between p or not-p. This may be expressed by saying ‘I believe p is not proven’. We may call the first type of doubt ‘contradictory’ and the second ‘agnostic’.

显而易见，矛盾怀疑的表达“我相信非p ”与它所质疑的肯定“我相信p ”具有相同的性质。因为p与非p之间没有区别，只是它们指的是不同的事实。“我相信非p ”可以代表行星沿着非椭圆轨道运行的主张。

It is immediately apparent that an expression of contradictory doubt ‘I believe not-p’ is of the same character as the affirmation ‘I believe p’ which it calls in question. For between p and not-p there is no other difference than that they refer to different matters of fact. ‘I believe not-p’ could stand for the allegation that planets move along orbits which are not elliptical.

科学史为肯定与矛盾的逻辑等价性提供了许多例证。在数学中，一个问题常常被设定为正解，然后反过来求其反解，即证明它不可能找到解。用尺规化圆为方和三等分角，一段时间后都被反过来了；这些构造已被证明是不可能的。在力学中，人们耗费了数个世纪的智慧来解决永动机问题，最终，建造这种机器的不可能性被确立为自然的基本定律。热力学第二定律和第三定律、化学元素理论、相对论和测不准原理以及泡利原理，都是用否定的形式表述的。爱丁顿的整个自然体系建立在一系列不可能性的假设之上。在所有这些情况下，肯定陈述和否定肯定陈述之间的区别仅仅在于措辞的问题，而对任何一种指控形式的接受和拒绝都是通过类似的测试来决定的。

The history of science offers many illustrations for the logical equivalence of affirmation and contradiction. In mathematics a problem may often be set for a time in the positive form and then turned round into its opposite, namely to prove the impossibility of finding a solution for it. The squaring of the circle and the trisection of an angle by aid of ruler and compass were both inverted after a time in that sense; these constructions have been proved to be impossible. In mechanics, centuries of misplaced ingenuity having been spent on solving the problem of perpetual motion, eventually the impossibility of constructing such a machine was established as a fundamental law of nature. The Second and Third Laws of Thermodynamics, the theory of Chemical Elements, the Principles of Relativity and of Indeterminacy, as well as the Pauli Principle, were all formulated in terms of negations. Eddington based his whole system of nature on the assumption of a series of impossibilities. In all these cases the difference between a positive statement and the denial of a positive statement is merely a matter of wording, and the acceptance and rejection of either form of allegation are both decided by similar tests.

不可知论怀疑稍微复杂一些，因为它由两半组成，而其中后半部分并不总是明确暗示。不可知论怀疑的前半部分是一种矛盾的怀疑，可以是暂时的，也可以是最终的。暂时的不可知论怀疑（“我相信p未被证明”）留下了p将来可能被证明的可能性；而其最终形式（“我相信p无法被证明”）则否认p能够被证明。但严格来说，这两种否定都没有提出任何有关p可信度的问题，因此它们仅代表不可知论怀疑的第一部分，而且迄今为止尚无定论。

Agnostic doubt is somewhat more complex, as it is composed of two halves of which the second is not always clearly implied. The first half of an agnostic doubt is a contradictory doubt, which can be either temporary or final. A temporary agnostic doubt (‘I believe p is not proven’) leaves open the possibility that p may yet be demonstrated in future; while in its final form (‘I believe p cannot be proven’) agnostic doubt denies that p can ever be demonstrated. But neither of these denials alleges, strictly speaking, anything concerning the credibility of p, and hence they represent only a first and so far inconclusive part of agnostic doubt.

事实上，在很多情况下，提出不可知论怀疑的前半部分并不损害被怀疑断言的可信度。假设我们想要考虑构建一个以p作为其公理之一的演绎系统的可能性。为此，p必须与其他公理相一致且独立于它们；这意味着，当缺少p本身时， p和非p都不应该在所提出的公理系统中可证明。如果这一点得到成功证明，我们可以自由地将p纳入我们的公理之一，或者拒绝它，这取决于通常与所讨论的证明完全无关的理由。只有在给定形式系统中肯定其自身不可判定性的哥德尔句子，在其不可判定性得到证明后才会为真。否则则不然。举例来说，高斯证明欧几里得第五公设不能从他的前四条公设中推导出来：这为将第五公设视为可选公设并用新发明的非欧几里得公设取代它提供了理由。

There are, in fact, various instances in which the first half of agnostic doubt is raised without prejudice to the credibility of the affirmation that is called in doubt. Suppose we want to consider the possibility of forming a deductive system with p as one of its axioms. For this it would be necessary that p should be consistent with the other axioms and independent of them; which means that neither p nor not-p should be provable within the proposed system of axioms when set out short of p itself. If this has been successfully demonstrated, we are at liberty to include p as one of our axioms, or else reject it, depending on reasons which in general will be quite independent of the demonstration in question. Only the Gödelian sentence which affirms its own undecidability within a given formal system emerges as true, once its undecidability has been demonstrated. Not so otherwise. Take, for example, the proof given by Gauss that the Fifth Postulate of Euclid cannot be derived from his first four Postulates: it served as a justification for considering the Fifth Postulate as optional and replacing it by newly invented non-Euclidean alternatives.

然而，即使在这种情况下，不可知论者对特定陈述的信念悬置并未表明其可信度，它仍然具有信托的内涵。它意味着接受某些关于证明可能性的信念。康德要求，在纯数学中，除非我们知道，否则我们必须放弃一切判断行为，因此，不可知论的怀疑本身就站不住脚。因为这一要求基于肯定“我相信p未被证明”或“不可证明”，这意味着接受某个并非严格不容置疑的框架，在这个框架内，p可以被说成是被证明的或未被证明的，可证明的或不可证明的。康德当然不会认识到这种矛盾，因为他认为数学的基础，包括欧几里得的公理，都是先验不容置疑的；但事实证明，这种观点是错误的。

Yet even though in such cases the agnostic suspension of belief in respect to a particular statement says nothing about its credibility, it still has a fiduciary content. It implies the acceptance of certain beliefs concerning the possibilities of proof. Kant’s demand that, in pure mathematics, unless we know, we must abstain from all acts of judgment, would therefore make agnostic doubt itself untenable. For this demand is based on affirming ‘I believe p is not proven’ or ‘not provable’, which implies the acceptance of some not strictly indubitable framework within which p can be said to be proven or not-proven, provable or not-provable. Kant would of course not have recognized this contradiction, since he held that the foundations of mathematics, including the axioms of Euclid, were indubitable a priori; but this view has proved to be mistaken.

我们即将在自然科学、法庭和宗教事务中进一步探讨不可知论怀疑的范围。

We shall presently explore the scope of agnostic doubt further in the natural sciences, the law courts and in religious matters.

 

 

  1. 合理和不合理的怀疑
  2. REASONABLE AND UNREASONABLE DOUBT

怀疑的受托性质体现在法律以及怀疑哲学所特有的“合理怀疑”的限制上。主张怀疑必须是合理的，就等于依赖某种无法被合理怀疑的东西——用法律术语来说，也就是“道德确定性”。297我将用科学怀疑的例子来说明这一点。

The fiduciary character of doubt is revealed by the limitation to ‘reasonable doubt’ characteristic of law and also of sceptical philosophy. To urge that doubt must be reasonable, is to rely on something that cannot reasonably be doubted—that is, in legal phrase, a ‘moral certainty’.297 I shall illustrate this by the example of scientific doubt.

自然科学家之所以比占星家更具批判性，仅仅在于我们认为自然科学家对星辰和人类的理解比占星家的理解更真实。更准确地说：当我们无视星座真实性的证据时，我们表达的信念是，这些证据可以用科学的星辰和人类观来解释，认为它们仅仅是偶然的或其他原因造成的。在十七、十八世纪，科学信仰因此反对并抹黑了整个超自然信仰体系以及宣扬这些信仰的权威。我们或许认为这种怀疑论运动完全合理，并且直到我们直面其错误时才会意识到它的可靠性，例如我之前提到的科学家对陨石的怀疑论。298当一块炽热的物质在​​几码外轰然撞击地球，发出雷鸣般的轰隆声时，普通民众相信这是陨石坠落，并倾向于赋予其超自然的意义。法国科学院的科学委员会非常不喜欢这种解释，以至于在整个18世纪，他们设法为这些事实找到自圆其说的解释。正是科学怀疑论，将所有以神奇治愈和迷惑形式出现的催眠现象实例置之不理，甚至在梅斯梅尔及其后继者系统地演示催眠术的情况下，在梅斯梅尔首次出现后的一个世纪里，也依然否认催眠现象的真实性。当医学界无视诸如在他们眼前连续进行的数百例无痛截肢等显而易见的事实时，他们采取了怀疑态度，坚信自己是在捍卫科学，抵御欺骗。299如今，我们认为这些怀疑论行为既不合理，甚至荒谬，因为我们不再认为陨石坠落或催眠术与科学世界观相悖。但如今，我们基于自身科学世界观而认为其他怀疑是合理的，而这些怀疑再次只能基于我们对这一世界观的信念。有些怀疑，或许终有一天会被发现，如同我们如今已根除的那些怀疑一样，是肆意妄为、偏执武断的。我对客观主义的批判已经指出了当今怀疑论所表达的一些荒谬的怀疑。

Natural scientists can be said to be more critical than astrologers only in so far as we regard their conception of stars and men as truer than that of the astrologers. More precisely speaking: when we disregard the evidence for the veridicity of horoscopes, we express the belief that this evidence can be explained within the scientific view of stars and men, as being merely accidental or otherwise invalid. During the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries scientific beliefs have thus opposed and discredited a whole system of supernatural beliefs and the authorities which taught these beliefs. We may regard this sceptical movement as altogether reasonable and be unaware of its fiduciary character until we are confronted with its blunders, for example in the scepticism of scientists concerning meteorites, of which I spoke before.298 Ordinary people were convinced of the fall of a meteorite, when an incandescent mass struck the earth with a crash of thunder a few yards away, and they tended to attach supernatural significance to it. The scientific committees of the French Academy disliked this interpretation so much that they managed, during the whole of the eighteenth century, to explain the facts away to their own satisfaction.
