It was again scientific scepticism which brushed aside all the instances of hypnotic phenomena occurring in the form of miraculous cures and spellbinding, and which—even in the face of the systematic demonstrations of hypnosis by Mesmer and his successors—denied for another century after Mesmer’s first appearance the reality of hypnotic phenomena. When the medical profession ignored such palpable facts as the painless amputation of human limbs, performed before their own eyes in hundreds of successive cases, they acted in a spirit of scepticism, convinced that they were defending science against imposture.299 We regard these acts of scepticism as unreasonable and indeed preposterous today, for we no longer consider the falling of meteorites or the practice of mesmerism to be incompatible with the scientific world view. But other doubts, which we now sustain as reasonable on the grounds of our own scientific world view, have once more only our beliefs in this view to warrant them. Some of these doubts may turn out one day to have been as wanton, as bigoted and dogmatic as those of which we have now been cured. My critique of objectivism has already pointed to some of these perverse doubts which scepticism expresses today.

 

 

  1. 自然科学中的怀疑论
  2. SCEPTICISM WITHIN THE NATURAL SCIENCES

在自然科学中，对一个主张的证明不可能像数学中那样严格。我们常常拒绝接受一个所谓的科学证明，主要是因为我们通常不愿意相信它试图证明的东西。正是沃勒和李比希对发酵源于活细胞这一观点的否定，使得他们忽视了支持该观点的证据。范特霍夫提出的关于不对称碳原子的证据，被科尔贝斥为因其论证的本质而毫无价值。巴斯德提出的关于自然发生论不存在的证据，被他的对手以他们自己的方式解释，并被拒绝，甚至巴斯德也承认这种可能性不能排除。 300

In the natural sciences the proof of an allegation cannot be as rigorous as it normally is in mathematics. We often refuse to accept an alleged scientific proof largely because on general grounds we are reluctant to believe what it tries to prove. It was the presumption of Wöhler and Liebig against the idea that fermentation was due to living cells which made them disregard the evidence in its favour. The kind of evidence produced by van’t Hoff for the asymmetrical carbon atom was condemned by Kolbe as worthless by the very nature of its argumentation. Pasteur’s evidence for the absence of spontaneous generation was rejected by his opponents by interpreting it in their own way, and even Pasteur admitted that this possibility could not be excluded.300

实验室里不断发生着令人费解的事情。例如，微量氦气或微量金可能会莫名其妙地出现在密封容器中，而且这种效应或许可以重现。在元素人工嬗变初现雏形的时代，许多科学家接受了此类观察结果，将其作为发生嬗变的证据。但一旦嬗变的真正条件被阐明，这类观察结果就不再受到科学家的重视。301我在之前的一本书中提到过瑞利勋爵于 1947 年 6 月在《皇家学会会刊》上发表的一篇论文，其中描述了一个简单的实验，该实验表明氢原子撞击金属线时会释放高达一百电子伏的能量。302如果这个结论正确，那将意义非凡。我咨询过的物理学家们虽然挑不出这个实验的毛病，却忽视了它的结果，甚至认为不值得重复。R.H. 伯格斯和J.C. 罗布最近的一项实验对此提出了一个可能的解释。303他们证明，在存在微量氧气（0.22-0.94毫米）的情况下，氢原子会导致金属丝温度升高，其升高程度是金属丝上氢原子复合热的许多倍。如果这就是解释，物理学家最好忽略这项研究。

Inexplicable things continue to happen in a laboratory. For example, traces of helium or traces of gold may unaccountably turn up in sealed vessels and the effect may be reproducible. At a time when the artificial transmutation of elements first appeared vaguely possible, a number of scientists accepted such observations as evidence that transmutation had taken place. But once the true conditions for transmutation had been elucidated, observations of this kind were no longer heeded by scientists.301 In an earlier book I have mentioned a paper published by Lord Rayleigh in June, 1947, in the Proceedings of the Royal Society, describing a simple experiment which demonstrated that a hydrogen atom impinging on a metal wire released energies ranging up to a hundred electron volts.302 This conclusion, if correct, would have been of immense importance. Physicists whom I consulted could find no fault with the experiment, yet they ignored its results, and did not even think it worth while to repeat it. A possible explanation of it is suggested by a recent experiment of R.H.Burgess and J.C.Robb.303 They have shown that in the presence of traces of oxygen (0.22–0.94 mm.), hydrogen atoms will cause a rise in temperature on a metal wire many times exceeding the heat of recombination of H atoms on the wire. If this is the explanation, physicists were well advised to ignore this work.

科学家必须对其知识领域内提出的任何重要主张做出承诺。如果他忽略该主张，实际上就意味着他认为该主张毫无根据。如果他注意到该主张，他投入到检验该主张的时间和注意力，以及他在指导自身研究时对该主张的考虑程度，都衡量了他认为该主张有效性的可能性。只有当该主张完全超出其责任范围时，科学家才能对其采取完全公正的怀疑态度。他只能对自己知之甚少且毫不关心的领域保持严格的不可知论立场。

A scientist must commit himself in respect to any important claim put forward within his field of knowledge. If he ignores the claim he does in fact imply that he believes it to be unfounded. If he takes notice of it, the time and attention which he diverts to its examination and the extent to which he takes account of it in guiding his own investigations are a measure of the likelihood he ascribes to its validity. Only if a claim lies totally outside his range of responsible interests can the scientist assume an attitude of completely impartial doubt towards it. He can be strictly agnostic only on subjects of which he knows little and cares nothing.

 

 

  1. 怀疑是一种启发式原则吗？
  2. IS DOUBT A HEURISTIC PRINCIPLE?

我们已经看到，对于被科学驳斥的论断，科学怀疑论的实践在于维护其主题的现有科学观点，我们也看到，在科学界的根本性争论中，这种怀疑论也针对同行科学家。但难道没有一种反叛的科学成就需要质疑迄今为止公认的科学信念的力量吗？诚然，每一项科学发现都是保守的，因为它维护并扩展了整个科学，并在一定程度上证实了科学的世界观，加强了它对我们思想的掌控；但任何重大发现都必然会改变科学观，有些发现甚至深刻地改变了科学观。许多革命性的发现，例如日心说、基因、量子、放射性或相对论，都很容易让人想到。将新主题融入现有体系的过程，难道不只是在保守科学，而真正的创新则包含着一场革命性的变革，通过这场变革，整个科学框架都将得到彻底改革吗？

We have seen that the practice of scientific scepticism in respect to allegations rejected by science consists in upholding the current scientific view of their subject matter, and we have seen this kind of scepticism also directed against fellow scientists in a fundamental controversy within science. But is there not a kind of rebellious scientific achievement which requires the power to doubt hitherto accepted beliefs of science? To be sure, every scientific discovery is conservative in the sense that it maintains and expands science as a whole, and to this extent confirms the scientific view of the world and strengthens its hold on our minds; but no major discovery can fail also to modify the outlook of science, and some have changed it profoundly. A number of revolutionary discoveries, like those of the heliocentric system, of genes, of quanta, of radioactivity or of relativity, come readily to mind. Might it not be that the process of assimilating fresh topics to the existing system merely conserves science, while true innovations include a revolutionary change by which the whole framework of science is reformed?

这听起来似乎有理，但事实并非如此。将迄今公认的信念扩展到迄今为止已探索的含义范围之外的力量本身就是科学变革的强大力量。正是这种力量推动哥伦布横渡大西洋寻找印度群岛。他的天才之处在于将地球是圆的这一事实从字面上理解并作为实际行动的指南，而他的同时代人对地球是圆的持有模糊的看法，仅仅是猜测。牛顿在《自然哲学的数学原理》中详细阐述的思想在他的时代也广为流传；他的工作并没有动摇科学家们所持有的任何坚定信念，至少在他自己的国家是这样。但是，他的天才再次体现在他能够将这些模糊的信念转化为具体的、具有约束力的形式。当代最伟大、最令人惊奇的发现之一，即晶体对X射线的衍射（1912年），是由数学家马克斯·冯·劳厄（Max von Laue）发现的。他凭借着比任何人都更坚定地相信公认的晶体和X射线理论，取得了这一发现。这些进步的大胆和冒险精神，丝毫不逊于哥白尼、普朗克或爱因斯坦的创新。

This sounds plausible, but it is not true. The power to expand hitherto accepted beliefs far beyond the scope of hitherto explored implications is itself a pre-eminent force of change in science. It is this kind of force which sent Columbus in search of the Indies across the Atlantic. His genius lay in taking it literally and as a guide to practical action that the earth was round, which his contemporaries held vaguely and as a mere matter for speculation. The ideas which Newton elaborated in his Principia were also widely current in his time; his work did not shock any strong beliefs held by scientists, at any rate in his own country. But again, his genius was manifested in his power of casting these vaguely held beliefs into a concrete and binding form. One of the greatest and most surprising discoveries of our own age, that of the diffraction of X-rays by crystals (in 1912) was made by a mathematician, Max von Laue, by the sheer power of believing more concretely than anyone else in the accepted theory of crystals and X-rays. These advances were no less bold and hazardous than were the innovations of Copernicus, Planck or Einstein.

因此，自然科学中不存在任何有效的启发式准则，推荐人们将信仰或怀疑作为发现的途径。有些发现源于这样一种信念：现有科学框架中存在着某些根本性的缺失；而另一些发现则源于相反的感觉：现有科学框架中蕴含的内涵远比人们目前认识到的要丰富得多。前一种信念或许被认为比第二种信念更具怀疑性，但恰恰是前一种信念更容易受到怀疑的阻碍——这是由于人们过度坚持现有的科学正统观念。

There exists, accordingly, no valid heuristic maxim in natural science which would recommend either belief or doubt as a path to discovery. Some discoveries are prompted by the conviction that something is fundamentally lacking in the existing framework of science, others by the opposite feeling that there is far more implied in it than has yet been realized. The first conviction may be regarded as more sceptical than the second, but it is precisely the first which is more likely to be hampered by doubt—owing to excessive adherence to the existing orthodoxy of science.

此外，在决定下一步研究方向时，没有规则告诉我们什么是真正的大胆，什么仅仅是鲁莽，因此也没有规则来区分怀疑和怀疑。怀疑会抑制鲁莽，从而成为真正的谨慎；怀疑会削弱大胆，最终被斥为缺乏想象力的教条主义。维萨里被誉为科学怀疑论的英雄，因为他大胆地驳斥了心脏隔壁被看不见的通道穿透的传统学说；而哈维却因完全相反的原因而受到赞誉，即他大胆地假设存在连接动脉和静脉的看不见的通道。

Besides, as there is no rule to tell us at the moment of deciding on the next step in research what is truly bold and what merely reckless, there is none either for distinguishing between doubt which will curb recklessness and thus qualify as true caution, and doubt which cripples boldness and will stand condemned as unimaginative dogmatism. Vesalius is praised as a hero of scientific scepticism for boldly rejecting the traditional doctrine that the dividing wall of the heart was pierced by invisible passages; but Harvey is acclaimed for the very opposite reason, namely for boldly assuming the presence of invisible passages connecting the arteries with the veins.

 

 

6. 法庭上的不可知论怀疑

6. AGNOSTIC DOUBT IN COURTS OF LAW

法院程序规定，在特定范围内的议题上，必须严格遵守公正的不可知论怀疑原则。许多通常被认为与刑事指控相关的事项，法院不得进行调查。如果一个人刚刚目睹了一场谋杀，并向一群人描述了这一过程，之后倒地身亡，那么凶手可能会逍遥法外，而该群体中的任何成员都不得在法庭上报告目击者告诉他的情况。许多其他信息，例如有关被告性格的证据，通常与案件相关，但公诉方不得提出。如果任何被排除在司法认知之外的信息被无意中提及，陪审团将被指示将其遗忘。通过执行这些限制法庭成员对案件通常关注范围的规则，法律成功地阻止了他们考虑一些原本会考虑的指控及其矛盾之处。通过压制任何一种选择，法律希望对它们达成一种严格的不可知论态度。这相当于对相关p建立起不可知论怀疑的前半部分，而没有对这些p的可信度做出任何后续判断。在这种情况下，人们持有的信念范围实际上会缩小，但其程度仅限于我们被阻止了解这些信念所指代的事物的程度。

The procedure of the law courts prescribes the observance of strictly impartial agnostic doubt in respect to a specified range of topics. There are a number of matters which would normally be considered relevant to a criminal charge, into which the court may not enquire. If a man, having just witnessed a murder, described it to a party of people and later collapsed and died, the murderer might go scot free without any member of the party being allowed to report in court what the man who witnessed the deed had told him. Much other information, for example evidence concerning the character of the accused, that would normally be relevant, may not be raised by the prosecution. If any information excluded from judicial notice is inadvertently brought up, the jury are directed to forget it. By the enforcement of such rules which restrict the usual range of interest to which the members of the court would respond in connection with the case before them, the law succeeds in keeping out of their minds a certain number of allegations p and their contradictories not-p which they would otherwise entertain. By suppressing the voicing of either of these alternatives the law hopes to achieve a strictly agnostic attitude in respect to them. This is equivalent to the establishment of the first half of agnostic doubt in respect to the p’s in question, without any subsequent decision as to the credibility of these p’s. In such a case the range of beliefs entertained is effectively reduced, but only to the extent to which we are prevented from knowing of the matters to which they refer.

另一方面，与法庭受理的争议相关的问题必须以某种方式裁决。如果在证据耗尽之后发现p和not- p都与证据相符，则法律规定的推定将决定两种选择中的一种。最广为人知的法律推定或许是那些在刑事诉讼中给予被告人“疑点利益”的推定。如果p和not- p的指控都与证据相符，法院通常会推定——即相信——不损害被告无罪的另一种选择。但在这方面，并没有绝对的推定。在没有相反证据的情况下，被告被推定为神志清醒，尽管这对他不利。民事和刑事诉讼中都存在许多特定类型的法律推定，它们与争辩双方的区别无关。这些推定主要是为了避免僵局，并尽可能合理地裁决那些通常没有充分证据的重要问题。例如，法官会发现，一对夫妻同时溺水身亡，年纪较长的一方会先死亡，尽管他对此一无所知。

On the other hand, the questions relevant to the issue which are admitted in court must be decided one way or another. If, after the evidence is exhausted it is found that both p and not-p are consistent with it, the presumptions laid down by law decide in favour of one of the two alternatives. The most widely known legal presumptions are perhaps those which grant the benefit of the doubt to the accused in criminal proceedings. If the allegations p and not-p are both consistent with the evidence, the court will as a rule presume—i.e. believe—the alternative which does not prejudice the innocence of the accused. But there is no sweeping presumption in this respect. In the absence of proof to the contrary an accused is presumed sane although this tells against him. There are numerous legal presumptions of a particular kind which prevail both in civil and criminal suits and bear no relation to the distinction between the two contesting sides. Such presumptions serve largely to avoid deadlock and to decide as reasonably as possible important issues for which there is no evidence that would be normally regarded as adequate. The judge will find for example that, of a married couple who were drowned together, the older one will have died first, even though he knows nothing whatever about it.

考虑任何法院不应关注的事项，或形成与正当法律推定相悖的信念，或更普遍地说，形成任何法律上不合理的信念，都会被谴责为偏见或任性。就这些规则排除我们通常会形成的某些信念而言，它们强制人们对这些信念产生怀疑或采取不可知论的态度。但再次强调，如同对经验的科学解释一样，在此取代普通人信念的信念体系，其明确性和全面性丝毫不逊于其他情况下的信念体系。法律规定一个人在被判有罪之前应被假定无罪，但这并非强加于法院以开放的心态，而是相反，它从一开始就告诉法院应该相信什么：即该人是无辜的。即使是法律上对通常相关事项的排除，也可以被解释为对特定信念的规定，即这些信念实际上与问题无关。在所有这些方面，一个公正法庭所谓的开放心态，唯有靠着比不履行司法责任的人通常持有的信念更强烈的信念才能维持。前一种信念远比后一种信念更难以令人信服，从这个意义上讲，它们可以说是为了当时的情况而武断地强加的。这似乎是西方观察家最初倾向于轻视莫斯科审判中明显缺失的法律保障措施的原因之一。正当的法律程序并非常识所能理解。

To take into consideration any matter which the court must not notice, or to form beliefs that are contrary to the proper legal presumptions, or quite generally, to form any legally unreasonable beliefs, is condemned as bias or caprice. In so far as these rules exclude the forming of certain beliefs to which we would normally be prone, they enforce a doubt or a state of agnosticism in respect to these beliefs. But once more, as in the scientific interpretation of experience, the system of beliefs which displaces here the beliefs of the man-in-the-street is no less definite and comprehensive than that which would be held otherwise. The law which orders that a man be presumed innocent until he is found guilty, docs not impose an open mind on the court, but tells it on the contrary what to believe at the start: namely that the man is innocent. Even the legal exclusion of normally relevant matter may be interpreted as the prescription of specific beliefs, namely that they are in fact irrelevant to the issue. In all these respects the supposedly open mind of an unbiassed court can be sustained only by a much stronger will to believe than the usual beliefs of a person discharging no judicial responsibility. The former beliefs are much less plausible than the latter, and to this extent they may be said to be dogmatically imposed for the occasion. This seems to have been one of the reasons why Western observers were at first inclined to take lightly the patent omission of legal safeguards in the Moscow trials. Proper legal procedure does not appeal to common sense.

法律强加的信念所具有的教条性乃至往往武断性，是由其确立和确认的特殊背景所决定的。法院并非试图探寻某些引人关注事件的真相，而只是通过法律规定的程序，寻找与特定法律问题相关的事实。即使这些断言本身无法自证其理，相信这些断言的意愿也源于通过做出这些断言并据此采取行动来伸张正义的意愿。因此，严格来说，法院的事实认定与科学和日常经验的认定之间不存在任何可能的矛盾。它们相互交织。观察到的事实与法律事实之间的关系，原则上类似于事实经验与基于此类经验的艺术之间的关系，或经验事实与数学概念之间的关系。在所有这些情况下，经验都成为一种智力活动的主题，这种智力活动将经验的一个方面发展成一个体系，并基于其内部证据而建立和接受。法律事实体系被接受为由相应法律框架塑造的社会生活的一部分。

The dogmatic and often arbitrary character of legally imposed beliefs is justified by the peculiar context in which they are established and affirmed. The court does not try to find out the truth about certain interesting events, but only to find—by a legally prescribed procedure— the facts relevant to a certain legal issue. The will to believe these affirmations, even when they are not justifiable in themselves, originates in the will to do justice by making these affirmations and acting upon them. There is therefore, strictly speaking, no possible contradiction between the factual findings of a court of law and those of scientific and ordinary experience. They by-pass each other. The relation between observed facts and legal facts is similar in principle to that between factual experience and an art based on such experience, or between empirical facts and mathematical conceptions. In all these cases experience serves as a theme for an intellectual activity which develops one aspect of it into a system that is established and accepted on the grounds of its internal evidence. The system of legal facts is accepted as part of a social life shaped by the corresponding legal framework.

 

 

  1. 宗教怀疑
  2. RELIGIOUS DOUBT

从休谟到罗素，人们相信怀疑能够有效化解谬误，这种信念主要源于对宗教教条的怀疑以及对宗教偏执的厌恶。几个世纪以来，这一直是批判性思维的主导激情，并在此过程中彻底改变了人类的宇宙观。因此，它必须成为我批判怀疑论的主要主题。我将把论证局限于对基督教信仰的宗教怀疑，并从我在“理智激情”一章中提到的要点继续展开。

The belief in the efficacy of doubt as a solvent of error was sustained primarily—from Hume to Russell—by scepticism about religious dogma and the dislike of religious bigotry. This has been the dominant passion of critical thought for centuries, in the course of which it has completely transformed man’s outlook on the universe. It must, accordingly, form the main subject of my critique of doubt. I shall limit the argument to religious doubts in respect of the Christian faith, picking up the thread from the point reached in my chapter on Intellectual Passions.

宗教，作为一种崇拜行为，是一种内在的栖居而非一种肯定。上帝无法被观察到，正如真理或美无法被观察到一样。他存在于被崇拜和服从的意义上，而非其他意义上；他并非作为事实而存在——正如真理、美或正义并非作为事实而存在一样。所有这些，就像上帝一样，都是只有在侍奉它们时才能被领悟的事物。因此，“上帝存在”这句话并非像“雪是白的”那样是一个事实陈述，而是一个授权陈述，例如“‘雪是白的’是真的”，这决定了“上帝存在”这句话可以承受何种怀疑。304因为“‘雪是白的’是真的”这句话代表着说话者做出的一种非批判性的断言行为，它不是一个描述性句子，也不能成为明确怀疑的对象。它只能以不同程度的自信说出，而其断言本身可能缺乏完全的自信，因此可以被视为说话者对其自身断言附加的怀疑。这是一种心照不宣的怀疑，一种含糊不清的犹豫，就像一个神枪手怀疑地扣动扳机一样，而“上帝存在”这句话也只能在心照不宣的犹豫的意义上受到怀疑。

Religion, considered as an act of worship, is an indwelling rather than an affirmation. God cannot be observed, any more than truth or beauty can be observed. He exists in the sense that He is to be worshipped and obeyed, but not otherwise; not as a fact—any more than truth, beauty or justice exist as facts. All these, like God, are things which can be apprehended only in serving them. The words ‘God exists’ are not, therefore, a statement of fact, such as ‘snow is white’, but an accreditive statement, such as ‘“snow is white” is true’, and this determines the kind of doubt to which the statement ‘God exists’ can be subjected.304 For since ‘“snow is white” is true’ stands for an a-critical act of assertion made by the speaker, it is not a descriptive sentence and cannot be the subject of explicit doubt. It can merely be uttered with varying degrees of confidence, and what its assertion may lack in perfect assurance might then be regarded as the doubt attached by the speaker to his own assertion. This would be a tacit doubt, an inarticulate hesitancy, like that of a marksman dubiously pulling the trigger, and the words ‘God exists’ can also be doubted only in the sense of a tacit hesitancy.

但这种表述多少夸大了信仰行为（其含义尚待探讨）与“上帝存在”一词的含义之间的区别。诚然，这些词语并不构成崇拜，其意义也仅限于认可说话者臣服于上帝的信仰行为。然而，我们不可能像区分对事实陈述的接受与被接受的陈述那样，将这种接受行为与它所接受的行为截然区分开来。

But this formulation somewhat exaggerates the sharpness of the distinction between acts of faith which imply (in a sense yet to be explored) the existence of God, and the meaning of the words ‘God exists’. It is true that these words form no part of worship and can mean nothing beyond the endorsement of an act of faith by which the speaker has surrendered to God, yet it is not possible to separate this act of acceptance as sharply from that which it accepts, as we can the acceptance of factual statements from the accepted statements.

因此，我们将转而探讨我们内隐的理解力与受我们理解力控制的口头语言和经验细节之间更普遍的关系。（参见第二部分，第五章，第92页。）这将引导我们回归宗教崇拜作为一种启发式视角的概念，并将宗教与数学、小说和美术等伟大的知识体系联系起来，这些体系因成为人类心灵的幸福居所而得到验证。届时我们将看到，尽管宗教信仰具有非批判性的特征，但它的力量确实依赖于事实证据，并且会受到对某些事实的怀疑的影响。让我来详细阐述一下这个方案。

We shall turn for guidance instead, therefore, to the more general relationship which obtains between our tacit powers of comprehension and the spoken words and empirical particulars controlled by our comprehension. (See Part Two, ch. 5, p. 92.) This will lead us back to the conception of religious worship as a heuristic vision and align religion in turn also with the great intellectual systems, such as mathematics, fiction and the fine arts, which are validated by becoming happy dwelling places of the human mind. We shall see then that in spite of its a-critical character, the force of religious conviction does depend on factual evidence and can be affected by doubt concerning certain facts. Let me develop this programme.

在“理智激情”一章中，我将基督教信仰描述为一种充满激情的启发式冲动，它没有实现的希望。启发式冲动总是意识到自身可能存在不足，而它所缺乏的绝对确信，或许可以描述为它内在的怀疑。但基督教信仰与生俱来的不足感远不止于此，因为基督教信仰的一部分在于，它的奋斗永远无法达到一个终点，在这个终点，当它获得预期结果后，继续下去就变得毫无必要。一个基督徒如果在今生达到了精神的终点，就不再是基督徒了。对自身不完美的认识，对他的信仰至关重要。“信仰包含自身以及对自身的怀疑，”蒂利希写道。305

In the chapter on Intellectual Passions I have described the Christian faith as a passionate heuristic impulse which has no prospect of consummation. A heuristic impulse is never without a sense of its possible inadequacy, and what it lacks in absolute assurance may be described as its inherent doubt. But the sense of inadequacy inherent in the Christian faith goes beyond this, for it is part of the Christian faith that its striving can never reach an endpoint at which, having gained its desired result, its continuation would become unnecessary. A Christian who reached his spiritual endpoint in this life would have ceased to be a Christian. A sense of its own imperfection is essential to his faith. ‘Faith embraces itself and the doubt about itself,’ writes Tillich.305

然而，根据基督教信仰，这种对真信仰的固有怀疑是罪孽，而这种罪孽是无法根除的痛苦之源。一旦消除怀疑、罪孽和痛苦，基督教信仰就变成了自身的讽刺画。它变成了一套不准确、往往是虚假且大多毫无意义的陈述，伴随着陈词滥调和自鸣得意的道德说教。这是所有基督教徒努力的禁忌终点：回归空虚。

Yet according to the Christian faith this inherent dubiety of the true faith is sinful and this sin is an ineradicable source of anguish. Take away doubt, sin and anguish, and Christian faith turns into a caricature of itself. It becomes a set of inaccurate, often false and largely meaningless statements, accompanied by conventional gestures and complacent moralizing. This is the forbidden endpoint of all Christian endeavour: its relapse into emptiness.

启发式的冲动唯有在追求其恰当的探究中才能得以生存。基督教的探究即是敬拜。祷告和忏悔的言辞、仪式的行动、教诲、布道以及教堂本身，都是敬拜者追寻上帝的线索。它们引导他的悔悟和感恩之情，以及他对神圣临在的渴望，同时让他免受纷扰。

A heuristic impulse can live only in the pursuit of its proper enquiry. The Christian enquiry is worship. The words of prayer and confession, the actions of the ritual, the lesson, the sermon, the church itself, are the clues of the worshipper’s striving towards God. They guide his feelings of contrition and gratitude and his craving for the divine presence, while keeping him safe from distracting thoughts.

宗教敬拜作为一种框架，表达了其作为寻求上帝的热情居所的认同，因此它无可非议。祷告的话语是向上帝发出的，而礼拜仪式的其他部分虽然也提及上帝，但大多是人际关系的宣告——例如对上帝的赞美。敬拜的某些部分，例如信经，诚然包含神学主张，而圣经的教训则以浅显易懂的叙述语言表达。但信经的重点在于“我信”这几个字，它在情感上支持敬拜；而基督教宗教仪式中引用圣经经文并非为了传达信息，而是作为维系信仰的教义的起点。所有这些陈述都作为敬拜的补充。

As a framework expressing its acceptance of itself as a dwelling place of the passionate search for God, religious worship can say nothing that is true or false. Words of prayer are addressed to God, and while other parts of the service speak of God, they are mostly declarations of interpersonal relations—such as the praise of God. Some parts of worship, like the credo, admittedly make theological assertions, and the lessons from the Bible are couched in plainly narrative language. But the accent of the credo lies on the words: ‘I believe’ which emotionally endorse worship, while the extracts from the Bible are not quoted in the course of a Christian religious service in order to convey information, but as starting points for teachings that sustain the faith. All such statements function as subsidiaries to worship.

但神学教义和圣经记载本身也教导了人。那么，它们的陈述究竟是真是假，又该受到明确的质疑吗？答案既非是，也非是，这里只能略作概述。

But the doctrines of theology and the records of the Bible are also taught in themselves. Can their statements then be said to be true or false and be subjected to explicit doubt? The answer is neither yes nor no, and it can be given here only in outline.

只有忠于信仰的基督徒才能理解基督教神学，也只有他才能领悟圣经的宗教意义。神学与圣经共同构成了敬拜的背景，我们必须理解它们与敬拜的关系；但我们将会看到，这两种关系是不同的。

Only a Christian who stands in the service of his faith can understand Christian theology and only he can enter into the religious meaning of the Bible. Theology and the Bible together form the context of worship and must be understood in their bearing on it; but we shall see that this bearing is different in the two cases.

像“上帝存在”这样的神学陈述，可能只不过是用描述性术语来认可某种崇拜行为；就像在自信地说出“雪是白的”之后，又说“‘雪是白的’是真的”。就此而言，“上帝存在”这一表述是非批判性的，并非明显值得怀疑。但神学作为一个整体，是对重大问题的复杂研究。它是一种宗教知识理论，也是与之相应的已知事物的本体论。因此，神学揭示或试图揭示宗教崇拜的含义，它可以说是真或假，但这仅限于其在构建和净化先前存在的宗教信仰方面的充分性。虽然神学试图证明上帝存在的行为与哲学试图证明数学前提或经验推理原理一样荒谬，但作为基督教信仰公理化的神学，肩负着重要的分析任务。虽然只有虔诚的基督教徒才能理解其结果，但它可以极大地帮助他们理解自己正在实践什么。

A theological statement, like ‘God exists’, may be little more than the endorsement of an act of worship in descriptive terms; something like saying ‘“Snow is white” is true’ after having confidently said ‘Snow is white’. To this extent the expression ‘God exists’ is a-critical and not explicitly dubitable. But theology as a whole is an intricate study of momentous problems. It is a theory of religious knowledge and a corresponding ontology of the things thus known. As such, theology reveals, or tries to reveal, the implications of religious worship, and it can be said to be true or false, but only as regards its adequacy in formulating and purifying a pre-existing religious faith. While theological attempts to prove the existence of God are as absurd as philosophical attempts to prove the premisses of mathematics or the principles of empirical inference, theology pursued as an axiomatization of the Christian faith has an important analytic task. Though its results can be understood only by practising Christians, it can greatly help them to understand what they are practising.

当然，如果神学对上帝的阐释在可观察经验的宇宙中声称其有效性，那么它必然显得毫无意义，而且常常自相矛盾。每当一种适用于某一主题的语言被用于指代另一个完全不同的主题时，这种结果就不可避免。用经典电磁学和力学来描述原子过程的相对温和的尝试，导致了自相矛盾，这种矛盾在我们最终习惯之前似乎并难以忍受。如今，物理学家们享受着这些只有他们才能理解的荒谬之事，就像德尔图良似乎享受着他信仰中令人震惊的悖论一样。基督教的悖论非但没有让我对基督教信仰的合理性产生怀疑，反而会成为我构建和稳定其他信仰的范例，人类正是通过这些信仰努力满足自己设定的标准。

Theological accounts of God must, of course, appear meaningless and often blatantly self-contradictory if taken to claim validity within the universe of observable experience. Such a result is inevitable, whenever a language that is apposite to one subject matter is used with reference to another altogether different matter. The comparatively modest attempt to describe atomic processes in terms of classical electro-magnetics and mechanics has led to self-contradictions which appeared no less intolerable until we eventually got accustomed to them. Today physicists enjoy these apparent absurdities which they alone can comprehend, even as Tertullian seems to have enjoyed the startling paradoxes of his faith. Far from raising doubts in my mind concerning the rationality of Christian beliefs, the paradoxes of Christianity will serve me as examples for an analogous framing and stabilizing of other beliefs by which man strives to satisfy his own self-set standards.

神学包含圣经释经及其原则，在此背景下，它也探讨了我在此提出的问题：宗教信仰如何依赖于可观察的事实，或者更准确地说，如何依赖于关于可观察事实的陈述的真假。因此，我现在不得不短暂地涉足神学领域。

Theology comprises biblical exegesis and the principles of biblical exegesis, and in this context it deals also with the question which I have set myself here, namely how religious faith depends on observable facts, or—more precisely—on the truth or falsity of statements concerning observable facts. I shall therefore have to trespass now for a short stretch on the domain of theology.

我曾将基督教的宗教仪式描述为一个由各种线索组成的框架，这些线索很容易引发人们对上帝的热情探索。我曾谈到一种默契的理解行为，正是这种理解行为从这些线索中衍生出信仰。这种娴熟的宗教认知能力似乎普遍存在，至少在儿童中是如此。一旦掌握，这种技能几乎不会丢失，但如果没有在童年时期接受过一些训练，人们很少能在成年后掌握它。对于一个完全缺乏宗教认知技能的人来说，神圣的仪式毫无意义。

I have described Christian religious service as a framework of clues which are apt to induce a passionate search for God. I have spoken of the tacit act of comprehension which originates faith from such clues. The capacity for such skilful religious knowing seems universal, at least in children. Once acquired, the skill is hardly ever lost, but it is rarely mastered at an advanced age without some previous training in childhood. Divine service can mean nothing to a person completely lacking the skill of religious knowing.

一个由言语和手势构成的框架，其能否在一个接受者心中引发其自身的宗教理解，部分取决于其要素的非宗教意义。该框架必须首先通过其教义、叙事、道德和仪式的吸引力，打动儿童或非信徒，然后他们才能从宗教角度理解这些内容。因此，证实福音书中某些决定性事件的历史证据，将增强基督教教义的力量。反之，圣经批判和科学进步削弱或摧毁了许多圣经叙事的超宗教可信度，并质疑了某些基督教仪式所谓的神奇力量，这必然会动摇通过宣扬此类教义和执行此类仪式而建立起来的信仰。现代神学已将这些攻击作为其重新诠释和巩固更真实基督教信仰的指南。下文我将尝试用我自己的语言来阐述这一结果。 306

The power of a framework composed of words and gestures to elicit its own religious comprehension in a receptive person will depend partly on the non-religious significance of its elements. The framework must impress a child or an unbeliever in the first place by the appeal made by its dogma, its narratives, its morality and its ritual exercise, before these have been religiously comprehended by him. Historical evidence confirming some decisive event recorded by the Gospels will, therefore, augment the strength of Christian teaching. And conversely, Biblical criticism and the progress of science which weakened or destroyed the extra-religious plausibility of many Biblical narratives and discredited the supposed magical powers of some Christian ritual, were bound to shake a faith implemented by the assertion of such teachings and the performance of such rituals. Modern theology has accepted these attacks as its guide for re-interpreting and consolidating the Christian faith in a truer form. In the following I shall try to state this result in my own terms.306

为此，让我们将全部经验纳入考量，包括——当然也远不止——阅读圣经，并观察其在人皈依过程中对其心灵的宗教影响。所有这些经验，迄今为止仍非宗教性质，或许能为心灵提供通往基督教信仰的线索，正如各种知识，无论是从科学书籍中提炼出来的，还是通过直接观察获得的，都能为科学观点提供线索一样。这两种理解方式都建立了各自的启发式视野，并不主张任何具体的事实。它们是高度个人化的知识形式，辅之以一系列相对非个人化的经验。事实线索与启发式视野之间的这种关系，类似于事实经验与数学和艺术作品之间的关系。这种类比将宗教信仰与这些同样基于经验的伟大而清晰的体系联系起来，但心灵无需主张任何明确的经验事实即可栖居其中。外部经验对于数学和艺术来说都是不可或缺的，作为它们的主题，但对于一个准备居住在它们的框架中的人来说，数学或艺术传达了他们自己的内部思想，并且正是为了这种内部经验，他的思想才接受它们的框架作为其居所。

Let us take in for this purpose the whole of experience, including—but extending of course far beyond—the reading of the Bible, and let us observe its religious effects on a person’s mind in the process of his conversion. All this experience, which so far is still non-religious, may supply the mind with clues to the Christian faith, even as all kinds of knowledge, whether culled from scientific books or obtained by direct observation, may serve as clues for a scientific outlook. Both kinds of comprehension establish their own heuristic vision which asserts no specific fact. They are forms of highly personal knowledge which subsidiarily comprise a set of relatively impersonal experiences. This relation of factual clues to a heuristic vision is similar to the relation of factual experience to mathematics and to works of art. The analogy brings religious faith into line with these great articulate systems which are also based on experience, but which the mind can yet inhabit without asserting any definite empirical facts. External experience is indispensable both to mathematics and art, as their theme, but to a person prepared to inhabit their framework, mathematics or art convey their own internal thought, and it is for the sake of this internal experience that his mind accepts their framework as its dwelling place.

宗教与非宗教经验的关系类似。世俗经验是宗教的原材料：宗教以这种经验为主题，构建自身的宇宙。每一个伟大的清晰体系的宇宙，都是通过阐释和转化先前经验的某一特定方面而构建的：基督教信仰以其自身的内在经验，阐释并赋予先前经验的超自然方面以生命力。皈依者通过沉浸于其体系所唤起的宗教狂喜，并由此认可其有效性，从而进入清晰的崇拜和教义框架。这又类似于人们学习享受和追求数学，或愉悦地思考——有时甚至创作——艺术作品的验证过程。307

Religion stands in a similar relation to non-religious experience. Secular experiences are its raw material: religion uses such experience as its theme for building up its own universe. The universe of every great articulate system is constructed by elaborating and transmuting one particular aspect of anterior experience: the Christian faith elaborates and renders effective the supernatural aspect of anterior experience in terms of its own internal experience. The convert enters into the articulate framework of worship and doctrine by surrendering to the religious ecstasy which their system evokes and accredits thereby its validity. This is again analogous to the process of validation by which men learn to enjoy and pursue mathematics or to contemplate with pleasure—and sometimes even produce—works of art.307

我已经阐述了自然科学、数学和技术是如何相互渗透的。所有艺术都以类似的方式交织在一起；而在人文学科领域，艺术与科学方法也相互渗透。宗教的亲和力甚至更为广泛：它能够将所有的智识经验转移到它自己的领域，同时也反过来，成为大多数其他智识体系的主题。我们在此感兴趣的基督教与自然经验的关系，仅仅是这张相互渗透之网中的一条线索。

I have shown how natural science, mathematics and technology mutually interpenetrate each other. All the arts are similarly interwoven; while the arts and the methods of science penetrate each other in the domain of the humanities. Religion has even more comprehensive affinities: it can transpose all intellectual experiences into its own universe, and has also served, in reverse, most other intellectual systems as their theme. The relation of Christianity to natural experience, in which we are interested here, is but one thread in this network of mutual penetrations.

宗教发现和自然发现这两种发现相互绕过，就像法庭的发现绕过日常经验一样。接受基督教信仰并不表达对可观察事实的断言，因此你无法通过实验或事实记录来证明或反驳基督教。让我将这一点应用于对奇迹的信仰。自从像培尔和休谟这样的哲学家攻击奇迹的可信度以来，理性主义者一直主张，对奇迹的承认必须建立在事实证据的力量之上。但事实上，情况恰恰相反：如果水变成酒或死人复活可以通过实验验证，这将严格推翻它们的神奇性质。事实上，任何事件，只要能够用自然科学的术语来证实，它就属于事物的自然秩序。无论它多么怪诞和令人惊讶，一旦它被完全确立为可观察的事实，它就不再被视为超自然的。例如，最近一些生物学观点认为，处女生子可能发生在特殊情况下，如果以此作为基督诞生的解释，那么这不仅不会证实，反而会彻底推翻处女生子的教义。试图用自然检验来证明超自然现象是不合逻辑的，因为这些检验只能确定事件的自然方面，而永远无法将其视为超自然现象。观察或许能为我们对上帝的信仰提供丰富的线索；但任何科学上令人信服的对上帝的观察，都会将宗教崇拜变成对一个纯粹的物体或自然人的偶像崇拜。

The two kinds of findings, the religious and the natural, by-pass each other in the same way as the findings of law courts by-pass ordinary experience. The acceptance of the Christian faith does not express the assertion of observable facts and consequently you cannot prove or disprove Christianity by experiments or factual records. Let me apply this to the belief in miracles. Ever since the attacks of philosophers like Bayle and Hume on the credibility of miracles, rationalists have urged that the acknowledgment of miracles must rest on the strength of factual evidence. But actually, the contrary is true: if the conversion of water into wine or the resuscitation of the dead could be experimentally verified, this would strictly disprove their miraculous nature. Indeed, to the extent to which any event can be established in the terms of natural science, it belongs to the natural order of things. However monstrous and surprising it may be, once it has been fully established as an observable fact, the event ceases to be regarded as supernatural. Recent biological suggestions, for example, that virgin birth might take place in exceptional circumstances would, if accepted as the explanation of the birth of Christ, not confirm, but totally destroy the doctrine of the Virgin Birth. It is illogical to attempt the proof of the supernatural by natural tests, for these can only establish the natural aspects of an event and can never represent it as supernatural. Observation may supply us with rich clues for our belief in God; but any scientifically convincing observation of God would turn religious worship into an idolatrous adoration of a mere object, or natural person.

当然，一个实际上从未发生过的事件不可能具有超自然意义；它是否发生过必须由事实证据来证实。因此，圣经批判的宗教力量动摇了某些构成基督教主要主题的事实，或者反过来，证实了这些事实。但有时，即使某个事实并未发生，描述其发生的叙述所传达的宗教真理也未必会受到太大影响。《创世纪》及其伟大的图画插图，如同米开朗基罗的壁画，对宇宙的本质和起源的描述远比将世界描绘成原子的偶然组合更为明智。因为圣经的宇宙观——无论多么不充分——仍在表达世界存在以及人类从中诞生这一事实的意义，而科学的图景则否认世界有任何意义，甚至忽略了我们对这个世界所有最重要的体验。认为世界具有某种意义，这种意义与我们作为世界上唯一负有道德责任的生物的使命息息相关，这一假设是经验超自然层面的一个重要例证，基督教对宇宙的诠释正是探索和发展这种超自然层面的。在第十三章中，我将展示我们如何通过连续的阶段，从对进化论的科学研究，到将其解读为通往上帝的线索。

Of course, an event which has in fact never taken place can have no supernatural significance; and whether it has taken place or not must be established by factual evidence. Hence the religious force of biblical criticism, shaking or, alternatively, corroborating certain facts which form the main themes of Christianity. But evidence that a fact has not occurred may sometimes leave largely unimpaired the religious truth conveyed by a narrative describing its occurrence. The book of Genesis and its great pictorial illustrations, like the frescoes of Michelangelo, remain a far more intelligent account of the nature and origin of the universe than the representation of the world as a chance collocation of atoms. For the biblical cosmology continues to express—however inadequately—the significance of the fact that the world exists and that man has emerged from it, while the scientific picture denies any meaning to the world, and indeed ignores all our most vital experience of this world. The assumption that the world has some meaning which is linked to our own calling as the only morally responsible beings in the world, is an important example of the supernatural aspect of experience which Christian interpretations of the universe explore and develop. In chapter 13, I shall show how we can arrive by continuous stages from the scientific study of evolution to its interpretation as a clue to God.

基督教是一项进步的事业。我们日益拓展的知识视野，应当为宗教信仰开辟新的前景。《圣经》，尤其是保罗的教义，或许仍蕴藏着意想不到的教诲；而我们时代的新物理学和逻辑哲学运动所展现出的现代思想的更高精确性和更自觉的灵活性，或许很快就会引发概念上的改革，这些改革将基于现代宗教以外的经验，更新和澄清人与上帝的关系。一个伟大的宗教发现时代或许就在我们面前。

Christianity is a progressive enterprise. Our vastly enlarged perspectives of knowledge should open up fresh vistas of religious faith. The Bible, and the Pauline doctrine in particular, may be still pregnant with unsuspected lessons; and the greater precision and more conscious flexibility of modern thought, shown by the new physics and the logico- philosophic movements of our age, may presently engender conceptual reforms which will renew and clarify, on the grounds of modern extra-religious experience, man’s relation to God. An era of great religious discoveries may lie before us.

在进一步探讨之前，让我先总结一下关于宗教怀疑的结论。基督教信仰可能以两种方式受到怀疑的攻击。其内在证据可能受到怀疑，就像数学中的概念创新或新颖的艺术作品可能被认为是不健全的一样。我们可能拒绝，或者至少犹豫，进入它们所提供的精神生活，要么是因为缺乏欣赏，要么——更强烈地说——是因为害怕失去对现实的把握。类似的怀疑也适用于每一种启发式视野：我们总是意识到它附带着某种风险。这种怀疑是接受的犹豫。我们不愿接受提供给我们心灵的居所，可能是懦弱的，也可能是明智的，因此我们最终可能会被证明是迟钝或鲁莽的。然而，我们无法用任何可以用来证明或反驳明确声明的测试来检验我们的行为。因此，我们不可能像怀疑明确声明那样怀疑我们所做的事情（或宣称我们做的事情）。我们的怀疑必须保留在我们自己的心理行为中。

Let me sum up my conclusions about religious doubt before going further. The Christian faith can be attacked by doubt in two ways. Its internal evidence can be doubted in the sense in which conceptual innovations in mathematics or novel works of art can be held to be unsound. We may refuse, or at least hesitate, to enter on the mental life which they offer, either for want of appreciation for it or—more forcibly—for fear of losing our hold on reality. A similar kind of doubt applies to every heuristic vision: we are always conscious of some hazard attached to it. This kind of doubt is the hesitancy of an acceptance. Our reluctance to accept the habitation offered to our minds may be craven or wise, and so we may prove eventually to have been dull or rash. Yet we can apply to our action no test of the kind to which we can appeal for proving or disproving an explicit declaratory statement. There is therefore no possibility either for doubting what we do (or declare we do) in the sense in which an explicit statement can be doubted. Our doubt must remain intrinsic to a mental act of our own.

基督教信仰的本质也在于其所追求的目标无法实现。它必须始终痛苦地意识到其内在的可疑性。但既然这是信仰的一部分，它就不会贬损信仰。然而，通过对我们赖以部署信仰的清晰框架进行明确的批判性检验，基督教信仰这种不可或缺的内在可疑性可能会加剧，甚至达到彻底摧毁我们信仰的程度。因为，这一框架能否以臣服于上帝的方式引导其自身理解，在很大程度上取决于其构成要素的陈述的说服力，正如一组线索能否基于这些线索引导启发式​​视野，取决于用作线索的事实的可靠性。因此，针对作为事实的线索的怀疑可能会动摇依赖这些线索的体系的内在证据。明确的怀疑可能会加剧我们对接受的内在怀疑，直至将其转化为彻底的拒绝。

It is also part of the Christian faith that its striving is unfulfillable. It must always remain painfully conscious of its inherent dubiety. But since this is part of the faith, it does not derogate from it. Yet this indispensable internal dubiety of the Christian faith can be increased, even to the point of destroying our faith altogether, by explicit critical tests of the articulate framework on which we rely for deploying our faith. For the power of this framework to induce its own comprehension in terms of a surrender to God depends to an important extent on the convincing power of the statements which are its elements, in the same way as the power of a set of clues for inducing a heuristic vision based on these clues will depend on the reliability of the facts used as clues. Doubts directed against the clues as facts may thus shake the internal evidence of the system relying on them. Explicit doubts may intensify the intrinsic doubts of our acceptance to the point of converting it into a complete rejection.

因此，在过去300年中，在历史和科学知识不断发展的冲击下，宗教信仰的弱化体现了怀疑的巨大影响。它摧毁了事物的宗教意义，却没有用其他意义来完全弥补这种损失，而信仰的总量——所有意义的源泉——实际上也减少了。如果宇宙真的毫无意义，那么摧毁宗教信仰就完全有道理了。由于我不相信宇宙毫无意义，我只能承认，鉴于当时宗教教义所依据的依据，拒绝宗教是合理的。今天，我们应该感谢理性主义者对宗教的长期攻击，他们迫使我们重新审视基督教信仰的根基。但这丝毫不能证明，将怀疑视为消除谬误的万能溶剂，不会触及真理。因为所有真理都只是信仰的外在极点，而摧毁所有信仰就等于否定所有真理。尽管宗教信仰的表述往往比其他信仰更加教条，但这并非必要。基督教广泛的教义框架源于数个世纪以来持续不断的巧妙努力，旨在将基督徒早已践行的信仰公理化。鉴于基督教信仰以其高度的想象力和情感力量掌控着整个人，并将人与宇宙联系起来，这些信仰的具体阐述远比算术公理或自然科学前提更加丰富多彩。但它们属于同一类陈述，履行着类似的信托职能。

The weakening of religious beliefs under the impact of advancing historical and scientific knowledge during the past 300 years represents, therefore, a case in which the effect of doubt was substantial. It destroyed the religious meaning of things without fully compensating for this loss by a different meaning, and the total volume of belief, from which all meaning flows, was effectively reduced. If the universe were in fact meaningless, the destruction of religious beliefs would have been fully justified. Since I do not believe that the universe is meaningless, I can admit only that the rejection of religion was reasonable in view of the grounds on which religious doctrines were asserted at the time. Today we should be grateful for the prolonged attacks made by rationalists on religion for forcing us to renew the grounds of the Christian faith. But this does not remotely justify the acknowledgment of doubt as the universal solvent of error which will leave truth untouched behind. For all truth is but the external pole of belief, and to destroy all belief would be to deny all truth. Though religious beliefs are often formulated more dogmatically than other beliefs, this is not essential. The extensive dogmatic framework of Christianity arose from ingenious efforts, sustained through many centuries, to axiomatize the faith already practised by Christians. In view of the high imaginative and emotional powers by which Christian beliefs control the whole person and relate him to the universe, the specification of these beliefs is much more colourful than are the axioms of arithmetic or the premisses of natural science. But they belong to the same class of statements, performing kindred fiduciary functions.

我们的精神存在主要归功于艺术作品、道德、宗教崇拜、科学理论以及其他清晰的体系，我们将其视为我们的居所和精神发展的土壤。客观主义完全歪曲了我们对真理的理解，它高举我们能够认知和证明的事物，却用模棱两可的表述掩盖我们所知道但无法证明的一切，即使后者的知识是我们能够证明的一切的基础，并且最终必须将其封存。客观主义试图将我们的思维限制在少数可论证、因而也明显可质疑的事物上，从而忽视了决定我们整个心灵存在的非批判性选择，并使我们无法承认这些至关重要的选择。

We owe our mental existence predominantly to works of art, morality, religious worship, scientific theory and other articulate systems which we accept as our dwelling place and as the soil of our mental development. Objectivism has totally falsified our conception of truth, by exalting what we can know and prove, while covering up with ambiguous utterances all that we know and cannot prove, even though the latter knowledge underlies, and must ultimately set its seal to, all that we can prove. In trying to restrict our minds to the few things that are demonstrable, and therefore explicitly dubitable, it has overlooked the a-critical choices which determine the whole being of our minds and has rendered us incapable of acknowledging these vital choices.

 

 

  1. 内隐信念
  2. IMPLICIT BELIEFS

怀疑作为一种原则的局限性，可以通过将我们的探究延伸到我们以概念框架形式持有的信念（这些信念以我们的语言表达）来进一步阐述。我们最根深蒂固的信念，取决于我们用来诠释经验的习语，以及我们用来构建清晰表达体系的习语。308我们正式宣布的信念最终能够被认为是真实的，只是因为我们在逻辑上预先接受了一组特定的术语，我们对现实的所有引用都是从这组术语构建出来的。

The limitations of doubting as a principle can be elaborated further by extending our enquiry to the beliefs held in the form of our conceptual framework, as expressed in our language. Our most deeply ingrained convictions are determined by the idiom in which we interpret our experience and in terms of which we erect our articulate systems.308 Our formally declared beliefs can be held to be true in the last resort only because of our logically anterior acceptance of a particular set of terms, from which all our references to reality are constructed.

原始人拥有独特的信仰体系，这些信仰根植于他们的概念框架，并反映在他们的语言中，这一事实最早由列维-布吕尔在本世纪初强调。埃文斯-普里查德近期关于阿赞德信仰的著作309证实并进一步明确了这一观点。作者对原始非洲人展现出的智慧力量感到震撼，他们坚守自己的信仰，对抗着在欧洲人看来公然驳斥他们的证据。一个恰当的例子是赞德人对毒药神谕力量的信仰。神谕通过一种名为本格（benge）的有毒物质对家禽的影响来解答问题。这种神谕毒药是从以传统方式采集的蔓藤中提取的，据说只有在适当的仪式中用言语表达后才会生效。我们被告知，阿赞德人没有正式的强制性教义来强制人们相信巫医及其毒药神谕的实践，但他们对这些信仰的信仰更加坚定，因为他们根植于一种将所有相关事实都解释为巫术和神谕力量的习语中。埃文斯-普里查德举了各种例子来证明他们这种隐性信仰的奇特坚韧。

The fact that primitive people hold distinctive systems of beliefs inherent in their conceptual framework and reflected in their language was first stated with emphasis by Lévy-Brühl earlier in this century. The more recent work of Evans-Pritchard on the beliefs of Azande309 has borne out and has given further precision to this view. The author is struck by the intellectual force shown by the primitive African in upholding his beliefs against evidence which to the European seems flagrantly to refute them. An instance in point is the Zande belief in the powers of the poison- oracle. The oracle answers questions through the effects on a fowl of a poisonous substance called benge. The oracle-poison is extracted from a creeper gathered in a traditional manner, which is supposed to become effective only after it has been addressed in the words of an appropriate ritual. Azande—we are told—have no formal and coercive doctrine to enforce belief in witch-doctors and their practice of the poison-oracle, but their belief in these is the more firmly held for being embedded in an idiom which interprets all relevant facts in terms of witchcraft and oracular powers. Evans-Pritchard gives various examples of this peculiar tenacity of their implicit belief.

假设神谕在回答某个问题时回答“是”，紧接着又对同一个问题回答“否”。在我们看来，这往往会使神谕完全失去可信度，但赞德文化为这种自相矛盾的情况提供了许多现成的解释。埃文斯-普里查德列举了不少于八种对其信仰的次要阐述，阿赞德人会据此解释神谕的失败。他们可能会认为，采集了错误的毒药，或者违反了禁忌，又或者毒藤生长的森林的主人被激怒了，于是为了报复而破坏了毒药；等等。

Suppose that the oracle in answer to a particular question says ‘Yes’, and immediately afterwards says ‘No’ to the same question. In our eyes this would tend to discredit the oracle altogether, but Zande culture provides a number of ready explanations for such self-contradictions. Evans-Pritchard lists no less than eight secondary elaborations of their beliefs by which Azande will account for the oracle’s failure. They may assume that the wrong variety of poison had been gathered, or a breach of taboo committed, or that the owners of the forest where the poisonous creeper grows had been angered and avenged themselves by spoiling the poison; and so on.

我们的作者进一步描述了阿赞德人如何抵制任何关于本格可能是天然毒药的说法。他告诉我们，他经常问阿赞德人，如果他们给一只家禽注射神谕毒药而不致于致病，或者如果他们给一只已经从常规剂量中恢复过来的家禽注射额外的毒药，会发生什么。“赞德人，”他继续说道，“不知道会发生什么，也不关心会发生什么；没有人会愚蠢到浪费优质的神谕毒药去做这种毫无意义的实验，这种实验只有……

Our author describes further the manner in which Azande resist any suggestion that benge may be a natural poison. He often asked Azande, he tells us, what would happen if they were to administer oracle-poison to a fowl without delivering an address, or if they were to administer an extra portion of poison to a fowl which has recovered from the usual doses. ‘The Zande’—he continues—‘does not know what would happen and is not interested in what would happen; no one has been fool enough to waste good oracle-poison in making such pointless experiments which only a

欧洲人可以想象……如果一个欧洲人做了一个实验，在他看来，证明了赞德的观点是错误的，他们会惊讶于欧洲人的轻信。如果家禽死了，他们会简单地说这不是什么好东西。家禽死亡的事实本身就向他们证明了它的糟糕。310

European could imagine…. Were a European to make a test which in his view proved Zande opinion wrong they would stand amazed at the credulity of the European. If the fowl died they would simply say that it was not good benge. The very fact of the fowl dying proves to them its badness.’310

阿赞德人对我们看来至关重要的事实视而不见，这背后隐藏着非凡的智慧。“他们运用自身信仰的语言进行推理，非常出色”（埃文斯-普里查德说道），“但他们无法在信仰之外进行推理，也无法与信仰相悖，因为他们没有其他语言来表达自己的想法。” 311

This blindness of Azande to the facts which to us seem decisive is sustained by remarkable ingenuity. ‘They reason excellently in the idiom of their beliefs,’ (says Evans-Pritchard), ‘but they cannot reason outside, or against, their beliefs because they have no other idiom in which to express their thoughts.’311

我们的客观主义不容许任何公开的信仰宣言，它迫使现代信仰呈现出隐晦的形式，就像阿赞德人的信仰一样。无人否认，那些掌握了这些信仰所蕴含的习语的人，也确实能够在这些习语中巧妙地进行推理，即便——同样像阿赞德人一样——他们毫不犹豫地忽略了习语未涵盖的一切。我将引用两段文字，以说明基于以下原则的两个现代解释框架的高度稳定性：

Our objectivism, which tolerates no open declaration of faith, has forced modern beliefs to take on implicit forms, like those of Azande. And no one will deny that those who have mastered the idioms in which these beliefs are entailed do also reason most ingeniously within these idioms, even while—again like Azande—they unhesitatingly ignore all that the idiom does not cover. I shall quote two passages to illustrate the high stability of two modern interpretative frameworks, based on these principles:

 

 

我的党性教育让我的头脑中充满了精妙的缓冲机制和弹性防御机制，以至于我所看到和听到的一切都会自动转化为符合预设模式的模式。（A·库斯特勒，《失败的上帝》，伦敦，1950年，第68页）

My party education had equipped my mind with such elaborate shockabsorbing buffers and elastic defences that everything seen and heard became automatically transformed to fit a preconceived pattern. (A.Koestler, in The God that Failed, London, 1950, p. 68.)

弗洛伊德逐渐发展起来的理论体系如此连贯，以至于一旦人们固守其中，就很难做出不带其思维方式偏见的观察。（卡伦·霍妮，《精神分析新方法》，伦敦，1939年，第7页）

The system of theories which Freud has gradually developed is so consistent that when one is once entrenched in them it is difficult to make observations unbiased by his way of thinking. (Karen Horney, New Ways of Psychoanalysis, London, 1939, p. 7.)

 

 

前者出自一位前马克思主义者之口，后者出自一位前弗洛伊德学派作家之口。在他们仍然接受马克思或弗洛伊德（视情况而定）的概念框架时，这些作家会将该框架包罗万象的解释力视为其真实性的证据；只有当他们对它失去信心时，才会感到其解释力过于强大且似是而非。我们将在对不同概念体系的解释力评估中再次看到同样的差异，这体现在我们接受或拒绝这些体系的过程中。

The first of these statements is by a former Marxist, the second by a former Freudian writer. At the time when they still accepted as valid the conceptual framework of Marx or of Freud—as the case may be—these writers would have regarded the all-embracing interpretative powers of this framework as evidence of its truth; only when losing faith in it did they feel that its powers were excessive and specious. We shall see the same difference reappear in our appraisals of the interpretative power of different conceptual systems, as part of our acceptance or rejection of these systems.

 

 

  1. 稳定的三个方面
  2. THREE ASPECTS OF STABILITY

一种信仰习语如何抵御不利证据的影响，可以分为三个方面来看待，每个方面都体现了阿赞德人在面对我们认为应该使其信仰失效的情况时，如何坚守信仰。其他信仰体系中也存在类似的案例。

The resistance of an idiom of belief against the impact of adverse evidence may be regarded under three headings, each of which is illustrated by the manner in which Azande retain their beliefs in the face of situations which in our view should invalidate them. Analogous cases can be adduced from other systems of beliefs.

赞德信仰的稳定性首先源于这样一个事实：对它们的反对意见可以被逐一驳斥。内隐信仰体系之所以能够逐一驳斥有效反对意见，是因为这种体系具有循环性。我的意思是，用这样的概念框架来解释任何特定新主题所具有的说服力，是基于过去将同一框架应用于大量目前尚未考虑的其他主题；而如果现在对这些其他主题中的任何一个提出质疑，那么对它们的解释反过来又会同样依赖于对所有其他主题的解释。埃文斯-普里查德在赞德对神秘概念的信仰中观察到了这一点。“经验与一个神秘概念之间的矛盾可以通过参考其他神秘概念来解释。” 312

The stability of Zande beliefs is due, in the first place, to the fact that objections to them can be met one by one. This power of a system of implicit beliefs to defeat valid objections one by one is due to the circularity of such systems. By this I mean that the convincing power possessed by the interpretation of any particular new topic in terms of such a conceptual framework is based on past applications of the same framework to a great number of other topics not now under consideration, while if any of these other topics were questioned now, their interpretation in its turn would similarly rely for support on the interpretation of all the others. Evans-Pritchard observes this for Zande beliefs in mystical notions. ‘The contradiction between experience and one mystical notion is explained by reference to other mystical notions.’312

只要每个疑问依次被驳倒，其效果就是强化它所反对的基本信念。埃文斯-普里查德写道：“读者不妨思考一下，任何能够彻底推翻赞德人所有关于神谕力量主张的论据。如果将其转化为赞德人的思维方式，它将有助于支持他们的整个信仰体系。”313因此，概念系统的循环性往往会通过每次接触新主题而得到强化。

So long as each doubt is defeated in its turn, its effect is to strengthen the fundamental convictions against which it was raised. ‘Let the reader consider (writes Evans-Pritchard) any argument that would utterly demolish all Zande claims for the power of the oracle. If it were translated into Zande modes of thought it would serve to support their entire structure of belief.’313 Thus the circularity of a conceptual system tends to reinforce itself by every contact with a fresh topic.

任何特定语言所体现的宇宙理论的循环性，其基本体现在于该语言词典的存在。例如，如果你怀疑某个英语名词、动词、形容词或副词在英语中是否有意义，英语词典会通过解释其他名词、动词、形容词和副词来消除这种疑虑，而这些名词、动词、形容词和副词的意义暂时不会受到质疑。此类探究将使我们对语言的使用更加坚定。

The circularity of the theory of the universe embodied in any particular language is manifested in an elementary fashion by the existence of a dictionary of the language. If you doubt, for example, that a particular English noun, verb, adjective or adverb has any meaning in English, an English dictionary dispels this doubt by a definition using other nouns, verbs, adjectives and adverbs, the meaningfulness of which is not doubted for the moment. Enquiries of this kind will increasingly confirm us in the use of a language.

还要记住我们关于数学公理化的发现；即它仅仅声明了数学推理实践中隐含的信念。因此，公理化的系统是循环的：我们先前对数学的接受赋予了它的公理权威，然后我们依次从中推导出所有的数学证明。将数学公式或任何演绎系统的断言语句划分为公理和定理，实际上在很大程度上是惯例，因为我们通常可以用定理替换部分或全部公理，并从中推导出先前的公理作为定理。演绎系统的每个断言都可以由其他断言来证明，或者被证明为其他断言的公理。因此，如果我们依次怀疑每个断言，每个断言都会被发现通过循环得到证实，而对每个连续怀疑的反驳都会加强我们对整个系统的信念。

Remember also what we have found about the axiomatization of mathematics; namely that it merely declares the beliefs implied in the practice of mathematical reasoning. The axiomatized system is therefore circular: our anterior acceptance of mathematics lends authority to its axioms, from which we then deduce in turn all mathematical demonstrations. The division of mathematical formulae, or of the asserted sentences of any deductive system, into axioms and theorems is indeed largely conventional, for we can usually replace some or all of the axioms by theorems and derive from these the previous axioms as theorems. Every assertion of a deductive system can be demonstrated by, or else shown to be implied as axioms of, the others. Therefore, if we doubt each assertion in its turn each is found confirmed by circularity, and the refutation of each consecutive doubt results in strengthening our belief in the system as a whole.

当一群持有同一套预设的人互相印证彼此对经验的解读时，循环论证就通过角色划分来运作。以下是列维-布吕尔收集的南非探险家L.Magyar的故事，他认为这个故事很典型。 314

Circularity operates by divided roles when a number of persons holding the same set of pre-suppositions mutually confirm each other’s interpretation of experience. Take the following story of a South African explorer, L.Magyar, collected by Lévy-Brühl who regards it as typical.314

两位非洲土著，S. 和 K.，去森林采蜜。S. 发现四棵大树上结满了蜂蜜，而 K. 只找到一棵。K. 回家哀叹自己的厄运，而 S. 却很幸运。与此同时，S. 回到森林采蜜时，遭到狮子袭击，被狮子撕成了碎片。

Two African natives, S. and K., went to the wood to gather honey. S. found four big trees full of honey, whilst K. could find only one. K. went home bewailing his ill luck, while S. had been so fortunate. Meanwhile S., having returned to the wood to bring away the honey, was attacked by a lion and torn to pieces.

狮子受害者的亲属立即前往占卜师那里，询问谁该为他的死负责。占卜师多次求问神谕，声称K.嫉妒S.丰收的蜂蜜，化身为狮子进行报复。被告坚决否认有罪，酋长下令以毒刑来裁决此事。“事情随后照常进行，”探险家写道，“毒刑对被告不利，他认罪并屈服于酷刑……对于提出指控的占卜师、下令进行毒刑审判的王子、旁观者以及化身为狮子的K.本人来说，这项指控似乎理所当然，事实上，除了碰巧在场的欧洲人之外，所有其他人都觉得这很自然。” 315

The relatives of the lion’s victim at once went to the soothsayer to discover who was responsible for his death. The soothsayer consults the oracle several times and declares that K., jealous of S.’s rich harvest of honey, assumed the form of a lion in order to avenge himself. The accused denied his guilt strenuously and the chieftain ordered the matter to be settled by the ordeal of poison. ‘Matters then followed their usual course’—says the explorer’s account—‘the ordeal was unfavourable to the accused, he confessed and succumbed to torture…. The accusation appears quite natural to the soothsayer who formulates it, the prince who orders the trial by ordeal, the crowd of bystanders and to K. himself who had been transformed into a lion, in fact to everybody except the European who happens to be present.’315

我们很清楚，K. 从未真正经历过变成狮子并将 S. 撕成碎片的经历，所以起初他否认自己做过这件事。但他面临着压倒性的不利于自己的证据。他与原告共享的解释框架并不包含意外死亡的概念；如果一个人被狮子吞噬，背后必定有某种有效的原因，例如对手的嫉妒。这使他成为明显的嫌疑人，而当他一直信赖的神谕证实了这一怀疑时，他再也无法抗拒自己有罪的证据，便承认自己变成狮子并吞噬了 S.。这结束了整个论证过程，并证实了进行论证的巫术框架，从而增强了该框架对下一个即将纳入其管辖范围的案件的理解力。

It is clear to us that K. had not actually experienced turning into a lion and tearing S. to pieces, and so at first he denied having done so. But he is confronted with an overwhelming case against himself. The interpretative framework which he shares with his accusers does not include the conception of accidental death; if a man is devoured by a lion there must be some effective reason behind it, such as the envy of a rival. This makes him an obvious suspect and when the oracle, which he has always trusted, confirms the suspicion, he can no longer resist the evidence of his guilt and he confesses having turned into a lion and having devoured S. This closes the circle of the argument and confirms the magical framework in which it was conducted, and it thus enhances the powers of this framework for assimilating the next case which will come under its purview.

经历过俄国蓄意破坏审判中招供程序的共产党员，也描述了类似的循环。囚犯通常一开始会抵制指控，但当预审法官从各个方面持续不断地向他灌输指控，以及从他以前的同伙那里逼供出的证据时，他开始屈服于针对他本人的指控的说服力。316他过去常常以谴责他人的理由来谴责自己，现在他却倾向于用这些理由来谴责自己——这样就形成了一个循环，再次证实了这些理由，并使它们在下一次谴责中比以往任何时候都更加有力。

Communists who have experienced the procedure which leads to confessions in Russian sabotage trials have described a similar circularity. The prisoner will usually resist the accusation to start with, but when it is persistently borne in upon him from all sides by the examining magistrate and by the evidence extorted from his former associates, he begins to give way to the convincing power of the case against himself.316 On the grounds on which he had habitually condemned others he tends now to condemn himself—and thus close the circle which once more confirms these grounds and makes them stronger than ever for the next occasion.

稳定性的第二个方面源于解释系统运作的循环的自动扩展。它能够轻松地提供系统的详尽阐述，涵盖几乎所有可能出现的情况，无论这些情况乍一看多么令人尴尬。具有这种自我扩展能力的科学理论有时被描述为本轮式的，这与托勒密和哥白尼理论中用来将行星运动表示为匀速圆周运动的本轮有关。所有主要的解释框架都具有本轮结构，为应对棘手情况提供了一系列补充解释。赞德信仰的本轮特性已在上文中得到体现，即人们可以随时使用八个不同的补充假设来解释神谕中两个连续答案中截然相反的自相矛盾之处。

A second aspect of stability arises from an automatic expansion of the circle in which an interpretative system operates. It readily supplies elaborations of the system which will cover almost any conceivable eventuality, however embarrassing this may appear at first sight. Scientific theories which possess this self-expanding capacity are sometimes described as epicyclical, in allusion to the epicycles that were used in the Ptolemaic and Copernican theory to represent planetary motions in terms of uniform circular motions. All major interpretative frameworks have an epicyclical structure which supplies a reserve of subsidiary explanations for difficult situations. The epicyclical character of Zande beliefs was shown above by the ready availability of eight different subsidiary assumptions for explaining a point-blank self- contradiction in two consecutive answers of an oracle.

第三，赞德信仰的稳定性体现在它拒绝任何竞争观念的根基。支持它的经验只能逐一列举。但一个可以取代赞德迷信的新观念，例如自然因果关系，只有通过一系列相关的事例才能确立，而如果由于缺乏赋予其意义的概念而忽略了每一个新观念，那么这些证据就无法在人们的头脑中积累。埃文斯-普里查德试图说服阿赞德人，让他们相信本格是一种天然毒药，其效力与服用时通常伴随的咒语无关。阿赞德人的行为体现了我们通常对那些我们无法理解的事物所抱有的那种轻蔑的冷漠态度。威廉·詹姆斯写道：“对于那些远远超出我们理解范围、我们既没有概念来参照它们，也没有标准来衡量它们的事物，我们既不会感到好奇，也不会感到惊奇。”他回忆说，达尔文航行中的费吉人对小船感到惊奇，但却没有注意到停泊在他们面前的大船。317最近的一个例子是苏联驻加拿大大使馆密码员伊戈尔·古津科 (Igor Gouzenko)，他冒着生命危险，连续两天（1945 年 9 月 5 日和 6 日）在渥太华展示有关苏联原子间谍的文件，试图引起人们的注意，但最终徒劳无功。

The stability of Zande beliefs is manifested, thirdly, in the way it denies to any rival conception the ground in which it might take root. Experiences which support it could be adduced only one by one. But a new conception, e.g. that of natural causation, which would take the place of Zande superstitution, could be established only by a whole series of relevant instances, and such evidence cannot accumulate in the minds of people if each of them is disregarded in its turn for lack of the concept which would lend significance to it. The behaviour of Azande whom Evans-Pritchard tried to convince that benge was a natural poison which owed none of its effectiveness to the incantations customarily accompanying its administration, illustrates the kind of contemptuous indifference with which we normally regard things of which we have no conception. ‘We feel neither curiosity nor wonder’, writes William James, ‘concerning things so far beyond us that we have no concepts to refer them to or standards by which to measure them.’ The Feugians in Darwin’s voyage, he recalls, wondered at the small boats, but paid no attention to the big ship lying at anchor in front of them.317 A more recent instance of this occurred when Igor Gouzenko, cypher clerk of the Soviet Embassy in Canada, tried in vain for two days in succession (September 5th and 6th, 1945) to attract attention to the documents concerning Soviet atomic espionage which he was showing round in Ottawa at the risk of his life.

内隐信念的第三种防御机制可以称为抑制成核原则。它与循环和自我扩张的运作相辅相成。虽然循环和自我扩张可以保护现有的信念体系免受任何不利证据引起的怀疑，但抑制成核原则则阻止了任何基于此类证据的替代概念的萌芽。

This third defences mechanism of implicit beliefs may be called the principle of suppressed nucleation. It is complementary to the operations of circularity and self-expansion. While these protect an existing system of beliefs against doubts arising from any adverse piece of evidence, suppressed nucleation prevents the germination of any alternative concepts on the basis of any such evidence.

循环性，加上随时可用的本轮式阐述，以及由此产生的对任何竞争性概念发展的抑制，赋予概念框架一定程度的稳定性，我们可以将这种稳定性描述为其完整性的衡量标准。我们可以承认一种语言及其所传达的概念体系的完整性或全面性——就像我们对阿赞德人巫术信仰的理解一样——但这并不意味着该体系就是正确的。

Circularity, combined with a readily available reserve of epicyclical elaborations and the consequent suppression in the germ of any rival conceptual development, lends a degree of stability to a conceptual framework which we may describe as the measure of its completeness. We may acknowledge the completeness or comprehensiveness of a language and the system .of conceptions conveyed by it—as we do in respect to Azande beliefs in witchcraft—without in any way implying that the system is correct.

 

 

  1. 科学信念的稳定性
  2. THE STABILITY OF SCIENTIFIC BELIEFS

我们不认同阿赞德人对毒药神谕力量的信仰，也拒绝他们的许多其他信仰，摒弃神秘主义观念，代之以自然主义的解释。但我们或许可以否认，我们对赞德迷信的拒绝源于任何普遍的怀疑原则。

We do not share the beliefs of Azande in the power of poison-oracles, and we reject a great many of their other beliefs, discarding mystical conceptions and replacing them by naturalistic explanations. But we may yet deny that our rejection of Zande superstitions is the outcome of any general principle of doubt.

因为我们目前接受的自然主义体系的稳定性恰恰建立在相同的逻辑结构之上。任何特定科学概念与经验事实之间的矛盾，都可以通过其他科学概念来解释；存在着大量现成的科学假设，可以用来解释任何可以想象的事件。科学以其循环性为保障，并进一步以其本轮性为保障，可以否定，或至少将其视为毫无科学意义的整个经验领域，而这些领域在非科学人士看来既庞大又至关重要。 318

For the stability of the naturalistic system which we currently accept instead rests on the same logical structure. Any contradiction between a particular scientific notion and the facts of experience will be explained by other scientific notions; there is a ready reserve of possible scientific hypotheses available to explain any conceivable event. Secured by its circularity and defended further by its epicyclical reserves, science may deny, or at least cast aside as of no scientific interest, whole ranges of experience which to the unscientific mind appear both massive and vital.318

我所概括的客观主义的科学观的局限性，一直是本书反复出现的主题。我试图突破这种高度稳定的框架，找到客观主义阻碍我们进入的、通往现实的合法途径，我将在不久的将来进一步探讨。目前，我只想举几个例子，说明在科学内部，理论相对于经验的稳定性是如何通过本轮储备来维持的，这些储备从一开始就抑制了其他概念的产生；回想起来，这种方法在某些情况下似乎是正确的，在其他情况下则可能是错误的。

The restrictions of the scientific outlook which I summed up as objectivism have been recurrent themes throughout this book. My attempt to break out of this highly stabilized framework and to enter avenues of legitimate access to reality from which objectivism debars us will be presently pursued further. At the moment I only wish to give some illustrations to show how, within science itself, the stability of theories against experience is maintained by epicyclical reserves which suppress alternative conceptions in the germ; a procedure which in retrospect will appear right in some instances and wrong in others.

阿伦尼乌斯于1887年提出的电解离解理论，假设溶液中电解质的离解态与未离解态之间存在化学平衡。从一开始，测量结果就表明，这只适用于像乙酸这样的弱电解质，而不适用于像食盐或硫酸这样非常突出的一类强电解质。三十多年来，这些差异被仔细测量并记录在教科书中，但从未有人想到要质疑他们如此公然反驳的理论。科学家们满足于谈论“强电解质的异常现象”，丝毫不怀疑它们的行为实际上受制于它们未能遵循的规律。我仍然记得，大约在1919年，我第一次听到有人提出，这些异常现象应该被视为对阿伦尼乌斯所假设的平衡的反驳，并应该用另一种理论来解释时，我感到多么惊讶。直到这一替代概念（基于离子之间的静电相互作用）被成功详细阐述后，先前的理论才被普遍抛弃。

The theory of electrolytic dissociation proposed in 1887 by Arrhenius assumed a chemical equilibrium between the dissociated and the undissociated forms of an electrolyte in solution. From the very start, the measurements showed that this was true only for weak electrolytes like acetic acid, but not for the very prominent group of strong electrolytes, like common salt or sulphuric acid. For more than thirty years the discrepancies were carefully measured and tabulated in textbooks, yet no one thought of calling in question the theory which they so flagrantly contradicted. Scientists were satisfied with speaking of the ‘anomalies of strong electrolytes’, without doubting for a moment that their behaviour was in fact governed by the law that they failed to obey. I can still remember my own amazement when, about 1919, I first heard the idea mooted that the anomalies were to be regarded as a refutation of the equilibrium postulated by Arrhenius and to be explained by a different theory. Not until this alternative conception (based on the mutual electrostatic interaction of the ions) was successfully elaborated in detail, was the previous theory generally abandoned.

与当前科学观念相矛盾的观点，常常被冠以“异常”之名；这是任何理论中本轮储备中最便捷的假设。我们已经看到，阿赞德人如何利用类似的借口来应对毒物预言的矛盾之处。在科学领域，当后续对相反证据的修正或对原始理论的深化解释了这些异常现象时，这种做法往往被证明是极其合理的。对阿伦尼乌斯强电解质理论的修改就是一个很好的例子。

Contradictions to current scientific conceptions are often disposed of by calling them ‘anomalies’; this is the handiest assumption in the epicyclical reserve of any theory. We have seen how Azande make use of similar excuses to meet the inconsistencies of poison-oracles. In science this process has often proved brilliantly justified, when subsequent revisions of the adverse evidence or a deepening of the original theory explained the anomalies. The modification of Arrhenius’s theory for strong electrolytes is a case in point.

另一个例子或许可以说明，一系列曾经被认为是重要科学事实的观察结果，几年后就完全被否定并被遗忘，既没有被证伪，也没有经过新的检验，仅仅是因为科学的概念框架发生了巨大的变化，使得这些事实不再显得可信。上世纪末，HBBaker 报告了许多观察结果。319强力干燥能够阻止一些通常极快的化学反应，并降低多种常用化学品的蒸发速度。贝克在之后的三十多年里不断发表关于这种干燥效应的实例。320斯米茨从荷兰报告了大量据称与此相关的现象321来自德国的一些非常引人注目的例证。322HBBaker有时只需将样品干燥长达三年即可使其失去反应活性；因此，当一些作者未能重现他的结果时，可以合理地假设他们没有达到相同的干燥程度。因此，当时几乎没有人怀疑，观察到的强力干燥效应是真实的，并且反映了所有化学变化的一个基本特征。

Another example may illustrate how a series of observations which at one time were held to be important scientific facts, were a few years later completely discredited and committed to oblivion, without ever having been disproved or indeed newly tested, simply because the conceptual framework of science had meanwhile so altered that the facts no longer appeared credible. Towards the end of the last century numerous observations were reported by H.B.Baker319 on the power of intensive drying to stop some normally extremely rapid chemical reactions and to reduce the rate of evaporation of a number of commonly used chemicals. Baker went on publishing further instances of this drying effect for more than thirty years.320 A large number of allegedly allied phenomena were reported from Holland by Smits321 and Some very striking demonstrations of it came from Germany.322 H.B.Baker could render his samples unreactive sometimes only by drying them for periods up to three years; so when some authors failed to reproduce his results it was reasonable to assume that they had not achieved the same degree of desiccation. Consequently, there was little doubt at the time that the observed effects of intensive drying were true and that they reflected a fundamental feature of all chemical change.

这些在1900年至1930年间引起人们极大兴趣的实验，如今几乎已被人们遗忘。那些不假思索地继续汇编已发表数据的化学教科书，仍然详细记录着贝克的观察结果，只是补充说，这些观察结果的有效性“尚未确定”。 323或者“他的一些发现受到后来研究者的质疑，但这项技术很难”。324但是活跃的科学家不再对这些现象感兴趣，因为根据他们目前对化学过程的理解，他们确信其中大多数一定是虚假的，并且，如果有些是真实的，那么它们很可能是由于琐碎的原因造成的。325既然如此，我们现在对这些实验的态度，就如同阿赞德人对待埃文斯-普里查德提出的不附带咒语的神谕毒药效果的建议一样。我们耸耸肩，拒绝在这些显然毫无意义的探究上浪费时间。科学界和阿赞德人选择关注事实的过程确实相同；但我相信，科学在应用科学时往往是正确的，而阿赞德人用它来维护他们的迷信时，则是完全错误的。326

Today these experiments, which aroused so much interest from 1900 to 1930, are almost forgotten. Textbooks of chemistry which thoughtlessly go on compiling published data still record Baker’s observations in detail, merely adding that their validity ‘is not yet certainly established’,323 or that ‘some (of his) findings are disputed by later workers, but the technique is difficult’.324 But active scientists no longer take any interest in these phenomena, for in view of their present understanding of chemical processes they are convinced that most of them must have been spurious, and that, if some were real, they were likely to have been due to trivial causes.325 This being so, our attitude towards these experiments is now similar to that of Azande towards Evans-Pritchard’s suggestion of trying out the effects of oracle-poison without an accompanying incantation. We shrug our shoulders and refuse to waste our time on such obviously fruitless enquiries. The process of selecting facts for our attention is indeed the same in science as among Azande; but I believe that science is often right in its application of it, while Azande are quite wrong when using it for protecting their superstitions.326

我的结论是，早期哲学家们所说的连贯性作为真理标准，其实只是一种稳定性标准。它同样可以稳定对宇宙的错误或正确看法。将真理归于任何特定的稳定替代方案是一种信托行为，不能用不置可否的术语来分析。我将在下一章回到这一点。目前，它只是为了明确一点，即不存在任何怀疑原则，通过运用它我们可以发现两个内隐信念体系中哪一个是正确的——除非我们承认反对我们认为不真实的一个体系的决定性证据，而承认反对另一个体系的决定性证据。再次，承认怀疑在这里被证明是一种信念行为，就像不承认怀疑一样。

I conclude that what earlier philosophers have alluded to by speaking of coherence as the criterion of truth is only a criterion of stability. It may equally stabilize an erroneous or a true view of the universe. The attribution of truth to any particular stable alternative is a fiduciary act which cannot be analysed in non-committal terms. I shall return to this point in my next chapter. At the moment it only serves to make it clear that there exists no principle of doubt the operation of which will discover for us which of two systems of implicit beliefs is true—except in the sense that we will admit decisive evidence against the one we do not believe to be true, and not against the other. Once more, the admission of doubt proves here to be as clearly an act of belief as does the non-admission of doubt.

 

 

  1. 普遍的怀疑
  2. UNIVERSAL DOUBT

从这个角度来看，我们能赋予普遍怀疑的原则什么意义呢？只要对任何单一信念的重新考量是在大量不容置疑的信念背景下进行的，那么构成这一背景的信念就不能同时被指认为值得怀疑。尽管我们信念的每一个要素都可以依次与所有其他要素进行对比，但所有要素同时接受这种对比操作却是不可想象的。但这并不是说，一个信念体系作为一个整体永远不能被怀疑。非欧几何的建立使欧几里得几何作为一个整体受到了质疑，并沦为一种可有可无的地位。可以想象，有一天，我们可能会倾向于重新考虑我们对整个数学的接受。我已经承认，宗教信仰的衰落导致了我们信念数量的真正减少。

What meaning can we attach in this light to a principle of universal doubt? So long as the reconsideration of any single belief is undertaken against an overwhelming background of unquestioned beliefs, the beliefs forming this background cannot simultaneously be alleged to be doubtful. Though every element of our belief can conceivably be confronted in its turn with all the rest, it is inconceivable that all should be subject simultaneously to this operation. But this is not to say that a system of beliefs can never be doubted as a whole. Euclidean geometry was called in question as a whole and reduced to an optional status by the establishment of non-Euclidean geometry. We might conceivably feel inclined to reconsider one day our acceptance of mathematics as a whole. I have admitted already that the decline of religious faith entailed a genuine reduction in the volume of our beliefs.

此类思辨或许可以表明一种普遍怀疑的意义，这种怀疑不自相矛盾。我们可以设想，放弃迄今为止公认的表达体系，以及在这些术语中构建的或我们在使用这些术语时所隐含的理论，这一过程将无限延伸。这种怀疑最终可能导致我们毫无补偿地放弃所有现存的表达方式。它会让我们忘记所有迄今为止使用的习语，并消解这些习语所传达的所有概念。我们通过处理可指称的概念而运作的、清晰的智识生活，将因此暂时搁置。

Such speculations may serve to indicate a meaning of universal doubt which is free from self-contradiction. We may imagine an indefinite extension of the process of abandoning hitherto accepted systems of articulation, together with the theories formulated in these terms or implied in our use of them. This kind of doubt might eventually lead to the relinquishing, without compensation, of all existing means of articulation. It would make us forget all hitherto used idioms and dissolve all concepts which these idioms conveyed. Our articulate intellectual life, which operates by the handling of denotable concepts, would thus be reduced to abeyance for the time being.

这种对普遍怀疑的解读无疑会遭到怀疑原则的拥护者的否定，但我看不出他们有任何理由反对它。这是唯一能够真正将我们的思想从不加批判地习得的先入之见中解放出来的怀疑方式。如果我们无法接受不加批判地持有信念的正当性，那么我们唯一合乎逻辑的选择就是彻底根除所有这些先入之见。即使实践证明这很困难，我们至少必须承认这是我们追求完美的理想。我们必须接受纯洁的、不带任何权威印记的心灵，作为智识完整性的典范。

Such an interpretation of universal doubt would certainly be repudiated by the adherents of the principle of doubt, but I can see no grounds on which they can dissent from it. This is the only manner of doubting which could truly liberate our minds from uncritically acquired preconceived beliefs. If we cannot accept the justification of holding beliefs uncritically, then our only logical alternative is to wipe out all such preconceived beliefs. And if this proves difficult in practice, we must at least recognize it as our ideal of perfection. We must accept the virgin mind, bearing the imprint of no authority, as the model of intellectual integrity.

即便略显繁琐，我们仍需明确，这种假设究竟意味着什么：心智能够在不受任何先入之见影响的情况下对所有问题进行判断。它并非指新生儿的心智，因为新生儿的心智还缺乏足够的智力来理解任何问题并找到解决方案。一颗童心必须被允许成熟，直到它达到其完全自然的智力水平，但在此之前，它必须保持未受任何教育的塑造。它不能被教授任何语言，因为语言的习得只能在不加批判的情况下进行，而练习使用一种特定的语言，就意味着接受该语言所预设的特定宇宙理论。

At the risk of labouring the obvious, it should be made quite clear what exactly is implied in this assumption of a mind which could shape its judgment on all questions without any preconceived opinions. It cannot mean the mind of a newborn child, since this yet lacks sufficient intelligence to grasp any problems and discover any solutions for them. A virgin mind must be allowed to mature until the age at which it reaches its full natural powers of intelligence, but would have to be kept unshaped until then by any kind of education. It must be taught no language, for speech can be acquired only a-critically, and the practice of speech in one particular language carries with it the. acceptance of the particular theory of the universe postulated by that language.

然而，心智完全未经引导的成熟会导致愚昧。动物生命中固有的情感和欲望冲动，当然会涌入它们所能利用的渠道。由于缺乏理性的概念框架来引导，它们的表现不会受到怀疑的约束，而是会变得狂乱而幼稚。我们已经在远低于人类水平的动物身上观察到了这种情况。我曾提到，在隔离环境中长大的小鸡第一次与其他小鸡相遇时，会感到困惑，行为混乱，反映出绝望的惊慌失措。 327

An entirely untutored maturing of the mind would, however, result in a state of imbecility. The emotional and appetitive impulses that are inherent in animal life will of course pour into such channels as are available to them. In the absence of a rational conceptual framework to guide them, their manifestation will not be sceptically restrained but frantic and inchoate. We have observed this already in animals well below the human level. I have mentioned how chickens brought up in isolation were perplexed and behaved confusedly, reflecting desperate consternation, when confronted for the first time with other chicks.327

然而，即使是如此愚昧的生物也无法阻止他们形成严重损害批判性思维的概念。我们已经看到，心智是如何积极参与我们对事物的感官知觉的（第 97 页）。有时这种看待事物的方式是错误的，这种本能的错误可能会严重阻碍哲学和科学的进步。物体“静止”和“运动”之间的对比在所有视觉感知中都是显而易见的。我们看到地球处于绝对静止状态，太阳、月亮和星星围绕着它旋转。地心说世界观在我们最原始的感知偏见中有着坚实的支持。事实上，即使在牛顿力学中，太阳系也被认为是固定的，宇宙的其余部分围绕它运动；而这种偏见最终只是在爱因斯坦的广义相对论中才被抛弃。今天，牛顿框架被谴责为不加批判的思想的产物；然而，它的错误可以追溯到视觉感知的最低水平，因此，即使是在狼群中长大的孩子或在孤独的孵化器中长大的孩子也会犯这种错误。

Yet even such dumb creatures would not be prevented from forming conceptions which seriously prejudiced a critical detachment. We have seen already how the mind actively participates in our sensory awareness of things (p. 97). Sometimes this way of seeing things is mistaken, and such instinctive error may gravely hamper the progress of philosophy and science. The contrast between a body ‘at rest’ and ‘in motion’ is compelling in all visual perception. We see the earth at absolute rest, with the sun, the moon and the stars swinging round it as their centre. The geocentric world view has a firm support in our most primitive perceptive prejudices. Indeed, even in Newtonian mechanics, the solar system was regarded in its turn as fixed, with the rest of the universe moving around it; and this prejudice was finally discarded only in Einstein’s general theory of relativity. Today the Newtonian framework is condemned as the product of uncritical thought; yet its error can be traced back to the lowest level of visual perception and would therefore be committed even by children raised among wolves or nursed to maturity in the solitude of an incubator.

因此，如果要将纯真心灵的理想推向逻辑极限，我们就必须面对这样一个事实：对事物的每一种感知，尤其是我们用眼睛感知到的，都包含着关于事物本质的推断，而这些推断可能是错误的。我们将一个物体看作黑色还是白色，并不取决于它进入我们眼睛的光量。黄昏时分看到的雪是白色的，阳光下看到的晚礼服是黑色的，尽管在这种情况下，晚礼服比雪反射到眼睛里的光更多。俗话说黑就是黑，白就是白——然而，我们将一个物体看作黑色还是白色，却取决于物体光线到达我们眼睛的整个环境。我们如何将这种环境体现在我们对所感知物体的颜色、大小、距离和形状的感知中，是由我们先天的生理倾向及其在经验影响下的发展决定的。如今，我成年后的感知与婴儿时期的感知截然不同，这种差异很大程度上源于会聚、适应以及其他更复杂的感觉过程，而这些过程的运作原理可能存在错误。但如果通过训练自己再次用无感知的眼睛看事物，让影像像电影一样不断滑过放映机的闸门，从而消除所有这些功能，我却无法确信自己能够获得大量确凿的原始信息。我只会遮挡视线，就像苦行僧睁着眼睛进入恍惚状态时那样。我也无法通过某种严格控制的过程恢复感知能力，只能努力运用眼睛及其所有复杂的功能，在头部姿势调整的帮助下，结合对声音、触觉和身体探索性动作的感知，努力重新看清事物——这个过程包含着一整套含义，而我必须暂时不加批判地投入其中。虽然我们可以通过让自己陷入麻木状态，将我们有意识的接受总量减少到不同程度，甚至为零，但任何特定的意识范围似乎都包含着一套相应广泛的、不加批判地接受的信念。

If, therefore, the ideal of a virgin mind is to be pursued to its logical limit, we have to face the fact that every perception of things, particularly by our eyes, involves implications about the nature of things which could be false. Whether we see an object as black or white is not determined by the amount of light it sends into our eye. Snow seen at dusk appears white, a dinner jacket seen in sunshine appears black, though the jacket in this case sends more light into the eyes than the snow. It is said that black is black and white is white—yet whether we see an object as black or white is decisively affected by the whole context in which the light from the object reaches our eyes. The way we embody this context in our perception of the colours, sizes, distances and shapes of the perceived object is determined by our innate physiological inclinations and their subsequent development under the influence of our experience. My perceptions today as an adult are different from those which I had as a new-born baby, and much of this difference is due to the functioning of convergence, adaptation and other more complex sensory processes, which are performed according to principles which may be wrong.
